title: The Ever-So-Elegant Tracksuit
description: In the current movie ''Laurel Canyon,'' Frances McDormand, as a rock 'n' roll mama, lopes around her living room wearing frayed jeans. Her son's girlfriend, played by Kate Beckinsale, ambles in her wake, dressed in the slouchy components of a tracksuit: tank top, hooded sweatshirt and floppy trousers slung low on the hips. She wears the tracksuit like a uniform, shopping, jogging and even making love in it.

title: Henry Racamier Dies at 90; Revitalized Louis Vuitton
description: Henry Racamier, who married a descendant of Louis Vuitton and built a family-owned leather goods company into one of the world's largest luxury goods groups, died on Saturday while traveling in Sardinia. He was 90.

title: Conflicting Reports on North Korea Missile Test Add to Tensions

title: National Briefing | West: California: No Appeal Of Drilling Halt
description: The Interior Department announced that it would not appeal federal court decisions that halted oil and natural gas exploration off the Central California coast, a decision celebrated by environmental groups that had opposed new drilling. The decision means that future drilling will have to be approved by the state's Coastal Commission.

title: Jordan Arrests Iraqis in Plot to Poison U.S. Troops' Water
description: AMMAN, Jordan, April 1  The Jordanian authorities have arrested a handful of Iraqi agents in connection with a botched plot to poison the water supply that serves American troops in the eastern desert near the border with Iraq, officials here said today.

title: SK Group Restates Earnings And Korean Stocks Tumble
description: Fresh problems emerged today at the scandal-plagued trading arm of the SK Group, South Korea's third-largest conglomerate, rocking the Korean financial community and sending other stocks tumbling.

title: No Rest for Dunham; Little Choice for Sather
description: Mike Dunham was in goal for the Rangers against the Atlanta Thrashers last night at Madison Square Garden. He was also scheduled to be in goal against the Islanders tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SRI LANKA: REBEL BOAT SUNK IN BATTLE A navy ship carrying 1,700 troops sank a suspected rebel boat that had fired on it off the east coast of the country, military officials said. Four sailors were wounded, one of them seriously, in the battle, the latest in a series of similar attacks that are testing the fragile cease-fire between the government and the rebels of the Liberation Tamil Tigers of Eelam. It was not known how many were aboard the sunken boat. (Reuters)

title: Senior Engineer Faulted NASA for Not Seeking Satellite Help

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONGO, CATHERINE
description: LONGO-Catherine, 88 years old of Holmdel, NJ, died on Sunday, March 30, 2003 in Bayshore Health Care Center, Holmdel. She was a homemaker. She was born in Bristol, PA, where she lived until the age of 13. She then moved to Brooklyn and upon leaving Brooklyn she lived in Minnisink Village, Matawan for 21 years before moving to Holmdel five years ago. She was a member of the St. Clement's Senior Citizens group of Matawan and the Minnisink Social Club. Surviving are two daughters and sonsin-law, Jacqueline & John Snowber of Queens, NY, and Nina & Joseph Oldham of Matawan, New Jersey, two grandsons and a granddaughter-in-law, Scott and Eileen Oldham, and Steven Oldham, and a great-granddaughter, Sophie Catherine Oldham. She was preceded in death by her husband, Anthony Longo in 1987. Visitation will be held 2-4 and 7-9, Wednesday, April 2 at the Waitt-Nelms Funeral Home, 501 Highway 79, Morganville, NJ. Services will be held at St. Clements Church, Matawan, Thursday, April 3, 2003 at 11:00 AM. Interment will follow in the St. Joseph's Mausoleum, Keyport.

title: LABRANCHE SAYS EARNINGS TO FALL BELOW EXPECTATIONS
description: LaBranche & Company, a leading specialist firm on the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that it expected its first-quarter profit to fall short of Wall Street's expectations. It said it would report a profit of 6 cents to 8 cents a share, down from 43 cents a year ago and below the 25 cents expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. LaBranche, which makes more than 80 percent of its profits trading stocks for its own account, said revenue from principal trading fell to about $52 million from $89 million a year earlier.

Beloved wife of the late Daniel McMahon. She is survived by her daughter Marita, son and daughterin-law Daniel and Mary and two grandchildren Evelina and Edward. Also survived by loving members of the Rowland and Jordan families. Visitation Tuesday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM at McMahon, Lyon and Hartnett Funeral Home, Inc, 491 Mamaroneck Ave, White Plains, N.Y. Bush, and went on to win billions of dollars from Texaco in a dramatic legal battle, died on Friday in Houston. He was 81.

title: The Wounded Find Respite At U.S. Unit In Germany
description: The wounded arrive here daily on C-141 transport planes: 46 on Friday, 39 on Saturday, 38 on Sunday, 25 today. The number is one barometer of the combat in Iraq, and over the last week it has settled into a busy but manageable rhythm.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: $780,000 Disappears From Courier
description: An armored car containing $780,000 in cash disappeared Sunday night, two guards from the armored-car company told the police. The guards, from Iron Eagle Armored Courier, said they left the engine of the armored car running when they stopped about 8 p.m. at the 7-Eleven at 254-02 Hillside Avenue in Bellerose, Queens. When they came out a few minutes later, the police said yesterday, the truck was gone. It was found a short time later at 256th Street and 83rd Avenue, less than two blocks from the 7-Eleven, the police said. The cash is still missing. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOMZE, SHIRLEY
description: BOMZE-Shirley, 77. Beloved wife of Herman, devoted mother of Eric and Beth (Bracha Nechama), died suddenly on March 30. Funeral at Plaza, Amsterdam Avenue and 91st St, at 1 PM on April 1. Shiva will be observed.

title: A Dinner Becomes A Disaster, In Triplicate
description: Yasmina Reza may have the tidiest mind of any popular playwright working today. It's not that Ms. Reza, the author of that internationally beloved trifle called ''Art,'' doesn't acknowledge that life can be fuzzy, mysterious and downright messy. Her ''Life x 3,'' which opened last night in a damagingly miscast production at the Circle in the Square Theater, might even be called a comedy of chaos.

title: Carrier in the Gulf Gets More Striking Power, and Maybe the Hint of a Return Home
description: With the ground war intensifying, the Navy increased its airstrike capacity today with the arrival aboard this carrier of four additional F/A-18 Super Hornet jets.

title: Knight Bounds Into Town With Big Love for N.I.T.
description: Whether Bob Knight wished he were really at the Final Four in New Orleans -- or whether he suddenly got a hankering for a chilly 35-degree spring day in New York -- was unclear. Either way, Knight, college basketball's most famous face, strolled into a Midtown hotel yesterday afternoon, declaring his affection for a postseason basketball tournament that gets no love anymore.

title: Power Games
description: Federal regulators have now provided decisive evidence of the cynical behavior of major energy companies in the power crisis that crippled California's economy in 2000 and 2001. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, in an exhaustive study released last week, found that Enron and more than 30 other major companies in the energy markets manipulated not only wholesale electricity prices but also the price of natural gas, a basic fuel for generators. This manipulation was enough to bankrupt a major utility and cost the state billions in excess electricity charges.

title: Red-Blue Terror Alert
description: As recriminations fly over Operation Predicted Cakewalk, some commentators look back wistfully to the early post-Sept. 11 era, when -- or so they imagine -- the nation stood united against the terrorist threat. On my beat, that era was brief indeed: less than 48 hours after the atrocity, Congressional Republicans tried to exploit the event to pass a cut in the capital gains tax. But on national security issues, there was at first some real bipartisanship.

title: 600 victims of 1995 Srebrenica massacre are finally buried
description: Six hundred victims of the Srebrenica massacre in 1995 were buried on Monday while, in another reminder of that conflict, the UN war crimes tribunal sentenced two former Bosnian-Croat commanders to up to 20 years in jail for atrocities against Muslims in the city of Mostar.

title: Powell Heads For Turkey And Europe To Mend Ties
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, seeking to ease tensions with Turkey and the European alliance, today scheduled a quick visit this week to Ankara and Brussels to confer on the war and possible cooperative steps on Iraq's postwar reconstruction.

description: PUBLIC relations professionals, confronted by the war's dominance in the news, are overhauling their strategies to spread their clients' messages.

title: 15 Are Accused of Involvement In a Multinational Drug Ring
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn said yesterday that they had broken up a multinational ring that laundered tens of millions of dollars in proceeds from the sale of cocaine and ecstasy. Fifteen men were arrested yesterday in New York, Miami, Houston and Israel, prosecutors said.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Police Advised To Make Changes
description: The federal Justice Department has recommended that the Portland Police Department amend 17 of its policies, including how it used force and investigated police misconduct, after an initial review. City officials asked for the review in January 2002 in the wake of several lawsuits accusing officers of using excessive force. Chief Michael Chitwood said the recommendations would serve as a guide for change. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: GENERAL MOTORS EXTENDS NO-INTEREST LOANS TO 5 YEARS
description: General Motors said yesterday that it would extend no-interest loans to five years on most of its models in April because of a slower-than-expected March, going beyond what it did to aid sales after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. G.M. said it would offer the loans on all 2003 Buick, Cadillac, Chevrolet, GMC, Oldsmobile, Pontiac, Saab and Saturn cars and trucks, excluding only two Hummer sport utility models. After 9/11, it offered no-interest loans for five years on certain 2001 car models and for three years on all other 2001 and 2002 car and truck models. G.M. scaled back no-interest loans on March 1.

title: 2 U.S. Columns Are Advancing on Baghdad Defenses
description: American forces leading the drive north to Baghdad battled their way today into a town 50 miles south of the capital, capturing Iraqi troops and regaining some momentum in a war that has proved more complex than expected.

title: Versailles Resounds Again to Hoofbeats
description: Louis XIV loved the equestrian arts. He ordered two sets of stables built near the Palace of Versailles that were large enough to house 600 horses. He enjoyed watching the horse ballet known as dressage and would participate enthusiastically in ''carrousels,'' as the royal tournaments of the era were called. Elsewhere in France, horses were used for agriculture, transportation and warfare; in Versailles, their role was entertainment.

description: COLLAND-Joe R., 82. On March 28, 2003, in San Francisco, CA. Survived by his son, Obo Help, his son's partner, Jane Logan, both of San Francisco, his step daughter, Ashera Cinnamon, of Knoxville, TN, and brother, Rolf Cohen, of Amsterdam, Holland. Born Josef Cohen in Amsterdam, came to the U.S. in 1939, served in the U.S. Army during World War II, and spent most of his working life on Wall Street. A small family memorial was held. We dearly miss him.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: Egypt: Food Company Acquired
description: The food and beverage company Kraft Foods Inc. said that it had reached a preliminary agreement to acquire a leading Egyptian biscuits and snack producer, the Family Nutrition Company S.A.E. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cuny Applicants Improve
description: High school students applying to the City University of New York's honors college this year were stronger academically than last year's applicants, Matthew Goldstein, CUNY's chancellor, told trustees yesterday. The honors program provides free tuition, laptop computers and special academic and cultural opportunities for students at seven CUNY campuses. The number of applicants -- 2,537 -- was about the same as last year, but they had better grades and test scores, said Mr. Goldstein, above. CUNY says it expects about 300 students to accept its offer to join the program. Dr. Goldstein said CUNY has raised more than $12 million in private funds. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Nations Fail to Agree on Farm Subsidies
description: Negotiators failed today to meet their deadline for figuring out how wealthy nations can reduce their huge agriculture subsidies, the issue at the heart of a current round of negotiations at the World Trade Organization.

title: Challenge for Bonds Is to Have Pitchers Challenge Him This Year
description: Four steps. That is how many short steps Barry Bonds had moved from the on-deck circle today when the fans at Qualcomm Stadium bathed him in boos, a vocal bashing that was really a grudging sign of respect for the most feared hitter in baseball. No one delayed sipping beverages or eating snacks for a second to boo J. T. Snow.

title: Self-Protection or Delusion? The Many Varieties of Paranoia
description: ''I am being harassed by the guy next door and I want him to stop,'' the woman in my office said with firm conviction. The man would leer at her in the elevator just to make her squirm, she said.

description: Opponents of President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe apparently sealed their political control over Harare in weekend parliamentary elections, but the triumph was marred today by the arrest of an opposition leader.

description: Newly recovered data from a recorder on the shuttle Columbia raise doubts that the much-discussed protective tiles were the site of the flaw that led to its destruction, the chairman of the panel investigating the accident said today.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Jailer Is Found Guilty
description: A former officer at a Boston jail has been found guilty of obstruction of justice, perjury and civil rights violations stemming from assaults on inmates. The former officer, Brian Bailey, was one of seven employees at the city's Nashua Street Jail indicted in the beatings of five detainees from June 1998 to October 1999 and covering up the attacks. Two other defendants were acquitted. Another four defendants pleaded guilty. The Suffolk County Sheriff's office, which operates the jail, has been accused of corruption and mismanagement. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Failing to Heed Warning, 7 Iraqi Women and Children Die
description: American soldiers killed seven women and children Monday afternoon after a van they were riding in failed to stop when troops from the Second Brigade of the Third Infantry Division waved them down and fired warning shots, the Army announced Monday night.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Cuts Jobs
description: A leading German bank, the Commerzbank Group, said it would cut another 3,100 jobs to cut costs. The job cuts will come on top of 4,300 job reductions that are to be completed next year and form part of the group's plan to save expenses of 688 million euros ($750 million) through 2004. About two-thirds of the cost savings are to be achieved this year, which should reduce Commerzbank's total costs to less than 5 billion euros ($5.45 billion), down from 5.2 billion euros last year. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Telecom Investment
description: Telefnica Mviles, the wireless arm of Spain's Grupo Telefnica, said that it planned to invest $600 million in its Mexican subsidiary this year to roll out an advanced network using the GSM wireless standard. The company said it would offer the service by the end of June in Mexico City, Guadalajara, Monterrey and Tijuana. At a news conference in Madrid, Antonio Viana, executive president of Telefnica Mviles, said that the company was focusing on high-growth markets such as Mexico, Brazil and Spain. ''We expect positive cash flow in Mexico during 2006,'' he said. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Irvington: Woman's Extradition Sought
description: Investigators were working with Canadian law enforcement officials yesterday to extradite Sultana Haque, who is accused of killing her two stepchildren last week. Ms. Haque, 30, was arrested in Toronto on Sunday night and is being held on murder charges, said Michael Chase, the acting chief of the Irvington Police Department. She is awaiting extradition to New Jersey, where she will be formally charged with murder and possession of a deadly weapon, said Charlotte Smith, spokeswoman for the Essex County prosecutor's office. The Irvington police said that Ms. Haque slashed the throats of her stepchildren, Alstan, 8, and Aisha, 5, on Saturday while her husband, the children's father, was at work.

title: Pentagon and State Department In Tug-of-War Over Aid Disbursal
description: People in southern Iraq waited today for the assistance promised by the Bush administration while debate simmered over the Pentagon's plans to oversee the distribution of the aid, a task that has traditionally been controlled by civilians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, RABBI SIDNEY
description: GREENBERG-Rabbi Sidney. Died March 31, 2003, age 85. Gentle dedicated servant of God who embraced all that was Jewish and life-affirming. Founding Rabbi of Temple Sinai, Philadelphia, where he served for 53 years. ''A Rabbi's Rabbi'' and outstanding preacher. His legacy of sermonic gems fills volumes; his prayerbooks serve congregations throughout the world. Shared his life with beloved partner, Hilda, for 60 years. Devoted father of Shira Ruskay, z''l, Reena Keren & Adena Greenberg. Cherished father-in-law of John Ruskay & Shlomi Liran. Adored by nine grandchildren and two great-granddaughters, and countless family, friends, congregants. His wisdom and love touched all who knew him. Funeral April 1, noon, Ansche Chesed, 100th St. and West End Ave. Contributions to Akim, c/o Sidney and Hilda Greenberg Foundation, Jewish Federation of Greater Phila., 2100 Arch St., Phila., PA 19103.

description: William Klein, the renowned photographer, filmmaker and graphic artist, was wondering what sort of reception he might find when he arrives in New York next week for simultaneous exhibitions of his work at Herms, the Howard Greenberg Gallery and the French Institute.

title: In Reversal, Masters Invites Older Past Winners to Return
description: The Masters, which a year ago shut the door on Arnold Palmer and other older past champions, confirmed yesterday that it was reversing its policy. After conferring with Palmer and Jack Nicklaus, who are members of the host Augusta National Golf Club, the tournament and the club's chairman, William Johnson, said that the champions of old would remain welcome with a proviso.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Trade Rules Eased
description: In a bid to attract foreign investment and increase exports, India announced a new trade policy that eases restraints and offers tax breaks for companies developing and maintaining infrastructure like roads and power. The policy, which will take effect this month, will lift export curbs on items like silk and remove import restrictions on items like spices. The government proposed incentives for financial institutions and banks to offer credit to infrastructure companies at international rates, the trade minister, Arun Jaitley, said. A protracted war in Iraq could hurt India's $2.7 billion trade surplus with the countries in that region, Mr. Jaitley said. title: FRONTIER TO BUY RIVAL OIL REFINER FOR $438 MILLION

Frontier will also assume about $26 million in Holly's long-term debt, Frontier's chief executive, James R. Gibbs, said during a conference call with analysts. The acquisition would increase Frontier's production by about two-thirds, adding three refineries to the two the company now operates. Mr. Gibbs will remain as chief executive of Frontier, and Holly's chief executive, Lamar Norsworthy, will become Frontier's chairman. The board will be equally divided between Frontier and Holly, and shareholders of Frontier will own about 60 percent of the combined company.

title: In New Job, Former Schools Chancellor Tackles Teacher Training
description: Harold O. Levy, the New York City schools chancellor until last August, has gone to work for Kaplan Inc., the test-preparation company, where he will oversee the creation of a for-profit school of education that will offer bachelor's and master's degrees to teachers in training.

title: Grant Will Support Development Of Topical H.I.V. Medications
description: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation announced yesterday that it would give $60 million to the International Partnership for Microbicides, a nonprofit organization dedicated to speeding the development and distribution of topical means of preventing H.I.V. transmission like foams or gels.

title: Italy Arrests Four Men Suspected of Links to Al Qaeda
description: ROME, April 1  The Italian police have arrested four men in the northern cities of Milan and Parma on suspicion of having links to international terrorism and possession of false documents, a police spokeswoman said today.

title: A 1977 Golda Meir Gets Into Shape
description: Tovah Feldshuh gives such a fiercely committed performance as Golda Meir in the one-woman show now at the Manhattan Ensemble Theater that she does more than just resurrect Meir. She embodies an entire country, its hopes and paranoia and anger.

title: After 11 Days of War, Anticipation and Reflection
description: As an intelligence analyst and an enlisted soldier, Sgt. Jennifer M. Raichle is at the bottom of the intelligence apparatus that, commanders now acknowledge, miscalculated the will of Iraqi forces to resist American troops here.

title: Historian Named as Provost As Columbia Shapes Future
description: Lee C. Bollinger, the president of Columbia University, yesterday named a Columbia historian, Alan Brinkley, the next provost, a post that will give Mr. Brinkley great influence in shaping the school's future.

title: Extra Pampering for Users of Car Services
description: The economic downturn may have produced an era of no frills, but for the business traveler taking a limousine or car service these days, times have never been better.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I've got 30 cannons, and I'm shooting them all. I never shot so much in my life. I need some more bullets.''

title: Survey Finds Growing Worry About Outlook for Japan's Economy
description: Tokyo, April 1 -- Japanese business leaders were more pessimistic about their prospects for the first time in five quarters as slumping stock prices and jitters about the war in Iraq dampen confidence, a key central bank survey showed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLIN, DAVID SANDERS
description: BERLIN-David Sanders, 80. Died March 12 on Cape Cod. He is survived by his wife Gloria, six children and four grandchildren. Mr. Berlin was a graduate of NYU and a respected educator in the New York City school system for forty years. He retired in 1989. He is missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULZBERGER, GRETA SPEIER
description: SULZBERGER-Greta Speier. Formerly of Hof, Germany, New York City and Teaneck, NJ. March 24, 2003. Devoted wife of the late Otto Sulzberger, beloved mother of Jean Gumpert (David) and Edward Sulzberger (Linda Ercole - Musso), adored grandmother of Jason and Laura Gumpert.

title: Pentagon Plans to Extend Its Use Of Commercial Planes for Troops
description: As it prepares to send 100,000 additional troops to the Persian Gulf, the Pentagon plans to extend the mobilization of a fleet of commercial aircraft that has been used to transport military personnel and equipment, airline industry officials said yesterday.

title: A New Doctrine's Test
description: From the day that he took office as defense secretary, Donald H. Rumsfeld has sought to change the nature of American defense. The military Mr. Rumsfeld wants to build is more mobile, can deliver precision weapons at vast distances and takes full advantage of sophisticated reconnaissance systems.

title: After Fear Or Agony, Faith And Love
description: Zwan, the new band led by Billy Corgan of the Smashing Pumpkins, put everything it had into its opening song on Friday night at the Hammerstein Ballroom: ''Jesus, I,'' which is about a faith that is both humbling and exalting. The song, from the band's debut album, ''Mary Star of the Sea,'' was folky, psychedelic, anthemic, ecstatic and loud, laying out all Zwan's ambitions and living up to them.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL GAINS. Crude oil rose on concern that a longer-than-expected war in Iraq would delay the return of that country's exports to the market. In New York, crude oil for May delivery rose 88 cents, or 2.9 percent, to $31.04 a barrel.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

description: To the Editor:

title: Survey Predicts More Planting Of Altered Crops
description: Farmers expect to expand the planting of genetically modified crops in the United States this year, according to the results of a survey of farmers' intentions released yesterday by the Agriculture Department.

title: Budget Shenanigans
description: To the Editor:

title: Briefly Noted
description: VISITS TO IRAQI PRISONERS The International Committee of the Red Cross said it had started visiting Iraqi prisoners of war held by American-led forces at a camp near the southern town of Umm Qasr. The Middle East chief for the Red Cross, Balthasar Staehelin, said at a news conference that a 15-member team, including a doctor and six interpreters, registered about 100 prisoners after talking with the camp commander for several hours and touring the facilities. In keeping with Red Cross practice, Ms. Staehelin would not comment on the treatment of prisoners or the conditions of detention at the camp, which houses about 3,000 prisoners of war. Under the 1949 Geneva Conventions, which both sides have signed, the Red Cross must be allowed to visit prisoners of war. (Reuters)

title: Two Correspondents, One Predictable Outcome
description: There are strains of Sophoclean tragedy in Peter Arnett's latest fall from grace. Mr. Arnett, the 68-year-old war correspondent, has braved countless perils since the Vietnam War, but he was his own greatest danger.

title: NORDSTROM SAYS PROFIT TO BE LESS THAN FORECAST
description: Nordstrom Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings would be less than forecast because sales had slowed since the war in Iraq began. It did not provide a specific estimate for the quarter, which ends April 30. The company's original projection was for net income of 23 cents to 27 cents a share. The retailer had a net loss of $24.6 million, or 18 cents, in the first quarter last year. Sales at stores open at least a year have fallen so far this quarter. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected Nordstrom to earn 25 cents a share. The retailer plans to report first-quarter earnings in May.

title: True Moral Education
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Look for a 10-Story Oddity
description: Evoking both loom and kiln, the Museum of Arts and Design plans to reclad 2 Columbus Circle -- an abandoned work of romantic modernism that has irritated and amused New Yorkers for 39 years -- in a scrim of bright terra cotta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFFY, ALICE GRATTAN
description: DUFFY-Alice Grattan. Of Southold, L.I. (formerly of Forest Hills, N.Y.) on March 30, 2003. Retired Teacher at Russell Sage Junior High School, Forest Hills. Beloved wife of the late Eugene H. Duffy. Loving mother of Alice Duffy Grant, Eugene O. Duffy, Rosalie Duffy Crabbe and James H. Duffy. Cherished grandmother of eight. The family will receive friends on Thursday from 2 until 9 P.M. at the family residence at 2050 Youngs Avenue in Southold. The Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial will be offered on Friday morning at 11:00 A.M. at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Main Road, Southold. Interment St. Patrick's R.C. Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the College of New Rochelle or the Ursuline Marian Residence, New Rochelle, NY 10801. DeFriest - Grattan Funeral Homes, Directors

title: Angry Words Jar Funeral Of 3-Year-Old Murder Victim
description: Krystal Singleton stood over the ivory-colored coffin of her 3-year-old brother, Amir Beeks, today and gave plaintive voice to the grief that has seared this suburb for the past four days.

title: 30 Hours in the Trenches As an Air System Copes
description: THERE are at least a few places I would rather be at 6 a.m. than the Newark airport, but at least I wasn't alone. The departure lounge for my Continental flight to Chicago last Wednesday morning was full of business travelers, many already talking into cellphones -- the postdawn party lines of the damned -- or tapping on laptops. The electronic message board behind the check-in desk blinked a grimly disconsolate admonition, over and over and over: ''WORK HARD . . . FLY RIGHT.''

title: The Home Front
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: $163 Million Mine Judgment
description: Trinity Industries, the largest manufacturer of rail cars in the United States, has been ordered to pay $163.8 million to the family of a mechanic who was killed while working at a Trinity gravel mine near Waco. The mechanic, Brad Johnson, 34, was trying to fix the brakes on an earthmover at the mine when a 500-pound tire exploded. He received head and chest injuries and died 12 days later. A jury in Beaumont found that the company had failed to properly train workers at the mine.

title: Jabbing and Feinting Through the Grand Life of Muhammad Ali
description: Craig Harris, Marlies Yearby and Aaron Davis Hall took three years to create ''Brown Butterfly,'' but the monumental production, performed on Saturday night at the hall at City College, is well worth the wait. Music, dance and video imagery combine inseparably to pay tribute to Muhammad Ali and his place in American social history.

title: Suit Is Settled In Inmate Death, Lawyers Say
description: Lawyers for Nassau County agreed today to pay $7.75 million to relatives of an inmate who was beaten to death by guards in the county jail, lawyers for the inmate's family said, settling a federal civil rights lawsuit.

title: As SARS rages, Hong Kong orders a quarantine
description: HONG KONG:  The police locked more than 200 residents into their housing block Monday in Hong Kong as the government imposed drastic measures to combat the fast-spreading outbreak of a deadly atypical pneumonia.

title: Arnett Is Dismissed by NBC After Remarks on Iraqi TV
description: Peter Arnett, the longtime foreign correspondent who on Sunday criticized the allied war plan on Iraqi television, was dropped by NBC News yesterday in a move that was played out vividly on live television.

title: 3 Airlines Approved For Sharing Agreement
description: The Transportation Department gave its approval yesterday to a marketing partnership among Continental Airlines, Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines after the carriers proposed a compromise intended to make the arrangement more competitive.

title: Belgium Rethinks Its Prosecutorial Zeal
description: ''The News from Absurdistan'' was the headline on a commentary here the other day, written by Luc Van der Kelen, the chief editor of the Flemish newspaper Het Laatste Nieuws.

title: Battle at Karbala, Key City South of Capital
description: KUWAIT, April 1 - American forces attacked a Republican Guard division tonight at Karbala, on the Euphrates River approach to Baghdad, in what officials said was the beginning of a drive to push through the outer defenses of the Iraqi capital, 50 miles to the north.

title: Jazz Without Borders Arrives at Lincoln Center
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center will dedicate its next season to exploring jazz as it is played around the world.

title: Success Stories Abound in Efforts to Prevent and Control Cancer
description: Anyone who has recently lost a loved one to cancer may be inclined to think that little progress has been made in conquering this complex disease. That would be very wrong.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Detective Suspended After Escape
description: A detective was suspended from duty early yesterday after a prisoner escaped from the 32nd Precinct station house on West 135th Street in Central Harlem, the police said. They said the 23-year-old suspect, arrested on drug charges, escaped while he was being questioned. The details of the escape, which occurred about 7 p.m. on Sunday, were not released, and it was unclear whether the suspect, whose name was not released, was handcuffed at the time. About eight hours after the escape, the detective, John McAndrews, was suspended. At least five other prisoners have escaped from police custody so far this year. Nearly three dozen prisoners escaped from the police last year. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Front Row; 26 Norells for Sample Sizes
description: The first outfit Norman Norell ever made was for his mother. In 1920, the two were about to take a train trip from Indianapolis to California, and for the excursion Norell, a 20-year-old aspiring designer, concocted a floor-length dress in red chiffon, a straw hat with flowing black ribbons and a lace-trimmed parasol.

title: Moynihan's Apt Words
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR FALLS. The dollar declined against the euro on concern that a prolonged war in Iraq will slow an already sputtering United States economy. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0896, up from $1.0778 on Friday.

title: National Briefing | New England: New Hampshire: Group Fights Bishops
description: A group of lay Catholics in the Diocese of Manchester has formed an organization to campaign for the resignation of Bishop John B. McCormack and Auxiliary Bishop Francis Christian for their handling of a sexual abuse scandal involving clergymen. The group, New Hampshire Catholics for Moral Leadership, was formed after more than 9,000 pages of diocesan personnel documents about the abuse of children were released under an agreement with the state attorney general that granted the diocese criminal immunity for admitting it failed to protect children adequately. The diocese said the bishops would continue to serve. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Manufacturing On Downswing In Midwest
description: Manufacturing in the Chicago area unexpectedly contracted in March for the first time in five months as the war with Iraq shook consumer confidence and slowed spending, a survey of purchasing executives showed yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTEIN, HILDA KIR SCHBAUM
description: GERSTEIN - Hilda Kir schbaum. On March 31, 2003. Former President and ViceChairman of Petrie Stores Corporation. Beloved wife of the late Max Gerstein. Devoted mother of Nancy Novogrod and her husband John. Cherished grandmother of James and Caroline. Family will receive friends Tuesday, 6-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Private interment to take place on Wednesday at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery. Family will also receive friends at the Novogrod residence, Wednesday, 2:30 PM-8 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the New York Botanical Garden or Breast Cancer Research Foundation.

title: Market Place; A sales deal with Bertelsmann restores AOL to the unwanted attention of regulators.
description: RICHARD D. PARSONS, AOL Time Warner's chief executive, must wonder when it will be safe to sound upbeat instead of contrite.

title: Beijing and Caspian Oil Fields
description: China's bid to join in the development of rich oil and gas fields in Kazakhstan stands a good chance of being thwarted by the existing partners in the project, industry executives and analysts here said.

title: Twenty Journalists Slain in 2002, Fewest in 17 Years, Group Says
description: The number of journalists killed last year dropped to its lowest level in 17 years, while the number in prison climbed for the second year in the row, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists, an international monitoring organization.

title: Why Epidemics Still Surprise Us
description: At Novena Square in downtown Singapore normally bustling with shoppers and diners at sparkling-clean restaurants -- the sidewalks are quiet. Since mid-March, people have been avoiding this area because it's close to a hospital that has been designated to deal with the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS. So far, about 90 of the more than 1,500 cases of the illness and four of the 58 deaths it has caused have been in Singapore, a place known for its antiseptic cleanliness and its usual immunity to the contagious diseases that plague its neighbors. It is believed that the illness was brought here by three women returning from a trip to Hong Kong.

title: Brazil Chief's Hometown Is Poor as Ever
description: Half a century ago, Antnio Ferreira de Melo and his older cousin Luiz were playmates here in the poor and arid interior of Pernambuco state. They would chop down tree branches and pretend they were riding horses or use their slingshots to hunt birds and lizards for their families to eat.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Man Sentenced In Kidnapping
description: A man convicted of kidnapping a gambler for reneging on a usurious debt has been sentenced to more than nine years in prison. In February 2002, the kidnapper, Chang Ping Lin, lent a gambler $18,000 with a daily interest rate of $1,800, prosecutors said. The gambler repaid the principal but not the interest. The following month, Mr. Lin and his girlfriend, Ying Li, arrived at the gambler's home in Queens, telling him he could win the rest of the money gambling in Atlantic City. Instead, they drove him to a house in Atlantic City, where Mr. Lin and another man, Kui Li, who is believed to be Ms. Li's brother, threatened to kill him, prosecutors said. Mr. Lin was sentenced on Friday. Ms. Li, who is in custody, and Mr. Li, a fugitive, have been indicted on charges of kidnapping and extortion. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Home Repairs Accomplish Only So Much
description: ALL spruced up for the Mets' opener, Shea Stadium glowed with the city's $19.1 million in new paint, new logos and new ambience. But the weather did not cooperate.

title: On the Tactics of War, and the Searing Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Powell Hastily Heads for Meetings With European Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  As Secretary of State Colin L. Powell headed to Europe today for consultations with America's erstwhile allies, he left behind a simmering debate over the adequacy of coalition war plans and he faced meetings with bitter European leaders who indicated they may not greet him with open arms.

title: Rumsfeld's Design for War Criticized on the Battlefield
description: Long-simmering tensions between Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and Army commanders have erupted in a series of complaints from officers on the Iraqi battlefield that the Pentagon has not sent enough troops to wage the war as they want to fight it.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHAIKIN, SOL CHICK
description: CHAIKIN-Sol Chick. April 1, 1991. Now and forever in our hearts and minds. We lovingly remember your intellect, humor, humility and strength. We follow the precepts you established in life. Eric, Stacey, Lee and Shan

title: U.S. Rebukes Pakistanis For Lab's Aid To Pyongyang
description: The Bush administration has imposed sanctions against a major Pakistani nuclear laboratory -- the first such action since Pakistan became an ally in the battle against terrorism -- for its role in helping North Korea obtain crucial equipment and designs to produce nuclear weapons, administration officials said today.

title: Letters
description: `Unnatural' Path to Health

title: Doing Business With an Environmental Bent
description: THE word ''environmentalist'' does not roll easily out of Roger Ullman's mouth. He enunciates each syllable. It is a pleasant if unfamiliar way to define himself. When he says it, even for the second or third time, he sounds a little like a young contestant in a spelling bee.

title: Transcript of Arguments in Gratz v. Bollinger
description: Following is a transcript of the arguments before the Supreme Court in Gratz v. Bollinger, as recorded by the Alderson Reporting Company . Kirk O. Kolbo argued on behalf of the plaintiffs; Theodore B. Olson, the United States Solicitor General, argued in support of them; and John Payton the university. The Times supplied the identities of the justices.

title: Cause of Tank Plunge Under Investigation
description: The fog of war, or of fatigue? Or of a sandstorm?

title: HealthSouth Fires Chief Executive And Audit Firm
description: The HealthSouth Corporation's board has fired Richard M. Scrushy, the company's chairman and chief executive, and its auditor, Ernst & Young, less than two weeks after regulators charged Mr. Scrushy and HealthSouth with sweeping accounting fraud.

title: Families Recall 4 Who Died in Bombing
description: In his last letter home from the war zone, Cpl. Michael E. Curtin said he felt sorry for some of the soldiers in his platoon. They did not receive as many letters and care packages as he did, so he gave his family several names and asked that they write to them. It was, his family said, a telling gesture by a man known for his thoughtfulness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHON, CONNIE C. (NEE GIANNONE)
description: MAHON-Connie C. (nee Giannone) on March 29, 2003. Devoted wife of the late Joseph P. Beloved mother of Linda Pasternack, Gary, Patrick and Laura Marzella. Loving sister of Eugene Giannone and Anna McHenry. Cherished grandmother of seven. Funeral Wednesday, 9:30 AM from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd., Bklyn. Mass St. Thomas Aquinas R.C. Church, 10:30 AM. Entombment Pine Lawn Mem. Park. Visiting hours Tuesday 2-5 & 7-9 PM.

title: Warning of Doom, Edgy Iraqi Leaders Put On Brave Front
description: With American advance units pushing ever closer to Baghdad and Saddam Hussein's presidential compound once again under remorseless aerial attack with what seemed like American bunker-busting bombs, the Iraqi leadership put on a show of redoubled defiance today and promised American troops nothing but ''death in the desert.''

title: 'Vibes Made Man Kill... and Confess, Police Say
description: For Larme Price, the man who the police say has confessed to four unprovoked killings in Brooklyn and Queens, life was increasingly controlled by vibes.

title: Sports of The Times; Jeter Was Ready, but Not for Injury
description: Derek Jeter began the night sitting at his stall in the Yankee clubhouse, wondering what the fuss over some silly marketing ploy was about. The Toronto Blue Jays had asked their fans to come out and boo the Yankees? They had contrived a cartoon with bird droppings on the famous Yankee headwear with the interlocking NY?

title: Extradition Sought for Woman Accused in Deaths of 2 Children
description: IRVINGTON, N.J., March 31  Investigators today were working with Canadian law enforcement officials to extradite a woman accused of killing her two stepchildren here last week.

title: Cablevision and YES Reach an Agreement
description: A deal that was completed minutes before the Yankees' opener last night in Toronto brought the YES Network into Cablevision households after a season in which the Yankees' cable network could be seen by none of the cable operator's customers in New York City, Westchester County, Long Island, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Justices Hear Debate on Extending a Statute of Limitations
description: Until the mid-1990's, sex crimes were like most other criminal offenses under California law and could not be prosecuted after three years had elapsed.

title: Lindros Takes Control, Then Loses It in the End
description: With the Rangers' season on the thin line at Madison Square Garden last night, Eric Lindros pulled out a page from early in his career with perhaps his most dominant period of the season. It helped take the Rangers from a two-goal third-period deficit into overtime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLEVOY, LOUIS
description: POLEVOY-Louis. Of Aventura, FL formerly of Verona, NJ, on Sunday March 30, 2003. He was a Founder of Pathmark Supermarkets. Survived by his beloved wife Beatrice, loving children Ira and his wife Phyllis, Steven, and Stuart and his wife Gina, cherished by nine grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. Services are today, 1:30 PM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel W-150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Seeing Stars
description: Q. When you fly on commercial jets at night, why can't you see stars out the window? And why are there no stars in photographs taken in space by the astronauts?

title: Hollywood Toning Down Ads and Froth During War
description: The invasion of Iraq has Hollywood executives scrambling to revise advertising campaigns to reflect wartime sensibilities, canceling movie premiere parties and debating whether to delay movies that they fear will be hard to sell to a war-obsessed public.

title: A Top Commander Suggests Shiites Haven't Rebelled Because U.S. Failed Them in '91.
description: The United States, through its past acts, is largely to blame for the failure of Iraq's Shiite majority to rise in revolt against Saddam Hussein, a senior American military commander at Central Command said here today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, HARRY A.
description: HALPERN-Harry A., 91, cherished husband for 66 years and very best friend of Sylvia (Nee Stillman), loving and caring father of Joel A. Halpern, deceased, and Linda Lesser (Warren). Adored grandfather of Jon Halpern (Kerri), Julie Cook (Jim), Beth Lipman (Larry), Jason Halpern (Katelyn) and Mark Lesser. He proudly boasted of his ten precious greatgrandchildren, Kelsey Rose, Kelsey Lauren, Joel, Leah, Reed, Mackie, Samara, Jackson, Max and Paige. Harry, along with his family, built a successful real estate enterprise that has sustained four generations, but the focal point of his life was his overwhelming love, concern and involvement with his family. He was the patriarch of his family. His presence will be felt forever. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, April 2, at Beth El Synagogue, North Avenue, New Rochelle, New York, at 10:30 AM.

title: Friends of Affirmative Action
description: Without affirmative action, the United States might not be able to defend itself from foreign enemies. That startling assertion comes from a legal brief filed by high-ranking retired officers and civilian leaders of the military, including Adm. William Crowe Jr., the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff under President Ronald Reagan, and Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of allied forces during the first gulf war.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MASSACHUSETTS: JAILER IS FOUND GUILTY A former officer at a Boston jail has been found guilty of obstruction of justice, perjury and civil rights violations stemming from assaults on inmates. The former officer, Brian Bailey, was one of seven employees at the city's Nashua Street Jail indicted in the beatings of five detainees from June 1998 to October 1999 and covering up the attacks. Two other defendants were acquitted. Another four defendants pleaded guilty. The Suffolk County Sheriff's office, which operates the jail, has been accused of corruption and mismanagement. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Rumsfeld and Myers at the Pentagon
description: Following is the transcript from a news conference at the Pentagon on Tuesday by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and Gen. Richard B. Myers, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as recorded by eMediaMillWorks.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Economic Growth Slows
description: India's economic growth slowed in the quarter that ended in December as a result of a decline in agriculture, according to a government report. The Central Statistical Organization said the economy grew at 2.6 percent in the quarter, which was the third of India's fiscal year, compared with 6.3 percent a year earlier. Growth in the farm sector, which accounts for about a quarter of the country's gross domestic product, diminished to 5.9 percent from 7.9 percent a year ago as a result of insufficient rain. The industrial sector grew at 6.3 percent, and finance, insurance, real estate and business services at 8.1 percent. A drawn-out war in Iraq is expected to hurt the economy, as it would send oil prices higher. India imports more than 70 percent of its oil. The government has projected a 4.4 percent growth for the coming year. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: MACEDONIA: EUROPE'S MILITARY DEBUT The European Union began its first military operation, taking over NATO's small peacekeeping mission in the former Yugoslav republic Macedonia. "By taking on its first military mission, the E.U. is demonstrating that its project of a European security and defense policy has come of age," said the NATO secretary general, Lord Robertson. A French general will be in charge of the force of 300 lightly armed peacekeepers drawn from 27 countries with current or pending membership in the European Union. The Europeans are planning to take over NATO's much larger Bosnian peacekeeping mission early next year. (Reuters)

title: On Affirmative Action, High Court Seeks Nuance
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  Opponents of affirmative action came to the Supreme Court today to make an absolute case against race-conscious government policies but found the justices impatient with absolutes and hungry for nuance. Prepared to argue the merits of the color-blind principle, the opponents found the justices more concerned about a world where color still matters and where senior military officers describe affirmative action as essential for national security.

title: I.Q. Unfazed With Intense Care
description: In a study that has bearing on how aggressively doctors should treat children with diabetes, researchers have found that extremely low blood sugar does not appear to cause learning problems.

title: Pentagon Says Geraldo Rivera Will Be Removed From Iraq
description: Geraldo Rivera, the Fox News Channel correspondent who broadcast a report from Iraq on Sunday night that gave details of the position and plans of United States troops, is expected to be pulled from the country on Tuesday, military officials said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Industrial Output Falls
description: Industrial output, a key indicator of economic health, fell a worse-than-expected 1.7 percent in February compared with the previous month, as production of personal computers and passenger cars declined. The decrease came as exports to the United States and some parts of Europe were easing. Inventories, however, declined faster than production, a sign that manufacturers are adjusting quickly to weaker demand. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Lady Vols Top Villanova To Reach the Final Four
description: Villanova Coach Harry Perretta spent a few days last summer teaching his Tennessee counterpart, Pat Summitt, how to play the motion offense.

title: On the Tactics of War, and the Searing Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: City Agrees to Settle Lawsuit Over Homeless, Lawyers Say
description: New York City has agreed to settle a lawsuit that accused the Police Department of adopting a deliberate policy of singling out homeless people for arrest, according to court records and lawyers involved.

title: In a Starburst, Interstellar Dust
description: A burst of light from a strange star is giving the Hubble Space Telescope an unusual view of the interstellar medium, the gases and dust in space. The burst of light, first observed on May 20, 2002, is from a star 20,000 light-years from Earth in the constellation Monoceros, the Unicorn. The light reflects off the medium, creating the startling images shown in these NASA photographs. When the burst appeared, the star, V838 Monocerotis, brightened to a luminosity 600,000 times as great as the Sun's. NASA scientists say the shell of light will continue to expand for several more years. The gaps are regions around the star where there is little dust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIENER, BEATRICE
description: DIENER-Beatrice. ''...She is robed in strength and dignity and cheerfully faces whatever may come...She opens her mouth with wisdom, her tongue is guided by kindness ...Her children come forward and praise her; her husband, too, and he lauds her:'Many daughters have amassed achievement, but you surpass them all.'...Charm is deceitful and beauty is vain, but a G-d revering woman is much to be praised...wherever people gather, her deeds speak her praise.'' (Proverbs) Beatrice Diener's deeds speak her praise. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns with profound sorrow the passing of a most cherished member of its extended family. We are honored that one of Boys Town's crown jewel institutes bears the illustrious Diener family name-The Beatrice and Leonard Diener Torah and Science Academy. Together with her beloved husband, Leonard, z''l, who was her partner in life, business and tzedakah, the Dieners demonstrated their commitment to the future builders and leaders of Israel through their magnanimous support of virtually every Boys Town program and project. Mrs. Diener took great delight in the accomplishments of Boys Town's students and truly regarded them as ''her'' boys. Mrs. Diener exuded aristocracy in her very word, action and manner. Her Hebrew name, Bracha, reflects the blessing and inspiration of her lasting memory. Leonard and Beatrice Diener's legacy of Torah im Derech Eretz is not only manifest in the philosophy of the institution they so generously endowed with great modesty and humility, but is evident in the sterling character of their children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren and indeed, the entire family. Like the Torah itself, whose ideals they personified, the Dieners' ways were ways of pleasantness. To her children, our esteemed Board Members and benefactors, Larry (Adele) and Marjorie, her treasured sister, Toby Greller, her cherished grandchildren, great-grandchildren, nieces and nephews, we extend heartfelt condolences to the family and offer our prayers. Hamakom y'nachem eschem b'soch shaar aveilay Tzion v'Yerushalayim. Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Rebbetzin Yocheved Linchner Rebbetzin Batsheva Linchner Josh S. Last year, the DeBenedittis family (sisters Marie, Carmela, Irene and their mother, Nancy) opened a tiny branch of Leo's Latticini (known informally as Mama's), their shop in Corona, Queens, in the Backstop Bar at Shea Stadium (field level behind third base). Among the offerings are Mama's Special, a sandwich with pepper ham and salami; a grilled vegetable sandwich; and a turkey hero with brown gravy. Sarubbi, the Camden County prosecutor. Doctors determined that she had recently given birth, and a police search of her neighborhood turned up a bag containing the body of a boy. An autopsy determined the cause of death as suffocation, Mr. Sarubbi said.

description: A man leaped to his death from the Nelson Avenue Bridge onto the Cross-Bronx Expressway yesterday after fatally stabbing the mother of his two children in her Bronx apartment, the police said. The couple had a history of domestic disputes, the police said. The woman, Niurka Pineda, 30, had an order of protection against the man, Jose Alcatara, 33, dating from Aug. 8, 2002, when he was arrested on charges that he assaulted her, the police said. Despite that, she let him into her apartment sometime Monday night, and he attacked her about 2:30 a.m., the police said. Ms. Pineda and Mr. Alcatara had two sons, 2 and 6, and Ms. Pineda had a third son, 10. The children were sleeping when the attack took place, the police said. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

Nature is a part of my city, and I want to help take care of the environment,' '' said CAROL ENSEKI, the museum's president.

title: Decadence and Decay as Art Forms
description: Neil Jordan's ''Good Thief'' is nominally a remake of Jean-Pierre Melville's 1955 atmospheric and poetic film noir, ''Bob le Flambeur.'' But Mr. Jordan, as writer and director, has soaked his remake in color and pushed the combustion by a few cylinders. The movie feels more like a breezy, jazz-inflected version of the original: it's a triumph of flourish, all weathered, movie-star-size gestures. Melville's original was engulfed by reticence and oppression; his gambling Bob was a pained ghost floating through the story.

It was not a jury trial, and the company was not found guilty.

title: How to Hide Money in Albany
description: Last week the security chief at New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority suddenly accused his own agency of corruption. The M.T.A. leadership then suspended him with pay, and it is hard to determine at this early stage whether New Yorkers are watching an internal feud or an unfolding scandal. Getting any real information will not be easy. The M.T.A. is a huge, remote patch of New York's expanding shadow government. It is one of more than 50 authorities, corporations or other entities that are ''off budget,'' which means the public and even the Legislature have almost no access to their secret doings. These authorities, worth billions, are controlled almost exclusively by Gov. George Pataki. And the public seldom gets even the barest glimpse of how they operate.

description: It was the way St. John's Coach Mike Jarvis had envisioned his backcourt from the very start. But it took 32 games for Marcus Hatten and Elijah Ingram to get there. Hatten, the Red Storm's senior star, and Ingram, the highly recruited freshman, finally jelled in the Red Storm's pulsating 64-63 victory over Texas Tech and Coach Bob Knight last night in the National Invitation Tournament semifinals at Madison Square Garden.

title: Powell, in Ankara, Ties Assistance for U.S. to Aid
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the United States was preparing a new request for help from Turkey in sustaining American military operations in northern Iraq. He said a cooperative response would help win Congressional approval of the $1 billion in aid for Turkey requested by President Bush.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDONESIA: MUDSLIDES KILL 27 Mudslides caused by flash floods killed 27 people with at least 5 others reported missing, local officials said. The floods swept away 17 houses and damaged hundreds of others in three villages on Flores island, 1,030 miles east of the capital of Jakarta. A local official said more than three feet of fast-moving water rushed through the area late Monday night while most residents were sleeping and carried away everything in its path.    (AP)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It is not helpful to have those kind of comments come out when we've got troops in combat, because, first of all, they're false, they're absolutely wrong, they bear no resemblance to the truth, and it's just harmful to our troops.''

title: Putting Fellini In Front Of the Lens
description: At one point in ''Fellini: I'm a Born Liar,'' Donald Sutherland recalls a deleted scene from ''Casanova'' in which, as he puts it, ''Fellini makes love with a man.'' The actor does not correct his slip -- it is Casanova, the character played by Mr. Sutherland, not the director, who is amorously engaged -- which is almost as telling as his having committed it in the first place. In addition to being, by his own admission, a fabricator of untruths, Federico Fellini was a consummate narcissist. His movies, neo-realist or phantasmagorical, black-and-white or color, grand or merely grandiose, were at bottom all about himself.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Milton Henschel, a member of the Governing Body of Jehovah's Witnesses, misstated his age. He was 82, not 72.

title: Arab Volunteers Seek To Join Fight for Iraq
description: Hundreds of men from across the Arab world and beyond gather in Damascus, Syria, each day, aiming to make their way to Baghdad to fight coalition troops. A combination of religious zeal and Arab nationalism is driving the volunteers, and not a day goes by without some exhortation from Iraq for the faithful to join the fray.

title: Onward Toward the Tigris, With Iraq's Capital in Mind
description: Heavy armor and troops from the First Marine Division crossed the Tigris river overnight and continued to move north along the east bank of the river toward Baghdad.

title: Orders in Place, Word Goes Out That 'This Is It'
description: ''This is it,'' said Brig. Gen. John F. Kelly, assistant commander of the First Marine Division.

title: Thousands of Students Gather Outside Court in Support of Admission Policies
description: The black and Latino teenagers who rallied outside the Supreme Court today were largely new to public protest. But they came from every corner of the country because the arguments taking place inside, about the use of race in university admissions, could not be more personal to them.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: GATEWAY TO DELAY FILING 2002 REPORT Gateway said yesterday that it would delay filing its 2002 annual report by up to 15 days because of plans to restate 2000 and 2001 revenue and cost of goods sold as it reviews transactions with AOL Time Warner . The company also attributed the delayed filing to a previously disclosed inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission into accounting in the 2000 fiscal year. Gateway said the accounting change, which it said would not affect its results, is related to the way it accounted for bundled Internet services with AOL Time Warner in 2000 and the first quarter of 2001. Gateway shares fell 13 cents, or about 5.5 percent, to $2.23. (Reuters)

title: Second-Guessing the War
description: As secretary of defense, Donald Rumsfeld has bruised a lot of egos. Right now, when soldiers' nerves are edgy and the public is concerned about the pace of the war, he can use all the support he can get among the military brass. But many officers -- in Iraq and back home -- have been stunningly critical. Mr. Rumsfeld tried to fight the war ''on the cheap,'' they say. He amassed far fewer troops than the Army had wanted, leaving supply lines vulnerable to attack and providing fewer troops than needed for the coming confrontations outside Baghdad.

title: An Updating of Shakespeare By Changing All the Sexes
description: 'Love's Labour's Lost'

title: First Medicine for Sickle Cell Anemia Can Also Prolong Life for Sickest Patients, Study Says
description: The first drug approved to reduce the frequency and intensity of attacks of sickle cell disease prolongs life among the ailment's sickest patients, researchers said today.

title: Tie Is Victory for Isles and a Defeat for the Rangers
description: The weary Rangers said to a man tonight that they were still alive, after they rallied from a two-goal third-period deficit to salvage a 2-2 tie with the Islanders at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Kirkuk on the Horizon, and a Falcon and Shells Nearby
description: Picking their way through a suspected minefield, two armed Kurds climbed to the top of a sun-browned knoll. There, in the distance, beyond the orange glow of a burning oil well, the prize of northern Iraq shimmered in the sun.

title: Eavesdropping on History
description: Bowing to the extraordinary public interest in yesterday's argument on affirmative action, the Supreme Court agreed to release an audio recording of the historic two-hour legal showdown as soon as it ended.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, PENNY B.
description: BAKER-Penny B., Salisbury, CT, 58, mother, housewife, and photo stylist in her husband's illustration business, died Monday, March 31, 2003 at New York University Tisch Hospital after a long battle with the disease of scleroderma (CREST). She was the wife of Joe Baker of Salisbury, CT and mother of Stephen Koshland also of Salisbury, CT. Mrs. Baker was born November 4, 1944 in Manhattan, NY. Daughter of Gwen (Gaillard) Bloomingdale of Nantucket, MA and the late Lymans G. Bloomingdale of Manhattan, NY. Great-granddaughter of the late Lymans G. Bloomingdale, the founder of Bloomingdale's Department Store. After attending Grace Church School in New York and Nantucket High School she graduated from Mills College. She taught nursery school at Little Scholar School in Lakeville, CT. In addition to her husband, son and mother, she is survived by two sisters, Jennifer Nelson of Milton, MA., and Billie Logan of Reno, NV., and several nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Critical Care East ICU, New York University Tisch Hospital, 560 First Ave., New York, NY 10016, Attention Judy Dillworth. For information Newkirk-Palmer Funeral Home, 118 Main St., Canaan, CT 06018. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, April 5, at the funeral home 1 PM.

title: Los Angeles Archdiocese Tries to Shield Documents
description: As sexual abuse scandals engulfed the Roman Catholic Church nationwide last year, Cardinal Roger M. Mahony of Los Angeles won praise for his promise to be an advocate for victims and to provide a full and open accounting of what happened here in the country's largest archdiocese of five million Catholics.

title: 4 Journalists Are Safe in Jordan After a Week in an Iraqi Jail
description: Four journalists who had been missing in Iraq for a week crossed over safely into Jordan tonight, saying they had been held for unknown reasons in one of the nation's most notorious prisons.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the challenge facing Nancy Pelosi, the House minority leader, whose Democratic colleagues are divided over the Iraq war, misstated the leadership position of Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, who supports the war. He is the Democratic whip, not the assistant leader.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: ELIZABETH: FUGITIVE KILLER SURRENDERS A fugitive convicted of killing a police officer surrendered to the authorities yesterday, a week after slipping away from the minimum-security Bayside State Prison in Leesburg. The fugitive, Anthony Russo, 63, turned himself in at a public library in Elizabeth. Mr. Russo faces up to a year of suspended privileges and possibly a criminal charge for escape, said Chris Carden, a spokesman for the State Department of Corrections. Mr. Russo was convicted of killing an off-duty Newark police officer during a robbery in 1961. He received the death penalty, but his sentence was commuted to life after the Supreme Court ruled the death penalty unconstitutional. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Taking Comfort From an Unexpected Source
description: SO maybe this is not the best time to come out with an Iraqi cookbook.

title: Turkey Agrees to Step Up Support of U.S. in Iraq
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 2  The United States reached agreement with Turkey today to upgrade Turkish support of American military actions in the war with Iraq by permitting use of Turkish territory to supply food, fuel and other necessities to American military forces operating in the northern Iraqi theater.

title: Second Plane From Cuba Is Hijacked To Key West
description: A hijacker claiming to be carrying hand grenades surrendered to the police today at Key West International Airport after commandeering a plane originally bound for Havana. It was the second hijacking to Florida of a Cuban plane in two weeks.

title: Italian Police Arrest 6 Men Suspected of Ties to Al Qaeda
description: The Italian police have arrested six men in the northern cities of Milan and Parma for suspected links to international terrorism and possession of false documents, a police spokeswoman said today.

title: Responses to a Growing Outbreak
description: 21 A professor from Guangzhou in Guangdong checks into Metropole Hotel in Hong Kong and becomes sick. Twelve other Metropole guests become sick.

title: Stocks Rally Sharply as Optimism on War Grows
description: Stock prices around the world staged a sharp, broad advance today, as the advance of American troops toward Baghdad reinstilled optimism that a speedy end to the war with Iraq might still be possible.

title: Martha Stewart's 2002 Bonus Is Decreased by About 42%
description: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia had the roughest year of its short life as a public company in 2002. In June, Martha Stewart, its chairwoman and chief executive, came under scrutiny for her sale of shares in ImClone Systems, and her company's share price, ad sales and public image all began a downward spiral from which they have yet to recover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTUCCI, ARTHUR A.
description: MARTUCCI-Arthur A. Beloved son of the late Albert and Mamie Martucci, dear brother of the late Florence Azzolino and Felix Martucci, died March 31st, 2003, age 89. In gratitude for your generous and loving life, from your nephews, Robert and Philip Harding, your nieces, Maria Zifchak, Rita Ronan.

title: A 'Heretic' Ruffles Feathers in France
description: TO many French purists, selling wine by the name of a grape chardonnay, for example, or merlot -- is heresy. But the French wine industry is in trouble, and the way out may lie in the ideas of a man viewed by many as a heretic.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Computer Associates Will Combine 2 Units
description: Computer Associates International, the software company, will combine two units to cut jobs and expenses while improving customer service. The company is merging divisions that help customers install and fix Computer Associates' business programs, a spokesman, Dan Kaferle, said yesterday. About 450 jobs will be cut, or 2.8 percent of Computer Associates' work force of 15,900 people. The move will save the company about $10 million a quarter, Mr. Kaferle said. Customers have complained about the quality of the company's service as it bought more than 60 companies and cut some of their employees, the chief executive, Sanjay Kumar, and other managers have said. In another development, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had granted Mr. Kumar options to buy 700,000 shares as the stock dropped 36 percent in the last year.

title: Doherty Quits Tar Heels
description: Matt Doherty resigned today as coach of North Carolina, ending a three-year tenure marked by inconsistent play and rocky relations with players and alumni.

title: Corrections
description: A program listing and a highlight in the Television section on Sunday for Thursday at 8 p.m. on Channel 7 have become outdated. The premiere of the reality series ''Extreme Makeover'' has been postponed to 9 p.m. on April 10. Two episodes of ''Whose Line Is It Anyway?'' will be shown in its place.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: A TAKEOVER OFFER The French engineering company Alstom said it received a takeover offer from an unknown Dutch investor, sending its shares up 10 percent. The bid valued the company at 700 million euros ($763.5 million). A spokesman confirmed that the company received a letter from a company called MJ Global Acquisition. But the spokesman added: "It could be a joke; it could be a speculative operation. For the moment, we don't have all the information. For the moment we don't think this letter was serious." Alstom became a candidate for takeover after its market value fell by half in less than a month. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Plan To Fingerprint Immigrants
description: The government has proposed fingerprinting all non-European nationals, including legal residents, in an effort to crack down on immigrants who use multiple false identities to abuse welfare and other benefits, a Justice Department spokesman said. The plan, which must be approved by the cabinet ministers, would go into effect in the summer and would apply to non-Europeans entering the country for the first time or renewing their permission to stay. The Green Party has criticized the plan, which would be unique among European Union countries, as racist and an infringement of civil liberties. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: TOP-RANKED OFFICER DENOUNCES CRITICS OF IRAQ CAMPAIGN
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and Gen. Richard B. Myers, the nation's highest-ranking military officer, denounced critics of the campaign in Iraq today, declaring that complaints about the handling of the war were misinformed, inaccurate and harmful to American forces in combat.

title: Plans for Postwar Iraq Are Re-evaluated As Fast Military Exit Looks Less Likely
description: Three weeks before the war in Iraq began, Bush administration officials based their plans for reconstructing the country on what they called a ''major assumption'' -- that military operations would end in 30 days, according to briefing documents circulated in the White House.

title: Judicial Nominee Distances Herself From Past Positions
description: Carolyn B. Kuhl, President Bush's nominee to a federal appeals court, faced a withering barrage of questions from Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee today and responded that many of her staunch conservative positions over the years were not relevant to her being a judge.

title: Is it Nature or Nurture, That Makes Spring Menus Sing?
description: AT Chanterelle in TriBeCa, David Waltuck, the chef, often prepares a dish called Wild Striped Bass with Wild Mushroom Broth. The fish is always wild. As for the mushrooms, ''it depends,'' he said. ''Sometimes I use cultivated ones, too.'' Wild boar ragout is on the menu at Union Square Cafe; at Alain Ducasse, there is the exotic, disheveled-sounding creature called a half-wild duckling.

title: U.S. STEEL TO BUY SERBIAN COMPANY FOR $23 MILLION
description: In a purchase that will give Serbia's limping economy some badly needed foreign investment, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation in Serbia, U.S. Steel Balkan, agreed yesterday to buy Serbia's largest steel producer, Sartid, which is owned by the state, for $23 million. Offering a lift to Serbia, two weeks after a sniper assassinated the country's prime minister, the American-owned company pledged to spend $150 million to upgrade the plant. The purchase is subject to review under Serbia's antimonopoly laws and is scheduled for completion in the third quarter of this year. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENSTER, SANDRA LEE
description: FENSTER-Sandra Lee. Of Port Washington, age 56, on March 31. Sandra was born in Warwick, New York. Adored wife of Fred, loving and devoted step-mother of Jordan and Sarah, and grandmother to Miriam and Naomi. Treasured aunt to Nancy, Charlie, Daralyn, Mary, Jessica, and Joshua. Beloved sister-in-law to Susan and Roy Sparber, & sister to Mary Lee. Sandra was a trust-officer for J.P. Morgan, and left as a result of a thirteen year battle with cancer. All those blessed by a relationship with Sandy were inspired by her strength, perseverance, friendship, kindness and helpfulness. She will be missed by her many friends, especially Linda, Roberta, Maureen, Cecil, Evelyn, Lily and more too numerous to recall. The services will be held today at The Community Synagogue, 150 Middle Neck Road, in Port Washington at 10:00 AM.

It is easier to release a puffy gloss on an artist's life (there have been many recent examples, a few among this year's Oscar nominations) than it is to draw a wide public into the dark and messy domain of an artist's actual work.

title: Writing 9/11 Eulogies Links Two Disparate New Yorkers
description: ''The Guys,'' which will be shown tonight as part of the New Directors/ New Films series, before opening commercially on Friday, takes place in New York in the immediate aftermath of Sept. 11. Sigourney Weaver plays an Upper West Side writer named Joan who helps Nick, a fire captain played by Anthony LaPaglia, compose eulogies for some of his men. The two of them, very different types of New Yorkers, meet in a Park Slope brownstone belonging to Joan's sister and try to find words to capture the lives of the dead firefighters, and also, hesitantly and inadvertently, to help each other through a time of grief and confusion.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Trade Gap
description: South Korea posted its third consecutive trade deficit in March despite an 18 percent increase in exports. Fueled by sales of autos and electronics, exports totaled $15.6 billion in March, but they were $362 million less than imports, which were pushed up by the high price of oil. Hyundai Motor posted a 7.7 percent increase in auto sales, and its affiliate Kia Motors sold 45 percent more vehicles for export. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Trade Concerns as Canada Sits Out War

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Elizabeth: Fugitive Killer Surrenders
description: A fugitive convicted of killing a police officer surrendered to the authorities yesterday, a week after slipping away from the minimum-security Bayside State Prison in Leesburg. The fugitive, Anthony Russo, 63, turned himself in at a public library in Elizabeth. Mr. Russo faces up to a year of suspended privileges and possibly a criminal charge for escape, said Chris Carden, a spokesman for the State Department of Corrections. Mr. Russo was convicted of killing an off-duty Newark police officer during a robbery in 1961. He received the death penalty, but his sentence was commuted to life after the Supreme Court ruled the death penalty unconstitutional. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Land-Rich Museums Find New Income Source
description: An outdoor history museum, where the grounds are dotted with staff members in period costume demonstrating how life was lived more than two centuries ago, seems an unlikely place for a shopping center.

title: Celebrating Effort to Make The Elevator A Dull Ride
description: Elevators go up and down. That much is not difficult.

title: Former Chief's Protg Puts His Estate on the Block
description: Richard Scrushy is not the only former HealthSouth executive who is not living high.

title: Gionta's Dash-and-Bash Style Is Perfect Fit for Devils
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 1 - Brian Gionta considers himself a lucky man these days.

title: Pataki Names Former Yale Head To Serve as Chairman of CUNY
description: Gov. George E. Pataki named Benno C. Schmidt Jr. chairman of the City University of New York yesterday, just four years after a task force that Mr. Schmidt led labeled CUNY ''an institution adrift.''
