description: With the exception of Michigan, form held on the first weekend of the N.C.A.A. Division I tournament, as three of the four top-seeded teams in the regionals advanced to the Frozen Four in Buffalo next Thursday and Saturday.

title: Top General Denounces Internal Dissent on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and Gen. Richard B. Myers, the nation's highest-ranking military officer, denounced critics of the campaign in Iraq today, declaring that complaints about the handling of the war were misinformed, inaccurate and harmful to American forces in combat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, HARRY A.
description: HALPERN-Harry A., 91, cherished husband for 66 years and very best friend of Sylvia (Nee Stillman), loving and caring father of Joel A. Halpern, deceased, and Linda Lesser (Warren). Adored grandfather of Jon Halpern (Kerri), Julie Cook (Jim), Beth Lipman (Larry), Jason Halpern (Katelyn) and Mark Lesser. He proudly boasted of his ten precious greatgrandchildren, Kelsey Rose, Kelsey Lauren, Joel, Leah, Reed, Mackie, Samara, Jackson, Max and Paige. Harry, along with his family, built a successful real estate enterprise that has sustained four generations, but the focal point of his life was his overwhelming love, concern and involvement with his family. He was the patriarch of his family. His presence will be felt forever. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, April 2, at Beth El Synagogue, North Avenue, New Rochelle, New York, at 10:30 AM.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: U.S. Accuses Hynix Of Being Unfairly Subsidized
description: Hynix Semiconductor, the maker of computer memory chips, is unfairly subsidized by the South Korean government, the United States said yesterday in a ruling that may lead to punitive tariffs on the company. The Commerce Department, in a preliminary decision, ruled in favor of a claim by Micron Technology that Hynix received loans and guarantees from government-backed lenders that allowed the company to undercut foreign rivals.

title: Do-It-Yourself Bloody Marys For the Persnickety Bruncher
description: Does your favorite bar make a bloody mary exactly the way you like it? Or do you always wish that your drink had a bit more celery salt, clam juice or hot sauce?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITNEY, ROBERT AVERY
description: WHITNEY - Robert Avery. Died March 30, 2003 in Corte Madera, CA. Born in Buffalo, NY, 1912, he resided in West Orange, NJ, New York and London. Management consultant to 300 firms, publisher and author of The Instant Manager. Founder and director of the 1st Int'l Distribution Congress in Milan, Italy, 1956, which led to founding the European Common Market created by the Treaty of Rome, 1957. He will be sorely missed by all those whose lives he touched. He was energetic and enthusiastic about life, a religious man, who sought to share his observations, innovations, and ideas, with those around him. Survived by his wife, Marie Therese Whitney - Thone, children, Grace Ann, Marguerite, Barbara Griffith, Robert Avery, John David, and Virginia Bradley. Services will not be held. Please make contributions to: Hospice of Marin, 150 Nellen Avenue, Corte Madera, CA. 94925.

title: Commandos Rescue P.O.W. and Locate Bodies
description: CAMP SAYLIYA, Qatar, April 2  Senior military officers at Central Command headquarters here watched the dramatic rescue of Pfc. Jessica Lynch unfold over two tense hours early this morning through a live video feed from special forces commandos deep inside Iraq.

title: Come the Revolution
description: To read the Arab press is to think that the entire Arab world is enraged with the U.S. invasion of Iraq, and to some extent that's true. But here's what you don't read: underneath the rage, there is also a grudging, skeptical curiosity -- a curiosity about whether the Americans will actually do what they claim and build a new, more liberal Iraq.

title: U.S.-Led Forces Face First Heat Waves of War
description: One week after American-led forces in Iraq were pummeled by a paralyzing dust storm, they face a new meteorological antagonist on the sun-baked battlefields: the first heat wave of the war.

title: A Quicker Teaching Degree at N.Y.U.
description: New York University's Steinhardt School of Education is introducing an accelerated master's degree program that will prepare students for teacher certification in 14 months rather than the usual two school years. Unlike participants in New York City's fast-track teaching fellows program, who start teaching after only a summer of training, the N.Y.U. master's degree students will begin their course work during the summer session and complete the program the following summer. Karen W. Arenson

title: Despite Protests, Seoul to Send Troops to Iraq for Reconstruction
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 2  Ending several days of bitter stalemate, South Korea's Parliament today approved the sending of 700 soldiers to Iraq to help in the country's reconstruction effort.

title: Medicare Drug Benefit Plan Is Proposed by 2 Democrats
description: In a break with party leaders, centrist Democrats proposed today that Medicare provide drug benefits immediately to people who have low incomes or high prescription drug expenses.

title: U.S. Raises Some Fuel Economy Rules
description: The Bush administration said today that it would raise fuel economy regulations for light trucks -- S.U.V.'s, pickups and minivans -- by 1.5 miles a gallon, or about 4.5 percent, by the 2007 model year.

title: Panels Approve War Spending but Reject Free Rein for White House
description: Two powerful committees in the House and Senate today approved President Bush's request for new spending to pay for the war in Iraq, but only after refusing to grant his administration broad latitude to spend the money without Congressional oversight.

title: Worries Over Respiratory Illness Prompt Quarantine of Jet in California
description: The mysterious respiratory illness suspected of sickening 1,800 people around the world seemed to loom at the United States' gates yesterday as a jetliner from Asia was briefly quarantined in California, a Congressional subcommittee announced that it would investigate the illness and two more people died in Canada.

title: Reliving the Day a Shot Was Fired in Memphis; Museumgoers Get The Evidence That James Earl Ray Killed Martin Luther King
description: The National Civil Rights Museum here offers exhibits ranging from a Ku Klux Klan robe to signs that say ''Colored Seating in Rear'' and ''Rest Room -- White Only.'' But from the moment this museum opened more than a decade ago, the central exhibit has been the building itself. It is the former Lorraine Motel, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was shot dead on April 4, 1968.

title: Piazza's Ban Is Reduced
description: Mike Piazza's suspension for his role in a brawl two weeks ago in an exhibition game with the Los Angeles Dodgers was reduced yesterday by one game, to four games, to Bob DuPuy, baseball's chief operating officer. Piazza, who had appealed the original penalty, will begin serving his suspension with tonight's game between the Mets and the Chicago Cubs. Piazza's $3,000 fine was upheld.

title: New Dean of Admission at Princeton
description: Princeton University named JANET LAVIN RAPELYE as dean of admission, effective July 1. She has held the same post at Wellesley College for 12 years. She will succeed FRED HARGADON, who is retiring after 15 years at Princeton. Princeton's president, SHIRLEY M. TILGHMAN, who has made increased diversity a goal for the college, said that no one plays a more central role in shaping the university's future than the dean of admission. Ms. Rapelye said that the Supreme Court decision in the University of Michigan case could have a significant impact on how Princeton and other private universities conduct their admissions decisions, and that wide recruitment could become even more important than it is now. A graduate of Williams College, where she was an English major and varsity skier, Ms. Rapelye, 44, taught high school English for a year in Vermont and then joined the Williams admissions office. She worked in the Stanford University admissions office while earning a master's degree there in education, and then worked in admissions at Bowdoin College before moving to Wellesley. Karen W. Arenson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNSTEIN, S. LAWRENCE
description: HORNSTEIN-S. Lawrence. Beloved husband of Francine. Devoted father of Meryl and Mark Nachbar, and David and Nancy Hornstein. Loving brother-in-law of Phyllis Feinstein, cherished uncle of Stuart and Margaret Feinstein, Steven and Yvonne Feinstein. Adored great uncle of Mary, David, Andrew, and Matthew. Services Thursday 1:15 P.M. at ''Riverside - Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opp LIRR) Great Neck, NY. Contributions in his name may be made to The Long Island Hearing and Speech Society Inc, 430 Lakeville Rd, New Hyde Park, NY 11041.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: Student Dies Of Meningitis
description: A seventh grader at Intermediate School 229 in Morris Heights died Sunday of bacterial meningitis, the authorities said. Several people with whom she had contact were given antibiotics to prevent the spread of the disease. The student, a 15-year-old girl whose name was not released, died in a local hospital. School officials sent letters home to parents and held meetings with them. Parents are advised to take their children to the hospital if they exhibit symptoms like fever, vomiting, stiff neck, mental confusion, lethargy or headache. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STERN, REBECCA (RUBY)
description: STERN - Rebecca (Ruby), March 9, 1916 to April 2, 2002. In all our hearts. Love

title: U.S. Columns Roll Forward Near Baghdad
description: Armored columns of the Army's Third Infantry Division thrust through the Karbala Gap early today, sweeping past the city of Karbala and passing a major obstacle on the road to Baghdad.

title: Highs and Lows in Park Slope Rezoning Plan
description: When the city planning commissioners vote today on a proposal to rezone more than 100 blocks in Park Slope, Brooklyn, they are likely to fulfill the long-held desire of many residents to preserve the small-scale brownstone charm that has long lured refugees from high-priced Manhattan.

title: African AIDS, and Helping Orphans Remember
description: Rebecca Nakabazzi's son Julius is about to become an AIDS orphan. Right now the shy 11-year-old lives at home with Ms. Nakabazzi, who is frail and feverish but still very much a doting mother.

title: Shock and Pause
description: The ''pause'' that British and American forces took on the road to Baghdad was a setback, right? After all, hesitation looks bad, particularly when it follows sunny pronouncements of a warm reception in the Iraqi capital. But as the coalition advance slowly resumes, we would do well to recall that the last few conflicts have taught us that in warfare, winning sometimes involves looking bad for a while.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: City Revitalization Plan Advances
description: In an ambitious effort to address the decline of New Jersey's poorest city, the state will begin selling $175 million in bonds today to help pay for revitalization projects. The bond sale, initially set for January, was delayed by legal challenges; all but one has been dismissed. The state's Economic Recovery Board will use the proceeds to double the size of the state aquarium, expand hospitals and colleges and repair roads. Opponents had objected to a provision of the deal that imposes state control over many government functions. A third suit, seeking to block the state takeover of the school board, is pending. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: National Briefing: South
description: MISSISSIPPI: BANNED FROM PREPARING TAXES A man who defied a federal judge by continuing to seek tax refunds for fellow blacks based on his contention they are second-class citizens has been permanently barred from preparing tax returns. The tax preparer, Andrew Wiley, 79, was accused of helping to file almost 4,000 tax returns seeking refunds of $43,209 each for what Judge Henry T. Wingate called fraudulent claims. At least three taxpayers received the full refund. Judge Wingate issued a preliminary injunction against Mr. Wiley last May. It was made permanent when Mr. Wiley said he would not stop. (AP)

title: Iraqi Agents Held in Plot To Poison Water Supply
description: The Jordanian authorities have arrested several Iraqi agents in connection with a plot to poison the water supply that serves American troops in the eastern desert of Jordan near the border with Iraq, officials here said today.

description: The city's Department of Correction, responding to reports of corruption and abuse of power among some of its top officials, announced management changes yesterday that it said would make the department more accountable.

description: Gen. Richard B. Myers of the Air Force did not accuse commanders down the chain of command today of being insubordinate by voicing their doubts about the war in interviews from the front.

title: UConn Rides Flawed Victory Over Purdue To Final Four
description: This Connecticut team drove him crazy, Coach Geno Auriemma said with an indeterminate smile. Every day, he hated practice. Some days he just hated it less. Four seniors from a championship team had been replaced by four freshmen. They were great kids, nice and genuine, but too young, too introverted. Never was a group so hard to work with.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLAUBERMAN, FRIEDA
description: GLAUBERMAN-Frieda, 98. Passed away at The Hebrew Home for the Aged on March 31, 2003. Beloved aunt of Laura, Naomi and Arthur, and great-aunt of Sarah, Sam, Molly and Julia. Frieda was the oldest living alumna of the Beth Israel Nursing School. Services Wednesday 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made in Frieda's memory to Shaarei Tikvah, 46 Fox Meadow Road, Scarsdale, New York 10583.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Superfund Law Is Upheld
description: A federal district judge in Washington dismissed the General Electric Company's broad constitutional challenge to the Superfund law, which requires that sites contaminated by toxic wastes to be cleaned up by the parties that are responsible. G.E., which has 75 Superfund sites nationwide, had argued that the law violated due process because the Environmental Protection Agency does not conduct hearings before it issues an administrative order. The judge, John D. Bates, dismissed G.E.'s challenge for lack of jurisdiction. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Harry Ellis Dickson, 94, Violinist and Conductor in Boston
description: Harry Ellis Dickson, an old-school musician and personality who was a first violinist of the Boston Symphony Orchestra for five decades and a conductor of the Boston Pops for nearly as long, died on Saturday after a brief illness. He was 94.

Brother of Harold Casty. Grandfather of nine grandchildren and one great grandchild. Services will be held in Newton, MA. today. Remembrances may be made to a charity of your choice. For further information BrezniakRodman Funeral Directors 617-969-0800.

title: Nets Take Time to Nurse Injuries Before Hitting the Homestretch
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 1 - Nets Coach Byron Scott had scheduled a practice session for his players today before their flight to New Orleans, but he opted instead to make it a voluntary workout. That left the banged-up roster with a day to receive treatment and, in the case of forward Kenyon Martin, find a comfortable spot in the locker room and sleep.

description: The Newark Municipal Court, troubled by computer problems that led to calling thousands of drivers to court on the same day, today announced changes to its system for handling traffic violations.

title: Going Against the Grain
description: Although he has played baseball for most of his life, Drew Gribbons, a 16-year-old second baseman, had never held a wood bat in his hands. But because a ruling has led scores of Massachusetts high schools to ban metal baseball bats, Gribbons stood at home plate a few days ago swinging -- for the first time -- a polished piece of lumber.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AEZEN, JOSEPH
description: AEZEN - Joseph, passed away at his home on Sunday, March 23, 2003. He is survived by his friend of 20 years, Elaine Rosomoff; the mother of his children, Mollie Aezen, daughter Samantha Harris Aezen and son Peter Michael Aezen. He was delighted to learn from his friend Elaine Rosomoff that the Rittenhouse Square flower bed that he had enjoyed for much of his life was to be dedicated in his memory by longtime friend Ralph Lauren. He will be deeply missed.

title: Japan Survey Finds Rise In Pessimism
description: Japanese business leaders have turned pessimistic again about their economic prospects, as slumping stock prices and jitters about the war in Iraq damp confidence, according to the Bank of Japan's widely followed Tankan quarterly survey.

title: Justices Rule H.M.O.'s Can Be Forced to Open Networks
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 — The Supreme Court today unanimously upheld a law credited by its supporters with giving patients a much broader choice of doctors and hospitals from which to choose.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Chip Maker Forecasts Loss
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, one of Japan's largest chip makers, said it would lose 14 billion yen ($118 million) for the year that ended Monday because of the sliding value of its stock holdings. The company had previously forecast a 25 billion yen profit. The company's sales target is unchanged, but it expects to book a one-time loss of 50 billion yen on shares it holds. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Justices Look for Nuance in Race-Preference Case
description: Opponents of affirmative action came to the Supreme Court today to make an absolute case against race-conscious government policies but found the justices impatient with absolutes and hungry for nuance.

title: House and Senate Panels Approve Aid for Airlines
description: The appropriations committees in the House and the Senate each voted today to give the airline industry about $3 billion in emergency assistance, enough to provide modest relief but nowhere near the amount needed to cure the industry's most acute problems.

title: SBC Drops Out Of Bidding For Hughes And TV Unit
description: SBC Communications dropped out of the bidding yesterday for Hughes Electronics and its coveted DirecTV satellite television operation, executives close to the negotiations said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Brokers Expect Losses
description: Nomura Holdings Inc., the country's largest stockbroker, will book a one-time 41.2 billion yen ($349 million) loss on its stock investments in the year that ended Monday. Three quarters of that loss stemmed from a decline in the value of the Jafco Company, Nomura's venture capital affiliate. The Daiwa Securities Group, Japan's second-biggest broker, also said it would take a 37.2 billion yen loss on its stock holdings. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: In Trenton, Some Propose Raising Taxes On the Richest
description: In a day of discouraging forecasts about New Jersey's fiscal future, some Democrats in the State Senate publicly called today for consideration of a tax increase on high earners that could alleviate some of the pain in Gov. James E. McGreevey's proposed budget.

title: Rising Medicare Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Shares Rise on Expectations of Strong Growth After War
description: Stocks rose for the first trading day in five yesterday as some investors speculated that economic growth would accelerate once the war with Iraq ends.

title: Author to Teach Jazz at Columbia
description: JOHN F. SZWED, a Yale anthropology professor and the author of ''So What: The Life of Miles Davis'' and ''Space Is the Place: Sun Ra's Life on Earth,'' has been appointed the 2003-2004 Louis Armstrong visiting professor of jazz studies at Columbia. Professor Szwed succeeds ROBIN D. G. KELLEY, a professor of history, and the writer and critic STANLEY CROUCH. The appointment is supported by a grant from the Louis Armstrong Educational Foundation, which Armstrong founded to support jazz education. Professor Szwed will teach two courses on jazz next year. He has been at Yale since 1982, where he has served as director of graduate studies in anthropology and acting chairman of African-American studies.

title: EXPRESS SCRIPTS DISCLOSES $2.48 BILLION IN REBATES, FEES
description: Express Scripts Inc., which manages prescription benefits for employers and insurers, received $2.48 billion in rebates and fees from pharmaceutical companies in the last three years. The company disclosed the rebates under a change in accounting practices in a regulatory filing, accounting for the money as a decrease to cost of goods sold, rather than an increase to revenue. The change means Express Scripts' revenue for 2000 through 2002 was reduced by the same amount, a company spokesman, Steven Littlejohn, said. Express Scripts said in the filing that it had received a second subpoena in a federal inquiry of pharmacy-benefit prices. Barrett Toan, the chief executive of Express Scripts, said last month that his company would disclose financial relationships with drug makers because of concern that the dealings might create conflicts of interest.

title: Air Force Secretary Says Academy's Leaders Could Be Punished in Rape Scandal
description: Prompted by scathing rebukes at a Senate hearing on Monday, Air Force Secretary James G. Roche today vowed to ''look deeper'' into the actions of top officials at the Air Force Academy and issued criteria by which they could be punished for failing to address the difficulties women cadets faced in reporting sexual assaults.

title: Europe Assesses Damage To Western Relationships And Takes Steps to Rebuild
description: European governments, reeling from the political earthquake the war in Iraq touched off on their own Continent, are struggling to dig out from the rubble and rebuild relationships with the United States and among themselves.

title: Excerpts From Arguments Before the Supreme Court on Affirmative Action
description: Following are excerpts from Supreme Court arguments yesterday in Grutter v. Bollinger and Gratz v. Bollinger, two challenges to affirmative action programs at, respectively, the University of Michigan Law School and College of Literature and the Science and the Arts. Kirk O. Kolbo argued for the plaintiffs; Theodore B. Olson, the United States Solicitor General, argued in support of them; Maureen E. Mahoney defended the law school and John Payton defended the College. The Alderson Reporting Company recorded the arguments; The Times identified the justices.

title: End of Bridge Work to Bring Subway Changes Next year
description: With construction on the Manhattan Bridge nearly complete, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will soon announce its most substantial change in the subway map in nearly two decades, officials confirmed yesterday.

title: Protective Suits, Often Tested in Labs, May Soon Face Real-World Challenge
description: As American-led forces push toward Baghdad, the shrink-wrapped $200 suits that troops are carrying to protect against chemical and biological weapons could soon have their first real-world test, and experts and officials are divided over how well they will work.

title: A NATION AT WAR: IN THE FIELD | 75th EXPLOITATION TASK FORCE; Smoking Gun Still Proves To Be Elusive for Searchers
description: A military team charged with hunting for Iraqi weapons of mass destruction returned from its first foray into southern Iraq Monday night, having found thousands of rounds of ammunition and tons of weapons, but not the smoking gun it was seeking.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Human Genome To Announce News On Healing Drug
description: Human Genome Sciences is expected to announce today that its wound-healing drug Repifermin protected chemotherapy recipients from painful mouth sores in a midstage clinical trial. A previous trial had been unsuccessful, casting doubt over the future of Repifermin, one of the first drugs discovered through genomics. ''We brought it back from the dead in this clinical trial,'' said William A. Haseltine, chief executive of Human Genome, the biotechnology company based in Rockville, Md. In the new trial, the drug was administered both before and after chemotherapy, while in the earlier trial it was administered only afterward. The sores caused by cancer chemotherapy, in what is known as mucositis, are so painful that some patients cannot eat. Andrew Pollack (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about efforts to put out oil well fires in Iraq reversed the names of a Texas company that is doing the work. It is Boots & Coots.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: CITIZENSHIP LAWS TIGHTENED British citizenship can be stripped from people with dual nationality who act in a way that is "seriously prejudicial" to the country's interests, the Home Office said, inaugurating a radical overhaul of citizenship, immigration and asylum laws. "If we are to welcome those that aspire to and qualify for British citizenship, we must also ensure that those who acquire it by deception or prove to be abusing the privilege of that citizenship by acting against the U.K.'s vital interests are not able to retain it," the home secretary, David Blunkett, said in a statement. In Parliament, a Labor minister called for the new powers to be used to deport Abu Hamza al-Masri, the Egyptian-born sheik who has become Britain's most notorious Muslim cleric because of his praise for Al Qaeda and Osama bin Laden and his outspoken criticism of Western foreign policy.   (Agence France-Presse)

But a good gin can be sustained by a surprisingly wide range of foods. Gin can be herbal and citrusy, and with its high alcohol content it begs for salty foods that have a little heft and fat.

title: BEST BUY SAYS PROFIT DROPPED 11% IN FOURTH QUARTER
description: Best Buy, the electronics retailer, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit fell 11 percent because of a loss at its mall-based stores. The company said first-quarter earnings would decline. Net income dropped to $311 million, or 96 cents a share, from $350 million, or $1.08 a share, a year earlier, the company said. Sales in the three months ended March 1 rose 11 percent, to $6.99 billion, after the company opened more stores. Earnings were hurt by a $67 million loss at its subsidiary Musicland, which it is trying to sell. Sales at its non-Musicland business rose after price reductions and no-interest financing enticed shoppers. Sales at its electronics stores open at least 14 months fell 3 percent in March as consumers stayed home to watch television coverage of the war in Iraq. Excluding Musicland, fourth-quarter profit was $1.16 a share. On that basis, analysts had expected $1.13, according to Thomson First Call. Best Buy is based in Eden Prairie, Minn.

title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: SMOKING BAN LINKED TO BIG DROP IN HEART ATTACKS Heart attacks in Helena, Mont., fell by more than half last summer after voters passed a broad indoor smoking ban, doctors are reporting. The doctors, who support the ban, acknowledged that the effects need to be demonstrated in a larger locale. Helena's smoking ban lasted six months, until enforcement was suspended after a legal challenge. It "led to an immediate and dramatic decline in the number of heart attacks we saw," said a local doctor, Richard Sargent. Heart attacks climbed back to their usual level after smoking returned, Dr. Sargent told a meeting of the American College of Cardiology in Chicago. (AP)

Steve gave encouragement and brought joy to all who knew him. He was full of love for his family, friends, the Torah, the Jewish people and the Amighty. He was a powerful advocate for the Jewish People and for Israel, and was a linchpin of Colel Chabad, which honored him with its Founders Award for his many years of dedicated work. title: Not the Kind of Planter To Roll Over in a Breeze
description: It's hard to think of concrete as a material that inspires passion -- until you talk to Phid Lawless of Lunaform, a company in Sullivan, Me., that makes concrete planters, urns and jars. From smallest to largest, the company's products are more like fine ceramics than they are like conventional cast concrete, or ''cast stone,'' a euphemism that Mr. Lawless disdains. He prefers words like ''noble'' for what he calls this ''remarkable medium,'' and Lunaform's Borghese urn (seen in the sheds at right, $3,700) bears him out. At four feet tall and 1,300 pounds, it is a true garden heavyweight. One in the Jane Watson Irwin Perennial Garden at the New York Botanical Garden has a terra-cotta finish, for an Italian classical look. Other choices -- like fieldstone and patinated bronze -- are also available.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: DIRECTV WINS DISMISSAL OF SUIT ON PIRACY LETTERS DirecTV, the nation's largest satellite television service, has won dismissal of a lawsuit filed by people who contended that the company accused them of piracy in letters and tried to extort money. Judge Charles W. McCoy Jr. of California Superior Court in Los Angeles ruled that DirecTV's letters were sent in connection with litigation, which is constitutionally protected speech. The letters were sent to people whose names turned up on invoices of raided companies as purchasers of piracy equipment. DirecTV, owned by the Hughes Electronics Corporation, has filed 2,000 federal lawsuits against people who failed to respond to the letters. The court action preserves DirecTV's ability to pursue a tactic it says it needs to protect its proprietary interests. Signal pirates cost DirecTV millions in revenue last year, the company says, and it cut off service to at least 50,000 viewers who were improperly receiving its programming. The court found sufficient evidence "to show DirecTV sent its demand letters in serious contemplation of litigation," Judge McCoy wrote in a four-page ruling dated Tuesday. "I guarantee this will be appealed," said Jeff Wilens, a lawyer for the letter recipients who sued the company.   (Bloomberg News)

title: Metro Briefing: New York

Meeting at Madison Square Garden, members of Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union said 28,000 building service workers were willing to strike unless they obtained a contract giving them substantial raises. The Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, which represents building owners and managers, said that negotiations were continuing and that a strike authorization vote did not necessarily mean that a walkout will occur. title: From the House, a Pulse
description: For those who were wondering whether Congress heard New York City's pleas for help in the fight against terror, the House of Representatives gave a promising answer this week. Its Republican-controlled appropriations panel voted to distribute $700 million to New York, Washington and other densely populated, vulnerable localities across the nation.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mitsubishi Recalls Vehicles
description: The Japanese automaker Mitsubishi will recall 305,351 cars, one-quarter of which are overseas, because of faulty brake hoses. The action will cost the company 5.22 billion yen ($44 million) and be paid from money already set aside. According to the Transport Ministry, the recall affects 223,702 RVR wagons and Chariot Grandis minivans sold in Japan and made from 1997 to February 2003. Another 62,100 Space Wagons sold in Europe will also be recalled. So far, no accidents have been reported. The company, which is 37 percent owned by DaimlerChrysler, recalled more than two million vehicles in 2000 and 2001.

Nevin knew instantly that Jeter had dislocated his shoulder. He could see Jeter's twisted shoulder and twisted face.

title: Adirondack Dreaming, Nothing Loud but the Color

And it comes in two styles -- with a round back, right, or the more familiar fan shape, left. The chairs ($385), made of mahogany, can be left outside in all weather. They are finished in a marine enamel, making them impervious to moisture.

title: Web Dial-Up Gains Speed, But at a Price
description: FOR those who are still in the Internet's slow lane, there are some new ways to step on the gas -- for a price. Much of the talk on the Internet is about high-speed, or broadband, service. But a majority of Internet users -- about three-quarters of households with Internet access -- have found broadband service too expensive or unavailable, and connect instead over phone lines at speeds that are only 5 percent to 10 percent as fast as a broadband connection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALVARY, HALLIE CARR
description: ALVARY-Hallie Carr. On March 29, 2003 at her home in New York City. Born October 2, 1900 in Moon Lake, Mississippi. Beloved and prized wife of the late Metropolitan Opera basso, Lorenzo Alvary and of industrialist Norman J. Fox of La Porte, Indiana. Mother of the late Joan Fox Walton. She is cherished in memory and survived by granddaughters: Alison Walton Macheras, Andrea Walton de Vogel of New York City and Barbe Walton Williams of South Bend, Indiana and by great grandsons: Mark Williams, Francois and Gustave Macheras, Alexander-Willem and Ligon deVogel. She will be remembered for her devotion to family and friends, her untiring work for the Service League, for the women's suffrage movement and as a forerunner in children's early education. A private interment will take place in La Porte, Indiana.

title: War News Gets Better
description: After bitter bickering over the adequacy of the invasion force and a delay caused by blinding sandstorms and attacks on the supply lines, the allied campaign in Iraq has finally begun moving again. Over the last two days American forces have scored some heartening successes. They do not guarantee a quick end to the war, but they did offer a hint of light at the end of the tunnel.

description: With United States troops closing on Baghdad, investors bid up stocks yesterday, sending markets worldwide strongly higher.

title: Another Peril of Home Video

If camcorders were as small as digital cameras, Sony reasons, people would carry them around everywhere.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Steel Maker's Shares Surge
description: A report that the Corus Group, a leading British metals producer, was talking to a potential buyer of some or all of its steel making plants set off a sharp rise in Corus's share price. According to the report, in The Financial Times, Corus was talking about the sale with the LNM Group of the steel maker Lakshmi Mittal. LNM may acquire one or more of Corus's most-efficient plants, the newspaper said, without citing any sources. Corus's shares rose 25 percent in response to the report.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BOSNIA: TOP SERB QUITS Mirko Sarovic, the Serbian chairman of Bosnia's tripartite presidency, resigned after being implicated in spying and arms-to-Iraq scandals. Mr. Sarovic, a member of the hard-line Srpska Democratic Party, quit just hours before he was to be fired by Paddy Ashdown, the former British politician who administers Bosnia under the 1995 Dayton agreement, which divided Bosnia into a Serb republic and a Muslim-Croat federation. Mr. Sarovic reportedly knew that Bosnian Serb military intelligence spied on NATO, the European Union police and others investigating war crimes in Bosnia. He was also accused of doing nothing to halt the sale and export by a local company of engine parts for Iraqi fighter jets in violation of the United Nations arms embargo. The multi-ethnic Bosnian Parliament is expected to meet soon to choose a successor from among its Serbian deputies. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Bank Bid Raised
description: DnB Holding, Norway's largest lender, raised its offer for a rival, Gjensidige NOR, by 9.6 percent, to 19.5 billion kroner ($2.7 billion), after shareholders threatened to scuttle the purchase. DnB will pay 43 kroner and 6.2 of its own shares per Gjensidige stock compared with a bid of 23 kroner and 6.2 shares in the original plan, DnB's chief executive, Svein Aaser, said. The initial offer valued Gjensidige, the No. 2 bank in Norway, at 17.8 billion kroner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, DR. ALAN STEVEN
description: GREENE-Dr. Alan Steven, 73. Loving husband of Joyce (Rosenthal). Devoted father of Sanford and Marie-France (Cyr); Roger; David and Jodi (Radzley). Proudest Grandfather of Samuel, Ella and Jake. Son of the late Herman and Jean. Founding partner of Froelich Greene, NYC. Earning his PhD from NYU in 1991, he was a member of the Board of Trustees of Temple Sholom in Cedar Grove; Board of Trustees of Green Brook Country Club, North Caldwell; Board of Trustees, Metropolitan Lithographers Association, NYC; and Planning Board and Board of Adjustment for the town of North Caldwell, NJ. Alan loved skiing, golf, flying, the opera, classical music, good food, old films, and new technology...but most of all he deeply loved his family and friends. Alan-Husband, Father, Grandfather, Friend, Mentor-will be missed, but the love and memories will always be with the people he touched. Funeral services will be held on Friday, April 4, 10:30 AM, at Temple Sholom of West Essex, 760 Pompton Avenue, Cedar Grove, NJ.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: DirecTV Wins Dismissal Of Suit On Piracy Letters
description: DirecTV, the nation's largest satellite television service, has won dismissal of a lawsuit filed by people who contended that the company accused them of piracy in letters and tried to extort money. Judge Charles W. McCoy Jr. of California Superior Court in Los Angeles ruled that DirecTV's letters were sent in connection with litigation, which is constitutionally protected speech. The letters were sent to people whose names turned up on invoices of raided companies as purchasers of piracy equipment. DirecTV, owned by the Hughes Electronics Corporation, has filed 2,000 federal lawsuits against people who failed to respond to the letters. The court action preserves DirecTV's ability to pursue a tactic it says it needs to protect its proprietary interests. Signal pirates cost DirecTV millions in revenue last year, the company says, and it cut off service to at least 50,000 viewers who were improperly receiving its programming. The court found sufficient evidence ''to show DirecTV sent its demand letters in serious contemplation of litigation,'' Judge McCoy wrote in a four-page ruling dated Tuesday. ''I guarantee this will be appealed,'' said Jeff Wilens, a lawyer for the letter recipients who sued the company.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Nicotine Patches On The House
description: Anyone in New York City who wants nicotine patches to quit smoking can get them free with a phone call, Health Commissioner Thomas R. Frieden announced yesterday. He said the city would send the six-week patch therapy kit to the first 35,000 people over 18 to call the state's telephone line for smokers who want help to stop, (866) NYQUITS, or (866) 697-8487. He called it ''a one-time offer,'' lasting until supplies run out. A two-week supply of patches sells for about $50. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

Services were held at the Goldstein Funeral Home in Edison, New Jersey. Donations can be made to the Alzheimers Foundation, or the General Israel Orphans Home for Girls.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drinking Laws To Be Tightened
description: Justice Minister Michael McDowell promised urgent new regulations to curb drunkenness and under-age drinking after a government commission reported that they are growing problems. The commission spent two years examining the pub trade, and its lengthy report carried 130 recommendations. Mr. McDowell said the new rules would allow pubs to bar entrance to anyone under 18 and might force pubs to close at 11:30 p.m. on Thursday, the standard work-week closing time, to address problems of people not turning up for work on Fridays. Other proposals favor encouraging the number of smaller bars owned by people who live on the premises, which he said, encourage ''moderate social consumption,'' rather that the ''superpubs'' of the 90's, which he said encourage binge drinking. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: U.S. and Europe Agree on U.N. Role in Iraq, but Split on Scope
description: BRUSSELS, April 3  The United States and its European allies reached what officials on both sides said was a broad consensus that the United Nations should play a significant role in the postwar reconstruction of Iraq, but remained divided over many of the details of how extensive that role should be.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Crackdown On Dissent
description: The authorities are seeking life sentences for 13 dissidents arrested in recent weeks on charges of subversion and conspiring with American diplomats, human rights advocates said. Among those expected to stand trial in the next few days is Hctor Palacios, a former political prisoner who is among the top organizers of the Varela Project, which seeks democratic reforms. Marta Beatriz Roque, an economist and former political prisoner who was the host of an event at her home attended by James Cason, the chief United States diplomat in Havana, is also reported to be facing a life sentence. Cuban human rights advocates said nearly 80 people, including journalists, librarians and opposition activists, have been arrested in the recent crackdown, which has been condemned by many rights groups. David Gonzalez (NYT)

Sisk, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, joins all the Bishops, the Dean, clergy and people of the Diocese in mourning the death of our beloved Retired Bishop Suffragan Walter Decoster Dennis. We will miss his guidance, pastoral counseling and wisdom. We thank God for his service to the Diocese & the Cathedral. Memorial service will be held at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on April 9th at 10:30 A.M.

In this soothing comedy from Czechoslovakia, directed by Vladimir Michalek from a screenplay by Jiri Hubac, breaking the rules means racking up expensive restaurant bills, staging madcap pranks and impersonating others.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Date Set For Bus Agreement
description: The city and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that by the end of June they planned to complete an agreement for the authority to take over bus services now provided by seven privately operated lines. Together, the private lines run about 1,325 buses and carry 114 million passengers a year in Queens, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Manhattan, making them the ninth-largest transit bus fleet in North America. But the private lines receive about $98 million a year in city subsidies, which Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has said the city can no longer afford. Randy Kennedy (NYT)

title: Getting Satisfaction, Even in Minor Events
description: At the Spring Nationals in Philadelphia last month, thousands of players competed in hundreds of minor events. Some stuck to one partner throughout, while others switched happily from one to another. A curious record in this respect was set by Todd Thorsen of Lititz, Pa., who played in five events with five partners, all of them relatives. He played with his wife, his mother-in-law, his father-in-law, a sister-in-law and a brother-in-law. He would have been willing to play with his son and his daughter, both of whom are players, but they are not quite ready, at 11 and 8, for tournaments.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: CONGO: ACCORD SIGNED The government signed a peace agreement with rebel groups in a bid to end a four-and-a-half-year civil war. The agreements, signed in Sun City, South Africa, will see President Joseph Kabila remain as head of state during a transition of two years, extendable to three, leading to the first democratic elections since those on independence from Belgium in 1960. He will share power with four vice presidents; one from each of the two main rebel movements, one from the government and one from the opposition.    (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ARTHUR
description: GOLDBERG - Arthur, 74, passed away peacefully on April 2, 2003, in the comfort of his home in Monroe Township, N.J. A proud & devoted husband, father and grandfather, Arthur is survived by Helen, his loving wife of 44 years. He will be dearly missed by his loving children Lynne & her husband Elliot, Steve and his wife Janice, Ken and his wife Vicky; his wonderful grandchildren Danielle, Ethan, Lauren, Allison, Alyssa, and Jillian, of whom he was so proud; and his brothers Sidney and Ralph and their families. Arthur was born in The Bronx, N.Y. and subsequently resided with his family in Miami, FL., and Union, Westfield and Springfield, N.J. He was a avid Yankees fan all his life. Arthur received a Bachelor's degree in Business Administration from the University of Miami in Coral Gables, FL., served in the Armed Forces and was a dedicated District Sales Manager of the Gerber Company for over 25 years. Funeral services will be held on April 3 at 11:30AM at Menorah Chapel, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, N.J. (phone 908964-1500). Interment will be at the New Montefiore Cemetery in Pinelawn, N.Y. Contributions in memory of Arthur may be made to the Society for Progressive Supranuclear Palsy by calling 800-457-4777 or visiting www.psp.org.

title: Senators See Bill for War Payment as Way to Push Pet Projects
description: The bombs are falling on Iraq, and the Pentagon says it is eight weeks from running out of money for the war. But today, as the Senate began debating the bill to pay for the conflict, lawmakers were unable to resist trying to attach pet projects.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trader Cuts Profit Forecast
description: The trading company Sumitomo Corporation cut its profit forecast for the full year by almost half because of greater-than-expected losses on its stockholdings. Sumitomo expects to earn 28 billion yen ($235 million) in the year that ended Monday, or 49 percent less than previously anticipated. The company said the value of its stock holdings was hurt the most by the falling value of bank stocks. A leading index of Japanese bank stocks, the Topix banks index, fell by one-third in the year that ended on Monday. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: NOW that I've turned a hayloft into a house on the farm here, the garden I've carried around in my mind for so long has finally flown in for a landing.

title: A New Underground at Carnegie, in More Ways Than One
description: The first season of Carnegie Hall's new $100 million underground stage will include concerts ranging from Afro-Cuban music to avant-garde multimedia productions to jazz, the hall announced yesterday.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Everglades Water Plan
description: A scientific panel, in a study requested by the Interior Department, concluded that an ambitious federal plan to restore natural water flows to the Everglades needed to be more carefully integrated with monitoring of the ailing ecosystem. Otherwise, it will be impossible to determine if the billions of dollars that will be spent to store excess summer rainwater and supply it to the Everglades in dry times is having a beneficial effect. The plan also needs to account more carefully for rising sea levels and other changes brought on by global warming, said the panel, which was convened by the National Academies. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Russian Muslims Split on a Call for Holy War Against U.S.
description: MOSCOW, April 3  The two top leaders of Russia's estimated 14 million Muslims split today over the question of whether to proclaim a jihad against the United States in retaliation against the invasion of Iraq.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Detective Suspended
description: A police detective has been suspended from duty after a prisoner escaped from an East Harlem station house, the second such incident in Upper Manhattan in two days, the police said. The detective, Ryan Dean, assigned to the Manhattan North Narcotics Initiative, was suspended Tuesday night. The prisoner, Nyisha Jones, 23, who had been arrested on drug charges, escaped from the 25th Precinct station house earlier that day, about 12:40 p.m. Ms. Jones, who slipped out of her handcuffs, was arrested a short time later several blocks away, the police said. A detective was suspended from duty Monday after a prisoner escaped from the 32nd Precinct station house in Central Harlem, the police said. That suspect, arrested on drug charges, remains at large, the police said. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: No French, No Job
description: The federal government announced that an estimated 200 senior bureaucrats who have failed to become sufficiently bilingual in French and English face transfer, demotion or dismissal. Against a March 31 deadline, thousands of federal employees have taken French classes in recent months to improve their proficiency, with a large majority succeeding, in what is a continuing effort to make the government fully bilingual. title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Trooper Shoots Driver
description: A state trooper shot a driver on the New Jersey Turnpike yesterday after the driver's vehicle struck the trooper, the authorities said. The state police said the 46-year-old driver, a Toms River man whose name was not immediately released, was taken to the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Newark. The driver was shot at least twice, in his upper body, and was listed in stable condition last night. The trooper, Mark Kepenis, suffered cuts and bruises. The shooting occurred about 1:30 p.m. near the Exit 15-E toll plaza in Essex County. Trooper Kepenis saw the motorist driving a black 2002 Mercedes-Benz ''in an unsafe manner'' and pulled the car over, the police said. As the trooper walked toward the car, it pulled away, striking him. Trooper Kepenis then fired his 9-millimeter service revolver, officials said. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

Either a new relationship is being created or an existing relationship is being tested. In the first, you have antagonists coming to an understanding (or not), a seemingly ill-suited man and woman falling in love (or not), reluctant allies growing on each other (or not): ''The Zoo Story,'' ''Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune,'' ''Oleanna.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDES, MILO

Grandfather of David, Brian and Elizabeth. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Friday April 4, 2-5 and 6-8 PM & Sat., April 5, 11-1 PM.

title: LINEN SUPPLIER AGREES TO BE SOLD FOR $112 MILLION
description: National Service Industries, which rents linens to hotels and restaurants, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by an investment firm for $112 million and be taken private. The California Investment Fund, based in San Diego, will pay $10 for each common share, National Service said. The price is almost double the closing share price on Tuesday of $5.20. National Service, which is based in Atlanta, said it had 11.2 million shares outstanding at the end of the second quarter. The company's chief financial officer, Chester J. Popkowski, said employees would keep their salaries and benefits.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Interest Rate Unchanged
description: The Central Bank of Australia left official interest rates unchanged at 4.75 percent in a decision reflecting caution about global economic prospects. It was the 10th consecutive month that the central bank has left the rate alone. Australian current economic annual growth of 3 percent is the strongest among developed nations, but exports, which account for about 20 percent of the gross domestic product, are declining because of weakening economies elsewhere and the impact of a prolonged drought at home. John Shaw (NYT)

title: A Pesky Vine, Perhaps, But Beautiful if Turned Into a Garden Bench
description: A tangle of invasive Oriental bittersweet vines can turn, in Laura Spector's hands, into a charmingly rustic bench, chair or arbor. ''There is no predator of the vine, and people invite me to remove it from their gardens,'' she said.

description: DUDA-Janina (Nina). A nurturing, caring and selfless woman who enriched the lives of all who knew her. A survivor of the Warsaw uprising and a prisoner of war liberated by the U.S. Army. Devoted mother of Halina and maternal caretaker of the extended Robinowitz family including Stuart and Anne, their children and grandchildren for more than half a century. Visitation at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery Chapel, Rt. 9, Sleepy Hollow, NY on April 4 at 10 A.M., services at 11 A.M. Contributions may be made to: Holocaust Museum in Washington, D.C. or the White Plains Hospital Dickstein Cancer Center.

title: Corrections

Martin, former general counsel of the Immigration and Naturalization Service. While he said that temporary detention of asylum seekers from certain countries was defensible in wartime, he opposes discouraging such people from seeking asylum.

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: COLORADO: NO TRANSIT STRIKE Union leaders and transit officials in Denver averted a strike when they reached a tentative agreement for 1,900 bus drivers, mechanics and light rail operators. The Regional Transportation District serves 250,000 passengers daily in a seven-county area around Denver, and a strike would have shut two-thirds of the bus routes and all rail lines. Under the agreement, which is subject to ratification, union members would pay more health care premiums and have wages frozen. Union members would keep two holidays and grievance policies.    Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Europe Inquiry On French Aid To Big Utility
description: The European Commission opened an investigation today into the French government's financial safeguards for its energy company Electricit de France, asserting that the loan guarantees and immunity from bankruptcy it grants to the company amount to illegal state aid.

title: Oil Prices Off on War News And Increase in U.S. Supply
description: The price of oil fell 4 percent yesterday, as traders took heart that supplies might be growing soon because of the recent progress of coalition forces in Iraq and increases in oil supplies in the United States.

description: The law firm of Pillsbury Winthrop settled a case against it yesterday that had been brought by one of its former partners, Frode Jensen.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Doormen Authorize Strike
description: Thousands of janitors, doormen and other building workers voted overwhelmingly last night to authorize a strike on April 21 at 3,000 buildings in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens if no contract agreement is reached by then. Meeting at Madison Square Garden, members of Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union said 28,000 building service workers were willing to strike unless they obtained a contract giving them substantial raises. The Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, which represents building owners and managers, said that negotiations were continuing and that a strike authorization vote did not necessarily mean that a walkout will occur. The management group said it cannot offer large raises because of the weak real estate market and fast-rising property taxes and fuel costs. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: FORMER COMPUTER EXECUTIVE IS NEW KODAK PRESIDENT
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it had named a former Hewlett-Packard Company executive, Antonio Perez, its president and chief operating officer. Mr. Perez, 57, spent 25 years at Hewlett-Packard and headed its consumer and digital media business, Kodak said. He will take over his new posts from the chairman and chief executive, Daniel Carp. Mr. Perez will work to persuade consumers to print more digital pictures, Kodak said. Kodak has suffered from a three-year drop in sales because people are switching to digital cameras and developing fewer of those pictures. Kodak also said that Martin Coyne, head of its photography business, plans to retire.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: REBUFF FOR LAWMAKER ON ESTATE A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit filed by Representative Katherine Harris, left, and two siblings in a battle with fellow heirs over her grandfather's multimillion-dollar estate. Judge Robert Hinkle of Federal District Court ruled on Monday that the court lacked jurisdiction because a state court had already decided that no fraud occurred in the March 2002 settlement of the estate of the citrus and cattle baron Ben Hill Griffin Jr. In the suit, Ms. Harris, Fran Harris King and George Harris III accused their first cousin, State Senator J. D. Alexander, his father, John Alexander, and their uncle, Ben Hill Griffin III, of inflating stock values, among other things. (AP)

title: MONSANTO SAYS FIRST-QUARTER PROFIT TOPPED FORECAST
description: The Monsanto Company said first-quarter profit was higher than forecast as sales in Brazil increased and some costs declined. The company did not provide specific figures. Monsanto cut selling and manufacturing costs, and sales of its weed killer Roundup were better than anticipated in Brazil. The company had losses or profit declines the previous five quarters amid the loss of a patent for Roundup, its top-selling product, and competition from generic rivals. Kerry Preete, vice president for United States markets, said at a conference of analysts in New York that the company expected to earn as much as 20 percent of its 2003 profit in the first quarter, up from its previous estimate of 10 percent.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: Arrests Under Megan's Law
description: Twenty-three convicted sex offenders were arrested yesterday and accused of failing to comply with Megan's Law, said John L. Molinelli, the Bergen County prosecutor. They face up to 18 months in jail if convicted. Mr. Molinelli said his office had identified 31 sex offenders who had violated the law, either by failing to reregister with their local police department or by failing to notify the authorities of a change in address. Two were tracked as far as Florida and arrested; eight are still fugitives. The law is named for Megan Kanka, 7, of Hamilton, who was killed in 1994 by a neighbor who was a convicted sex offender. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: NEW HAVEN: VICTIM'S FAMILY APPEALS TO PUBLIC The parents and uncle of a 12-year-old boy killed in a hit-and-run accident urged witnesses yesterday to contact the police. Relatives of the boy, Christopher Norton-Velez, also offered a reward for information leading to the arrest of the driver. Christopher was at the intersection of Ferry and Clay Streets about 8 p.m. Saturday when he was hit. Witnesses said the driver hit Christopher, got out of his car to look at him, then drove away. Anyone with information can call the confidential police tips line at (866) 888-TIPS. (AP)

title: Lloyd's of London, the Insurer, Reports First Profit in Six Years
description: Lloyd's of London, the international insurance market, yesterday reported its first profit in six years, reflecting a surge in insurance prices since the Sept. 11 attacks and a sharp decline in the organization's payments for claims.

title: In Search of a Family Home on the Road
description: MY husband is a very delicate sleeper. Every night he lies down on a firm mattress in a dark room on a quiet street in a peaceful town and falls into a deep sleep. Then at 2 a.m. he wakes, runs to the window and peers out. ''What's that noise?'' he demands. ''A cricket,'' I say. ''Three blocks over.''

description: The objectives of the battle for Baghdad will be a microcosm of the war itself: destroy the forces that support President Saddam Hussein, avoid civilian casualties, limit damage to civilian infrastructure and provide aid.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: NORWAY: BANK BID RAISED DnB Holding, Norway's largest lender, raised its offer for a rival, Gjensidige NOR, by 9.6 percent, to 19.5 billion kroner ($2.7 billion), after shareholders threatened to scuttle the purchase. DnB will pay 43 kroner and 6.2 of its own shares per Gjensidige stock compared with a bid of 23 kroner and 6.2 shares in the original plan, DnB's chief executive, Svein Aaser, said. The initial offer valued Gjensidige, the No. 2 bank in Norway, at 17.8 billion kroner.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: WebEx Lowers Forecasts On Sales And Profits
description: Web-Ex Communications, a provider of video-conferencing services, said yesterday that profit and sales this year would be lower than it forecast, as fewer subscribers pay to use the Internet to hold meetings. Earnings in 2003, excluding compensation expenses, will be 45 cents to 50 cents a share, down from an earlier forecast of 50 cents to 55 cents. Sales will be $180 million to $190 million, down from its earlier forecast of $200 million, WebEx said. Last year, the company earned 39 cents a share on sales of $139.9 million. The chief executive, Subrah S. Iyar, blamed lower subscription contracts and nonrecurring sales this year for lower profit and revenue as companies curb spending. First-quarter profit, excluding some expenses, was about 11 cents a share, according to preliminary data, the company said. That would match the average estimate of eight analysts polled by Thomson Financial. The company had about $42 million in sales for the period. A year earlier, WebEx earned 3 cents a share on $33.2 million in sales. Its shares fell 43 cents, to $8.82.

Someone with a new perspective often sees what is invisible to me. I call this fresh addition to my two eyes ''the third eye,'' and I welcome observations from the outside to help with my garden. So every spring, I plan for a visit from the third eye.

description: At least 16 people were killed today when a bomb exploded near a ferry terminal in the southern Philippines, where the government is fighting Muslim separatist rebels.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Singapore: On Second Thought
description: A 17-year-old boy was sentenced to 14 years in prison and 24 lashes with a rattan cane for stealing mobile telephones from schoolchildren. The boy, Jerriek Chen Weixiong, had appealed a sentence of nine and a half years. Instead, Chief Justice Yong Pung How increased it, telling the defense lawyer, ''In the public interest we lock them away so that you, your partners, more important your family, your children, can walk along Orchard Road even at night without harassment.'' Orchard Road is the main shopping street in the sternly disciplined city-state. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Oakdale: Boy Killed After Playing With Gun
description: A 14-year-old Suffolk County boy was killed yesterday after a gun that he and a friend had been playing with discharged, the police said. The boy, Anthony Vazquez, was at his home in Oakdale with another 14-year-old boy, whose identity was not disclosed, when the shooting took place about 2:30 p.m., the Suffolk police said. They said both boys had been holding the gun to pose for a picture when the friend pulled the trigger, apparently assuming that the gun was not loaded. The bullet struck Anthony in the head. Anthony's friend was charged with manslaughter because his behavior was reckless, the police said. The handgun belonged to Anthony's father, Officer Jose Vazquez of the New York City police, who was not at home when the shooting occurred, the authorities said. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Boston Archdiocese Is Sued By San Bernardino Diocese

While he discussed several possible outcomes, including a moratorium on payments, he said that a debt swap or voluntary restructuring, similar to one in June 2001, was more likely.

title: Bribery Scandal Threatens Poland's Bid to Join European Union
description: Poland's embattled leftist prime minister, Leszek Miller, said yesterday that he would call for early general elections amid growing suspicions about his role in a political corruption scandal. His announcement comes in the same week that two more cabinet ministers fled his government, and just ahead of a crucial referendum on Poland's entry into the European Union.

title: Reclaiming Disk Space From 'Temporary' Files
description: Q. What are temp files? I thought they were just unneeded files, but when I tried to delete them from my Windows 98 system I got a message saying that one of them was in use.

title: With $7 Million in Donations, Kerry Trails Democratic Rival
description: Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts said today that he had raised $7 million during the first three months of the year in his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination, falling short of the $7.4 million taken in by Senator John Edwards of North Carolina.

title: 2 Officers and Cabby Shot in New Jersey; Suspect Is Killed
description: Two law enforcement officers were shot and a suspect was killed last night during a crime spree through Hoboken and Jersey City that involved the shooting of a cab driver, a carjacking at gunpoint, and two shootouts, the authorities said.

title: That Championship Season, in Code
description: YANG YIN, a 21-year-old computer student from China, was fidgety, slightly bewildered, it seemed, by his surroundings. Sitting alone at a computer, one of dozens in the cavernous and opulent Beverly Hilton ballroom, he was working on some code, just flexing his brain a bit to relax and prepare for the next morning's competition. ''The U.S. is very clean,'' he said in response to a reporter's question about how he liked it here. ''But the California sun is too shiny.''

title: Casualties
description: Announced military casualties in the Iraq war zone as of 5 p.m. eastern time Wednesday:

description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Season Seems Lost, but Houston Won't Stop Nagging Knicks
description: DENVER, April 2 - Days after Antonio McDyess's season-ending knee injury in October, Allan Houston dared to say that the Knicks could still make the playoffs. Moments after an embarrassing loss to Detroit in January, Houston challenged his teammates to improve, and the Knicks won five of their next six games.

title: A Catalog Entrepreneur Takes the New York Test
description: THE topic at Rob Forbes's penthouse on Russian Hill here was supposed to be furniture: to be exact, how Mr. Forbes was planning to fill his converted ballroom atop a building from the 1920's. Given Mr. Forbes's credentials -- he is founder of Design Within Reach, the Internet and catalog retailer of modern furniture whose first New York outlet opened on Saturday -- it seemed reasonable to expect that he might turn his 2,200-square-foot apartment, bought at the end of last year, into a high-design laboratory.

title: Blair Says Hussein Plans to Blame Allies for Desecration
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair charged today that Saddam Hussein planned to harm Muslim shrines in Iraq and pin responsibility for the desecration on allied troops. Mr. Blair delivered his warning to the British Parliament, but the real addressees of his message, he indicated, were Muslims around the world.

title: Swift Rescue Boosts Morale At Unit's Base
description: The war in Iraq has turned into a dreadful waiting game for the families of the missing members of the 507th Ordnance Maintenance Company that trained at this military base stretched out over an area of rugged desert larger than Rhode Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTEIN, HILDA K.
description: GERSTEIN-Hilda K. The Board of Directors and Staff of The Breast Cancer Research Foundation mourn the death of Hilda K. Gerstein. We extend most sincere condolences to her daughter, Nancy Novogrod, esteemed member of our Advisory Board, and to her entire family. Evelyn H. Lauder, Founder and Chairman Myra J. Bidlowit, President

title: Peabody Award Winners
description: Multiple citations for HBO, National Public Radio and ABC's ''Nightline'' were among the 62nd Annual George Foster Peabody Awards announced yesterday. The prizes, which are administered by the Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication at the University of Georgia, are for television and radio productions.

title: Crystals to Help a Rose Stay Happy for a Week
description: For years gardeners have added polymer crystals to soil, where they absorb and slowly release water. Now event designers have begun using hydrated crystals for displays. Bill Kocis, of Bill Kocis Important Flowers, 155 Prince Street (West Broadway), (212) 254-7770, calls the stuff ''swell gel.'' ''Everybody wants to know what it is,'' he said. ''It almost feels like rubber with water in it.'' He rests roses in it, as at right, where they last a week or more, or suspends flowers in giant pillars of the gel, which is often mistaken for crushed ice. The crystals, which are nontoxic and biodegradable, are sold as Plant Gel, $3.95 for a one-ounce bag (enough to make a gallon), at www.seedman.com. Gardeners can buy a one-pound box for $4.95 at www.hydrosource.com. (Caveat: do not drop the crystals down a drain). LINDA LEE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEXLER, SYLVIA
description: WEXLER-Sylvia. The Members and entire personnel of Herzfeld & Rubin, P.C. express our heartfelt condolences to our esteemed Partner, Howard Wexler, his brother Gary and sister Linsey Miller, on the passing of their beloved mother on March 28. Herbert Rubin Herzfeld & Rubin, P.C.

title: With Sosa Falling a Bit Short, the Mets Don't
description: Sammy Sosa's body recoiled from the force of his swing in the sixth inning last night and he hopped out of the batter's box, the way he always does when he hits a home run. Sosa bounced once more as the chin of Mets pitcher Al Leiter tilted upward, in the direction of the baseball that climbed toward the left-field fence at Shea Stadium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCK, DAVID
description: GLUCK-David. On March 31, 2003 at the age of 55. Father of Sofi, son of Eleanor and the late Irvin, brother of Kathy and Andrew Berkman and uncle of Emily and David Harris, their daughter Ella, and Benjamin Berkman. A memorial service will be held at the Cornell Cinema in Willard Straight Hall, Ithaca, N.Y.. on April 3 at 10 AM. David's mother will receive guests in Great Neck, on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, and his sister will receive guests at her home on April 8, from 7 to 9PM.

title: Industry Says Decision Won't Set Back Managed Care
description: Insurance industry officials said yesterday that they would not let a Supreme Court decision on health plans hobble managed care, but some industry experts said the ruling was part of trend that is shrinking the role of insurers.

title: Columbia Job Entices Bobby Hurley
description: Bobby Hurley won two national championships as a point guard for Duke, played in the N.B.A. before a car accident slowed his career and then became a successful owner of race horses. Why would he be interested in coaching Columbia's basketball team, which did not win a game in the Ivy League this season?

title: A NATION AT WAR: IN THE FIELD | 101st AIRBORNE; A Bridgehead, and a Thirsty Welcome
description: In the giddy spirit of the day, nothing could quite top the wish list bellowed out by one man in the throng of people greeting American troops from the 101st Airborne Division who marched into town today.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: HACKENSACK: ARRESTS UNDER MEGAN'S LAW Twenty-three convicted sex offenders were arrested yesterday and accused of failing to comply with Megan's Law, said John L. Molinelli, the Bergen County prosecutor. They face up to 18 months in jail if convicted. Mr. Molinelli said his office had identified 31 sex offenders who had violated the law, either by failing to reregister with their local police department or by failing to notify the authorities of a change in address. Two were tracked as far as Florida and arrested; eight are still fugitives. The law is named for Megan Kanka, 7, of Hamilton, who was killed in 1994 by a neighbor who was a convicted sex offender. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: PC Gamers; The Windows Version, at Your Fingertips
description: Renting games at the local store is common practice for owners of game consoles but a rarity for PC gamers. While you still cannot go to a Blockbuster store for a PC version of Civilization III, users with a broadband Internet connection running Windows can rent that game and others from Yahoo's Games on Demand service (gamesondemand.yahoo.com).

title: Circling Protectively Above New York City
description: Looking straight up from the Midtown pavement, New York City seems like a fortress of granite, so solid and secure. But looking straight down at the city from 1,000 feet above, the metropolis seems almost naked in its majesty. Every landmark -- the Empire State Building, the Chrysler Building, the Statue of Liberty -- looks as though it could be molded not with concrete but with marzipan. That impression of vulnerability is, in a way, the reason for the aircraft providing this view of the city yesterday: a Black Hawk helicopter, whose pilot could have been talking about wartime when he assured the passengers that ''the vibration is normal.''

title: China Takes Issue With Health Group's Travel Warning
description: HONG KONG, April 3  As more suspected cases of a deadly respiratory disease were reported around the world today, China and the World Health Organization traded barbs over a travel warning placed on Hong Kong and the southern Chinese province of Guangdong.

title: News Media Access Brings Chorus of Criticism and Queries
description: When the Pentagon's top brass denounced critics of the war strategy on Tuesday at a news conference, Victoria Clarke, the Pentagon spokeswoman, was just as stunned as the reporters in the room -- and the wider television audience.

title: Attack From 2 Sides Shatters the Iraqi Republican Guard
description: KUWAIT, April 3  In a sweeping advance, Army and Marine forces raced to the outskirts of Baghdad today after crippling or destroying two divisions of the Republican Guard that had blocked their drive on the capital.

title: U.S. Ground Forces Sweep Toward Baghdad
description: KUWAIT, April 2  In a sweeping advance, Army and Marine forces closed to within 20 miles of Baghdad from two directions today after crippling or destroying two divisions of the Republican Guard that had blocked their drive on the capital.

title: 13 Arrested At Girls' Home After a Prank Turns Violent
description: A counselor and two police officers were slightly injured after an April Fool's prank at a school for troubled teenage girls erupted into fighting Tuesday night, the police said.

title: From Tourism to High Finance, Mysterious Illness Spreads Havoc
description: As the highly contagious respiratory disease that began in China continues to spread, its impact on business activity is stretching from Hong Kong around the globe, disrupting complex supply chains and forcing industries from airlines to banking to adjust their operations.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: METROLOGIC RAISES EARNINGS ESTIMATE Metrologic In- struments raised its first-quarter earnings estimate yesterday, saying that more retailers were upgrading checkout and inventory-management systems and the weak dollar padded international sales. After the announcement, stock of the company, a bar code maker, shot up nearly 30 percent to its highest in more than two years, before closing up nearly 25 percent as the No. 5 percentage gainer on Nasdaq. Metrologic said it now expected to report first-quarter net income of 30 cents a share, up 5 cents from the previously estimated 25 cents a share. It earned $22,000, or break even on a per share basis, a year earlier. Metrologic said sales for the quarter increased 16 percent, to $32 million, about 7 percent above its earlier estimate of $30 million in sales. Metrologic said stronger sales were driven by demand for bar code scanners and other products, mostly in Europe and America. Metrologic said its first-quarter results were helped by the euro's big run-up this year. As of March 31, when Metrologic's quarter ended, the euro had gained 25 percent against the dollar from the year before. Metrologic shares rose $2.65, or 24.8 percent, to $13.35.   ( Reuters )

title: For Isles, One Goal: 2 Points In 3 Games
description: The Islanders never seem to do things the easy way. They needed a victory over the Rangers on Tuesday to make the playoffs but lost a two-goal lead in the third period and settled for a tie that really did not settle much of anything.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia: Top Serb Quits
description: Mirko Sarovic, the Serbian chairman of Bosnia's tripartite presidency, resigned after being implicated in spying and arms-to-Iraq scandals. Mr. Sarovic, a member of the hard-line Srpska Democratic Party, quit just hours before he was to be fired by Paddy Ashdown, the former British politician who administers Bosnia under the 1995 Dayton agreement, which divided Bosnia into a Serb republic and a Muslim-Croat federation. Mr. Sarovic reportedly knew that Bosnian Serb military intelligence spied on NATO, the European Union police and others investigating war crimes in Bosnia. He was also accused of doing nothing to halt the sale and export by a local company of engine parts for Iraqi fighter jets in violation of the United Nations arms embargo. The multi-ethnic Bosnian Parliament is expected to meet soon to choose a successor from among its Serbian deputies. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: 65 and Just Itching for a Little Convergence
description: In the uncertain and rocky world of media conglomeration, Nobuyuki Idei, the chairman of Sony, is an undaunted preacher for convergence in music, movies, games and communications in all forms.

title: Doomsday Budget
description: For months Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who prides himself on his salesmanship, has used the soft sell when it comes to Albany.

title: Thin Work Force of North Dakota Gets Thinner as Residents Go Off to War
description: As the National Guard and reserves mobilized, North Dakota State University had 95 students called to duty. The Sherwin Williams paint store in Bismarck had four out of its five employees deployed. The Bobcat factory in Gwinner, population 700, lost 14 employees. Hillsboro lost half its police force.
