title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about former military officers whose statements about strategy have irritated the Pentagon gave a misspelled surname in some copies for a retired general who is a news analyst for NBC News. He is Barry McCaffrey, not McCaffery.

title: Crushing Iraqi Units, Daring Rescue and the Saddam Hussein Mystery
description: Army and Marine forces attacking from different directions shattered two Iraqi Republican Guard units before advancing to within 25 miles of the capital, Baghdad. Those divisions are "no longer credible forces," Maj. Gen. Stanley McChrystal said at a Pentagon briefing.

title: Tell a Story in Pictures, And the Palmtop Unlocks
description: For help in developing a password protection system for hand-held computers, Pointsec Mobile Technologies turned to an unexpected resource: teachers of children with learning disabilities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIRSHEIN, MICHAEL
description: FIRSHEIN-Michael. Beloved husband of Sylvia for 56 years. Extraordinary and loving father of Dr. Steven, Dr. Dan (Joy) and Dr. Richard. Dear grandfather to Dylan, Brittnay, Meredith, Jessica, Shannon and Jenna. All who knew him were inspired by his strength and kindness. He was devoted to many Jewish causes and support of Israel. He will be deeply missed. Services will be held at the Castle Hill Funeral Home, 1528 Castle Hill Avenue, Bronx, Thursday, April 3, at 1 PM. Donations can be made in his name to American Red Magen David, 888 7th Ave, Rm 403, NY, NY 10126.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: TRADER CUTS PROFIT FORECAST The trading com- pany Sumitomo Corporation cut its profit forecast for the full year by almost half because of greater-than-expected losses on its stockholdings. Sumitomo expects to earn 28 billion yen ($235 million) in the year that ended Monday, or 49 percent less than previously anticipated. The company said the value of its stock holdings was hurt the most by the falling value of bank stocks. A leading index of Japanese bank stocks, the Topix banks index, fell by one-third in the year that ended on Monday. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Tie a Yellow Ribbon and Watch the Fur Fly in a New Jersey Town
description: It began as a thimble-size dispute in the tiny South Jersey town of Fieldsboro, which ordered last week that some ribbons be removed from a sign welcoming drivers to the borough of 522 people.

title: Pathmark Has Profit In Fourth Quarter
description: Pathmark Stores Inc., the Northeastern supermarket chain, reported a fourth-quarter profit of $7.9 million yesterday on reduced costs, and said it planned to cut as many as 50 administrative jobs at headquarters.

title: Fighting at Baghdad Airport, and Iraqi Capital Goes Dark
description: KUWAIT, April 3  Moving swiftly through the suburbs of Baghdad, American forces launched an attack today on the capital's main international airport, less than 10 miles from the city.

title: Cairo, Once 'the Scene,' Cracks Down on Gays
description: In the late 1990's, word was spreading through the gay grapevine in Egypt, and even through some nearby Middle Eastern countries, that this hectic and vibrant city on the Nile was the place to be.

title: Mortgage Applications Fall
description: Applications for mortgages fell for a second consecutive week as refinancing slumped and purchase requests slowed, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANRICH, GEORGE
description: KANRICH-George. On April 2, 2003, cherished husband for 59 years of Margaret, loving father of Dorothy Sandford (Scott), adored grandfather of Nina Roa (Adam) and David Sandford, beloved greatgrandfather of Jamie and Jonathan Roa. Brother of Ruth Besser and the late Nathan, Julius, Joseph and Ernest Kanrich. Services Friday at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. For information call Levine Memorial Chapels, 800-427-0280.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Accounting Expansion
description: KPMG International has formed the biggest accounting firm in Japan with the addition of Asahi & Company, a former unit of Andersen Worldwide, KPMG said. Asahi joined KPMG's existing business in Japan on April 1 to form AZSA & Company, which has annual revenue of about $500 million, Gavin Houlgate, a KPMG spokesman, said.

title: Council Reassesses the Cost of Not Recycling
description: Nine months after New York City suspended the recycling of glass and plastics to save money, the city comptroller and several City Council members charged yesterday that the city would not save close to the $40 million the Bloomberg administration had projected.

title: What's in a Name? Royalties, If the Mayor Has His Way
description: There are some New Yorkers who may not realize that under the Bloomberg administration, their city is no longer simply a municipality, but also a brand.

description: The Martian NetDrive Wireless sounds as if it might be a device capable of connecting you with extraterrestrial neighbors. Its reach is not quite that far, but it does allow people who are not in the same room to share data.

Mrs. Diener and her late husband Leonard were longstanding supporters and beloved leaders of Israel Bonds and the local community. Mrs. Diener's dedicated efforts on behalf of Israel and the Jewish people will long be remembered. Our heartfelt condolences to her children: Marjorie, Larry and Adele, and the entire family. description: Nine people were found tortured and killed outside the border city of Nuevo Laredo today in what officials say is a continuing struggle over control of one of Mexico's biggest cocaine cartels.

description: With little resistance in Karbala, U.S. troops came within 20 miles of Baghdad.

title: A Space Reborn, With a Show That's Never Finished
description: Curatorial correctness has never carried much weight at Exit Art, the venerable SoHo alternative space that has now relocated to new Manhattan quarters on 10th Avenue, at 36th Street. Jeanette Ingberman and Papo Colo established it in their Canal Street loft in 1982 with the intention of doing things differently.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Reuters Rating Lowered
description: The long-term credit rating of the Reuters Group, the news and information provider, was lowered one level by Standard & Poor's on concern a cost-cutting plan may hurt revenue. Reuters, which is based in London, said in February that it planned to cut 3,000 jobs by 2006 because of a slump in the global finance services industry. Standard & Poor's warned in February that it might lower the rating but said yesterday that the rating was now stable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRKEL, STEPHEN
description: KIRKEL-Stephen. Beloved and loving husband of Adele (nee Gillman). Adored and loving father of Janice and Peter. Service today, 11:30 AM at Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mt Vernon, NY.

title: Squeezed, a Jewelry Designer Closes Shop
description: Angela Cummings is taking her diamonds and going home.

title: National Briefing | West: California: More Time For Child Abuse Cases
description: Gov. Gray Davis signed a law giving prosecutors more time to gather evidence and file charges against suspects in child molestation cases. The law will prevent 18 potential sexual abuse cases involving the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles from expiring from now through June. Under the previous law, prosecutors were allowed a year after receiving accusations to determine whether a case should go to trial. Calvin Sims (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Professor's Job Safe
description: Nicholas De Genova, 35, the Columbia University anthropology professor who caused an uproar with his rhetorical wish for ''a million Mogadishus,'' referring to the city in Somalia where 18 American soldiers were killed in 1993, is in no danger of losing his job, the university's president has said. Some alumni donors have called for Mr. De Genova's dismissal because of a speech at a campus antiwar teach-in on March 26 in which he called for the defeat of American troops in Iraq. Lee C. Bollinger, the president of Columbia, repeated on Wednesday an earlier statement that while he was horrfied by Mr. De Genova's remarks, they were protected by academic freedom. Greg Retsinas (NYT)

title: Outrageous Comedy Onstage, Outrageous Relatives at Home
description: On those occasions when the comedy-concert film ''Dysfunktional Family'' gives Eddie Griffin a chance to step out of the bag that has become a package of surefire, guffaw-forcing clichs for African-American comedians -- boring mockery of square white people, low-grade homophobia, comments like the feds can't find Osama bin Laden but ''they can find my 4-foot 11-inch cousin in Compton'' -- it's worth paying attention to. But in ''Family'' that occurs with any consistency only in the last 20 minutes. There is a blueprint here for what should be the next wave of comedy-concert movies, but the filmmaking team has only used part of it.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: CHECHNYA: DEADLY BUS BLAST An explosion from a remote-controlled land mind on the side of the road gutted a bus taking workers home from a Russian military base, killing eight and dealing a serious blow to the Kremlin's peace plan for the region. The explosion in Grozny was the most serious attack since what Moscow says was an overwhelming Chechen vote last month in favor of a constitution anchoring the region within Russia.   (Reuters)

title: Terrorism Task Force Detains an American Without Charges
description: For the last two weeks, Maher Hawash, a 38-year-old software engineer and American citizen who was from the West Bank and grew up in Kuwait, has been held in a federal prison here, though he has not been charged with a crime or brought before a judge.

title: Leaseholders at Brooklyn Port Worry What Study May Bring
description: The city has hired a consultant to study uses for approximately 100 acres of Red Hook waterfront that now serve as Brooklyn's last active port, raising the possibility that the site will become a park, a museum or luxury housing.

title: Tiny Insurers Face Scrutiny As Tax Shields
description: Congressional Republicans and Democrats said yesterday that they were looking into supposedly tiny, tax-exempt insurance companies and how they have been used to shield many millions of dollars of investment profits from taxes.

title: Amnesia Closes One Door But Then Another Opens
description: ''The Man Without a Past'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from A. O. Scott's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 2; the full text is online at nytimes.com/movies. The film, in Finnish with English subtitles, opens today in Manhattan.

title: Council Proposes Ways to Keep Trucks Off Residential Streets
description: Truckers beware: The New York City Council has its eyes on you.

title: Investigation On Identities Of 9 Bodies Has Begun
description: Pentagon officials said today that a preliminary examination of nine sets of remains found during the rescue of Pfc. Jessica Lynch indicated that they could be Americans. The remains have been ordered sent to the United States for testing.

title: DISNEY EXECUTIVE TO BE CHIEF OF HERBALIFE
description: Herbalife International Inc., a marketer of nutritional and weight-loss products, said it hired Michael Johnson, president of the Walt Disney Company's international operations, as the chief executive. Herbalife had been searching for a chief executive since last year, when Frank Tirelli left the company, said William Lowe, senior vice president for finance at Herbalife. The company is based in Los Angeles.

title: Having Seized Baghdad Airport, Army Ponders Next Move
description: SADDAM INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT, Iraq, March 4  After months in the Kuwait desert, after two weeks in Iraq, after the Army's Third Infantry Division seized this airport, its ultimate objective, Master Sgt. Russell B. Carpenter asked a question today with reverberations from Baghdad to Washington.

description: Directed by Dennie Gordon

title: American companies are adjusting almost everything that represents them overseas.
description: WITH the recent surge in petition drives, demonstrations, even physical attacks that equate brands born in the United States with imperialism or militarism, advertisers are confronting perhaps the most sustained anti-American feelings abroad since the Vietnam War.

title: ECHOSTAR LOSES EFFORT TO BAR MEXICAN NETWORK IN U.S.
description: TV Azteca, one of Mexico's biggest broadcasters, won a legal victory yesterday in its effort to build a third Spanish-language television network in the United States. Judge Alvin Hellerstein of United States District Court in Manhattan refused to grant an injunction sought by the satellite broadcaster EchoStar Communications that would have prevented an affiliate of the network, Azteca America, from sending programs to local cable and satellite systems. EchoStar claimed that Azteca's distribution agreements violated a contract giving EchoStar exclusive rights to carry programs from Azteca's Channel 13 in Mexico on its American direct broadcast satellite service. The judge's decision allows the Azteca affiliates to sign deals with local cable operators. EchoStar said it still expected to prevail when the case goes to trial. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: Coach Awaits a Transplant
description: Trey Schwab, a Marquette assistant basketball coach, has been waiting more than a year for a life-saving lung transplant. Now he hopes to put it off a week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, STEPHEN A.
description: KRAMER-Stephen A. The Board of Directors and staff of the Henry Kaufmann Campgrounds are deeply saddened by the untimely passing of Stephen A. Kramer, our former President and Chairman. Stephen nurtured our agency with his honesty, judgment, love and unfailing support. In doing so, he touched the lives of hundreds of thousands of day campers in the New York area. We were all honored to have known him and will miss him. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Walter L. Harris, President Jeffrey A. Coopersmith, Executive Director

title: Chirac Apologizes for Vandalized Graves
description: President Jacques Chirac, seeking to avoid a further worsening of relations with Britain, has written words of apology and outrage to Queen Elizabeth over the desecration of graves at a cemetery in northern France for British soldiers who fell in World War I.

title: British Court Orders Extradition in French Bombing Case
description: LONDON, April 4  A British court ordered today the extradition to France of an Algerian man accused of participation in a series of bombings in the Paris subway and commuter train system in 1995 that terrorized the French capital, killing 8 people and wounding more than 200.

title: How to Make Antiwar Music Without Using Words
description: Another wartime concert, another night of protest music. It started with one word in frantic, spidery letters flickering on a screen above the band: ''Hope.'' Near the end, film of an antiwar rally was shown. Downstairs, you could buy a T-shirt that said, ''International Terrorist,'' with a picture of President Bush.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL GAINS. Crude oil rose after a United States military engineer said Iraqi forces still hold about 40 percent of the Rumaila oil field. In New York, crude oil for May delivery rose 41 cents, or 1.4 percent, to $28.97 a barrel.

title: Export Apple Of China's Eye Is, Er, Apples
description: This is where much of America's apple juice now comes from the outskirts of historic Xian, where the orchards stretch for miles and miles. Apples are so plentiful here that they are often left to rot in the fields. They are scattered on the ground in old farming villages and pitched against walls by playful little boys like red and gold baseballs.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Reducing Overtime Pay
description: A House subcommittee approved a bill that would make it easier for employers to offer tens of millions of workers compensatory time instead of paid overtime. In a party-line vote, the subcommittee of the Education and Workforce Committee voted 8 to 6 for the bill, which would ease provisions that bar companies from offering compensatory time instead of overtime to employees who work more than 40 hours a week. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: U.S. Forces at Edge of a Blacked-Out Baghdad

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANENBAUM, ROBERT M.
description: TANENBAUM-Robert M. On March 22, 2003. A memorial service will be held Monday, April 7, 2003, 4 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City. At his request, a reception in honor of his life will be held at his home immediately following the service.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: M.T.A. Guilty Plea
description: A former union official pleaded guilty yesterday in federal court in Brooklyn to charges that he secretly ran a shell company that overbilled the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for hundreds of thousands of dollars. It is the latest plea stemming from fraud in the construction of the authority's new headquarters in Lower Manhattan. The former official, James Roemer, 36, of Sloatsburg, N.Y., is the former treasurer of Local 14 of the International Union of Elevator Constructors. He faces 4 to 5 years in prison and agreed to pay restitution of $800,000, the amount he said he misappropriated and used to buy a bed-and-breakfast near Lake George. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: With a Dash Of Difference
description: Justin Lin's ''Better Luck Tomorrow,'' which opens nationally next Friday, is a film about teenagers who drink, use drugs, cheat on tests and contemplate murder as a way of getting ahead. If that sounds like standard fare, the context is not: Mr. Lin's film takes place among prosperous suburban Asian-Americans, the sort of young characters usually seen in comedies as nerds with thick glasses staring lecherously at blond cheerleaders. With its detached depiction of rampant amorality, the picture is a chiller and hardly the sort of thing you'd expect from MTV Films.

title: Through the Woods, en Route to Broadway
description: At Camp Ovation, a summer musical theater workshop for young people in upstate New York, the reigning pop deity isn't Eminem but Stephen Sondheim. Aboard the yellow school bus carrying the 6- to 16-year-old students from New York City to this miniature Oz, the fresh-faced passengers spontaneously burst into that jolly old singalong ''Losing My Mind,'' from ''Follies.''

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Cleared Of Rapes
description: A man convicted of raping three women is free after 19 years in prison, exonerated by DNA evidence. Middlesex County prosecutors have dropped all charges against the man, Dennis Maher, 42, who was convicted in 1983 after three women identified him as their attacker. In 2001 a law student working on the case found a box of evidence in a courthouse basement that included clothing from one victim. DNA testing was done on the clothing and on evidence from a second victim. There was no physical evidence from the third victim, but prosecutors expressed confidence that Mr. Maher was not the assailant. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Amazon And Google Begin Ad Venture
description: John Doerr's concept of a keiretsu, or alliance, of Internet companies may have taken some hits, as many of Mr. Doerr's investments have failed, but the concept is not dead. Yesterday, for example, Google, the search engine, said that it would sell advertising for Amazon.com's vast Web store. Terms were not disclosed. Mr. Doerr, a partner at the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, sits on the board of both Amazon and Google. Owen Van Natta, Amazon's vice president for business development, said the arrangement was solely to help users find the products and information they were looking for. For example yesterday, Amazon's page that sold the Bruce Springsteen album ''The Rising'' had a section marked ''customers interested in Bruce Springsteen may also be interested in.'' It had an advertisement, sold by Google, for a Web site selling concert tickets. Companies not in the alliance cannot use this as a back door onto Amazon's site. EBay and Buy.com, both Amazon rivals, buy ads that appear on the Springsteen pages of Google, but are blocked from appearing on Amazon. Saul Hansell(NYT)

title: War's Impact? What Impact?
description: The video industry doesn't crow about it, of course, but national crises normally don't hurt the bottom line or alter the flow of releases. After Sept. 11 retailers found themselves heir to a cocooning effect, a general withdrawal to home and hearth with a pile of movies. Then it was supposed that tastes would tilt to comedy and light subjects, but violent action sounded no retreat.

title: A Role at Ground Zero for the Master of the Piers
description: A BIG, brawny blur of a man in a somber navy blue suit, Roland W. Betts, chairman of Chelsea Piers Ltd., the developer and operator of the Chelsea Piers Sports and Entertainment Complex, which bills itself as New York City's third-most-visited site, waves his arms semaphore style, his way of providing infallible directions to his corner domain overlooking the Hudson River.

title: Latinos Gave Their Lives To New Land
description: Lance Cpl. Jos Gutirrez, 27, was among the first to die, in a tank battle outside Umm Qasr on March 21.

title: Carriers Respond as Disease Raises Concerns Over Air Circulation in Passenger Cabins
description: The spread of a new highly infectious respiratory disease is reigniting questions about the cleanliness of the air inside airplane cabins and cutting into bookings for airlines flying into areas where the infection is prevalent.

title: Behind New York's Smoking Ban, the Tenacity of Two Legislators
description: When Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis proposed his first antismoking bill a quarter-century ago, many of the lawmakers here laughed it off. Some blew smoke in his face, literally.

title: US Airways Narrowed Loss in February
description: The US Airways Group, which emerged from bankruptcy protection this week, posted a smaller net loss in February than in January even as revenue decreased from the prior month.

title: Sports of The Times; Memories of War And Basketball
description: Ever since Texas earned a berth in this weekend's Final Four, Slater Martin and Vilbry White have become the lost treasures of Longhorns basketball. Martin, 77, and White, 74, were members of the last Texas team to reach the N.C.A.A. semifinals, in March 1947.

title: First Woman Is Appointed As Dean of Harvard Law
description: Elena Kagan, a former White House aide to President Bill Clinton and onetime clerk to Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court, has been appointed dean of the Harvard University Law School, Lawrence H. Summers, the university president, announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARREN, ADA (NEE LUSTBADER)
description: WARREN-Ada (nee Lustbader), 95, of Lakewood, NJ; formerly of Woodside, NY, died April 1, 2003 at Brick Hospital. Predeceased by her beloved husband Stephen in 1967. Survived by her loving sister-inlaw Ilona V. Katonah, and many nieces, nephews, and cousins. For information contact Van Hise and Callagan Funeral Home, 732-892-0100.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a union drive among residents and interns at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx misidentified the neighborhood for the center's main campus. It is Norwood, not Bedford Park.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: A Voyage Of Victory

title: Out of Iraq: The Rescue of Pfc. Jessica Lynch
description: To the Editor:

title: Ah, the Pastoral Beauty of Oakland (Wait, Did You Say Oakland?)
description: THERE is the Oakland of the popular imagination: the home of ferocious silver-helmeted football players and out-of-control fans; the Oakland with the high murder rate, the disintegrating public schools and the balding, once-spacy Zen mayor who lives in a loft. But there is a secret Oakland, a wild Oakland, an Oakland that truly lives up to its name. For those of us who live in this California city of 400,000 people, the proximity to miles of wild, even remote country within a 15-minute drive of downtown is the thing that makes Oakland life miraculously different from life in, say, Houston, New York or Chicago. Utterly devoid of cachet -- unlike nearby San Francisco or Marin County or even Berkeley -- the Oakland wilderness is un-touristed, known only to those seeking solace and silence and the clarity that natural places can bring.

title: Gephardt Trails 2 In Raising Money
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, one of the Democratic Party's most visible leaders during the past decade, reported today that he raised $3.6 million this year for his presidential campaign, or only half as much as two of his rivals for the nomination.

title: Union's Membership Holds Seeds of Dissent
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein has made a priority of giving New York City principals more power to run their schools as they see fit, so it is reasonable to assume that he has an eager ally in the principals' union.

title: Regulators Near Final Deal With Big Investment Banks
description: More than three months after investment banks and regulators agreed to the outlines of a $1.4 billion settlement over abusive banking practices, the two sides are near a final agreement, a number of officials involved in the investigation said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUSSELL, KATHRYN V.
description: RUSSELL-Kathryn V. On April 4, 1977. Dearest friend, always kind and thoughtful. May you rest in peace with God throughout eternity. You will always be remembered. Howar

title: Beverly Semmes -- 'In the O'
description: Leslie Tonkonow Artworks

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Spanish Premier's Support for War Is Hurting Him Politically
description: Only a few weeks ago, the Spanish Prime Minister, Jos Mara Aznar, was basking in the glow of international attention, a privileged visitor to George Bush's ranch in Texas, an A-list participant in Anglo-American meetings on Iraq.

title: The Loyalty Test
description: KUWAIT--It was not surprising that Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld came to the Pentagon podium this week to mount a spirited defense of the Bush administration's military campaign to topple Saddam Hussein.

title: North Utah Faces Influx of Racists
description: In the cold months, the stark tattoos of white supremacy are concealed beneath layers of clothing, but the ex-convicts and parolees who wear them are becoming known by their faces.

title: WESTLAW PARENT TO BUY LEGAL BILLING COMPANY
description: The Thomson Corporation, owner of the Westlaw online legal research service, agreed to buy the Elite Information Group Inc. for $122 million to gain Elite's legal billing and case-management software. Thomson will pay $14 a share for Elite, 40 percent more than the closing price on Wednesday of $9.97. Elite's board members, who own about 22 percent of the company, approved the sale and will tender their shares, Thomson said. Elite's 800 customers use its software and Internet services to track client billings and court dates. The company, which is based in Los Angeles, will become part of Thomson's legal division, which includes Westlaw. Thomson is based in Toronto.

title: North Uist Journal; The Isle Is Full of Hedgehogs: It's a Prickly Issue
description: To the extent he ever thinks about hedgehogs, Colin MacMillan thinks about them from the perspective of inadvertently running them over with his car.

title: News Groups Want Terror Case Files
description: Several of the nation's largest news organizations demanded access today to a variety of secret court documents filed in the case of Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person charged in an American court with involvement in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: SINCLAIR BROADCAST SAYS WAR HAS CUT INTO AD SALES
description: The Sinclair Broadcast Group, the owner of 62 television stations, said first-quarter broadcast sales rose less than forecast because the war in Iraq led some advertisers to cancel commercials. About $2.2 million in advertising was canceled, much of it by automobile makers, Sinclair said. Broadcast revenue was about $152 million, missing a Feb. 13 forecast for as much as $154.8 million, the company said. Sinclair, which had broadcast revenue of $144.5 million in the same period a year ago, will report full results on May 8. Shares of Sinclair rose 33 cents, to $8.30. The company is based in Baltimore.

title: Images Of Victory Obscure Reality
description: Either victory was at hand, or television had rewound news coverage back to the first, optimistic days of the war.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Man Charged In Assault
description: A man shot in the head by a state trooper on Wednesday was charged yesterday with aggravated assault and eluding the police. The man, Leon H. Wolniewicz, 48, of Toms River, was accused of hitting the state trooper with his car during an attempt to evade a motor vehicle stop. The trooper, Mark Kepenis, fired his weapon, striking Mr. Wolniewicz, who was listed yesterday in critical but stable condition at a Newark hospital, the authorities said. Trooper Kepenis suffered minor injuries. The Division of Criminal Justice said yesterday that Trooper Kepenis had made several attempts to stop Mr. Wolniewicz after observing him speeding. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Rare Charges Filed in Wounding of Sea Lion
description: In a rare prosecution under the Marine Mammal Protection Act, two California men, a sport-fishing company and a charter boat it owns were charged today in the November 2002 shooting of a sea lion pup that became known as Arrow for the crossbow bolt found protruding from its neck.

title: Freed Soldier Is in Better Condition Than First Thought, Father Says
description: The father of Pfc. Jessica Lynch said today that his daughter, who was rescued this week after nine days in Iraqi custody, was in better condition than previously thought and had not suffered gunshot or stabbing wounds.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Events

title: Senator Kerry Angers G.O.P.
description: Senator John Kerry, a Democratic presidential candidate, suggested in a speech on Wednesday that ''we need a regime change in the United States'' as well as in Iraq, drawing angry responses from Republican leaders.

title: Camby Has Words for Knicks
description: Marcus Camby and his former Knicks teammates turned Wednesday's game at Denver's Pepsi Center into Trash Talk 101, the art of verbal gamesmanship. Camby followed every shot, every block, every rebound with boisterous chatter, often glaring at the Knicks' bench and even screaming in the faces of Latrell Sprewell and Kurt Thomas.

title: INSIDE
description: Israelis Kill 7 Palestinians

title: Data on Viral Outbreak Is Yielded Reluctantly
description: In early March, when a new mystery illness started hopscotching around the globe, Chinese health officials looked on in silence, as if to say, ''This has nothing to do with us.''

title: Forget About J. Lo. These Paparazzi Are After a BMW.
description: STANDING in the parking lot of a roadside motel in the Mojave Desert last July, with the temperature approaching 120 degrees and the water in her bottle getting too hot to drink, Brenda Priddy was starting to worry about the dust. She had already been there for an hour with nothing to show for her troubles, and she had just noticed another photographer at a gas station across the road. As she checked her Canon EOS-1D digital camera, she began to wonder whether her competitor had picked a better vantage point and whether the omnipresent dust would obscure the shot she was trying to get.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Charge For Telecom Concern
description: The telecommunications carrier NTT DoCoMo said it would take a one-time charge related to taxes, cutting its profit for last year by 27 billion yen ($226 million). NTT DoCoMo forecast a profit of 182 billion yen for the year that ended Monday, so the one-time charge represents a 15 percent reduction. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Unemployment Rises
description: German unemployment figures continued to rise, disappointing expectations that unusually mild temperatures in March would lead to the creation of new jobs. The Federal Labor Office said the number of unemployed rose a seasonally adjusted 52,000, to 4.41 million, nearly half a million people more than a year before. The jobless rate increased one-tenth of a percentage point from February, to 10.6 percent. Because of weak growth prospects for the economy, the Labor Office expects no recovery of the labor market soon. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Bloomberg Says State Vies for Security Money the City Needs
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made his differences with Gov. George E. Pataki public yesterday, suggesting that the governor is trying to claim a share of federal money that the city needs to defend itself against terrorist attacks.

title: On the Outskirts of Baghdad
description: American forces reached the outskirts of Baghdad with astonishing speed yesterday, raising hopes that the endgame in the Iraqi conflict may be close at hand. There were signs that both the battle for military supremacy and the battle for acceptance by ordinary Iraqis were proceeding well.

title: Florida Urged To Withdraw AIDS Leaflet Invoking Jesus
description: The American Civil Liberties Union of Florida is asking the Florida Department of Health to recall an AIDS information brochure that includes biblical references and tells people to ''answer Jesus' call'' by reaching out to people with H.I.V. and AIDS.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BID FOR PIZZA CHAIN PizzaExpress, a British chain struggling against a trend among Britons to order more pizza to go than to eat in restaurants, said it urged investors to accept an all-cash takeover offer from the South African owners of the Nando's chicken restaurants. The bid by Nando was made jointly with a private equity firm, TDR Capital. The offer of 387 pence a share, valuing PizzaExpress at the equivalent of $436 million, topped a bid of 367 pence from the company's co-founder and former chairman, Luke Johnson, who holds 8.7 percent of the chain's stock. Mr Johnson said he might increase his offer. Scenting a bidding war, investors pushed the share price up by 2.6 percent, to 389.5 pence.

title: U.S. Gunships Hit Taliban Camp; Most Fighters Escape
description: Apaches, Harriers, A-10 Thunderbolts and AC-130 gunships unleashed a barrage of firepower against a rebel camp in southeastern Afghanistan today, an American military spokesman said, in one of the heaviest nights of bombing in months in Afghanistan.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Rumsfeld's News Briefing: 'The Coalition Continues to Close In on Baghdad'
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference yesterday by Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld and Gen. Richard B. Myers, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as recorded by Federal Document Clearing House Inc. A complete transcript is online at nytimes.com/international.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKMAN, MARTIN
description: MARKMAN-Martin, 83 years old. Died on April 3rd, 2003. Beloved husband of 54 years of the late Shirley Markman. Loving father of David and Deborah Markman, Marcia and Irwin Siegel, and Barbara and Bruce Spiegel. Adoring grandfather of Erica, Richard, Lilly, Jared and Meredith. Devoted brother of Dorothy Weintraub, Stanley and Cynthia Gingold, and Ruby and Herb Janof. We'll miss your wisdom, loyalty, love and strength. Services Friday, 2 PM, at RiversideNassau North Chapels, Great Neck, New York.

title: Doctor Kills 2 and Wounds 6 in Spanish Hospital Rampage
description: A doctor with a history of mental illness went on a violent rampage at work, stabbing two people to death and wounding six more in a frenzied attack upon colleagues and patients. Witnesses said the woman, a 31-year-old resident in rheumatology at a well-known teaching hospital in Madrid, was chatting with some co-workers when she suddenly pulled out a knife and lunged at a nurse, slashing her neck. Other medical staff who rushed to the nurse's aid were hurt by the doctor, identified only as Noelia M. N., who inflicted at least 17 stab wounds on her victims.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR RISES. The dollar gained as United States troops advanced on Baghdad, raising optimism the war in Iraq will be over within weeks. In New York, the euro settled at $1.07370, down from $1.07654 on Wednesday.

title: Agnes Martin -- 'Five Decades'
description: Zwirner and Wirth

title: Casualties
description: Announced military casualties in the Iraq war zone as of 5 p.m. eastern time Thursday:

title: House and Senate Approve Bush's Wartime Spending Request
description: Nine days after President Bush presented Congress with the first bill for the war in Iraq, the House and Senate approved the cost tonight, voting to spend nearly $79 billion on the war and related needs for foreign aid and domestic security. The Senate's vote was unanimous; the House vote was 414 to 12.

title: Officials Warn Of Cuts' Impact On Health Care
description: An association of county health officials warned today that proposed reductions in state aid next year would lead to drastically curtailed health services, affecting everything from cancer screenings to home health care and possibly leaving their communities vulnerable to disease outbreaks and bioterrorism.

title: When a Sniper Calls the Shots
description: A haunting slogan from the golden days of radio, spoken by the disembodied voice on ''The Shadow,'' was the boast: ''Who knows what evil lurks in the hearts of men? The Shadow knows,'' followed by an insinuating cackle. In ''Phone Booth,'' Joel Schumacher's flashy stunt of a movie, a contemporary descendant of that phantom voice unleashes a similarly nasty, all-knowing snicker every few minutes during the protracted phone conversation that consumes most of this clanking, overheated thriller.

title: Tragedy Pierces the Heart, Memory the Skin
description: ''It was now quite plain that he must be some abominable savage.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Combat in Iraq Is Felt In the Aisles of Wal-Mart

title: Too Costly an Appeal
description: When it comes to civil lawsuits, tobacco companies are high on the list of disliked defendants. That makes it even more important that judges be vigilant in making sure that cigarette makers, like other unpopular parties, are given the full protection of constitutional due process. Mindful of that, an Illinois trial court acted wrongly when it required Philip Morris to post a $12 billion bond before it could appeal an adverse judgment.

title: Moody's and Fitch May Cut Reynolds Tobacco Credit Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service and Fitch Ratings said yesterday that they might cut the credit rating of R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings in the near future.

title: Iraq May Try Defensive Use Of Chemicals, Experts Warn
description: As coalition forces push toward Baghdad, they are preparing for possible attacks by chemical weapons, which Saddam Hussein's forces are known to have used in the past. But experts say the ways his and other armies have dispersed chemical weapons -- bombs, rockets and artillery shells directed at troops -- are not the only means to deploy them.

title: Bill Jensen
description: Mary Boone Gallery

title: Waste Management Promotes Officer
description: Waste Management Inc., the trash hauler, promoted David P. Steiner to chief financial officer today and assigned him to oversee a new department that will work to reduce expenses amid slumping demand for services.

title: Balboa Retires After 13 Pro Seasons
description: Marcelo Balboa, who played on three consecutive United States World Cup teams, retired two months after being cut by the MetroStars of Major League Soccer.

title: National Briefing: Plains
description: OKLAHOMA: MAN WHO KILLED AT 17 IS EXECUTED After the United States Supreme Court voted 5 to 4 to overturn a stay, the state executed Scott A. Hain, who was convicted of killing two people when he was 17. Mr. Hain had won the stay of execution on Wednesday in an appeals court. Oklahoma asked the Supreme Court to intervene, arguing that his appeals had run out. Members of the court voting to lift the stay were Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia, Anthony M. Kennedy and Clarence Thomas. Mr. Hain and an accomplice abducted their victims outside a bar, robbed them of $565, and then locked them in the truck of their car and set the car afire.    (AP)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Rockville Centre: New Auxiliary Bishop
description: Msgr. Paul H. Walsh, the pastor of St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Smithtown, has been appointed an auxiliary bishop for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, Bishop William Murphy announced yesterday. When he is installed on May 29, Monsignor Walsh, 65, will become one of three auxiliary bishops in the diocese. He will work primarily with parishes in western Nassau County, Bishop Murphy said, and will also serve as pastor of Queen of the Most Holy Rosary Church, in Roosevelt. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: KANSAS CITY LIFE IS ACQUIRING GUIDEONE LIFE
description: The Kansas City Life Insurance Company, which had $440.2 million in revenue last year, is buying the GuideOne Life Insurance Company for about $78 million in cash, increasing its number of customers, the company said yesterday. GuideOne Life, based in West Des Moines, Iowa, is owned by the GuideOne Financial Group and has 75,000 policyholders, Kansas City's general counsel, William Schalekamp, said. Kansas City, which was founded in 1895 and is based in Kansas City, Mo., had $3.9 billion in assets as of the end of last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDELSMAN, JOYCE
description: HANDELSMAN-Joyce. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Joyce Handelsman. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved family. Richard J. Bornstein, Pres. Leon Fassler, Secretary

title: Anti-Doping Executive Plans to Prod Pro Leagues
description: The man who helped devise a new uniform standard for banned substances and drug testing in all Olympic sports says he plans to ask North America's four major professional sports leagues why they have not signed on to the new regulations.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: On the Scene: Baghdad 'Clueless' About Airport
description: AMMAN, Jordan (CNN) -- CNN correspondent Rym Brahimi talked with CNN anchor Anderson Cooper Friday morning about the fighting in and around the Baghdad airport.

title: Residential Real Estate; Luxury Rentals on Yonkers Waterfront
description: The first residential development in downtown Yonkers in more than 30 years, a luxury rental complex with 266 one- and two-bedroom apartments, is nearing completion on the city's burgeoning waterfront. Called Hudson Square, the $60 million complex includes 22,000 square feet of office, retail and restaurant space.

title: Gun, Germs and Stall?
description: Over the last two weeks, nobody has been paying much attention to economic news; even the ups and downs of the Dow have reflected reports from the battlefield, not the boardroom. But the economic news is quite worrying. Indeed, the latest readings suggest that our recovery, such as it is, may be stalling.

title: The Cat Who Liked To Drive
description: EVERYBODY knows dogs love to ride in the car and cats hate it. Dogs sit up, bright-eyed and eager, and hang their heads out the window. Cats cower under the seats and wail.

title: Lucian Adams, 80, Is Dead; Army Hero in World War II
description: Lucian Adams, an Army sergeant in World War II who received the Medal of Honor for a single-handed assault on German troops that opened supply lines for an isolated American battalion, died on Monday in San Antonio. He was 80.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: No Automatic Resentencing
description: The State Supreme Court held that 27 people on death row were not necessarily entitled to new sentencing hearings, even though the United States Supreme Court ruled last year that the procedure used to sentence them to death was unconstitutional. The state court said it would examine each case, and hours later it ordered resentencing for three inmates. But the court held that the mere fact that judges rather than juries had made the factual finding supporting the sentences -- the procedure rejected by the United States Supreme Court -- did not in itself require resentencing. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Mets Contain Sosa, but Are No Match for Prior
description: The Mets were facing another early deficit yesterday when Sammy Sosa began rubbing his right foot into the back of the batter's box. Sosa had driven home two runs with a first-inning single and was now facing Steve Trachsel in the third with the bases loaded and nobody out.

title: Iraq's Not Vietnam
description: Let's be clear: Iraq will not turn into another Vietnam.

title: Telling Understatement Meets the Excitable Boy
description: The common assumption that songwriters are the most insightful interpreters of their own work has been proved wrong time and again. But in the case of Alan Bergman (one half of the Hollywood lyric-writing team Alan and Marilyn Bergman) and his longtime musical collaborator, Michel Legrand, it holds true in a nonmusical sense. Mr. Bergman and Mr. Legrand, who are performing well over a dozen of their songs with Patti Austin at Feinstein's at the Regency, are die-hard pop romantics of opposite stage demeanor.

title: Suddenly, Puccini's Bohemians Can Be Seen All Over Town
description: THE major reason the director Baz Luhrmann gave for bringing his production of ''La Bohme'' to Broadway last fall is that he wanted new audiences to discover the lyrical richness and contemporary resonance of Puccini's enduring opera.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Premium Is the Norm

title: Quick Escapes
description: THOUGH it was hard to tell from the subfreezing temperatures that hit much of the Northeast last week, spring is finally here. Want to jump start a celebration of the season with a quick trip next weekend? Here are some places to melt away the lingering effects of a brutal winter.

title: Edward Weston and Margrethe Mather -- 'A Passionate Collaboration'
description: AXA Gallery

title: Freed Soldier Undergoes Several Operations in Germany
description: LANDSTUHL, Germany, April 4  Pfc. Jessica Lynch, the female soldier freed from captivity in Iraq on Tuesday, is undergoing a battery of operations at a military hospital here to treat wounds that include a fractured right arm, two broken legs and a spinal injury.

title: China Defends Actions in Battling Contagious Illness
description: As a mysterious respiratory illness appeared in new countries and more cases were reported from already affected countries, China defended itself against criticism that its initial refusal to be more open about the disease had contributed to its spread.

title: In Wal-Marts Close to Bases, Emotions Spill Into the Aisle
description: It is springtime, and so all the Wal-Marts around the country have plastic flowers in the crafts aisle and chocolate eggs in the candy section. But it is also wartime, and at Wal-Mart, which sometimes functions in its vastness as a kind of substitute town square, the impact of the war in Iraq is on display around the clock.

title: At Final Four, Studying Takes a Back-Row Seat
description: His team had just defeated Oklahoma and cut down the nets as the East region champion last Sunday. Now there was only a two-hour bus ride from Albany back to Syracuse, but Craig Forth did not use the time to look ahead to Syracuse's national semifinal matchup against Texas in the N.C.A.A. Final Four on Saturday. Instead, he got out his schoolbooks and studied.

title: The Pregnant Possibility of Words
description: PRETTY GIRL IN CRIMSON ROSE (8)

title: As an Injunction Ends in Englewood, an Era in School Desegregation Closes as Well
description: A decision by the State Board of Education this week puts an end to an injunction that has helped define education in Englewood and Englewood Cliffs, N.J., since 1990.

title: In Basra, Weapons of War Vie for Hearts and Minds
description: NEAR BASRA, Iraq, April 4  Two rocket-propelled grenades were launched at British troops on the outskirts of Basra today, one striking a tank but doing little damage and the other exploding above civilians on the highway, sending them scrambling for cover and leaving an unknown number wounded. The injured were behind the British front lines and were carried away by Iraqis.

title: A Sleepwalking Mafia Wife, Awakened by Some Irresistible Cheekbones
description: At times, the romantic melodrama ''Angela,'' directed by Roberta Torre, seems to be the poshest television movie ever made -- an extremely well directed and acted telling of a story that's short on surprise. But a meal doesn't have to be new to be satisfying, which ''Angela,'' showing tonight and tomorrow as part of the New Directors/New Films series, is.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Like Carnival in Rio, Douglas Rodriguez's Nuevo Latino party just keeps going on. Ever since he arrived in New York from Miami, bringing his splashy, exuberant style to Patria, and later to Chicama and Pipa, Mr. Rodriguez has been a big force on the dining scene, as much host as chef. His cooking is an expression of his personality, oversize and extroverted, so it's no wonder that wherever he wanders, diners follow. The latest stop for Mr. Rodriguez is Ola, which sounds like the Spanish word for hello but also stands for Of Latin America.

title: Overcrowding Cited in Fire That Killed 4 In Brooklyn
description: The day after a deliberately set fire killed four people in a third-floor apartment in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, residents and city officials said that the building that burned was overcrowded.

title: Out of Iraq: The Rescue of Pfc. Jessica Lynch
description: To the Editor:

title: American Soldiers, at the Behest of an Iraqi Officer, Topple a Hussein Statue
description: At one end of the city, the Tomb of Ali, son-in-law of the Prophet Muhammad, occupies a place of honor that has been revered by Shiite Muslims for centuries. And dominating the four-lane boulevard approaching the holy site is a monument loathed by the Shiites for a decade: a gigantic bronze statue of Saddam Hussein on a horse, seeming to dare posterity to set its gaze on his grandeur.

title: Chemical Spill Shuts Down Part of the Long Island Rail Road
description: Transit officials shut down a 23-mile stretch of the Long Island Rail Road for nearly two hours just before the evening rush hour today as the police in Suffolk County investigated a chemical spill from a truck near the tracks.

title: At Airport, Bombs Provide the Only Light
description: Iraq's international airport was dark late Thursday night and strangely quiet. Baghdad itself lay shrouded in darkness for the first time since the war began, lighted only by the intermittent white flash of American bombs and the red streaks of anti-aircraft fire rising into the night like feeble fireworks.

title: Iraq Vows 'Unconventional' Tactics to Defend Capital
description: KUWAIT, April 4  As Marine and Army units fanned out around the southern fringes of Baghdad in sweltering heat today, officers said they had secured most of the capital's international airport and captured 2,500 Iraqi soldiers on the way to the capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALMUS, GEOFFREY M.
description: KALMUS-Geoffrey M. Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel LLP regrets the death of one of our firm's founding partners, Geoffrey M. Kalmus, who died last night at home in Albuquerque, NM. From the time our firm was formed in 1968 to the day he retired in 1993, Geoff was our natural leader and everyone's first source of good counsel. He was the sounding board for any difficult ethical or practice issue that arose. He was the one to build consensus and to offer direction on issues that mattered. Geoff's voice was heard because its source was selfless: he always viewed an issue from the perspective of what was best for the firm, no matter its effect on him personally. His intellect, analytical skills and judgment were towering. He was a mentor to many of us: vigilant and vigorous in the prosecution of his clients' views, meticulous and scholarly in his legal advocacy, and honest and just in the positions he took. That our beloved GMK-quirky, eccentric, unique-has died is a great loss to the firm and the lawyers that he mentored.

Cherished grandfather of Sara and Melissa Benerofe. Dear brother of Helen Forrest. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 11:30 AM Friday.

title: Are Those People Just Passing By or Part of the Act?
description: Sarah Michelson loaded her ''Shadowmann'' with heart-sinking aesthetic baggage: the piece was to unfold in two parts at two theaters, usually a bad sign. Described as a ''Bauhaus anti-epic,'' it was to explore the boundaries between audiences and performers. That again.

title: Laughing Off The Hurt

Yet as portrayed by Eddie Izzard and Victoria Hamilton in the Roundabout Theater Company's sensational new revival of Peter Nichols's ''Day in the Death of Joe Egg,'' neither husband nor wife seems remotely staled by familiarity.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Toxic Dumping Charged
description: The owners of 4 junkyards in Brooklyn and 10 of their employees were arrested on charges of illegally dumping thousands of gallons of toxic materials onto the ground and into the sewer system, state and city officials announced yesterday. Through the use of hidden surveillance cameras, investigators gathered what they said was evidence that the Auto Gobbler, A1A Auto Parts, Jet II Auto Parts and Andy's All Van, all on Preston Court in Canarsie, had dumped antifreeze, transmission fluid and other toxic materials, which carries a maximum sentence of four years and fines of up to $100,000. Efforts to reach the owners last night were unsuccessful. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: When Urban Life Gets to Be Too Much, Escape Is Often Close By
description: SKYLINES may still be visible from these hiking areas located on the outskirts of five major American cities. But short drives -- none more than 45 minutes -- will take visitors to rivers, woodlands and vantage points far enough to escape the urban grit and grime.

title: U.S. troops close in on Baghdad airport
description: U.S. forces approached Saddam Hussein International Airport in Baghdad on Thursday, only 16 kilometers from the western edge of the city, and a U.S. spokesman in Qatar said, "When we decide to go into Baghdad, we will be in Baghdad within a matter of hours from when we decide to go."

title: Technology Briefing | Software: MRO Shares Drop On News Of License Sales
description: Shares of MRO Software Inc., a business-software maker, fell 10 percent after the company said yesterday that its second-quarter licensing revenue was about $7 million as sales were delayed. That is half the amount expected by an analyst. MRO had been expected to have licensing sales of $13.8 million in the second quarter, said Tad Piper, an analyst with U.S. Bancorp in Menlo Park, Calif. He estimated that the company made $7.1 million in the period. Shares of MRO declined 76 cents, to $6.82. They have fallen 44 percent this year. MRO told investors and analysts during a conference call that one sale closed about a day after the quarter ended on Monday, according to Mr. Piper. Five sales, valued at more than $5 million, were also delayed, he said.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: VIETNAM: MEETING WITH DISSIDENT In what an international Buddhist group called a "significant event," Prime Minister Phan Van Khai met with the leader of a banned Buddhist church and spoke about religious freedom. The monk, Thich Huyen Quang, patriarch of the Unified Buddhist Church of Vietnam, has been under arrest at his temple in central Vietnam since 1982 and is the subject of frequent reports by human rights groups. Despite the meeting, the prime minister was quoted as saying that the banned group would not be recognized. "We already have the Vietnam Buddhist Church," he said. "That's quite enough."   Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Israeli Army Strikes at Palestinians; 7 Are Shot to Death

title: Search for Hidden Arsenals in Iraq Yields Little Evidence
description: KUWAIT, April 3  More than two weeks into the war in Iraq, the search for weapons of mass destruction has come up empty. The main group charged with hunting for chemical and biological arms, the 75th Exploitation Task Force, has not found any evidence of hidden arsenals of such weapons so far.

title: BANKATLANTIC PLANS TO SPIN OFF HOME-BUILDING UNIT
description: The BankAtlantic Bancorp plans to split into two companies by spinning off its Levitt Corporation unit, the home builder that pioneered the mass production of low-cost, suburban communities after World War II. BankAtlantic shares rose 12 percent after the company said that it planned to issue stock in Levitt to shareholders during the second half of this year. BankAtlantic purchased Levitt for $21 million in 1999. BankAtlantic said spinning off Levitt would allow the company to expand more quickly. BankAtlantic is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Praising Nadelman, or Burying Him?
description: RESURRECTIONS of neglected artists can sometimes threaten to rebury them. This possibility shadows the Whitney Museum of American Art's overly decorous retrospective of Elie Nadelman, the great Polish-born American sculptor. This fourth and largest retrospective yet devoted to Nadelman's suavely economical heads, figures and animals, organized by Barbara Haskell, the museum's curator of prewar art, could have been much livelier and more persuasive.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Hitting Back
description: China officially retaliated against a State Department critique of its human rights record, saying American human rights standards had deteriorated sharply even as the United States was ''pretending to be the world's judge.'' The report by China's State Council said discrimination, especially against Arabs and Muslims, was on the rise in the United States since the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks. It said the United States was inflicting vast suffering on the people of Afghanistan and Iraq, while practicing ''democracy of the rich'' at home. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Medical Acquisition Inquiry
description: The European Commission said it had opened an investigation into the planned acquisition by General Electric of the Finnish medical equipment maker Instrumentarium. The commission said the combined entity would have high market shares in the markets for patient monitors, mobile X-ray machines and mammography equipment bought by hospitals. It also suspects that the deal may allow the company to squeeze out suppliers of machines that work alongside patient monitoring equipment, like anesthesia machines, the commission said. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Blair Says Coalition Not Responsible for Market Attack
description: LONDON, April 4  Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that allied forces were not responsible for the aerial attack on a market in Baghdad last month that killed 14 civilians and inflamed Arab public opinion when the destruction and bloodied victims were shown on television.

title: Royal Ahold to Sell Its South American Businesses
description: Royal Ahold, the troubled multinational food retailer based in the Netherlands, said today that it planned to sell its South American businesses, including the Argentine store chain where some of its problems arose, to raise cash and reduce debt.

title: Documents Raise Questions About Confession in Sniper Case
description: FAIRFAX, Va., April 4  Although the teenager charged in the Washington-area sniper attacks indicated he wanted to talk to a lawyer, a detective interviewed him last fall before he received legal advice, according to police documents. Law enforcement officials say the teenager, Lee Malvo, confessed to several shootings in that interview.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: College Students Sued Over Downloading
description: The Recording Industry Association of America filed lawsuits against five college students who, the organization said, were operating systems for trading copyrighted music files over their university computer networks. The legal action represents the first time the trade group for the major music labels has sued students who were apparently not trying to profit from copying files. According to the legal briefs, the students operated Napster-like systems at Princeton University, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and Michigan Technological University, allowing other students to search and download a centralized index of thousands of songs. None of the students could be reached for comment. Amy Harmon(NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bid For Pizza Chain
description: PizzaExpress, a British chain struggling against a trend among Britons to order more pizza to go than to eat in restaurants, said it urged investors to accept an all-cash takeover offer from the South African owners of the Nando's chicken restaurants. The bid by Nando was made jointly with a private equity firm, TDR Capital. The offer of 387 pence a share, valuing PizzaExpress at the equivalent of $436 million, topped a bid of 367 pence from the company's co-founder and former chairman, Luke Johnson, who holds 8.7 percent of the chain's stock. Mr Johnson said he might increase his offer. Scenting a bidding war, investors pushed the share price up by 2.6 percent, to 389.5 pence. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Big Board Abandons a Plan To Restrict Some Press Access
description: The New York Stock Exchange backed away from a plan yesterday to stop Wall Street analysts from talking to newspapers, television networks or other media outlets that do not disclose the analysts' potential conflicts of interest in their reports.

A small, athletic team that shot poorly during its disappointing regular season, St. John's turned to its withering transition game, its doggedness on the offensive boards and its star senior guard, Marcus Hatten.

title: Jeter Has an M.R.I., And Decisions Are His
description: The only person who will decide Derek Jeter's immediate future, his agent said yesterday, is Jeter. The Yankees' doctors will study the results of the magnetic resonance imaging test on Jeter's dislocated left shoulder, and club officials will be consulted. But Jeter will make the call.

Before the carousel stops, vacancies at Clemson, Georgia, North Carolina and Pittsburgh will have been filled and names like Roy Williams, John Calipari and Manhattan's Bobby Gonzalez will have been run back and forth through the rumor mill.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: UNION BUDGET PLAN New York City's municipal unions gave the city a proposal yesterday that they described as meeting the Bloomberg administration's demand for $600 million in labor savings as a way to avoid or reduce layoffs. The city is reviewing the proposal. Randi Weingarten, president of the teachers' union, is chairwoman of the Municipal Labor Committee, a coalition of municipal unions. She said the proposal called for saving money through early retirements and by adjusting some benefits.

description: President Bush told 12,000 cheering marines today that the ''vise is closing'' on Saddam Hussein, as the president's top military adviser declared that the final phase of the war -- toppling Mr. Hussein -- was now under way.

title: War's Impact? What Impact?
description: The video industry doesn't crow about it, of course, but national crises normally don't hurt the bottom line or alter the flow of releases. After Sept. 11 retailers found themselves heir to a cocooning effect, a general withdrawal to home and hearth with a pile of movies. Then it was supposed that tastes would tilt to comedy and light subjects, but violent action sounded no retreat.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: BRAZIL: FINANCIAL REVISION ADVANCES The lower house of Congress passed a bill that could pave the way for increased autonomy for the central bank in a vote markets saw as a barometer of the left-leaning government's capacity to push through tax and pension changes later this year. The vote passed 442 to 13. The proposal would alter the legal framework of Brazil's financial system in the Constitution, which would allow the government to grant more independence to the central bank at a later date. The vote showed President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva could successfully mobilize support from his coalition allies and opposition lawmakers, something markets had been eager to see. Mr. Da Silva will need similar support when he tackles thorny reforms of Brazil's bloated state-sector pension system and byzantine tax system later this year. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC Starts Unlimited Calling Plan
description: Highlighting a trend in the marketing of telephone calling plans, SBC Communications Inc. yesterday became the latest company to introduce a package that permits unlimited long-distance and local calling for a single price. SBC's introduction of All Distance Connections follows similar announcements in the last several months by Verizon Communications and BellSouth, according to Aurica Yen, an analyst with the Yankee Group, a market research firm. In the case of SBC, the company is offering its unlimited calling plan for around $50 depending on the state where the consumer lives. The plan is available initially only in California, Texas, Kansas, Oklahoma, Missouri and Arkansas, SBC said. Shares of SBC fell 47 cents, or 2.1 percent, to $21.68. Matt Richtel(NYT)

title: U.S. Investment Firm Considers Buying Stake in Air Canada
description: The Texas Pacific Group, the private investment firm, said yesterday that it was considering buying a stake in Air Canada when it emerges from bankruptcy protection in coming months.

description: String instruments are often said to sing. The implied comparison of instrument and voice was made tangible at two string quartet recitals last weekend, both featuring a male singer.

''The formation of Chinese civilization was synonymous with the establishment of its ritual system and religions, an establishment continuously illustrated through dress.''

Now that most of the guns in the news are being fired by soldiers, not criminals, the industry's defenders seem more ready to be counted.

title: Corrections

It was a Republican strategist, Rich Galen -- not Dan Schnur, a public relations consultant -- who said: ''You've got to have the stature to stand there next to Rumsfeld and not look like you're a 13-year-old boy or girl. She has the presence to pull that off.''

title: Editorial Observer; To Imagine Iraq After Saddam Hussein, You Must Think Like an Iraqi
description: Every journalist abroad wants to tell his readers at home two contradictory things. The first is: ''The people here may look and sound strange, but they are no different from you and me. They want security and dignity; they seek a better life for their children. What you share with them far outweighs your differences.'' The second message is the opposite: ''Yes, people here hunger and hurt and love; yes, they enjoy ice cream and action movies. But if you think that by knowing that, you know them, you are mistaken. These people are very different from you.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 43 Arrested In Drug Raids
description: After a yearlong investigation, New York City law enforcement agents moved to break up six drug rings in Ozone Park and Howard Beach, Queens, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly and District Attorney Richard A. Brown of Queens said yesterday. The police arrested 43 people and confiscated illegal drugs, 7 guns, 10 luxury cars and nearly $150,000 in cash, the officials said. Most of those arrested, Mr. Brown said, were ''unemployed mob wannabes'' who spent time dining at expensive restaurants and visiting tanning salons. Among those arrested were three people believed to have ties to the Gambino crime family, and the actor Richard Maldone, the police said. Mr. Maldone, who played Albert Barese in several episodes of ''The Sopranos,'' was charged with one count of selling ketamine, a drug popular in nightclubs. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: BORDERS SAYS IT MAY HAVE A FIRST-QUARTER LOSS
description: Borders Group Inc., the book retailer, said it may have a first-quarter loss because of slowing sales, the second time in less than a month that the company reduced its forecast. Consumers' focus on the war in Iraq has hurt sales, Borders said. The company, which had earlier forecast a break-even quarter excluding some costs, said the slowdown will probably affect full-year sales and earnings estimates. Sales are below expectations at all of Borders' businesses, with those at stories open at least a year declining at both the Borders and the Waldenbooks units. The company had expected full-year earnings of $1.50 to $1.60 a share.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Guilty Plea In Shooting
description: A Korean-born postal worker pleaded guilty in federal court yesterday to firing a handgun on the grounds of the United Nations to protest what he called North Korea's mistreatment of its citizens. No one was injured in the Oct. 3 incident, in which the worker, Steve S. Kim, 57, a naturalized American citizen, used a handgun to fire seven shots. Mr. Kim, who then handed out leaflets, said he aimed almost straight up to avoid injuries. Mr. Kim pleaded guilty to assault with a dangerous weapon against foreign officials and their premises. He could face 30 to 37 months in prison when sentenced on July 22. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YORK, RICHARD T.
description: YORK-Richard T., 52, of New York, died on April 2, 2003. He was President and Founder of The Richard York Gallery in New York. He was a member of the Art Dealers Association of America (serving for 3 years as vice president), and a William Cullen Bryant Fellow with the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Richard was born in Nashville, Tennessee and graduated from Vanderbilt University in 1972. He will be deeply missed by his partner Kevin Scott, his parents James and Jeane York, his brother James Leslie York and his sister Brenda Phillips. Funeral service will be held in Nashville on Monday. A memorial service will be held in New York at a date to be announced. Contributions in memory of Richard may be made to the Rockefeller University/Direct Effect, medical research that was deeply meaningful to him and sent to the Rockefeller University, Box 164, 1230 York Avenue, New York, New York 10010.

description: Barbara Doyle Duncan, who collected, exhibited and wrote about modern Latin American art when the field was still little known to much of the United States art world, died on March 28 at her home in New York. She was 82.

title: 36 Hours | Key Biscayne, Fla.
description: FOR Americans of a certain age, Key Biscayne is probably best known as the place where Richard M. Nixon, a man not known for his relaxation skills, used to hang out with his friend Bebe Rebozo. It is easy to imagine the appeal of this quiet island, a few minutes' drive from downtown Miami, for a busy and eventually beleaguered president. (Nixon was on Key Biscayne on the weekend in 1972 when burglars were arrested inside the Democratic Party's national headquarters at the Watergate complex.) Presidential helicopters have not come by for a long time now; the house the Nixons lived in no longer exists. The island is still a quiet haven -- a bedroom community for Miami; a second-home spot for the well-heeled, including many whose primary homes are in Latin America; and a serene alternative to South Beach for vacationers. Life remains casual and slow: a 20-mile-per-hour speed limit and a number of speed bumps help keep it that way. Landscaped rotaries, which also help keep traffic slow, are lighted at night so drivers can admire the foliage and avoid plowing into the palm trees. MAURA J. CASEY

title: Powell and Europeans See U.N. Role in Postwar Iraq
description: The United States and its European allies proclaimed today that they had reached a broad consensus that the United Nations should play a significant role in the postwar reconstruction of Iraq, but they remained divided over many of the details of how extensive that role should be.

description: PARIS, April 4  A day after the United States and its European allies agreed on significant international cooperation in rebuilding Iraq, France, Russia, and Germany sought today to stake out as extensive a United Nations role as possible in reconstructing the shattered country.

description: Federal authorities in Manhattan said yesterday that they had broken up a ring that had shipped hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of heroin into the New York area from Afghanistan and Pakistan, often hiding the drugs in the seams of traditional Afghan clothing.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Plane Diverted
description: A flight from London to Kennedy Airport in New York was diverted to Shannon Airport after a crew member found a message that was interpreted as a bomb threat, an airline official said. The police escorted 180 passengers and 17 crew members off the plane, United Flight 905, after determining there was no immediate danger. They stayed in Shannon overnight, and the police said they planned to search the plane early today. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Setback For Tobacco Company

The action means that tobacco companies must still make a 10 percent down payment in any judgment of more than $1 billion. Philip Morris, a unit of Altria, has been lobbying to limit the amount as it appeals a $10.1 billion judgment.

title: The More Things Change
description: The wielding of influence is Washington's most lucrative occupation -- a life-support system for the many capital politicians who never go home after their incumbency ends. A fresh head count of the top 100 executive officials at the end of the Clinton administration shows that 51 of them settled in a year later to lobby the government or work for companies that do. This is about the same percentage as for the alumni of the preceding Republican administration, according to the study, by the Center for Public Integrity, a nonpartisan but aggressive watchdog group. ''Where do they go?'' the center's director, Charles Lewis, is quoted as saying by The Associated Press. ''They basically go to the bank.''

description: The federal investigation into Royal Ahold, the Dutch grocer, appeared to broaden yesterday when three of the largest food manufacturers in the United States said that they had been contacted by regulators about their dealings with Ahold's distribution business.

title: At Convention, Builders Talk Of a Common Foe: McGreevey
description: Talk of war filled the air here today, but the battle in question was not being fought against Iraq. Among the thousands of septic-tank installers, brick-face salesmen and big-name developers who gathered for the state's annual builders convention, the enemy was Gov. James E. McGreevey, a smart-growth zealot who has vowed to stamp out sprawl in our lifetime.

title: National Briefing | New England: New Hampshire: Parole In 'To Die For' Killing
description: A man convicted of helping Pamela Smart kill her husband in 1990 was paroled after almost 13 years in prison. The inmate, Raymond Fowler, now 31, waited in a car while four accomplices broke into Mrs. Smart's condominium and shot her husband, Gregory Smart. Mrs. Smart is serving life in prison. The case was the basis for the 1995 film ''To Die For.'' Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Financial Revision Advances
description: The lower house of Congress passed a bill that could pave the way for increased autonomy for the central bank in a vote markets saw as a barometer of the left-leaning government's capacity to push through tax and pension changes later this year. The vote passed 442 to 13. The proposal would alter the legal framework of Brazil's financial system in the Constitution, which would allow the government to grant more independence to the central bank at a later date. The vote showed President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva could successfully mobilize support from his coalition allies and opposition lawmakers, something markets had been eager to see. Mr. Da Silva will need similar support when he tackles thorny reforms of Brazil's bloated state-sector pension system and byzantine tax system later this year. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: New Spokeswoman
description: Gov. John G. Rowland's press secretary, Chris Cooper, has been promoted to special assistant to the governor, and two press aides have been dismissed, Mr. Rowland said yesterday. Calling the changes a routine shakeup, Mr. Rowland said that Mr. Cooper's new responsibilities would include more speechwriting and contributing to the administration's policies. Michele Sullivan, currently the spokeswoman for the state Department of Environmental Protection, will become Mr. Roland's spokeswoman on April 14. The two press aides, Adam Liegeot and Christine DeLoma, were given two weeks' notice yesterday. They are being let go for budgetary reasons, Mr. Cooper said. Paul von Zielbauer (NYT)

Jeremy is bankrupt after taking bad investment advice. Marcia, a single mother, has a child-care emergency. Elsie, who is all alone in the world in her late middle age, has received bad news from her doctor. Peter is cowed by everyone, especially his scary father-in-law. Rose, an unappreciated wife and sometime beautician, mysteriously gives herself a makeover in a ladies' room at the Old Bailey every morning, putting on brighter colors, high-heeled sandals and another layer of makeup.
