title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Paper Maker Slips
description: UPM-Kymmene, the world's third-biggest paper manufacturer, said first-quarter profit fell by about 50 percent from the period a year earlier, hurt by lower paper prices and a weaker dollar. Demand for UPM's products is weak, the chief executive, Juha Niemelae, said. A 20 percent drop in the value of the dollar against the euro in the last year has crimped North American sales, which generate 14 percent of revenue. The company's credit outlook was revised to negative by Standard & Poor's.

He is ''often uncurious and as a result ill informed,'' his former speechwriter, David Frum, wrote in a memoir this year, adding that ''conspicuous intelligence seemed actively unwelcome in the Bush White House.''

title: ARMSTRONG WINS APPROVAL TO SETTLE ASBESTOS CLAIMS
description: Armstrong World Industries, the maker of vinyl flooring, won court approval to pay $2 million to settle 360 asbestos claims by property owners. Judge Randall Newsome of United States Bankruptcy Court approved the accord at a hearing in Wilmington, Del. The property owners, including school districts and churches, sued to recover damages caused by the presence or removal of Armstrong building materials that contained asbestos, a carcinogen. The company sought bankruptcy protection in December 2000.Armstrong, based in Lancaster, Pa., is a unit of Armstrong Holdings Inc.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Commons Leader
description: Robin Cook, who resigned from Prime Minister Tony Blair's cabinet because of Britain's decision to go to war in Iraq without a United Nations mandate, was succeeded in his post as leader of the Commons by John Reid, left, the head of the Labor party and a former Northern Ireland secretary. The appointment of Mr. Reid, considered a political heavyweight, was seen as an effort by Mr. Blair to exert greater party discipline in the House, where Labor rebels have been challenging government positions on critical social policy reforms and the war. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Phelps Continues To Dominate
description: Michael Phelps of Baltimore, 17, won the 100-meter butterfly in 51.89 seconds, a hundredth of a second off his United States record, at United States Swimming's national spring championships in Indianapolis last night.

title: African Mission to Investigate Tensions in Zimbabwe
description: Representatives of a southern African task force are scheduled to visit Zimbabwe next week to investigate intensifying political tensions that threaten to push the country toward further unrest and economic ruin.

title: Bush and Blair Will Meet In Belfast Early Next Week On Iraq, Mideast and Ulster
description: The White House said today that President Bush would meet with the British prime minister, Tony Blair, in Belfast next week to discuss the war in Iraq and the peace efforts in Northern Ireland and in the Middle East.

title: Beijing's Total of Infected Is Revised Up, to Over 50
description: More than 50 cases of a mysterious respiratory illness have now been identified in the Chinese capital, health workers here say, despite the fact that the Chinese Health Minister on Thursday reported a total of just 12 cases as of March 31. The cases are all being treated at You'An Hospital, an infectious disease hospital in central Beijing.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a reorganization of New York City's Correction Department misstated the work that a former commissioner, William J. Fraser, acknowledged subordinates had performed at his home. (The error also occurred in an article last Nov. 27.) According to the department, Mr. Fraser -- who resigned in November amid reports of corruption among his deputies -- said he paid them several years ago to help put a liner in his above-ground pool, not to put in the pool.

title: 10 Americans and 400 Kurds, With Help From U.S. Bombs, Stave Off Iraqis for Now
description: They are 10 Americans and 400 Kurds taking on as many as 2,000 Iraqi soldiers, and with scores of bombs from American planes, they are holding their own for now.

title: The Fragility of Iraq
description: The good news about the looming humanitarian crisis in Iraq is that it is not yet a crisis. There are pockets of desperate need but no widespread suffering. If sufficient military power can be brought to bear quickly to guarantee the security of aid workers, it should be possible to supply all the food, water and medical supplies needed.

title: Antiwar Marchers Invoke Ideas of King 35 Years After His Death
description: Playing bluesy funeral dirges, a Dixieland band led about 200 antiwar demonstrators from Morningside Heights to Bryant Park yesterday on a frigid, misty, gray Manhattan morning. Marchers carried mock coffins. A woman wore a black shroud.

title: Looking at Old Guidelines To See When They Apply
description: In 1920 Joseph Bowne Elwell was murdered, and the crime was apparently unconnected to his skill at auction bridge, the ancestor of the modern game. He was the leading authority of his time, and the author of many books. An English writer, David Bird, has had the interesting idea of examining Elwell's guidelines to determine the extent to which they are still valid.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about President Bush's address to marines at Camp Lejeune, N.C., carried an erroneous byline in some copies. The writers were David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt, not William E. Schmidt.

title: Michael Kelly, 46, Editor And Columnist, Dies in Iraq
description: Michael Kelly, former editor and then editor at large for The Atlantic Monthly and a syndicated columnist for The Washington Post, was killed in Iraq yesterday when the military vehicle in which he was riding ran off a road and into a canal south of Baghdad. He was 46.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurance Unit Spinoff
description: In its first major step to remedy an 800 million ($1.25 billion) capital shortfall, the insurer Royal and Sun Alliance will sell its Healthcare and Assistance business for 147 million ($230 million). The unit is being bought by a newly formed group of its managers and former managers, backed by Barclays Private Equity and by the Bank of Scotland. The insurer will also release 100 million ($156 million) in capital from the unit. Analysts' reaction to the news was mixed. While some felt the unit had fetched a decent price, others expressed concern that Royal and Sun Alliance is disposing of some of its most attractive assets, ultimately limiting its growth prospects. Under pressure to quickly turn a deficit into a surplus, the insurer also intends to issue shares in Promina, its Australian and New Zealand unit, sell some assets in the United States and reduce staff. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: A Nation at War, a daily separate section, begins on Page B1.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: LOWER FILM OUTLOOK Fuji Photo Film said its profit fell 42 percent because of the declining value of its stockholdings. The company, the world's second-largest producer of film, now expects to report that it earned 47 billion yen ($391 million) for the fiscal year that ended Monday. The company said its sales rose 3.9 percent, to 2.5 trillion yen ($20.8 billion).

title: F-16's Pick Off Iraqi Tanks In 'Kill Box' Near Baghdad
description: About 20,000 feet above the ''kill box'' just north of Baghdad yesterday morning two Air Force F-16CG fighter-bombers suddenly spotted potential prey parked next to a railroad freight depot: Iraqi Republican Guard T-72 tanks.

title: Lawmakers' Opposition to New York's School Plan Increases
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's fast-paced effort to overhaul the city's public school system has run into growing and formidable opposition from local and state lawmakers, including some Republicans in Albany who say they feel betrayed after granting the mayor full control of the school system last year.

title: Amherst Chooses New President From Columbia
description: Amherst College has selected Anthony W. Marx, a political science professor at Columbia University and a prize-winning author, as its new president, the college announced yesterday.

title: Pension Shift At Northwest Raises Fears
description: Northwest Airlines is seeking permission to shore up its pension funds with the stock of a subsidiary airline, more stock than the law generally allows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPERMAN, JEROME
description: COOPERMAN-Jerome. Of Pompano Beach, FL, formerly of Ft. Lee, NJ. Husband of Betty (nee Smull). Father of Mitchell, Randi and the late Helene. Brother of the late Milton Cooperman. Grandfather of six grandchildren. Services Sunday, 12:30 PM, ''Wien & Wien,'' 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.

title: British Soldiers' Long Battle for a Southern City's Trust Requires Bullets and Handshakes
description: Two rocket-propelled grenades were launched at British troops on the outskirts of Basra this morning, one exploding above civilians on the highway, sending them crashing for cover and wounding an unknown number. Another struck a tank but did little damage.

title: 2 Brothers Critically Wounded By Shots in Brooklyn Barbershop
description: Two men who the police believe were bent on robbery walked into a Brooklyn barbershop late Thursday night after it had closed and shot the owner and his brother, critically wounding both men, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Dayne in Limbo After Levens Agrees to a Deal
description: On one of the many frustrating days for Giants running back Ron Dayne last season, he sat on a chair at the west end of an otherwise empty Giants Stadium and stared silently at the field. Dayne had not realized the team's expectations, or his own.

title: Creating a New Lure to Catch Crowds for Classical Music
description: In the current economy classical music is often said to be in trouble. Selling tickets in New York is a competitive business. Organizations are struggling with the question of how to attract wider audiences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, GODFREY
description: BECKER-Godfrey. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our beloved longtime member Godfrey Becker. He is a Bar Mitzvah and Confirmant of Rodeph Sholom as well as part of a third generation family. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his wife Minna, his daughter and our beloved sexton, Gail, and son Alan. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Nancy Solomon, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORNELL, CAROL ANNA MARIA
description: CORNELL-Carol Anna Maria went to Heaven on April 3rd, 2003. Mom & Dad gave her life, Carol gave them the world. Beautiful daughter to Henny & Carl. Loving sister to Carl & Lorraine. Sweet aunt to Jonathon, Jennifer & Steven. Precious godmother with precious gifts to Steven. Flight attendant with TWA for 25 years.

title: Little Resistance Encountered as Troops Reach Baghdad
description: Thousands of American marines advanced on the Iraqi capital from the southeast on Friday, moving to within 10 miles of the center and firing artillery as they spread along a broad arc east of the city.

title: Ruling Favors Suspended Meat Inspectors
description: The Agriculture Department retaliated against two federal meat inspectors in the New York area for reporting possible misconduct by other inspectors, according to a ruling by an administrative judge made public yesterday.

title: Assault Charge For Teacher With H.I.V.
description: A teacher at a Roman Catholic elementary school here has been arrested on charges that he sexually assaulted a former student over a two-month period in the summer of 2001, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Liberators and Enemies Can Look a Lot Alike
description: Some administration officials predicted that most Iraqis would immediately rise up against Saddam Hussein and welcome American troops into their country. At this point, the response has ranged from warmth to hostility. Arts & Ideas asked historians to consider their own areas of expertise and explain why citizens often don't embrace outsiders who say they come to liberate them from oppressive regimes. Felicia R. Lee compiled their responses.

title: Rumsfeld and the Generals
description: In this week's mini-mutiny of the generals against Donald Rumsfeld, it was awfully tempting to side with the generals. The defense secretary is a cocksure control freak who seems bent on running the world from his stand-up desk in the Pentagon's E Ring. So when aggrieved officers and former officers suggested that Mr. Rumsfeld was mismanaging the war, it was a delicious story. But was it true?

title: Survival Of Hussein Still Doubted
description: Despite the broadcast today of two videotapes of Saddam Hussein on Iraqi television, intelligence officials said they still lacked conclusive proof that he was alive.

title: Ex-Net to Pay $2.75 Million in Suit Over Killing
description: Jayson Williams, the former New Jersey Nets basketball player, agreed to pay $2.75 million to the family of a limousine driver he is accused of shooting last year, his lawyer said today.

title: NATO's Long View
description: To the Editor:

title: Beliefs; History's pagans might have approved of President Bush's Iraq policy, an author suggests.
description: Once again, the religious rhetoric of President Bush is causing a stir. Fair enough. Mr. Bush does not disguise that his evangelical Christian convictions are an essential part of how he makes decisions, and he has not hesitated to link them with the war on Iraq.

title: SYBASE SHARES DROP AFTER WEAK FIRST QUARTER
description: Shares of Sybase Inc., a maker of database software whose sales have fallen for the last year and a half, fell after the company said first-quarter earnings and sales fell short of estimates. Many customers canceled orders in the final week of the quarter, the chief executive, John Chen, said Thursday. Stock in Sybase, based in Dublin, Calif., fell 60 cents, or 4.7 percent, to $12.13. Sybase said yesterday that first-quarter profit was 16 cents to 20 cents a share, excluding acquisition expenses and other costs. On that basis, profit was expected to be 23 cents, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. First-quarter sales fell to $180 million to $185 million, Sybase said, below the $201 million expected by analysts and the $211 million posted last year.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose as United States forces pushed toward Baghdad. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0734, down from $1.0737 on Thursday. The dollar traded at 119.90 yen, up from 119.49.

title: Israel Stems Suicide Bombings, but at a Cost
description: Amid a wave of suicide bombings last summer, Ali Ajouri, a young militia leader, dispatched a pair of young attackers who blew themselves up in a rundown Tel Aviv neighborhood in July, killing two Israelis and three foreign workers.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Suspected Drug Kingpin Held
description: The government said it had captured a leader of the Jurez drug cartel, one of the country's biggest cocaine syndicates. Mexico's attorney general, Rafael Macedo de la Concha, said the arrest of Arturo Hernndez Gonzlez, whom he described as the chief assassin for the cartel, came amid a power struggle between the Jurez gang and the rival Gulf cartel for control of cocaine shipments. The chief of the Gulf cartel, Osiel Crdenas, was captured on March 14, and at least a dozen murders of suspected cartel members have followed. Mr. Macedo said that with the arrest of Mr. Hernndez, along with eight suspected associates, the Jurez cartel has been left without its main killers. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Betraying the World's Poor
description: Two months after the Sept. 11 attacks, a grieving world agreed to an ambitious new round of trade talks with the aim of helping the world's poorest -- and reducing the motives for terror. Held in Doha, Qatar, these new talks were labeled ''the development round,'' and at their center lay a pledge by rich countries to lift the barriers that keep third-world farm products out of their markets.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Ex-Governor Says Company Defamed Him
description: The former Illinois governor James R. Thompson, who served as special counsel to the embattled union-owned insurance company Ullico said the company had made false and defamatory statements about his highly critical report concerning stock trades by many Ullico directors. Mr. Thompson noted that Ullico said he had found no violations even though his report found compelling evidence of violations of state fiduciary law. Mr. Thompson, who was hired to do an independent investigation of the trading, said Ullico had defamed him and his law firm by saying he was ill-served by a staff that did not fully explore laws about fiduciary duties. Ullico denied misrepresenting the report.

title: The American Portrayal of a War of Liberation Is Faltering Across the Arab World
description: To win over the Islamic world in the war of public relations, the Bush administration's message masters devised a theme, ''Iraq: From Fear to Freedom,'' that casts the war as a humanitarian venture to liberate the Iraqi people from Saddam Hussein.

title: New Dangers In Final Push
description: As American troops rushed to the outskirts of Baghdad, many people seemed to have the impression that the war was all but over. But the American forces are now moving from a fast-paced operation in which they covered vast distances in days to a more methodical fight in a confined area: the streets of the Iraqi capital.

title: The Beauty Within
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Battles: For Baghdad, and for the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: PEOPLESOFT SHARES FALL WITH MISSED FORECAST
description: Shares of PeopleSoft Inc., which makes software that manages payroll and tracks inventory, fell 9 percent after the company said first- quarter profit and sales declined more than forecast. PeopleSoft blamed the war in Iraq for slack license revenue, as customers trimmed spending amid concern that the conflict would hurt the economy. License sales were as low as $80 million after a forecast of $125 million to $135 million, based on a preliminary review, PeopleSoft said late Thursday. Stock in PeopleSoft, based in Pleasanton, Calif., fell $1.48, to $15.02 a share. Profit fell to 11 cents or 12 cents a share, missing a company estimate of as much as 14 cents, the company said. Total sales dropped to $450 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7

title: GENESOFT WINS APPROVAL FOR PNEUMONIA-FIGHTING DRUG
description: GeneSoft Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology company, said the Food and Drug Administration approved its first product, an antibiotic called Factive, for treatment of pneumonia and chronic bronchitis. The drug, which is expected to be available late this year, could help doctors cope with bacteria that are becoming increasingly resistant to older antibiotics. GeneSoft, based in South San Francisco, Calif., said it believed that Factive, which it licensed from LG Life Sciences of South Korea, is the first drug developed by a Korean company to be approved by the F.D.A.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Job Growth Slows
description: Canada's unemployment rate inched down to 7.3 percent in March from 7.4 percent in February, but the pace of job creation slowed markedly, Statistics Canada said. About 14,000 new positions were created in March, a quarter of the number in the previous month. The weakening trend, which confirms other recent economic data, is largely a result of a loss of jobs over the last five months in manufacturing, especially the automotive sector. But restaurants, the lodging sector and construction companies have continued to hire employees in sizable numbers. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article yesterday about the American and British forces' strategy of bypassing some Iraqi cities on the way to Baghdad misstated the rank of the top commander, Tommy R. Franks. He is a general, not a lieutenant general.

title: Of Westerns, Cowboys and the Use of Force
description: To the Editor:

title: Walter Rodgers: Iraqi Officials Fleeing Baghdad
description: (CNN)  U.S. forces began the difficult move into Baghdad on Saturday, pressing from the surrounding areas into the heart of the Iraqi capital.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: CONGO: NEW CONSTITUTION President Joseph Kabila issued a new Constitution for Congo in the wake of a peace accord signed Wednesday in South Africa by representatives of the government, rebel movements, militias and the political opposition. The accord ends more than four years of brutal warfare in Congo, formerly Zaire, and sets up a two-year national unity government that is to lead to the first democratic elections in more than 40 years. An aide to Jean-Pierre Bemba, the head of one of the main rebel groups, Movement for the Liberation of Congo, said Mr. Bemba would swear his loyalty to the new Constitution. (Agence France-Presse)

title: Casualties
description: Announced military casualties in the Iraq war zone as of 5 p.m. eastern time Thursday:

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile on March 27 about Sid Ramin, an orchestrator of the original ''Gypsy'' who is working on the revival, referred incorrectly to Roxbury, where he grew up. It is a section of Boston, not outside the city.

title: Michael Kelly
description: Twelve years ago a 34-year-old freelance writer named Michael Kelly phoned The New Republic magazine and asked its editors to let him file dispatches from the gulf war. They agreed. Mr. Kelly's vivid and intrepid reportage over the ensuing weeks not only won prizes but also helped define the war's coverage and its place in our memory.

title: New York's Horror Budget
description: Albany's three top leaders are circling one another warily, trying to figure out who will be the first to admit the hard truth: New York State's budget is in such horrendous shape that it will take a mix of taxes, cuts and borrowing to fix it.

title: Looking for Roots of War and Terror
description: War may indeed be a continuation of politics by other means. But as cataclysms, shocks and surprises accumulate, wars may often be most comfortably understood as continuations of other wars. Wars make most sense when they resemble wars already known.

title: Of Westerns, Cowboys and the Use of Force
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: NEW COMMONS LEADER Robin Cook, who resigned from Prime Minister Tony Blair's cabinet because of Britain's decision to go to war in Iraq without a United Nations mandate, was succeeded in his post as leader of the Commons by John Reid, left, the head of the Labor party and a former Northern Ireland secretary. The appointment of Mr. Reid, considered a political heavyweight, was seen as an effort by Mr. Blair to exert greater party discipline in the House, where Labor rebels have been challenging government positions on critical social policy reforms and the war. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Wells Keeps the Devil Rays Quiet
description: David Wells, in his first start of the regular season after a controversial spring, tonight showed why he was able to win 19 games for the Yankees last season.

title: Two Battles: For Baghdad, and for the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Augusta and New York
description: To the Editor:

title: No. 500: Sosa Hops Into Rare Territory
description: When Sammy Sosa stepped to the plate in the seventh inning of the Chicago Cubs' game in Cincinnati last night, he was not facing a stranger. Scott Sullivan, the Reds reliever, threw two pitches to Sosa last season that became his 477th and 496th home runs.

title: Kidd's Position Is Unchanged: He's Staying, Unless He Isn't
description: Like the warm breezes of spring blowing in one day, Jason Kidd says his intention is to stay in New Jersey. Like the winter gusts returning the next day, Kidd says nothing is certain.

title: Fight Bribery Abroad
description: Federal authorities have brought corruption charges against two American businessmen involved in multibillion-dollar contracts to develop the oil fields in Kazakhstan. One of them, James Giffen, an adviser to the president of Kazakhstan, is charged with transferring tens of millions of dollars to the offshore accounts of a "senior Kazakh official." Both men say they are not guilty. But the indictments alone are a heartening sign that Washington remains serious about opposing corruption, even when foreign policy interests push the other way. The case may also encourage other major developed countries to finally join the fight on corrupt practices in international business.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FLEMING COS., Lewisville, Tex., the United States' largest grocery distributor, won a bankruptcy judge's approval of $50 million in financing intended to allow it to pay suppliers while it restructures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YALOWITZ, ARTHUR
description: YALOWITZ-Arthur. On April 4th, 2003. Loving father of Lee and Angelica and Eve and Sean. Dear brother of Vic and Sandy. He will be deeply missed. Service Sunday, 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: U.S. Committee Ponders Leadership
description: Paul George, a vice president of the United States Olympic Committee, has asked the organization's executive committee to nominate William C. Martin, the acting president since February, as permanent president at a meeting next Friday.

title: With Current War, Professors Protest, As Students Debate
description: It is not easy being an old lefty on campus in this war.

title: Breisch Sets Record For Discus Throw
description: Becky Breisch of Nebraska set a meet record in the women's discus throw at the Texas Relays last night. The Husker sophomore's throw of 192 feet 7 inches is the best by a collegian this year.

title: Of Westerns, Cowboys and the Use of Force
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki Criticizes Bloomberg in Dispute Over Federal Antiterror Aid
description: As criticism grew over his attempt to secure a large portion of federal security aid earmarked for New York City, Gov. George E. Pataki chastised Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday, hinting that the mayor's insistence on the greater share of aid was hurting his request for a commuter tax.

title: Dash to Baghdad Leaves Debate in Dust
description: Even by the standards of the Third Army's headlong dash across France under Gen. George S. Patton in World War II, the allied invasion of Iraq has accelerated with stunning speed in less than a week.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a reorganization of New York City's Correction Department misstated the work that a former commissioner, William J. Fraser, acknowledged subordinates had performed at his home. (The error also occurred in an article last Nov. 27.) According to the department, Mr. Fraser -- who resigned in November amid reports of corruption among his deputies -- said he paid them several years ago to help put a liner in his above-ground pool, not to put in the pool.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Moi Lets Go
description: Daniel arap Moi, who led Kenya for 24 years before stepping down as president at the end of last year, announced that he would resign as chairman of the Kenya African National Union to allow new blood to lead the ailing political party. The party had never lost an election in Kenya until last year, when Mwai Kibaki assembled a coalition of opposition parties and soundly defeated Mr. Moi's handpicked successor for the presidency. Mr. Kibaki assumed the office on Dec. 30. Mr. Moi, 78, said also that he would start a Moi Africa Institute to tackle problems facing all of Africa.

title: Allies Once Again? But That Could Be the Rub
description: Suddenly, almost as if reflecting American progress on the battlefield, things are looking up in Washington's relations with its European allies -- or, at least, they are looking a little bit better.

title: Expos Sweep Aside Uncertainties and Show They Merit Respect
description: Braves Manager Bobby Cox kept shaking his head in Atlanta this week, while his pitching coach, Leo Mazzone, rocked next to him, each occasionally muttering to the other through creased expressions. The Montreal Expos can do that to you.

title: 108,000 Jobs Lost in March, U.S. Says
description: The job market continued to deteriorate in March as the economy lost 108,000 jobs, the government reported yesterday, raising worries that the United States is closer to slipping into a recession than it has been for more than a year.

title: At 87, a Playboy Can Dream, Can't He?
description: AT 87, Jorge Guinle still retains the penetrating blue eyes and suave charm that once helped make him one of the world's most celebrated playboys. What he no longer has, aside from his youth, is his fortune.

title: Defiant Iraqis Say U.S. Advance Has Been Broken
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 5 - Senior Iraqi officials remained defiant today in the face of American military might, asserting that Iraqi soldiers and suicide bombers had ``crushed'' American troops at Baghdad's international airport and broken the American advance on the capital into isolated pockets that were surrendering to relentless Iraqi attacks.

title: Agency Lowers Estimate of Post-9/11 Aid to Small Businesses
description: Prompting the latest dispute over whether government programs are meeting Lower Manhattan's needs since Sept. 11, 2001, New York State's economic development agency has sharply cut its estimate of how much it will spend on a major incentives program for small businesses to stay in the area or move there.

title: Commission Backs Bloomberg On Plan to Close 8 Firehouses
description: A commission charged with exploring alternatives to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to close eight firehouses has apparently voted in favor of it, city officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. Squeezes Baghdad and Readies Next Step
description: United States troops began a gradual encirclement of Baghdad on Friday, apparently as part of a strategy to isolate the capital, and American tanks were reported moving into the city this morning.

title: Judge Critical of Secrecy In Terror Case Prosecution
description: The Justice Department's hopes of placing Zacarias Moussaoui on trial on charges of conspiring in the Sept. 11 terror attacks suffered a new blow today when a federal trial judge said she was skeptical that the government could prosecute the case ''under the shroud of secrecy under which it seeks to proceed.''

title: A Reminder
description: Daylight saving time resumes at 2 a.m. tomorrow. Clocks are set ahead one hour.

title: Two Battles: For Baghdad, and for the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Safety Note
description: Fire officials recommend changing the batteries in smoke alarms twice a year, when daylight time starts and ends. This spring, that is tomorrow.

title: For Weary U.S. Troops, End Is Still Elusive
description: The capture of Iraq's principal international airport just west of Baghdad today left many American soldiers feeling more exhausted than elated, with a dull sense that the end was not yet in sight.

title: Tokyo Gives Ailing Banks More Time to Fix Finances
description: In their tug of war with the major Japanese banks over how hard and how fast the banks must move to solve their financial problems, Japan's financial regulators voluntarily let go of some of their rope today.

title: Illness Takes a Toll On Hotels in Asia
description: The hotel industry is suffering almost as much as the airline industry from outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome, as guests cancel trips and hotel managers take emergency steps to prevent guests and employees from becoming infected.

title: Cuba Arrests 8 in Hijacking of Havana Ferry
description: Cuban security forces arrested at least eight armed men who hijacked a passenger ferry west of Havana and tried to reach the United States, the Cuban government said today. Nearly 50 hostages, including some children, aboard the ferry were freed.

title: United Chief Takes Pay Cut But Retains Other Payments
description: United Airlines said yesterday that Glenn F. Tilton, its chief executive, would take a 14 percent cut in his base salary this year, though Mr. Tilton's much more significant stock and cash bonuses and other compensation, worth millions, will remain intact.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLUM, CHRISTOPHER RAINEY
description: PLUM-Christopher Rainey. On March 30, at age 39 in Los Angeles. Son of Roy Rainey Plum and the late Alix Ryan Plum and brother of Richard Ryan Plum. A memorial service for relatives and close friends will be held Saturday, June 21, at The St. Andrews Dune Church, Gin Lane, Southampton, N.Y. at 2 PM.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: BOLIVIA: HOPES FADE FOR MUDSLIDE VICTIMS Officials have all but lost hope of finding survivors of a landslide that buried up to 400 people in a northern gold-mining town, and they said they might evacuate the town and declare it a cemetery. Rescuers have found 19 bodies beneath the tons of mud and rock after a mountainside collapsed Monday in Chima, 117 miles from the capital, La Paz. Heavy rains and the haphazard use of dynamite by miners were blamed for the slide. (Reuters)

title: Legislators In Georgia Act on Change To State Flag
description: Seeking to settle a long-running dispute, Georgia lawmakers took the first step today toward approving a new state flag, one based on the Confederacy's Stars and Bars rather than its battle flag.

title: Al Jazeera Returns to Coverage From Baghdad After Shutdown
description: Al Jazeera, the most-watched Arab-language television news network, resumed its coverage from Iraq yesterday after the Iraqis rescinded a reporting ban on its two correspondents in Baghdad.

title: Judges Uphold Convictions In '93 Bombing
description: A federal appeals panel in Manhattan yesterday upheld the convictions of Ramzi Ahmed Yousef in the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center and a 1994 plot to blow up a dozen American airliners as they flew across the Pacific.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about an ethnic conflict that has shut down oil production in southwestern Nigeria misidentified the scene. It was Madangho, a village destroyed in the fighting, not an oil terminal in the nearby town of Escravos.

title: Mobil Is Under Scrutiny in Bribe Inquiry
description: The United States government is investigating the role of the Mobil Oil Corporation, a unit of Exxon Mobil, in what the government says was a scheme to bribe the leaders of Kazakhstan for the country's oil rights, a prosecutor said yesterday.

title: NETWORK ASSOCIATES TO BUY ENTERCEPT FOR $120 MILLION
description: Network Associates Inc., the maker of McAfee antivirus software, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Entercept Security Technologies for $120 million to add programs that protect computers from new types of attacks. Entercept, which is closely held, sells software that detects and stops attacks against server computers, which run Web sites and networks and maintain databases, said Art Matin, president of Network Associates' McAfee security unit. Network Associates, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said Tuesday that it had agreed to buy IntruVert Networks, a maker of hardware devices that look for intruders on computer networks, for $100 million.

title: INSIDE
description: 108,000 Jobs Lost in March

title: Knicks' Hard-Earned Victory May Become a Moot Point
description: The move was vintage Allan Houston, so nice, so smooth. On the right wing, with the 6-foot-9 Andrei Kirilenko guarding him, Houston drove toward the baseline and lost Kirilenko with an exaggerated pump fake. Suddenly free, Houston sank a soft 19-foot jumper to give the Knicks a hard-fought 94-92 overtime victory over the Utah Jazz at the Delta Center.

title: Our Failure in Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: Philip Morris To Push Bill In Illinois To Lower Bond
description: Philip Morris USA, the nation's biggest cigarette maker, is expected to push next week for new legislation in Illinois that would allow the company to post a $1.2 billion bond while it appeals a recent court judgment rather than putting up 10 times that amount, a company lobbyist said yesterday.

title: The Rural Opposition: Protesting Where Everybody Knows Your Name
description: When Eva Barr called the county courthouse to ask about a permit for an antiwar protest, the clerk on the other end of the line went silent.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Lower Film Outlook
description: Fuji Photo Film said its profit fell 42 percent because of the declining value of its stockholdings. The company, the world's second-largest producer of film, now expects to report that it earned 47 billion yen ($391 million) for the fiscal year that ended Monday. The company said its sales rose 3.9 percent, to 2.5 trillion yen ($20.8 billion). Ken Belson (NYT)

title: A Child Copes With Dad's Zealotry
description: This is probably an unusual -- but perhaps apt -- time for Tareque Masud's intelligent drama, ''The Clay Bird,'' an offering of the New Directors/New Films series and easily one of the finest pictures of this year or any other. Masud's expansive fluidity is rapturous, inspired equally by the floating equanimity of Satyajit Ray and the work of the Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami, who deftly uses ritual behavior to provide social commentary.

title: Public University in Ohio To End Instate Tuition Break
description: Miami University in Ohio hopes to become the first public university in the nation to charge residents the same tuition that out-of-state students pay.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: OIL EXECUTIVE SETS TENURE Mikhail Kho- dorkovsky, left, the chief executive of the Russian oil producer Yukos Oil, said he would resign in 2007. In an interview with the Russian daily Vedomosti, Mr. Khodorkovsky, 39, said that he expected that four years from now he would want "to rest" and that one of his goals as manager was to prepare a candidate to take his place. Analysts interpreted the announcement as one of the first steps by a Russian tycoon to hand over management of an empire he built to hired outsiders. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: M. Anthony Fisher, 52, Partner In a Leading Real Estate Firm
description: M. Anthony Fisher, a senior partner at Fisher Brothers, one of the most prominent real estate firms in the city, died yesterday in a plane crash in Massachusetts that killed six of the seven people on board. He was 52.

title: Transcript of Bush's Radio Address
description: Following is a transcript of a statement by President Bush broadcast on radio today, as recorded by The New York Times .

title: Handling of Suspicious Mail Raises Questions in Hartford

title: Britain Moves to Deport Radical Cleric
description: LONDON, April 5 — Britain moved today to deport Abu Hamza al-Masri, the country's most outspoken radical cleric, who until recently was the imam of a mosque in North London widely depicted as a recruiting ground for fundamentalist Islam and Al Qaeda.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Semiconductor Forecast Cut
description: Europe's biggest semiconductor maker, STMicroelectronics, issued its second warning in three months that it would miss its first-quarter revenue target. The company, which has been hurt by delayed orders and a strong euro, warned that its quarterly gross profit margin would be 35 percent, slightly less than its earlier prediction of 36 percent, and that revenue would be $1.6 billion. When STMicroelectronics announced its annual results in January, the chief executive, Pasquale Pistorio, said the outlook for the full year 2003 was still positive and that gross margin would be about 40 percent at the end of 2003. The company, which is based in Switzerland, will release first-quarter results April 23. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: TRAVEL WARNINGS Britain, Canada and Australia warned against traveling to the Philippines as police searched for suspects in a bombing Wednesday that killed 16 people and wounded 50 at a ferry terminal in the southern port city Davao. That explosion came less than a month after a bomb killed 23 people at the airport in Davao. "Further bomb explosions are possible across the country, including Manila," Australia's travel advisory said, "and risks are high in airports and seaports." (AP)

title: When a Dash Becomes a Siege
description: Gen. George S. Patton, my grandfather, has received a lot of mention lately in connection with the astonishing dash of the American military across more than 300 miles of Iraq in less than a week. Beginning with the breakout from Normandy in August 1944, Patton's Third Army similarly used speed and maneuverability to press the attack, stretching supply lines to the breaking point while gobbling up huge tracts of territory and taking thousands of enemy prisoners.

title: Oil Companies to Resume Work in Niger Delta
description: Roughly two weeks after political violence closed the spigot on oil from the western Niger Delta, two of the three major multinational oil companies that operate in the restive riverine area said today that they would gradually resume production.

description: Shipments of freight on the nation's railroads rose 3.4 percent in the first quarter, helping the companies as they paid more for fuel, battled delays caused by winter storms and hauled less coal, the Association of American Railroads said today.

description: Mikhail Khodorkovsky, left, the chief executive of the Russian oil producer Yukos Oil, said he would resign in 2007. In an interview with the Russian daily Vedomosti, Mr. Khodorkovsky, 39, said that he expected that four years from now he would want ''to rest'' and that one of his goals as manager was to prepare a candidate to take his place. Analysts interpreted the announcement as one of the first steps by a Russian tycoon to hand over management of an empire he built to hired outsiders. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

So far, he said, the academy has made offers to 1,234 applicants, compared with 1,026 last year, a number that includes a 15 percent increase in the number of offers to women, to 243 this year from 181 a year ago. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Building Begins On Holocaust Memorial
description: After years of debate and delay, construction began on Germany's national Holocaust memorial. Bulldozers started leveling the five-acre site in Berlin, near the Brandenburg Gate, about 18 months after a groundbreaking ceremony. The Parliament president, Wolfgang Thierse, said the monument, designed by the American architect Peter Eisenman, should be completed by May 8, 2005, the 60th anniversary of the defeat of Germany in World War II. The memorial -- 2,700 concrete slabs laid out in a plot the size of two football fields to look like a graveyard -- commemorates the more than six million Jews who died in the Holocaust. The first slabs are to be put in place in August or September. The monument was approved by the Parliament in June 1999, after decades of emotional debate on how Germany could remember Holocaust victims.

title: National Briefing: Southwest

The contractor, Francisco Vazquez-Torres, was convicted of conspiracy resulting in death and was fined $125,000. In May 2001, Border Patrol agents found a group of immigrants on the Cabeza Prieta National Wildlife Refuge. About 30 Mexicans paid $1,400 each and were told that the trip would take two days. By the third day, the group's guides became lost and stranded the immigrants in the desert, where temperatures reached 115 degrees. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALMON, ROSEMARY KENNEDY
description: SALMON-Rosemary Kennedy. Passed away early Saturday morning from heart failure. She was born in Albany, NY, to Evelyn M. and Thomas P. Kennedy. A graduate of Kenwood Convent of The Sacred Heart and Parsons School of Design where she majored in costume design and illustration. Afterwards, she was a member of The New York Art Students League. While in New York she met and married Donald B. Salmon, deceased. The ceremony was performed by Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen in the Lady's Chapel within St. Patrick's Cathedral. Her husband Donald was a chemical industry executive and an owner of Hoke Inc. involved in the design and manufacture of fluid precision valves and instruments. Her interest in art continued as a longtime member of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She resided in Englewood, NJ, and is survived by a son Thomas C. The cop who failed to collar the person who strangled Angella Benton on her 24th birthday can't do much about it now; having taken a bullet in the spine, he's paralyzed from the neck down. But the man can talk, and he talks Harry Bosch into taking the cold case, a challenge that appeals to the former Los Angeles homicide detective because he, too, was touched by Angella, who died with hands outstretched in a plea for help. ''I know my mission and I know there is no turning away or turning back,'' he says. ''My job in this world, badge or no badge, was to stand for the dead.''

What could be more basic than the combination, in 1999, of Meg White's elementary drumbeat and Jack White's loud electric guitar, as he set loose a voice steeped in Elvis Presley, Elmore James and Robert Plant to wail, ''Where do you want an explosion now?''

title: Something Wrong With Charlie
description: In the first few paragraphs of THE BOY ON THE BUS (Free Press, $23), what seems just a small change in routine alters everything: Meg's 8-year-old son, Charlie, does not rush off the school bus. ''This ritual, her son coming home from school, was all wrong,'' Meg thinks, and boards the bus to encounter a child whose face is ''fuller, firmer, more grown into itself.'' This isn't her son, she decides. Even the boy's father, returning home late and checking on him in his sleep, can affirm only that he ''sure looks enough'' like Charlie. (''Enough?'' Meg asks, never losing her gift for dry comedy.) It would seem to drain the story of its complexity to suggest that people vanish as they grow, but Deborah Schupack's strange, unsettling, lyrical novel defies simple paraphrase. Driven by rage -- at her perpetually absent husband, at the willfulness of her teenage daughter, at her formerly asthmatic son (or, rather, his replacement), who seems not to need her -- Meg journeys through a sort of psychological fifth dimension, the internal world being the one she sees. Motherhood with all its contradictions has rarely been shown so nakedly. Schupack gives us Meg's view and everyone else's in overlapping layers, delineating domestic life in a small Vermont town where even the attentive sheriff and the friendly pediatrician whom you address by first name take on a potentially threatening edge. From beginning to end in this novel, nothing is ordinary, while at the same time everything is. Matthew Flamm

title: The Iraqi Time Bomb
description: The denial of economic reality that permeated Wall Street a few years ago has now migrated to Washington. On Wall Street, when companies did not generate the promised profits to justify the bubble in stock prices, many analysts told investors that profits did not matter. A new economy would be gauged by other measures, they insisted. Today, in similar fashion, as the federal budget has plunged into the red over the past two years, President Bush's economic team is telling the nation that deficits no longer matter.

title: The Party's Over
description: ON a quiet spring afternoon, the white building at 1181 North Sea Road looks like an oversize home, hardly uncommon in the Hamptons. There is a white picket fence, and tall trees that obscure the view from the road. The only noises come from rustling squirrels, chirping birds and passing cars.

title: Commercial Property/Hotels; Bookings Are Down, but Properties Keep Opening
description: DESPITE a decline in bookings attributed to economic softness and the uncertainties of the war in Iraq, hotel operators have been showing confidence in the future of travel to New York by opening new projects and refurbishing older properties.

title: The Ideas Are Outside the Box; The Art Is in It

Nina Bentley's ''Choosing a Carrier'' is fairly memorable, as well. They're both, well, hokey, although herein lies the appeal of this oddball exhibition of around 100 works of box art, wooden boxes filled with bric-a-brac from dime stores, Salvation Army bins and backyard garages. The eclecticism and zany inventiveness of it all leaves you momentarily gasping in astonishment.

title: Member of the Club
description: Sometime in the early fall of 2001 (not long after 9/11), my friend Bobby Harling met me in Nashville, the city where I'd spent my childhood summers with my grandparents and where I still often visit my various close friends and relations. Bobby had originally planned to stay for a night (there was a belated birthday party in my honor -- I was born, alas, on Sept. 11), but that was before we started eating. I think it was on the third day of his visit, and during our second meal at the Belle Meade Country Club, that he put his fork down and asked: ''Do they stop you at the city limits and check to make sure you're not smuggling the food out? Why haven't I ever tasted any of this stuff before?''

It even has a ''panic room'' where residents can hide from intruders in high-tech bulletproof safety until the police come. But there's a safe in this panic room, and three men (Dwight Yoakam, Jared Leto and Forest Whitaker) break in to steal its contents: $3 million. Unfortunately, the telephone in the panic room hasn't been installed yet -- Saturday at 10 p.m on Cinemax.

title: Film; Amnesia, Without the Melodrama
description: MIDNIGHT in Helsinki. A large man with a weathered face steps off a train, carrying a suitcase that contains all of his possessions. He sits down on a park bench for a few moments' rest, but just as he nods off, three street punks sneak up behind him and hammer him into unconsciousness with a baseball bat. When he wakes up in the hospital the next day, he no longer knows who he is -- but with his head swathed in bandages, he irresistibly suggests Claude Rains in the 1933 ''The Invisible Man.'' And without a name, he has indeed become invisible in this strange new city -- unable to apply for work or welfare or even a place to live.

title: DEADLINE MISSED

As a result, it will have to pay $100,000 to the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation. Officials said they would now try to meet an April 30 deadline or face paying $50,000 more. The foundation is expected to spend the money for preservation efforts in Stone Harbor. The borough originally said that leaving the waste on unused beach land would not hurt the habitat of endangered piping plovers. The government sued to have it removed, leading to the settlement. title: Captive Audience
description: From 1966 to 1970, I disappeared from snapshots. I hid, even from my parents' camera. See, I was ashamed, of the uniform. I'd tried for ''conscientious objector'' in my Carolina county and was laughed out of the office. So, avoiding six years in a federal pen, I spent four in bell-bottoms, floating just off Southeast Asia. Buddies wore their caps cocked, making this assigned life feel more personal. I wore my uniform as a prisoner wears his. Why am I finally ''coming out'' about all this? I never ever speak of it. The new war drives me. My ''service'' years I freeze-dried. Till last week, I kept them stashed in the dark rear corner of a lead-lined meat locker. Now they're thawing -- fact is, ''My name is Allan and I am secretly . . . B-32-37-38.'' Name, hometown and serial number, that's what Iraqi captors ask of our latest P.O.W.'s. These kids' faces are banged up, squinty. Eyes shocked and awed at gunpoint, they recall me to myself. Such dulled innocence drives me to confess.

title: 'Enough'
description: For the first few miles of the marathon, I was still fresh enough to look around, to pay attention. I remember mostly the muffled thump of several thousand pairs of expensive sneakers padding the Ottawa pavement-an elemental sound, like surf, or wind. But as the race wore on, the herd stretched into a dozen flocks and then into a long string of solitary runners. Pretty soon each of us was off in a singular race, pitting one body against one will. By the halfway point, when all the adrenaline had worn off, the only sound left was my breath rattling in my chest. I was deep in my own private universe, completely absorbed in my own drama.

title: 'The Crisis of Islam'
description: It is difficult to generalize about Islam. To begin with, the word itself is commonly used with two related but distinct meanings, as the equivalents both of Christianity and of Christendom. In the one sense it denotes a religion, a system of belief and worship; in the other, the civilization that grew up and flourished under the aegis of that religion. The word Islam thus denotes more than fourteen centuries of history, a billion and a third people, and a religious and cultural tradition of enormous diversity. Christianity and Christendom represent a greater number and a longer period-more than 2 billion people, more than twenty centuries, and even greater diversity. Nevertheless, certain generalizations can be and are made about what is variously called Christian, Judeo-Christian, post-Christian, and-more simply-Western civilization. While generalizing about Islamic civilization may be difficult and at times in a sense dangerous, it is not impossible and may in some ways be useful.

As we moved forward, mostly through sand but occasionally on an unfinished road that was half-gravel, Iraqis appeared at the convoy's flanks, doing what comes naturally to destitute civilians when well-provisioned men and machines of war rumble by: they were begging.

title: 'It's tentative, amorphous folk and folk rock for people and a moment...too unsettled for the certainty of anthems.'
description: ''Big shot guns with no guns/big shot army with no army at all,'' Cat Power sings in her affectingly benumbed way. Drums lope. A bass line climbs to the upper frets, retreats, repeats. A guitar emits a soft cloud of fuzz-tone and feedback. ''I don't know what is worse,'' she continues, ''and I can't tell what is the best.'' The song is called ''Shaking Paper,'' and it is not a protest song. ''Shaking Paper,'' like most every other song on Cat Power's new album, ''You Are Free,'' is about inquietude, balkiness, dread. Since its release in late February, ''You Are Free'' has topped the playlists of the country's left-of-the-dial college radio stations. It has a pared-down sound -- a couple of grave minor chords, a muffled guitar, a piano with bare-room echoes: the sound of a sleepless night. It has lyrics that tend toward the dreamy and mystic and even biblical: faint visions, quiet supplications, muted lamentations. It's tentative, amorphous folk and folk rock for people -- and a moment -- too unsettled for the certainty of anthems.

title: All Dew, No Shine

Molton Brown's Instant Matte Moisturizer claims to soften skin and control sebum, or skin oil, with a blend of plant-based ingredients ($43 at Barneys New York). Clearasil's Total Control All Day Mattifying Moisturizer contains vitamins A and E to hydrate, along with powdered white Chinese clay, which the company says will eliminate oil and reduce shine ($7.99 at Duane Reade). Caudalie's Vinopure, which will be out later this year, says it targets early signs of aging as well as excess sheen ($45 at Sephora.com).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEADER, SYLVIA Z.
description: LEADER-Sylvia Z., 89. Beloved mother of Jonathan and Dina Leader, wife of the late Milton R. Leader, and grandmother of Jessica, Amanda, Lyuba, and Marc, died peacefully at home on April 4, 2003. Sylvia Leader was a graduate of The Fieldston School, class of 1932, and of Barnard College, where she majored in French literature. She subsequently worked as a book buyer at Macy's and was an early writer of children's radio shows at WQXR. She also sang in the chorus of the predecessor company of the New York City Opera. Sylvia Leader was a woman of great aesthetic taste, who always enjoyed doing things well. She was an early collector of Abstract Expressionist painting and went to the studios of Paul Georges, Al Held, George Segal, and many others, where she purchased their works. She was deeply committed to Judaism and spent much time helping those who were less fortunate than herself. Her wonderful imagination and flair will always be remembered by her family. She will be greatly missed. Jonathan and Dina Leader

title: The Philosopher of Islamic Terror
description: Berman's article was a revealing and essential account of the ideological background of terrorism. However, after surveying the thinking of Sayyid Qutb, a man who traces all the world's problems to liberalism and reason itself, Berman asks, Where are the thinkers who will bring reason to bear against liberalism's enemies? For followers of Qutb, the problem is not that we haven't used liberal reason persuasively enough but that we use liberal reason at all. Against men who ''urge one another to death and to murder'' for the sake of their theocratic visions, the ''war of ideas'' cannot be fought with ideas alone. Berman's litany of the West's inadequacies -- United Nations resolutions, unilateralism, multilateralism, weapons inspectors, coercion and noncoercion -- is in fact the only answer to the terrorists.

title: Without Health Insurance, Stark Choices

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, THOMAS
description: FOX-Thomas. Dearest Tom, wherever you walked, you carried a ceaseless charm, an unefforted style, a generosity of spirit, an exuberance in your approach to matters of both weight and frivolousness, a playful appreciation for things high and low, an ability to bring light into a darkened room, an unabashed hearty laugh, and an unmatched steadfastness toward those fortunate enough to be close to you. You were indeed the fourth brother. The world is already a poorer place without you. Wherever you may be, take comfort in knowing that the ever-present smile on your sweet face is how you'll always be remembered. With affection and fond remembrance, Edward Nahem

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARKER, MARY (NEE SZUR)
description: BARKER-Mary (nee Szur). On Friday, March 28, 2003. Widow of Chris K. Barker. Mother of John, prematurely deceased in 1993 at age 46. Born in East Chicago, IN, Mary was a woman clearly ahead of her time. She graduated from Purdue University, and ignoring the conventional thinking of the time as to what constituted a ''woman's place'', relocated to New York City, taking a clerical job at Sears Roebuck to ''make ends meet'', and retiring 38 years later as Fashion Director of Sears. Member Metropolitan Museum of New York, and proud volunteer in costume restoration. Longtime parishioner of Church of Our Saviour, and dedicated volunteer to their fellowship. Survived by three grandsons, Jordan, Christopher and Joshua; two great-grandchildren, Dylan and Madeline. To all who knew her, she leaves a legacy of perseverance and indomitable fortitude. So many people loved and respected her, and will deeply miss her presence, and cherish her memory. Visiting hours 7:009:00 PM, Monday, April 7 at Dimiceli & Sons Funeral Home, 152 E. 28 St., NYC. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10:00 AM at Church of Our Saviour, Park Ave. at 38 St. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUZUKI, ALICE
description: SUZUKI-Alice. The Union Settlement staff and Board of Directors deeply mourn the loss of Alice Suzuki, 90, the first and longtime director of the Union Washington Community Center, founded in 1956. Born in Los Angeles, Alice was interned with other Japanese-Americans after Pearl Harbor. Thanks in large part to the Religious Society of Friends and to the YWCA, she graduated from UCLA and came East to graduate from the Columbia School of Social Work. She served first at Five Towns Neighborhood Association in Lawrence, L.I. and then at Union Settlement for the remainder of her career. With no children of her own, Alice helped to raise hundreds of East Harlem children. She inspired and trained her staff who in turn have been imaginative and dedicated social workers. She encouraged Raphael Flores, who later became the founder of Hotline Cares. Our warm sympathies to Alice's family. Stuart Mieklejohn, Chairman Ellen Simon, Executive Director

title: The Ping of Spring

In the ensuing furor, it is clear far more is at stake than a retreat from the modern to the antique, from the ping to the crack of the bat. title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDMAN, CLARA

She was a gentle and gallant lady who was admired and deeply loved by those lucky enough to have known her. She left us a legacy of love and a lifetime of treasured memories of her warmth and wisdom. She is deeply missed by us and always will be. The Family

Powerful lobbyists and corporate executives track down his new telephone number and call him unannounced; strangers buttonhole him in the halls of Congress, hoping for a few precious minutes of his time.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WALERSTEIN, JEFFREY D.
description: WALERSTEIN-Jeffrey D. April 7, 1964-April 14, 1989. Always in our daily thoughts. We miss you more each passing day. Love ya, Mom, Dad & Mark.

description: American forces pushed into the outskirts of Baghdad, encountering only sporadic resistance. After intense air attacks on Iraq's Republican Guard, the Army advanced to the airport west of Baghdad and the Marines closed in from the east. There were reports of large-scale surrenders by Iraqi troops. Saddam Hussein, or at least pictures of him, appeared on Iraqi television, providing some evidence but not proof that he is alive. American officials warned that Baghdad might not fall without further heavy fighting.

description: AS coalition forces met resistance in Iraq, it was a stark reminder that foreign populations often do not behave as Americans would expect.

title: Beyond Iraq; Paramilitaries on the March
description: PARAMILITARY forces are linked to some of the deadliest crimes of recent history. The ethnic cleansing in Bosnia and Kosovo was largely carried out by Serb paramilitary forces, not the regular military. Hutu militias, known as the Interahamwe, were responsible for the 1994 genocide in Rwanda. In Indonesia, West Timorese paramilitaries and government-organized youth squads ledthe ''dirty wars'' against the separatists of East Timor.

description: In the largest covert military campaign in recent history, more than 9,000 Special Operations forces are conducting some of the riskiest missions of the war in Iraq, working in nearly every corner of the country and penetrating even the streets of Baghdad.

description: THE Ailey II company can be counted on to deliver high-energy dancing made even more electric by the push of youthful ambition. And this junior troupe of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater delivered just that in a performance last month at Aaron Davis Hall at City College in Harlem. But the most memorable moments of the evening came at the start, in opening comments by Sylvia Waters and Judith Jamison, the directors, respectively, of Ailey II and the senior company.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation: Defying Expectations; Holding Steady? It's What Americans Do.
description: AS American troops encountered strong resistance a week ago, critics of the war against Iraq were quick to play the expectations card. The president never fully explained the costs of a protracted war in either money or lives, some charged. As a result, surely the public mood would soon shift from the belief that the war would be over in days to the conclusion that a quagmire was all but inevitable.

title: Board's Approval of Sale by Sponsor
description: Q -- I signed a contract to buy a co-op apartment directly from the sponsor. It was clearly understood that there would be no need for board approval. The sponsor told me, though, that as a courtesy to the board, he had agreed for them to have a meeting with me just to get to know me. I agreed. Now, after two months, the bank is ready for a closing, but I have been asked to do all the paperwork normally necessary for board approval. Can I refuse to provide these papers? Will I be breaking the contract? . . . Marlen Garcia, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Do You Want to Smoke? Step Outside
description: To the Editor:

title: Bed Among the Lentils
description: ALKING HEADS," a collection of monologues by the British playwright Alan Bennett, are vivid, wry, psychological X-rays of individuals who don't even know they are being examined. Originally written for the BBC in the 1980's and subsequently seen in the United States on PBS, "Talking Heads" opens tonight in a new production at the Minetta Lane Theater. The two programs of three monologues each will be presented on separate evenings. The cast  Kathleen Chalfant, Daniel Davis, Christine Ebersole, Valerie Mahaffey, Lynn Redgrave and Brenda Wehle  is directed by Michael Engler.

title: Syracuse Is in a Zone and Heading to Its Third Final
description: There were the splayed legs of the sophomore Hakim Warrick as he rammed home a tomahawk dunk on the baseline. There was the freshman Gerry McNamara's stick-his-landing jump stop before arcing a 3-pointer from the top of the key. And there was an awful lot of the freshman Carmelo Anthony spinning beneath the basket for a reverse slam, falling away and kissing jumpers off the glass, smoothly sinking free throws.

title: Mutombo Struggles to Find Rhythm and Role on Court
description: Dikembe Mutombo wanted to play. He wanted to run and bump through a physical workout. Instead, with the Nets opting for a brief shooting session this afternoon, Mutombo again found himself lightheartedly swatting at Kerry Kittles's hook shots, a feat hardly even worthy of a wag of his finger.

title: The Sound of Things to Come
description: Are there no lengths to which we will not go to intrude on the privacy of others? Norris's HyperSonic Sound seems poised either to invade our privacy or to fry the brains of our adversaries in war. In'nat cool?

description: IVESTING in emerging stock markets has always been risky for mutual fund managers, but finding rising markets has become even more challenging lately.

title: Empire Maker Maintains Status as Derby Favorite
description: The races were spread across the map yesterday, from sunny Florida to chilly Chicago all the way to California, but in each place the theme was the same: is there any horse out there that can challenge Empire Maker in the Kentucky Derby? Although the question won't be answered until the first Saturday in May, it can be said that Empire Maker had a good afternoon.

title: Amid Ruins of Baath Party's Headquarters, a Town's Pervasive Sense of Fear Remains
description: The bombed-out headquarters of the ruling Baath Party here has collapsed like a house of cards, spilling the party's secret files into the courtyard.

title: Working With Brush Strokes of Light
description: WHEN Donald Holden jokes that his watercolors are in the best basements, he is being modest as well as practical. True, museums store more than they can show, and to be acquired is not necessarily to be known. Watercolors are considered light sensitive, so museums shelve them in dark areas like basements. That puts Mr. Holden in good company in places like the Metropolitan Museum of Art. ''I'm on the same shelf as Homer and Hopper,'' he likes to say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BETTINGER, ABE
description: BETTINGER-Abe. On April 4, 2003. Beloved husband of Carol. Loving father of Paul and Marc. Adoring grandfather (Pepa) of Joshua, Ethan, Tami, Jamie, Allie and Jeffrey. title: A Tough Chip Category
description: Even as cable modems remain American consumers' preferred medium for high-speed Internet access, the business of making chips for cable modems is ripe for a shakeout. That is the view of a recent report from the research firm In-Stat/MDR, which expects only a handful of chip makers, led by Broadcom and Texas Instruments, to be in the modem chip market within a few years. The eight chip makers currently in the market had global sales of only about $159 million last year, In-Stat says.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARGAMENT, HILDA (NEE SCHMELTZER)
description: PARGAMENT - Hilda (nee Schmeltzer). Died on April 5, 2003, after a long and courageous battle with emphysema. She was proceeded by her husband David and son Joseph. She is survived by her daughter Frances (Paul) daughter-in-law, grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. She was a woman of morals, a fighter for the underdog, a Yiddishist, possessed a wonderful sense of humor, was an extraordinarily wise woman and a remarkable mensch. She will be greatly missed by those who knew her.

Now, imagine that events veer toward something close to a worst case. What are the implications, and how could companies cope in such an environment?

Services ''Wien & Wien,'' Hackensack, NJ, Tuesday, 12:30 PM.

description: A Long Island high school teacher was arraigned Saturday on charges that he sexually abused two teenagers he had worked with in his previous job, as director of a church's youth ministry.

Ever since, the friendship has been nurtured on fairways and greens, and fired by competitive challenges.

By then, plants, soil and sacks of manure cover the sidewalks in front of hardware stores and bodegas all over town. Americans do not think of gardening when they think of vertical, asphalt New York. But even people who have never touched dirt in their lives get the urge to garden after moving to a city where leafy green things are notoriously rare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPANELLI, MICHAEL
description: CAMPANELLI-Michael. Our deepest sympathy to your friends and family. We will deeply miss your gentle soul, artistic talent and ability to bring calm to every situation. We ask why such good people are taken from the world so soon as we deeply mourn our loss. Brenda and Robert Grosbard

title: An Ominous Attack on Judges
description: House Republicans, aided by the Bush Justice Department, are trying to severely curtail federal judges' discretion in sentencing. Provisions buried in a popular bill to expand the Amber Alert system for notifying the public about abducted children would drastically narrow judges' flexibility to impose sentences below the range of federal guidelines to avoid an unjust result, not just in child kidnapping cases but across the board. The flexibility of judges to impose harsher sentences would be untouched.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Midtown Parking Fees Go Up
description: Parking rates for trucks and cars in Midtown have been raised today and, in some cases, doubled. The increases are part of a plan the city began in 2000 to discourage double- and triple-parking in congested areas, especially in the morning and afternoon, city transportation officials said. Under the plan, the city began charging trucks for parking when loading and unloading around Times Square. Today, parking fees for trucks are $2 for one hour, $5 for two hours and $9 for three hours of parking. The rates apply from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. on weekdays. The old rate was $1 for one hour, $3 for two hours and $6 for three hours. For cars parking after-hours, charges are lower. Parking now costs $2 an hour from 6 p.m. to midnight weekdays and from 8 a.m. to midnight on weekends. The old charge was $1 per hour. Randy Kennedy (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Ruling Favors Gun Collector
description: A gun collector whose legally registered firearms were seized by the police has been cleared of all charges. The State Court of Appeals has ruled that the September 1999 search warrant for the home of the collector, Thomas Walczyk, was invalid. The court ordered the state to refund the $200 in fines Mr. Walczyk paid for improper storage of firearms, many of them antiques. Mr. Walczyk, of Farmington, had a property dispute with a neighbor. He told police they weren't doing enough to ''avoid a bloodbath.'' The court, in a decision made public last week, ruled the ''bloodbath'' remark, among other things, was insufficient to justify the warrant. Other charges were dismissed earlier. Hope Reeves (NYT)

description: Extreme big-wave surfing, a fairly new twist on an ancient sport, is possible wherever monstrous storm swells and lunatic surfers converge. This generally happens in only two places on earth: Hawaii and California.

title: Webdenda
description: Bev Andal was named to the new post of chief operating officer at CMR , New York, part of Taylor Nelson Sofres. She continues as president and chief operating officer at Evaliant, New York, which was acquired by CMR last year. Sylvia Auton , managing director for the Country and Leisure Media group at IPC Media , London, was named chief executive, succeeding Sly Bailey, who left to become chief executive at Trinity Mirror, London. IPC is part of the Time Inc. unit of AOL Time Warner. Bob Costabile was named director at 30FPS , Glen Cove, N.Y., a production company. He had been an art director at Young & Rubicam Advertising, New York, part of the Young & Rubicam division of the WPP Group. Evins Communications , New York, and the It Management Global Corporation , New York, formed a strategic partnership to work together on accounts, though the agencies do not plan to merge. Terms were not disclosed. The Hartford Financial Services Group , Hartford, Conn., was named ``Company of the Year'' by the Financial Services Council of the Direct Marketing Association at an April 3 ceremony in Clearwater Beach, Fla. The Hispanic Public Relations Association , Los Angeles, elected Laura Hernandez as secretary, a vacant post. Ms. Hernandez is an assistant account executive at Rogers & Associates, Los Angeles. Integrated Entertainment Partners , Beverly Hills, Calif., is being opened by several longtime advertising, marketing and entertainment executives. Among them are Mitch Kanner , who had led his own company, Idea Bridge; Rich Frank, former chairman at Walt Disney Television, part of the Walt Disney Company; and entertainment lawyer Skip Brittenham . Stacey Lynn Koerner , senior vice president and director for broadcast research at Initiative Media North America , New York, was promoted to the new post of director for global research integration. Initiative Media North America is part of Initiative Media Worldwide, a unit of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. The Lead Dog Marketing Group , New York, an event management and sports marketing agency, acquired the event marketing division of the National Media Group , New York. Terms were not disclosed. Laura Molen was named to the new post of vice president and director for ad sales at TNN , New York, the cable network that is part of the MTV Networks division of Viacom. She had been senior vice president and general sales manager at Paramount Advertiser Services, New York, also part of Viacom. The New Jersey Advertising Club named four executives to its Hall of Fame at a ceremony in West Orange. They are: Deb Di Gregorio , president at Camares Communications, Cedar Knolls; Arden Davis Melick , a communications consultant; John P. Manos , president and chief executive at DKB & Partners, Morristown; and Philip H. Roberts , executive director at the New Jersey Broadcasters Association, Monroe Township. Mervyn's , Hayward, Calif., which operates more than 260 department stores in 14 states, named Castells & Asociados , Los Angeles, to handle a television campaign aimed at Hispanic consumers. Spending was not disclosed. Mervyn's, a division of the Target Corporation, assigns advertising on a project-by-project basis. The campaign is based on the theme ``La ropa lo hace todo,'' or ``The clothes say it all.'' Duncan Marshall and Howard Willmott were named to the new posts of executive creative directors at Publicis in the U.S., New York, part of the Publicis Worldwide division of the Publicis Groupe . They had been group heads and associate creative directors at a sibling agency, Saatchi & Saatchi, London, and will report to Peter Nicholson, chief creative officer. PSA-Dong Feng Motors , Beijing, a joint venture between PSA Peugeot Citroen and Dong Feng Motors, named Star East , Beijing, to handle advertising and communications in support of the introduction of the Peugeot brand in China. Billings were not disclosed. Star East is part of Havas. The Christopher Reeve Paralysis Foundation , Springfield, N.J., named the Crossbow Group, Westport , Conn., to handle direct-mail campaigns, which had been handled by Craver, Mathews, Smith & Co., Arlington, Va. Billings were not disclosed. Rubio's Fresh Mexican Grill , Carlsbad, Calif., a chain of 144 restaurants in six states, named two agencies to handle duties on its account. Siltanen/Keehn , El Segundo, Calif., will handle the creative duties for television and radio commercials, and Tesser , San Francisco, will handle brand, graphics and design assignments. The television duties had been handled by the Los Angeles office of Grey Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group; the other assignments are new or had been handled internally. Spending was estimated at $3 million. The Schadler Kramer Group , Las Vegas, hired three employees. Jessica Cipolla was named account executive; she had been account executive at Shonkwiler Marcoux Advertising, Las Vegas. Greg McFarlane was named copywriter; he had been copywriter at DRGM Advertising and Public Relations, Las Vegas. And David Sadowski was named graphic designer; he had been a freelance graphic designer. Scott D. Schulman was named senior vice president for sales and marketing at The Wall Street Journal , New York, part of Dow Jones & Company, succeeding Paul C. Atkinson, who left to pursue other interests, the company said. Mr. Schulman had been president at the Dow Jones Consumer Electronic Publishing division; succeeding him there is Todd Larsen, who had been vice president and general manager at the division. John Shea , senior vice president for strategic programming at MTV: Music Television , New York, part of the MTV Networks division of Viacom, was promoted to the new post of executive vice president for sponsorship development and integrated marketing for the MTV Networks Music Group. The group is composed of the CMT, MTV, MTV2 and VH1 cable channels. Tim Wallace was named managing director and senior entertainment and broadcasting analyst at UBS Warburg , New York, assuming duties that had been handled by Christopher Dixon and Lee Westerfield, analysts, who left, the company said. Mr. Wallace had been a managing director and senior research analyst at Banc of America Securities, New York, part of Bank of America. UBS is part of UBS A.G.
