title: White House Letter; Another President Bush Watches on the Sidelines
description: On the opening night of the Persian Gulf war, Jan. 16, 1991, President George Bush unloaded his anxieties into a tape-recorded diary. ''I have never felt a day like this in my life,'' he said. ''I am very tired. I didn't sleep well, and this troubles me because I must go to the nation at 9 o'clock. My lower gut hurts, nothing like when I had the bleeding ulcer. But I am aware of it, and I take a couple of Mylantas. . . . I think of what other presidents went through. The agony of war.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronxville: Hospital Strike Avoided
description: The union representing 300 nurses' aides, housekeepers and other nonprofessional workers at Lawrence Hospital reached a tentative five-year contract yesterday and called off a strike planned for today. Officials with the union, 1199/SEIU, said the deal, the first union contract reached at the hospital, would provide annual raises of 3 percent for the first four years and a wage reopener in the fifth year. Lawrence Hospital also agreed to join the union's benefits fund, meaning that many workers, whose pay averages $20,000 to $30,000 a year, would no longer have to contribute $1,200 to $1,900 a year toward their benefits. The hospital had resisted unionization for 37 years before 1199/SEIU unionized it last year. A ratification vote is set for this week. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

He had two senior starters on that team, as well as three future N.B.A. players in the freshman Derrick Coleman, the sophomore Sherman Douglas and the junior Rony Seikaly. But when Keith Smart hit a baseline jumper with four seconds left to give Indiana a 1-point victory, that experience and talent did not mean a thing.

And so, too often, is the film, filled with lines like: ''The cops used every trick in the book. It was a race against time to recover 'The Scream.' ''

title: Metro Briefing: New York

The police said the collapse, which occurred about 9 p.m., apparently was caused by the weight of soil and construction material on the roof, which was at ground level. The man was in stable condition at Elmhurst Hospital Center early today, the hospital said. Ilyse Fink, a spokeswoman for the Department of Buildings, said the garage is attached to a complex of co-op apartment houses, and has space for about 500 cars.  Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DULIS, EDWARD JOHN
description: DULIS-Edward John. 83, of Upper St. Clair, on April 4, 2003, at Allegheny General Hospital. A noted research metallurgical engineer, he held many patents and prestigious awards, including AMA's Albert Sauveur Achievement Award. Mr. Dulis had a 39-year career in research, from the Philadelphia Navy Yard, to U.S. Steel Corporation, and Crucible Steel Corporation, from which he retired in 1991 as President of the Research Division. He also served as a Vice President of Colt Industries. He was a fellow and trustee of the American Society of Metals, served on the National Materials Advisory Board, and was active in AIME, AISI, APMI and AMA. An avid golfer, tennis player, and sailor, he was also a Life Master bridge player, photographer, world traveler, gardener, and dancer, and a lover of opera, football, fine food and wine. In his sixties, he took up scuba diving, whitewater rafting, and backpacking. He is survived by his wife Dorothy; his children Barbara of Washington State; John of Washington, PA, and Beverly of Washington State; his grandchildren Bethany, Caleb, Noah, Ezra, Hannah, and Theodora; and his nephews and niece. Friends may call at Beinhauers, 2828 Washington Road, Peters Township, Saturday, April 12, 2003, from 9 AM, until the time of the funeral service at 2 PM. For further infomation call 724941-3211. The family is establishing an Edward J. Dulis Scholarship in the field of materials research. woodrufffamilyservices.com

This is especially true of the Masters tournament, which begins on Thursday and has always been the most prestigious and tasteful event of the PGA Tour. This year, the tournament will not have the same elegant feel for many spectators. An undercurrent of ill will has begun in this golfing village, distracting the focus from bogeys and birdies to the policies of the golf club where the Masters has been played for almost 70 years. The Augusta National Golf Club has no women members, and, by gum, William (Hootie) Johnson has stubbornly declared that he will not add women even ''at the point of a bayonet.''

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: QUEENS: WOMAN RAPED NEAR BUS STOP A 58-year-old Queens woman was attacked and raped as she waited for a bus at 5:30 a.m. yesterday in Hollis, the police said. The woman, whose name was not released, was treated at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center for injuries that investigators said were not life-threatening. She was waiting for a Q110 bus at the corner of 193rd Street and Jamaica Avenue when a man in his 20's approached her, displayed a gun, forced her into an alley and raped her, the investigators said. They said late yesterday that the gun was recovered at the scene but that no one had been arrested. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: COURT APPROVES TOY RETAILER'S REORGANIZATION PLAN
description: The toy retailer FAO said yesterday that a bankruptcy court judge had approved its reorganization plan and the company had received a commitment for up to $77 million in bank financing. FAO, parent of F. A. O. Schwarz, Zany Brainy and Right Start stores, said its bank financing included $67 million in revolving credit provided by a group of banks led by Fleet Retail Finance and a $10 million term loan from Back Bay Capital Funding. In addition, FAO reached agreement to sell $30 million in convertible preferred stock to a group of investors led by Kayne Anderson Capital Advisors. After FAO issues the preferred stock and securities to creditors under the bankruptcy plan, existing stockholders will own 11 percent of FAO's outstanding equity.

title: After the War

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: LAYOFFS AT ARMS MAKER Giat Industries, the state-owned French arms manufacturer, will close three factories and eliminate as many as 3,750 jobs, or 60 percent of its 6,250 employees, by the end of 2006 in a reorganization. Giat, or Groupement Industriel de l'Armement Terrestre, which builds the Leclerc battle tank as well as artillery pieces for the French military and for export, has not posted a profit in more than a decade. It reflects the downturn in European military spending and increased competition in international arms markets. In 2001, Giat's management was castigated in a government report and ordered to reorganize.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Computer Network Agrees To Buy Inrange
description: The Computer Network Technology Corporation, which provides software and hardware for computer storage networks, agreed yesterday to buy the Inrange Technologies Corporation for about $190 million in cash, to add networking services. Computer Network will pay $2.31 a share for Inrange, a unit of the SPX Corporation, and expects the purchase to increase earnings this year by at least 10 percent, the company said. The price is 4.1 percent above Inrange's closing price Friday of $2.22. The purchase will allow Computer Network to provide more products that help speed connections between computer and telecommunications networks, the company said. As a result of the acquisition, Computer Network will raise its 2003 profit forecast from the 17-cent average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial, the chairman and chief executive officer, Thomas G. Hudson, said. Shares of Computer Network fell $1.95, or more than 27 percent, to $5.10. Inrange shares rose 6 cents, to $2.28. Computer Network plans to cut an undisclosed number of sales, information technology and administrative jobs as part of the purchase, Mr. Hudson said, without being more specific.

title: A Cellist Tethered Lightly To Bach and Britten Solos

description: Never mind the records or the averages. What matters isn't what happened years ago or what usually happens -- just what happened yesterday. A mass of warm air sliding up from the south collided with a dome of unseasonably cold air, and snow fell in New York City and across the mid-Atlantic states. It came down in demoralizing fistfuls, like scraps of winter's calendar flung into spring. Everything was put on hold: the rose leaves in Bryant Park, the first blush on the buds in the botanical gardens, even the Yankees' home opener. Winter has never seemed quite so reluctant to retreat for good.

She also admitted that she watched the child slowly die over the next 24 hours, then let the boyfriend, Kevin Abrahams, 25, burn the body in a fireplace. Ms. Morgan's mother became suspicious in June when the couple visited her without the baby. She alerted the police, who found the baby's remains, prosecutors said. The couple, who had fled to Florida, were arrested in July. Ms. Morgan will testify against Mr. Abrahams, who faces 30 years to life in prison if convicted of murder. title: OPPOSING AN AUCTION
description: More than a half-century after Surrealism's quiet demise, the movement was again stirring passion in Paris yesterday. For 30 years Andr Breton's widow and daughter found little support for their efforts to find a permanent home for the Surrealist leader's art, manuscript and book collection. As the vast collection went on sale, however, artists and intellectuals were ready to protest the dispersal of the principal record of the interwar Surrealist movement. Gathered outside the Htel Drouot, the main Paris auction house, they distributed pamphlets, chanted slogans and blocked bidders trying to enter the building. Finally, calm was restored as the first of 22 auction sessions through April 18 went ahead with the sale of books from Breton's collection, many of them dedicated to him. Among the 4,100 lots in the auction are 3,500 books, 800 manuscripts, 500 photographs, 400 paintings and drawings and 150 American Indian and Oceanic art objects. The estimated value of the sale is $30 million to $40 million. In France the preferred scapegoat is always the government. Successive governments showed no interest in creating a foundation or museum for the works preserved in Breton's tiny apartment at 42, rue Fontaine in the Pigalle district. In reality, the best of the collection may still stay in France. Over the last three decades, the Breton estate sold a number of paintings to government-owned museums. After the death of Breton's widow, Elisa, ''Breton's Wall'' -- the 250 works of art on the wall behind his desk -- was given to the Georges Pompidou Center in lieu of estate taxes. During the current auction, the government is also expected to exercise its right to buy prized objects at the price they have been sold to a bidder. ALAN RIDING

title: They Can Run but They Can't Fly
description: The question of whether elephants run has been a biomechanical puzzle. To see how the great creatures move, Dr. John R. Hutchinson of Stanford and his colleagues videotaped Asian elephants as they chugged along at speeds up to 13 miles an hour. They found that elephants don't change the pattern of footfall as they run, as horses and other animals do when they go faster. But the researchers noted, in a paper in the current issue of Nature, there are different definitions of running. If you are standing in front of a charging elephant, it is running, whatever its gait, although the scientists did not mention this fact. But they did report that elephants' feet touch the ground only briefly and that their hind legs display a motion characteristic of running, although the front legs move more as if they were walking. This is unusual. In most animals if the back runs the front does too. So more research is needed. One thing seems clear, however, and can be seen in the picture sequence above. Unlike Dumbo, real elephants don't leave the ground. Although the elephant in the second photo of the sequence has only one leg touching the ground, briefly, that's as close to airborne as they get. More data is needed, the researchers say, ''to understand why elephants avoid using an aerial phase.''

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Broadcom Will Have 2nd-Quarter  Expense
description: The Broadcom Corporation, the maker of cable modem chips, will have a second-quarter expense of as much as $238 million for letting employees exchange stock options that are currently worthless. The amount of the noncash expense depends on the number of options exchanged, Broadcom said yesterday. Workers holding options with exercise prices of at least $23.58 can swap them for a fewer number of Class A shares or options with lower strike prices, the company said. The shares trade at less than $14. The swap is aimed at retaining key employees, said Broadcom, which traditionally caps salaries at $110,000. The company has posted 10 straight quarterly net losses and its shares have fallen 58 percent in the last year. The former chief executive, Henry T. Nicholas III, quit in January citing family reasons, and the head of the company's server-chip business, Raju Vegesna, was replaced last month. Less than 10 percent of the 57 million options eligible for exchange belong to top-level executives, said Bill Blanning, a company spokesman. Broadcom shares rose 36 cents, or 2.7 percent, to $13.49. They traded as high as $274.75 in August 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWAN, GARTH
description: COWAN-Garth. On April 4th, 2003. Beloved longtime companion of 36 years of Joseph Maio. Mourned by his many nieces, nephews and friends who will always miss his many kindnesses and humor. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Troops Bring Home an Iraqi Who Fled in '91
description: Unsure how the local residents would react to their presence, commanders of the 24th Marine Expeditionary Unit planned only to tear down likenesses of Saddam Hussein and rummage through a secret police headquarters this morning when they entered this town of 45,000, about 150 miles southeast of Baghdad.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; As Prices Fall For Crude Oil, OPEC Leader Calls for Talks
description: OPEC's president called yesterday for a special meeting later this month to discuss the recent slide in oil prices, which have fallen almost 20 percent since just before the war with Iraq began.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the influence of Rupert Murdoch on the News Corporation's properties misidentified the Fox News Channel commentator who accused competitors of dwelling on casualties in Iraq and misstated the term he used for them. He was Fred Barnes, not Bill O'Reilly; he called the competitors ''weenies,'' not ''liberal weenies.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUVER, RICHARD M.
description: BLUVER-Richard M. Of Delray, Florida, formerly of Brooklyn, NY and Long Island; beloved husband of Ruth; loving father of Mark and Laurie and Harriette and Don; caring brother of Irene Tullman & Mel Bluver; proud & adoring grandfather of Adam, Louis, Cait & Alanna.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a chart yesterday about budget problems at Mount Sinai Hospital omitted a line showing a decline in hospital occupancy. A corrected version appears today, on Page D5.

title: Ccile de Brunhoff, 99, Creator of Babar
description: Ccile de Brunhoff, whose husband turned a bedtime tale she told their children into the world-famous stories about Babar the Elephant, died yesterday in Paris. She was 99.

title: Iraqis, Hoping Against Hope, Swarm Prison
description: Hundreds of people came to the gates of a special prison here today, armed with hopes that taunt the bereaved: somewhere beneath the floors of the compound, they believed, a secret network of tunnels existed. There they would find the brother, the father, the son, unseen for years after being seized by government agents but surely alive.

title: At McDonald's, an Effort to Restore Lost Luster
description: In his 97th day as chief executive of McDonald's, James R. Cantalupo told investors yesterday that he would bring the company back to its glory days by focusing on the basics: customer service, clean restaurants and reliable, appealing food.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Black Lawmakers Oppose Flag Plan
description: The Legislature's black caucus announced its opposition to plans for a new state flag that is based on the Confederacy's Stars and Bars. State Senator Ed Harbison, chairman of the 48-member caucus, said his group's biggest worry was a provision that if the Stars and Bars version were defeated in a referendum next March, the Confederate battle flag, a different design that has been associated with the Ku Klux Klan, could be considered in a July referendum. Two years ago, the state shrank the battle emblem on its flag. The House of Representatives was expected to vote on the issue today.

title: NAUTILUS SAYS PROFIT TO MISS TARGET IN QUARTER AND 2003
description: The Nautilus Group, the maker of exercise machines like the StairMaster, reduced its forecast yesterday for 2003 profit because of lower sales. Full-year earnings will be $1.60 to $1.70 a share on revenue of $525 million to $545 million, the company said. It previously forecast earnings of $2.50 to $2.60 a share on sales of $580 million to $600 million. Nautilus said it had first-quarter earnings of 39 cents to 42 cents a share on revenue of $124 million to $129 million, based on a preliminary review. The company was expected to earn 65 cents on revenue of $146.2 million, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial.

title: A Decision on Cross Burning
description: The Supreme Court upheld a Virginia statute yesterday that makes it illegal for Ku Klux Klansmen and others to burn crosses. The case was a difficult one, forcing the court to weigh the free-expression rights of those who burn crosses against the right of their victims not to be physically intimidated and threatened with harm. The court got the balance right in a decision that upholds the ban on cross burning but warns the states against trampling on political speech.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASSER, EZRA
description: NASSER - Ezra. Profound sympathies to the extended Nasser family. Ezra was a respected friend, mentor and beautiful human being. His warmth, humor and unique joie de vivre were a joy to all. J. Howard Johnson and Family

title: Managed Care Companies Win Ruling
description: The UnitedHealth Group and PacifiCare Health Systems, the managed care companies, have won a Supreme Court decision allowing them to send a dispute with doctors to arbitration, at least initially.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose as United States troops seized control of government buildings in Baghdad, bolstering optimism for a quick end to the war. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0659, down from $1.0734 on Friday.

title: The Ring Of Truth?
description: The front line in the war for hearts and minds in the Arab world and beyond is here, at the U.S. Central Command headquarters and media center, and it's prettier than most battlefields. The stage that the generals speak from each day was built for the government by a showbiz professional at a cost of $250,000, and it's as high-tech as an Abrams tank.

title: New Look for MetroStars
description: MIKE MAGEE has the shaggy hair and youthful good looks of a BMX racer or a snowboarder. RICARDO CLARK is gifted, crafty and creative. What the two rookies have in common, besides being accidental roommates, are starting spots in the MetroStars' lineup for Saturday's season opener against Columbus.

title: Mets and Reynolds Not Connecting
description: Shane Reynolds was negotiating exclusively with the Mets last weekend before the team refused to increase the term of its offer to the pitcher. Reynolds is now likely to sign elsewhere.

title: When a Patient Is Lost in the Translation
description: One afternoon, I was paged to see a man who had passed out while waiting for an appointment. When I arrived, he was lying on his back, awake and looking at the nurses and medical staff bustling around him.

title: BAR CODE COMPANY CUTS JOBS AND WARNS ON EARNINGS
description: The Paxar Corporation, which makes bar code printers and labels, said yesterday that it was cutting 120 jobs, or 4 percent of its work force in the United States, and that first-quarter profit would be lower than it had forecast. Net income will fall to $400,000 to $1.2 million, or 1 cent to 3 cents a share, the company said. Sales will be $162 million to $163 million. Paxar's previous forecast was for a profit of 15 cents to 18 cents a share on sales of $160 million to $165 million. The company, based in White Plains, earned $7.5 million, or 19 cents a share, on sales of $152.7 million in the year-ago period. The company will have $2.6 million in costs in the first quarter related to the job cuts.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSEN, SHELLY
description: ROSEN-Shelly. April 8th, 1951-May 27th, 2000. When you died, family and friends lost the soft-spoken gentle man who listened without judgment and shared his boundless love. You overcame the hate and loss of love from your family to create a loving family with me. We had a love and commitment to each other that grew deeper and deeper. Together we shared art, music, literature and a commitment to social justice issues. You loved to read, watch old movies and debate about politics, religion, society, music and art. You had a kind and gentle wit. You were generous to a fault. I miss hearing your bass. I sorely miss you. I love you. Hop

title: Holocaust Survivors' Insurance Ordeal
description: When Jack Weiss got out of the concentration camp at Muldorf at the end of World War II, he returned to Vrable, Czechoslovakia, to find his family home in ruins. Exhausted and weak, he moved into an abandoned house with other refugees.

title: Two Iraqi Ministries Are Afire After U.S. Warplanes Strike
description: BAGHDAD, April 8  United States forces launched an air and artillery assault on central Baghdad this morning, targeting government buildings in the heart of the city. The Planning Ministry and the Information Ministry were on fire after low flying American planes attacked the center, and bursts of Howitzer fire sounded across the city.

title: A Generation Gap Over the War?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE BRUNHOFF, CECILE
description: de BRUNHOFF-Cecile. The Staff of Harry N. Abrams, Publishers sends its love and sympathy to Laurent de Brunhoff and his family at the passing of his mother, Cecile de Brunhoff, wife of Jean de Brunhoff. In 1930, Cecile de Brunhoff first told the story of an elephant that inspired the Babar books and was an inspiration to her family. Steve Parr, President & CEO Abrams Howard Reeves, VP and Director Abrams Books for Young Readers

title: Promising Results Are Seen In Small Parkinson's Trial
description: A new approach to Parkinson's disease has shown promising results with a small group of patients in a preliminary trial. Though not yet confirmed, the development could relieve the gloom that recently settled on the field when the technique of implanting fetal brain cells in patients proved to do some harm and not much good.

title: BUSH MEETS BLAIR
description: President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair turned their attention today to planning for a postwar Iraq, seeking to bridge their differences over how much of a role to give the United Nations in rebuilding the country and putting together a new government.

title: Disease's Pioneer Is Mourned as a Victim
description: When the microbe that causes severe acute respiratory syndrome is finally isolated, some people will know what to call it. They want a Latin variation on Carlo Urbani's name.

title: Textured Insoles Win High Scores
description: A rough surface inside the shoes of athletes can help protect their feet, knees and ankles, according to a new study that involved 17 members of the Australian women's soccer team.

title: Sharing Advice, and Pills, for Woes of Jet Lag
description: For advice on the best remedy for minor ailments, people often turn to experts outside the medical establishment -- to a bartender, say, for a hangover cure, or to a hypochondriac for the pros and cons of various cold or flu medications.

title: With Opportunity in Hand, Snow Is Taking Charge
description: Besides opponents who trespass in his goal crease and coaches who claim his pads are too big, not much bothers Islanders goaltender Garth Snow. His teammates like him because he has not been a troublemaker -- for them, anyway.

title: With Money and Blondes on His Mind
description: Nothing fazes John Corbett's characters. There was Chris, the New Age disc jockey in ''Northern Exposure,'' who just shrugged and smiled beatifically when people referred to his prison record. There was Aidan, Carrie Bradshaw's fianc, on and off, in ''Sex and the City,'' who stood by calmly as Carrie went through her emotional frenzies. Aidan even broke up peacefully. And there was Ian, the white Anglo-Saxon Protestant hero of ''My Big Fat Greek Wedding.'' Whatever it took to marry the heroine -- even being baptized, as a grown man, into the Greek Orthodox Church -- Ian would happily do. No big deal. Hakuna matata.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Peugeot Investigation
description: The European Commission said it had conducted follow-up raids on offices belonging to the French carmaker Peugeot, as part of its antitrust investigation into claims that the company is preventing car buyers from purchasing their vehicles outside of the country in which they live. The latest raids, which took place last week, extend the Peugeot investigation to Denmark, which is one of the cheapest countries in the European Union to buy a car. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: South Korea Seeks Reversal Of Chip Tariff
description: The South Korean government proposed yesterday that the United States Commerce Department rescind its preliminary decision to impose a 57 percent tariff on chips shipped by Hynix Semiconductor in return for an agreement to reduce the amount of exports from Hynix. The Korean commerce ministry qualified the proposal, however, by saying that it would not apply to future investigations and that it would not imply any guilt. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Augusta National May Not Be Up to Speed for Masters
description: Early this afternoon, a small stream was flowing through the first fairway at Augusta National Golf Club, a remnant of heavy rain that washed out the first official day of Masters practice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNCAN, BARBARA DOYLE
description: DUNCAN - Barbara Doyle. The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art expresses great sadness upon learning of the passing of Barbara Duncan. A member of the Council since 1964, Barbara was a passionate advocate of the art of Latin America. She was a key part of our Program Committee and Latin American subcommittee for many years. An avid traveler and devoted friend, Barbara will be deeply missed. Our most sincere sympathies are extended to her husband John and children Gale, Craig and Lynn. Sir Brian Urquhart, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, MICHAEL
description: KELLY-Michael. Of Swampscott, MA, in Iraq, age 46. Beloved husband of Madelyn (Greenberg) Kelly. Devoted father of Tom and Jack. Loving son of Thomas and Marguerite (Lelong) Kelly. Relatives and friends are invited to attend a wake liturgy and tribute Wednesday, 10 A.M. in St. John's the Evangelist Church, 174 Humphrey St., Swampscott which will be followed by Funeral Mass at 11 A.M. in the Church. Interment will be in Mt. Auburn Cemetery, Cambrige, MA. In lieu of flowers or gifts, memorial donations may be made in Mike's memory to the Tom and Jack Education Fund, c/o Donna Papadopoulos, Sovereign Bank, 495 Paradise Rd., Swampscott, MA, 01907. A memorial Mass will be celebrated Friday at a time to be announced in St. Joseph's Church, Capitol Hill, 2nd and C St., NE, Washington, D.C. For more information, contact the Murphy Funeral Home, 85 Federal Street, Salem, 978744-0497 or www.MurphyFuneralHome.com

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTONE, LEONARD
description: GREENSTONE-Leonard. On April 7, 2003, of Huntington Station, LI. Beloved husband of Beth. Devoted father of Dr. Judith Yantis and Dr. E. Mitchell Greenstone. Loving father-in-law of Alice. Dear brother of Lillian Fischer and Eleanor Campion. Services Wednesday, at 11 AM, at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: A Generation Gap Over the War?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mothers' Minds and Babies' Bellies
description: Mothers who are depressed or anxious are more likely to take their children to doctors for stomachaches and abdominal pains, a new study has concluded.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat Sells Unit
description: Fiat, raising cash to rescue its troubled auto division, agreed to enter exclusive talks to sell its profitable aerospace unit, FiatAvio, for 1.6 billion euros ($1.7 billion) to a combination of the Carlyle Group of Washington and the Italian state-owned conglomerate Finmeccanica, the country's biggest military contractor. Last month, Fiat sold its Toro insurance business for 2.4 billion euros as part of a drive to raise 5 billion euros for the unprofitable Fiat Auto. FiatAvio, which posted operating income last year of 210 million euros on revenue of 1.5 billion euros, makes components for military and civilian aircraft and for the European Ariane space rocket. The French state-owned maker of engines for aircraft and rockets, Snecma, was also interested in FiatAvio. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday and in some late editions on Saturday about M. Anthony Fisher, a senior partner at the Fisher Brothers real estate firm in New York City, omitted two survivors. They are his brother Lester Fisher of Purchase, N.Y., and his sister Irma Fisher Mann of Boston.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Woman Raped Near Bus Stop
description: A 58-year-old Queens woman was attacked and raped as she waited for a bus at 5:30 a.m. yesterday in Hollis, the police said. The woman, whose name was not released, was treated at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center for injuries that investigators said were not life-threatening. She was waiting for a Q110 bus at the corner of 193rd Street and Jamaica Avenue when a man in his 20's approached her, displayed a gun, forced her into an alley and raped her, the investigators said. They said late yesterday that the gun was recovered at the scene but that no one had been arrested. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: J. P. MORGAN CHASE & CO., New York, said it had bought Citizens Financial Group, Providence, R.I., a corporate and municipal bond trust business, from Royal Bank of Scotland Group, Edinburgh.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: CAPITAL HAS LOOK OF A BATTLEFIELD
description: Gunfire erupted on the grounds of the Republican Palace early this morning, almost 24 hours after an American tank column entered the compound, which has been repeatedly bombed by allied planes since the war began. The explosions shook awake residents of a city that has now come to resemble a battlefield, with Iraqi special forces and militiamen taking up position on crucial streets and bridges.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: D.J. Pleads Guilty In Scuffle With Rival
description: A popular hip-hop disc jockey known as Funkmaster Flex pleaded guilty yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court to harassing a rival disc jockey, and was ordered to serve 35 hours of community service. Prosecutors said Funkmaster Flex, who works for radio station WQHT-FM (97.1) and whose real name is Aston Taylor Jr., was also placed under an order of protection to stay away from Stephanie Saunders, the rival from radio station WWPR-FM (105.1). Ms. Saunders is known as Big Steph Lova. Ms. Saunders, 29, accused Mr. Taylor, 35, of choking her and punching her face. Mr. Taylor was arrested in September and charged with assault. He could have faced up to a year in prison. In a ratings war for months before the arrest, Ms. Saunders and Mr. Taylor traded insults during their broadcasts. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Institute Names President
description: Dr. Robert A. Eisenstein, a physicist and former administrator at the National Science Foundation, has been named president of the Santa Fe Institute, a New Mexico research organization that studies complexity in nature and in social systems. Dr. Eisenstein will take office in June. He succeeds Dr. Ellen Goldberg, who has been president for seven years. Dr. Goldberg will continue as an institute research professor and co-director of a consortium of scientists studying infant and child development. Sandra Blakeslee (NYT)

title: People
description: Barbara J. Thompson was named to the new posts of senior vice president, media director and head of West Coast planning at the Los Angeles office of Horizon Media. She had been senior vice president and media director at the Irvine, Calif., office of Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the FCB Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Is Fear Spreading Faster Than SARS?
description: First there was denial, then a sluggish response and now irrational fear out of proportion to the danger.

title: Mayor Says the City Will Lay Off 3,400 To Reduce Deficits
description: The Bloomberg administration took its strongest steps yet to close an ever-worsening budget gap yesterday, informing the city's unions that it intends to lay off 3,400 employees and announcing it will close eight firehouses over the objections of many residents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, JERE
description: JONES-Jere. We celebrate the life of Jere Jones-an adoring husband, father, grandpa, friend, mentor, and passionate professor - a maverick and an original. Jere loved to dream, lived to think, and changed the world around him. A memorial service will be announced. The Family

title: Still Intrigued by History's Shadows; Gnter Grass Worries About the Effects of War, Then and Now
description: For Gnter Grass, as a German and a writer, there is no escaping history. His first and best-known novel, ''The Tin Drum,'' published in 1956, was set around World War II, as was ''Dog Years,'' another of his best. His latest, ''Crabwalk'' (Harcourt), now published in English, recalls a maritime tragedy early in 1945.

description: ''DO you understand that?''

description: Club Sandwich, and Pile It On High

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLIFKA, SYLVIA
description: SLIFKA-Sylvia. Passed away Sunday, April 6th, 2003 after a long and lovely life. Adored wife of the late Joseph Slifka. Loving mother of Alan and Barbara Slifka. Grandmother of Michael, Randolph and David, and great grandmother of Grace and Joshua. Services private. Family receiving Tuesday and Wednesday evenings, 5-8PM at Mrs. Slifka's residence. Contributions in her name may be made to Temple Emanu - El, 5th Avenue at 65th Street, NY, NY 10021, or The Abraham Joshua Heschel School.

title: Better Schools Through Better Teaching? How Novel
description: CLASS has been dismissed, but the principal is finding it hard to tear herself away from the classrooms. So here we are at City Hall Academy, the much-critiqued multimillion-dollar educational innovation on the ground floor of Tweed Courthouse, a landmark lately reincarnated as a sumptuous homeroom for New York City's Department of Education, courtesy of a mayoral brainstorm.

title: Nattily Attired for a Striptease
description: NEWARK - Hubbard Street Dance Chicago is a pleasure to watch. Founded by Lou Conte in 1977 and now directed by Jim Vincent, it is a technically eclectic group of high-energy dancers. Gusto dominated the program of passionate works they offered recently at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here.

description: BASEBALL

title: Bush Meets With Blair to Discuss Postwar Iraq
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 7  President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair turned their attention today to planning for a postwar Iraq, seeking to bridge their differences over how much of a role to give the United Nations in rebuilding the country and putting together a new government.

title: Iraqi Leaders Said to Use Civilian Areas In Baghdad
description: Iraq's senior political leaders have made no effort to flee Baghdad, but some appear to be frantically shifting operations to civilian buildings in residential neighborhoods to avoid American ground and air assaults, intelligence officials said today.

title: Appointment at Gap
description: Gap Inc., the clothing store chain, named Patricia Johnson today as the chief financial officer of its Old Navy division. Ms. Johnson, 45, succeeds Lee Bird, who was named chief operating officer of Gap, a spokeswoman, Stacy MacLean, said. Ms. Johnson resigned as chief financial officer of Kohl's, a department-store chain, to join Gap.

title: Savidge: Marines Destroy Equipment and Inspect Factories
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq (CNN) -- As U.S. Marines moved into the Iraqi capital for the first time, CNN correspondent Martin Savidge, traveling with the 1st Battalion, 7th Marines, spoke to CNN anchor Michael Holmes via videophone about the latest war developments Tuesday.

title: Iraqi Missile Strike Kills Four At Tactical Operations Center
description: An Iraqi rocket exploded in a headquarters of the Army's Third Infantry Division south of Baghdad today, killing at least two soldiers and two journalists and wounding 15 others, one of them gravely, officers here said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, SANDRA
description: GREENE-Sandra. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Sandra Greene, associated with The Times from April 24, 1956 until retiring in January 1, 1987

title: The Cosmos Gets Another Set of Eyes
description: NASA is preparing to launch the last of its ''Great Observatories,'' space telescopes that astronomers hope will explore the faint warm glow of the early days of the universe and see through the billowing clouds of interstellar dust that obscure the birthplaces of stars and, possibly, far-off planets.

title: Bush's Next Role: Mediator in Disputes Over Running Postwar Iraq
description: With an end in sight to the battle for Baghdad, President Bush is now moving to end two arguments that were never resolved before the shooting started: One between the United States and Europe over who will run Iraq, and a second between his own State and Defense Departments over how to run it.

title: U.S. Military Says It Hears Hussein Son Calling Shots
description: American military officials said today that they believed that Saddam Hussein's younger son, Qusay, was still alive and leading Iraq's security forces.

title: U.S. Officers to Search For Pilot From 1991 War
description: American intelligence officers are preparing to move into Iraq to search for a Navy pilot who may have survived the downing of his fighter jet during the Persian Gulf war 12 years ago, but has never been accounted for, United States officials said today.

title: American Force Moves to Demolish State's Organs of Control
description: DOHA, Qatar, April 8  American forces waged an aggressive assault on the symbols of Saddam Hussein's rule in Baghdad today, expanding their grip inside the city and pressing inward from the periphery with Army and Marine units.

title: General Franks Makes His First Visit to Troops in the Battle Zone
description: Near the end of his first flight into Iraq this war, Gen. Tommy R. Franks, overall commander of the invading allied troops, pulled two folded aerial photographs of Baghdad from his back pocket.

title: Charges Against Unions
description: To the Editor:

title: Jardn Journal; A Bird-Watcher's Heaven (if War Wasn't Hell)
description: Slogging through heavy mud on a mountain trail, Paul Salaman, a British bird scientist, turned suddenly to recount the colleagues who had been kidnapped in Colombia.

title: Official Says NASA Erred on Tank Problem
description: The astronaut who will be in charge of planning the resumption of shuttle flights said today that NASA had failed to see a trend in the shedding of foam from the external tank, despite a similar incident a few months before the Columbia accident, because the agency thought that it had solved the problem years earlier.

title: Frontier of Military Technology Is the Size of a Molecule
description: Nanoscale materials and components, including some of the tiniest products ever manufactured, have already found their way into communications systems and weapons being used in the war in Iraq. But the role of nanotechnology is still so limited that the Iraq war will more likely be remembered as the last to be fought without its benefits than the first that fully deployed it.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: MICROCHIP TECHNOLOGY TO CUT 140 JOBS Microchip Technology Inc., a maker of semiconductors, said yesterday that it planned to spend as much as $33 million to cut 140 jobs and close a factory, as concerns about the war in Iraq and the spread of a respiratory illness reduced demand. Fourth-quarter net income was 16 cents a share on revenue of $159 million to $160 million, the company said in a statement of its preliminary results. That fell short of a forecast the company gave on March 18 for earnings of 17 cents on sales of $164 million to $166 million. The company plans to close its Chandler, Ariz., factory and move some operations and employees to a plant in Tempe, Ariz. It expects restructuring costs of $27 million to $33 million in its first fiscal quarter, which ends June 30. Shares of Microchip Technology lost as much as $2.10, or 10 percent, falling to $18.43 in after-hours trading after the announcement. They fell 23 cents, to $20.53, in regular trading.   (Bloomberg News)

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: RAIL WORK SET Metronet Rail, a group of five British and Canadian companies, announced plans for a 30-year program to refurbish a large section of the London subway system, including a 3.4 billion contract ($5.3 billion) to Bombardier for trains, equipment and maintenance services. Bombardier, based in Montreal, is a member of the Metronet consortium, which has responsibility for about two-thirds of the modernization program. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: From Amusement Park to Power Plant
description: Consolidated Edison built the first privately financed, commercial nuclear power plant in the United States in Buchanan, N.Y. That plant and the two others eventually built on the site have had troubled histories.

title: Premature Births Rise Sharply, Confounding Obstetricians
description: The 19 babies in the neonatal intensive care unit at New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn were typical of the infants in similar hospitals elsewhere.

title: Five Ways to Take a City
description: FIRST BRITISH ARMORED DIVISION HEADQUARTERS, Southern Iraq, April 6  The attack began with raids, as armor and infantry darted in and out of the city. The next step was to grab a piece of the urban terrain and stay. Finally, after a bombing raid that appeared to kill the Iraqi strongman who ruled the city, the allies mounted a major offensive, pushing deep into the city to seize control.

description: Microchip Technology Inc., a maker of semiconductors, said yesterday that it planned to spend as much as $33 million to cut 140 jobs and close a factory, as concerns about the war in Iraq and the spread of a respiratory illness reduced demand. Fourth-quarter net income was 16 cents a share on revenue of $159 million to $160 million, the company said in a statement of its preliminary results. That fell short of a forecast the company gave on March 18 for earnings of 17 cents on sales of $164 million to $166 million. The company plans to close its Chandler, Ariz., factory and move some operations and employees to a plant in Tempe, Ariz.
