title: Excerpts From a Briefing by Rumsfeld and Myers: 'The Circle Is Closing'
description: At a news conference yesterday at the Pentagon, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld and Gen. Richard B. Myers, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, discussed reports of chemical weapons caches in Iraq, the role of Iraqi exiles and other subjects. Following are excerpts from the session as recorded by Federal Document Clearing House Inc. A complete transcript is online at nytimes.com/iraq.

title: Early Surge Falters, Leaving Modest Gains at End of Day
description: After surging as much as 3 percent earlier in the day, the three main stock gauges rose only modestly yesterday, despite news that United States-led forces had taken control of Baghdad's airport and made forays into downtown Baghdad.

title: Player in Cellular Phone Market In Europe Predicts Consolidation
description: In his four years as head of Italy's largest mobile telephone company, Telecom Italia Mobile, Marco De Benedetti has had to keep a close eye on Europe's cellphone market -- so close that 14-hour workdays are the norm.

title: Bombs Attack on Hussein, a Bush-Blair Meeting, and Protests at Home
description: As President Saddam Hussein's control over Iraq appeared to crumble further, American forces made an attempt to kill him with a precision bombing strike. Meanwhile, American troops seized two of Mr. Hussein's palaces in the capital and British troops consolidated their control of Iraq's second-largest city, Basra. Rapid military advances added urgency to a meeting between President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair over rebuilding Iraq.

title: An Old-Fashioned Salon Concert With Young Singers
description: The popular chamber music series that James Levine and musicians from the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra play at Weill Recital Hall took the form of an old-fashioned salon concert on the afternoon of March 30. The principal offerings, performed after the intermission, were Brahms's two books of ``Liebeslieder'' (Op. 52 and Op. 65), sets of ensemble songs cast as waltzes, with piano four-hands accompaniment. In the first half of the program, the four young singers took solo turns in sets of French songs.

title: Viacom to Cut Board Size While Increasing Outside Directors
description: Viacom said yesterday that it was reorganizing its board to reduce its size and increase the number of outside directors.

title: Freshmen Give Boeheim a Finish to Savor
description: Sixteen years ago here in the Superdome with the national title on the line, Jim Boeheim watched his Syracuse Orangemen play 39 minutes and 56 seconds of gorgeous basketball against the Indiana Hoosiers. He had two senior starters on that team, as well as three future N.B.A. players in the freshman Derrick Coleman, the sophomore Sherman Douglas and the junior Rony Seikaly. But when Keith Smart hit a baseline jumper with four seconds left to give Indiana a 1-point victory, that experience and talent did not mean a thing.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page map caption on Sunday referred incorrectly in some copies to the route taken by an American armored force through Baghdad on Saturday. The force rolled into the center of the city from the south, then went west to the airport and returned to its starting point in the south. It did not start at the airport and return there.

title: Still Descends on Baghdad After Raging Street Battles
description: BAGHDAD, Tuesday, April 8 - A still descended on the city after raging battles that lasted all morning and left the Americans in firm control of an area encompassing the principal seats of governmental power.

title: Saddam Hussein as Surrogate Dictator
description: Tolstoy would have said that every democracy is different, but all totalitarian countries look the same,'' my cousin said as images of Baghdad rolled by on television. They reminded him of his visit to Pyongyang, but I could have easily added Stalin's Moscow or Mao's Beijing. He added, ''The leader puts his statues everywhere and gets 100 percent of the vote -- and you know life must be living hell in that country.''

title: Emanuel Tobier, Economist and Urban Planner, Dies at 73
description: Emanuel Tobier, a New York economist and urban planner who was an outspoken authority on the metropolitan area's vital signs, died on Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 73 and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Consultant Gets First European President
description: Partners at the Boston Consulting Group announced yesterday that they had elected Hans-Paul Brkner as president, making him the first European to lead the firm.

title: Bush to Help Ulster Take 'Final Steps' to Peace
description: HILLSBOROUGH, Northern Ireland, April 8  President Bush today gave the Northern Ireland peace process a boost at a timely moment in the province's struggle to achieve longterm stability, pledging to help local leaders take "the final steps towards a lasting peace."

title: Text: Briefing at the Pentagon
description: At a news conference yesterday at the Pentagon, Victoria Clarke, the Pentagon spokeswoman, and Maj. Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, vice director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, discussed the bombing of a Baghdad neighborhood on Monday, the destruction of the Iraqi command and control structure, and other subjects. Following is the transcript from the session as recorded by Federal Document Clearing House Inc.

title: Shiites, Resenting Both Sides, Are Swing Group
description: Pictures of President Saddam Hussein kneeling in prayer no longer dominate the exterior of the gilded tomb of the Imam Ali in the southern Iraqi city Najaf. The ostensible family tree of the prophet Muhammad -- with only Mr. Hussein's face peeping out from among the myriad branches -- was removed as well. But his spirit still haunts the place.

title: There's Work to Be Done Before Declaring Victory, Rumsfeld Cautions
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that declaring victory in Iraq would come ''later rather than sooner,'' warning that American-led forces must still quell stiff resistance across Iraq before aid could flow freely and displaced Iraqis could return home safely.

title: American Air Discloses Cuts In May Flights
description: American Airlines said yesterday that it would curtail its May flight schedule by cutting its international service by 13 percent and domestic service by 2 percent from planned levels because of the travel slump caused by the war in Iraq and a slow economy.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: ALGERIA: HUNT FOR MISSING EUROPEANS German and Austrian police have joined the search in the vast southern Sahara for 29 European tourists missing without a trace since February. Among the missing are 15 Germans and 8 Austrians. The reinforcements came as the Algerian police drew a blank about the fate of the tourists, traveling in at least five separate groups and in four-wheel drive vehicles or on motorbikes. Some reports suggested the tourists were kidnapped. Smugglers, drug runners and a militant group linked to Al Qaeda frequent the desert area. Others missing include a Swede, a Dutchman and four Swiss. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Casualties
description: Announced military casualties in the Iraq war zone as of 5 p.m. Eastern time yesterday:

title: War Tests a German Niche Industry
description: From the makers of the duct tape bought by Americans fearful of a terrorist attack to the suppliers of sandstorm-proof goggles to British and American troops, German companies have profited handsomely from the American-led war on Iraq.

title: Chemistry Council Chooses Ogilvy
description: The American Chemistry Council in Arlington, Va., an industry trade association, has named Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York as agency of record on its account, which had been inactive. Billings were estimated at $50 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Matsushita Expects A Loss
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the maker of the Panasonic brand, said it probably lost 23.5 billion yen ($196 million) in the fiscal year that ended March 31 because of losses on its stockholdings. The company had previously forecast a 25 billion yen profit. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: The Kiss of Desperation: A Disgusting Practice Vanishes With the Token
description: In five days, when the last New York City subway token slides through the slot of the last booth to sell them, few people will notice and fewer will care. There will be no official ceremony to mark the passing. If there is music in the background, it will not be taps; it will be the bleating song that turnstiles sing to valid MetroCards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, MARILYN
description: WEISS-Marilyn. On April 6, 2003. Of East Meadow, LI. Beloved wife of Arthur. Devoted mother of Gail Schneider, Sheila Weiss & Ilene Bacine. Dear sister of Irma Kiviat. Cherished grandmother of Marc, Samara, Sebastian, Julia, Jessica, Noah, Elena and Shay. Services Wednesday, 12 noon at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York.

title: American Soldiers Find Drums Possibly Storing Chemical Agents
description: American soldiers searching an empty military training camp in the Karbala area have found several drums that, according to preliminary tests, may contain deadly nerve agents and mustard gas.

title: Retail Borrowing Slowed in February
description: Consumer borrowing through credit cards and auto loans edged up at a slower pace in February as Americans bought fewer new cars and trucks, Federal Reserve statistics released today showed.

title: A Week Into April, and Wondering Where That Snow Shovel Is Stored
description: In the winter that would not die, the snowstorm that nobody wanted had the effrontery to deliver yet another unappreciated gift to the metropolitan region yesterday, doing its best to nip spring quite literally in the bud.

title: Corrections
description: A review of the New York City Opera production of ''La Bohme'' on Wednesday misstated the given name of the tenor singing Rodolfo. The error also occurred in Weekend on Friday in a picture caption and a Critic's Notebook article about an abundance of New York productions of the opera. The tenor is Gerard Powers, not Gerald.

title: AIR PRODUCTS ISSUES WARNING ON EARNINGS
description: Air Products and Chemicals, a producer of industrial gas, estimated yesterday that its fiscal second-quarter income declined to 51 cents a share as energy costs rose and North American sales waned. The preliminary results are lower than a previous company estimate for the period. Air Products had earnings of $126.1 million, or 57 cents a share, a year earlier. The company, which supplies liquid argon, oxygen and nitrogen to chemical makers, sold less of those gases than expected as customers reduced demand. The company, based in Allentown, Pa., said it expected to report profit of 51 to 54 cents a share when full results are released April 24. Its earlier estimate was for a profit of 56 to 58 cents a share.

title: '3 BR, Forest Vu' May Have Added Feature: Lyme Disease Risk
description: Building a dream house in the woodlands of the Northeast can be a blueprint for getting Lyme disease, according to a recent study in Dutchess County, N.Y.

title: Bush's Security Adviser Meets Putin in Effort to Repair War-Strained Relations
description: President Bush's national security adviser met with President Vladimir V. Putin and his top aides here today in what a senior American diplomat later called a mission to repair relations badly bruised by divisions over the war in Iraq.

title: Who Wins From an Analyst's Rich Deal
description: Meirav Chovav, a biotechnology stock analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, agreed last April to join UBS Warburg, whose health care banking group is led by Benjamin Lorello. Her compensation: a guaranteed $10 million over three years, say bankers with a knowledge of her contract.

title: Choreographing Up a Storm
description: Storms battered the stage of the Duke on 42nd Street recently when the Kevin Wynn Collection presented "Ruptured Angels on the Asphalt" as an event of the 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Project.

title: Strawberry Seeks Privacy Upon Leaving Jail Today
description: Several hours before the Yankees start anew by playing their home opener, Darryl Strawberry will begin the newest phase of his troubled life when he is released today from the Gainesville Correctional Institution in Florida. Strawberry, who has served almost one year there for violating his probation on cocaine possession charges, is scheduled to leave the medium security prison at about 8:30 a.m.

title: Songwriting That Revels In Beauty
description: Extravagant musical beauty of the sort that induces swoons and sighs is a quality most contemporary composers scrupulously parcel out in an age of irony, cynicism and guarded emotional expression. But for Adam Guettel, the composer of the musical ''Floyd Collins,'' the creation of songs whose voluptuous chromaticism inflects the vocabulary of Rachmaninoff and Wagner with modernist touches and international pop colors is pretty much the whole show.

title: Penney Expects Flat Sales
description: The J. C. Penney Company said today that sales last week at its department stores open at least a year were worse than it expected and this month's results will be little changed from those of a year ago.

title: Music Before Politics For French Sister Act
description: In a period when restaurateurs are gleefully flushing bottles of Dom Prignon down toilets and boycotts of everything from Herms handbags to Peugeot automobiles are being proposed, now may not be the best time for a French act to be courting the United States. And yet, Les Nubians, a sister duo from Bordeaux, are doing just that, placing music before international politics.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Algeria: Hunt For Missing Europeans
description: German and Austrian police have joined the search in the vast southern Sahara for 29 European tourists missing without a trace since February. Among the missing are 15 Germans and 8 Austrians. The reinforcements came as the Algerian police drew a blank about the fate of the tourists, traveling in at least five separate groups and in four-wheel drive vehicles or on motorbikes. Some reports suggested the tourists were kidnapped. Smugglers, drug runners and a militant group linked to Al Qaeda frequent the desert area. Others missing include a Swede, a Dutchman and four Swiss. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: A Generation Gap Over the War?
description: To the Editor:

title: Playing a Cat-and-Mouse Game
description: Two American Special Operations soldiers sat in their Humvee on a small ridge here this afternoon and watched a white-and-orange taxi speed down a nearby road. As they viewed the car through binoculars, a second group of Americans shot at it with a .50-caliber machine gun.

title: Corrections
description: A review of the New York City Opera production of ''La Boheme'' on Wednesday misstated the given name of the tenor singing Rodolfo. The error also occurred in Weekend on Friday in a picture caption and a Critic's Notebook article about an abundance of New York productions of the opera. The tenor is Gerard Powers, not Gerald.

title: Eying Postwar Iraq, Chirac to Meet With Putin and Schrder
description: MOSCOW, April 8  A long-planned meeting of the leaders of Russia and Germany acquired a sudden new cast late today when President Jacques Chirac of France said he would attend the session this weekend, in St. Petersburg, and suggested that the situation in postwar Iraq would top the agenda.

title: Stock Dealing at Union-Owned Insurer Creates a Schism Within Labor
description: The nation's labor leaders are split into two feuding camps over how to respond to the stock trading under investigation at Ullico, the beleaguered union-owned insurance company, and to the company's deepening financial crisis.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Layoffs At Arms Maker
description: Giat Industries, the state-owned French arms manufacturer, will close three factories and eliminate as many as 3,750 jobs, or 60 percent of its 6,250 employees, by the end of 2006 in a reorganization. Giat, or Groupement Industriel de l'Armement Terrestre, which builds the Leclerc battle tank as well as artillery pieces for the French military and for export, has not posted a profit in more than a decade. It reflects the downturn in European military spending and increased competition in international arms markets. In 2001, Giat's management was castigated in a government report and ordered to reorganize. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIER, EMANUEL
description: TOBIER-Emanuel. The NYU Wagner community mourns the passing of Emanuel Tobier, Professor Emeritus of Economics & Planning. For over 30 years, Manny demonstrated his commitment to the school and the university through his dedication to teaching, passion for research and service to the city. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his wife Nina and his children. Ellen Schall, Dean Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service New York University

title: Toilet Training by the Clock
description: Starting toilet training early is a good way to have it last longer, a study released yesterday said.

title: Police Crossed Line by Arresting Onlookers, Antiwar Protesters Say
description: Antiwar protesters said the police arrested more than 70 people yesterday who were merely looking on as others lay down on a sidewalk to block the entrance of a Midtown office building.

title: Leon Levy, Philanthropist, Is Dead at 77
description: Leon Levy, a hedge fund pioneer who began investing at 13 with $200 and went on to make many millions, enough to make him one of the main individual backers of archaeological research, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 77.

title: Sports of The Times; In Experience vs. Youth, It's the Talent That Wins
description: Jim Boeheim prepped and rehearsed for this moment for 16 years, ever since that dismal night in this very same Superdome, where Indiana's Keith Smart hit a jumper with seconds left and sent Syracuse and Boeheim to defeat in the 1987 national championship game. This week Boeheim said that it had taken him nearly a decade to recover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, DAVID
description: BLOOM-David. The Convent of the Sacred Heart, Greenwich, mourns the loss of our devoted parent David Bloom. David was an inspiration and enthusiastic member of our community. Sympathy is extended to David's wife Melanie, and daughters Ava, Christine and Nicole. Our lives at Sacred Heart were enriched by his presence among us. A scholarship fund is being established in his memory at the School. Joan Magnetti, rscj, Head Mistress, Board of Trustees, Staff and Students

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bid For Engineering Concern
description: The privately held engineering company Robert Bosch made another bid to take over the Buderus Group, Bosch's main rival in the heating technology business. Bosch said it offered 29.15 euros a share to buy the remaining 53 percent of shares in Buderus, the same price it agreed to pay Bilfinger Berger for its 30 percent stake. Both companies are based in Germany. The merged company would be the leading supplier of heating technology in Europe if it gets the approval of antitrust authorities. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Family Says Lynch in Good Spirits After Ordeal
description: LANDSTUHL, Germany, April 8  Bearing a white teddy bear with a red-white-and-blue ribbon, the parents of Pfc. Jessica D. Lynch ventured into the hospital room where their 19-year-old daughter was recuperating from her wounds.

title: Endangered Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraq War Sets Bad Precedent, Mbeki Warns
description: President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa today issued his most stinging evaluation of the war against Iraq, saying that the United States and Britain had unevenly applied standards of democracy, and warning Africans that they could be the next victims of what he depicted as international bullying.

title: U.S. Blasts Compound in Effort to Kill Hussein
description: WASHINGTON, April 7  An Air Force bomber dropped four 2,000-pound bombs on a Baghdad neighborhood this afternoon in an attempt to kill Saddam Hussein and his sons, military and Bush administration officials said tonight.

title: XEROX HIRES TREASURER FROM PHONE EQUIPMENT COMPANY
description: The Xerox Corporation, the copier maker, has hired Rhonda Seegal of Avaya as treasurer to succeed Gregory B. Tayler, who was reassigned last year amid lawsuits accusing Xerox of accounting misconduct. Ms. Seegal has been treasurer at Avaya, a leading maker of office telephone equipment, since September 2000 and was deputy treasurer at General Electric before that. She will join Xerox on April 21 and will represent the company to lenders, debtholders and credit-rating companies, Xerox said. Her primary task will be to help Xerox raise cash to meet debt obligations, including $9 billion due in the next three years.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Math-Wiz Birds

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: A Nation at War, a daily separate section, begins on Page B1.

title: A Generation Gap Over the War?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mine Owner In Australia Being Bought
description: After four months of haggling and weeks of intense industry speculation, the British-Swiss mining company Xstrata agreed to acquire MIM Holdings, an Australian miner of coal and base metals, for $2.04 billion in cash.

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile on Friday about Roland W. Betts, chairman of Chelsea Piers and a director of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, omitted the context for a phrase he used about President Bush, his longtime friend. When Mr. Betts was asked if he had ''his ear'' regarding the development of downtown Manhattan, Mr. Betts said, ''Oh, you mean 'the big ear.' '' It is not a nickname he uses for the president.

title: Study Finds Charter Schools Lack Experienced Teachers
description: Charter schools, regarded by hundreds of thousands of families as an alternative to low-performing public schools, rely heavily on young, inexperienced, uncredentialed teachers and often do not have the resources to provide the instructional help that many of their students need, a new study has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOHN, JEROME M.
description: LOHN-Jerome M. Born May 30, 1950 in Lakewood, OH, currently of New York, NY died on Friday after a brief illness. He was 52 years of age. Jerry was a Vice President and credit specialist in the Investment Banking Division at JP Morgan Chase & Co. Jerry is survived by his much adored wife, Joanne (nee Haring), his family, Barbara Lohn and Raymond Centa, Susan and Peter Williams, Timothy and Barbara Lohn, Nancy and Michael Chenderlin, Jane and Douglas Cosler, Patrick and Maritza Lohn, his lifelong friend Joseph Sabatini and wife Mariko, as well as his many nieces & nephews. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to either the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation at www.jdrf.com, 432 Park Avenue South, 15th Floor, New York, NY 10016 or St. Edward High School, www.sehs.net, 13500 Detroit Road, Lakewood, OH. 44107-4697. The family will receive friends at The Westchester Funeral Home, 190 Main Street, Eastchester, 914337-4585, Wednesday, April 9, from 4-7 PM, where a service will be held at 6 PM.

title: The Selfless Founders
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush's Next Role: Mediator in Disputes Over Running Postwar Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, April 7  With an end in sight to the battle for Baghdad, President Bush is now moving to end two arguments that were never resolved before the shooting started: One between the United States and Europe over who will run Iraq, and a second between his own State and Defense Departments over how to run it.

title: Dreaming of a Bright Ray
description: To the Editor:

title: Path of Glory for an Obscure Corsican
description: Napoleon Bonaparte could be lionhearted, as when he sent his fabled 500,000 troops into battle. He could be tenderhearted, as when he learned of his dear Josephine's wayward affections. And over four fanciful hours, A&E tries to examine that conflicted heart, from its adrenalized glory days to the lonely afternoon in exile when it stopped ticking.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Camping Fees To Rise
description: Facing sharp cuts in in its budget, the State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation announced yesterday that it would charge campers more for services, including the basic fee for campers to hook up to water at campsites. That fee, which applies to campers using recreational vehicles, will rise to $12 from $3 in the season that will begin next Tuesday. Entrance and electrical fees will also rise, but the $13 charge for a basic campsite will not change. Last year, camping fees brought in about $7 million, more than 10 percent of the department's $65 million budget. This year, the department faces cuts of more than 40 percent, or $27 million. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSCHMAN, DAVID WIL LIAM
description: HERSCHMAN - David Wil liam, born NYC, January 6, 1968, passed away peacefully, April 3, 2003 in San Francisco after a fierce struggle with melanoma. A UC Berkeley graduate, he traveled extensively and excelled as an athlete. A successful entrepreneur, by 1999 he created the world's leading online gaming site, Prize Central, sold to Vivendi-Universal in April 2000. David is survived by his beloved wife, Dr. Michelle Birch, His parents, Lee and Stanley Herschman, sister, Jill Herschman, uncle Arthur Salzfass, and scores of close friends and relatives.

title: Usually Resilient United Way Now Predicts a Leaner Year
description: United Ways across the country have struggled to raise money in the charity's 2002-03 campaign, which is shaping up to be one of the worst fund-raising periods in three decades for the organization.

title: Knicks' Margin For Error Is No More
description: The final blow to the Knicks' season could come as early as Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden. A loss to the Atlanta Hawks would eliminate the Knicks from the playoffs.

title: While Mourning Dead, Many Americans Say Level of Casualties Is Acceptable
description: The number of United States casualties in the Iraq war, 88 dead by the Pentagon's count as of today, has surprised both Alan Wolfgang and Chuck Wutke, colleagues in magazine publishing who eat lunch weekly in the cafeteria of the Equitable Building on the edge of the Chicago River downtown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAUL, KATHLEEN O'CALLAGHAN
description: MAUL-Kathleen O'Callaghan of Dix Hills, NY on April 5, 2003 after 52 years of a family-filled and wonderful life. Executive Director of United Cerebral Palsy. Beloved wife of George. Loving mother of Brehan, Meaghan and Katharine. Dear sister of Maureen Davies, Mary Pat Sullivan, Jerry and James O'Callaghan. Reposing Moloney's Hauppauge Funeral Home, 840 Wheeler Rd (Rte 111) Hauppauge, where religious services will be held 8:00 PM Thursday. Funeral Mass Friday, 9:45 AM at St. Matthews R.C. Church, Dix Hills. Interment following at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, New York. Visiting Wednesday & Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made to U.C.P. of Greater Suffolk, 250 Marcus Blvd, Hauppauge, New York 11788.

title: Another Ex-HealthSouth Executive Charged With Fraud
description: Federal prosecutors filed criminal charges against another onetime executive of the HealthSouth Corporation today, alleging that Michael Martin, a former chief financial officer, conspired to commit wire and securities fraud and filed false books and records.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, SOLOMON
description: COHEN-Solomon. On April 5, 2003. Loving brother, husband, father and grandfather. His career in medicine, as an oncologist, span 40 years at Montefiore and Our Lady of Mercy Hospitals and in a devoted practice in the Bronx. He gave comfort and peace to his many patients and touched the lives of so many people. He cherished the simple pleasures in life and was a true original. He will be deeply missed by family and friends. Service Thursday, April 10th at 2:30PM at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South, NYC.

title: In the Heart of Baghdad
description: Now firmly entrenched in Iraqs capital city, American forces target a building in a residential district in an attempt to kill Saddam Hussein. Ground troops drive an armored column into the center of the capital, impressing on the citys defenders that American forces can move at will, even at the very core of the Iraqi power structure.

title: Congress's Pet Arsenal
description: Under cover of war, the domestic gun industry is prodding Congress to anoint it as the ''Arsenal of Democracy'' by enacting a disastrous bill to give gun makers and dealers unprecedented protection from liability suits by state and local governments and victims of gun violence. The ''Arsenal'' argument is being pressed by lobbyists who want to enshrine the industry as the safeguard of freedom ''here at home and around the world,'' as the National Shooting Sports Foundation puts it.

title: Pataki Drops Attempt for Bigger Share of Antiterror Funds
description: Facing a barrage of criticism by members of both parties, Gov. George E. Pataki today abandoned his demand that the state receive a greater share of federal antiterrorism money, agreeing to allow New York City to have the money it is seeking from Congress.

title: Battle in Baghdad
Primate Primer
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Champs Paint the Town Orange
description: Syracuse defeated Kansas, 81-78, Monday to win the N.C.A.A. men's basketball championship, the first in school history.

title: Prison Tours, Vengeance and Tea
description: In Basra, onlookers broke into a prison. In Baghdad, Marines moving northward.

title: Israeli Forces Kill 5 Palestinians in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, April 9  The Israeli military in tanks and other armored vehicles charged into the northern Gaza Strip and shot dead five Palestinians today following Palestinian rocket fire on an Israeli town.

title: Garment District's Ethnic Mix Now Offers 'Balkanian'
description: FEW neighborhoods in Manhattan are as much fun for walking as the garment district, if only for its unpredictability. The almost brutally functional buildings offer little to the architectural historian, though a pedestrian looking up through the oversize windows will see any number of activities: fabric trimming, clothes modeling at a strut, dance rehearsals, rock 'n' rolling. But for me, the excitement is in the ever-changing population of hole-in-the-wall eating establishments at street level.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Power Plant Plan
description: The Bombay High Court gave domestic creditors of the $2.9 billion Dabhol power plant three months to prepare a feasibility plan to restart the stalled plant so they can recover part of their loans. The legal counsel for the Indian lenders said the plan must include a provision for the government-owned National Thermal Power Corporation to restart and run the plant. The court order came in response to a request from the domestic lenders to revive the plant, which has been idle for nearly two years. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Casualties
description: Announced military casualties in the Iraq war zone as of 4 p.m. Eastern time yesterday:

title: 111 Unidentified Corpses at Crematory Perplex Investigators
description: Investigators said on Monday that they had been unable to identify 111 of more than 334 sets of human remains that were found last year scattered at a crematory in northwestern Georgia.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 3 Convicted In Bombing Campaign
description: A London jury convicted three Irishmen of plotting a series of bombings in 2001. The homemade explosives went off in cars parked near the BBC's television headquarters in London and at subway stations in Ealing and Birmingham. No one was killed in the attacks, which took place on Saturday nights, but they caused millions of dollars worth of property damage. The three men, Noel Maguire, 34, and two brothers, Robert Hulme, 23, and Aiden Hulme, 25, were members of the Real I.R.A., a breakaway republican group that opposes the I.R.A.'s participation in the Northern Irish peace negotiations. They are to be sentenced today. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: HOCKEY ; Quest for the Cup, Round 1
description: A look at the eight first-round matchups. By JASON DIAMOS

title: A Reporter Killed in Iraq Was Known For Tenacity
description: Despite the obvious perils of cycling in Manhattan, Julio A. Parrado knew there was no better means of navigating the traffic-choked city than on a beat-up three-speeder.

title: Editors' Note; Editors' Note
description: An article on Saturday about the search by United States forces for chemical, biological and radiation weapons in Iraq included a comment attributed to Amy Smithson, a chemical weapons expert at the Henry L. Stimson Center, a research institute in Washington. Ms. Smithson was depicted as suggesting that Bush administration officials might be less certain of finding such weapons now than before the war. She was quoted as saying that ''they may be trying to dampen expectations because they are worried they won't find anything significant.''

title: One More Time, Ready to Race to the Firehouse's Rescue
description: In the 1970's, the people of Williamsburg took over the firehouse of Engine Company 212 for 16 months, eating and sleeping there and holding vigil in an eventually successful effort to keep it open. Their sit-in came after hordes of people marched through the streets and once even shut down the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Accord On Ramsey Murder Theory
description: JonBenet Ramsey was most likely killed by an intruder and not her parents, the Boulder district attorney and a judge in Georgia agree. In dismissing a suit against the parents, John and Patsy Ramsey, a federal judge in Atlanta said the evidence pointed to an intruder rather than the speculation that the Ramseys had something to do with the death of JonBenet, their 6-year-old daughter, in 1996 in Boulder. Mary Keenan, the district attorney since 2001 who took over the case from the police last year, released a statement this week to say she concurred with that ruling. ''Since Mr. and Mrs. Ramsey have not even been charged, much less convicted, they must be presumed innocent and must be treated accordingly,'' Ms. Keenan said. The suit was filed by a journalist whom the Ramseys described as a suspect in a book they wrote. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Police Respond To a 911 Call Only to Find A Burglar Dead
description: A burglar who sneaked into a Queens house and assaulted a 50-year-old woman in her bed ended up in the morgue yesterday, and the police said that two men who responded to the woman's cries for help may have played a role in his death.

title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times review on Jan. 22, about ''The Spooky Art: Some Thoughts on Writing,'' a collection of works by Norman Mailer, referred erroneously to the absence of dates for some works republished and excerpted. While the dates were missing from the proof copy furnished to reviewers, the published book has thorough source notes at the back, compiled by the editor, J. Michael Lennon. A letter from Mr. Mailer dated March 24 pointed out the error.

title: HealthSouth Ex-Executive Is Charged
description: As HealthSouth continued to struggle to avoid bankruptcy, federal officials yesterday charged another former senior executive of the company with participating in a multibillion-dollar accounting fraud.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAESEKER, DONALD H.
description: HAESEKER-Donald H. Age 81, of Glen Allen, Virginia, died Sunday, April 6, 2003. He was retired from Chubb & Son Insurance Company after 45 years in the Surety Department. Survivors include his wife, Beryl Barbuti Haeseker; daughter, Jane H. Sketchley and her husband, Garsed; son, Thomas P. Haeseker and his wife, Karen; grandchildren, Andrew B. and Gregory B. title: How to Boil an Egg: So Simple, but Not Easy

Like all the foods associated with Passover, the hard-boiled or roasted egg has been invested with a staggering array of symbolic values. Haggadot, the Passover books used at Seders, variously cite the egg as a symbol of rebirth, of mourning, of the complete nourishment of the Jewish people by the Torah and even of the hardening of the Jews' spirits during their enslavement in Egypt.

Leonid Fedun, a vice president at Lukoil, said in a telephone interview that his company would sue any usurping company in international court in Geneva. Lukoil, said Mr. Fedun, is confident about the contract, which was concluded with the Iraqi government, but never advanced because of economic sanctions imposed on Iraq by the United Nations. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Poor Sales At Retailer
description: The retailer Marks & Spencer delivered one of the starkest indications yet of a downturn on Britain's Main Street when it announced fourth-quarter sales growth of just 1 percent, its slowest since 2001, when the company finally began regaining ground after years of falling profits. Sales of clothing, footwear and home furnishings were down 0.3 percent, while food sales rose by 2.6 percent. Analysts said they had been expecting rises of 3 to 5 percent. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: NEW MEXICO: AIR FORCE CROSS-BURNING CASE Four members of the Air Force are being investigated for possible white supremacist activities at Kirtland Air Force Base in Albuquerque. One airman, a member of a security squadron, had a party last month at his house outside the base, and a cross was burned in the backyard. The police responded to a noise complaint. Supremacist literature, possibly from the Ku Klux Klan, and swastikas were found at the house and in the houses at Kirtland of other airmen at the party. The four have been put on leave while Air Force officials investigate. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Acxiom Shares Plunge On Lowered Estimates
description: Shares of the Acxiom Corporation, which makes database-management software, fell as much as 29 percent after the company cut estimates for the 2004 fiscal year and said fourth-quarter sales and profit missed forecasts. Shares declined $3.45, or about 21 percent, to $13.05. They dropped as low as $11.65, after gaining 5.6 percent in the last year. Excluding write-offs of as much as $40 million, profit in the quarter that ended on March 31 would have been about 3 cents a share on sales around $238 million, Acxiom said after a preliminary review. Analysts expected the company to earn 21 cents on sales of $259.9 million, according to a Thomson Financial survey. Customers canceled purchases because of the war in Iraq and slow economic growth, the company said. The chief financial officer, Robert S. Bloom, did not return a call seeking comment. Acxiom attributed the write-off to investments that fell in value, software inventories and some unprofitable operations.

It was up to Mr. Hobbs to determine a retail price that would let him pay off some debts and draw the attention of serious wine drinkers, yet be low enough that he could actually sell the wine, not just this year but for vintages to come.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Stolen Frescoes Found
description: The police recovered a pair of 2,000-year-old frescoes stolen from a villa at the ruins of Pompeii, but the thieves had vanished. The ancient treasures -- one a depiction of Cupid and the other of a rooster pecking a pomegranate -- were found slightly damaged and packed up, ready to ship, in a nearby abandoned building. The frescoes, hacked off the walls of the House of the Chaste Lovers over the weekend, date from 45 A.D. to 79 A.D, when Vesuvius erupted and buried Pompeii in ash. Excavations at the villa, named for a fresco of two clothed lovers, began in 1987. It has never been opened to the public. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

Stock options currently granted by G.E. provide windfalls to executives in good economic times and penalize them in bad times, Calpers said.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: PanAmSat And Level 3 Form Data Network
description: The PanAmSat Corporation, the United States commercial satellite operator, and Level 3 Communications agreed yesterday to create a network that their customers can use to transmit data faster. The companies will share revenue from the service, PanAmSat's chief executive, Joseph R. Wright Jr., said in an interview. He declined to be specific or to discuss financial terms. It is the first major agreement between a United States satellite operator and a data-network company, Mr. Wright said. Level 3 is backed by the investor Warren E. Buffett. PanAmSat got 8 percent of its sales from government customers last year and expects to double that percentage by 2005, Mr. Wright said. The company bought the government sales unit from the Hughes Electronics Corporation this year and is 81 percent owned by Hughes.

title: In Search of Horror Weapons
description: As allied forces seize control of more Iraqi real estate every day, one of the great questions still to be answered is whether Saddam Hussein has the unconventional weapons that were cited as the prime reason for launching the invasion. Most Western analysts believe that Mr. Hussein has at least some chemical and biological arms. Otherwise, they reason, he could have headed off the invasion by showing that he had destroyed his previously known chemical and biological stocks. Yet if Iraq does have chemical weapons, Mr. Hussein has shown remarkable restraint by not using them even as his government heads for certain destruction. Solving this mystery requires urgent, neutral investigation once the allies gain full control of Iraq and can mount a sustained search.

title: Corrections

title: National Briefing | West: California: Looking For A Name
description: What's in a name? The Los Angeles City Council is to consider a motion today to rename the largely black, crime-ridden South-Central neighborhood. If approved, the 16-square-mile area, known for riots, poverty and gang violence, would be referred to as South Los Angeles in future documents, including maps and correspondence. The move is intended to leave the past and reflect growing racial diversity. Calvin Sims (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORNELL, GEORGE D.
description: CORNELL-George D. Cornell University mourns the passing of George Cornell, a man who claims a solid place in the history of the University and in the hearts of many alumni, friends, and staff members. A distant cousin of the University's founder, George shared Ezra Cornell's commitment to education and accessibility to it. ''Education is what made our country great,'' he said, explaining one of the largest scholarship gifts the University ever received, which he made with his wife, Harriet. George and Harriet endowed the Edward Cornell Librarianship and the Edward F. Cornell Professorship of Law at the Cornell University Law School, both named for George's father who received his Cornell law degree in 1890. They took the lead to renovate Bailey Hall, a 90-year-old concert hall and campus landmark. Ever active and involved with Cornell, George served as a presidential councillor up until his death and hosted and attended many University events in both Florida and New York. In 1988, he and Harriet were named foremost benefactors, an honor bestowed on the University's most generous patrons. The Cornell University community expresses its sincere condolences to George Cornell's sisters, Katherine Stainton and Phebe Maresi; and his two nieces and nephew, Alice, Beatrice, and Henry Maresi, who survive him. Hunter R. Rawlings III, President, Cornell University Peter C. Meinig, Chairman of the Board of Trustees, Cornell University

title: A Little Plantain At the Passover Table
description: A BEAN soup bubbled on the stove while Rebeca Esquenazi fried plantains for that evening's dinner and chatted in Spanish with two friends. Palm trees laid a blanket of shade over her second-floor balcony, cooling the hundreds of perfectly crafted burekas and bulemas, flaky pastries filled with feta cheese, spinach and potatoes that she had set out in foil pans. As she has done for the last 36 years, she would send some to friends, saving the rest for her family.

title: It's as Light as Air, but Tastier
description: A cloud of zabaglione is lovely to spoon over strawberries or a fruit compote and makes a great Passover dessert. At Shallots NY, a kosher restaurant at 550 Madison Avenue (55th Street), the chef, Damian Sansonetti, beats 4 egg yolks with 2 tablespoons superfine sugar and 1/4 cup of kosher Italian moscato, a delicately sweet wine. He places the bowl over a pot of simmering water and whisks the mixture, adding another 1/4 cup of the wine, for about 10 minutes, until soft peaks form. The zabaglione can be held for more than an hour if a scant teaspoon of potato starch is mixed with the sugar. For children, white grape juice can replace the wine. Serve layered with fruit in four pretty glasses or dessert dishes. Passover meringues would make an excellent accompaniment; Shallots NY sells them and other baked goods. Orders can be placed at www.shallotsny.com.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ashley and Michael, Meet Destiny
description: For New York City parents, at least, the most fashionable baby names are still Ashley and Michael, according to the city's latest annual survey of baby names. Of 60,264 births of girls in 2001 that were recorded by the Department of Health, Ashley was the must-have name for the 10th straight year, while Michael continued its reign, for the 14th consecutive year, among the city's 63,759 newborn boys. The biggest surprises on the list were the debut of Destiny at No. 9 in the Top 10 girls' names, and for boys, the re-emergence of Anthony at No. 7, a venerable contender that lost favor in 2000. Nichole M. Christian (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: STOLEN FRESCOES FOUND The police recovered a pair of 2,000-year-old frescoes stolen from a villa at the ruins of Pompeii, but the thieves had vanished. The ancient treasures — one a depiction of Cupid and the other of a rooster pecking a pomegranate — were found slightly damaged and packed up, ready to ship, in a nearby abandoned building. The frescoes, hacked off the walls of the House of the Chaste Lovers over the weekend, date from 45 A.D. to 79 A.D, when Vesuvius erupted and buried Pompeii in ash. Excavations at the villa, named for a fresco of two clothed lovers, began in 1987. It has never been opened to the public.  Jason Horowitz (NYT)

Such an intramural fracture's winding up in the secular courts would have been unimaginable until now in America's Roman Catholic Church. Church solidarity is the latest victim in the sorry scandal.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: APPEALS COURT RESCINDS FINE AGAINST AT&T A federal appeals court yesterday struck down a fine the Federal Communications Commission had imposed on AT&T for unauthorized switching of long-distance phone service, and said part of the commission's "anti-slamming" regulations exceeded its authority. The ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit said the commission was overstepping its authority by requiring carriers to guarantee that the person authorizing a change of service is the customer. The court said federal law required only that carriers get "verification" of a customer's decision to switch, usually through a call back to the customer's number by a third-party service. A representative of the F.C.C. was not immediately available for comment. The case stems from a 2000 ruling by the commission, which found AT&T liable for 11 incidents of slamming and levied fines totaling $520,000, the court said. AT&T opposed the sanctions in two of the cases, which accounted for $80,000 in fines. The company argued that it had complied with F.C.C. rules that require "independent third-party verification" that the customers had ordered a change in long-distance service, the appeals court said. The commission had rejected the company's argument. The two customers at issue complained that they did not even know the people who had verified the change on their behalf. But the appeals court disagreed, ruling that the F.C.C.'s regulations "go beyond the anti-slamming statute's express terms." An AT&T spokeswoman, Claudia Jones, said the company has "a zero-tolerance policy for slamming."

title: UNIONBANCAL TO BUY MONTEREY BAY BANCORP
description: The UnionBanCal Corporation, which has bank branches in California, Washington and Oregon, agreed to acquire Monterey Bay Bancorp Inc. for $96.5 million in cash and stock to add branches in the Monterey Bay area south of San Francisco. UnionBanCal will pay about $48.3 million in cash and 1.1 million to 1.34 million of its shares for all of Monterey Bay's shares outstanding. Monterey Bay has $610 million in assets and 130 workers in eight branches in the Monterey Bay area. The purchase is expected to close in the third quarter and add to per-share earnings in 2004, UnionBanCal said. The company has about $40.2 billion in assets and 283 branches. UnionBanCal is based in San Francisco. Monterey Bay Bancorp is based in Watsonville, Calif.

title: AT DINNER WITH: Nell Campbell and Matilda Roche; A Diva Enters, With Marabou And Mashed Potatoes

Famous for so many things -- dancing on the tables at Nell's, her club that set the gold standard for New York night life in the 1980's; tap-dancing her way into cult film history in ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show'' -- but mostly famous for just being famous, this redhead with the Cleopatra bob and the killer legs makes her Broadway debut tomorrow in ''Nine,'' with Antonio Banderas. A supporting role, to be sure, but as she announced with dramatic flourish, ''I want you to know I make every moment on that stage count.''

And now, his treats are available online from www.partistry.com. The truffles, in flavors like star anise and Grand Marnier, are $15 a dozen or $29 for 24. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOKOTOFF, HAROLD S.

Loving and devoted husband to Rhoda, who passed away in 1997, and ever-encouraging grandfather to Lizzie Berne, Alexander Berne and Sophia Mokotoff; son-in-law Robert Berne, daughter-in-law Hue Mokotoff and caregiver Red Mackey. Our lives were profoundly nurtured by the warmth of his insight and humor. As a member of the NYS Bar for over half a century, his dedicated professional work improved the lives of thousands. There will be a private graveside service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, HELEN E. (NEE O'LEARY)
description: McCARTHY-Helen E. (nee O'Leary) fortified with the Sacraments of Holy Mother Church, Saturday, April 5th, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Joseph F. McCarthy. Dear mother of Helen P. Sheehan. Dear sister of Thomas O'Leary and the late Lillian Healy and Francis O'Leary. Dear grandmother of John P., Jr. M.D. (Sandy), Dennis M. (Liz) and Joseph B. (Anne) Sheehan. Dear great-grandmother of Alex, Brendan, Maegan, Maureen, Alison and Jack Sheehan. Dear aunt, great aunt, cousin and friend to many. Interment Thursday, April 10th 1PM at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Republicans Press for Bill to Shield Vaccine Makers From Suits
description: The mysterious new respiratory ailment that has terrified people around the globe has extended its reach to the Capitol, where Senate Republicans are using the disease to press their case that vaccine manufacturers should be shielded from lawsuits.

title: Topps Posts 38% Rise in Quarterly Profit
description: The Topps Company, the maker of collectible trading cards and Bazooka bubble gum, said yesterday that its profit rose 38 percent in its most recent quarter as its European soccer and ''Yu-Gi-Oh!'' Japanese cartoon products led sales higher.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Claw Protection
description: The West Hollywood City Council has approved an ordinance to ban the declawing of cats. The measure, the first of its kind in the United States, prohibits declawing except in medical emergencies. Supporters of the ban, which affects three veterinary practices, said declawing crippled cats or caused arthritis and emotional problems. Calvin Sims (NYT)

title: Health Fears Spoil a Swiss Jewel Show
description: The World Jewelry and Watch Fair, the industry's pre-eminent trade show, had been getting so big recently that it outgrew its home in Basel, and part of the show, which is known as Baselworld, had to be moved to Zurich this year.

title: Beaujolais, Shedding the New for the Old
description: BEAUJOLAIS has been going through a quiet revolution. For years it was a high-profile fun wine with ever-more outlandish stunts to introduce the arrival of the ''nouveau'' every November. The annual race to bring the new wine to market enlisted marathon runners, automobile racers, horse-drawn carriages, even parachutists, to see who could have the first bottles of the new wine. Parties were held everywhere -- Paris, New York, Sydney -- to welcome the new wine.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, M.
description: FISHER-M. Anthony. It is with great sadness that the Board, staff and friends of Lincoln Center mourn the passing of M. Anthony Fisher, and his wife Anne. Our thoughts and prayers are with his brother Richard L. Fisher, a cherished member of the Lincoln Center Board of Directors. We also extend our heartfelt sympathy to his mother, Emily Fisher Landau, his five children and the entire Fisher family and friends. Bruce Crawford, Chairman Reynold Levy, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc.

title: Spokesman Molded by Urban Warfare
description: Peter Pace, the four-star Marine general who is the country's second-ranking military officer, got his baptism in combat in the tangled warrens of Hue, Vietnam, and later helped to preside over an ignominious American withdrawal from Somalia.

title: Terror Defense Lawyers Say Jailers Held Them for 2 Hours
description: Lawyers for a Staten Island man detained in a terrorism case have told a federal judge in Manhattan that two members of their legal team who had been meeting with their client in jail were kept in a locked cell for nearly two hours, despite their requests to leave.

title: Power Broker Has No Post, But Big Role
description: There is no mutually agreed-upon term to describe the role George E. Norcross III plays in New Jersey politics, and most state residents barely know his name, but within the halls of the State House, he has recently emerged as one of the most powerful and most vilified figures in the state.

title: Trial Begins in Bias Suit By Deaf U.P.S. Workers
description: Lawyers for 900 deaf workers at United Parcel Service argued today as a trial in their discrimination lawsuit opened that the company had excluded them from numerous job categories and generally limited them to bottom-rung positions.

title: Asia Faces Increasing Isolation Because of Deadly Disease
description: HONG KONG, April 9  Asian countries battling the spread of a deadly respiratory disease today faced increasing international isolation as visa restrictions were tightened for their citizens, top officials from other nations shunned visits and airlines canceled flights.

title: MasterCard and Visa Are Ordered to Refund Currency Fees
description: In a ruling that could cost MasterCard and Visa hundreds of millions of dollars, a California judge has ordered the credit card companies to refund currency conversion fees that the judge said were improperly disclosed.

title: Interstate Bakeries Seeks New Loan Terms
description: The Interstate Bakeries Corporation , maker of Hostess Twinkies and Wonder bread, is in talks with its lenders as higher costs and slowing sales raise the risk of violating loan terms.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: AFGHANISTAN: ENTERING CYBERSPACE The country graduated its first computer networking class and took another small step onto the information superhighway, which has bypassed the war-ravaged nation. Speaking at the graduation ceremony for 6 women and 11 men at Kabul University, Telecommunications Minister Mahsoon Stanikzai said that Afghanistan was two decades behind the world in technology. Last month, the country gained control of the ".af" domain for Afghan Web sites and e-mail addresses.   (Agence France-Presse)

title: With All the Little Wars, Big Peace Is Elusive
description: Amid celebratory handshakes last week, representatives of the Congolese government and some of the rebel groups and militias that have been fighting for their own slice of power signed an accord aimed at ending a war that has claimed millions of lives, most of them through hunger and disease.

title: Baghdad Under Assault
description: American forces pursue a forceful attack on the symbols of Saddam Hussein's rule in Baghdad, expanding their grip inside the city and pressing inward from several directions.

title: VARIAN MEDICAL'S PROFITS RISE WITH INCREASED ORDERS
description: Varian Medical Systems, the world's biggest maker of radiation machines used to treat cancer patients, said profit rose as much as 40 percent in the second quarter on increased orders. Varian, based in Palo Alto, Calif., is benefiting as hospitals buy new versions of its X-ray equipment. Sales of cancer products are rising as more doctors diagnose the disease among an aging population. Net income in the quarter, which ended March 28, was 35 percent to 40 percent higher than the 34 cents a share reported in the same period of 2002, the company said. Varian had estimated that earnings would be 26 percent higher than a year earlier. Sales will be about 20 percent higher than the $220.6 million reported in the second quarter of 2002, it said.

title: In Spain, Premier Is Focus of Anger at Journalist Deaths in Iraq
description: MADRID, April 9 — Hundreds of Spanish journalists demonstrated today to protest the deaths of two colleagues killed covering the assault on Baghdad and to show opposition the Spanish government's support for the war.

title: INSIDE
description: UConn Repeats as Champion

title: Ex-Officer Pleads Guilty to Abusing Drivers
description: A former Suffolk County highway patrol officer pleaded guilty today to violating the civil rights of four female drivers he had either forced to undress or inappropriately touched after detaining them, taking them to remote places and indicating that they were in danger of being arrested.

title: TECUMSEH TO MOVE PRODUCTION OUT OF U.S.
description: The Tecumseh Products Company, a leading maker of engines for lawn mowers, will close its plant in Douglas, Ga., and lay off 550 employees as it moves production outside the United States. The job cuts, to begin June 6, represent 2.4 percent of the company's global work force, a spokeswoman, Pat Walsh, said. The company's second-quarter earnings will be reduced by $19 million to $23 million because of costs related to closing the plant and cutting jobs. The company declined to provide a forecast of second-quarter results. The company, based in Tecumseh, Mich., is moving manufacture of engines to low-cost plants in India, Brazil and the Czech Republic to reduce expenses as customers demand lower prices, Tecumseh's chief financial officer, David W. Kay, said. The company, which also makes air-conditioning compressors, pumps and motors, has moved more than half of its production outside the United States, Mr. Kay said.

title: Babatunde Olatunji, Drummer, 76, Dies; Brought Power of African Music to U.S.
description: Babatunde Olatunji, the Nigerian drummer, bandleader and teacher who was a tireless ambassador for African music and culture in the United States, died on Sunday in Salinas, Calif. He was 76 and lived at the Esalen Institute in Big Sur, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, DAVID
description: BLOOM-David. The Northern Westchester Center for the Arts mourns the loss of our dear friend David Bloom, chairman of our capital campaign and strong supporter of our Center. We were all deeply touched by your generosity and kindness. NWCA Board of Directors

title: Molire's Mixed Feelings About Don Juan's Sins
description: There can't be many roles more fun for an actor than Don Juan, a character whose monumental self-regard is like a license to steal scenes. By that measure Byron Jennings is almost reserved.

title: Despite Grim Finding, P.O.W. Families Try to Hold On to Hope
description: The fall of Baghdad may be near, but Anecita Hudson was not celebrating today. Between rapid telephone conversations in Tagalog with friends here and peeks at the television set, all she could do was try to stop shaking.

title: A NATION AT WAR: IN THE FIELD | 101st AIRBORNE DIVISION; Battalion Stages Assault On Iraqi Hilltop Position And Guard's Complex
description: It took an antitank missile to blow a hole through the steel-reinforced wall surrounding the Special Republican Guard's headquarters at the foot of this hill overlooking the capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOS, CLARA (CEE GEE)
description: ROOS-Clara (Cee Gee). Died peacefully in her sleep early Saturday morning March 15, 2003. Born in Peoria, IL, Clara Gertrude was the daughter of Gertrude Bennett Bloom and Henry Tonkey Bloom. Predeceased by her husband Seymour and daughter Sally Dene Ross Schneck. C.G. is survived by her son, Thomas Bloom Roos, and his wife, a son-in-law, five grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren, and many individuals not necessarily of her ''blood'' whom she considered and treated as kin. Graveside service Saturday April 19th at 2 P.M. at Springdale Cemetery on The Bluffs overlooking The Illinois River and Peoria, IL. Contributions in C.G.'s memory may be sent to The Delia Bloom Fund, c/o Development Office, The Experiment At World Learning, PO Box 676, Brattleboro, VT 05032. Info: Donnellan Family Funeral Services: 847-675-1990.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUBIE, JOHN S.
description: KUBIE-John S. Of Purchase, NY died Monday, April 7 of complications from surgery. He was the former president and CEO of Seligman and Latz, Inc., a chain of beauty salons in fine department stores. Mr. Kubie was very active in the alumni affairs of Phillips Academy at Andover and Yale University and was also a long-time advocate for several non-profit agencies, most notably Grand Street Settlement and the Wiltwick School. He is survived by his dear friend Patricia Goldman, his children: Nancy Fenichel, John L. Kubie, Kathryn Kubie, and Lisa Kubie, and his grandchildren: Jesse, Willie and Teresa Fenichel, Sahrula Kubie, Nicole Quinn, and Leo and Marcus Stilwell. Adored husband of the late Marian (Latz) Kubie, cousin of Warren Heilbron, and friend to many. Services will be held at 11AM on Thursday, April 10 at the Congregation Emmanuel, 2125 Westchester Ave. East, Rye, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to Grand Street Settlement, att: Marcela Hahn, 80 Pitt St., NY, NY 10002, to the White Plains Hospital Center, Development Office, Davis Ave. and East Post Rd., White Plains, NY 10601, or to the charity of your choice.

title: Push to Finish the Job
description: American commanders say Iraqi forces are reeling from almost three weeks of air and land attacks, and they are mounting a three-pronged Army assault on Baghdad to try to force a quick end to the war. When the land campaign was first devised, American commanders envisioned a far more deliberate assault.

title: The Budget No One Wants
description: Less than a week before he unveils his executive budget plan to close New York's $3.5 billion budget gap, Mayor Michael Bloomberg is already cutting thousands of jobs and closing eight firehouses. New York City would be lucky indeed if that was the extent of the layoffs and lost services this year. But the mayor has rightly warned that more pain -- perhaps a great deal more -- will follow.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Air Force Cross-Burning Case
description: Four members of the Air Force are being investigated for possible white supremacist activities at Kirtland Air Force Base in Albuquerque. One airman, a member of a security squadron, had a party last month at his house outside the base, and a cross was burned in the backyard. The police responded to a noise complaint. Supremacist literature, possibly from the Ku Klux Klan, and swastikas were found at the house and in the houses at Kirtland of other airmen at the party. The four have been put on leave while Air Force officials investigate. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: LOOKING FOR A NAME What's in a name? The Los Angeles City Council is to consider a motion today to rename the largely black, crime-ridden South-Central neighborhood. If approved, the 16-square-mile area, known for riots, poverty and gang violence, would be referred to as South Los Angeles in future documents, including maps and correspondence. The move is intended to leave the past and reflect growing racial diversity.

title: India Pressed on Kashmir Attacks
description: At first glance, the argument is seductive: if America can strike out at a suspected sponsor of terrorism and hugely destructive weapons thousands of miles away, why can't India hit out at one next door?

title: British Shift to Stopping Crime in Basra
description: BASRA, Iraq, April 9  The battle for Iraq's second-largest city is all but won, but the fight for control is just beginning.

title: THE CHEF: Hlne Darroze; A French Version of Polenta, With Help From Cheese
description: ''IN the Landes region in the southwest, you'll see more cornfields than vines,'' said Hlne Darroze, who is from that region of France but who now has a restaurant in Paris. She let a few handfuls of finely ground white cornmeal -- closer in texture to corn flour than cornmeal -- drift through her fingers into a saucepan.

title: Italy Expected to Join European Union Deficit Nation List
description: The European Commission sharply reduced its forecast for economic growth this year and said that another of its members, Italy, may soon break through the treaty-imposed ceiling on budget deficits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, SOLOMON
description: COHEN-Solomon. On April 5, 2003. Loving brother, husband, father and grandfather. His career in medicine, as an oncologist, span 40 years at Montefiore and Our Lady of Mercy Hospitals and in a devoted practice in the Bronx. He gave comfort and peace to his many patients and touched the lives of so many people. He cherished the simple pleasures in life and was a true original. He will be deeply missed by family and friends. Service Thursday, April 10th at 2:30PM at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South, NYC.

title: A Maze of Identities for the Muslims of France
description: To enter the Rue du Bon Pasteur in the heart of this Mediterranean port is to leave France. Or rather, it is to leave a France still fixed in the imagination of many, a land where French is spoken and the traditions of a secular society are enforced.

title: Music in Review
description: POP

title: Clothes Can Be Flung Off, But Anxieties Still Remain
description: Dj Donn, an experimental dance troupe founded in Prague in 1996, shot Dance Theater Workshop's new international season, World Wide Works, off to a cannonball start.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, MARTIN H.
description: BECKER-Martin H. on April 7, 2003. Devoted husband of the late Florence, dear father of Scott and the late Glenn, loving grandfather of Michael. Graveside service Thursday, 10:30AM, at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, Long island.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The end game is the end of the regime, and that's a lot closer now than it was.''

title: Deaths of Journalists Bring Accusations and Concerns
description: The deaths of three journalists in American air or artillery attacks in Baghdad yesterday prompted accusations that the United States military was deliberately aiming at journalists and led at least two countries to call for reporters to evacuate the Iraqi capital because of the increased danger.

title: Worse Than Marie Antoinette: Let Them Eat Maggots
description: ''Empress of China''

title: North Korea's Neighbors Seek Crisis Role
description: Three months after North Korea announced its withdrawal from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, the United Nations Security Council will meet Wednesday to discuss the nation's nuclear program.

title: Dayne and Fassel Finally Connect
description: Running back Ron Dayne, who wants to be traded and has declined to participate in the Giants' off-season workout program, spoke with Coach Jim Fassel on Saturday after weeks of not returning his calls. Dayne cited personal problems for his absence, Fassel said, an explanation that did not abate Fassel's frustration.

title: A Chinese Palace Just West of Chinatown
description: AT this point in his infallible career, Jean-Georges Vongerichten resembles a studio head as much as he does a chef. Over the last 12 years, he and his longtime partner, Phil Suarez, have displayed an uncanny knack for developing an appealing, innovative culinary idea, packaging it attractively and putting it in the right spot. Stylish and hip, with an enviable reputation for high quality, his restaurants have the cachet of a Miramax film. It helps that Mr. Vongerichten is a talented chef. But food is only one part of the complex, lucrative equation behind his small empire, now a dozen restaurants scattered around the world.

title: United and 5 Groups Agree on Concessions
description: United Airlines said yesterday that it had reached tentative agreements on concessions with five labor groups represented by the International Association of Machinists.

title: 2003 Masters Predictions
description: Times reporters Clifton Brown and Dave Anderson made their predictions for this year's top 3 at the Masters.

title: American Reining In Frequent-Flier Plan
description: American Airlines is raising the number of miles that members of its frequent-flier program need to accumulate before the miles can be redeemed for certain kinds of tickets. The required miles for those tickets will go up as much as 25 percent.

title: For a Range of Dishes, A Taste of Celery, No Strings Attached
description: Such a tiny leaf, so much flavor. Celery microgreens, hand-snipped as they sprout in Eli Zabar's greenhouses on East 91st Street, have the slightly bitter pungency and parsley-like aroma of full-grown celery. They're excellent in a chicken salad sandwich or in a lobster roll, as a garnish for potato salad and afloat in golden chicken soup. A one-ounce container -- about a cup of the greens -- is $2 at Eli's Manhattan and Eli's Vinegar Factory.

description: To the Editor:

title: Two Million Inmates, and Counting
description: The population of the nation's jails and prisons passed two million last year, for the first time in history. The United States has one of the highest incarceration rates in the world, and one that falls unevenly. An estimated 12 percent of African-American males between 20 and 34 are behind bars, more than seven times the rate for white men the same age. Our overflowing jails and prisons come at a high price, in dollars and in wasted lives.

title: Ex-Grey Executive Pleads Guilty to Charges
description: A former executive of Grey Worldwide in New York, part of the Grey Global Group, pleaded guilty yesterday in federal court in Manhattan as part of the Justice Department's antitrust investigation into the print production and advertising industries.

title: In Iraq Towns, Allegiances Shift Quickly to Winning Side
description: KUMAIT, Iraq, April 9  In the center of this rural village near the border with Iran, an American colonel was talking with three sheiks.

title: Samuel N. Antupit, 71; Designed Magazines
description: Samuel N. Antupit, art director for more than 100 magazines and newspapers and the designer of books by artists like Roy Lichtenstein, Alex Katz and Barbara Kruger, died on Saturday in Seattle. He was 71.

title: Men and Music of Another Time and Another War
description: His hair is silvery now, his steps slower than in the early days at the Great Lakes Naval Station, where he played the saxophone as a young Navy bandsman. But the soul-stirring sound of jazz from Von Freeman's tenor sax is still as smooth as Scotch.

title: No Neat Categories for the Casualties of War
description: DOHA, Qatar, April 9  The effort to number the dead on the Iraqi side in the war begins with a conundrum: who is a civilian and who is a combatant?

title: G.M. AND BMW TO ANNOUNCE JOINT VENTURE ON FUEL CELLS
description: General Motors and BMW plan to announce today a joint venture to develop liquid hydrogen as a fuel for cars, a person close to the plan said yesterday. Hydrogen is used to power fuel cells, a clean power system that President Bush has envisioned as replacing gasoline-powered cars in future generations. G.M. and BMW have developed fuel cell prototypes, and BMW has developed other prototypes with internal combustion engines that run on hydrogen instead of gasoline. The two companies said they planned to start selling affordable vehicles powered by fuel cells by 2010. Danny Hakim (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the reluctance of most news media to show the bloodiest images of the war in Iraq misstated the title of a magazine editor who declined to publish a photograph of the charred head of an Iraqi soldier during the Persian Gulf War of 1991. The editor, Daniel Okrent, was executive editor of Life, not managing editor.

title: 2 Companies Said to Agree To Settle Suits on Emissions
description: Alcoa and Archer Daniels Midland have agreed to settle federal air pollution complaints by upgrading smelters and other factories at a cost the government estimates at $700 million, one of the companies and people familiar with the case said today.

title: Films Flee the Loop, but Chicago Fights Back
description: If Hollywood were to make a movie about the film industry here, it would chronicle the making of ''My Big Fat Greek Wedding,'' set in Chicago's Greek neighborhoods, and ''Chicago,'' the musical set in its namesake city. But it would be shot in Toronto.

title: Some Iraqis Are Grateful, But Still Wary of U.S. Plans
description: President Saddam Hussein's agents were working until the last moment.

title: A Caterer Goes From TV To Just Tea
description: When Jayne Harkness, a fashion consultant, decided to have friends over for lunch, she first called Debbie Samuelson. Ms. Samuelson, a former television and music producer, owns Verith, a catering company that specializes in teas. She filled bento boxes with smoked salmon sushi, tea-smoked chicken, fresh sesame tofu and summer rolls, with traditional Japanese confections for dessert. And a choice of teas, of course. Ms. Samuelson takes her own teapots and cups to her jobs. She also offers Moroccan and French tea menus. She will serve a classic English tea, too, but prefers not to. ''Everybody does that,'' she said. Most of her teas start at about $50 a person. For information: (212) 366-4623 or www.verithe.com.

title: Study Abroad, Nail-Biting at Home
description: Lindsay Enders, a biology major at Earlham College, is thoroughly excited about her plans to study in Kenya starting in August.

title: Sharing, Alaska-Style
description: Though most Americans don't believe this war is about oil, much of the rest of the world does. How the United States handles Iraq's oil after the war is therefore crucial. For guidance, America might look to its experiences in Japan after World War II and -- perhaps more surprisingly -- in Alaska in the 1970's.

title: Israeli Missiles Kill 7, Including a Hamas Leader, in Gaza City
description: Israeli aircraft fired five missiles into a Gaza City neighborhood tonight, killing at least 7 people, including a leader of Hamas and a 14-year-old bystander, and wounding 47 others, witnesses and Palestinian hospital officials said.
