description: Assessment

title: Palestinian Premier Faces Competing Demands Over Cabinet
description: The new Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, is battling to form a government as he faces wide-ranging demands from fellow Palestinians, including his boss, Yasir Arafat.

title: Senate Rolls a Pork Barrel Into War Bill
description: The hour was late, the war in Iraq was raging, and members of the Senate simply wanted to pass the $80 billion bill to pay for the war and go home for the night. In their haste, many senators never realized last week that they were also voting to send $10 million to a research station at the South Pole that had had a hard winter.

title: MUTOMBO DISCUSSES STATUS
description: Nets center Dikembe Mutombo met with his coach, Bryon Scott, and the team president, Rod Thorn, before practice yesterday as both sides expressed their concerns over Mutombo's frustration about his limited playing time.

title: Plea by Man Who Met bin Laden
description: A man who said he had two one-on-one meetings with Osama bin Laden a few months before the Sept. 11 terror attacks pleaded guilty today to aiding Al Qaeda, the terrorist organization.

title: Bush Sees Aid Role Of U.N. as Limited In Rebuilding Iraq
description: President Bush pledged today to grant the United Nations a ''vital role'' in postwar Iraq, but defined that principally as providing food, medicine and aid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINLAYSON, JOHN LATHROP
description: FINLAYSON-John Lathrop. Of Greenwich, CT, on April 7, 2003, at Kings Street Nursing Home. Born in Milwaukee in 1928, he was a graduate of The University of Illinois, and The Wharton School of Business. Mr. Finlayson served in The U.S. Army Corp of Engineers in Korea during that conflict. He started a long business career with Cargill, Inc., in 1953. He became a grain industry spokesman on major issues and is a Past President of The North American Export Grain Association. In 1994 he retired as Chairman of The Board of Louis Dreyfus Corp. Mr. Finlayson was an avid private pilot and based his airplane at Westchester County Airport. He held instrument and instructor ratings in single and multi engine aircraft. He is survived by his wife, Carrie, his two sons, Douglas, of Los Angeles, and Raleigh, of Boston, and his sister, Ann, of Warwick, NY. He is predeceased by a third son, Stuart, in 1997. Services will be private and the family suggests donations in lieu of flowers to: Greenwich Hospital, 5 Perry Ridge Rd, Greenwich, CT 06830 or Greenwich Library, 101 West Putnam Avenue, Greenwich CT, 06830, or a charity of your choice.

title: Doing Battle for Buildings
description: On a traditional battlefield, the goal is to seize territory, but in urban warfare, government buildings, palaces and other multi-story structures become the quarry. Every building and every situation is different, but as allied forces march through Baghdad, there are some standard tactics and equipment that they are likely to use.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: CONTRACTOR GUILTY OF ENDANGERMENT A building contractor and his company were convicted of reckless endangerment yesterday in connection with a building collapse that killed one worker and severely injured three others last year. The contractor, Michael Tam, 49, owner of the Tamco Corporation, was found guilty by a jury in State Supreme Court and faces up to a year in jail and a $1,000 fine when he is sentenced. His company faces a $1,000 fine. Mr. Tam was acquitted of second-degree manslaughter in the death of Antonio Romano, 41, a Mexican immigrant who was crushed by concrete blocks and other debris on May 16 while renovating a five-story town house on East 61st Street. Prosecutors said that Mr. Tam knew that the building was not secure. (AP)

title: FIDELITY INVESTMENTS IN DEAL FOR UBS UNIT
description: Fidelity Investments, the mutual fund company owned by FMR, said yesterday that it would acquire the United States securities-processing unit of UBS A.G. to add new sources of revenue as fees from managing money decline. The Correspondent Service Corporation of UBS processes trades and keeps records for other brokers. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The purchase, Fidelity's biggest, will nearly double its roster of brokerage customers. Fidelity is diversifying amid a three-year stock market slump that contributed to a 39 percent drop in profit last year.

title: Anatomy of the Chad Morton Debacle, According to the Jets' General Manager
description: Jets General Manager Terry Bradway compared the aftermath of an arbitrator's decision to award kick returner Chad Morton to the Redskins to the feeling he has after the Jets lose a game they are supposed to win. But Bradway defended the Jets' handling of Morton's contract yesterday, saying they are exploring their options to contest the decision.

title: Cardinal Seeks Citizenship For Noncitizens In U.S. Forces
description: Saying ''there is something terribly wrong with our immigration policies if it takes death on the battlefield to earn citizenship,'' Cardinal Roger M. Mahony has urged President Bush to award immediate citizenship to all immigrant troops serving in the Persian Gulf.

title: Woods Hopes His Game Will Do All His Talking
description: The subject was raised by different people in different ways, but the answers were familiar. Tiger Woods has come to Augusta National Golf Club this week to make history, not to make waves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUSIKAR, SAM
description: MUSIKAR-Sam. Artist, resident of Ardsley, NY, lifetime New Yorker, passed away April 6, 2003, at 79.

title: Arabs Shocked, Relieved at Baghdad's Fall
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 9 - It was a day of raw emotion across the Arab world, a historic day with elation, sadness, disbelief, anger and shock all blending as the government of Saddam Hussein seemed to come crashing down with barely a whimper. The moment was marked not as in previous decades by a coup and glorious anthems booming out of the radio, but by American troops, foreigners, pulling down a statue in a main Baghdad traffic circle.

title: Two Start-Ups Aim to Take On Cisco and Juniper
description: Two Silicon Valley start-ups plan to introduce products on Wednesday that they say will make it less expensive for Internet and telephone companies to route their data traffic.

title: Corrections
description: A review in Weekend on Friday about ''Camp,'' part of the New Directors/New Films series, misstated the given name of an actor. As shown in the picture caption and the credits listing, he is Daniel Letterle, not David.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Terminal Planned
description: The Russian oil company Surgutneftegaz said it planned to build a $400 million oil products terminal near St. Petersburg to help accommodate its burdgeoning oil exports. Vladimir Bogdanov, the company's chief executive, was quoted by the Reuters news agency as saying the terminal will ship 150,000 barrels of oil products a day by the end of next year. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Matsui's Bat Warms Hearts of Yankees

MATTHEW'S MONASTERY, Iraq, April 9  He came to this 1,600-year-old monastery 16 years before Saddam Hussein took power and has lived through military coups, droughts, two wars and now an American invasion. The union, the International Association of Bridge, Structural, Ornamental and Reinforcing Iron Workers, did not heed the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s call for unions to withhold endorsements until a majority of the labor federation's members had agreed on a candidate. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, ANNETTE R. (DICKIE)
description: KAUFMAN - Annette R. (Dickie). Age 96 on April 8, 2003. One of a kind with a very big heart. Always giving to others, kind and generous from the bottom of her heart. A dynamic person, retired as a prominent milliner with Hattie Carnegie and Henri Bendel. She adored life and was very much loved by all who knew her. Mother of the late Grace Shelton. Survived by her grandchildren, Julie and Tom and her greatgrandchildren Spencer and Cole. There are no words to describe how much she will be missed. She will always have a special place in all our hearts. Graveside service Sunday April 13th at 11:15 AM at Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY. The family will receive Sunday from 3-5 PM at her home.

title: A Refuge of Orchids
description: In the lobby and concourse of 30 Rockefeller Plaza, it looks like ''Bring Your Orchid to Work Day.'' The public spaces of that busy building are filled with astonishing floral displays created for the 23rd New York International Orchid Show, and will be through the weekend. The indifference of an ordinary lunch hour slips aside, and people pause in front of one elaborate arrangement, one summit of extraordinary blooms after another. Only the true orchid aficionados look on with any discretion. The other people in the crowd simply gaze in awe, whether they are gardeners or not. ''I never knew these things existed,'' said one stunned young man, who might have had trouble telling a sunflower from a rose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YANNOPOULOS, KONSTANTI NOS DINO
description: YANNOPOULOS - Konstanti nos Dino on April 6, 2003, of Philadelphia. Loving husband of Marguerite (nee Willauer). Father of Sotorius Yannopoulos and Elsa Spaulding. Grandfather of Lucas and Christine Spaulding. Great grandfather of Elsa and Pablo Spaulding. Son of the late Admiral S. Yannopoulos and Elsa (Thiele). Also survived by a step daughter, Linda Maria Gendron. He was director of the Academy of Vocal Arts in Philadelphia, head of the Opera Department at the Curtis Institute and principle stage director at the Metropolitan Opera in New York. Relatives and friends are invited to his memorial service Wednesday, May 14, 10AM at St. George's Cathedral, 256 South 8th St, Philadelphia, PA. An additional memorial service will be held Thursday, May 15, 3:30PM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave, NYC. Donations in Mr. Yannopoulos' name may be made to your favorite charity. Contact Oliver Bair Funeral Home, Upper Darby, PA.

The company said that sales in the United States were strong, despite fears that some Americans might boycott French products like Cognac and Champagne because of France's stance over the Iraq war. description: Citing the slack global economy and the climbing cost of sales incentives in the United States, DaimlerChrysler said it would be difficult to meet its profit targets for 2003, though it has not given up hope. The company aims to exceed last year's operating profit of $6.2 billion, driven in part by a projected $2 billion profit at Chrysler. But with Chrysler's sales in the United States down 6.2 percent so far this year, the chairman, Jrgen E. Schrempp, above, said, ''it has become much more difficult to reach the targets we have set ourselves.'' Mark Landler (NYT)

Orders fell 9.6 percent in February from January. Despite the steeper-than-expected decline, orders are still on track to rise in the first quarter. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: U.S. STEEL SAYS IT WILL CUT JOBS IF IT ACQUIRES RIVAL
description: The U.S. Steel Corporation said it would cut 5,700 jobs, or about 20 percent of the work force of the combined companies, if it won a bid for the National Steel Corporation over a rival, the AK Steel Holdings Corporation. U.S. Steel, North America's biggest steel maker, won approval for the job cuts as part of a tentative labor contract announced yesterday with the United Steelworkers of America. The union is still negotiating with AK Steel, which had until midnight to reach its own labor contract, a condition of the acquisition agreement. National Steel and the bankruptcy judge have said they prefer AK Steel's $1.13 billion offer to U.S. Steel's $950 million bid, but the union objects to AK Steel's three-year lockout of workers at a plant in Ohio.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BELGIUM: EASTWARD HO! The Parliament of the European Union endorsed the bloc's historic expansion eastward, overwhelmingly supporting membership for Poland, Lithuania, Estonia, Latvia, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovenia, Slovakia, Malta and Cyprus. The expansion is to take effect on May 1, 2004. The union currently has 15 members. The newcomers were told to fix remaining problems in fighting corruption and protecting minority rights and all 25 nations were urged to show "a stronger sense of solidarity," a reference to the gaping rift within Europe over Iraq. (AP)

title: Brooklyn Sex Harassment Suit Is Settled for $5.4 Million
description: A Brooklyn hospital has agreed to pay more than $5.4 million to settle complaints by dozens of female employees that a doctor sexually harassed them during pre-employment physical examinations.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: High Court Upholds Borrowing Method
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court yesterday upheld the state's increasingly common practice of long-term borrowing to finance major projects like sports arenas and, most recently, the $180 million redevelopment of Camden. The practice was challenged by a mayor in northern New Jersey who argued that the method violated the constitutional requirement that long-term borrowing be approved by the voters. The state has sidestepped the requirement by establishing authorities and making contracts with them to repay their bonds. The court's 4-to-3 decision approved that method, reasoning that the state does not guarantee the debt and thus does not obligate taxpayers. Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERGER, DR. BERNARD
description: STEINBERGER-Dr. Bernard. Steinberger, Bernard, MD. OB/GYN, DOG, FACS, ACOG, AMA, 78, of Highland Beach, FL, passed away on April 8, 2003. Best friend and most deeply beloved husband of Sandy Berkowitz - Steinber ger. Devoted father to Dr. Robert, Carl, Joshua and Paul. Grandfather of Michelle and Amanda. Loving and loved stepfather to Jill and Jay Glasser, David Forrest and Glen Berkowitz, and stepgrandfather to Max, Zachary, and Richard Glasser. Born on October 22, 1924 to Jack Steinberger and Mollie Kirschenbaum, in Brooklyn, NY. Brother of Marvin Steinberger (deceased). World War II Vet, 2nd Lieutenant, US Airforce. Dr. Steinberger graduated from Columbia Medical School, and SUNY Downstate Medical Center '51. Interned '51-'52 Jewish Hospital, Brooklyn, NY. '52-'55 Resident OB/GYN Maimonides Medical Center, Brooklyn, NY. Cons. Emeritus KHH, St. Joseph's-St. John's Hospital, Far Rockaway, NY. He retired in 1990 from Maimonides Medical Center and St. John's. He was a wonderful, caring doctor who was vigorously involved in the total care of his patients, and will always be remembered as a dedicated and compassionate practitioner of medicine. He will be deeply missed and remembered with love by his families, friends, and everyone he touched. In his memory donations may be made to: The Dr. Bernard Steinberger National Fragile-X-Foundation, 4408 Intracoastal Drive, Highland Beach, FL. 33487. Funeral Sunday, April 13, 2003 at 12 noon from Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York.

title: Rending Pork From the War Bill

Dozens of non-war items were inserted into the $80 billion measure at the last minute, as the forget-the-deficit mentality ran shamelessly out of control. Pork, not war, is the only common denominator linking boons for the salmon industry in Alaska, a leaky dam in New Hampshire, business protection for a cargo deliverer, feed subsidies for catfish farmers, a senator's election-year franking privileges and much more costly fine print.

description: THE first management conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies to be held in New Orleans is shaping up as neither big nor easy, mostly because of a dearth of les bons temps.

title: 2 Allies to Prod Bush on Plan For the Mideast
description: With war beginning to wind down in Iraq, the foreign ministers of France and Britain agreed today on the urgent need for a new diplomatic initiative to end the conflict between Israel and the Palestinians, a view that could put pressure on the Bush administration to move forward.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: JUSTICE FAULTS PRISON NUMBERS Too many people are behind bars in America, and prison terms are often too long, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy of the Supreme Court told Congress. As of June 30, 2.1 million people were in prison or jail, an increase of 2.8 percent from the year before. "Two million people in prison is just unacceptable," Justice Kennedy said in a hearing on the Supreme Court's budget. He criticized mandatory minimum sentences. (AP)

title: Home Sweet Home For Aircraft Carrier
description: The aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln, the world's largest warship, left the Persian Gulf today, entering the final phase of one of the longest deployments since the Vietnam War.

title: Last-Minute Setback for Northern Ireland Peace Deal
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 10  Hopes of a breakthrough in the deadlocked Northern Ireland peace process were dashed today when Prime Ministers Tony Blair of Britain and Bertie Ahern of Ireland had to cancel a joint appearance here because of last minute objections by Sinn Fein, the political party of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Success for Brazil Despite Naysayers
description: As the government of President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva passed its 100th day in office this week, the specters of economic calamity that his election had raised for foreign investors -- debt default, a sinking currency and economic mismanagement -- seemed to be just that, shadows.

title: In Vintage Maps, a Japan Bygone Floats Lyrically Online
description: FOR half a century, a rare and extensive collection of historical Japanese maps spanning hundreds of years have been stored in the East Asian Library at the University of California, revealing their secrets only to those few who had received permission to handle them. Now, through state-of-the-art imaging technology, anyone can view these fragile maps online, at www.davidrumsey.com/japan.

title: Military and C.I.A. Searching Baghdad for Hussein and His Sons or Their Bodies
description: Besieged by reports and rumors on the whereabouts of Saddam Hussein, a formerly covert intelligence operation in Baghdad turned into a wide-open manhunt today as military and C.I.A. teams raced through barely secured neighborhoods of the Iraqi capital searching for any sign of Mr. Hussein, his two sons and other leaders of the Baath Party.

title: Suit Accuses Toyota Of Bias in Lending
description: A lawsuit was filed in San Francisco yesterday accusing the financing unit of Toyota Motor of discriminating against black and Hispanic car buyers in setting the interest rates on their dealer-arranged loans.

title: Wedeman: 'Little Resistance' in Kirkuk
description: (CNN) -- On the northern front of the war in Iraq, Kurdish forces swept into the oil town of Kirkuk, apparently facing minimal resistance.

title: A Closer Look at Scandinavia Finds More Than Teak and Saunas
description: With the ongoing popularity of Scandinavian design, nobody needs another picture of an Aalto vase or a Marimekko print. But two books published this month each have a point of difference. ''Scandinavian Living'' by Magnus Englund and Chrystina Schmidt (Ryland Peters and Small, $27.50) visits the homes of designers like Eero Aarnio and Finn Juhl. They are well respected for a reason: they know domestic virtue when they see it, as these interiors prove.

title: Is It Greenwich Or Stamford? Lay Your Head On Either Side
description: Gerald Porricelli walks his one-acre property here, showing off a lovingly renovated carriage house that could easily be featured in the upscale Greenwich magazine that so many of his neighbors read. Only one problem. Greenwich now says that he does not live in Greenwich, and that as long as his pillow is on the Stamford side of the border, that is where he should vote.

title: Another Championship for UConn Women Brings Out the Fans
description: They waited two hours in wet snow to meet the airplane. Then they caravanned to the home court here for the victory rally, with paw-printed faces and toy husky dogs pinned to their caps, shaking banners that said, ''I wanna be just like you!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREIZEN, DR. DAVID
description: DREIZEN-Dr. David. Newmark and its partners would like to express their condolences to Michael Dreizen and his family for the loss of Dr. David Dreizen, father and grandfather. Our prayers and sympathy are with you in this time of need. Newmark & Company Real Estate, Inc.

title: Tearing Loose as a New Power Arrives at the Ruins of Babylon
description: Atop the site of ancient Babylon on the edge of this city, American soldiers walked today through a palace built by Saddam Hussein, a spectacle of grandiosity with several hundred thousand square feet of fine marble, paneled wood and 360 degree ceiling murals.

title: Frivolous No More: Deco Draws More Bids Than Indulgent Smiles
description: The Paris Exhibition of 1925 introduced a style then known as Modern or Art Moderne. ''But not Art Deco, which was coined in 1966,'' said Ghislaine Wood, curator of ''Art Deco: 1910-1939,'' an exhibition of 300 objects at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, which runs through July 20. In France, the style involved luxury furniture inlaid with woods and metals by designers like Jacques-mile Ruhlmann. The style spread to England, where Clarice Cliff designed the Sunray vase in 1929, above right, part of the show, and later evolved into streamlined skyscrapers and objects with Egyptian motifs. In the middle of the last century, ''Art Deco was seen as frivolous,'' Ms. Wood said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Chirac Urges Nation Guard Against Bias
description: President Jacques Chirac called on the French authorities to use ''the greatest firmness'' in dealing with racist and religious attacks, after heightened tensions in France between Muslims and Jews. Muslims have complained of greater hostility and aggression against them since the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks in the United States. Jews have denounced a rising wave of anti-Semitic incidents, which have intensified in recent months with Israel's crackdown on Palestinian militants and the war in Iraq. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Microsoft Sues Lucent Over Patents
description: Microsoft, the world's biggest software maker, has filed a lawsuit seeking to invalidate six patents owned by Lucent Technologies. Lucent, which makes computer networking gear and is the largest maker of telephone equipment in the United States, has sued Dell Computer and Gateway over the inventions, which include color memory, video-search functions and a method for controlling a computer with a stylus. Microsoft says Dell and Gateway want the software maker to reimburse them for any damages they have to pay as a result of the suits. A Lucent licensing agent called ThinkFire has also sent letters to Microsoft, saying 16 Lucent patents are ''crucial to the current and planned product offerings of Microsoft.'' Microsoft wants a judge to rule that its products do not infringe the six patents in the Dell and Gateway suits. Alternatively, the suit seeks a ruling that the patents are invalid or unenforceable. Microsoft is waging its patent dispute with Lucent as it defends its intellectual property in antitrust litigation with the government and competitors. A Lucent spokesman, John Skalko, said the company had no comment on the federal lawsuit, which was filed on Tuesday in San Diego.

title: In Practice; No Holds Barred for a Roving Office
description: FOR the frequent business traveler, the need to stay connected to the office and home is often paramount, and the cost of technology may be no object if it can provide a competitive edge.

title: Microsoft to Allow Partners To Alter Some Source Code
description: Microsoft announced yesterday that it would allow its industry partners to modify and then redistribute the underlying programming code used in cellphones, hand-held computers, television set-top boxes and other small devices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLIFKA, SYLVIA
description: SLIFKA-Sylvia. The Board and staff of the American Friends of the Israel Museum and the Israel Museum, Jerusalem are deeply saddened by the death of longtime Board member, friend and supporter Sylvia Slifka. Our heartfelt condolences to Alan and to Barbara and the entire family. Barbara Lane, Hon. Pres., AFIM James S. Snyder Anne & Jerome Fisher Dir., IM

description: Rupert Murdoch's begging days are over.

title: Vaccine Liability Compromise Collapses
description: A bipartisan compromise on vaccine liability legislation, negotiated by the Senate majority leader, collapsed this morning when vaccine makers objected, prompting the chairman of a Senate committee to cancel consideration of the bill.

title: Mob Kills Islamic Cleric
description: NAJAF, Iraq, April 10  A prominent Islamic cleric, newly returned from exile and cooperating with the American forces that are nominally in control of this city, was killed by an angry mob here today at one of Shiite Islam's holiest shrines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, JACOB (JACK)
description: STEIN - Jacob (Jack) of Brooklyn, NY died Tuesday, April 8 at the age of 90. Jack was a Navy Veteran of WWII, retired attorney, former secretary of Manhattan Beach Jewish Center, past commander and associate chairman for senior citizens of the Jewish War Veterans. He is survived by his loving wife of 63 years, Mathilda, his sons Mark and Allan and numerous grandchildren and great grandchildren. Viewing Thursday, 12 noon at Kehila Chapels, 60 Brighton 11 St, Brooklyn followed by funeral services at 1pm.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Disaster Plans For Chemical Plants
description: A bill to require chemical plants in New York to draw up disaster preparedness plans was introduced in the State Assembly yesterday. A Senate version is due to be introduced this week. More than 100 chemical plants in the state house hazardous substances and may be vulnerable to terrorist attack. Under the bill, written plans would be sent to the state's Office of Public Security, which could order increased perimeter security or background checks of plant employees. Assemblyman Michael N. Gianaris, a Democrat who represents a Queens district anchored in Astoria, introduced the bill and is urging a similar plan for power plants. Al Baker (NYT)

title: In Debate, Democrats Seek To Focus on Domestic Issues
description: Candidates in the large Democratic presidential field clashed tonight over the justification for the war in Iraq and the role the United States should now play in that country's reconstruction. Their debate signaled a postwar phase of a contest that has to date been overshadowed by the fighting in the Persian Gulf.

title: W.N.B.A. Cancels Tryout Camp; Draft in Doubt
description: Having already canceled the predraft tryout camp for college players, which had been scheduled to begin today, the Women's National Basketball Association refused to say yesterday whether it would hold its draft next Wednesday as planned.

title: A Bountiful Trip Down Daffodil Lane
description: IT is dangerous following spring down the highway. I almost rear-ended a car on I-95, west of Washington, because I was stealing glances at the amalanchiers, what old-timers call shadblow -- shrubs, covered in white, marching down the middle of the median strip. (Poor New York -- it had trees covered in white on Monday, but that was snow.) Just over the Virginia line, I spied the soft pink flowers of cherry trees and the tiny wine-red blossoms of the redbuds, clinging to bare branches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, DAVID G.
description: GRAY-David G. Passed away peacefully on April 9, 2003. He was a retired partner of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett. A kind and generous soul survived by his wife, Diane; son Neil; brother Larry and many nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Mary Manning-Walsh Home, 1339 York Ave., New York, NY 10021.

description: ARKIN-Tessie. April 10, 1912November 22, 2000. Happy Birthday Mom! Your presence is always with me. I love you. Joan

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline Orders Boeings
description: Boeing beat its rival, Airbus, for an order worth as much as $2.25 billion for 45 single-aisle jetliners from All Nippon Airways, Asia's No. 2 airline. The planes will replace a third of the carrier's fleet, including 25 Airbus A320 jetliners and 27 older 737's, making Boeing its sole supplier of single-aisle planes, the airline said. That generates savings as the airline will be able to have pilots and mechanics working on a single type of aircraft.

title: Focus Shifts to Northern Iraq, U.S. Says Baghdad 'Still an Ugly Place'
description: BAGHDAD, April 10  Several hundred Kurdish fighters under the command of 100 American special force fighters took control of the oil town of Kirkuk today as the focus of the American campaign switched to the northern part of Iraq.

title: A Self-Powered DNA Computer Redefines Small
description: EXPERIMENTAL computers that calculate using DNA rather than electronics have many promising properties. To start with, they are exceptionally tiny. About one trillion DNA computers would fit in a single drop of water. Yet their storage capacity is potentially vast. A single gram of DNA holds about as much information as one trillion compact discs.

title: Number of Iraqis Killed May Never Be Determined
description: The effort to number the dead on the Iraqi side in the war begins with a conundrum: who is a civilian and who is a soldier?

title: INSIDE
description: 11 Die in Afghanistan Error

title: Globetrotting Traveler Infected With SARS
description: HONG KONG, April 10 - In a striking example of how far and fast a virus can be carried in an era of international jet travel, health officials announced here tonight that a man infected with a newly discovered respiratory disease had flown from Hong Kong to Munich, Barcelona, Frankfurt, London, Munich again, Frankfurt again and then back to Hong Kong before entering a hospital.

title: Behind the A B C's, a Buzz Saw; Ambitious Schools Deputy Shakes Up the Curriculum
description: The rumor bounced all over town last month: Diana Lam, the new deputy chancellor with the onerous job of overhauling instruction in New York City's 1,200 schools, had resigned.

title: The Web By Modem, A Bit Faster
description: THESE young people today, with their loud music and cable modems! They're too young to remember the olden days, when it wasn't just your PC and your Windows version that became obsolete every other year; it was also your modem. Modems that ran at 9.6 kilobits per second gave way to 14.4K models, and then to 28.8 and 33.6. In all, Americans spent more than 15 years trying to keep up with the Hayses.

title: Four Marines Said to Be Wounded in Suicide Bombing in Baghdad
description: Asuicide bomber seriously wounded four U.S. marines at a military checkpoint in Baghdad Thursday, a U.S. Marine officer said.

title: France Proposes Adoption of Plea Bargaining in Legal Overhaul
description: The French government today proposed a major overhaul of laws intended to fight organized crime, including for the first time a plan to allow American-style plea bargaining.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Borland Reports First-Quarter Net Loss
description: The Borland Software Corporation, a maker of software to customize computer programs, reported yesterday a first-quarter net loss of as much as 27 cents a share, a contrast to net income of 6 cents a share a year earlier. Sales rose less than forecast, to a range of $72 million to $75 million, Borland said in a statement on its Web site after a preliminary review. The company blamed a weak global economy as customers canceled purchases in the quarter's final weeks. The company did not return calls seeking comment. Borland shares fell 69 cents, to $8.48, after earlier dropping to $8.02.

title: Law Requiring Drug Testing Of Welfare Parents Is Voided
description: The federal appeals court in Cincinnati has struck down a Michigan statute that required drug testing for parents who apply for or receive welfare benefits.

title: Internet via the Power Grid: New Interest in Obvious Idea
description: As cable, telephone and wireless companies compete to provide high-speed Internet access to homes, a new challenger is emerging based on a decidedly old technology.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Caterer Lowers Outlook
description: Sodexho Alliance, the world's second-largest caterer, trimmed its estimate for full-year revenue growth, citing stagnating economies and the war in Iraq. The French company's stock dropped 1.36 euros ($1.46) a share, to 19.69 euros, in Paris. Sales will probably grow 4 percent at most for the year ending Aug. 31, excluding acquisitions and currency swings, the company said. This was below an estimate of 4 percent to 6 percent. (Bloomberg News)

title: Robin Winks, 72, Scholar, Parks Advocate and Author
description: Robin W. Winks, a Yale scholar who combined a love of British imperial history with enthusiasm for open spaces and a consuming interest in international espionage and detective fiction, died on Monday in New Haven. He was 72.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: HIGH COURT UPHOLDS BORROWING METHOD The New Jersey Supreme Court yesterday upheld the state's increasingly common practice of long-term borrowing to finance major projects like sports arenas and, most recently, the $180 million redevelopment of Camden. The practice was challenged by a mayor in northern New Jersey who argued that the method violated the constitutional requirement that long-term borrowing be approved by the voters. The state has sidestepped the requirement by establishing authorities and making contracts with them to repay their bonds. The court's 4-to-3 decision approved that method, reasoning that the state does not guarantee the debt and thus does not obligate taxpayers. Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: Amid the Scenes of Joy, A Sight Less Welcome
description: A dismayed hush fell over Firdos Square in Baghdad yesterday as a United States marine pulled an American flag over the head of Saddam Hussein's statue like a gallows hood.

title: The Fall of Baghdad
description: The murderous reign of Saddam Hussein effectively ended yesterday as downtown Baghdad slipped from the grip of the Iraqi regime and citizens streamed into the streets to celebrate the sudden disintegration of Mr. Hussein's 24-year dictatorship. The scene in central Baghdad, where jubilant Iraqis and American marines collaborated in toppling a huge statue of Mr. Hussein, signaled that a complete American military victory in Iraq may be achieved within a matter of days, not months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASKELL, IRWIN
description: HASKELL - Irwin. Loving husband of Zelma Karen. Beloved father of Lloyd and Marla Rose. Dear brother of George. Cherished grandfather of William, Bennet and Hunter. Devoted father-inlaw of Mary Jean Haskell and David Kronish. Services today at 1:30, Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn (Ave M).

title: Bewailing Fate and the Gods in the Hills of Scotland
description: ''The Women of Lockerbie'' by Deborah Brevoort is a sincere attempt to create a modern tragedy in the classical Greek mode. Like the Greeks, Ms. Brevoort has based her tale on a historical horror and used it to burrow into the psyches of the play's individuals and into the parameters of society.

title: Indy 500 Receives Fewest Entries Ever
description: Thirty-four sets of cars will compete for the 33 starting spots in the 87th running of the Indianapolis 500, the fewest number of entries since the Indy Racing League began in 1996.

title: A Specialist in Trompe l'Oeil Is Stirred Anew by Semigloss
description: Paul Rosenfeld specializes in trompe l'oeil, stenciling, glazing and gilding. But because business has been slow, he said, ''I'm getting in touch with my roots as a house painter.'' Thus his ''recession special'': hire him to paint the interior of your house, and he will glaze one room (a foyer or a similar space) for free. The cost would usually be $500 more. He charges $1,000 to paint a medium-size living room, 300 square feet, with two coats. He can be consulted on choosing colors, and he works in New York City and its suburbs; (845) 398-8942. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: A Voice Recognition Tool Frees Hands for Other Tasks
description: Long the holy grail of software development, voice recognition has proved a tricky feat, but developers have made enough progress in recent years to produce several low-priced options. The latest is the QPointer, which enables users to operate a PC without touching the mouse or even, in some models, the keyboard.

title: Executives See Weak U.S. Economy Over Next 6 Months
description: Chief executives of large companies  perhaps the most accurate group of economic forecasters recently  expect the American economy to remain weak over the next six months but to avoid a new recession, according to a survey released today.

title: U.S. Plan for Wall St. Firms Drops Provision for a Move
description: Federal regulators have recommended that companies critical to the nation's financial system should try to resume operations within hours of a disaster or terrorist attack. The regulators did not require that Wall Street firms move their operations out of Manhattan, as many executives and city officials had feared.

title: Profits Exceeded Expectations at Yahoo in First Quarter
description: Better-than-expected advertising sales, along with steady growth of its fee-based businesses, helped Yahoo earn better-than-expected profits in the first quarter.

title: U.S. to Move Its Army Headquarters in South Korea Out of Seoul
description: American and South Korean negotiators agreed today to move the United States Army command headquarters out of Seoul as soon as possible.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SINGAPORE: CHURCH SUSPENDS CONFESSIONS The Roman Catholic Church has told priests across the island not to hear individual confessions for fear that the disease SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome, could be transmitted in the closed confines of the confessional booth. For the Easter season priests will grant a "general absolution," said Archbishop Nicholas Chia. Churchgoers have also been advised not to hold each other's hands, and communion wafers are to be placed by priests into the palms of parishioners rather than directly onto their tongues. Eight people have died of the disease in Singapore, including a Catholic pastor who visited a victim on her sickbed. Seth Mydens (NYT)

title: Cheers, Tears and Looting in Capital's Streets
description: Saddam Hussein's rule collapsed in a matter of hours today across much of this capital city as ordinary Iraqis took to the streets in their thousands to topple Mr. Hussein's statues, loot government ministries and interrogation centers and to give a cheering, often tearful welcome to advancing American troops.

title: Winemaker Shows Higher Sales and Profits
description: Constellation Brands Inc., the world's largest winemaker, said yesterday that fiscal fourth-quarter profit climbed as sales of its high-end wines and imported beer and spirits rose and its British business grew.

title: Joy in Baghdad, Arab Consternation and the Mystery of Saddam Hussein
description: American military commanders did not call it the fall of Baghdad, but the virtually unhindered entrance of American troops into the heart of the city to the cheers of local Iraqis yesterday clearly represented a turning point in the war. Troops found no sign of a surviving Iraqi government, nor of Saddam Hussein and his sons. Like people all over the world who watched live broadcasts of jubilant crowds welcoming the troops, American officials who monitored the images from Washington rejoiced. As those running the war cautioned that much work remained, officials turned their focus to what will happen after the war ends.

title: Star Data Lights Their Way
description: LINDA LAGUNZAD and Adam Wise were baffled. The two students, high school seniors from West Orange, N.J., could not figure out what caused the ripples in the Crab Nebula. To figure it out, they came up with the ''sprinkler theory.''

title: Bush and Blair Take Their Message Directly to the Iraqis
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  The United States and Britain began a broad media campaign in Iraq today with speeches by President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain beamed from an American aircraft to televisions nationwide.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Parish Principal Wins Pay Dispute
description: A Roman Catholic school principal who was removed from her school after accusing her former pastor of financial and sexual wrongdoing must be paid her salary and back pay by the Diocese of Brooklyn, a judge ruled yesterday. The principal, Barbara Samide, had accused the pastor, the Rev. John Thompson, of housing a male stripper in the rectory and of using parish funds to lavish gifts on him. In September, Father Thompson pleaded guilty to stealing nearly $100,000 from the parish. Mrs. Samide has been on unpaid leave since the school year began. The judge, Duane A. Hart of State Supreme Court in Queens, left open the question of whether Mrs. Samide, who is still under contract, would resume her old job at St. Elizabeth's School in Ozone Park. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: PPL Will Sell Subsidiary To Investor Group
description: PPL Therapeutics, the Scottish company that helped clone Dolly the sheep, is selling its American subsidiary to an investor group led by the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center. The subsidiary, which is based in Blacksburg, Va., is developing medical treatments using stem cells and xenotransplantation, the transplanting of animal organs into people. The transaction illustrates the problems that companies pursuing such exotic technologies are having in raising money. PPL, which has been trying to sell the American unit for months, is essentially giving it away. The medical center, a well-known transplant center which has been working with PPL to develop xenotransplantation, formed the investor group to keep the research going. The investor group, which also includes Highmark Health Ventures Investment Fund of Pittsburgh and the venture arm of Fujisawa Pharmaceuticals of Japan, is putting $3.5 million into a new company, Regenecor Holdings. Andrew Pollack (NYT)

description: South-Central Los Angeles, the neighborhood that became infamous in recent years for riots, gang violence and poverty, is no more -- at least according to the Los Angeles City Council.

title: Daddy's Home, on the TV Screen, Direct From Baghdad
description: Like other military wives left waiting here, Deanna Simpson was up at 6 this morning, watching television coverage of Iraqis toppling a statue of Saddam Hussein with the help of a tank that people in town swear held a crew from the Marine Corps Ground-Air Combat Center here.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the linking of the drug PCP to a suspect in four killings in Brooklyn and Queens misstated the number of people hospitalized in New York City in 1997 because of PCP use. It was 248, not 348.

title: A War Like No Other Uses New 21st-Century Methods To Disable Enemy Forces
description: The march on Baghdad exemplifies 21st-century warfare, allied commanders and outside military experts say: swift, agile and decisive, employing overpowering technology to bring relentless violence to bear in many places at once.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, FRANZ
description: ROSENTHAL - Franz. The American Academy For Jewish Research expresses its profound sorrow over the death of its distinguished Fellow, Professor Franz Rosenthal, of Yale University. Prof. Rosenthal not only made an enormous contribution to the study of Islam, but simultaneously pursued interests in Aramaic and Jewish Studies, bridging both fields with his impressive erudition and intellectual curiosity. He will be sorely missed by his many colleagues and students. David Ruderman, President American Academy For Jewish Research

title: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Is Accused of Passing Secrets to Lover
description: A Chinese-American woman in Southern California who worked as an informer for the F.B.I. took numerous top-secret documents from her bureau handler, who was also her longtime lover, and she passed secrets on to Chinese government, officials said today.

title: FleetBoston, Rocked by Bad Loans, Seeks Stability as a Consumer Bank
description: Charles K. Gifford, chief executive of FleetBoston, is struggling to overcome his bank's past.

title: Police Stop Collecting Data on Protesters' Politics
description: When a series of large antiwar protests began nearly eight weeks ago, the New York Police Department started questioning hundreds of people arrested at the demonstrations about their prior political activity and recording the information in a database.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: BILL ON SAME-SEX COUPLES DIES IN COMMITTEE A legislative committee rejected a bill yesterday that would have extended the rights of marriage to same-sex couples and set up a domestic registry system. Opponents of the bill said it would have become a springboard to sanctioning gay and lesbian unions. The bill died on a 26-to-16 vote in the Joint Judiciary Committee. The committee vote was the first time that Connecticut lawmakers had voted specifically on extending rights and benefits to same-sex couples. Last year the Legislature passed a law allowing two people of either gender to legally designate each other to make medical decisions and end-of-life choices like organ donation and life support. (AP)

title: Yanks Roll Up Their Sleeves and Edge Twins
description: The arm that threw the final pitch of last night's Yankee game was not covered by a long sleeve. Neither was the arm that reached up to stab the final out. Juan Acevedo, the pitcher, and Erick Almonte, the shortstop, may have been the only ones at Yankee Stadium who did not mind the cold.

title: A Troubled Jockey Tries To Stay on the Right Path
description: The two very different sides of Norberto Arroyo Jr. had formed a most complex relationship. Even at the racetrack, which tends to be a hardscrabble place, owners and trainers have a hard time understanding how someone who is young and talented and comes across as articulate and gentlemanly can also have a violent side, wage fights with a pool stick and wind up in jail.

title: Furniture Forecast: Thawing Prices
description: SPIRITS were surprisingly good at the International Home Furnishings Market, the largest wholesale furniture expo in the world. Under budding dogwood trees, international news faded to a whisper. A headline in Furniture Today read ''War Causes Rug Delays,'' and analysts reminded retailers and buyers that despite a three-year slump in furniture sales, housing starts and existing home sales were up and interest rates were down, traditionally good signs for the furniture industry. ''We've got to get this war behind us so we can go out there and furnish those hundreds of thousands of new homes,'' Pat Norton, chairman of La-Z-Boy, said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Concrete Investor Set Back
description: The Swiss billionaire Thomas Schmidheiny is surrendering control of Holcim, the concrete company run by his family for 89 years, trying to rebuild investor confidence after an insider trading case and a decline in profit. Holcim is creating a single class of stock, cutting Mr. Schmidheiny's 54 percent voting stake in half, a spokesman, Roland Walker, said. Mr. Schmidheiny, who has amassed a $1.9 billion fortune, controls Holcim with 27 percent of the stock.

title: A High Point in 2 Decades of U.S. Might
description: WASHINGTON, April 9  The collapse of government authority in Baghdad, dramatized by the toppling of a colossal statue of President Saddam Hussein, constitutes the high-water mark for a new American determination to use the nation's military might to project its power around the world.

title: Leading Exile Figure Draws Mixed Reviews
description: A joyous Ahmad Chalabi held a rally yesterday in the town of Nasiriya in southern Iraq to spread the word of the collapse of Saddam Hussein's government, seizing the initiative as the most prominent Iraqi exile opposition leader to return to his country so far.

title: View From Ancient Monastery as Yet Another War Intrudes
description: He came to this 1,600-year-old monastery 18 years before Saddam Hussein took power and has lived through military coups, droughts, two wars and now an American invasion. So when strangers arrived today saying Baghdad had fallen, the placid face of Father Paulus, a blind 71-year-old monk, betrayed little emotion.

title: Two Yankee Iconoclasts Juxtaposed on the Piano
description: Carl Ruggles is often included alongside his friend Charles Ives in the pantheon of great Yankee iconoclasts, musical division. Yet performances of his works are woefully few, and recordings are hardly more plentiful.

description: To the Editor:

title: Zap a Foe, Surf the Web: Keys to Suit Your Software
description: It's often difficult to remember which key does what when you're playing a PC game; a key that fires a gun in one game may operate a flashlight in another. Ideazon's solution is its Zboard, which offers keyboard interfaces for specific games and other applications.

title: Fears in Turkey That Its Cyprus Problem Is Alienating Europe
description: Remarks by Turkey's president and prime minister provided fresh signs today of the frustration many Turkish leaders feel over the divided status of Cyprus and, more specifically, over the degree to which it may hamper Turkey's bid to join the European Union.

title: On College Basketball; In the End, No One Could Beat Taurasi
description: No team had ever won a women's N.C.A.A. basketball championship without a senior on the roster.

title: Security Council Averts Standoff on North Korea Nuclear Issue
description: The Security Council today stepped back from a potential standoff over North Korea's withdrawal from the treaty that prohibits it from developing nuclear weapons, as China signaled its openness to ''promote political dialogue'' and the United States eased off its pursuit of a formal statement of condemnation.

title: In Many Co-Ops, Ordering In Becomes 'Go Fetch'
description: AT any hour of the day, New Yorkers can order almost anything, from a bowl of beef noodles to a box of office supplies, and simply wait for the world to come to their high-rise apartments. Clothed or unclothed, all they need do is open the door a crack when the delivery guy arrives, thrust some money into his hands and retreat, unnoticed, to their sanctuaries in the sky.

title: Text: At the Pentagon
description: At a news conference yesterday at the Pentagon, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld and Gen. Richard B. Myers, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, discussed the collapse of Saddam Hussein's government, the remaining resistance in Iraq and other subjects. Following is a transcript from the session as recorded by Federal Document Clearing House Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCIARRA, DANIEL, M.D.
description: SCIARRA-Daniel, M.D. The faculty, staff, and students of Columbia University Health Sciences and the NewYorkPresbyterian Hospital mourn the loss of an esteemed colleague, mentor, and friend, Dr. Daniel Sciarra. An invaluable member of the Columbia Presbyterian community since 1948, Dr. Sciarra most recently served as professor of clinical neurology and as a neurologist at the New York Neurological Institute at NewYork-Presbyterian. In addition to giving five decades of service to Columbia Presbyterian as a teacher and clinician, Dr. Sciarra also founded the Neurological Institutes first fully funded clinical chair-the Sciarra Professorship in Clinical Neurology-in 1987, perpetuating his legacy of excellence in education and patient care. He was a graduate of Harvard University and Harvard Medical School. He is survived by his wife Lilo, children Dalen Cole, Lorraine, J. Daniel, Gina Louise and Michael Sciarra, and Chetra Kotzas, and six grandchildren, to whom we extend our most heartfelt sympathies. He will be deeply missed. Gerald Fischbach, M.D., Executive Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences and Dean of the Faculty of Medicine, Columbia University Herbert Pardes, M.D., President and Chief Executive Officer, NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Thomas Q. Morris, M.D., Vice President for Health Sciences and Vice Dean of the Faculty of Medicine, Columbia University Joseph Tenenbaum, M.D., Senior Associate Dean for Clinical Affairs, Columbia University

title: Biting Humor Set to Music
description: Songs of protest or advocacy are not the only means for musicians and their audiences to respond to national crises. There is also comedy. Outside vaudeville and the musical, however, songwriters who invoke laughter in times of economic or political duress have received little respect. But now a new crop of talented singer-comedians has emerged with hopes of changing this.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALANTER, WYNNE L.
description: GALANTER-Wynne L. The faculty and staff of NYU School of Medicine and the Department of Psychiatry extend our heartfelt condolences to our friend and colleague, Mark Galanter, M.D., on the death of his wife, Wynne Galanter, Ph.D. Since 1985 the late Dr. Galanter was a Clinical Instructor of Psychiatry and an outstanding member of the faculty. Our thoughts and prayers are with the Galanter family. Robert M. Glickman, M.D., Dean, NYU School of Medicine Robert Cancro, M.D., Chairman, Department of Psychiatry, NYU School of Medicine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, MARY AGNES
description: O'BRIEN-Mary Agnes. On April 8, 2003. Beloved daughter of the late Catherine and Dennis O'Brien. Funeral mass 11AM Friday at the Epiphany R.C. Church, Second Avenue and 22nd Street. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Modern Remembrances of Things Past
description: CENTRAL to Passover, which begins on Wednesday evening, is the retelling of the story of the Exodus from Egypt. "In fact it is a story of all people's flight to freedom," said Jean Rosensaft, the director of the museum at Hebrew Union College in Manhattan. "After all, `Let my people go' is universal."

title: Denver Judge Releases 2 Men Investigated for Terrorism Ties
description: In a rebuff to the government's detainment policies, a federal district judge in Denver has ordered the release of two Pakistanis held on immigration-related charges while the F.B.I. investigates them for possible links to terrorism.

title: Martin Loses Alltel To DDB Worldwide
description: The Alltel Corporation, the telecommunications company, yesterday named the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide as agency of record on its account, which had been handled by the Martin Agency in Richmond, Va., for the last four years. Billings were estimated at $70 million.

title: Hong Kong Balks at Wide Quarantines for Mystery Illness
description: HONG KONG, April 10  Despite growing international pressure to halt the spread of a new respiratory disease here, Hong Kong officials are strongly resisting the kind of broad quarantines that some countries have imposed, taking only another modest step today to control the movements of potentially infected people.

title: SPRINT PRESIDENT RESIGNS AMID TAX QUESTIONS
description: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that its president, Ronald LeMay, had stepped down after the board questioned his use of tax shelters set up by the company's auditor. Mr. LeMay, who joined Sprint in 1986, will provide consulting services for one year, the company said. Sprint did not disclose severance terms or name a successor. The departure leaves Sprint without a No. 2 executive three weeks after it named Gary Forsee as chief executive, replacing William Esrey. Mr. LeMay, who used shelters set up by the company auditor, Ernst & Young, joined Sprint's predecessor, the United Telephone System, as general counsel. Ten years later, he was named Sprint's president and chief operating officer.

title: Attention Now Shifts to the Role of the Kurds
description: The focus of the ground campaign in Iraq has now shifted northward to a string of cities still under Iraqi Army control: Saddam Hussein's hometown and power base, Tikrit, and the oil cities of Kirkuk and Mosul.

title: James D. Finley, 86, Textile Executive, Dies
description: James D. Finley, a textile executive who led the giant J. P. Stevens & Company for 14 years, steering it through some of the industry's most intense labor disputes, died on Saturday in Gulfstream, Fla. He was 86.

title: Isles Knock the Flash Out of the Senators
description: Aleksei Yashin left the arena tonight with a fat lower lip, but it seemed worth it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLLENBERGER, GERARD
description: WOLLENBERGER - Gerard, 71, on April 8, 2003, after a sudden short illness. Distinguished member of the New York bar for more than four decades. Survived by his brother, Lutz Wollenberger, his sister-in-law, Eva Wollenberger, his nephew, Neal Wollenberger (Ruby) and his nieces, Tina Wollenberger Calderon (Rafael) and Linda Wollenberger. Graveside service at 1 PM Friday, April 11, 2003 at Old Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, Queens, NY (718-528-1700).

description: With satisfaction, Gen. Al Jazar Al Ghoul, a fierce commander of Yasir Arafat's bodyguards, contemplated his candy-striped petunias.

description: Troops searching today for biological, chemical and radiation weapons in Iraq had another frustrating day as they toured four suspected sites in southern Iraq.

She is Deborah Senn, not Barbara.

title: Welfare Veto Is Overridden By Council
description: Over the veto of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the City Council passed legislation yesterday that would significantly soften the welfare-to-work policies that became New York City's trademark during the Giuliani administration.

title: Iraqis in the U.S. Celebrate Hussein's Seeming Downfall
description: Hundreds of Iraqis and Iraqi-Americans held an impromptu street celebration here today, chanting and cheering the seeming fall of President Saddam Hussein.

description: Proposed regulations to govern the way companies change to a controversial type of pension plan were assailed yesterday both by workers and corporate officials at a hearing by the Treasury Department.

description: From Israelis and Palestinians, the official response as American forces swarmed through Baghdad today was muted, in keeping with the carefully restrained approach of both sides to the war.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Club Capacity Called Overstated
description: A document from the remains of a West Warwick nightclub fire that killed 99 people implies that owners publicized a capacity above the club's legal limit, lawyers for potential litigants said. The lawyers say that in the document -- an unsigned contract between the club's owners, Jeffrey and Michael Derderian, and Great White, the band that played on the night of the fire -- the club was said to have a capacity of 550. Town officials have said the club could hold a maximum of 404 occupants. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Turkish Leaders Sending Military Observers to Kirkuk
description: URGUP, Turkey, April 10  Turkish leaders said today that they were sending military observers to monitor Kurdish forces in the Iraqi city of Kirkuk, while American officials worked to discourage Turkey from any steps more provocative than that.

description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: AT HOME WITH/Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Brad Hall; A House That Any Tree Would Hug
description: ''BUCKLE up,'' said Julia Louis-Dreyfus, punching a small square button in the hallway of her newly renovated beach house. Above her a vaulted skylight ribbed with steel slid open with a mechanical hum. ''How James Bond is that!'' she said, as sunlight and salt air poured in through an eight-foot-square opening.

description: To the Editor:

title: Senators Delay $80 Billion War Bill Over Special Interest Items
description: Talks to approve the $80 billion bill to pay for the Iraq conflict were postponed today after leading senators refused to attend, angry that the House will not accept the many pork-barrel and special interest items that the Senate has inserted into its version of the bill.

title: Tables, Cabinets And for the Venturous, A Kangaroo Throw
description: Judy Olson Dunne (above right), is an industrial designer who once designed toys. Now her playful spirit has led her to open a store called Butter and Eggs, which she describes as ''a collection of designs for the home that were not found everyplace else.'' The store offers cherry or walnut cabinets, bookcases and tables from a Northern Italian company, El Marangon, with expanding dining tables for $3,500 to $7,000, the more expensive ones with marquetry. Cabinets and armoires start at $2,700 and bookcases at $3,000, and beds are $3,000 to $6,000. Lloyd Loom Italia woven furniture, perfect for country living rooms and porches, is also available. Dining chairs start at $565 and armchairs at $1,050.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx Man Arrested In 7 Bank Robberies
description: A 21-year-old Bronx man was arrested yesterday in seven bank robberies in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, the police said. The man, Martin Pedro, of East 169th Street in the Bronx, was accused of robberies that occurred between August and January, the first and the last taking place at the same bank, Banco Popular, at 539 Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn. The other banks included Chase branches on Grand Street in Brooklyn and Westchester Avenue in the Bronx, Greenpoint Bank branches on Linden Boulevard in Queens and Fulton Street in Brooklyn, and an M&T Bank on Queens Boulevard in Queens. The police did not release information about the amount of money stolen, or where Mr. Pedro was arrested. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Dr. Frederic Lawrence Holmes, a historian of science and medicine at Yale, misstated the name of a university where he taught in the 1970's. It is the University of Western Ontario, not West Ontario.

title: A Right to Retaliate
description: To the Editor:

title: Far From the Cheering Crowds, Marines in 'Standby Mode'
description: WITH TASK FORCE TARAWA, near Qualat Sikur, Iraq, April 10  In Baghdad, a statue of Saddam Hussein toppled, and a great crowd cheered. Here, a dusty lug nut fell from a Humvee wheel to the sand with a mute puff, and no one said much of anything as the marine began loosening the next one.

Devoted father of Marc (with Andree) Frost & Glenn (with Kate) Newmark. Adored grandfather of Michael and Lauren Frost and Ethan and Amelia Newmark. Cherished brother of Ruth Weiser. Services Thursday April 10, 12 noon, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, N.Y.

title: American Air Attack Mistakenly Kills 11 Afghans
description: An American warplane mistakenly bombed a house in eastern Afghanistan today, killing 11 civilians and wounding one, a United States military spokesman said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Rev. Tandy Sloan, whose 19-year-old son, Pfc. Brandon U. Sloan, was killed in Iraq, misstated the name of the Cleveland suburb where the family had lived. It is Bedford Heights, not Bedford Hills.

title: Grief and Joy: Stark Contrast
description: It would be hard to imagine two more different dances than ''Elegy'' and ''Pegao,'' the two highlights of a program presented by the Alpha Omega Dance Company on Friday night at Aaron Davis Hall at City College. A woman grieves in ''Elegy,'' choreographed by Martial Roumain to music by Michael Wimberly. Donna Clark made the grief majestically stoical and imposing in her powerful performance of the solo.

title: Economic Scene; Some risks are more manageable than others. Can we design markets to change that?
description: UNEMPLOYMENT is up. Housing sales are weakening. Oil prices continue to fluctuate, and the stock market remains volatile. There's no doubt we live in risky times, yet our tools for managing risk are limited.

title: Toyota Dealer Group Is Starting a Review
description: The Greater New York Toyota Dealers Association, which includes more than 100 dealers, has begun a review for its account, which has been handled by Saatchi & Saatchi in New York for more than 20 years. Billings were estimated at $90 million.

title: Israeli-Palestinian Clashes Leave Six Dead
description: JERUSALEM, April 10  In a trio of stealth attacks today, Israeli soldiers and Palestinian militants caught each other off guard in strikes that left two soldiers and four militants dead in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: Another Chance for a Notorious Work
description: The world premiere of Samuel Barber's ''Antony and Cleopatra,'' which inaugurated the Metropolitan Opera House at Lincoln Center in 1966, has entered the annals of famous flops. Barber's lushly Neo-Romantic score was deemed anachronistic at a time of rampant, complex high modernism. The very idea of a grand opera based on Shakespeare's play seemed terribly retro to some. And Franco Zeffirelli's extravagant and cumbersome production was undermined by opening night technical glitches in the Met's new equipment, including a recalcitrant rotating stage.

title: Milan Mandate: Grow the Brand
description: TALK of rising costs and slipping sales was willfully postponed this week in anticipation of the 42nd Salone Internazionale del Mobile, the world's premier showcase of elegance and daring in contemporary design, which opened yesterday in Milan.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: ALBANY: DISASTER PLANS FOR CHEMICAL PLANTS A bill to require chemical plants in New York to draw up disaster preparedness plans was introduced in the State Assembly yesterday. A Senate version is due to be introduced this week. More than 100 chemical plants in the state house hazardous substances and may be vulnerable to terrorist attack. Under the bill, written plans would be sent to the state's Office of Public Security, which could order increased perimeter security or background checks of plant employees. Assemblyman Michael N. Gianaris, a Democrat who represents a Queens district anchored in Astoria, introduced the bill and is urging a similar plan for power plants. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Escapism in Sexy, Streamlined Fun; Art Deco's Exuberance Is on Display at the Victoria and Albert
description: In the years between the world wars, everything from furniture and fashion to architecture and industrial design came under the sway of a flashy art style variously known as Industrial Moderne, Jazz Moderne and Streamline Moderne. Flourishing nearly everywhere, it represented the first global design fad. Yet by the time it ran out of steam, it still had no agreed name. Only in the mid-1960's was it tagged Art Deco.

title: Negotiators Reach Rare Deal on Tax Cut
description: House and Senate budget negotiators today broke their impasse over how large a tax cut to allow by postponing the decision until later in the year.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about Indian Point Park, the former amusement attraction in Buchanan, N.Y., on the property now occupied by the Indian Point nuclear power plant, misidentified the plant's owner. It is the Entergy Corporation; Con Edison sold the property in September 2001.

title: U.S. Left Out of Emissions Trading
description: During negotiations over the Kyoto Protocol, the United States preached the importance of market solutions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Few countries listened.

title: Heartache And History In a Style Of the Greeks
description: Love, fate and history were the makings of the songs of George Dalaras and Marinella, two singers who have been stars in Greece since the 1960's and who shared the stage of Radio City Music Hall on Friday night. The audience regularly sang along on their hits.

title: Albany Senator Seeks to Block Bloomberg's School District Plan
description: State Senator Frank Padavan said yesterday that he would introduce legislation to block Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to eliminate New York City's local school districts, a centerpiece of the mayor's effort to reorganize the public schools.

Hale of NYC. Beloved brother of Elliott J. Skluth of Rye Brook, NY and the late Judith Skluth Weinberg. Cherished grandfather of Elisabeth S. Zeche of Norwalk, CT, Nathan Hale and Edward E. Herbert Skluth, M.D. Memorial Lecture Fund, 34 Maple St, PO Box 5050, Norwalk, CT 06856 or the Connecticut Hospice, 1 Park St, Norwalk, CT 06851.

title: Military and C.I.A. Searching Baghdad for Hussein and His Sons or Their Bodies
description: WASHINGTON, April 9  Besieged by reports and rumors on the whereabouts of Saddam Hussein, a formerly covert intelligence operation in Baghdad turned into a wide-open manhunt today as military and C.I.A. teams raced through barely secured neighborhoods of the Iraqi capital searching for any sign of Mr. Hussein, his two sons and other leaders of the Baath Party.

title: At Augusta National, the Lines Have Been Drawn
description: All was quiet late on the afternoon of April 14, 2002, as Tiger Woods rapped two putts across the 18th green at Augusta National Golf Club to complete a routine par for a splendidly easy victory at the Masters. So hushed was the scene that the sound of Woods's ball clattering into the cup was clearly audible.

title: Speed and Flexibility
description: If there is a single reason for the allied success in toppling President Saddam Hussein's government, it is the flexibility the American military demonstrated in carrying out its campaign.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: WEAK MACHINERY ORDERS Orders for new machinery, a crucial indicator of capital spending, fell at twice the rate expected by economists because of slowing demand from electronics makers. Orders fell 9.6 percent in February from January. Despite the steeper-than-expected decline, orders are still on track to rise in the first quarter. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: News Corp. Adds to Empire With Control of DirecTV
description: Completing the final piece in Rupert Murdoch's global satellite empire, the News Corporation agreed yesterday to buy control of Hughes Electronics and its DirecTV satellite operation from General Motors in a deal valued at $6.6 billion.

title: Covering the War
description: The Pentagon's decision to let about 600 journalists travel with the armed forces invading Iraq has been in the main a win-win story. The media have been able to provide war coverage more immediate and intense than ever before. The military learned, to its pleasure, that reporters ''embedded'' with the troops better understood the perspective of the men and women on the front. The war planners, as it turned out, did not need to be afraid to let the American public see the reality of the conflict.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNANOUDJ, FORTUNEE PAULETTE, NEE AKNIN
description: SNANOUDJ-Fortunee Paulette, nee Aknin. Died April 8, 2003 at age 89. Wife of late David. Mother of Sylvain, Jacques and Nicole. Grandmother of Astrid, Didier, Marc, Denise. Great-grandmother of Ryan, Sam, Jake & Jared. Survived by sisters Raymonde and Lysange and brother Charles. Services today, 9:30AM, Plaza Memorial, 91st Street and Amsterdam.

description: After a day of speeches denouncing gun violence and praising the constitutional right to bear arms, the House of Representatives easily passed a bill today limiting lawsuits against the firearms industry.

title: Joy in Baghdad, Arab Consternation and the Mystery of Saddam Hussein
description: American military commanders did not call it the fall of Baghdad, but the virtually unhindered entrance of American troops into the heart of the city to the cheers of local Iraqis yesterday clearly represented a turning point in the war. Troops found no sign of a surviving Iraqi government, nor of Saddam Hussein and his sons. Like people all over the world who watched live broadcasts of jubilant crowds welcoming the troops, American officials who monitored the images from Washington rejoiced. As those running the war cautioned that much work remained, officials turned their focus to what will happen after the war ends.

title: It's Official: No Playoffs For Knicks
description: On the bright side, they hung around much longer than they did last season, when the games in March, April and even a part of February were meaningless. Nonetheless, the end result is the same: the Knicks failed to make the playoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAELS, SELMA
description: MICHAELS-Selma. Beloved wife of Albert. Beloved mother of Jeffrey and the late Leslie, the late Phyllis Andors and the late Ruth Bolling. Adored grandmother of Jessica Andors and Brian Bolling & great-grandmother of Malaika Bolling. Not just a mother-in-law but a real mom to Stephen and Ann Andors and Tessa Michaels. Selma transformed tragedy and sorrow into courage, generosity and gentleness. Visiting at Harmon Funeral Home, 571 Forest Ave, Staten Island, Friday, 9-11 AM, to be followed by a service.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Church Suspends Confessions
description: The Roman Catholic Church has told priests across the island not to hear individual confessions for fear that the disease SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome, could be transmitted in the closed confines of the confessional booth. For the Easter season priests will grant a ''general absolution,'' said Archbishop Nicholas Chia. Churchgoers have also been advised not to hold each other's hands, and communion wafers are to be placed by priests into the palms of parishioners rather than directly onto their tongues. Eight people have died of the disease in Singapore, including a Catholic pastor who visited a victim on her sickbed. Seth Mydens (NYT)

Mr. Levy was a firm friend of City College and a generous supporter of education. He will be sorely missed. On behalf of City College's faculty, students, and alumni, I wish to extend my deepest sympathies to his wife, Shelby, his daughter Tracy, and his brother Jay. Gregory H. Williams, President, The City College of New York/CUNY

title: Energy Matters Return to Fore On Capitol Hill
description: Two years ago, with California suffering from rolling blackouts and oil prices sinking, energy policy was a centerpiece of the Bush administration's domestic agenda. Then the terror attacks intervened and momentum for a wide-ranging new energy program was lost.

title: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly
description: When coaches who lose championship games are interviewed by TV reporters, they usually speak in hushes worthy of a golf correspondent. But Monday night, Kansas Coach Roy Williams took a different tack in responding to a question about his interest in the vacant North Carolina job.

title: South Korean Banker Warns of More Scandals
description: The head of South Korea's largest bank warned today that the market-rocking scandal at the SK Group, one of the conglomerates that dominate the South Korean economy, may not be the last.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORSCHEL, MRS. ALBERT K.
description: ORSCHEL-Mrs. Albert K., the former Peggy Rauh of New York City, New York, wife of the late prominent corporation attorney, Albert K. Orschel, born July 16, 1915, died April 9, 2003, at her home in Chicago, Illinois. She is survived by her daughter, Lynn Orschel, son, Alan (Nora Mitchell) Orschel, and two grandsons, Bradley Mitchell and Jeffrey Mitchell Orschel. Services will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to the Children's Memorial Foundation, 2300 Children's Place, Box 4, Chicago, IL, 60614. Blake-Lamb Funeral Home information: 312-944-5594.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: TOUGH TARGET FOR CARMAKER Citing the slack global economy and the climbing cost of sales incentives in the United States, DaimlerChrysler said it would be difficult to meet its profit targets for 2003, though it has not given up hope. The company aims to exceed last year's operating profit of $6.2 billion, driven in part by a projected $2 billion profit at Chrysler. But with Chrysler's sales in the United States down 6.2 percent so far this year, the chairman, Jurgen E. Schrempp, above, said, "it has become much more difficult to reach the targets we have set ourselves." Mark Landler (NYT)

title: In Basra, There's Weariness About the Same Old Faces
description: BASRA, Iraq, April 9  British and American officials, having taken control of Iraq's second-largest city, are trying to help potential leaders emerge from the local population here. But it is difficult to find anyone in southern Iraq who held some position of authority who was not tied to Saddam Hussein's government.

description: The debris viewed on Air Force radar as it drifted away from the shuttle Columbia in its second day in orbit was apparently not the wing part investigators had believed it to be, two people close to the investigation said today.
