description: The collapse of government authority in Baghdad, dramatized by the toppling of a colossal statue of President Saddam Hussein, constitutes the high-water mark for a new American determination to use the nation's military might to project its power around the world.

title: I.M.F. Cuts Worldwide Forecast To a 3.2% Expansion This Year
description: The world economy will grow 3.2 percent this year, hindered by concerns over war and terrorism that may also limit the pace of expansion in 2004 and beyond, the International Monetary Fund said today.

title: It Adds Up (and Up, and Up)
description: WHEN Jon Green was growing up in rural Massachusetts in the 1970's, his family's phone service consisted of a party line shared with several neighbors. A simple rabbit-ears antenna captured all of seven television channels.

title: Dow Focuses on Earnings, and Doesn't Like What It Sees
description: Stocks fell yesterday as concern that earnings growth was slowing overshadowed optimism that the toppling of a Saddam Hussein statue in central Baghdad meant the war in Iraq was ending.

title: Anita Borg, 54, Trailblazer For Women in Computer Field
description: Anita Borg, a computer scientist who devoted much of her career to the advancement of women in computer science, died on Sunday at her mother's home in Sonoma, Calif. She was 54.

title: Chief Quits Big Maker Of Chemicals
description: Imperial Chemical Industries, the British specialty chemical and paint company, said today that its chief executive, Brendan O'Neill, had resigned. His departure comes two weeks after the company surprised investors with a profit warning.

title: Competing for Work in Postwar Iraq
description: The roster of United States companies that have received potentially lucrative contracts for work in the Iraq region continues to grow despite a demand this week by Democrats in Congress for an independent review of the process for awarding such deals.

title: British and French to Halt Concorde Flights
description: LONDON, April 10  After 27 years of supersonic travel lofting rock stars, executives, and the rest of the champagne set across the Atlantic Ocean, British Airways and Air France said today that they would retire their fleet of Concorde airplanes later this year. The decision will bring to an end an era when the needle-nosed jet stood for the ascendancy of technology and economic hope in the late 20th century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, LILLIAN
description: STEINBERG-Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Martin (Moe). Cherished friend of Arkadie, Elaine, Nancy and Tamara Pikulik. Services at ''Boulevard - Riverside'', Chapels, 1895 Flatbush Avenue (at Avenue L), Brooklyn, New York, Friday at 9:30 A.M.

title: Hobey Baker Award Has Three Finalists
description: The Hobey Baker Memorial Award will be presented tomorrow, and among the three finalists, only Cornell goaltender DAVID LENEVEU will be playing in the Frozen Four.

title: People
description: * William B. Grogan Jr. was named to the new post of president at Berlin Cameron/Red Cell, New York, part of the WPP Group. He had been senior vice president for marketing at the global marketing solutions division of AOL Time Warner, New York, and previously held posts including global director for Coca-Cola Company brands at the Interpublic Group of Companies, New York, and executive vice president at McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, part of Interpublic.

title: Arab World Shows a Mix Of Emotions
description: It was a day of raw emotion across the Arab world, a historic day with elation, sadness, disbelief, anger and shock all blending together as the government of Saddam Hussein seemed to come crashing down with barely a whimper, the moment marked not as in previous decades by a coup and glorious anthems booming out of the radio, but by American troops, foreigners, pulling down a statue in a main Baghdad traffic circle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, JUDY
description: GREENBERG - Judy. The members of Shelter Rock Tennis Club record with great sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Judy Greenberg. She was a friend to all and will be sorely missed. Our sincere condolences to her entire family.

title: Senate Passes Version of Religion Initiative
description: A pared version of President Bush's religion-based initiative passed the Senate today by an overwhelming margin, but Republicans are already using other legislation to press the White House's agenda of expanding government grants to religious groups.

title: Overwhelmed by What's on TV? Then Get a Smaller Screen
description: The cha-cha music is on the hi-fi, and Anita Ekberg is pouring a Campari and soda. Who wants a big flat plasma-screen television display with that? Perhaps instead one of these beauties from Brionvega, an Italian manufacturer of television sets since 1945, which has retooled and reissued the 1964 Algol (below, with a retractable handle, $750), designed by Marco Zanuso and Richard Sapper; the 1962 Doney (above, $850), by the same team; and the 1969 Cuboglass ($990), designed by Mario Bellini. And while the looks remain the same, the innards have been seriously upgraded. Souped-up features include color screens, storable programs and remote controls. And the sets work with DirecTV, standard cable and PlayStation. Available this week at the Terence Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street; (866) 755-9079. Information: www.brionvega.com. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

title: U.S. Forces Take Control of Baghdad
description: KUWAIT, Thursday, April 10  Much of Baghdad tumbled into American hands on Wednesday as Saddam Hussein's image was pulled down from pedestals and portraiture in the city. But American and British commanders said the war in Iraq, including the battle for Baghdad, was not over and faced critical days ahead.

title: Play Fascinating Rhythms, for Your Ears Only
description: Except for the models designed to be children's toys, digital drum sets have been beyond the budget of many musicians who perform only at home. But at $300, Pacific Digital's DrumXtreme might find an audience among amateurs.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOKOTOFF, HAROLD S.
description: MOKOTOFF-Harold S. Of Sagaponack, NY died April 7, 2003 at age 92. A member of the NYS Bar for over half a century, he was respected in his profession and adored by his family. His wife of 63 years, Rhoda Becher Mokotoff died in 1997. He leaves his children, Steffi and Robert Berne, and Moke and Hue Mokotoff; his grandchildren, Lizzie Berne, Alexander Berne and Sophia Mokotoff; and his care-giver, Red Mackey. There will be a private graveside service.

title: A Sense That the Iraqi Leader Is Gone Brings Joy in the North
description: Northern Iraq erupted in celebration this afternoon as crowds from the largely Kurdish population, which has fought Saddam Hussein and his party for most of four decades, sensed Baghdad's government had been broken.

title: Spanish Journalists Assail U.S. Over Colleagues' Deaths in Iraq
description: Hundreds of journalists in Madrid downed their cameras and notebooks today and gathered outside the heavily guarded American Embassy to protest the deaths of two Spanish colleagues killed while covering the American assault on Baghdad, as well as protesting their government's support for the war.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WELLS FARGO & CO., San Francisco, said it planned to sell $3 billion in 30-year convertible bonds and use the money for general corporate purposes and to buy back debt and shares.

title: Pact With Baggage Handlers and Mechanics at American Air
description: American Airlines said last night that it had worked out terms of a deal with the Transport Workers Union to give its members a short-term wage increase if they voted in favor of $620 million in concessions by Tuesday and if the credit rating of the company improved.

description: MIAMI, April 9 -Outfielder Tsuyoshi Shinjo of the Mets said goodbye to his glove tonight.

title: Church to Pay $323,000 and Apologize in Irish Sex Abuse Case
description: One of Ireland's prominent campaigners for the rights of victims of clerical sexual abuse settled a five-year-old case against the Roman Catholic diocese where he was abused more than 20 years ago for 300,000 euros ($323,000), in a deal that included a public apology and sets a precedent for how the Catholic Church here relates to abuse victims.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Department Store Bid
description: Selfridges, the 94-year-old British department store company, received a takeover offer worth more than 375 million ($585 million). The unidentified bidder offered ''a substantial premium to last night's closing share price,'' Selfridges said in a Regulatory News Service statement. Selfridges, which owns a 540,000-square-foot store on Oxford Street in London, is more likely to have attracted a real estate investor than a rival retailer and may fetch as much as 460 million, analysts said. Selfridges, which has three stores, was spun off from Sears of Britain in 1998. Profit has doubled to 28.3 million since 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMBER, JULES J.
description: DEMBER-Jules J. Of Massapequa and Amityville. Devoted husband of the late, Muriel ''Mimi''. Loving father of Stuart, Anne Ryan, John and Allyne, Peggy and Gary Zucker, Larry and Jennifer. Cherished grandfather of Robert, Philip, Ian, Jasmine, Rebecca, Ryan and Liam. Adored brother of Phyllis and Abby Katzman. A proud veteran of World War II. He devoted 40 years to Slomin's Oil Company. He enjoyed the adventures of world travel with his wife. Services will be held Thursday, 11:30AM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah. Memorial donations may be made to the Cancer Center at St. Francis Hospital, Trenton, NJ.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Taiwan Chip Makers Post Higher Sales
description: The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company and the United Microelectronics Corporation, the world's largest suppliers of made-to-order chips, said yesterday that first-quarter sales rose on demand for their advanced technology. Taiwan Semiconductor said its first-quarter sales rose 9.9 percent from a year ago, to $1.1 billion. Its rival, United Microelectronics, said its sales in the same period rose 47.2 percent.

description: IT takes a four-wheel drive to climb the steep, snowy hill to Jim Bouton's house here in the Berkshires. Mr. Bouton, the one-time Yankee pitcher known for his 1970 best seller, ''Ball Four,'' has thrown a curve: he wants to talk architecture.

description: JUNGER-Agnes. From Buenos Aires to New York. Admiration always, for her courage, wisdom and friendship. Chilly Eberli and Family

title: Judge Orders Faster Review Of Cooling Unit At Indian Point
description: A State Supreme Court justice ordered state environmental officials today to speed up their review of the cooling system for the Indian Point nuclear complex in Westchester County, after environmentalists argued that it killed large numbers of fish by drawing water from the Hudson River.

title: Must What Goes Up Also Come Down?
description: It is almost certain that the toppling yesterday of Saddam Hussein's giant statue in the center of Baghdad will be considered in retrospect as one of the iconic images of the present war in Iraq. As I watched this scene unfolding on television, similar episodes from the not-so-distant yet already faintly hazy past, sprang to my mind.

title: The Tracking Stock Idea Goes Into Retirement at G.M.
description: General Motors, the originator of tracking stock, is retiring its last such issue in a deal that treats G.M. quite differently from the investors who bought the stock. The parent gets a lot of cash and a higher price for its shares in Hughes Electronics. The public shareholders get paper.

title: People Rise As Icons Of Nation Fall Down
description: As the sun set on Baghdad today, a blacksmith named Muhammad Abbas stood with his two young children at the base of a 60-foot statue of the Iraqi president. Mr. Abbas's eyes tilted upward in blinkered wonder as a group of American marines tied a noose around the leaden likeness of Saddam Hussein and began to pull it to the ground.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARRETT, DOLAN LEANDER
description: GARRETT-Dolan Leander, 51, of White Plains, NY, died Monday, April 7th as a result of a car accident. He is survived by his wife Claire Armanini Garrett and two children, Nicole (13) and Kevin (11). Visiting hours will be Thursday 5-9 PM at the McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains. Funeral mass Friday at 11:00AM at St. John the Evangelist Church, 148 Hamilton Ave., White Plains. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to a scholarship fund for his children by contacting Zachary Carter at (212) 415-9345.

title: Fall of a Northern City, Suicide Bombing on Marines, Killing of a Cleric
description: As Kirkuk fell in the north, American and British troops made important advances. But they also encountered heavy resistance and uncovered worrisome signs that the war was far from over. An important Muslim cleric was killed in Najaf, a suicide bomber wounded four marines in Baghdad and President Bush went on Iraqi television to reassure the Iraqi people of America's intentions. About two-thirds of Iraq has come under American and British control but coalition forces have not found Mr. Hussein or the weapons of mass destructions he was believed to possess.

description: The Illinois Senate adjourned today until Tuesday without reconsidering a bill to reduce a $12 billion bond Philip Morris USA was ordered to post if it wanted to appeal a state court ruling.

description: MIAMI, April 10 - It was hardly comforting for Mets pitcher David Cone to hear stories today about Hiram Bithhorn Stadium in San Juan, P.R.

description: President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain took to the Iraqi airwaves today, using newly seized state television facilities to tell the Iraqi people, in Mr. Bush's words, that ''the nightmare that Saddam Hussein has brought to your nation will soon be over.''

description: MOSUL, Iraq, April 11 - American forces entered this northern Iraqi oil city this afternoon after it fell without a fight as the last of Saddam Hussein's loyalists vanished during the night.

description: A large, angry mob was squaring off in the center of Basra against tense British troops backed by tanks and heavy machine guns, so I asked the Iraqis what they were doing.

description: DeVERGILES - Marie (nee Vitolo). On March 27, 2003. Cherished mother, sister, grandmother, great grandmother, mother-in-law, aunt, cousin, Nana Marie, friend.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Sale
description: A group of investors led by Wilbur Ross will sell a substantial share of its stake in an Osaka-based lender, Kansai Sawayaka Bank Ltd., to the Bank of Kansai Ltd. The two banks will then merge in two years. Bank of Kansai is 49 percent owned by the Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation, which is trying to strengthen its operations in Osaka, Japan's second-largest city. An investment fund led by Mr. Ross opened Kansai Sawayaka Bank in February 2001 after taking over Kofuku Bank, which was in bankruptcy. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: No Boycott of Restaurants, But the French Still Object
description: There is no actual organized boy cott of French restaurants in New York City.

description: To the Editor:

title: Golf Is Rained Out, but Burk Plays Through
description: So far, the 67th Masters has been more talk than action.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Fund Raises Industrial Stake
description: A Monaco-based fund raised its stake in the flagship of the SK Group, South Korea's fourth-biggest industrial group, and asked a shareholder group to support management changes after a financial scandal. The fund, Sovereign Asset Management Ltd., bought 4.76 million shares of the SK Corporation from April 3 to April 9, according to a filing at the Seoul stock exchange. Sovereign, SK's biggest shareholder, spent 75 billion won ($61 million) to expand its stake to 12.4 percent from 8.6 percent. SK Corporation intends to fight management changes. ''If Sovereign wants to participate in management to raise shareholder value, we can cooperate, but if their intent is an overhaul of control, we've got contingency plans,'' said Hugh Jung, head of the SK Corporation's investor relations team.

title: For EchoStar, the Real Challenge From DirecTV Begins
description: While Rupert Murdoch and General Motors executives worked out the News Corporation's deal for control of DirecTV, Charles W. Ergen, the chairman of EchoStar, the nation's No. 2 satellite-television company, spent most of this week south of the border.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Telecom Payout Planned
description: Telefnica plans to increase payments to shareholders in an effort to raise investor confidence in the company, Spain's largest telephone company, after its first loss ever last year. ''We can increase the reward to shareholders and we will do it,'' the chairman, Csar Alierta, said. He said compensating shareholders was a priority over acquisitions. Telefnica lost 5.58 billion euros ($6 billion) last year on costs from a failed Internet, media and European wireless expansion. To regain investors' confidence, the company plans to pay its first dividend since 1998, buy back shares and spin off half of the company's stake in Antena 3.

title: Details Given On Contract Halliburton Was Awarded
description: The Pentagon contract given without competition to a Halliburton subsidiary to fight oil well fires in Iraq is worth as much as $7 billion over two years, according to a letter from the Army Corps of Engineers that was released today.

title: U.S. Envoy Urges I.R.A. to Rescue Northern Ireland Peace Plan
description: LONDON, April 11  President Bush's special envoy to Northern Ireland, Richard N. Haass, said tonight that it was up to the Irish Republican Army to make a "historic transformation" to rescue the province's stalemated peace plan.

title: He Put the Rage in Outrageous Ticket Prices
description: THE temptation is to accuse Joseph T. Farrell -- the predictably dapper chief executive of Broadway Inner Circle, the theater ticket service that brought us the indispensable $480 premium orchestra seat for ''The Producers'' -- of committing the Great White Way version of highway robbery. Must be the combination of silver hair, silver stubble, silver tie and silver tongue offset by that sunny out-of-season tan that arouse suspicion -- he just hopped off a flight from Florida, so jealousy is factoring into first impressions.

title: Not Perfect, But Wells Is Almost Just as Good
description: David Wells stretched alone on the carpet in the Yankees' clubhouse, just beyond the giant interlocking ''NY.'' His beloved metal bands -- Creed, Disturbed, Metallica -- surged through the speakers. His favorite victims, the Minnesota Twins, were in town. A small but loyal crowd was filing into Yankee Stadium. Wells was home at last.

title: Gene Study Finds Cannibal Pattern
description: Deep in the recesses of the human heart, lurking guiltily beneath the threshold of consciousness, there may lie a depraved craving -- for the forbidden taste of human flesh. The basis for this morbid accusation, made by a team of researchers in London, is a genetic signature, found almost worldwide, that points to a long history of cannibalism.

title: Chicago and Police Face Suit Over Jailing of War Protesters
description: The local chapter of the National Lawyers Guild filed a class action lawsuit against the city and its police department today for what it called the unlawful arrest and imprisonment of hundreds of people in an antiwar protest last month.

title: Multiple Realities Clash in a World of Shimmering Reflections
description: Josiah McElheny's third solo New York gallery show is so extreme in its perfection that it might almost end his career. Where do you go after making a pristine ensemble of eight sleek 50's-style decanters from mirrored glass, encasing them in a mirrored, wall-mounted box so that they extend into infinity like neat rows of nose cones? The design studios at Tiffany's? Murano? NASA? Maybe you should just time-travel back to Faberg and the court of the last Russian czar.

title: Mayor Warns Of Less Money For Police And Teachers
description: For the first time in the current budget crisis, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday raised the specter of a smaller payroll for police officers, firefighters and teachers if the city did not get financial help from the state. Aides said later that the mayor was not speaking of layoffs.

title: War Strains Germans at American Base
description: Vera Kieren, a teacher at the Deutsche Schule here, said it happened when her husband told a convenience store cashier recently that their daughter did not drink Coca-Cola.

title: Sony Hires Agency for Aiwa Division
description: The Sony Corporation in Tokyo has tentatively named Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., as global agency of record on the consolidated creative account of its Aiwa division, which had been inactive or handled on a project basis in different regions. Billings were estimated at $50 million.

description: Shift Dooms Old Firehouses

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: PAKISTANI HELD IN KASHMIR ATTACK The police chief in Kashmir said security forces had arrested a Pakistani man they say planned and helped carry out the massacre of 24 Hindus last month. The chief, Ashok Kumar Suri, told a news conference in Srinagar, the summer capital of Kashmir, that the man told the police that he was a commander of the outlawed Pakistan-based group, Lashkar-e-Taiba and that the attack was in retaliation for the killing of Muslims in religious clashes in the western Indian state of Gujarat last year. The announcement came as a powerful bomb blast damaged the gates of Kashmir's Mughal gardens, once one of the main tourist attractions in Srinagar. (Reuters)

description: Following is a transcript of taped statements by President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain that were broadcast on Iraqi television yesterday, as recorded by The Associated Press.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZORINA, VERA
description: ZORINA-Vera. The Board of Directors and Staff of The Santa Fe Opera note with enormous sadness the death of Vera Zorina. Vera Zorina had a long association with the company, first as performer and director, and then as a member of the Board of Directors. She was an Honorary Director at the time of her death. Vera Zorina will be remembered as a woman of great spirit, great talent and great generosity. Her contribution to The Santa Fe Opera is immeasurable. The entire company expresses its deep sympathy to her family. David K. Ingalls, Chairman Susan F. Morris, President Richard Gaddes, General Director The Santa Fe Opera

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: COIN RUSH The Italian and Vatican police created a human chain to hold back thousands of people as they pushed at the Vatican's gates to buy limited-edition coins celebrating the 25th year of Pope John Paul II. Many had waited in the rain for more than 24 hours for the coins to go on sale, and some scuffles broke out. The sets, eight coins of different denominations, were being sold for 15 euros ($16) and attracted many scalpers, who said they could be resold for hundreds. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: 6 ARRESTED IN WHEELCHAIR PROTEST Six protesters who use wheelchairs were arrested when they refused to leave the Capitol office of Gov. Rick Perry, left, at the close of the business day. The group had occupied part of Mr. Perry's office demanding that he, Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst and Speaker Tom Craddick sign a pledge to protect services for the disabled. State lawmakers face a projected $10 billion shortfall in the 2004-05 budget and have warned that some services may face sharp cuts. (AP)

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Singing For a Tony

title: Too Soon to Declare Victory in Iraq, Bush Says
description: WASHINGTON, April 11  Despite overwhelming evidence that Saddam Hussein has lost his hold on power, President Bush said today he was not ready to pronounce victory in Iraq and not ready to call an end to the war.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: ARCHDIOCESE ENDS BACKGROUND CHECKS The Archdiocese of New York has suspended background checks of employees, including priests. The checks were put in place as a response to the clerical sex-abuse scandal. The archdiocese sent out a letter two weeks ago announcing the checks, which called for the verification of Social Security numbers and searches of crime and sex-offender databases. But on Tuesday, the chancery sent out a memorandum calling a halt to the checks until further notice. A spokesman for the diocese, Joseph Zwilling, said yesterday that priests, teachers and other employees had raised many questions about the checks, including what would would be done with the information. Archdiocesan officials will wait until after the busy Easter season to address the questions, he said. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Coin Rush
description: The Italian and Vatican police created a human chain to hold back thousands of people as they pushed at the Vatican's gates to buy limited-edition coins celebrating the 25th year of Pope John Paul II. Many had waited in the rain for more than 24 hours for the coins to go on sale, and some scuffles broke out. The sets, eight coins of different denominations, were being sold for 15 euros ($16) and attracted many scalpers, who said they could be resold for hundreds. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: The Suffering Of the Cities
description: Each of Iraq's cities seems to go through the same cycle: bombing, flight by refugees, a coalition assault, street fighting, the defenders' collapse, celebrations, looting, the tumbling of statues, food shortages and revenge killings. Order now reigns nowhere in what was once an orderly, if brutal, country. Kirkuk, in the north, fell to Kurdish fighters yesterday and the cycle began. Baghdad, which has been under American control for two days, is following in the footsteps of Basra, which fell to the British earlier and where efforts to restart local government began yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROISSER, MORRIS
description: GROISSER - Morris, 86, passed away peacefully April 9, at Jacob Perlow Hospice. Beloved brother of Esther Walter and Ann Groisser, cherished uncle of Jessica Walter and Richard Walter, adored great uncle of Brooke Bowman, Susanna and Daniel Walter. Served in WWII as U.S. Navy Lieutenant. A Memorial at a future date.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Far From the Battle, Marines Wait to Fight or to Go Home
description: In Baghdad, a statue of Saddam Hussein toppled, and a crowd cheered. Here, a dusty lug nut fell from a Humvee wheel to the sand with a mute puff, and no one said much of anything as the marine began loosening the next one.

title: The Future of Iraq's Oil
description: Iraq is no longer a republic of fear, but it is still a republic of oil. Some 112 billion barrels lie beneath its soil, more than a tenth of the world's known reserves. How the Bush administration handles the management of that resource as it gains control of the country will go a long way toward determining not just the future of Iraq but also America's worldwide reputation. Any effort to manipulate Iraq's oil for the benefit of the United States and American oil companies rather than the benefit of the Iraqi people will squander whatever political gains Washington has won in the war.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: NETWORK ASSOCIATES POSTS LOSS Network Associates reported a quarterly loss yesterday and cut its full-year outlook, citing last-minute order cancellations by corporate customers. Its share price dropped as much as 20 percent. The company, which is the subject of two inquiries by the federal government into the way it booked revenue, said it would still not be able to file its financial statement for 2002 because of a previously announced restatement of results for 1998 through 2000. The company  a provider of security software and services, including the McAfee antivirus programs  said spending by corporate customers was unexpectedly weak. "We saw a falloff in customer spending at the end of the first quarter that I've never seen before," the chief executive, George Samenuk, told analysts on a conference call, adding that the company typically closed about 50 percent of its business in the last few weeks of the quarter. Network Associates reported a first-quarter net loss of $3.7 million, or 2 cents a diluted share, in contrast to a profit of $15.8 million, or 10 cents a diluted share, for the period a year earlier. Excluding stock-based compensation costs, the company said it earned $21.2 million, or 11 cents a diluted share, in line with the average estimate of Wall Street analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue fell to $215.2 million from $220.7 million; analysts had expected $228.2 million. Shares of Network Associates closed down $2.54, or 19 percent, at $10.80. ( Reuters )

Best friend and most deeply beloved husband of Sandy Berkowitz - Steinber ger. Devoted father to Dr. Robert, Carl, Joshua and Paul. Grandfather of Michelle and Amanda. Loving and loved stepfather to Jill and Jay Glasser, David Forrest and Glen Berkowitz, and stepgrandfather to Max, Zachary, and Richard Glasser. Born on October 22, 1924 to Jack Steinberger and Mollie Kirschenbaum, in Brooklyn, NY. Brother of Marvin Steinberger (deceased). World War II Vet, 2nd Lieutenant, US Airforce. Dr. Steinberger graduated from Columbia Medical School, and SUNY Downstate Medical Center '51. Interned '51-'52 Jewish Hospital, Brooklyn, NY. '52-'55 Resident OB/GYN Maimonides Medical Center, Brooklyn, NY. Cons. Emeritus KHH, St. Joseph's-St. John's Hospital, Far Rockaway, NY. He retired in 1990 from Maimonides Medical Center and St. John's. He was a wonderful, caring doctor who was vigorously involved in the total care of his patients, and will always be remembered as a dedicated and compassionate practitioner of medicine. He will be deeply missed and remembered with love by his families, friends, and everyone he touched. In his memory donations may be made to: The Dr. Bernard Steinberger National Fragile-X-Foundation, 4408 Intracoastal Drive, Highland Beach, FL. 33487. Funeral Sunday, April 13, 2003 at 12 noon from Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Ali During His Best Years, Still Floating and Stinging

He survives as an ambassador from a more volatile era, and his status as a national treasure satisfies our collective need to remind ourselves how far we have come since then. Because the man's life has spanned so much change and tumult, because in his prime he so gracefully bobbed and weaved his way through the minefields of race and religion, celebrity and politics, Mr. Ali has spawned a minor industry among writers and filmmakers.

Clinton (a township in Dutchess County, not to be confused with the Village of Clinton farther upstate) has grown used to seeing celebrities and well-heeled visitors, including a growing corps of second-home buyers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Archdiocese Ends Background Checks
description: The Archdiocese of New York has suspended background checks of employees, including priests. The checks were put in place as a response to the clerical sex-abuse scandal. The archdiocese sent out a letter two weeks ago announcing the checks, which called for the verification of Social Security numbers and searches of crime and sex-offender databases. But on Tuesday, the chancery sent out a memorandum calling a halt to the checks until further notice. A spokesman for the diocese, Joseph Zwilling, said yesterday that priests, teachers and other employees had raised many questions about the checks, including what would would be done with the information. Archdiocesan officials will wait until after the busy Easter season to address the questions, he said. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Fire at a Russian School Kills 28 Deaf Boys
description: Asleep and unable to hear the frantic shouts of adults, 28 deaf boys died early today after a fire consumed their boarding school in the Caspian Sea city of Makhachkala in the Russian republic of Dagestan.

title: Rebuild Iraq, Disarm North Korea
description: As we begin the debate over how much authority the United States should cede to the United Nations in restructuring Iraq, one area should produce quick agreement: American officials should return responsibility for finding out whether Iraq has weapons of mass destruction to the United Nations.

title: Utah Man, in China, Dies of Disease
description: A Utah man teaching English in China died of severe acute respiratory syndrome on his way to a Hong Kong hospital on Wednesday, leaving a 6-year-old son who lived with him. The boy has flulike symptoms and is now under observation at another Hong Kong hospital to make sure he does not have the same ailment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGRO, NANCY POST
description: MAGRO-Nancy Post of Camden, ME. Surviving: sons Jonathan P. Magro (Cinc, OH), Benjamin Magro (Appleton, ME), daughters, Rev. Susan Pfeil (New Canaan, CT), Nancy Magro (Windham, NH); brother, George Post (Norwalk, CT); halfbrother, Ethan Emery (Mexico); half - sisters, Irene Goodale (Atlanta, GA); Lela Steele (Cinc., OH); nine grandchildren. Predeceased by husband of 55 yrs., John L. Magro, daughter Dr. Victoria Pfeil, half-sister, Melissa Lanier. Celebration of Life 11AM, April 12, 2003 at John St. Methodist Church. Laite Funeral Home, 207-236-0092

title: Another Northern City Captured; U.S. Unveils 'Most Wanted' List
description: American forces entered Mosul, a northern oil city, this afternoon after it fell without a fight as the last of Saddam Hussein's loyalists vanished during the night.

title: All Eyes Turn To Empire Maker At Wood Memorial
description: Empire Maker does not have much to prove and neither his wealthy Saudi Arabian owner nor his well-compensated trainer, Bobby Frankel, seem to care that much about the $450,000 that will go to the winner of tomorrow's Wood Memorial at Aqueduct. On what could be a dreary day in Queens, Empire Maker will spend his afternoon not going after glory, riches or a coronation, but merely stretching his muscles and staying sharp in an attempt to maintain his presumed stranglehold on the 3-year-old division. It's still spring training. The real games begin May 3 at Churchill Downs.

title: Behold, on the Eighth Day, Bringing Forth Modern Dance
description: Ballet companies and modern-dance troupes don't usually share an evening, but the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts here is presenting an ingenious double-header through Sunday with the Houston Ballet and the Paul Taylor Dance Company.

title: On a Straight And Narrow
description: The driver is lost in thought or feeling sleepy, and without realizing it is drifting off the side of the road or into the next lane. The AutoVue Lane Departure System from Iteris Inc., a subsidiary of Odetics Inc. in Anaheim, Calif., is an alarm intended to alert the driver before drifting too far.

title: The Tides Of Revenge In Basra Rise Quickly
description: Since the Baath Party was driven from power here earlier this week, images of people celebrating have competed with frightening scenes of a city where there is no law and thieves control the night.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.

title: Secret Recording Is Played At a HealthSouth Hearing
description: Richard M. Scrushy urged the chief financial officer of HealthSouth to ''fix'' the company's financial records, according to a secretly recorded conversation that was played yesterday in Federal District Court in Birmingham, Ala.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, LILLIAN
description: STEINBERG-Lillian. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Lillian Steinberg, a cherished friend who expressed an unwavering commitment to Jewish and humanitarian causes. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mrs. Steinberg's friends and loved ones. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Business Briefing column on Saturday about a warning from STMicroelectronics, Europe's biggest semiconductor maker, that it would fall short of its first-quarter revenue goal referred incorrectly to the timing. It was the first such warning, not the second in three months.

title: 'The Young Unknowns'
description: Directed by Catherine Jelski

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: EMS EXPECTS BREAK-EVEN QUARTER EMS Technologies , which makes systems for wireless communications and satellites, warned yesterday that a loss in its space and technology unit would hurt first-quarter results. The company said it now expected to break even, not earn a profit as analysts had forecast. The company said it expected to post total revenue for the quarter of $67 million. For the quarter a year earlier, it reported earnings of $2 million, or 20 cents a diluted share, on revenue of $70 million. Alfred Hansen, the chief executive, said the company began a major restructuring plan in late 2002 to address the effects of market conditions in the commercial space business. Shares fell $2.47, to $10.63. ( Reuters )

title: STATE STREET SAYS IT WILL ELIMINATE 1,800 MORE JOBS
description: The State Street Corporation said yesterday that it would cut as many as 1,800 more jobs, bringing the total to 13 percent of its work force this year. State Street, the world's largest custodian of assets, said it would eliminate positions at all levels. The company, based in Boston, expects the move to reduce expenses by $125 million for the rest of the year. In February, State Street said it would lay off 1,000 workers and close two offices in the United States after buying Deutsche Bank's record-keeping and securities-lending business. The company will take a pretax charge of $125 million to $175 million, decreasing second-quarter earnings per share by 25 to 35 cents.

title: Teammates Take Note Of Kidd's Criticism
description: Jason Kidd seldom speaks out critically about his teammates, but when he does, his words resonate with commanding power.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: TRADE SURPLUS GROWS Japan's current account surplus grew 2.4 percent in February from the month a year earlier, the first expansion in three months. The surplus, the broadest gauge of trade in goods, services, tourism and investment, stood at 1.46 trillion yen ($12.2 billion) as exports increased 7.7 percent as a result of strong demand in Asia. Japan's chronic services deficit also grew as more Japanese traveled overseas compared with February of last year.

title: News Organizations Remove Some Reporters From Units
description: As much of the story line of the Iraq war shifts from military action in the field to the events in Baghdad, news organizations began removing reporters yesterday from the American military units with which they have been traveling.

title: A Rally at Ground Zero for the Troops
description: Carrying American flags and pages from newspapers showing the toppling of a large statue of Saddam Hussein in Baghdad, thousands of union workers rallied yesterday by the site of the World Trade Center to say that victory had arrived.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: EVENTS

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Group To Plan Redevelopment
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday said that a 16-member task force will plan the redevelopment of the Homeport and its surrounding 36-acre, one-mile stretch of waterfront in Staten Island. The task force of representatives from the community, Staten Island elected officials and members of the Bloomberg administration will issue a request for proposals to develop the area in 60 days, and have a consultant in place after 90 days, the mayor said. ''This is not just another study group,'' Mr. Bloomberg said. Unlike other development plans for the area that have not been completed, this one would proceed, he said. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't have a car. I want to sell this in the market and get some money.''

title: Display of U.S. Flag Barred After Unfurling on Statue
description: Officers whooped and hollered in the Army's command center on Wednesday as they watched the televised scene of a United States marine draping an American flag over the face of a statue of Saddam Hussein in Baghdad.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Gen. George S. Patton and the siege of Metz misstated the date of the missile strike on the Iraqi leadership at the start of the war in Iraq. It was March 19, not March 18.

title: Casualties

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Ariba Restates Results
description: Ariba, whose software helps companies buy goods on the Internet, restated some results yesterday, increasing losses in 2000 and 2001 by $23.9 million. Costs of the revision deepened the loss for the latest quarter. Higher expenses from the accounting review widened the net loss by 2 cents a diluted share for the fiscal second quarter ended March 31. The company had forecast a net loss of 16 cents to 18 cents, the chief financial officer, James Frankola, said. Ariba failed to record some payments and stock options as expenses. The chairman, Keith Krach, also paid $1.2 million for chartered flights by the former chief executive, Larry Mueller, from September 2000 to July 2001, Ariba has said. United States rules require that payments by a principal holder to executives be treated as expenses paid on behalf of the company. The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating, Ariba has said. Ariba shares fell 6 cents, to $3.21.

description: Ace Gallery

title: Blown Save Is Becoming Bad Habit
description: MIAMI, April 10 - The Mets lost their second straight game in the ninth inning tonight, this time when Armando Benitez blew his second save in five days.

title: A Trip Back in Time Finds Mets' Alomar Where He Lives
description: The real Roberto Alomar, the one the Mets rarely saw during a miserable season last year, can be found an hour south of San Juan, off the highway, by turning at a gas station and knocking on the door of the middle of the three Alomar houses here.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: NEW BRUNSWICK: RULING ON ACCUSED CHILD KILLER A judge will rule on Monday whether to allow publication of the name of a 10-year-old boy accused of sexually assaulting and killing a 3-year-old. Lawyers for four newspapers yesterday urged Judge Roger Daley, a family court judge, to allow publication of the suspect's name and open future hearings to the public. Judge Daley barred reporters from yesterday's hearing, over the objections of the newspapers' lawyers. The state public defender's office opposed the motions, and the family of Amir Beeks, the child slain on March 26, asked for closed hearings. The New York Times and The Newark Star-Ledger argued for open hearings, and The Record of Hackensack and The Home News Tribune of East Brunswick appealed to the judge to lift a ban on the suspect's name and photograph.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: With Bella Via, Long Island City in Queens takes a big step up from red sauce and Frank Sinatra. It's a small neighborhood restaurant, but fresh, grilled dishes and imaginative thin-crust pizzas make it a large presence on Vernon Boulevard, which, if it is the ''beautiful street'' of the restaurant's name, proves that the owners have a rich sense of humor.

title: Ralph Eugene Meatyard
description: 'The Family Album of Lucybelle Crater'

title: Jean-Pierre Moueix, 89, French Wine Figure, Dies
description: Jean-Pierre Moueix, a Bordeaux wine merchant and chateau owner who first made the world aware of what is now one of the most fabled of that region's properties, Chteau Ptrus, died on March 28 at his home in Libourne, 20 miles east of Bordeaux. He was 89 and had been retired from the family business since 1978.

title: Isles' Godard Suspended for Aiding Embattled Teammate
description: The National Hockey League punished the Islanders today for attempting to stick up for their star center, Aleksei Yashin, but the Islanders did not feel particularly contrite. If they need to get tougher, they will.

title: U.S. digs in on lesser role for UN
description: WASHINGTON:  The United States made it clear Thursday that it would not give the United Nations more than a secondary role in postwar Iraq, to be focused on filling humanitarian needs.

description: KELLY-Thomas F. Sr., The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Thomas F. Kelly Sr., associated with The Times from January 1972 until retiring in October 1980.

title: McGreevey Meets Mayors, and Feels a Chill
description: A few weeks after James E. McGreevey was sworn in as governor in January 2002, he spoke before a group of New Jersey mayors in the State House and was greeted like a conquering hero.

title: Money Bill for War Stalls Over Alaska Senator's Insistence on Special Interest Extras
description: Increasingly frantic to pass a bill to pay for the war in Iraq before they leave for a spring recess, Senate and House leaders struggled today to persuade a leading senator to drop his insistence on a series of special interest provisions.

title: Executives See Weak Economy Continuing
description: Chief executives of large companies, perhaps the most accurate economic forecasters recently, expect the economy to remain weak over the next six months but do not foresee a new recession, according to a survey released yesterday.

title: Federal Agency Issues Guidelines On Handling Infected Students
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention yesterday issued the first guidelines for school administrators and health officials in determining what to do if a student has SARS, the mysterious respiratory disease. Students who have been exposed to SARS and who do not have fever, cough, sneezing or other respiratory symptoms should be allowed to attend school, but should be vigilant for onset of symptoms of SARS, the federal health agency said.

title: Plan to Alter A Yardstick For Pensions
description: Corporations would find billions of dollars of pension shortfalls eliminated overnight under a proposal being prepared to address a longstanding issue in pension accounting.

title: In Far East of Many Muslims, Press Is Anti-U.S. but Hardly Pro-Jihad
description: ''Heartening,'' one Filipino columnist wrote today after watching scenes of cheering Iraqis on television. But, he added, ''it's still an unjust war.''

description: THE PIECES FROM BERLIN

title: Turkey Sending Military Observers to Watch Kurds; U.S. Warns Against Further Moves
description: Turkish leaders said today that they were sending military observers to monitor Kurdish forces in the Iraqi city of Kirkuk, while American officials sought to discourage Turkey from any steps beyond that.

title: Conquest And Neglect
description: Credit where credit is due: the hawks were right to say that a whiff of precision-guided grapeshot would lead to the collapse of Saddam Hussein's regime. But even skeptics about this war expected a military victory. (''Of course we'll win on the battlefield, probably with ease'' was the opening line of my start-of-the-war column.) Instead, we worried -- and continue to worry -- about what would follow. As another skeptic, Michael Kinsley of Slate, wrote yesterday: ''I do hope to be proven wrong. But it hasn't happened yet.''

title: CAMPBELL DROPS INTERIM FROM DIVISION PRESIDENT'S TITLE
description: Campbell Soup said yesterday that it had named Larry S. McWilliams president of its North America Soup division, which has had four consecutive years of declining sales. Campbell, the world's biggest soup maker, named Mr. McWilliams interim president of the soup division, its biggest business, in August. The division had sales of $2.5 billion in the fiscal year that ended last July. Mr. McWilliams, 47, has focused on increasing soup sales since joining the company in February 2001, leading the introduction of a line of single-serving microwaveable soups, a spokeswoman said.

title: Bureau Never Administered Polygraph Test To 30-Year Agent Who Handled Informer
description: A former F.B.I. agent arrested on Wednesday in an espionage case had not been given a polygraph test in his nearly 30 years with the bureau, and lax oversight of his relationship with an informer now accused of being a Chinese double-agent appears to have violated numerous policies, bureau officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPIN, PAUL J.
description: HALPIN-Paul J. Husband of the late Catherine Halpin, father of Jeannette Thatcher, Paula Meyer, Sister Catherine Halpin, RDC and James Halpin. Brother of the late Br. John Halpin and the late Rev. Leo Halpin. Mass of Christian burial St. Raymond's Church, Bronx on Friday, April 11 at 10:45AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to KICS, Kids in Crisis Support, 2919 Davis Ford Road, Maryville, TN 37804. McGrath & Sons FH. (914)-337-6770.

title: Sports of The Times; The Hall of Fame Will Tolerate No Dissent
description: THE classic baseball movie ''Bull Durham'' ends with a voiceover and two quotations about the national pastime, one from Walt Whitman. Annie Savoy, the aptly named brainy baseball Annie played by Susan Sarandon, says: ''Walt Whitman once said: 'I see great things in baseball, it's our game. The American game. It will repair our losses and be a blessing to us.'''

title: Ambaji Shinde, 85, Designer Of Jewelry for the Wealthy
description: Ambaji Shinde, who brought design sensibilities honed under the maharajahs to the grandeur of the pieces he created as the principal designer at the New York jeweler Harry Winston, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: Crazy Shrink Treats The Last Sane Man
description: The poster for the psych-out comedy ''Anger Management'' is a peak of high concept: Adam Sandler and Jack Nicholson, nose to nose, jaws cocked to full bellow. That poster shot plays on the public perceptions of both: Mr. Sandler, the regular-guy screen idol who usually plays men with a boiling point of 12 degrees Fahrenheit, and Mr. Nicholson, the man who, in real life, whipped a golf club out of his trunk to settle a traffic argument. But what passes for a twist in this drab and punchless movie is that Mr. Sandler plays against a type he has virtually trademarked.

title: Hong Kong Resists Wide Quarantine for Mystery Illness
description: Despite growing international pressure to halt the spread of a new respiratory disease here, Hong Kong officials are strongly resisting the kind of broad quarantines that other countries have imposed, taking only another modest step today to control the movements of potentially infected people.

title: Ellen Takata and Jos Lerma
description: Southfirst

title: Victims to Be Honored Equally On 9/11 Memorial, Panel Says
description: Officials overseeing the creation of a memorial to victims of the World Trade Center attack rebuffed a request yesterday from a group of New York City firefighters for separate recognition of uniformed rescue workers on the memorial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, DAVID G.
description: GRAY-David G. Passed away peacefully on April 9, 2003. He was a retired partner of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett. A kind and generous soul survived by his wife, Diane; son Neil; brother Larry and many nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Mary Manning-Walsh Home, 1339 York Ave., New York, NY 10021.

title: Lagos Journal; Oil, Oil Everywhere, Except at the Gas Pumps
description: In the hottest month of the year, just days from the bare-knuckle brawl known here as elections, Africa's most populous city, the commercial hub of the world's sixth-largest oil producer, faces a gasoline shortage.

title: Discovery Offers Hope to Soldier's Family
description: The Army is holding out hope for the life of a soldier captured two weeks ago in Iraq, saying the discovery of American uniforms in Baghdad suggested that he and six other missing soldiers were being moved around.

title: FIRST FEDERAL CAPITAL AGREES TO BUY LIBERTY BANCSHARES
description: First Federal Capital, a Wisconsin savings and loan, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Liberty Bancshares for $78 million. First Federal bought seven banking offices in Minnesota in the last year, including four in large food stores, it said. The Liberty Bancshares purchase will give it an office in St. Paul and help it to expand into Minneapolis, a spokesman said.

title: Cruising Through With Precision
description: In George Coleman's sort of jazz, displays of speed are essential. But so is density, weightiness, and soul. How he links up all those attributes is the story of hard bop, the late-50's-to-early-60's category that he's usually associated with. But it's also the story of his current quartet, which has shaped up into a tight, organized band over the last few years.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Body Of Woman Missing In 2000 Is Found
description: The body of a 21-year-old woman who was reported missing in September 2000 has been discovered, and the police have arrested a 24-year-old Bronx man, charging him with her murder, the authorities said. After the woman, Talina Bryant, left, was reported missing by her mother, her apartment in Norwood was searched, and the police determined that a crime had occurred there, but an investigation yielded no results. In January, new information led detectives to the suspect, David Mundo, of Story Avenue in Castle Hill. Ms. Bryant's body was found in a lot near 237th Street and Bullard Avenue in Wakefield, the police said, but they did not say when it was found, or whether or not she knew Mr. Mundo. Mr. Mundo was also charged with conspiracy to commit murder in another case, said Steven Reed, a spokesman for the Bronx district attorney. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a New York City Fire Department study of neighborhoods where eight firehouses are scheduled to close referred incorrectly to response times there. They are well below the city average of 4 minutes 46 seconds, not well above.

title: Gals, Gams and Glamour
description: IT'S raining women in the glamour-saturated new production of ''Nine,'' Maury Yeston's 1982 musical portrait of the mind of a movie director. From the moment the first shapely pair of legs are seen insinuating their way down a heaven-scraping spiral staircase in David Leveaux's hyperelegant revival, ''Nine'' is flooded to the drowning point in glossy, exotic images of femininity.

title: Soaring Voices in Sacred Works
description: The New York premiere of a piece of music is generally a notable event, even when the piece is three centuries old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIESSBACH, SISTER JOSEPH DOLORES
description: SPIESSBACH-Sister Joseph Dolores, beloved member of the Sisters of Charity, Convent of Mary the Queen, died Wednesday, April 9, 2003. She is the dear sister of Rosemary and Joseph Spiessbach. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark Street, Yonkers, NY on Friday 1-8 P.M. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:30 A.M. at the convent. Interment to follow at St. Teresa's Cemetery, Summit, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY 10471.

title: Refusal to Fire Unattractive Saleswoman Led to Dismissal, Suit Contends
description: It was not the kind of order that Elysa Yanowitz, a regional sales manager for a giant cosmetics company, was used to hearing.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 10, 2003

title: A Disparate Collection Yields Surprising Links
description: A drawing can be: A blotchy inkblot. Irregular rows of holes punched in a sheet of paper. A line 295 feet long on a roll of paper wrapped around a core. The imprint made on a protective sheet of paper by a watercolor soaked in a flood. Or it can be something more conventional: a precise rendition of a human skull.

title: Sodden Lot Will Be Site of Protests Tomorrow
description: With the proper historical marker, it could pass for just another small Civil War battleground. Then again, cleared of trees, grassy and unoccupied, the five-acre lot half a mile from the main entrance to Augusta National Golf Club would also make a good picnic ground.

title: An Increase in Aircraft Orders Narrowed the U.S. Trade Deficit in February
description: The trade deficit unexpectedly narrowed in February, the Commerce Department reported today, as aircraft exports surged and American companies spent less on imported equipment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLDORF, AUDREY
description: HOLLDORF - Audrey. The Producer Circle Company extends heartfelt sympathy to our colleague Maryanne Dittmann, her sister Virginia and brother William on the loss of their mother. Graced with warmth and humor, Audrey was a cherished friend to all of us for many years. With deepest condolences to the family. Martin Richards Sam Crothers Monique Bell Dan Gallagher Michael Milton

title: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: New Powers For Voodoo
description: Voodoo adherents will now be allowed to perform legally binding marriages as President Jean-Bertrand Aristide has given official religious status to the practice. Voodoo, which developed among slaves, blends African beliefs and Roman Catholic rituals and has influenced most parts of Haitian daily life and culture, from the arts to literature to politics. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: `First Steps'; Ellen Takata and Jos Lerma; Tara Donovan
description: `First Steps: Emerging Artists From Japan'

title: Airlines Fear the Loneliness Will Persist
description: The nation's airlines, which blamed the war in Iraq for a plunge in business that forced the layoffs of more than 10,000 employees and the elimination of dozens of flights, are not expecting the postwar era to be much brighter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTUN, ROSE
description: CARTUN-Rose. Died April 10th, 2003 at age 94. Retired bookkeeper from Brooklyn. Widow of beloved husband Murray. Caring sister of Harold Gorenfeld. Devoted mother of Joel and the late Dorothy Amdurer. Dear mother-in-law of Susan Cartun and Arthur Amdurer. Proud grandmother of Alissa, Jeff, Deena and David and great-grandmother of Isaac.

title: Nostalgia Abounds as the Concorde's End Is Set
description: After 27 years of supersonic travel lofting rock stars, executives and the rest of the Champagne set across the Atlantic, British Airways and Air France said today that they would retire their fleets of Concordes this year.

title: Shopping List | Vision Instruments
description: SEEING is believing, especially when the object is up close and possibly personal. As bird-watching, fly-fishing, hiking, boating, baseball, open-air entertainment and party seasons seriously begin, a sharp third eye -- a great monocular or binocular -- could become your best friend. And that's just on land. For reaching to the heavens, a high-powered telescope could turn even couch potatoes into explorers of the universe. SUZANNE HAMLIN

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: RATE UNCHANGED For the second consecutive month, the Bank of England left interest rates unchanged at 3.75 percent, the lowest in almost half a century. Economists said, however, that pressure was building for a cut in rates next month to offset a decline in consumer confidence provoked by the war in Iraq and a broader economic slowdown. Manufacturers are also pressing for lower interest rates, despite worries that British inflation is rising beyond the Bank of England's 2.5 percent target.

title: Times Change, Officials Say, and So Firehouses Are Closing
description: Some of the most distinguished buildings in northern Brooklyn are firehouses, many of them built more than a century ago to protect the borough's densely populated warrens of wooden tenements.

title: Police Try to Defend Practice Of Debriefing Demonstrators
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly yesterday defended the department's questioning of hundreds of arrested antiwar protesters about their involvement in political groups and demonstrations -- a practice he ordered halted after it came to light on Tuesday -- saying it was neither illegal nor unconstitutional.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: On Capitol Hill, New Maneuvers Over the War
description: Waving tiny American flags and singing ''God Bless America,'' members of the House of Representatives staged a rally in the Capitol today to salute the troops in Iraq, an apparent show of patriotic unity on the war. But in the Capitol, it turns out, things are not always as they appear.

title: My First Day of Freedom
description: The downfall of Saddam Hussein's regime, metaphorically incarnate in the toppling of his statue in Firdos Square in Baghdad, filled me with hope.

title: Loss Widens at Barnes & Noble
description: Barnes & Noble Inc., the bookseller, said yesterday that its fiscal first-quarter loss would be wider than forecast because sales slowed as consumers stayed home to watch televised coverage of the war in Iraq.

title: Fall of a Northern City, Suicide Bombing on Marines, Killing of a Cleric
description: As Kirkuk fell in the north, American and British troops made important advances. But they also encountered heavy resistance and uncovered worrisome signs that the war was far from over. An important Muslim cleric was killed in Najaf, a suicide bomber wounded four marines in Baghdad and President Bush went on Iraqi television to reassure the Iraqi people of America's intentions. About two-thirds of Iraq has come under American and British control but coalition forces have not found Mr. Hussein or the weapons of mass destructions he was believed to possess.

title: Adding Layers Of Drama To Beethoven
description: So often do we cast Alfred Brendel as metaphysician -- as some pillar of rectitude helping to hold up the Classical-era piano literature -- that we forget how much a man of the theater he is. The Third Piano Concerto is one of Beethoven's more straightforward musical narratives, but with the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Monday night, Mr. Brendel added layers of drama that sat listeners up in their seats.

title: Same Rules for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAELITE, BELLE
description: ISRAELITE-Belle, April 9, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Cherished and devoted mother of Renee Hirsch, Ruth Seiger Maisel and David Israelite. Loving mother-in-law of Melvin Hirsch, Jerome Maisel, Carolyn Israelite and the late Martin Seiger. Adored grandmother of Steven Hirsch and his wife Fran; Clifford Hirsch and his wife Marilyn; Leonard Hirsch; Kenneth Seiger; Douglas Israelite and his wife Nathalie and the late Janet Beth Seiger. Treasured greatgrandmother of Jennifer and Zachary Hirsch; Rachel and Abigail Hirsch and Kira and Julie Israelite. Devoted and esteemed lifetime champion of Hadassah. Belle was as beautiful as her name. Her life was a blessing. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hadassah.

title: Sony Hires Agency For Aiwa Division
description: The Sony Corporation in Tokyo has tentatively named Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., as global agency of record on the consolidated creative account of its Aiwa division, which had been inactive or handled on a project basis in different regions. Billings were estimated at $50 million.

title: For Military Intelligence, A New Favorite Commando
description: Although hardly a household name from a Pentagon filled with vivid and public personalities, Dr. Stephen A. Cambone, the first under secretary of defense for intelligence, has become a favored bureaucratic commando for Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld.

title: Hudsons Survive. The Dealer Does, Too.
description: MILLER MOTORS HUDSON sits at Cross and River Streets in Ypsilanti, Mich., just as it has since 1929. Jack Miller goes to work there each day, as he has since 1953, when he worked for his father, Carl, and he still sells and services Hudsons. Business is necessarily limited. The last new Hudson was made in 1957. ''I'm a man in a time warp,'' he said.

title: Planning the 9/11 Memorial
description: Yesterday, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation introduced a 13-member jury to judge an international competition for the design of a memorial to the victims of 9/11. The memorial that will eventually be built at ground zero is the part of the downtown renovation closest to the heart of most New Yorkers. By any measure, the jury is a balanced, distinguished collection of individuals, including Maya Lin and Vartan Gregorian, as well as architects, art historians and a representative of the families of 9/11 victims.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Grows
description: Japan's current account surplus grew 2.4 percent in February from the month a year earlier, the first expansion in three months. The surplus, the broadest gauge of trade in goods, services, tourism and investment, stood at 1.46 trillion yen ($12.2 billion) as exports increased 7.7 percent as a result of strong demand in Asia. Japan's chronic services deficit also grew as more Japanese traveled overseas compared with February of last year.

title: Tax Cut Deal Is Set Back, but House and Senate Republicans Resume Talks
description: A deal struck by House and Senate negotiators on Wednesday to postpone a decision on how large a tax cut to allow unraveled today after a ruling by the Senate parliamentarian that would have limited the reduction this year to less than half of what President Bush requested.

title: Truth About Vegan Diet
description: To the Editor:

title: Power Company Stresses Its Commitment to Brazil
description: ''Nobody invests $4 billion to change their mind later,'' read the advertisements in leading Brazilian newspapers. The ads are meant to deliver a clear message from the AES Corporation to its customers, the markets and the government.

description: SEIDENBERG-Judy. A woman of great kindness, whose friendship was dear to all she knew. A poet, fitness guru and lover of life. Beloved office manager of 18 years for Dr. Jonathan Z. description: House members endorsed oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge tonight as they considered a wide-ranging energy measure that seeks to spur domestic energy production and provides tax incentives to oil and power companies.

title: Allies Widen Hold on Iraq; Civil Strife on Rise
description: Northern Iraq's oil capital, Kirkuk, fell on Thursday to a raucous army of Kurdish fighters who rolled into the city in pickup trucks, setting off new political tensions with Turkey, whose leaders oppose Kurdish dominion over the region's abundant resources.

description: The following is the full text of the daily Pentagon press briefing as recorded by Federal News Service.

title: In Art Deco, Perfection Is King
description: A prime criterion in the evaluation of important 18th-century American antiques is ''original finish,'' which means, technically, that the surface of a piece is untouched. At auction previews, collectors and experts can be seen examining scruffy cabinets, looking for telltale signs of refinishing in cracked shellac.

title: Hunting Top Iraqis, U.S. Attacks Mosque
description: American forces searching for Saddam Hussein attacked a mosque in Baghdad and later bombed it, but appear to have missed an opportunity to kill or capture members of the Iraqi leadership.

title: Harvard Adopts New Rules for Early-Admission Applicants
description: Reversing an admissions policy it announced last year, Harvard announced yesterday that as of this fall it would no longer allow applicants who file for early admission to apply early at other colleges.

title: Crooner Warms to His Task
description: In his superb new cabaret act at the Cafe Carlyle, James Naughton, like Dean Martin before him, builds a bridge between the crooning styles of Bing Crosby and Elvis Presley. But Mr. Naughton, the singer, actor and director whose deep, caressing voice has the resonance of a bass clarinet, does it in a way that avoids Martin's slippery, gin-soaked insinuation.

title: Look Who's Back: 'Boys' of Vietnam
description: The war is winding down here, and no one is happier than the old guys of the MC-130 Combat Talon squadron from Duke Field, Fla.

title: A Painter Who Tried to Change With a Changing World
description: The last big Frederic Remington show in a major East Coast museum was at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1989. And some who saw it fervently hoped that it would be a once-in-a-lifetime event. But no. Fourteen years later, the painter of Wild West kitsch is back in an august museum setting, this time the National Gallery of Art.

Survived by her grandchildren, Julie and Tom and her greatgrandchildren Spencer and Cole. There are no words to describe how much she will be missed. title: Downtown Flair, Dominican Flavor
description: By 1 a.m., the only creatures in the place with enough room to move about freely were the tropical fish in the three illuminated, distorted tanks. The young humans at the Arka Lounge in Washington Heights crowded into low-slung, cushioned seats; flirted at the slick, arced bar; or found a little space to dance as the D.J. maneuvered from Spanish rock to 1980's pop to merengue to hip-hop. Aside from myself and a friend, the crowd was largely Dominican and professional, raised, or at least college-educated, in the United States. And three years ago, few of them imagined a place like Arka would ever exist.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the On Stage and Off column last Friday about the potential effect on ticket sales for ''Take Me Out'' by Richard Greenberg if it won the Pulitzer Prize for drama misstated the experience of last year's winner, ''Topdog/Underdog.'' It indeed recouped its investors' money before closing last August. (On Monday the 2003 prize went to ''Anna in the Tropics'' by Nilo Cruz.)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Economic Growth Slows
description: Singapore's economy expanded less than expected in the first quarter, a sign that a global slump in demand for semiconductors and other electronics may have curbed growth elsewhere in Asia. Gross domestic product grew at an annual 0.7 percent pace in the quarter, according to an early estimate by the Ministry of Trade and Industry. (Bloomberg News)

description: CAIRO, April 11  Ten men, including some suspects in the bombing of the United States destroyer Cole, escaped from a high-security Yemeni prison today, according to Yemeni officials.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hospital's Debt Rating Reduced
description: A bond-rating firm lowered its assessment of Mount Sinai-N.Y.U. Health System's bonds yesterday, putting them below investment grade for the first time since Mount Sinai Hospital and NYU Hospitals Center merged in 1998. The firm, Fitch Ratings, said that the ''decline in financial performance of the system and the significant challenges faced by the system, primarily Mount Sinai Hospital'' prompted the lowering of its rating to BB+ from BBB-. The outlook on the bonds was also revised from negative (when it was classified investment grade) to stable. Last week, Mount Sinai reported losing $72 million last year and said it may lose at least that much this year. The hospital's spokesman was not available for comment last night.

title: A Gilded Age of Sumptuous Dining Comes to a Close in the St. Regis Hotel
description: Lespinasse, the airy, gilded four-star restaurant in the St. Regis Hotel that was for 12 years the preserve of European and corporate royalty, celebrities and commoners able to afford its sumptuousness announced yesterday that it would close April 19.

title: The War, Not Over, Now Seems Far Away for Some

description: STIRRING a pot of simmering tapioca pudding on the old stove in our Vermont farmhouse, I always find my eyes drawn to the hummingbirds that have taken a particular fancy to several of the flowers potted in old crocks on the back porch.

title: City Unemployment Rate Rose Again in February
description: The unemployment rate in New York City climbed to 8.8 percent in February, from 8.6 percent in January, while dropping slightly in the suburbs and upstate, according to state figures released yesterday. Jobs in the city continued to decline in construction, manufacturing, the film industry and finance, and to increase in health services.

title: The News We Kept To Ourselves
description: Over the last dozen years I made 13 trips to Baghdad to lobby the government to keep CNN's Baghdad bureau open and to arrange interviews with Iraqi leaders. Each time I visited, I became more distressed by what I saw and heard -- awful things that could not be reported because doing so would have jeopardized the lives of Iraqis, particularly those on our Baghdad staff.

title: New Gigs For the Wizard Of Baghdad
description: IF New York political leaders are as shrewd as they want us to believe they are, they will lose no time in tracking down Muhammad Said al-Sahhaf and signing him to a personal services contract. Gov. George E. Pataki, in particular, could use him as a tonic for approval ratings that have begun to look a bit wan.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Indian Point Park, the former amusement attraction in Buchanan, N.Y., on the property now occupied by the Indian Point nuclear power plant, referred incorrectly to the halt in power plant development after the Three Mile Island accident, of 1979. Although no plants have since been ordered, more than half the plants now operating were completed in the 1980's.

title: Little Change in Dropout Rate, And Many Graduate Late
description: The percentage of students who dropped out of New York City high schools declined minutely last year, the Education Department said yesterday, even as only half of those scheduled to graduate last June did so.

description: It was not drugs, brawls or the usual teenage recklessness that landed Bayram A. in trouble, confronting him with the prospect of as many as five years in prison.

title: Attack on Judicial Nominee Leads Panel to Delay Vote
description: The Republican majority on the Senate Judiciary Committee delayed a vote today on an Arkansas lawyer's nomination to the federal bench, after Democrats attacked his writings on religion, abortion and the role of women.

title: More Arrests Made In 9/11 Fraud Cases
description: A continuing crackdown on people who have attempted to defraud federal relief programs and private charities related to the 9/11 attack has resulted in the recent arrests of 33 people, who together falsely claimed nearly $135,000 in government and charitable funds, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Uruguay: Bond Exchange Sought
description: Uruguay asked bondholders to swap as much as $6.5 billion of debt due through 2027 for new securities that have longer maturities and are worth less, a transaction Standard & Poor's said would constitute a default. Uruguay wants at least 80 percent of bondholders to accept new securities that mature five years later and carry the same interest as the debt they own, the economy minister, Alejandro Atchugarry, said at a news conference. S.& P. cut the government's long-term foreign currency rating to CC from CCC and said it would lower it to ''selective default'' in mid-May if a sufficient number of bondholders take part in the exchange. (Bloomberg News)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the first-quarter financial results of Yahoo misstated the number of subscribers to its various fee-based services. It is 2.9 million, not 2.7 million.

title: In Brazil, Weak Market Gives Merger Better Chance
description: The News Corporation's takeover of DirecTV would give Rupert Murdoch control of the two main satellite television operators in Latin America and a virtual monopoly in Brazil, the region's largest market.

title: New Hampshire-Minnesota Final
description: Two goals by Steve Saviano in the second period helped New Hampshire defeat top-seeded Cornell, 3-2, this afternoon and advance to the N.C.A.A. Division I championship game.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: N.J. Transit Announces Service Changes
description: New Jersey Transit has announced an array of immediate and future changes, including more frequent cleaning of buses and train cars, faster ticket-vending machines, online monthly ticket purchases and more parking spaces at stations. The changes are all aimed at improving customer service on the nation's third-largest public-transit system. George Warrington, executive director of the agency, said that the changes were the result of research among 100 agency employees and 15,000 of its customers. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rate Unchanged
description: For the second consecutive month, the Bank of England left interest rates unchanged at 3.75 percent, the lowest in almost half a century. Economists said, however, that pressure was building for a cut in rates next month to offset a decline in consumer confidence provoked by the war in Iraq and a broader economic slowdown. Manufacturers are also pressing for lower interest rates, despite worries that British inflation is rising beyond the Bank of England's 2.5 percent target.

title: Lynch to Return to the U.S. on Saturday

title: No Longer Spry, Sprewell Must Find New Ways to Contribute

title: Jutta Hipp, 78, Jazz Pianist With a Lean, Percussive Style

title: For Bikers, All Roads Lead to Moab
description: WE are standing near the Abyss Viewpoint on the famed Slickrock Trail in Moab, Utah. The morning sunlight glows. A breeze whistles. The sky is the color of oceans, of opals, of piercing blue eyes. Before us, red rock cliffs and gullies ripple to the horizon. The peace is absolute.
