title: TECO ENERGY, FLORIDA UTILITY, CUTS DIVIDEND BY 46%
description: Teco Energy Inc., which owns the electric utility in Tampa, Fla., will cut its shareholder payout by 46 percent to save cash and maintain its investment-grade debt ratings. The company said that in May it would cut its quarterly dividend to 19 cents a share from 35.5 cents. Teco said it got $350 million in bank credit and exceeded its goal of raising $900 million. Teco said it would buy out its partner in four power plants after Moody's Investors Service raised concern about financing for the projects.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Relations With Thailand Resume
description: Cambodia and Thailand agreed to resume full diplomatic relations, which were suspended in January after after angry mobs vandalized the Thai Embassy in Phnom Penh and destroyed Thai-owned businesses. In response, Thailand shut its borders with Cambodia, withdrew its ambassador -- who had fled the embassy -- and ordered the Cambodian envoy in Bangkok to leave. Cambodia later paid Thailand $5.9 million for the destruction of the embassy. Thai business owners are seeking $46.8 million for damages to their properties. The riot was sparked by rumors that a Thai actress had said the Angkor temples, which have been contested over the centuries, belonged to Thailand. The announcement that relations were being resumed was made near the temples, in Siem Reap, which means ''victory over Siam,'' the historical name for Thailand. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Battling the spread of SARS, Asian nations escalate travel restrictions
description: HONG KONG:  Asian nations battling the spread of a killer disease across land, sea and air borders imposed dramatic new restrictions Friday on all travelers suspected of infection.

title: Nigerian Elections Seen as Test for Civilian Rule
description: Nigerians are trying to do what they have never managed before: move from one democratically elected civilian government to another, while keeping the nation's generals in their barracks.

title: Mideast Peace?: The Key to Peace Is a Stable Gulf
description: When President Bush and the British prime minister, Tony Blair, met this week in Hillsborough, Northern Ireland, they announced an all-out push to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict by implementing the "road map," the Middle East peace initiative that envisions a Palestinian state by 2005. Britain, along with France and other nations in Europe and the Arab world, have declared that a Mideast peace settlement is the only way to bring stability to the Arab world. The Bush administration, though, has treated the Israeli-Palestinian conflict as one problem that must compete with many others, like getting rid of Saddam Hussein.

title: A Brief History of the Multiverse

What would be the effect? The universe would look very different -- so different, in fact, that there wouldn't be anyone around to see the result, because the existence of life depends rather critically on the actual settings that Mother Nature selected.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Steel Maker's Profit Rises
description: The world's second-largest steel maker, Posco, said yesterday that first-quarter profit more than doubled to the highest in three years after increases in construction and car sales drove prices higher. Net income rose to 469 billion won ($382 million) from 190 billion won a year earlier, and sales climbed 23 percent, to 3.26 trillion won, the company said. The company's stock price declined, however, as demand for steel has cooled this year along with the South Korean economy.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Expects Loss
description: Mitsui Trust Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it expected to post a loss of 50 billion yen ($417 million) in the year that ended March 31 because of the weak stock market. The bank, one of the 10 largest in Japan, previously expected a profit of 55 billion yen. Mitsui Trust's stockholdings are estimated to be twice as large as its core capital, making the bank highly vulnerable to the performance of the stock market. Still, last year's loss is just one-fifth the size of the previous year's.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Software Profit Rises

Sage said that while revenue in its British business grew 5 percent, tough market conditions in mainland Europe, particularly France and Germany, led to a 1 percent fall in revenue there. The company, which is based in Newcastle, has withstood the technology downturn reasonably well because it provides services that are essential to its customer base of small and medium-size companies. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUGHTON, LAURA RICHARDSON
description: HOUGHTON-Laura Richardson, 102, died quietly April 9, 2003, at her home in Corning, NY. Wife of Amory Houghton, former Chairman of Corning Glass Works and American Ambassador to France under President Dwight D. Eisenhower, Mrs. Houghton was born in Providence, RI. A graduate of Milton Academy in Milton, MA, she moved to Corning with her husband in 1921. Their marriage lasted six months shy of sixty years. In the late 1950's, The Herald Tribune bestowed the name ''L'Ambassadrice Souriante'' (the Smiling Ambassadress) to Mrs. Houghton. The paper also referred to her as ''the undisputed First Lady of the Diplomatic Corps and of the American Colony in Paris.'' ''I would say she was the most gracious woman I ever knew,'' said Thomas Buechner, former Director of the Brooklyn Museum of Art and the Corning Museum of Glass. She served on the Boards of national institutions such as the Girl Scouts of America, Project Hope and Hobart and William Smith College; and numerous local charities. She received two Honorary Degrees. Once asked to become President of the Girl Scouts of America, she declined citing the need to be near her family. Several years later, she accepted the Vice-Chairmanship. ''She possessed deep personal beliefs which brooked no shoddy behavior,'' said her son, Congressman Amory Houghton, Jr. (R-NY). ''She had the endearing capacity for laughter in happy times, contagious; in times of stress, lightening the load.'' ''When someone of her stature passes away, we have to say a generation is going,'' said Thomas P. Dimitroff, a noted Corning historian. ''She was a lady in the best sense of the word.'' Mrs. Houghton is survived by four children: Elizabeth H. Weinberg, Congressman Amory Houghton, Jr., James R. Houghton, Chairman and CEO of Corning Inc., and the Reverend Alanson R. Houghton II, 18 grandchildren, and 32 great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by daughter, Laura H. Beer, on September 22, 2000. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, April 16 at 10AM at Christ Episcopal Church in Corning, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in memory of Mrs. Houghton to: Girl Scouts-Seven Lakes Council, Inc., 300 Route 318, Phelps, NY 14532-9315.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEINBERGER, DR. BERNARD. STEINBERGER, BERNARD, MD. OB
description: STEINBERGER-Dr. Bernard. Steinberger, Bernard, MD. OBYN, DOG, FACS, ACOG, AMA/d, 78, of Highland Beach, FL, passed away on April 8, 2003. Best friend and most deeply beloved husband of Sandy Berkowitz - Steinber ger. Devoted father to Dr. Robert, Carl, Joshua and Paul. Grandfather of Michelle and Amanda. Loving and loved stepfather to Jill and Jay Glasser, David Forrest and Glen Berkowitz, and stepgrandfather to Max, Zachary, and Richard Glasser. Born on October 22, 1924 to Jack Steinberger and Mollie Kirschenbaum, in Brooklyn, NY. Brother of Marvin Steinberger (deceased). World War II Vet, 2nd Lieutenant, US Airforce. Dr. Steinberger graduated from Columbia Medical School, and SUNY Downstate Medical Center '51. Interned '51-'52 Jewish Hospital, Brooklyn, NY. '52-'55 Resident OB/GYN Maimonides Medical Center, Brooklyn, NY. Cons. Emeritus KHH, St. Joseph's-St. John's Hospital, Far Rockaway, NY. He retired in 1990 from Maimonides Medical Center and St. John's. He was a wonderful, caring doctor who was vigorously involved in the total care of his patients, and will always be remembered as a dedicated and compassionate practitioner of medicine. He will be deeply missed and remembered with love by his families, friends, and everyone he touched. In his memory donations may be made to: The Dr. Bernard Steinberger National Fragile-X-Foundation, 4408 Intracoastal Drive, Highland Beach, FL. 33487. Funeral Sunday, April 13, 2003 at 12 noon from Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Airline Cuts Staff
description: The Scandinavian Airlines System said that it would cut 4,000 jobs, about 12 percent of its work force, as part of an overhaul to be completed by 2005. Scandinavian, the joint carrier of Sweden, Denmark and Norway, warned that it would have to reduce costs by 25 percent to 40 percent to cope with the downturn in business travel and increased competition from budget airlines. Most of the layoffs will be from support functions like ground services, ticketing and technical employees. The airline is also freezing pay for pilots and increasing the number of hours they spend flying by more than 40 percent. Scandinavian Airlines hopes to save 6 billion to 8 billion kronor ($706 million to $942 million). Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

The layoffs are in addition to the 1,500 jobs the company, which is based in New York, announced it would eliminate in the 12 to 18 months after it acquired American General for $23 billion in August 2001. A.I.G., which has 80,000 employees, bought American General, which is based in Houston, to gain $120 billion in assets, 12 million customers and $400 million in pretax cost savings. The company said in February that those savings ''have been largely realized.''

The company, based in Houston, now expects a profit of 13 cents to 14 cents a share, excluding discontinued businesses and the effect of changes in accounting. Net income a share was 22 cents for the first quarter of 2002. Sales from the company's oil field segment fell 4 to 6 percent from the fourth quarter of 2002. The company expects to report first-quarter earnings before trading starts on April 22. It previously forecast earnings of 17 cents to 20 cents.

title: A Doctor (and Inmate) at Auschwitz
description: Every dramatization of the Holocaust has to decide for itself at what point the depiction of unimaginable suffering becomes too much to bear, and the horror threatens to induce a defensive numbness and revulsion instead of empathy. ''Out of the Ashes,'' a Showtime original movie that tells the true story of Gisella Perl, a Jewish gynecologist who was forced to assist Josef Mengele in his hideous medical experiments at Auschwitz, is more horrific than most. But the film, directed by Joseph Sargent from a screenplay by Anne Meredith, has the good sense to avert its gaze from the most gruesome images of cruelty and death. In other words, it is approachable and never feels exploitative.

So when it came time for Mr. Bloom, 72, to choose a place to donate his immense personal library and his archives, he bypassed several larger prominent universities that in his opinion house those very practitioners of resentment in favor of a small, relatively unknown Catholic college in Colchester, Vt.

title: Robert G. Hoyt, 81, Founder Of National Catholic Reporter
description: Robert G. Hoyt, who founded The National Catholic Reporter, an independent weekly newspaper that substantially changed the way Roman Catholicism was covered and understood in the United States, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: Quarterly Profit Rises 47% at PanAmSat
description: The PanAmSat Corporation, the nation's largest commercial-satellite operator, said today that its first-quarter earnings increased 47 percent as cost cuts helped make up for a decline in sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, JOSEPH
description: WEISSMAN - Joseph. Died peacefully April 10, 2003 at age 85 in NYC. Beloved husband of Marion Lieben, the late Helen and the late Dorothy. Adored by his children, step-children and grandchildren. Retired pharmacist, army veteran, proud alumnus of College of Pharmacy. Funeral at Plaza Chapel, corner of 91st and Amsterdam, NYC, Sunday April 13th at 10am. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Arnold and Marie Schwartz College of Pharmacy, Office Of Planned Giving, University Center, 700 Northern Blvd, Brookville, NY 11548.

title: Article 2003041292526776463 -- No Title
description: Document is not available. A Template could not be found for NYT_Article #1050051185470.

title: Deal on Security Aid
description: Negotiators in Congress reached an agreement on a package that would satisfy requests from New York for millions in antiterrorism aid.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-6

title: Deaths of Journalists
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. Was Told Years Ago Of Possible Double Agent
description: Senior F.B.I. officials were told in the early 1990's that a Los Angeles woman accused this week of being a double-agent appeared to be spying for the Chinese, but they continued using her as an informer nonetheless, current and former officials said today.

title: Yo-Yos With Mystery Fluid Worry Agency and Parents
description: Albert Figueroa cannot say if the water yo-yo is a danger or just a letdown. The 11-year-old, who boasts of having had 25 water yo-yos, has often seen the rubbery, liquid-filled balls burst. Sometimes the yo-yos exploded after he threw them against his school building. Other times, he said, they would simply start leaking in his hand after too many squeezes.

title: Iraq's U.N. Envoy Departs for Mideast to Search for Family
description: Mohammed Aldouri, the Iraqi envoy who spent his final weeks at the United Nations unable to talk to his superiors, but still furiously railing against the United States-led war every time he was invited into the Security Council, has told associates that he will fly to Damascus, Syria, tonight and eventually on to Amman, Jordan, where he hopes to find information about his family in Baghdad.

title: A Bold New View of Turkish-German Youth
description: THE district of Kreuzberg here is known as Little Istanbul for its large concentration of Turkish immigrants and their German-born families. Now it is also becoming known as the territory of a former graffiti sprayer and youth gang member, Neco Celik, whose debut movie, ''Alltag,'' or ''Every Day,'' is gaining him a reputation as the Spike Lee of his time and place.

title: A Northern Push, an Uneasy Transition to Civil Peace and Appeals for Aid
description: A joint attack force of American and Kurdish soldiers swiftly took control of northern Iraq's largest city, Mosul, but rising lawlessness in Baghdad and elsewhere brought demands for United States troops to restore order. The transition from winning the war to winning civil peace intensified across Iraq, with American troops starting to police city streets. President Bush did not declare victory in Iraq, but he said there was no doubt that Saddam Hussein's rule had ended.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Bosnian Muslim To U.N. Tribunal
description: NATO-led forces arrested Naser Oric, a Bosnian Muslim wartime commander, and flew him to The Hague to face charges of war crimes against Bosnian Serbs. Mr. Oric was captured in the Bosnian city of Tuzla. In the war, he commanded Muslim forces in Srebrenica, a mostly Muslim town, which in 1995 was the scene of the worst massacre of civilian Muslims in the war. An estimated 8,000 men and boys were killed. Mr. Oric and his Muslim forces pillaged 15 villages predominantly inhabited by Serbs, according to his indictment. Serbs say 2,000 people died in one massacre, in Kravice in 1993. The main Serb perpetrator of the massacre of the Muslims, Gen. Ratko Mladic, remains at large. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Opposition Grows to Proposal on Bankruptcy Advisory Roles
description: Opposition is increasing in the Senate to a proposal that would make it easier for investment banks that represented a company that later filed for bankruptcy protection to advise the company in its reorganization.

title: Shifting Winds: The Victory and the Chaos
description: To the Editor:

title: Response to Kidd's Remarks Is Another Poor Performance
description: The Nets said they got the message from their captain, Jason Kidd. They said they would show up tonight, determined not to have another letdown against an inferior team.

title: Sports of The Times; A Good Idea, But Lacking In Good Will
description: THE players began to drift into the unfamiliar ballpark around 3 p.m., most with puzzled expressions, unsure where to go. The Expos' clubhouse? That would be the blue door, to your left, sir. Welcome home.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Quake Rattles North
description: An earthquake sent a jolt through northern Italy, sending frightened residents out onto the streets and prompting officials to evacuate some schools. Two people were injured in the quake, which registered a magnitude of 4.6 and had a center near Alessandria, about 55 miles east of Turin, local officials said. The tremor was felt in cities as far away as Milan and Genoa. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Fences Too Close To Give Cone Any Comfort
description: The globe-trotting Mets played their first game in Puerto Rico tonight, and David Cone made the second start of his comeback. It did not work out well for either the Mets or Cone.

title: Iraqi Exile Moves Fast To Establish a Presence
description: Ahmad Chalabi, a well-born, well-heeled and well-connected former banker who had not seen his native Iraq in 45 years, was huddled with tribal leaders, plotting his political rise in the post-Saddam Hussein era. Nearby, gunfire echoed as some 600 Iraqis Mr. Chalabi had recruited were being trained by United States Special Forces.

title: Shaky Ground Is Ahead And Behind in the North
description: The new no man's land separating the Kurds and American Special Forces advancing in northern Iraq from the retreating remnants of the Iraqi Army is haunted terrain, riddled with hastily abandoned tanks and ammunition trucks, and interlaced with trenches filled with oil once intended to be set afire to delay an American assault.

title: Marketing New York
description: To the Editor:

title: War and Peace; Anarchy in the Streets
description: The images of smiling children and cheering crowds in Iraq have been overtaken by a new, much more disturbing portrait of anarchy and fear. Looters, who began by going after the offices and homes of Saddam Hussein's henchmen, have moved on to stores, warehouses and even hospitals. At one site, thugs dragged away heart monitors and baby incubators. A prominent cleric returned from exile only to be murdered in one of Shiite Islam's holiest shrines. Frightened citizens have barricaded themselves in their homes in some places, or have begun shooting suspected robbers.

title: Metrocards? Not!
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, PETER
description: ADLER-Peter. Our beloved nephew and cousin. He will be missed. Rest in peace. Selma, Mike and Ricky

title: The Catch-22 Of Iraq Contracts
description: For some of the reconstruction work in and around Iraq, the United States Army Corps of Engineers confidentially awarded a one-year contract worth up to $100 million on April 1 to the Perini Corporation, which had revenue of barely $1 billion last year. The agency released a brief statement about the award on April 4, but Perini did not receive clearance to issue its own statement about the significant chunk of business until April 8. By then, its stock had climbed more than 40 percent.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Hostage Freed
description: Government troops rescued the last of three Indonesian seamen taken hostage last June by the Muslim separatist group Abu Sayyaf. One hostage escaped earlier, the other died in captivity on the southern island of Jolo, home to the group. The group is still holding five Filipino women, four of them Jehovah's Witnesses. The Abu Sayyaf group is thought to have some ties to Al Qaeda and is known for financing its operations by kidnapping. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLDORF, AUDREY
description: HOLLDORF - Audrey. The Producer Circle Company extends heartfelt sympathy to our colleague Maryanne Dittmann, her sister Virginia and brother William on the loss of their mother. Graced with warmth and humor, Audrey was a cherished friend to all of us for many years. With deepest condolences to the family. Martin Richards Sam Crothers Monique Bell Dan Gallagher Michael Milton

title: Shifting Winds: The Victory and the Chaos
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Acts to Compensate Victims of Smallpox Vaccine
description: With health and emergency workers around the country refusing to join the smallpox vaccination program, the House and Senate passed a measure today to compensate those disabled or killed by the inoculations.

title: Mideast Peace?: An Arab-Israeli Pact Must Come First
description: When President Bush and the British prime minister, Tony Blair, met this week in Hillsborough, Northern Ireland, they announced an all-out push to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict by implementing the "road map," the Middle East peace initiative that envisions a Palestinian state by 2005. Britain, along with France and other nations in Europe and the Arab world, have declared that a Mideast peace settlement is the only way to bring stability to the Arab world. The Bush administration, though, has treated the Israeli-Palestinian conflict as one problem that must compete with many others, like getting rid of Saddam Hussein.

title: Is Iraq More Crucial to Regional Peace Than Palestine?; An Arab-Israeli Pact Must Come First
description: When President Bush and the British prime minister, Tony Blair, met this week in Hillsborough, Northern Ireland, they announced an all-out push to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict by implementing the ''road map,'' the Middle East peace initiative that envisions a Palestinian state by 2005. Britain, along with France and other nations in Europe and the Arab world, have declared that a Mideast peace settlement is the only way to bring stability to the Arab world. The Bush administration, though, has treated the Israeli-Palestinian conflict as one problem that must compete with many others, like getting rid of Saddam Hussein.

title: Fear for a Navy Son, and for Fellow Muslims; Viewing Images of a War They Hate, a Brooklyn Family Is Proud and Sad
description: The aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln is finally coursing home from the war in Iraq, bringing with it an airman whose Brooklyn home is now filled with relief. The anxiety of a worried family -- the cigarettes, the acting out in school, the tears in front of the television news -- is drifting away.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Congress Passes a Budget With a Smaller Tax Cut

title: France Says Substance Found in Train Station Was Wheat Germ
description: French investigators said today that the contents of bottles found at a Paris train station last month and believed to be the poison ricin actually consisted of ground wheat germ and barley.

title: Vera Zorina, 86, Is Dead; Ballerina for Balanchine
description: Vera Zorina, a dancer and actress who starred in ballets, films and stage musicals choreographed by her first husband, George Balanchine, and whose mix of glamour and culture made her prominent in a variety of theatrical and musical fields, died on Wednesday at her home in Santa Fe, N.M. She was 86.

title: Cooperstown Muffs One
description: Maybe it's the stress of war, or maybe it's bad judgment. In any case, people thousands of miles from the front lines are behaving strangely in the name of patriotism. First came the New York Stock Exchange's ill-advised expulsion of Al Jazeera, the Arab television network, because of its reporting from Iraq. Now comes an equally knuckleheaded decision by Dale Petroskey, president of baseball's Hall of Fame, to cancel a 15th-anniversary celebration of the classic baseball movie ''Bull Durham,'' scheduled to begin April 26 in Cooperstown, N.Y. Mr. Petroskey said he was offended by antiwar criticism by Tim Robbins, who starred in the film along with his real-life partner, Susan Sarandon, also a vigorous critic of the war. Their ''very public'' criticism, Mr. Petroskey said in a letter to Mr. Robbins, could ''undermine'' the war effort and ultimately ''put our troops in even more danger.''

title: Seeking Calm In the Chaos
description: If the experience of Lt. Col. Alan King and the reservists in 422nd Civil Affairs Battalion is anything to go by, restoring electric power and rescuing Baghdad from the brink of anarchy will be a dangerous task.

title: Pillagers Strip Iraqi Museum of Its Treasure
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 12 — The National Museum of Iraq recorded a history of civilizations that began to flourish in the fertile plains of Mesopotamia more than 7,000 years ago. But once American troops entered Baghdad in sufficient force to topple Saddam Hussein's government this week, it took only 48 hours for the museum to be destroyed, with at least 170,000 artifacts carried away by looters.

title: Pilots Ratify Concessions At United
description: United Airlines said yesterday that its pilots had ratified labor concessions that would save it $1.1 billion a year and that it had reached tentative agreement with its mechanics on cost cuts.

title: In Baghdad, Free of Hussein, a Day of Mayhem
description: American troops cleared wide swaths of the capital of Iraqi forces today, but seemed powerless before a fresh wave of looting and mayhem that flowed in to take their place.

title: Crisis Plans Being Redrawn By Schools Across Nation
description: The Spence School now owns a scanner that directly monitors communications from the city's Office of Emergency Management. At a moment's notice, the school, on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, can turn its windowless gymnasium into a ''safe room'' where all students and staff can take shelter in case of a radiation or biochemical attack.

title: This Is for You, Mom and Dad
description: In the liner notes of her debut CD, ''Let Go'' (Arista), Avril Lavigne scribbles a heartfelt (but not copy-edited) message to her mother and father: ''If it wasn't for you pushing me so hard this CD would not of been made and I wouldn't have this career. Thanx guys for being great parents.''

title: Rumsfeld's Words on Iraq: 'There Is Untidiness'
description: Following are excerpts from an exchange between Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and reporters yesterday during a news conference in Washington, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. A full transcript is available online at nytimes.com/iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, BETTY
description: NEWMAN-Betty. On April 10, 2003. Beloved wife of Jack. Loving mother of Harvey and Linda. Adoring grandmother of Pam, Chuck and Elysa. Great-grandmother of Gabbie, Benji, Amanda, Max and Daniel. Services Sunday April 13th, 11:15am at ''The Riverside'' 76 St and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City. In lieu of flowers contributions to your favorite charity.

title: A Humanist's Unwitting March to an Inhuman End
description: PUSHING TIME AWAY

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Oil And Gas Fields For Sale
description: The ChevronTexaco Corporation said yesterday that it would sell oil and natural gas fields in Papua New Guinea, resulting in its exit from a $3.5 billion project of the Exxon Mobil Corporation. ChevronTexaco will sell stakes in the Kutubu, Moran, Gobe Main and South East Gobe oil fields as well as resign as operator, the company said. The sale of the fields, which produce about 53,000 barrels of oil a day, follows a review of its global portfolio, it said.

title: Hong Kong Tries to Allay Fears Outsiders Have About Its Citizens
description: Hong Kong officials struggled today to persuade other countries not to ban the entry of travelers from here.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: House Kills Restructuring Plan
description: The State House of Representatives defeated a proposal by Gov. Mike Huckabee to restructure the executive branch of state government by adding an amendment that crippled the plan. The defeat was the second major one of the legislative session for Mr. Huckabee, a Republican. The General Assembly, which is composed largely of Democrats, had earlier refused to enact his sweeping reorganization of public schools despite a State Supreme Court ruling that the education system was insufficient and underfinanced.

title: Ex-Official of HealthSouth Refuses to Answer Questions
description: Lawyers for Richard M. Scrushy, the ousted chief executive of the HealthSouth Corporation, tried today to assign blame for the multibillion-dollar accounting scandal engulfing the company to William T. Owens, the company's former chief financial officer.

title: Isles Like Being Underdogs While Leading Their Series
description: Even though they have grabbed a 1-0 lead, the Islanders still consider themselves overwhelming underdogs in their playoff series against the Ottawa Senators. Apparently, the Islanders want to keep it that way.

title: Still Paying for Past Support of Taliban, Pashtuns Flee South Toward Safety
description: Families fleeing harassment, beatings and extortion in northern Afghanistan arrive almost weekly at an impromptu refugee camp here, seeking shelter in patched tents on a dusty lot beside the city's animal market.

title: Leaving to Fail Another Day
description: The Republican-led Congress is limping into recess decidedly laurel-free, still consumed with its retrograde struggle over just how much more of a tax cut the wealthiest Americans need as the nation plunges into a decade of deepening budgetary pain. In midnight maneuvering, the leaders used a parliamentary snooker strategy to try to outflank Senate resisters who want to halve President Bush's fiscally destructive 10-year plan for $726 billion more in tax cuts.

title: Two Books With Lessons And Riddles Just for Fun
description: How would you explain the following? During a soccer argument in a bar, an Englishman strikes a German supporter of a rival team and knocks him down. The German gets up and says, ''Thank you.''

title: Tyson Is Rejected for Meadowlands Fight
description: For 48 hours, a promoter's dream seemed likely to be realized. Mike Tyson, who at 36 is still the biggest draw in boxing, would fight an opponent yet to be determined at Continental Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., on June 21. The bout would be on the undercard of a heavyweight title defense by Lennox Lewis.

title: Shifting Winds: The Victory and the Chaos
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: BANK EXPECTS LOSS Mitsui Trust Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it expected to post a loss of 50 billion yen ($417 million) in the year that ended March 31 because of the weak stock market. The bank, one of the 10 largest in Japan, previously expected a profit of 55 billion yen. Mitsui Trust's stockholdings are estimated to be twice as large as its core capital, making the bank highly vulnerable to the performance of the stock market. Still, last year's loss is just one-fifth the size of the previous year's.

title: German and French Businesses Are Expecting Cold Shoulder
description: Michael Sttzel thinks he has a lot to offer postwar Iraq. His company, German Water and Energy, designs and drills wells for drinking water, a commodity that has been in dangerously short supply in the battle-scarred towns of the south.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: MEXICO: CONCRETE PROFIT FALLS Cemex , the world's No. 3 concrete maker, reported a steep decline in first-quarter net profit because of foreign exchange and derivatives losses, but the company's stock rose as investors were cheered by better-than-expected operating results. Cemex said its net profit tumbled 71 percent, to $81 million, which was below expectations. Operating income, or earnings before interest and taxes, fell 6 percent to $301 million in the first quarter, narrower than the 12.1 percent drop expected by the analysts. Cemex's revenue was slightly higher than market expectations at $1.6 billion for the January-March period, up 2 percent from a year earlier. ( Reuters )

title: Australia Expects Dip in Grape Harvest
description: Australia's grape harvest could fall 12 percent, helping Southcorp, Foster's Group and other companies weather a glut caused by six years of increases, analysts and winemakers said today.

title: War and Peace; Triumph on the Battlefield
description: The swift military victory in Iraq has raised a critical question for the future of armed combat: Has the United States attained a new level of proficiency that will transform the nature of battle much as the machine gun, the tank and air power transformed warfare in earlier days?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMEAL, FRANK P.
description: SMEAL-Frank P. The Board and staff of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America mourn the loss of Frank P. Smeal, Eagle Scout, our former President, our generous and consistant supporter and, most importantly, our friend. His generosity and leadership has had an enormous impact on the lives of thousands of children and will be fondly remembered and continue to serve as an example to us all; he will be dearly missed. Our thoughts and prayers go out to the Smeal family during this difficult time. John F. McGillicuddy, President Daniel R. Gasparo, Scout Executive

title: Religion Journal; Recasting Jewish Rituals With Modern Additions
description: Passover seder tables will be groaning next week under the weight of the holiday's traditional ritual objects: seder plates, goblets of wine and platters of matzah. But in countless homes this year, set next to the wine-filled Elijah's cup, will be something new: a Miriam's cup.

title: Road to College Takes a Detour
description: Players who go from high school hockey straight to college hockey have become increasingly rare in recent years. The preferred road includes intermediate stops to prepare for a higher level of play.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Airline Acquired
description: The Irish low-budget airline Ryanair has completed its acquisition of Buzz, the struggling subsidiary of Royal Dutch KLM, for 20.1 million euros ($21.6 million). The purchase includes 10 planes, up to 130 employees, and Buzz's former headquarters at Stansted Airport of London; in May, Ryanair plans to start flying 12 Buzz routes from Stansted. British competition authorities have yet to approve the deal, but Ryanair said it had already booked more than 400,000 passengers on Buzz flights, bringing in enough advance revenue to cover the cost of the acquisition. The airline will continue to trade as Buzz, and John Osborne, former director of operations at Ryanair and former chief executive at the low-budget carriers GB Airways and Virgin Express, will serve as chief executive. The price that Ryanair paid was 3.8 million euros less than the originally agreed price, but a Ryanair spokeswoman declined to say why the price had fallen.

title: Workweek Woes
description: Last week was the 70th anniversary of a momentous yet forgotten event in American history. On April 6, 1933, the Senate overwhelmingly passed a bill that would have made the standard work week 30 hours. Anything more would be overtime.

title: Giants Look to Improve Pass Rush
description: The National League Football League draft may be in its sixth hour by the time the Giants make their selection on April 26, plenty of time for emotions to ebb and flow. A coveted player gets snagged, another unexpectedly slides into your lap, and there is disappointment, exhilaration, frustration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOYT, ROBERT G.
description: HOYT-Robert G. On April 10, 2003 at age 81. Born Janauary 30, 1922 to Guy R. Hoyt and Ella Winn Hoyt in Clinton, Iowa. Husband of Mig Boyle. Father of Michael Hoyt, Tim Hoyt, Mary Theresa Durkin, James Hoyt, Mary Jo Hoyt, Anne Hoyt and Sarah Hoyt. Grandfather of Megan Durkin, Luke Durkin, Anne Durkin, Emma Hoyt, Georgia Schoonmaker, Tim Hoyt, Jack Landry, Arthur Scavone, Claire Scavone and Jennifer Hoyt. Former husband of Bernadette Hoyt. Founding Editor of the National Catholic Reporter (1964-1970). Executive Editor, Christianity & Crisis Mag., Senior Writer, Commonweal Mag. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St Sunday 47pm. Mass of Christian Burial at Corpus Christi Church, 529 W. 121 St., Monday 10am. Contributions in his memory may be made to GoddardRiverside Community Center, 593 Columbus Ave, New York, NY 10024.

title: Warning to North Korea on Nuclear Arms
description: A top Russian diplomat said today that a nuclear-armed North Korea was against Russian national interests and that the Kremlin would re-evaluate its opposition to international penalties should the North Koreans develop nuclear weapons.

title: Corrections
description: Areport in the World Business Briefing column on Thursday about a decline in first-quarter revenue for LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton misstated the new revenue figure. It was 2.8 billion euros ($3 billion), not million.

title: Yemen Says 2 in Cole Attack Are Among 10 Qaeda Escapees
description: Ten suspected members of Al Qaeda, including at least two suspects in the 2000 bombing of the American destroyer Cole, escaped from a high-security Yemeni prison today, according to Yemeni officials.

title: Too Cold for Recess?
description: As New York City emerges from a spring cold snap, parents unwrapping their children from winter clothes may find something unexpected underneath: a new layer of fat. During this year's long and frigid winter, many of the city's public elementary schools canceled outdoor recess, instead keeping students inside where they watched videos (and snacked). At my son's school in Manhattan, children stayed indoors -- where they killed time in the gymnasium -- through much of April, too, because of rain. Wouldn't these children have been better off playing outside?

title: British Activist Is Reported Wounded by Israeli Sniper in Gaza
description: An Israeli sniper shot and critically wounded a British activist today as he tried to protect Palestinian children near a roadblock in the southern Gaza Strip, his organization said, citing witnesses.

title: Casualties
description: Announced military casualties in the Iraq war zone as of 6 p.m. Eastern time yesterday:

title: After the Rains, Augusta Drowns the Field
description: When the Masters finally began today, the golf course played wickedly, and it did not play favorites.

title: INSIDE
description: 10 Qaeda Suspects Escape

title: Aid Groups Urging Military to Protect Essential Services
description: The Bush administration's plan to pour large amounts of food and medical supplies into Iraq quickly appeared in danger of breaking down today as aid agencies took the unusual step of appealing to the military for help.

title: Suspended M.T.A. Security Chief Says Agency Failed to Pursue Internal Investigations
description: Testifying under oath at a State Assembly hearing, the recently suspended chief of security at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority charged yesterday that the agency was not interested in seriously investigating wrongdoing, asserting that its own inspector general often failed to act on evidence he had uncovered.

title: Deal Is Reached in Congress On New York Security Aid
description: House and Senate negotiators reached agreement tonight on an aid package that would fulfill New York City's request for tens of millions of dollars to pay for antiterrorism efforts.

title: G.E. Reports Profit That Matches Wall St. Predictions
description: The General Electric Company gave investors exactly what they expected yesterday, reporting a first-quarter profit that matched Wall Street's forecasts to the penny.

description: To the Editor:

title: Major League Soccer Preview
description: Eastern Conference

title: Senate Vote Could Sharply Reduce Bush Tax Cut
description: With Vice President Dick Cheney casting the tie-breaking vote in the Senate, Congress approved a $2.2 trillion budget plan today that would make room for a tax cut this year but possibly limit it to less than half the size President Bush proposed.

title: Apple Said to Discuss a Music Deal, but Not Too Seriously
description: Apple, the iconoclastic computer maker, has discussed an investment in Universal Music, the world's largest recording company, people close to the discussions said yesterday. These people, however, also cautioned that a deal was unlikely to be concluded.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Business Briefing column on Thursday about a decline in first-quarter revenue for LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton misstated the new revenue figure. It was 2.8 billion euros ($3 billion), not million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, MYRA
description: HARRISON-Myra. Beloved wife of Leonard J. and mother of Keith and Evan. She will always be remembered as a loving and caring ''woman of valour''. Services at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn on Sunday, April 13 at 10AM.

title: Fans and M.L.S. Await MetroStars' Success
description: For seven years, the MetroStars of Major League Soccer have struggled for acceptance and attention in a New York metropolitan area that has nine other professional teams in four major sports.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: QUAKE RATTLES NORTH An earthquake sent a jolt through northern Italy, sending frightened residents out onto the streets and prompting officials to evacuate some schools. Two people were injured in the quake, which registered a magnitude of 4.6 and had a center near Alessandria, about 55 miles east of Turin, local officials said. The tremor was felt in cities as far away as Milan and Genoa.   Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Atkins, the Diet Doctor, in Coma
description: Dr. Robert C. Atkins, whose low-carbohydrate diet earned him international acclaim, was in a coma and on life support late yesterday, three days after falling and striking his head on the pavement outside his Manhattan office.

title: Optimism Up; Retail Sales Also Increase
description: In the first encouraging news about the American economy in weeks, two reports released yesterday showed that consumers are not only spending more money, but that they are also somewhat more confident about the future.

title: End Early Admissions
description: To the Editor:

title: Conferees Bargain Over $80 Billion Plan to Finance War and Its Aftermath
description: House and Senate negotiators neared completion tonight of an $80 billion bill to pay for the war in Iraq, giving President Bush much of the flexibility he sought in rebuilding that nation. The bill also offers extra unemployment insurance for workers in the airline industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAICE, HERBERT H.
description: CHAICE-Herbert H. The law firm of Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler LLP mourns the death of our colleague, Herb Chaice, a superb lawyer and good friend, who retired from active practice in 1999. He brought true meaning to the term ''counsellor-at-law.'' He leaves us his wisdom, his love for the law, and the care and concern he brought to every client. We will all miss his leadership, his experience, and his wit. Our deepest condolences to Judith and the entire Chaice family.

title: Addressing Newspaper Editors, Bush's Political Adviser Faults Some War Coverage
description: The president's senior political adviser, Karl Rove, told a gathering of newspaper editors here today that the news media's exhaustive coverage of the war in Iraq had confused people by subjecting them to reporters' ''mood swings'' and the results of endless polling about the military's progress.

title: NEWMONT MINING RESTATES RESULTS FOR LAST 2 YEARS
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation, the world's largest gold producer, restated financial results for part of the last two years, resulting in a wider loss for the first nine months of 2001 and greater profit for the corresponding period in 2002. The restatements reflect changes in accounting for amortization of good will from acquisitions, asset depreciation and forward gold sales, according to Securities and Exchange Commission filings. The net loss for the first nine months of 2001 widened to $66.9 million, or 38 cents a share, from a previously reported $48.2 million, or 27 cents, the filings showed. For the first nine months of 2002, net income rose to $83 million, or 19 cents a share, from the previously reported $81.9 million, or 18 cents, the filings said.

title: Is Iraq More Crucial to Regional Peace Than Palestine?; The Key to Peace Is a Stable Gulf
description: When President Bush and the British prime minister, Tony Blair, met this week in Hillsborough, Northern Ireland, they announced an all-out push to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict by implementing the ''road map,'' the Middle East peace initiative that envisions a Palestinian state by 2005. Britain, along with France and other nations in Europe and the Arab world, have declared that a Mideast peace settlement is the only way to bring stability to the Arab world. The Bush administration, though, has treated the Israeli-Palestinian conflict as one problem that must compete with many others, like getting rid of Saddam Hussein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBER, SYLVIA

Sylvia's great courage and resilience in the face of her constant pain over many years was an inspiration to all who knew her. May she finally know the peace and freedom from pain that she so valiantly sought for so many years. Our condolences go out to Maurice, her husband for over 55 years; to her son, Philip, and his wife, Carole; to her daughter, Alice Glassman, her husband, Barry, and grandchildren, Adam and Kimberly Gruber. Fanny Levin, James P. and Emily Levin, and Gene A. Heller and their Families

title: Chvez Still on Top in Venezuela After Tough Year
description: The economy is expected to shrink by as much as 20 percent this year, the nation remains sharply divided and his opponents are still trying to force him from office. But a year after he survived a coup, President Hugo Chvez is as strong as ever.

title: DUKE ENERGY TO SHUT A TRADING BUSINESS
description: The Duke Energy Corporation, a leading owner of utilities, will shut its speculative energy-trading business in North America to reduce collateral payments and preserve its credit rating. Duke Energy North America, which owns unregulated power plants, will cut about a dozen energy-trading jobs, and about eight workers will be transferred within the company, a spokesman, Terry Francisco, said. Duke, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., had been trading crude oil, natural gas and electricity since the mid-1990's. It is retreating from trading after Moody's Investors Service said it might downgrade $22 billion of Duke debt on concern the company may have overestimated cash flow.

title: Cathay Pacific and Singapore Air Cut Back on Asian Service Because of Deadly Virus
description: Two of Asia's biggest air carriers, Cathay Pacific Airways and Singapore Airlines, announced deep cutbacks in service today because passengers have been scared off by the emergence of a virulent respiratory disease in the region.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Interim Chief For Baltimore Schools
description: Bonnie S. Copeland, who heads an educational foundation in Baltimore, has been named interim chief executive officer of the Baltimore school district. Ms. Copeland, 53, will replace Carmen V. Russo, who is quitting, on July 1. The school board is searching for a permanent chief as the district confronts budget deficits and continues a major overhaul. Ms. Copeland is executive director of the Fund for Educational Excellence. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Bus Driver in New Jersey Crash Will Not Face Criminal Charges
description: After a two-month investigation, the prosecutor in Ocean County, N.J., has ruled out filing criminal charges against the driver of a casino-bound bus that slid off the Garden State Parkway and crashed on Feb. 7, killing 2 passengers and injuring the other 28.

title: Finding the Right College, and Getting In
description: ASK B. J. Weimer how long she has been thinking about college choices for her daughter, Rachel, a senior in St. Louis with a learning disability, and she lets out a sound that's both a laugh and a sigh. ''Oh, about since seventh grade!'' she says. Mrs. Weimer may be joking, but her timing is not far off, according to administrators, advocates and educational consultants. Their message: the college search process is the same for learning disabled students as for everybody else -- but more so. ''A lot of the questions are not that different than for any student,'' says J. Thomas Viall, executive director of the International Dyslexia Association. ''They're just in a little more depth.''

Angelenos, of course, resent New York's claim to center stage. To them, Los Angeles is the future and New York is history. And they don't see the romance of living in an overpriced shoe box, waiting out snowstorms in April.

title: Minding a Field of Dreams
description: AS a kid, I could see my town's high school baseball field from the back porch. Anytime I saw anything going on over there, even if it was just the coach working on the field, I was on my bike and there like a shot. I would grab a rake and help prepare the field. I wanted to do anything I could to help my heroes, the guys on the team.

title: Getting Out of the Law and Into the Theater
description: BARRY LIEBMAN laughs at jokes about lawyers and says they are all accurate. He especially likes to tell the one about the lawyer who quit his well-paid career as a senior partner to run a community theater for almost no money and longer hours. The punch line is: all the other lawyers are jealous. That's the one about him, Barry Liebman, the lawyer-turned-director-and-producer of the Yorktown Stage in Yorktown Heights.

title: Americans Abroad
description: To the Editor: The article describing how Europeans' antiwar sentiment was aimed at our government and not at American visitors had a significant blind spot. Every visitor quoted in the article was opposed to the war in Iraq. Would the travelers have found their reception different if they supported the war? The article would certainly have had more value if pro-war Americans' perspectives had been included.

title: The War Goes Well. So Where's the Dividend?
description: THE images of military triumph from Baghdad last week, as Saddam Hussein's statue and his regime toppled, brought a measured sigh of relief from the business world. Economists' worst fears about the impact of the Iraqi war had not materialized. American casualties were limited. There were no big oil-field fires, and no terrorist reprisals yet on American soil. So far, so good, it seems.

title: Corrections
description: A table with the Executive Pay report overstated a measure of the accumulated wealth of Michael L. Eskew, chief executive of the United Parcel Service. The total value of his equity holdings in the company was $18,671,863, not $51,603,534.

title: Levittown and War: It's Not So Simple
description: The closing line of Joseph Mondello's opinion essay on a recent rally in Levittown prompted me to write this letter (''Levittown Confronts a New War,'' April 6). He concludes his glowing tribute to Levittown with the statement: ''How appropriate that Levittown should become the conscience of America.''

title: Executive Life; Show Me the Deal That I Really Want
description: WHEN he negotiated contracts for baseball stars like Cal Ripken Jr. and Kirby Puckett, Ronald M. Shapiro flouted the most cherished creed of sports agents: show me the money. Instead, he advised these baseball stars to accept relatively moderate pay packages in return for the right to spend their entire careers with the same teams, allowing them to plan their post-baseball business careers.

description: IT writes underwater! It writes in arctic cold and desert heat! It even writes in space!

description: AT Hommocks Middle School in Larchmont, students put their names on empty soda cans and place them in cafeteria recycling bins. Once a week, a can is randomly selected and that student wins a toy or a piece of candy.

description: Many thanks for the article by Garry Wills on religion and government. Clearly, the scoundrel in search of his last refuge now has a choice between patriotism and religious zealotry.

description: ANOTHER breakup, another album. When Annie Lennox performs at the Apollo Theater in Harlem tomorrow night, it will be part of the first headlining tour of her solo career and a preview of ''Bare,'' Ms. Lennox's first album of her own songs since ''Diva'' in 1992.

But for Craig, the search has involved factors that many of his friends have not had to worry about.

Stapleton (Little Compton).

title: BORROWING METHOD UPHELD
description: The state's increasingly common practice of long-term borrowing to finance major projects like sports arenas and, most recently, the redevelopment of Camden was upheld last week by the state Supreme Court. The court, voting 4 to 3, rejected an argument that the method violated the constitutional requirement that long-term borrowing be approved by the voters. The state has sidestepped the requirement by establishing authorities and making contracts with them to repay their bonds. The court reasoned that the state thereby does not guarantee the debt and thus does not obligate taxpayers. Laura Mansnerus

title: Smith Street's Delights
description: In 1997, Alan Harding, a chef, opened Patois on a quiet street in northern Brooklyn. The restaurant's success and the area's low rents attracted other ambitious chefs, making Smith Street Brooklyn's restaurant row. Here are some old favorites and relative newcomers.

title: Life Makes You Move
description: I NEVER expected to get into the restaurant business. But all my friends used to tell me I should become a bartender, and one night I went to the Tom Cruise movie ''Cocktail'' with my best friend. The movie got the wheels turning. But nothing happened until another friend asked me to work the door for him at a bar. I told everyone I knew that I was going to be there, and 50 people showed up just to see me. The owner said, ''How do you know all these people?'' He offered me a job working four nights a week. I didn't know how to do anything, but I lied and I absorbed.

Holding the vessel still for an instant, he breathed in, pulling the scent deep into his lungs. The sharp odor of earth and rank leaves surprised him; it was like something an apothecary might keep in a chipped porcelain jar.

As work crews repair the terra cotta cornice, the owner, Edwin Fisher, looks back on two decades, starting with his purchase of the 1886 structure as a backup location for his Astor Place liquor store a block away.

title: April 6-12: BUSINESS; MURDOCH'S SATELLITE

The addition of DirecTV, the nation's largest satellite operator with 11 million subscribers, means the News Corporation will have satellite operations serving more than 100 million households in the United States, Europe, Asia and Latin America. We believe the Bush administration has a historic opportunity to transform the psychology of the stalled Mideast peace process. If President Bush can muster the same single-minded determination he has shown over Iraq, he just might succeed.

title: 'Positively Fifth Street'
description: Anubile blonde squats on her boyfriend's bare chest and he's too stoned to do much about it. Nipple clamps? No sir, not this time. Even one would just be, like, way generous. Seizing him by the neck with both hands, she raises her shins from the carpet and presses her full dead weight onto his rib cage and solar plexus, forcing more air from his lungs. How's that feel? As she rocks back and forth, they lock eyes. "You like that?" she asks, flirty as ever. "How come?" Her name is Sandra Murphy. When she wears clothes, her taste runs to Gucci, Victoria's Secret, Versace. Her latest ride is the SL 500, in black. She used to work at a high-end sports car emporium in Long Beach, so she knows what the good stuff is. After that gig she moved to Las Vegas and danced topless professionally, but she hasn't had to work in three years-not since she danced for the guy she is currently laying her hands on. "My old man," she calls him sometimes, or "my husband," especially since she moved in. And she would sort of like to get married. Settle down, kids, that whole deal. Not right now, though. Because you, you've got time , as Liz Phair advises in "Polyester Bride," one of Sandy's all-time favorite songs. Time to get rich, see the world, party hearty. And lately she's been having the time of her used-to-be-not-so-great life. Million-dollar mansion, cute boyfriend, bionic sex, Benz, plus she's keeping her looks, above all. That's the key. In 1989 she was runner-up for the title of Miss Bellflower, a south-central suburb of Los Angeles. That was nine years ago, when Sandy was seventeen, but she maintains her dancer's physique by working out five days a week, and she still keeps the sash in her closet. Most men, her boyfriend included, cannot get enough of her, especially the way she looks now. She is lithe, wet, determined, on top.

title: The Antidecorator
description: The artist Laurie Simmons is best known for her photographs of miniature rooms populated by dolls -- images that evoke, especially for baby boomers like Simmons, both nostalgia and dislocation. But her 20-year obsession with domestic interiors took a new turn recently when someone gave her a copy of ''The Instant Decorator,'' a 1976 do-it-yourself book by Frances Joslin Gold. Line drawings of conventional rooms on transparent acetate pages allowed readers to insert samples of their own fabrics and wallpapers to get an idea of how their own rooms might look. The book's fundamental flaw -- the misleading discrepancy between the scale of actual fabric and wallpaper patterns and that of the rooms -- didn't matter to Simmons. Instead, the collage aspect of the book inspired her to break the confines of the doll-house rooms she was used to working with and to introduce furniture and figures clipped from magazines and comic books, as well as three-dimensional objects, into her domestic universe. Below, Simmons discusses her new work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERGER, DR. BERNARD
description: STEINBERGER-Dr. Bernard. Steinberger, Bernard, MD. OB/GYN, DOG, FACS, ACOG, AMA, 78, of Highland Beach, FL, passed away on April 8, 2003. Best friend and most deeply beloved husband of Sandy Berkowitz - Steinber ger. Devoted father to Dr. Robert, Carl, Joshua and Paul. Grandfather of Michelle and Amanda. Loving and loved stepfather to Jill and Jay Glasser, David Forrest and Glen Berkowitz, and stepgrandfather to Max, Zachary, and Richard Glasser. Born on October 22, 1924 to Jack Steinberger and Mollie Kirschenbaum, in Brooklyn, NY. Brother of Marvin Steinberger (deceased). World War II Vet, 2nd Lieutenant, US Airforce. Dr. Steinberger graduated from Columbia Medical School, and SUNY Downstate Medical Center '51. Interned '51-'52 Jewish Hospital, Brooklyn, NY. '52-'55 Resident OB/GYN Maimonides Medical Center, Brooklyn, NY. Cons. Emeritus KHH, St. Joseph's-St. John's Hospital, Far Rockaway, NY. He retired in 1990 from Maimonides Medical Center and St. John's. He was a wonderful, caring doctor who was vigorously involved in the total care of his patients, and will always be remembered as a dedicated and compassionate practitioner of medicine. He will be deeply missed and remembered with love by his families, friends, and everyone he touched. In his memory donations may be made to: The Dr. Bernard Steinberger National Fragile-X-Foundation, 4408 Intracoastal Drive, Highland Beach, FL. 33487. Funeral Sunday, April 13, 2003 at 12 noon from Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York.

title: The Next Resolution
description: In the upper floors of the United Nations Secretariat Building, where the organization's chief policy makers roost, the collapse of the tortured negotiations over a resolution authorizing the use of force in Iraq, and the subsequent decision of the United States and its allies to go to war nevertheless, has provoked a sense of dj vu. When I asked Shashi Tharoor, the under secretary general for communications and a U.N. lifer, whether he feared that the body was about to become irrelevant, as President Bush and other administration officials have threatened, he said: ''We've been here before. Look at Suez in 1956, look at the Congo in the early 60's, look at Kosovo in 1999'' -- all cases in which the Security Council was hamstrung by disagreements among the great powers, all accompanied by dire predictions about the body's future. ''We've seen too many special cases,'' Tharoor went on, ''and we know that it would be premature to write our own obituary.''

title: Who Owns the Rules of War?
description: During the euphoria of the opening air campaign against Baghdad, commentary was filled with triumphal rhetoric about hitting ''legitimate military objectives'' while causing little or even no loss of civilian life. A week ago, the air war was pounding more than symbols of the regime, and the ground war had become a real war. Scarcely a speech, briefing or interview was being given that failed to mention the laws of war. The Iraqi regime, for its part, was broadcasting denunciations of American airstrikes replete with images of corpses and wounded civilians in hospitals; the United States responded that Iraq had systematically situated military targets and equipment in the midst of civilian areas. The sheer frequency of these references on all sides belied the ancient maxim inter arma silent leges -- in time of war law is silent.

title: Coping With Food Allergies

title: 'The Devil Wears Prada'
description: The light hadn't even officially turned green at the intersection of 17th and Broadway before an army of overconfident yellow cabs roared past the tiny deathtrap I was attempting to navigate around the city streets. Clutch, gas, shift (neutral to first? Or first to second?), release clutch, I repeated over and over in my head, the mantra offering little comfort and even less direction amid the screeching midday traffic. The little car bucked wildly twice before it lurched forward through the intersection. My heart flip-flopped in my chest. Without warning, the lurching evened out and I began to pick up speed. Lots of speed. I glanced down to confirm visually that I was only in second gear, but the rear end of a cab loomed so large in the windshield that I could do nothing but jam my foot on the brake pedal so hard that my heel snapped off. Shit! Another pair of seven-hundred-dollar shoes sacrificed to my complete and utter lack of grace under pressure: this clocked in as my third such breakage this month. It was almost a relief when the car stalled (I'd obviously forgotten to press the clutch when attempting to brake for my life). I had a few seconds-peaceful seconds if one could overlook the angry honking and varied forms of the word "fuck" being hurled at me from all directions-to pull off my Manolos and toss them into the passenger seat. There was nowhere to wipe my sweaty hands except for the suede Gucci pants that hugged my thighs and hips so tightly they'd both begun to tingle within minutes of my securing the final button. My fingers left wet streaks across the supple suede that swathed the tops of my now numb thighs. Attempting to drive this $84,000 stick-shift convertible through the obstacle-fraught streets of midtown at lunchtime pretty much demanded that I smoke a cigarette.

title: 'Things My Mother Never Told Me'
description: Not long before she died, my mother gave me quite a turn. I was visiting her at a nursing home called Cromwell's, in the same Yorkshire village where she'd lived for forty years. For most of my childhood, Cromwell's had been the Manor House Hotel, a business that failed to prosper no matter how often it changed hands. She hated the greystone gauntness of the building, and when it became a nursing home said she'd rather take an overdose than `end up there'. In the event, when she became too ill to manage at home, it seemed the only sensible option. She resented the indignity but accepted the logic. Friends and neighbours could drop by. My sister lived just across the road.

description: Governor James E. McGreevey today announced the nomination of a Gloucester County judge to serve on the New Jersey Supreme Court.

This may prove more complicated than the Bush administration suspects. It may force us to think in new ways about what freedom is, and whether Americans have exclusive access to its meaning.

description: Rumors and intrigue swirled here today in a crowd of angry men milling around Iraq's holiest mosque two days after a prominent cleric was assassinated, but the truth of what happened remains a mystery.

description: Coming off a last-place finish in 2002, the Power opened this season with tough road games against two teams that qualified for the Women's United Soccer Association playoffs last year, the Atlanta Beat last week and the Washington Freedom tonight. Not only did the Power lose both games, but it also looked confused in doing so.

description: Food lovers will soon have a new spot to pursue their passion on San Francisco's waterfront.

description: An Army bus carrying 36 soldiers crashed on a highway just outside the Fort Drum military post in upstate New York yesterday morning, injuring 19 soldiers and the civilian driver, Army officials said.

title: New Fears Rise, Old Fears Stir
description: FOR some, the war in Iraq may be a sideshow to the main event of this still-young century, the international war on terrorism. But for a lot of New Yorkers, who had just started to feel better after the attack on the World Trade Center, the war, though thousands of miles away, and a few days ago triumphally winding down, has reopened the psychic wounds of 9/11.

title: A Nation at War
description: In France, a Softening

title: Oft-Injured Griffey Hobbling Toward the Hall
description: Sometime in the early 1980's, while working as a commentator for an N.F.L. game, Bob Trumpy became emotional when a wide-open receiver dropped an easy pass. ''That's tragic!'' Trumpy said. His colleague, Bob Costas, replied calmly: ''Bob, a plane crash is tragic. Dropping a football is merely unfortunate.''

title: Famous Plays, Famous Players, Forgotten Films
description: FAMOUS players in famous plays.'' It was, theoretically, quite a reasonable idea when Adolph Zukor thought it up in 1912. It still seemed (theoretically) a pretty good one when Ely Landau reimagined it as the American Film Theater in the early 70's. Except for this hitch: most plays, especially the more venturesome ones, stubbornly resist simple translation to the screen.

title: Return to Yucatn In Noble Pursuit Of an Old Dream
description: A few weeks ago, I made a pilgrimage to the Yucatn, the place where I first fell in love with fly-fishing nearly 30 years ago. On the Caribbean shores of Mexico , just south of Tulum and its sun-washed Maya pyramid, a very rutted road leads to a tidy line of thatched cottages. No television, no newspapers. Just the calming murmur of the surf.

title: Heavy Metal
description: Donald Gratz is a burly, avuncular man with an easygoing manner and a sly grin. He owns Gratz Industries, a custom metal-fabricating business -- commonly known by its old name, Treitel-Gratz -- which is housed in a graffiti-covered, blond-brick building that appears to cower beneath the 59th Street Bridge in Long Island City, Queens. Though Gratz doesn't seem like the kind of guy who would be on the speed dial of the New York design world's A-list, to many of them, he's something of a god.

title: Pop Quiz; Third Rock From the Sun
description: What better way to celebrate Earth Day on April 22 than to answer test questions about Mother Earth. To meet state standards, the New York Board of Regents recently revised high school exams in global history and geography and in earth science -- though it's now called ''physical setting'' to reflect a broader scope (or perhaps not to offend the other planets). Below, questions from the August exams.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: COMPLICATIONS: A Surgeon's Notes on an Imperfect Science, by Atul Gawande. (Picador, $13.) The author, both a surgeon and a staff writer for The New Yorker, examines the realms of the medically unexplained and uncertain, as well as the fallibility of a pursuit that ''may well be more complex than just about any other field of human endeavor.'' Last year in these pages, F. Gonzalez-Crussi praised ''Complications'' for its ''truth and authenticity'' and Gawande for ''his power to conjure the reality of the ward, the thrill of the moment-by-moment medical or surgical drama.''

title: Commentary Divided On Fall of Baghdad
description: As Baghdad fell to United States troops last week, the reaction of newspaper editorial writers around the world ranged from jubilation to dejection. And, as these excerpts show, many urged the United States to use its power wisely. The foreign-language editorials were translated by The New York Times or BBC World Monitoring.

title: Style & Entertaining; Modern Man
description: In theory, Eric Villency is not someone you really want to like. He is tall, dark and handsome. At the tender age of 28, he is the president of Maurice Villency Inc., the furniture retailing business founded by his grandfather in 1932. He lives in a minimalist-chic downtown loft, sparsely furnished with stylish items from said company. And this evening, he has invited some of his extremely attractive and accomplished friends -- many of whom attended the kind of fancy Manhattan private schools that he did -- for a dinner party. Ugh, right?

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Page 3 of the Travel section today about the opening of the Ferry Building marketplace in San Francisco misstates the telephone number. It is (415) 693-0996.

title: Childhood Amid Uncertainty
description: TWO years ago, organizers of the nonprofit Knowledgeitrust had a vague notion about helping students around the world exchange ideas. Sept. 11 decided its shape: Peace Diaries, an online space where children could air their feelings, guided by lesson plans. As fears about terrorism became fears about war, the Web site, peacediaries.org, has served as a journal of childhood amid uncertain times. The students' work is collected in book form; ''Peace Diaries Volume 2,'' due out in May, represents 13 countries. Children collaborate on a constitution of student rights, nominate candidates for ''peace president,'' design ''peace totems'' (at left) and describe lives defined by terror. An Azerbaijani teenager tells of being forced from home: ''Now we live in the kindergarten. We have one room and members of the family live in one room.'' A student in Queens describes the World Trade Center site: ''It looks like a graveyard over there now.'' An Israeli girl talks about bombings: ''My mother doesn't let me go because she afraid that something bad will happens to me.'' But she, as others, ends with a note of hope. ''Do you like listening to music?'' she asks. ''I hope we will be friends!!!'' KATE ZERNIKE

title: Bomb
description: All war, all the time. In the beginning, at least, the invasion of Iraq promised some of the drama and spectacle of a made-for-TV event, and as the ''crawl'' at the bottom of our screens counted down the hours to the expiration of the president's deadline, some of us whose attention spans have been deformed, perhaps, from watching too much sports on television even experienced a certain amount of impatience and anticipation. Game on! Drop the puck!

title: Fire and Silence: Children's Terror in Russia

Small groups of worried parents stood in shadowy corners of the worn lobby waiting for news of their children, who were hanging on to life after a night of terror.

title: The World; The Means to Make the Poisons Came From the West

If the troops do find it, they will also find something else: that the means for making it came primarily from Western companies years ago.

title: FOOTNOTES

The plywood chair here was made in his family's furniture factory in Northern Ireland. Just like the seating he's working on today, this early effort was the assemble-it-yourself variety -- but back then it was because he had to carry the chairs in pieces on flights back to England. Although this essentially Modernist room reflects his training at the Architectural Association in London, the classical bust reveals his abiding love of history. Clendinning once designed a Christopher Wren-influenced orangery, but his professors frowned upon such frippery. Still, he wrote, architects like Andrea Palladio or John Soane ''have influenced and inspired me more than any of the moderns.''

Early Thursday, a fire in the Caspian city of Makhachkala killed 28 boys, ages 7 to 14, as they slept in a boarding school for the deaf. The disasters seized average Russians. The government demanded that safety standards be upgraded in thousands of poorly maintained, aging schools. Michael Wines

Bad teachers play favorites and worry more about enforcing dress codes than making ''Henry IV'' interesting. Such conclusions fill the pages of ''Fires in the Bathroom: Advice for Teachers From High School Students,'' to be published May 1.

I discovered how out of date they really were when I went to the Chevy Chase Club a few weeks ago for a custom fitting from the head pro, Jim Fitzgerald.

title: Travel Advisory; Omaha Zoo Reveals Animal Night Life
description: More than 75 nocturnal species are on display in a new permanent exhibit at Henry Doorly Zoo in Omaha. Day-night cycles are reversed inside Kingdoms of the Night, enabling visitors to watch alligators, bats, owls, naked mole rats and other creatures hunt and play. A re-creation of a Louisiana bayou is populated by alligators, bullfrogs, flying squirrels and snakes. The indoor bayou, with large artificial cypress trees, features a crocodile trapper's cabin, a floating boardwalk and a large beaver's lodge.

title: TEACHERS SEEK HELP
description: Accountants say the state teachers' pension fund needs $484 million to keep operating, but State Treasurer John E. McCormac says the projected budget deficit will make that level of aid impossible. Instead, Mr. McCormac, anticipating requests from other pension funds in coming weeks, says the state was prepared to offer about 20 percent of that amount, spreading the full payment over the next five years. About 186,000 working and retired teachers are enrolled in the fund, which paid out $3 billion in benefits in the last two years. Jeremy Pearce

title: Soldier of Misfortune
description: First off I want people to understand that there is more than just combat. We're not seeing fighting at all times. Sometimes accidents happen. The other night, a good friend of mine, Lance Cpl. William White, and I were driving along in a Humvee. We were setting up communication because we were both com guys. It was night. I was driving. I had my night-vision goggles on. You know N.V.G.'s aren't the best; they're good, but your perception is not the greatest with them. When I came up on the hole, I didn't see it. The Humvee pretty much slipped into a canal and tipped upside down into the water. The cab we were in, me and him, completely flooded. Of course, I panicked. We were underwater. It definitely was a scary situation. You've got to stop and think, but you don't really have time to stop and think. You've got to be quick about it and decide, What do I need to do here, where do I need to go?

title: Boston's Michelangelo
description: In 1868, the young John Singer Sargent received his first sketchbook as a Christmas present. The Sargent family was living in Rome that winter, and the 12-year-old Sargent spent hours in the chilly Vatican galleries, honing his drawing skills by sketching works from antiquity.+Sargent (1856-1925) became one of the most international American artists of his day, shuttling around Italy, France, England and the United States, but he knew Italy most intimately. His Italian connections, from his birth in Florence to the Italian Renaissance influences in his murals, are the subject of the essays in SARGENT AND ITALY (Los Angeles County Museum/Princeton University, $49.95). Sargent hated the dull routine of society portraiture, and his Italian trips -- painting peasants in Capri, Venetian bead stringers, Alpine brooks -- refreshed him. Particularly interesting is Jane Dini's essay, ''Boston's Michelangelo,'' which discusses the Boston murals that Sargent considered his most important work. He relished the chance to bring his considerable knowledge of history and literature to his painting, and to work in the style of the Renaissance artists he had idolized as a child. In 1917, the art critic Frederick William Coburn reported on the progress of Sargent's murals at the Boston Public Library: ''Given perhaps five years more, one mind, one pair of hands will have presided over the creation of an American Sistine Chapel.'' Katherine Zoepf

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, E. KENNETH
description: MARKS-E. Kenneth. 81, died April 10, 2003 at home. Beloved husband of Bunny, loving father of Greg, Lynn and Kathi, father-in-law of Susan Marks, Clifford Pearlman and James Findley, grandfather of Andrew and Zach. Decorated naval officer, avid sportsman, he devoted many years to community service. title: A Man Plays a Woman, Without Any Disguise
description: THE central character in David Greenspan's new play, ''She Stoops to Comedy,'' a lesbian actress named Alexandra Page, spends most of the first scene offstage in the bathroom preparing an elaborate disguise. She has decided to audition for the role of Orlando in a production of Shakespeare's ''As You Like It,'' in which her girlfriend, Alison, has been cast as Rosalind. Because their relationship is on the rocks, Alex's scheme is partly a jealous lover's effort to spy on Alison and partly a bid to woo her back. So ingenious is her costume that when she finally emerges from the bathroom, in slacks, a short-sleeved shirt, furry arms and a butch haircut, Alex looks exactly like -- David Greenspan!
