description: THE skyscrapers and the verdant hills ringing one of the world's loveliest natural harbors are still here, but most of the tourists have been scared off by an outbreak of the new and deadly disease called SARS, for severe acute respiratory syndrome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBRADER, MYRON LAWRENCE
description: LIEBRADER-Myron Lawrence, Passed away Friday, January 31, 2003, age 73, after intrepid battle with leukemia. Born in Brooklyn, N.Y. Former resident of Sunnyside and Bayside, Queens. Son of Sol and Estelle Liebrader, beloved husband of 13 years to the late Barbara Liebrader. Survived by his son Andrew, daughter Donna, sister-in-law Ginny, brother-in-law Rick, and friend/companion Patricia Kobetts. His father, Sol, was a C.P.A. and his mother Estelle worked in real estate and for an attorney, named Lawrence Brinn. His parents also owned two candy stores in Queens. After his wife passed away in 1976, Myron Liebrader served as two parents to Andrew and Donna since Andrew was eleven yrs. old and Donna was eight. His family moved to Sunnyside from Brooklyn when he was eight years old. He graduated from Brooklyn Tech. H.S. He earned a B.A. Economics and M.A. Social Studies from N.Y.U. He also minored in math while in college. He spent two years in the Coast Guard during the Korean War. He also earned all the credits for a doctorate although never completing his dissertation. ABD, (All But Dissertation). Myron Liebrader started teaching social studies at Grover Cleveland H.S. in Ridgewood, Queens, N.Y. in 1954. His career at Cleveland lasted 47 years, which is a record for the most years spent by one person in the same high school building in the history of the N.Y.C. School System. He became Cleveland's principal in 1971 and remained in that position for 30 yrs. before retiring in 2001 as the most senior high school principal in the N.Y.C. School System. More teachers working under his direction went on to become supervisors and principals than any other principal in the history of the school system. He also taught a course at Q.C.C. at night for 37 years to prepare school secretaries for the N.Y.C. school system. Thank you, Dad, for teaching us to be decisive, not to look back too much, and to get the most out of life that we could get. Thanks also for teaching us to bring things to a closure and for being the exemplary man that you were. Contributions, in his memory, can be made to the Leukemia Fund, L.I.J. Medical Center, 270-05 76th Ave., New Hyde Park, N.Y. 11040 Attn: Dr. Kanti Rai.

title: Diagnosis
description: Lisa Sanders's article (March 30) was fascinating, especially following the discussion of malpractice in your March 16 issue on medicine. The question that comes to mind, however, is why, in this age of shared information, was the patient's entire list of medications not accessible to her doctors? Why was successful detection contingent upon the patient, or family member, being able to recall the extensive list of drugs? These were prescribed by a doctor and filled by a pharmacy. Surely a computerized list would be more efficient.

I don't find the fear debilitating, but it is chronic and a little fatiguing.

Nobody -- neither the real estate broker or the management of the building -- told me that the apartment had a serious problem. The outer wall in my bedroom was badly flooded during heavy rain in March of 2001. Since then it has happened eight times more. I asked the management several times to fix the problem, but nothing was done. The superintendent himself saw several times how water was flowing down the wall. Not only is the wallpaper ruined, but the Sheetrock under the wallpaper has started to crumble. Should I file a complaint with the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums or the Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives? Do I have a legal right to stop paying my maintenance until this is fixed? . . . Sergey Zhuravlev, Brooklyn

He plays a washed-up movie director who gets a chance to make a career-reviving film but is so terrified that he develops hysterical blindness just as they're starting to shoot. Mrs. Bleier is survived by her sons Richard, Steven, Ralph and daughter-in-law Kathy, her grandchildren Kenneth (Mariah), William (Rifka), Kelly, Michael and Jason, and her great-grandson Moses Bleier. Her family deeply mourns her passing. Funeral will be held 2:30 PM, Sunday, April 13, at Temple Beth El, 220 South Bedford Rd, Chappaqua, NY 10514.

title: On Screen, Parents Are A Girl's Best Friend
description: IN the new box office hit ''What a Girl Wants,'' Amanda Bynes plays Daphne Reynolds, a 17-year-old who leaves the New York loft she shares with her wedding-singer mother to go to London and meet a guy. The guy is Henry, and not long afterward, they are buying records together, going on motorbike rides and removing their shoes in public places.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMOGLU, DR. TEVHIT
description: CAMOGLU-Dr. Tevhit, a loving father and husband, passed away on April 2, 2003 after a long, full life. Dr. Camoglu was born in the small village of Anatolia in rural Turkey and worked his way to achieve proficiency in English and French, with a scholarship at the University of Sorbonne, Paris. In 1951, after graduating with a Master's and a Ph.D. in economics from the University of Sorbonne, Dr. Camoglu established himself in France as a pioneer of the chemical fertilizer business. In the 1960's Dr. Camoglu expanded his organization into international markets by opening offices in London; England; Paris; France; the Middle East; South-East Asia and India. After President Nixon de-linked the U.S. Dollar from the gold standard in 1971, Dr. Camoglu extended his business to become one of the largest international foreign exchange operations of the 1970's. In the 1980's, Dr. Camoglu moved his headquarters from Europe to the U.S., where he acquired interests in his operations in the international foreign exchange market and established a venture capital and asset allocation firm in Scottsdale, AZ. Dr. Tevhit Camoglu is survived by his wife, Ishik, three children and two grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOODMAN, RUBY (ROBERT)
description: GOODMAN-Ruby (Robert). April 16, 1973. Remembering my Dad. 30 years does not diminish my memories of his love, wit, and music. I cherish his mandolin. Arnold L.

O'Malley's fourth-period English class at Fordham Preparatory School in the Bronx posed a question people were grappling with before the United States invaded Iraq and will most likely be pursuing after the last gunshots in Baghdad: Decide whether you believe the war is moral, then defend your position.

title: The Last Shift
description: Congratulations on Sara Corbett's article about the nursing shortage (March 16). Much of the coverage of the nursing work force focuses on the sheer number of nurses that will be needed to provide care as the baby-boom generation ages. But there is not so much a shortage of nurses as a shortage of nurses willing to remain employed in hospitals working under the conditions that Corbett describes.

title: JAIL RELEASE DENIED
description: At a concert scheduled in San Jose, Calif., last night, the New Jersey rock star Jon Bon Jovi was without the aid of his long-time sound engineer, William O'Brien, because a county court judge in Pennsylvania refused last week to release Mr. O'Brien from jail. Mr. O'Brien, 53, is serving an 18-to-59-month jail term for sexual assault on a 15-year-old. Mr. O'Brien lives in Chester County, where the offense took place and where, coincidentally, the QVC shopping network, which broadcast the concert, is also situated. Although Mr. O'Brien has served the minimum 18 months, prosecutors argued that a rock concert was exactly the wrong kind of event for a person convicted of a sexual offense to be allowed to attend. Karen DeMasters

title: A Wake-Up Call For Huntington Station
description: On March 25, at Tower Street and Lowndes Avenue, adjacent to Huntington Intermediate School in Huntington Station, there was a shooting involving multiple gunshots. As a result, the intermediate school, Woodhull Intermediate School, and Huntington High School had lockdowns. Students on the playground were escorted indoors, doors and windows were locked, and the police made a thorough search of the buildings and grounds to determine that no unauthorized people were on school property. To the credit of School District 3 administrators and personnel, immediate and effective action was taken to ensure the safety and welfare of our children.

That concern seems almost quaint now, when so many stock funds are sitting on piles of capital losses that can offset gains for years to come.

title: At Solomon Schechter, Jayvee Bats Line Up
description: FOR a grade school growing into a high school, that first year of junior varsity baseball is seldom smooth or easy. Solomon Schechter is a conservative Jewish day school that has gone through the eighth grade for 28 years. Last year it added a ninth grade and opened a facility here in Hartsdale on the way to becoming a full high school. The school has had a modified program, which demands fewer requirements of its players than varsity or junior varsity (fewer practices per week, for example, or a no-cut policy) and is designed for students in seventh, eighth and ninth grade. This year, with the school adding a 10th grade, it also added a jayvee baseball team.

As of April 9, they held 1,475 inmates, 167 more than they were designed to hold.

After traveling a mile down a gravel road to the site, my husband and I were delighted to find there a nesting habitat in the mesquites for the elusive long-eared owl. Having hunted up and down the East Coast for this bird over the years, we were thrilled to discover several of them at this location.

title: 'A Few Short Notes on Tropical Butterflies'
description: On the first morning of the training in Bombay, just minutes before she collapsed, Elizabeth Dinakar stood in front of two hundred people in the conference hall, pointed up at the cholera bacteria magnified on the wall in front of her, and said "This is your enemy." The room was long and stuffy, with peeling walls and rattling air conditioners. People coughed and shuffled papers. The bacteria were the size of cars. Elizabeth Dinakar was tall and thin with thick black eyebrows. Her hair was pulled away from her face and held in a bun at the back of her head. She wore a silk shirt and khaki skirt, flat-soled shoes, and no makeup.

Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLENS, JOSEPHINE HARRINGTON
description: WELLENS-Josephine Harrington died peacefully at home among family in Fremont, CA on March 30, 2003. The daughter of Irish immigrant parents, Jo grew up in Manhattan, the third of five children. She met the love of her life, Arthur Wellens, while working at the Normandy Theater. They married and moved to CA in 1948. Family and friends will remember Jo for her delicious pies, her love of yellow, and a pragmatic but always positive outlook. Her daughter Judi, son-in-law Scott, longtime friends Corinne and Stan James, nieces, nephews and friends, will always miss her. A Memorial fund has been established at Holy Name School, 207 West 96 Street, NYC 10025.

title: April 6-12
description: BAGHDAD FALLS — American forces took control of Baghdad as Saddam Hussein's regime collapsed three weeks into the war. Jubilant Iraqis toppled statues of their former leader, whose fate remained unknown. With the collapse of the government came widespread looting by Iraqis in Baghdad and other cities. But the fighting was not yet over. In addition to sporadic shooting and a suicide bombing in the capital, there was heavy fighting for a town on the Syrian border. In the north, Kurdish fighters took control of Kirkuk and helped to begin securing Mosul, bringing concern from Turkey, which fears the Kurds will seek to establish an independent state. The last major military target for the United States was Tikrit, Mr. Hussein's ancestral home.

In an office tucked off the law library stacks, he takes out two piles of index cards adorned with the face-book pictures of his 91 first-year students. Like a blackjack dealer in a casino, he shuffles the piles, which are split by sex, then deals out 10 cards from each, the first step in compiling the list of students to be called on during class.

title: April 6-12: BUSINESS; SUPERSONIC NO MORE
description: After a quarter-century of supersonic travel, British Airways and Air France said their transatlantic Concorde flights would come to an end later this year. The two airlines blamed falling passenger numbers and ever-mounting maintenance costs, but some aviation specialists said the image of the delta-winged, needle-nosed Concorde never recovered from a crash in July 2000 outside Paris that killed 113 people. Others mourned its passing as the end of what one former Concorde aficionado called ''the last real travel club'' of the rich, the powerful and the famous. Alan Cowell

title: Sports of The Times; A Cool Customer Is the Talk of the First Pro-Am
description: AT one of Augusta National's walk-in gates out on Washington Road yesterday, a distinguished gray-haired Masters patron, a retired New York State judge, was suddenly stopped by a security guard.

title: A Small School District Rises Up Against Albany
description: At school district headquarters here, Superintendent William Cala's desk is strewn with congratulatory phone messages, letters and e-mail messages. Hundreds in all, they praise him and the Fairport Board of Education for taking a stand against a state government that has not passed a timely budget in 19 years and that they see as dysfunctional.

title: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 4-13-03: QUESTIONS FOR CHRISTOPHER lOGUE; Battle Lines
description: Q: The subtitle to your new book, ''All Day Permanent Red,'' is ''The First Battle Scenes of Homer's 'Iliad': Rewritten.'' What's the difference between translating the ''Iliad'' and rewriting it?

title: Melissa Notice, Lawrence Rocker
description: Melissa Ann Notice and Lawrence Herbert Rocker were married last evening by Rabbi Roger Ross at the Essex House in New York.

title: When Episodes Could Still Be Very Special
description: No historical record marks the first Very Special Episode -- that original television show meant to edify and entertain. Easy to mock yet oddly comforting, the V.S.E. has become something of a lost art: only the Christian dramedy ''Seventh Heaven'' and the dying ''Dawson's Creek'' maintain the tradition in its full, stylized glory. The V.S.E. requires innocence of a degree hard to imagine for today's wise-cracking characters: imagine the ''Friends'' clan confronting Phoebe's eating disorder or learning about environmentalism. But back in the 80's, in the golden age of very specialness, it was apparently possible to imagine that one Socratic dialogue -- on any issue from suicide to helium huffing -- could sort an issue out, at least on television.

title: Cinema Paradiso Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: Armstrong Not Resting on His Titles
description: Although it's early April, already in Lance Armstrong's mind it's July, the only month that counts, and he was not here in western France preparing for the unimportant four-day Circuit de la Sarthe but for the supreme bicycle race, the three-week Tour de France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRONSTER, NATALIE J.
description: BRONSTER-Natalie J. Died April 11. Daughter of Dr. Reuben Finkelstein and Mayme (Manishevitz) Finkelstein, her life was devoted to her family and Jewish causes. Widow of Col. Walter Bronster, she is survived by her sons Stephen, David and Jeffrey, and granddaughters Michelle and Samantha. Levaya was held today at Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 25 of Arts & Leisure today about the singer Annie Lennox misidentifies the record label that released her new album, ''Bare.'' It is J Records, not Arista.

title: A Smoothie For Easter Ham
description: At Easter dinners in Germany, riesling adds bliss to traditional baked ham oozing an apricot-and-honey glaze. The tangy, off-dry, featherweight St. Urbans-Hof from the Mosel's heavenly 2001 vintage is a welcome example. The $8 that Astor, 12 Astor Place (Lafayette Street), asks is a bargain for an aromatic smoothie that imparts apricot and peach flavors while teasing the taste buds.

title: Plans for Families, Degrees and Careers Come to Abrupt End in Iraq
description: Left behind, somewhere in the desert, were all of their plans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, BERNIECE (NEE RUBENSTEIN)
description: SHAPIRO - Berniece (nee Rubenstein). Died April 12, 2003, at age 83 in the comfort of her daughter's home. She was the beloved wife of the late Murray Shapiro. Loving mother of Andrew Shapiro and Donna D'Andraia, mother-in-law to Anthony D'Andraia and Sylvia Shapiro, grandmother to Rocco, Anthony, Vincent and Michael D'Andraia. There will be a memorial service in her memory on Sunday, April 13, at 11 AM at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY, 914793-3800. Donations can be made in her memory to the Hudson River Museum or to any hospice facility.

title: Small Kindnesses in the Big City
description: IN these awful times, it's soul-satisfying to watch New Yorkers draw together to ease each others' days. Of course, small-town neighborliness is legendary. If a fire suddenly reduces a trailer to twisted metal, says Tom Powers, an author from rural Vermont, neighbors save and help rebuild lives. But though the concept of urban altruism contradicts the notion of a cold, impersonal big city, I've been playing a game of collecting wonderful nuggets that define it.

title: When Exhibitions Have More to Say Than to Show
description: CALL it trickle-down festivalism; it's probably coming soon to a museum near you. It's the phenomenon of exhibitions that, while nowhere near as large as shows like Documenta, nonetheless display similar traits: a Lazy Susan of moralizing primness, eccentric materials, intellectual dryness, multidisciplinary amorphousness or high-tech spectacle slowly revolving on a pedestal of arrested artistic development.

title: Does Something Smell? Get a Gas Mask. Cheap.
description: A warehouse in Port Newark sits stuffed with 81,000 Russian gas masks, lost in customs limbo, just waiting for a disaster to strike. So Neil Chiarello, who understands how to move merchandise, saw an opportunity.

title: The World; What Victory in Iraq Means for U.S. Foreign Policy
description: LAST week was victory week for the Cheney-Rumsfeld wing of the Bush administration, and to some minds it was the decisive moment in the 27-month-long struggle for the soul of the president of the United States.

title: INSIDE
description: North Korea Eases Stance

title: Hotels Were Ready For This Slump
description: MANY of the nation's hotel rooms are empty, and innkeepers have few clues as to when conditions will improve.

title: Lisa Seslowe, Jeremy Gans
description: Lisa Ellen Seslowe, a daughter of Marsha and Jerry Seslowe of Manhasset, N.Y., was married last evening to Jeremy Adam Gans, a son of Diane M. Gans and Terry A. Gans of Potomac, Md. Rabbi Darcie Crystal officiated at the Pierre in Manhattan.

title: The Longtime Student
description: SEAN BOYLE has started college three times. The first time was right out of high school, nearly a decade ago, when he enrolled at Eugene Lang College in New York City. He had been a solid student in high school but dropped out of college just weeks into his first semester to pursue acting. The second time was about a year later, after giving up on the theater. This time, he worked as a temp and attended Nassau Community College on Long Island. That lasted a semester, until the company he was working for offered him a full-time job. He bolted again.

title: A House Historian
description: New Jersey has lots of homes built before World War II, and the owners either love them or hate them. Those of the first category can be passionate about wanting to know more about their property, and Beth Potter was no different. When she and her husband, Ned Potter, a correspondent for ABC News, bought an 1891 Victorian in Haworth, she landed at the Bergen County Courthouse in Hackensack. With her skills for hunting down detail from years in radio and TV journalism, she walked away with a new career.

title: Carolyn Stoller, Theodore Steingut
description: Carolyn Francine Stoller and Theodore Seth Steingut are to be married today on board the Marika, a yacht sailing the East River. Justice Abraham G. Gerges of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, will officiate.

title: 'EVERYONE'S A LITTLE BIT RACIST'
description: AS they come to terms, or don't, with being adults, the 20-something puppet and human characters in the new Off Broadway musical ''Avenue Q'' ruefully sing through their problems. In this song plus dialogue, the show's creators, Robert Lopez and Jeff Marx (music and lyrics) and Jeff Whitty (book), have their characters -- black, white and Japanese -- admit to taking guilty pleasure in racist jokes.

title: Emmanuel Ghent, 77, Composer, Innovator and Psychoanalyst
description: Dr. Emmanuel Ghent, a pioneering composer of computer-generated electronic music and a practitioner, researcher and teacher of psychoanalysis, died on March 31 in New York. He was 77.

description: WHEN Winslow Homer was a boy, his father moved the family from Boston to Cambridge, near Harvard. The old man's intentions were obvious: Charles Savage Homer wanted his three sons to study one day at the oldest and most prestigious institution of higher learning in the United States.

title: Diagnosis
description: I found it puzzling that an elderly woman in renal failure with a high fever would be expected to give an accurate accounting of her medication regimen. The physician's inquiry about ''any new medicines'' was fruitful ground for misunderstanding.

title: Israel Says Iraqi Missile Threat Has Passed
description: JERUSALEM, April 13  Israel's defense minister said today the danger of an Iraqi missile attack had passed and citizens could put away their gas masks. Meanwhile, Israeli commentators questioned whether other regional dangers might also soon diminish.

description: HIRSCH-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Herbert. Devoted mother of Mark (Rosalie), and Gail Liner (Robert). Cherished grandmother of Brian, Josh, Lisa, Jared and Alix. Dear sister of Roslyn Barberio (Paul), and Alfred Zeff (Doris). Services Sunday, 1:15 PM ''Sinai Chapels'' 162-05 Horace Harding Exp, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Bands Battle for Five-Minute Stab at Fame
description: LIKE many local musicians, Steven Marc Stoffers's dream is to make it big, real big. Which is why at 5:53 p.m. on a recent Tuesday, Mr. Stoffer, the lead singer in an alternative band called Shredds, was first in line, acoustic guitar in hand, for an 8 p.m. electric and acoustic amateur night at the Downtown, a club in Farmingdale.

title: Diagnosis
description: It was indeed fortunate that the patient's son happened to be in the room when the medical team was on rounds. If not, the resident might never have made a correct diagnosis. Of course, since allopurinol, the medication for gout, was stopped on admission to the hospital, the patient would have gotten better anyway. No etiology would have been identified. (''Sometimes you just get better.'')

Beifield Jr. will officiate at Congregation Beth Ahabah, where the bride's mother is the cantor and music director.

title: Coming Together Where a River Forks
description: ON the eighth day of our raft trip down the Kanektok River, from the Ahklun Mountains in southwestern Alaska to the Bering Sea, I had to admit it -- my 18-year-old son, Adam, and I were lost. We were without a phone or radio, without a guide and without the slightest bit of first-hand knowledge of the country we were in.

title: What Makes Sandy Run?
description: ONE of the most endearing traits of Sanford I. Weill, the chairman and chief executive of Citigroup, is that his drives and ambitions are transparent. He is obsessed with three things: doing deals, the price of Citigroup stock and how he is perceived by the business establishment.

title: Unreal Loyalties
description: As a word, ''freedom'' is frighteningly malleable. It becomes a banner in war -- unfurl it, and we are all supposed to cheer and go marching along in sanctimonious lock step. But it justifies honorable struggles too: for freedom from servitude and slavery, freedom from poverty or persecution, freedom from terror and despair. And not a day goes by without our invoking the right to speak, write and think freely.

title: Philadelphia Schools Look Within to Improve
description: Eight months into the school year, students, teachers, parents and administrators at Potter-Thomas Elementary School say that privatization has transformed their school. The hallways are clean and orderly, the classrooms calm. The new principal, Sergio Rodriguez, is in control.

title: BackTalk; Opening the Books Should Open N.H.L.'s Eyes
description: Four weeks ago, the Los Angeles Kings fan Phil Propper sat in a Midtown Manhattan restaurant explaining how he became the first fan to examine a team's financial records. The Kings' president, Tim Leiweke, had claimed that his team would lose at least $10 million, and to mollify skeptics who feared that the club would soon trade star players in a salary dump, he offered to open his books.

title: Responding to SARS
description: MARK SOUTRA, a social sciences teacher at East Windsor High School, had been anticipating for months his work-related trip to Guangdong province in southern China at the end of March. The war in Iraq didn't faze him, but when Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome struck Guangdong province, making it the epicenter of a disease that continues to spread throughout the world, he decided to stay home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENN, MATTHEW
description: PENN-Matthew, 89, died on April 3, from Alzheimers. He graduated from University of Penn and Columbia University School of Social Work. He was Executive Director of the Bronx YM-YWHA. He and his wife, Mary, owned and directed Camp Vega in Readfield, ME, for 21 years. Later he was Director of the National Conference of Jewish Communal Services. His wife Mary died in 1969 and his second wife, Aviva Kaufman Penn, died in 1998. He will be missed by his daughters, Janet Penn of Philadelphia, Diana Locker of Kinderhook, NY, and Roberta Zuckerman of Portland, ME; his grandchildren, Adam and Miriam, as well as the children of Aviva Kaufman Penn, Gideon and Josh Kaufman, Abigail Wenner, and their children. He was devoted to his family, his work and the Jewish community. Those wishing to honor him are encouraged to make a donation to the Alzheimers Association or the Israel Emergency Fund of Federation.

description: GELLERMAN-Dr. Saul William. Former Dean of the Graduate School of Management, University of Dallas. Worldwide management consultant. Died on March 26th, 2003 in Cleveland. title: 'A Mighty Wind': 'Spinal Tap' For Folkies?
description: FOLK music, as Bob Dylan defined it in the mid-1960's, when he was extricating himself from the genre to pursue rock 'n' roll, is ''a bunch of fat people.'' Four decades later, the writer and director Christopher Guest has provided an illustration to accompany that definition: ''A Mighty Wind,'' a mightily cutting film parody of the folk scene, populated mainly by people who are fat -- or bald or old, or cosmetically doctored to look so. Mr. Dylan and Mr. Guest have each made the same satiric point, that the world of commercialized acoustic music that culminated in the ''folk boom'' of the Kennedy era is a pathetic joke.

title: Island of Dreams Delayed
description: AT the end of March, Westchester County's option to buy Davids Island, 78 acres in the Long Island Sound, expired. The plan, only the last in a long series, had been to raze Fort Slocum, the deteriorating former Army base on the island and make the space into a county park.

title: Chinese Food That Emphasizes Finesse
description: IF most Chinese restaurants are bottles of beer, Garden Court is a martini, an affordable one. This sleek, sophisticated spot serves Cantonese fare, but don't expect egg foo young, shrimp in lobster sauce, chow mein and egg-drop soup Cantonese. The 150-seat Garden Court, at 206 East Jericho Turnpike in Huntington Station (631-351-6888), is not the restaurant of your youth. Instead, it's a newfangled Cantonese with creative Hong Kong twists and turns, a substantial wine list, a non-Asian wait staff and an emphasis on quality and finesse, not volume.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. Most people have watersheds in their careers. Tom Kundig had a water cabin. When he was a boy vacationing with his family on Lake Coeur d'Alene (only 10 miles from the house photographed on the previous pages), he was drawn to this 1960 Modernist cabin designed by his father's boss, the architect Royal McClure. ''It left an impression on me even then,'' he said. ''It was a very classic midcentury design, with delicate detailing and proportions -- open to the landscape and very optimistic.'' Thirty-odd years passed, and Kundig became an architect like his dad and started building weekend getaways for his own clients. Five years ago, he was on a Coeur d'Alene building site when a flashback made him wander down the road a bit. In a perfect bit of coincidence, there stood the McClure cabin. ''That little cabin helped teach me to keep things light and expressive of the landscape,'' he said.

description: Jody, Albert and Jason Laboz, the principals of United American Land, developers of a residential condominium building scheduled to open this summer at 63 West 17th Street, never actually met Lyla Aubry, the broker who sold them the property.

description: Pfc. Jessica D. Lynch, the Army supply clerk who was captured in Iraq and then rescued by United States troops there, arrived at an Air Force base in Maryland this afternoon and was taken to a medical center here with other wounded soldiers.

title: Investing; A New Investment, Courtesy of Canada
description: INCOME trusts, which have surged in popularity in Canada, are being offered on the New York Stock Exchange as antidotes to shrinking stock portfolios and tiny fixed-income returns.

title: As Labor Talks Bog Down, Tenants Face Prospect of Holding Doors and Hauling Trash
description: With both sides reporting scant progress in negotiations, the union representing 28,000 apartment building workers and the association representing building owners say that they remain far apart on critical issues and that there is a strong chance of a strike when the current contract expires at 12:01 a.m. on April 21.

title: Ideas & Trends; Rebuilding the Alliance to Rebuild Globalization
description: ALL wars end in reconstruction. This time the most visible reconstruction will be in Iraq -- in the form of roads, hospitals and, hopefully, a parliament. But there is the additional challenge of rebuilding the Western alliance: with President Jacques Chirac of France meeting with the leaders of Russia and Germany, the lyse Palace and the White House seem so far apart. Yet rebuilding the alliance is key if the Bush administration is to rebuild an idea that Washington has championed for half a century: globalization.

title: No-Minimum-Balance Bank Expands in Westchester
description: Washington Mutual Inc., the company that says it is ''ending the oppression of minimum balance,'' announced last week its plan to open five branches in Westchester this year. Washington Mutual, the largest savings and loans institution in the nation, does not require a minimum balance to open or maintain a free personal checking account, unlike most banks.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH -- Natasha Fraser-Cavassoni; Bookworms in Chic Places
description: HERE is the axis of chic: Hollywood, Harper's Bazaar, art, publishing and Paris. Natasha Fraser-Cavassoni, 40, is a daughter of Antonia Fraser, the British writer, and a stepdaughter of the playwright Harold Pinter. Through him, she got her first job, at 19, as a dogsbody, or gofer, for the fading Hollywood producer Sam Spiegel.

title: Portrait of the Art Teacher as a Melodramatic Twit
description: WATCHING ''Six Feet Under'' is a rich, strange experience no matter what business you're in. But for those of us in the art world, the HBO series has become something of a fixation. Last season's finale showed Claire (Lauren Ambrose), the mixed-up teenage daughter of the Fisher brood, desperate to win entrance to the fictitious LAC-Arts, a local art school. This season's opener found her happily ensconced there -- or as happily as an 18-year-old can be -- sketching nude models, learning to draw perfect circles and complaining about being ''forced to perform pointless tasks like a lab rat.''

title: Americans Abroad

title: April 6-12: INTERNATIONAL; BAGHDAD FALLS
description: American forces took control of Baghdad as Saddam Hussein's regime collapsed three weeks into the war. Jubilant Iraqis toppled statues of their former leader, whose fate remained unknown. With the collapse of the government came widespread looting by Iraqis in Baghdad and other cities. But the fighting was not yet over. In addition to sporadic shooting and a suicide bombing in the capital, there was heavy fighting for a town on the Syrian border. In the north, Kurdish fighters took control of Kirkuk and helped to begin securing Mosul, bringing concern from Turkey, which fears the Kurds will seek to establish an independent state. The last major military target for the United States was Tikrit, Mr. Hussein's ancestral home.

title: The Philosopher Of Islamic Terror
description: Berman concludes in his article, ''There is something to worry about.'' Indeed, there is. And it extends beyond the symbolism of Sayyid Qutb's Hitlerian mustache. Qutb's vision of Islam is a vision of the absolute law of sharia and the purity of jihad and martyrdom.

title: Carving a Niche in Generic Drugs
description: IMPORTING chemicals isn't glamorous. And for 50 years after it was founded in 1947 by two Queens chemists, the Aceto Corporation usually generated company news about as exciting to read as your old high school chem textbook.

title: In a Rush, the Senators Get Even With the Isles
description: The Islanders had been awaiting an onslaught from the Ottawa Senators for 72 hours, but it became apparent quickly tonight that knowing about a talented team's barrage and stopping one are two different things.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, RUTH
description: ALLEN-Ruth, on April 7, 2003, in Westminster, VT. Dear friend and mentor, talented psychotherapist. She lived a life full of music, gardening and travel. Fiercely independant. Generous spirit who loved gathering people to share the good things of life. Her impact has changed us all. B. & B. Clark, H. Brownlee, & M.A. Code

title: The Philosopher Of Islamic Terror
description: Berman asks, ''Who will defend liberal ideas against the enemy of liberal ideas?'' And, sadly, the great mind and voice of Daniel Patrick Moynihan have just been laid to rest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, SAMUEL
description: STEIN-Samuel. The Board and Officers of The Westchester Jewish Conference join Barbara and the family in mourning the loss of our past President. Sam was a strong supporter of the Westchester Jewish community and of Israel. His inspiration and leadership will be long missed. Irwin Davison, President

title: BLACKBOARD: War And Peace; Military Schools at the Forefront
description: PUBLIC opinion on the Iraq war may be deeply divided, but interest in the military is on the rise, judging by applications to service academies. ''This is a sea change in young people's attitudes,'' says Capt. Richard G. Gurnon, a Vietnam veteran and vice president of student services at the Massachusetts Maritime Academy. ''Instead of, 'I'm going into the maritime academy for its great placement rate,' what I see now is, 'I want to serve my country. I want to be part of the people ferrying the matriel for war with Iraq.''

title: Empire Maker's Dominance Displayed Again at Wood
description: Bobby Frankel developed a blueprint within minutes of Empire Maker's crushing victory in the Florida Derby, the race that solidified his status as the horse to beat in the Kentucky Derby. Frankel knew what his horse needed: one more race, not too easy but certainly not too hard, just something to start putting the finishing strokes on the masterpiece he was sure he was creating.

title: Americans Abroad
description: To the Editor: I have just returned from two months in South America, specifically Peru, Bolivia, Paraguay and Brazil, where I have lived and visited frequently. I did not experience any lessening of friendship for Americans, but people I know were appalled at the war and cynical about our administration's motives. Memories of this country's heavy-handed dealings with dictatorships during the cold war were uppermost in the minds of many of my friends; they felt that once again, treatment of Latin America would be given low priority and their needs and interests ignored.

title: If They Had Time in a Bottle
description: The Sisterhood of Temple Beth El in Chappaqua recently convened the fourth annual ''WWW: Wise Wonderful Women of Westchester'' and invited a panel to discuss their career challenges and the balance (or lack of it) in the lives they now lead. Each was asked the question: What would you do if you had three extra hours in your day?

title: The World; Iran Warily Confronts New Neighbors: Americans
description: AN American rocket killed a 13-year-old boy. A second injured three people; a third struck an empty Oil Ministry depot. These were not precision strikes in Iraq. They were rockets gone astray, landing in Iran.

title: A Purge With a Purpose
description: ''Propaganda,'' Fidel Castro instructed a comrade in a letter written in 1954, ''is the very soul of our struggle.'' What, then, was Mr. Castro, champion spinmeister, thinking last week when he tossed some 75 Cuban writers and dissidents into prison for up to 28 years, after a grim procession of quickie show trials worthy of Stalin? Or on Friday, when he summarily executed three men who had hijacked a passenger ferry on April 2?

title: Snow Days at the Broadmoor
description: TWILIGHT at the Broadmoor's dim and stately Hotel Bar. Television screens mounted above the amber Tiffany-glass bar lamps and the dark wood paneling flicker with the final countdown to war. Outside a late winter storm rages against the Rockies, billowing snow through the golden halos of the terrace lights. Black and white swans swim unperturbed on Cheyenne Lake, while a few hearty souls move back and forth across the bridge that connects the historic main building, where I sit nursing a drink, and the newer West Complex on the other side of the lake.

title: The Philosopher Of Islamic Terror
description: Paul Berman's remarkable article should put to rest the idea that United States policies are the reason for the terror attacks of Sept. 11. It isn't United States support for Israel or globalization or the extreme poverty in the third world. The reason for the terror is the existence of the secular state model best exemplified by the United States.

title: North Atlantic Race Lineup Grows
description: The 86-foot Zephyrus V, owned by the Californian Bob McNeil, joined 61 other yachts in the lineup for this summer's DaimlerChrysler North Atlantic Challenge, a trans-Atlantic race for fully crewed, monohulled yachts. The 3,600-mile course runs from Newport, R.I., to Cuxhaven, Germany, then up the Elbe River to Hamburg. The majority of the fleet will start June 14; the faster, larger yachts will start June 21.

title: Travel Advisory; Work in Progress From the 19th Century
description: Visitors to England who like to poke around old mansions have a new place to visit -- Tyntesfield (pronounced TINTS-field), a Victorian Gothic country house and estate that opened for guided tours last month.

title: Open House
description: The countryside around Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, would not seem to indicate that architecture -- at least the kind with a capital A -- is much of a priority. In fact, apart from a few new colonial-style farmhouses that look as if they were airlifted in from a Connecticut suburb, most of what you see simply falls under the category of ''buildings.'' So it's all the more surprising, after you've traveled some long, winding roads and come to the edge of a lake, to see an arresting house of concrete block. You enter through a 19-foot-high vaultlike steel front door and make your way along bare concrete floors around a massive wooden stair (which leads up to the master bedroom), and suddenly the space explodes into a double-height living area, with an enormous steel window that flips up, like some larger-than-life garage door, the better to showcase the spectacular view beyond.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 30 about mosquito control in Suffolk County misstated the source of printed information about the toxicity of methoprene, a pesticide that kills larvae. It was Kevin McAllister, executive director of Peconic Baykeeper in Riverhead, not Dominick V. Ninivaggi, superintendent of vector control for the Suffolk County Department of Public Works.

title: Entrepreneurship; Out of Trouble, Into Business
description: MARCUS OLIVER and Marcus Gallegos, both 20, run ''garage sales'' out of a small warehouse in the Mission District of San Francisco. They canvass the neighborhood for damaged household goods, used furniture to restore and toys to repair. They post fliers and take out small ads in community newspapers, looking for basements to clean out and overstuffed garages. ''We grab anything we can sell,'' Mr. Oliver says. In the last two years, they have held more than 40 sales, earning $100 to $200 each time.

title: It Killed His Date
description: To the Editor:

title: The Purest Mongrels
description: BLAU/KEIL/FELD: 'BRIGHT BALKAN MORNING' (Wesleyan University Press). Charles Keil is the kind of endangered-species scholar who believes that music is something played and shared and lived with, not studied at a remove. So he went with his Greek-born wife, Angeliki Keil, to live among the Roma musicians (some call them Gypsies) of northern Greece. This book attempts a kaleidoscopic report: he wrote about the musicians, the music and the gigs (at marches, weddings, baptisms, wrestling matches); she wrote about the people and their history; Dick Blau took high-contrast black-and-white photographs; Steven Feld made recordings for an enclosed CD. The result is a remarkable work on the ''layering'' (in their words) of culture within the Roma people. Because of a long history of invasions and colonizations, Roma language and music have been shaped by Indians, medieval Greeks, Huns, Persians, Bulgarians, Turks, Albanians, Americans. What can we take from it? That few people are defined by a single culture. Anyone interested in popular music could use more exposure to this idea. Which leads us to . . .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, ANTHONY M. AND ANNE
description: FISHER-Anthony M. and Anne. On behalf of the Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art and the Committee on Painting and Sculpture, we extend our most profound sympathy to our dear friend Emily Fisher Landau and her family on the untimely passing of Tony and his wife Anne. A family passionately committed to the arts had been deeply diminished by this tragic accident, but the world has forever been enhanced by their lives. We all share their sadness and send our heartfelt condolences. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art

title: April 6-12: NATIONAL; CANNIBALS ALL
description: Everyone knows that eating people is wrong, wrong, wrong. But geneticists have now discovered a genetic signature in many ethnic groups that suggests anthropophagy has been a fixture in human history. The signature protects people against the group of neurodegenerative diseases caused by protein elements known as prions. Because prions don't jump easily from one species to another, the researchers say the protective effect probably arose from frequent eating of human flesh, rather than of infected animals. Some anthropologists believe cannibalism is just a slogan to demonize enemies and rarely occurs in practice. The new genetic evidence suggests it was ubiquitous. Nicholas Wade

title: Farewell to Supersonic Travel
description: Time is money, but only up to a point. That is the bittersweet lesson of the supersonic Concorde's retirement, announced Thursday by British Airways and Air France. For three decades, the needle-nose jet, travel's ultimate status symbol, has been able to hurtle passengers across the Atlantic at twice the speed of sound. But the economics have never caught up with the technology.

title: I.R.A. Submits Statement on Deadlock
description: LONDON, April 13  The Irish Republican Army, under pressure to disarm to save the Northern Ireland peace process, submitted a confidential statement to the British and Irish governments tonight outlining how far it would go to break the deadlock.

title: April 6-12: INTERNATIONAL; CUBA CRACKDOWN
description: Fidel Castro's government executed three men who had hijacked a ferry in early April. They -- and four others who received life sentences during secret, summary trials -- had threatened to toss passengers overboard unless they were allowed to go to the United States.The executions, by firing squad, infuriated even moderate American lawmakers, who said that Mr. Castro seemed intent on eliminating any chance of easing the trade embargo.

title: Investing in the Futures of Oil
description: My friends and I ardently oppose the war in Iraq on both moral and political grounds. Would it be ethical to invest in oil futures, believing the war I oppose might increase their value? I say yes: my money would not finance anything directly war-related (as an investment in Northrop Grumman might), and these futures represent oil from places like Nigeria and the North Sea, not Iraq. My friends say such an investment would be war profiteering. I don't have money to invest; but if I did, would it be right? Andrew Miller, New York

title: Frankel Tries a 37,587-to-1 Shot
description: Two years ago in May, not long after laying eyes on a yearling sired by Unbridled and out of the mare Toussaud, Bobby Frankel proclaimed he had finally found his Kentucky Derby winner and could not wait until 2003. Two days ago at Aqueduct, after riding that nearly grown-up colt to a half-length victory in the Wood Memorial, Jerry Bailey offered his conviction that Empire Maker was a threat to capture the Triple Crown.

title: Appetite for War Films Seems Less Hearty
description: Nearly every military-related film to reach theaters this year has been a box-office disappointment, leaving some in Hollywood to question how much the 24-hour news coverage of the Iraq invasion has dimmed the public appetite for images of combat.

title: The Iraq Money Tree
description: Invading, occupying and rebuilding Iraq will cost American taxpayers more than $100 billion. But for some lucky companies, Iraq is emerging as a profit center. The administration has begun farming out contracts, and politically connected firms like Halliburton are among the early winners. This looks like naked favoritism and undermines the Bush administration's portrayal of the war as a campaign for disarmament and democracy, not lucre.

description: President Bush accused Syria today of harboring senior Iraqi military and government officials and demanded ''cooperation'' in punishing some of them. But he stopped short of threatening to use military force against Syria.

title: A NATION AT WAR: THE FAMILIES -- Lithia Springs, Ga.; A Convergence Of Joyous Relatives
description: His sister-in-law recognized him by his knock-knees. His mother recognized him by his smile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, IDA ROBBINS
description: GINSBERG-Ida Robbins. On April 13, 2003, in NYC. Beloved wife of the late Mitchell I. Ginsberg. She is survived by a sister, Anne Cheslow of Sierra Madre, CA, and six nieces and nephews. She will always be remembered for her warm smile and cheerful presence. The kindness and friendliness that she radiated will continue to inspire those who have been touched by her. Ida Ginsberg was loved by all who knew her and she will be sorely missed. Memorial service on Sunday, April 27, at 2 PM, The Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Ida R. and Mitchell I. Ginsberg Social Policy Fund at Columbia University School of Social Work, 622 West 113th St, NYC 10025.

title: Walter Mosley
description: Following his participation in the TimesTalks series on March 8, the author of "Devil in a Blue Dress" and most recently "What Next" answered NYTimes.com readers' questions.

title: A Landmark Under the Knife (Actually, the Chisel); Artisans in Stone and Bronze Remake a Building Scarred on 9/11
description: In the inexorable rebirth of ground zero, it is at last the season for the masters of bronze and stone.

title: U.S. May Have to Allow Others to Inspect Iraqi Arms
description: The Bush administration may be legally bound to let independent inspectors confirm any findings of unconventional weapons in Iraq, administration and independent arms experts said. But they added that the White House, which has resisted help from the United Nations in the search for weapons, may decide to ignore such legalities.

title: New Jersey Family Grieving Daughter's Death Is Lifted by Son's Rescue in Iraq
description: Last week Athol Riley found himself referring to his son, Sgt. James J. Riley, in the past tense. Nearly three weeks had passed since Sergeant Riley and several other members of the Army's 507th Maintenance Company were captured after being ambushed in southern Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAWSON, BEULAH
description: LAWSON-Beulah. April 14, 1988. My most beloved mother, to think of you brings more happiness, beauty, and joy to my heart and mind than this world ever could. Forever by your side, your adoring daughter, Norm

title: Seoul Tries to Thwart Takeover of Big Korean Oil Refiner
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 14 - A little-known overseas investment fund collided today with a government that is determined to keep it from gaining control of the SK Corporation, Korea's largest oil refiner and the flagship of the SK Group, the country's third-largest conglomerate.

title: Casualties
description: Announced military casualties in the Iraq war zone as of 3 p.m. Eastern time Sunday:

title: U.S. Search for Illegal Arms Narrowed to About 36 Sites
description: American forces have narrowed their hunt for banned weapons in Iraq to about three dozen sites, hoping to accelerate their search, government officials say. So far, no chemical, biological or nuclear weapons have been found.

title: Despite Victory Won by Mayor, School Control Is Not Assured
description: When Joel I. Klein took over as New York City schools chancellor last August, the first chancellor to be handpicked solely by the mayor, the political battlefield seemed to have been swept clean after decades of strife over the city's failing schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRINGTON, JOHN J. SR.
description: HARRINGTON-John J. Sr. On April 12, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Ruth M. (nee Cummings). Loving father of Dr. John J. Jr., Rev. Donald J., C.M., and Jay F. Cherished grandfather of William, Matthew, Patrick and Jennifer. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd. at 193 St. Visiting hours Tuesday, 7-9 PM, and Wednesday, 2-5 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 6 PM, St. John's University Chapel. Interment Thursday, Holy Cross Cemetery. Donations to St. John's University would be appreciated.

title: The Bchamel
description: Bechamel, or balsamella in Italian, is a simple sauce that is used as a base in numerous other sauces. In lasagna, it moistens and enhances flavor, lending sweetness and creaminess to the dish's character.

title: Benitez Shows Way to Another Defeat
description: Mets jerseys worn by fans in the bleachers became targets this afternoon when Armando Benitez took the mound. A game-tying home run by the Expos' Orlando Cabrera was soon sailing their way.

title: Choreography That May or May Not Include a Cab
description: Sarah Michelson has created a magical small world, a cocoon of sorts, in the concluding segment of her two-part ''Shadowmann.'' The new performance piece opened at the Kitchen last month, sprawling heroically across that large stage and out onto the street. Now at Performance Space 122, the piece continues with a reduced cast in an intimate white-carpeted space ringed with dowdy flowered curtains.

title: Spain Expels 6 Iraqi Diplomats Over Weapons in Embassy
description: MADRID, April 14  Spain has ordered six Iraqi diplomats to leave Madrid within 72 hours, after the charge d'affaires at the Iraqi mission apparently told the Spanish authorities about an illicit arms cache in the embassy.

title: Assaulting a Hussein Stronghold
description: American marines moved in three columns on Saddam Husseins ancestral home of Tikrit, where a garrison of his loyalists estimated to include 2,500 fighters is expected to make a last stand. American officials said Tikrit may harbor high-ranking military officials as well as members of Mr. Husseins inner circle, whose defeat might stand as the last major battle of the war. Looting continued in Baghdad, but the mobs now seem to be focusing on suburban communities. Marines came under fire from snipers in central Baghdad near the Palestine Hotel.

title: 'Untidy' Freedom, and a Cultural Calamity
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Untidy' Freedom, and a Cultural Calamity
description: To the Editor:

title: On Tape, a Discussion of HealthSouth's Finances
description: As the investigation into HealthSouth continues into what federal officials are calling a sweeping accounting fraud, securities regulators on Friday released part of a recording of a conversation between the company's two senior executives.

title: A NATION AT WAR: THE FAMILIES -- Valley Center, Kan.; The Old Buddies Plan a Big Party
description: This morning, a wet-eyed Shane Parker, 30, the half brother of Private Miller, phoned friend after friend from his porch, just down Meridian Avenue from Valley Center High School, where the private wrestled, played defensive end on the Hornets football team and dyed his hair purple.

title: In Hometown, Hussein's Glory Is Quickly Gone
description: TIKRIT, Iraq, April 14  The breeze off the Tigris blew through the empty halls of President Saddam Hussein's grandest palace today, its once fearsome opulence reduced, it seemed, to the most crushing sort of banality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBB, AUDREY WAGSTAFF
description: ROBB - Audrey Wagstaff. Died peacefully on April 11, 2003, following a long illness. Predeceased by her husband J. Hampden Robb. She is survived by her devoted daughters, Diana Robb McDowell and Christy Robb, her son-inlaw, Tony McDowell, and her two grandsons, Robb and Alex McDowell. She is survived also by her half sister, Debby Wainwright of West Yorkshire, England, and her half brother Philip Wagstaff of Leeds, England, and by her step-children, James, Wendy, Cynthia and David, and ten step-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers a contribution to the New York Society Library would be greatly appreciated. A memorial service will be held later this month in NYC.

title: Woodland Creatures Sing, Act and Dress Well
description: The winds of pollution have never visited the sylvan sanctuary of ''A Year With Frog and Toad,'' the pure-hearted children's musical that opened last night at the Cort Theater. No acrid airs of irony, condescension or frantic salesmanship hover over this gentle, agreeable production, which presents episodes in the friendship of two slime-free amphibians set to song.

title: Ragu Bolognese
description: The meat sauce used in our recipe is a classic and calls for ground chuck and pork. Feel free to use all beef; the pork, though, adds an extra layer of flavor. Note that the recipe is not very tomato-heavy: meat ragu should be about the meat; the tomato functions as a supporting player. If you are not making the entire dish the day before, it might still make sense to make the ragu ahead of time; it takes a good 3 hours or so, and the flavors will only get richer over time.

title: Using the Web to Pay Up
description: Fifty-three million Americans will file their taxes online this year, according to the Internal Revenue Service, and almost all of them will use software on one of the many tax-related Web sites. And so far, there seems to be two kinds of taxpayers: those who file early and those who wait until the very last minute.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Detective Charged With D.W.I After Accident
description: An off-duty Bronx detective was charged with drunken driving yesterday after he drove the wrong way on the Grand Central Parkway in Queens and ran into a car, the police said. The detective, Sean McLaughlin, was suspended from police duties after the collision at 3:10 a.m. near Francis Lewis Boulevard. Investigators said Detective McLaughlin, who sustained minor injuries, pulled his Jeep Cherokee out of a service station in the median of the parkway and into oncoming traffic when his Jeep hit a Toyota. The driver of that vehicle, who was not identified, sustained fractures to a foot and hand, the police said. The Toyota was also struck from behind by a sport utility vehicle, but the driver of the S.U.V. was not injured. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: New York Times Co.'s Earnings Rose 26% in First Quarter
description: The New York Times Company reported today that its net income rose 26.4 percent in the first quarter from the period a year earlier, bolstered by higher advertising and circulation revenue and a decline in newsprint costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EAGLE, HELEN
description: EAGLE-Helen. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Helen Eagle. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved husband, Manny, and their family. Richard J. Bornstein, Pres. Leon Fassler, Secretary

title: Israelis Get the All Clear To Stow Their Gas Masks
description: Israel's defense minister said today that the danger of an Iraqi missile attack had passed and citizens could put away their gas masks. Meanwhile, Israeli commentators questioned whether other regional dangers might also soon diminish.

title: Liberty Could Benefit From the DirecTV Deal
description: In early March, Liberty Media's chief operating officer, Gary S. Howard, told investors at a conference that Liberty was considering a bid for DirecTV. The news surprised media industry executives. Liberty, which is controlled by John C. Malone, also owned 18 percent of the News Corporation. Rupert Murdoch, the chief of News Corporation, was angered by the news, according to a veteran media executive who knows both men (although a News Corporation spokesman disagreed with that interpretation). Mr. Murdoch has long wanted to acquire DirecTV and a rival bid from his largest shareholder was hardly helpful.

title: Whitney Stoddard, 90, Art Historian and Teacher
description: Whitney S. Stoddard, an art historian and influential teacher who taught for many years at Williams College in Williamstown, Mass., died on April 2 at his home there. He was 90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOYT, ROBERT G.
description: HOYT-Robert G. Trusted friend and neighbor, fighter for peace and social/economic justice, the preservation of Capitol Hall will serve as your legacy. We mourn this great loss to our community. Board and Staff of Goddard Riverside Community Center

title: Knicks Hope to Spoil Jordan's Home Finale
description: Don Chaney does not feel the least bit mushy. He will not become teary-eyed or sentimental when Michael Jordan takes the floor tonight for the final time against the Knicks. In fact, Chaney hopes to ruin what will be Jordan's last home game.

title: Lab Decodes Genes Of Virus Suspected In Lethal Outbreak
description: Scientists in Canada announced over the weekend that they had broken the genetic code of the virus suspected of causing severe acute respiratory syndrome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEATING, MILDRED
description: KEATING-Mildred. On April 12, 2003. New York City school teacher for over 40 years. Beloved wife of the late John (Jack) Keating. Loving mother of Rev. Timothy F. Keating, Alice Keating-Sahner and the late Barbara Anne Novak. Also survived by her dear grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Visiting Sunday, 7-9 PM, and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10:30 AM, at St. Ephrem's R.C. Church. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery.

title: An Elegant Baghdad Street Becomes a Museum of Riches and Dreams
description: The opulence of Sadeh Street is almost too much to describe.

title: The Next to Go: Yasir Arafat
description: It has become de rigueur in Europe and the Arab world to proclaim that the problem in the Middle East is that the Bush administration is not ''engaged'' in restarting the Israeli-Palestinian peace process. Yet the United States has been engaged in important ways, and hopeful signs are now coming from Israel and the Palestinians. To exploit this moment, the European and Arab states themselves must now also become engaged.

title: Murdoch's First Step: Make the Sports Fan Pay
description: To understand why Rupert Murdoch is buying control of the satellite broadcaster DirecTV, ask fans of the Orlando Magic or the Minnesota Timberwolves. Mr. Murdoch's Fox cable networks have the local television rights to both basketball teams. When Time Warner Cable refused to pay the fees that Fox demanded to carry the channels this year, the company kept the games off cable for 10 weeks of the season.

title: Mocking the White House at War; Ignoring Criticism, a British Playwright Satirizes the Invasion of Iraq
description: In the run-up to the war with Iraq, when Justin Butcher's ''Madness of George Dubya'' was playing at a fringe theater in north London, Mr. Butcher began to sense that some Americans might bridle at his virulent lampoon of the Bush administration and its readiness to go to war.

description: BEIJING, April 14 — Reported cases of a mysterious respiratory disease jumped sharply today in an interior province of north-central China, heralding the possible spread of the dangerous pneumonia through the country's vast hinterlands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEBENZAHL, NANCY BAAR
description: NEBENZAHL-Nancy Baar. It is with deep sorrow and regret that we mourn the passing of Nancy Baar Nebenzahl of Glen Head, NY, and Lake Worth, FL. Talented artist, sculptor and rug maker. Beloved mother of Marcie Aiuvalasit, James and Andrew Nebenzahl, mother-in-law of Anthony Aiuvalasit, Sue Molinda and Maureen Nebenzahl, loving grandmother to Tony, Sharon, Jason, Alethea, Adam, Amelia and Christopher. Services Wednesday, 11 AM, at Congregation Emanuel of Westchester, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESSEGUIER, CLEMENS
description: RESSEGUIER-Clemens. On April 11, 2003, at age 87. Beloved husband of the late Olga, stepfather of Radford West, John Wyman and Virginia Meyer and stepgrandfather of seven.

title: U.S. Sharply Scolds Syria and Threatens Sanctions
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  The Bush administration sharply scolded Syria today, warning it to "ponder the implications" of what Washington says is that country's support of terrorism, its development of chemical weapons and its harboring of fugitives from the regime of Saddam Hussein.

title: Lacking Necessities, Many Iraqis Can't Focus on the Future
description: For the first time anywhere in Iraq since the war started, the people in this port town gathered tonight for a remarkable democratic display -- a town hall meeting.

title: New Work in Old Dublin House Spurs a Preservation Battle
description: As a city so old that construction crews regularly unearth medieval, and even Viking, artifacts, Dublin has surprisingly few examples of significant architecture. For many years, the Irish only made things worse by allowing the ruthless demolition of buildings that were perceived to be leftovers of British rule.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORISON, R. BRUCE
description: MORISON-R. Bruce. Age 60. Husband of Susan. Father of Amanda. Brother of James. Floor broker, Interstate Securities, NYSE. Memorial services will be held at the Rye Presbyterian Church, Rye, NY, Tuesday, April 15, at 4 p.m. Donations may be made to Berkshires School, Sheffield, MA 01257.

title: Brodeur Adds Another Shutout to Put Devils in Command
description: After recording his 14th playoff shutout today, Martin Brodeur was asked which of his 29 saves in the Devils' 3-0 victory over the Boston Bruins was the toughest.

title: Some optimism has been expressed on the prospects for improved demand for commercials.
description: DEBATE over the twin, intertwined topics of the moment the economy and the war -- dominated the closing general session of the 2003 Management Conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

title: Compressed Data; An AOL Service Allows Friends and Relatives To Follow the Troops
description: Zaneta Burkett of La Plata, Md., has been worried about her sister-in-law, who is stationed with an engineering unit in the Middle East. But she has been able to follow the movements of the 3rd or 4th Infantry Divisions through messages that pop up on her computer screen. ''I'd get an alert saying '45 miles to Baghdad,' she said. ''I knew exactly where they were.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDMAN, LAWRENCE, ESQ.
description: WALDMAN-Lawrence, Esq. Died April 9, 2003. Survived by his devoted wife, Ruth, three loving children, Cindy, Steven and Adam, and adoring grandchildren Benjamin, Jonathan and Caroline.

title: Photo Shops Find the Bright Side of Digital Technology
description: A couple of years ago, Oregon Photo Supply looked to be a goner. Its sales peaked at $1.3 million in the late 90's. Then, digital photography soared as the economy plunged. Sales sank so low that Oregon Photo closed four of its five stores.

title: As Chaos Continues, U.S. Sends Aid to Iraq
description: The first team of American health workers flew into Baghdad from Kuwait today on a military aircraft and brought with them medical supplies for one of the city's looted hospitals.

title: Paris Journal; Sister Nicole Fights the Good Fight as Financier
description: Soon after dawn, when Sister Nicole finishes her morning prayers, her thoughts quickly turn from God to Mammon.

title: Compressed Data; Satellite Radio Channel Will Focus on Interests Of Gays and Lesbians
description: Gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender radio listeners are getting a nationwide satellite radio channel focused on their interests starting today, thanks to Sirius Satellite Radio.

title: Theme Park In Florida Is Nothing But a Memory
description: Remember ''Easy to Love,'' the one where Esther Williams water-skis her way into the heart of Van Johnson? How about ''Moon Over Miami,'' where Betty Grable plays a gold digger and Don Ameche plays a rich Romeo?

title: Honoring Alan Lomax, Folk-Music Crusader
description: One Monday morning in August 1942, the Mississippi Delta bluesman David Honeyboy Edwards was sleeping off a weekend of playing and drinking when a big car -- a brand-new Hudson Super 6 -- roared up to his house. It wasn't a bill collector; it was the folklorist Alan Lomax.

title: Latino Church Greets Its New Home With a Procession of the Faithful
description: Hundreds of worshipers carrying palm fronds swaying in the breeze left Our Lady of Guadalupe church in a Palm Sunday procession yesterday. They walked one block west along 14th Street to St. Bernard's church, where they deposited a life-size portrait of the Blessed Virgin near the altar to symbolize the marriage of two Roman Catholic parishes.

title: Advocates' Groups to Fight Local Pursuit of Immigrants
description: A coalition of immigration advocacy groups is challenging the Justice Department's decision to allow state and local police departments to pursue illegal immigrants as part of the war on terror.

title: Burden Grows for Southwest Hospitals
description: Felipe Gomez and a few friends were goofing around, burning ants with gasoline, when the can caught fire and left Felipe, 12, with burns over 25 percent of his body. He was admitted to Maricopa Medical Center on March 25 and already his bill exceeds $55,000, not including costs for skin graft surgery on Wednesday and daily physician costs. Hospital officials say the weeks of additional surgery and care he needs will put his final bill well above $250,000.

title: Baghdad Residents Begin a Long Climb To an Ordered City
description: The chaos that turned Baghdad into a place of nightmarish lawlessness during the past five days began today to give way to tentative signs of a city determined to begin the long climb back toward order.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, LILIAN TARBELL (GRETA)
description: KENNEDY - Lilian Tarbell (Greta). Died peacefully in her sleep at Riddle Memorial Hospital in Media, PA, in the early hours of her 96th birthday on April 10th. Among many charities, Mrs. Kennedy was a state and national officer of the Daughters of the British Empire. She is survived by a brother, the Rev. Canon Albert W. Tarbell, Albuquerque, NM, three sons, Anthony III of Rose Valley, PA, where Mrs. Kennedy lived for over 60 years, Richard T. P., NYC and Rose Valley, Jackson W. T., of Toms River, NJ, and Eaglesmere, PA, six grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. Services will be Wednesday, at 11 AM, at Christ Church, 311 South Orange St, Media, PA. Burial will be private at the US Naval Academy, Annapolis, MD.

description: ''Given all the atrocities we've seen, we feared the worst. Our hearts were lifted today.''

title: For 7 Families, Relief After Weeks of Waiting
description: ALAMOGORDO, N.M., April 13  Anecita Hudson's joy poured out in a jumble of English and her native Tagalog today, as she explained how she had always believed her son, Joseph, would survive capture by the Iraqis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHINDE, AMBAJI
description: SHINDE-Ambaji. On April 8, 2003. With great regret and deepest sorrow, we mourn the loss of Shinde. To us, you were without a doubt the greatest designer ever, and we were very fortunate to have worked with you for so many years. Your humble disposition and your incredible skills will all be greatly missed. Your friends at Graff, NY Eduard, Henry, Peter and Nino

title: Washington Talk; Medicare Caught Up In Politics
description: Medicare is a fiscal time bomb, unsustainable over the long haul and badly in need of major structural changes to save it. That, at least, is what Republicans are arguing as they begin yet another effort to pass Medicare legislation, a central element of President Bush's domestic agenda.
