title: 'Untidy' Freedom, and a Cultural Calamity; 'Republic of Oil'
description: To the Editor:

title: Boston Journal; In Big Dig Town, a Solution Adds Confusion
description: If anyone would know how to get to the Avis car rental lot from Logan Airport, wouldn't it be the people who drive the Avis shuttle buses?

title: Election Results Move Malta Closer to European Union
description: The tiny Mediterranean archipelago of Malta re-elected Prime Minister Eddie Fenech Adami's pro-European Union government this weekend, overcoming the last hurdle on the path to membership. It would be the least populous member nation, and would join the union in 2004.

title: Sports of The Times; Mickelson Loses Out On Lefty Honor, Too
description: BEFORE the Masters started, Phil Mickelson was reminded that only one left-handed golfer, Bob Charles of New Zealand, had won a major championship, the 1963 British Open in an 18-hole playoff with Phil Rodgers at Royal Lytham and St. Annes.

title: Compressed Data; Computer Science Prize To Honor 3 Forerunners Of Internet Security
description: The Association of Computing Machinery plans to announce today that Ronald L. Rivest, Adi Shamir and Leonard M. Adleman will receive the 2002 A. M. Turing Award for their development work in public-key cryptography.

title: A Festival Pops Up From Brooklyn's Underground
description: In the 1950's and 60's Brooklyn was a stronghold of jazz performance, but that's no longer true. Still, a constellation of little places -- clubs, bars, nonprofit storefront arts presenters, music schools, churches and so on -- have joined forces to present 24/7 Jazz Brooklyn, the first boroughwide jazz festival.

title: Hussein Foe Tries to Get Baghdad On Its Feet
description: Sweating in his gray suit, Dr. Muhammad Zobaidi clutched his microphone, somehow managing to keep upright among the tangle of jostling job seekers.

title: Arafat and Top Palestinian Remain Deadlocked on Cabinet
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, April 14  The new Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, remained deadlocked today with the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat over Mr. Abbas's proposed ministers for a new government, as senior members of their Fatah movement tried to broker a compromise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYES, FATHER THOMAS L.
description: HAYES-Father Thomas L. Director of the Episcopal Peace Fellowship during the Vietnam War. He participated in the draft card burning in Sheep's Meadow in Central Park in 1967. He served as minister to the American draft resisters in Sweden. Funeral services today, 4 PM, at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Windsor, VT. Blessed are the peacemakers. Norma Becker, Vietnam Peace Parade Committee

title: Elegant Magazine, Avalanche Of Dirt
description: THE DEVIL WEARS PRADA

title: World Bank and I.M.F. Say They'll Send Experts to Iraq to Investigate Postwar Needs
description: The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund announced today that they would send teams to Iraq to assess needs for reconstruction as soon as it was safe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERKINS, RICHARD S.
description: PERKINS-Richard S. Died April 10, 2003, in Hobe Sound, FL. He was born in Milton, MA, in 1910 and had a career in banking, becoming Chairman of the Executive Committee of Citibank. He also held many corporate directorships and was active in numerous charitable and civic organizations in New York City. He was a Trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Carnegie Institution of Washington. He leaves his wife, Audrey W. Perkins, children, Richard S. Perkins, Jr., Thomas H. Perkins, Sarah H. Perkins and Judith S. Perkins, five grandchildren and seven greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will take place at Christ Memorial Chapel in Hobe Sound at 4 PM on Tuesday, April 15. A memorial service in New York City will take place at a later date. Instead of flowers contributions may be made to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Clemens Is His Solid Self In a Rare Yankees Loss
description: There have been 627 days in the career of Roger Clemens when it was his turn to pitch, his turn to stride in from the bullpen after warming up, walking across the field, head down. There might be only 30 days like this left in his lifetime.

title: The Assembly
description: The final key to a great lasagna is to use real, quality Parmesan cheese, most preferably the genuine, imported variety known as Parmigiano-Reggiano. You can find it in most quality grocery stores and Italian shops and delis. It's best to just grate as much as you need.

title: Peace Snagged, I.R.A. Outlines Its Intentions
description: The Irish Republican Army, under pressure to disarm to save the Northern Ireland peace process, submitted a confidential statement to the British and Irish governments tonight outlining what it might do to break the stalemate.

title: As Qualcomm Plots Future, C.E.O.'s Son Awaits Role
description: As a young man, Paul E. Jacobs discussed antennas and data transmission rates with his father the way many of his friends and their fathers talked balls and strikes. So in 1985, when Irwin M. Jacobs started Qualcomm, a pioneering firm in mobile phone technologies, it was natural for his son to spend summers working there.

title: Attacks Riddle Afghanistan, Including Shootings and Explosions
description: Opponents of the Afghan government continued their attacks this weekend. On Saturday, a car packed with explosives blew up in eastern Afghanistan, killing the driver and three others. In the Pakistani border town of Chaman today, gunmen fired on the motorcade of the brother of the Kandahar governor, wounding him and killing another relative.

title: Bouncer Dies; Family Blames Smoking Ban
description: A bouncer at a bar on Manhattan's Lower East Side was fatally stabbed early yesterday during a fight that broke out after he asked two patrons to put out their cigarettes, the police said.

title: E-Commerce Report; As the filing deadline nears, more ways (some free) to do your taxes online, or to have them done.
description: ONLINE tax preparation services are starting to show signs of significant growth, thanks in part to a strategic move by the Internal Revenue Service.

title: She Did Not Prevail This Year, But Burk Has Time on Her Side
description: They have sparred for 10 months, never more notably than during the past week, when William Johnson stood his ground from inside the guarded gates of his Augusta National Golf Club and Martha Burk, enveloped by sheriffs and state troopers, shouted revenge from a sodden hollow turned protest site.

title: Playing for Cash, in Theory This Time
description: Bridge comes in two varieties. Social bridge is a one-table affair played in homes and clubs, often for a money stake, normally with random partnerships. Duplicate bridge consists of two or more tables, played for masterpoints and prestige with partners and teams self-selected in advance.

title: Jim Clancy: Baghdad Protesters Decry Chaos
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq (CNN) -- Looting and lawlessness may be calming down in Baghdad as joint U.S.-Iraqi police patrols get under way, but demonstrators have started protesting the disorder.

title: Youth and Fitness Offer Little Defense Against Disease
description: The new respiratory disease known as SARS is beginning to kill younger and healthier adults as well as older people here, as medical treatments are proving somewhat less effective than originally hoped, health officials announced here today.

title: Research Shows Hazards in Tiny Particles
description: A new review of research on nanoscale materials suggests that tiny particles are often toxic because of their size and are likely to pose health hazards, especially to workers making them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, TOM. TOM
description: FOX-Tom. Tom, your beautiful smile will be missed by many. Our thoughts are with Tom, Lenny and Fox-Nahem Design. Dallas Boesendahl

title: Young Star for Columbus Is a Marked Man
description: The signs that KYLE MARTINO of the Columbus Crew has arrived are stippled all over his body  a bruise here, a bump there.

title: For Those Who Question the War, Complications Amid the Pain of Loss
description: The night before her son left for Kuwait, Ruth Aitken argued with him on the telephone for nearly three hours. From her living room in State College, Pa., she told him that a war with Iraq made no sense, that it was really a scuffle over oil. Her son, an Army captain based at Fort Stewart, Ga., countered that America needed to be protected from terrorists. ''Mother,'' he finally told her, ''it's my job.''

title: Another Daring Jailbreak Embarrasses French Government
description: PARIS, April 14  In the latest in a chain of spectacular jailbreaks at French prisons, three inmates were freed today by accomplices who descended on a prison in central France in a helicopter, then used a buzz saw to rip through security netting to reach the men, two of whom were said to be drug dealers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTTERMAN, DOLLY
description: GUTTERMAN - Dolly. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Franklin S. Abrams, Pres. Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Syria's Foreign Minister Calls U.S. Charges 'Baseless'
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 14  Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa today described as "baseless" a series of accusations leveled by the United States about covert Syrian assistance to Iraq, and criticized the American military for failing to establish order in Iraq.

title: Puerto Rico Enjoys Day in Sun
description: Couples carrying palms from Mass walked past Las Lomas Park this morning at 9:30 as teenagers played baseball inside on the dirt infield. Here in this residential neighborhood about five miles from Hiram Bithorn Stadium, the Montreal Expos' home for 22 games this season, it was difficult to find a skeptic about Major League Baseball's return to Puerto Rico.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COULSON, EDITH DE RHAM
description: COULSON-Edith de Rham. Peacefully on Wednesday, 9th April, age 69, at the Trinity Hospice, London. Beloved mother of Henry, Diana and Amanda, grandmother of Dylan, Charlie and Emily. A celebration of her life with her family and many friends will be held at the end of May. Any donations are to be sent to the Royal Marsden Hospital, Fundraising Department, Downes Road, Sutton, Surrey, SN2 5PT, England.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about the dancer and actress Vera Zorina misspelled the surname of one of her sons. He is Peter Lieberson, not Liberson.

title: In Coney Island, Cyclones (And a Crystal-Clear Day)
description: It was opening weekend at Coney Island, and Gregory Bitetzakis was ready at his snack bar on Surf Avenue. There were sugary funnel cakes, bags of airy cotton candy, cold sodas, greasy fried clams and smoking-hot corn cobs.

title: Washington Asked to Show 'Restraint' Toward Syria
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  With the Middle East still severely shaken by the Iraq war, Russia, the European Union and several Arab countries implored Washington to show "greater restraint" toward Syria, which the White House sharply denounced today as a "terrorist state."

title: Straitjackets for Judges
description: Just when we should be reducing unfairness in the nation's criminal justice system, Congress is moving in the opposite direction. Last week, lawmakers approved provisions that will prevent federal judges from using their discretion to give prison terms that are shorter than those prescribed by federal sentencing guidelines. The changes were tagged on to the Amber Alert bill that creates a national notification system for child abductions.

title: Nicholson and Sandler Offer Summer Preview
description: After four sluggish weekends in a row and a box office that is down by 8 percent from the same period last year, Hollywood finally found something that audiences wanted to see: Jack Nicholson humiliating Adam Sandler.

title: Dino Yannopoulos, 83, Director With Long Tenure at the Met
description: Dino Yannopoulos, a prominent stage director at the Metropolitan Opera and elsewhere, died April 6 in Philadelphia. He was 83.

title: 'Dynasty,' With a Hip-Hop Beat
description: Finally, a show that parents can watch with their children's probation officer.

title: `Untidy' Freedom, and a Cultural Calamity
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Could Use Boost at Home
description: Sometimes the Islanders hear their fans before they see them. Loud noise seems to seep through the old concrete at Nassau Coliseum and into their dressing room, providing the Islanders with a big boost before a big game.

title: Mount Sinai's Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: A Senseless Salute
description: Soon after Ronald Reagan assumed his presidency, something new appeared with his image on the television screen. When given a salute by uniformed military personnel, Mr. Reagan would return it, shooting his right hand up to his bare head, his smile suggesting that this was something he liked to do. This unnecessary and unseemly habit was adopted by Mr. Reagan's successors, including Bill Clinton and especially George W. Bush, who steps off his plane and cocks a jaunty salute.

title: Tax Inquiries Fall as Cheating Increases
description: Investigations and prosecutions of suspected tax criminals have fallen by half over the last decade, even as cheating has grown.

Cherished grandfather of Adam Miller, Charles, and Rachel Frank and Sydney, and Ethan Dymond. Dear brother of Gloria Weiss. Adored uncle. Services 11:30 AM, Monday, at Temple Beth El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, NY.

title: Cronkite On Famine, Pestilence And Death
description: T. S. Eliot had it backward. Forget the whimper, the world will end with a bang, and possibly soon. This kind of apocalyptic foreboding underlies ''Avoiding Armageddon,'' a disturbing four-part, eight-hour documentary series running tonight through Thursday on PBS.

title: Rumsfeld Seeks Power to Reshape Armed Forces
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld is asking Congress for broad new powers to reshape the uniformed services from the highest ranking officers down to reservists and supply clerks.

title: EZ Voting in Albany
description: A legislator's voting record should be a political profile, a documentation of how the people are being represented on the big issues of the day. In Albany, however, a legislator's voting record is anything but. Unlike lawmakers in Congress or other state legislatures or even in the assemblies of Nicaragua and Albania, New York's representatives don't actually have to be present to vote.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLOOM, PERRY
description: BLOOM-Perry. Five long years. In loving memory, Doris

title: French Islam Wins Officially Recognized Voice
description: For Karima Debza, an Algerian-born mother of three and a volunteer in the local mosque, casting her vote today is a symbolic step toward promoting the rights of Muslim women in the workplace.

title: Nightly News Feels Pinch of 24-Hour News
description: With the most televised war in history winding down, executives at TV news organizations are noticing one startling detail in how Americans are watching the coverage: viewers are increasingly tuning out the broadcast networks' evening newscasts.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Priest Admits Soliciting Prostitute
description: A New Jersey priest has pleaded guilty in a Canadian court to soliciting a prostitute, according to a spokesman for the Archdiocese of Newark. The priest, Eugene Heyndricks, 60, pleaded guilty last week to having had sex with a 16-year-old male prostitute while visiting Montreal last July. He could be sentenced to up to five years in prison. Charges against Father Heyndricks's companion on the trip, William Giblin, 70, a retired New Jersey priest, were dropped because of a lack of evidence, the spokesman said. Father Heyndricks, who has served in parishes in Guttenberg, Ridgewood, Park Ridge and Fairview, and Father Giblin, a former headmaster at Seton Hall Preparatory School in West Orange, have been on administrative leave since July. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Calpers to Invest $200 Million in Japan Turnaround Fund
description: Betting that Japan's battered stock market has finally hit bottom, the California Public Employees' Retirement System will invest $200 million in a fund managed by W. L. Ross & Company, the turnaround specialists, people involved in the deal said.

title: Syria's Foreign Minister Calls U.S. Charges 'Baseless'
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 14  Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa today described as "baseless" a series of accusations leveled by the United States about covert Syrian assistance to Iraq, and criticized the American military for failing to establish order in Iraq.

title: Patents; An inventor offers a salty road map of pitfalls for those looking to bring a product to market.
description: THREE years ago, Randice-Lisa Altschul was a celebrated entrepreneur and media darling. Her most recent invention -- a disposable cellphone -- caught the attention of the BBC, CNBC, ABC, NBC, CBS, Fox, Parade, Glamour, Business Week and The Financial Times of London, all of which interviewed her. She was invited, twice, to lecture at Harvard Business School.

title: Showdown on Debt Looms for Leader of a Mexican Conglomerate
description: Ricardo B. Salinas Pliego, the brash executive who bought Mexico's second-largest television broadcaster a decade ago and extended the reach of his chain of home appliance stores into everything from banking to telecommunications, may finally be running out of wiggle room.

title: A NATION AT WAR: THE FAMILIES -- Chesapeake, Va.; Son's Health Passes Muster
description: Pam Thacker peered at the television set in her Chesapeake, Va., home today and assessed her son's image. ''He looks real healthy,'' she said of Chief Warrant Officer David S. Williams, 30. ''A lot better than I thought he would.''

title: Outdoor Market Is to Open in Hell's Kitchen
description: Nobody knows who Paddy was, or if there ever was a Paddy, but from the 1870's to the late 1930's, Paddy's Market was a weekend institution in Hell's Kitchen, sprawled under the Ninth Avenue El from 38th to 42nd Street. It was a place where New Yorkers could buy anything from bedroom slippers to beans, from eels to end tables, depending on which of hundreds of pushcart vendors rolled in on Saturdays to sell their wares until well past midnight.

title: For 7 Families, Relief After Weeks of Waiting
description: ALAMOGORDO, N.M., April 13  Anecita Hudson's joy poured out in a jumble of English and her native Tagalog today, as she explained how she had always believed her son, Joseph, would survive capture by the Iraqis.

title: By Nigeria's Standards, Elections Exceed Expectations
description: Despite delays in opening some polling places and stolen ballot boxes, the civilian government managed to conduct elections this weekend that surpassed what one observer here described as ''realistically low expectations'' for its democratic experiment.

title: Indonesia Accuses Muslim Cleric of Plot to Oust Government
description: Prosecutors in Indonesia today indicted a prominent Muslim cleric, Abu Bakar Bashir, on charges of treason and plotting to overthrow the Indonesian government and to establish an Islamic state.

title: Bush's Warning to Syria, and Words From the Deputy Syrian Ambassador
description: Following are excerpts from a question-and-answer session between President Bush and reporters at the White House yesterday, and from the NBC News program ''Meet the Press'' yesterday with Tim Russert, the host, and the Syrian deputy ambassador to the United States, Imad Moustapha, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc. Full transcripts are at nytimes.com/iraq.

title: Washington Asked to Show 'Restraint' Toward Syria
description: WASHINGTON, April 14  With the Middle East still severely shaken by the Iraq war, Russia, the European Union and several Arab countries implored Washington to show "greater restraint" toward Syria, which the White House sharply denounced today as a "terrorist state."

title: Europe Seems to Hear Echoes of Empires Past
description: As the United States began the task of finding Iraqi leaders to take power after the war is over, there were many in Europe and elsewhere who were reminded of an earlier period in global history -- the era of imperialism.

His leadership inspired ''conflict resolution'' in public schools, County Tennis Club, the Northern Westchester Arts Society and every tennis and paddle partner. We will always cherish him. title: New Magazine Has the Sound, Not the Budget, Of the Late Talk
description: Radar, a new general-interest magazine with a specific interest in pop culture, has been billed as the second coming of Tina Brown's Talk, the much-ballyhooed publication that shut down early last year after an investment of $50 million. But while Talk was christened at a lavish, celebrity-populated party at the foot of the Statue of Liberty in the summer of 1999, Radar celebrated its first issue at the beginning of April by spending approximately $100 on drinks for the staff at a nearby bar. There was no food, although the spouse of one of the executives baked a cake decorated with Radar's logo for the occasion.

title: Battle for Tikrit, Joyful Day for Prisoners and Accusations Against Syria
description: American marines gained a foothold in Tikrit in northern Iraq after encountering significant resistance. Not far away, in Samarra, there were celebrations among another group of Marines who freed seven American P.O.W.'s held captive since the early days of the war. The nascent sense of order emerging in Baghdad and other Iraqi cities was interrupted by bursts of violence, and President Bush pointed an accusatory finger at Syria.

description: Statistics that came to light today about violence in the Russian republic of Chechnya and related crime reports detail a parade of disappearances, killings and beatings that run contrary to Russian government assertions that life in Chechnya is slowly returning to normal.

description: Seven American prisoners of war were discovered alive in a town north of Baghdad today, three weeks after they vanished during fighting with the Iraqis.

title: Real Frustrations Traverse a Fictional Realm
description: My stepfather, Dan Sullivan, came into my life when I was 4, driving a turquoise Cadillac with electric windows that hummed like flies as he put them up and down. He was a poker-playing Texan who won big and shared those winnings generously, throwing the cash into the air so that it fluttered to the ground beautifully before us -- my mother, sisters and me.

title: How 3 Weeks of War in Iraq Looked From the Oval Office
description: It was the morning of March 19 in the White House Situation Room, just hours before President Bush's 48-hour ultimatum to Saddam Hussein to get out of Iraq was to expire. President Bush had just polled his war council for any last-minute reservations about the war plan. Hearing none, he issued the ''execute'' command to Gen. Tommy R. Franks, who saluted back via a flickering video screen from his headquarters in Qatar.

description: WASHINGTON, April 14  The Bush administration sharply scolded Syria today, warning it to "ponder the implications" of what Washington says is that country's support of terrorism, its development of chemical weapons and its harboring of fugitives from the regime of Saddam Hussein.

title: Proposal Frustrates U.S.O.C. Board
description: In one weekend, the United States Olympic Committee proposed not only an overhaul of its bloated structure, but also a makeover of an image tattered by scandal and ethical violations. Now its top officials want the organization to be known as a model for good governance and high personal standards for its executives, if not democratic rule.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: MUSEUM ACCUSED OF ILLEGAL LAYOFFS The National Labor Relations Board has accused the Museum of Modern Art of illegally laying off three longtime workers in retaliation for their union activities. In a formal complaint issued on Friday, the labor board asserted that the museum had discriminated against Mary Corliss and Terry Geesken, workers in its Film Stills Archive, for their union activities when it laid them off in announcing that it was closing the archive to the public. The board also accused the museum of improperly discharging Michael Cinquina, a museum book buyer who was a leader of a strike against the museum in 2000. Museum officials said the layoffs were not retaliatory and were efficiency measures. The board will hold a hearing on the charges. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

description: The crowd started out small enough. Children were shouting, ''What's your name?'' and teenagers were trying to cadge cigarettes.

A man accused of being the driver, Emmanuel Kanios, 19, who lives a few blocks from the accident scene, at 25-39 80th Street, was later arrested, the police said. The boy, whose name was not released, was struck at 7:35 p.m. Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOUDENBERG, RICHARD
description: WOUDENBERG - Richard, age 76, on April 12, 2003. We celebrate the life of Richard, beloved by his family and friends, adoring wife Carole, children Eric, Timothy, Ruthe, Lisa and Valerie; and special grandpa to Carina, Toshi, Raina, Nathan, Cherissa, Michaela, Emma and Danny; and brother to John, Bill and Tom. A Memorial Service will be held at the Hermitage in HoHoKus, NJ on April 19th at 3PM (201-445-8311). title: CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF RELIANT RESOURCES RESIGNS
description: Reliant Resources, a power producer, said its chairman and chief executive, Steve Letbetter, had resigned and would be succeeded by a board member, Joel V. Staff. Mr. Letbetter, 55, is leaving to pursue new opportunities, he said in a statement. His departure was announced late on Sunday. Mr. Staff, 59, a former chief executive of National-Oilwell, will be acting chairman and chief executive until a replacement is found, the company said. Reliant, which plans to quit speculative energy trading because of losses and improper transactions, averted bankruptcy on March 31 by refinancing $5.9 billion in debt. Last month, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission accused Reliant of manipulating power prices during the California energy crisis of 2000 and 2001.

description: Lawyers representing the relatives of 10 World Trade Center victims asked a federal court yesterday to rule that the fund created to compensate families was unfair, arbitrary and tilted against those with high incomes, threatening to shortchange surviving families by hundreds of millions of dollars or more.

title: PFIZER GAINS FINAL APPROVAL TO BUY PHARMACIA
description: Pfizer won Federal Trade Commission approval yesterday for its $57 billion purchase of the Pharmacia Corporation, clearing the final regulatory obstacle to completing the takeover this week. Pfizer also said yesterday that Pharmacia's chief executive, Fred Hassan, had decided against becoming vice chairman of the combined company. Both companies agreed last month to sell some product lines to win antitrust approval. In February, they reached a similar accord to obtain European Commission clearance. Pfizer expects the combined company to have 10 percent annual revenue growth during the next three years, and it hopes for savings of $2.5 billion by 2005.

title: The Road to Damascus
description: The Bush administration is right to be alarmed and angry about Syria. There is reason to believe that both military equipment and potential suicide bombers have been sent from Syria for use in Iraq against American troops. Now, American officials are convinced that Syria is permitting Saddam Hussein's top lieutenants to escape across its border. As the United States begins to exercise its new role as godparent of a new, freer government in Iraq, it will have to figure out how to handle many hostile neighbors, starting with Syria.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: POLICE CHECK BODIES FOR MISSING WOMAN Detectives from Modesto, where a pregnant woman was reporting missing on Dec. 24, flew to San Francisco Bay after a woman's body was found. The police at the East Bay Regional Park District alerted the Modesto force because the body was found a day after a baby boy's body washed ashore in nearby Richmond. The missing woman, Laci Peterson, was eight months pregnant with a boy. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

description: Detectives from Modesto, where a pregnant woman was reporting missing on Dec. 24, flew to San Francisco Bay after a woman's body was found. The police at the East Bay Regional Park District alerted the Modesto force because the body was found a day after a baby boy's body washed ashore in nearby Richmond. The missing woman, Laci Peterson, was eight months pregnant with a boy. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: Spokeswoman in '91 War To Help U.S. Leader in Iraq
description: Margaret Tutwiler, the United States ambassador to Morocco, left Rabat for Baghdad today to assume a temporary position overseeing all public relations and information operations in postwar Iraq.

title: Moody's Downgrades WPP Debt Ratings
description: Moody's Investors Service yesterday downgraded by one notch the debt ratings for the WPP Group in London, which owns agencies like Ogilvy & Mather, J. Walter Thompson and Young & Rubicam. Moody's also upgraded the WPP rating outlook to stable; it had been on watch for a possible downgrading.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In San Juan; A Rich Spanish Heritage, Good Snorkeling and a Very Convenient Airport
description: Puerto Rico -- like Guam and the United States Virgin islands -- is in a fuzzy middle ground of national identity. Its 3.9 million residents are American citizens, yet are unrepresented in Congress, making the statehood movement a perennial political hot potato. The language and heritage are Spanish, but the currency is the dollar, and visitors from the mainland do not need passports.

title: Carnival Holders Back Bid
description: The Carnival Corporation said today that its shareholders had approved a $5.5 billion takeover of the cruise operator P&O Princess Cruises.

title: Former Iraqi Diplomat's Son Is Charged as Illegal Agent
description: The son of a former Iraqi diplomat at the United Nations was charged yesterday with working secretly on behalf of Iraqi intelligence officers who were seeking to track down Iraqis in the United States who were hostile to the government of Saddam Hussein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRINGTON, JOHN J. SR.
description: HARRINGTON-John J. Sr. On April 12, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Ruth M. (nee Cummings). Loving father of Dr. John J. Jr., Rev. Donald J., C.M., and Jay F. Cherished grandfather of William, Matthew, Patrick and Jennifer. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd. at 193 St. Visiting hours Tuesday, 7-9 PM, and Wednesday, 2-5 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 6 PM, St. John's University Chapel. Interment Thursday, Holy Cross Cemetery. Donations to St. John's University would be appreciated.

title: Spy Suspect May Have Told Chinese of Bugs, U.S. Says
description: Counterintelligence officials fear that an F.B.I. informer in Los Angeles tipped off the Chinese government to a covert United States effort to plant listening devices aboard China's version of Air Force One, several government officials said today.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: BID FOR BANK STAKE Cerberus Partners, an investment fund, offered to buy 49 percent of Aozora Bank for 101.1 billion yen ($839 million), raising its stake in a lender it helped return to profit after a government bailout. Cerberus, which owns 12 percent of Aozora, said it would exercise its right to match a bid by the Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, Japan's No. 2 bank, for the stake, which is owned by the Softbank Corporation. Cerberus said it planned a long-term investment, without being more specific. The fund is based in New York. (Bloomberg News)

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDONESIA: MEDIATORS SEEK TALKS ON RESTIVE PROVINCE International mediators have asked Indonesia and separatist rebels in the northern province of Aceh to hold a high-level meeting to put a fragile peace pact back on track, a government official said. The official said the separatist group, Movement for a Free Aceh, had agreed to meet on April 24. The province was torn apart by conflict for nearly 30 years, until both sides signed a peace accord in Geneva last year. But renewed clashes have put the agreement in danger. Indonesia has warned the rebels of a military assault.   (Reuters)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKALET, ROBINSON, SELMA (NEE HURWITZ)
description: SKALET - ROBINSON - Selma (nee Hurwitz), 91, of Bal Harbour, FL., and White Plains, NY, on April 13. Survived by Ira and Ellie Skalet, John H. and Barbara Skalet, grandchildren Paul and Francine Skalet, Joanne and Ken Sarama, Howard and Kelly Skalet, Adam and Kalli Skalet and six great - grandchildren. Also surviving are sisters Pearl H. Kaplan-Loeber and Naomi H. Emmet. She was predeceased by husbands Philip Skalet and Bernard Robinson. Interment at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York on April 15.

title: Hoping to Seize Moment, Bush Pushes Tax Cut Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 — Hoping to seize the political moment, President Bush insisted today that he wanted Congress to pass tax cuts totaling at least $550 billion over the next decade.

title: Tom King -- Wall Street Journal Columnist, 39
description: Tom King, the Hollywood columnist of The Wall Street Journal, died on Sunday while he was visiting friends on Long Island, The Journal reported yesterday. He was 39 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Unwanted Attention for Korea
description: Convinced that American attention will soon turn from Iraq to the Korean Peninsula, South Korean financial officials are waging a sales blitz this week on investors in New York.

title: Identity Consultant Taking Post at Visa
description: John Elkins, the chairman and chief executive at Future Brand Worldwide in New York, a corporate identity consultant owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, has left to join Visa International in Foster City, Calif., as head of global brand and marketing, a new post.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Steel Employees Protest
description: Thousands of employees of the troubled British-Dutch company Corus, the world's fourth-largest steel maker, held protests at plants across Europe to call for the immediate resignation of the chairman, Sir Brian Moffat. Corus angered labor unions earlier this month when it announced a new executive bonus plan, which is no longer linked to profitability, just days after warning of plant closings and 3,000 job cuts to stem losses of about 400 million ($629 million) a year. The company, which is already looking for a chief executive to replace Tony Pedder, who resigned last month, says Sir Brian will stay on until a successor is found. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: ABB Proposes New Shares
description: ABB Ltd. said it would ask for stockholder approval to issue new shares worth up to $1.1 billion to pay for asbestos lawsuits and to increase its dwindling cash reserves. Such an issue would increase ABB's shares outstanding by one-third. Concerned that new shares would dilute the value of existing stock, investors drove ABB's share price down by 4 percent. Shareholders will be asked to vote on the measure at the company's annual meeting on May 18. The company, which is struggling to keep itself out of bankruptcy, has said it will sell its oil, gas and petrochemical businesses and other, smaller units to pay for 2 billion francs in debt due this year. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: John Vause: Divisions Over New Government
description: NASIRIYA, Iraq (CNN) -- The United States invited handpicked Iraqi opposition leaders to Nasiriya on Tuesday for the first of a series of talks on shaping a new government, but thousands of protesting Shiite Muslims want to make sure their voices are heard.

title: New Battle Over Jenin, on Television
description: Scene one: Israeli soldiers fighting their way through the congested alleys of the Jenin refugee camp face frequent fire, but stop to open a tin of food for a distraught, elderly Palestinian woman, who thanks God for their kindness.

title: Islanders Are Left Grasping After Bounces Go Other Way
description: Nassau Coliseum was crowded and hot tonight, and the puck began to flutter and roll and bounce on the ice. A treacherous game of ricochet hockey followed, and the creative Ottawa Senators fumbled for the puck just as much as the Islanders.

title: S.E.C. to Review Policy on Board Elections
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it might change its policies on elections for corporate boards and shareholder proposals in an effort to increase corporate democracy.

title: Stem Cell Transplants Offer New Hope in Some Cases of Blindness
description: A little-known operation restores hope for people who lose sight from chemical or heat burns of the eye or certain rare diseases. The procedure, 50 to 100 percent effective in healing corneal damage, is used worldwide, including Iran, where it helps restore sight for victims of Iraqi mustard gas attacks.

description: The new Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, remained deadlocked today with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, over his proposed ministers for a new government, as senior members of their Fatah movement tried to broker a compromise.

description: GELLMAN - Zelda. Passed away peacefully at home on April 13, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Norman. Loving and devoted mother of Lance & Caren. Adored grandmother of Melissa, Glenn, Spencer and Kimberly. A woman with unmistakable flair, a passion & zest for life, a tremendous sense of humor and artistic creativity, Zelda was in the truest sense one-of-a-kind. She touched many with her gifts and will be missed by all. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to JAFCO. For further information please call ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, New Jersey.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: I.R.A. Outline Studied
description: The British and Irish governments, sponsors of the Northern Ireland peace agreement, welcomed a confidential statement from the Irish Republican Army outlining steps it would take to save the accord, but Paul Murphy, the Northern Ireland secretary, told the House of Commons that further clarification was needed on several aspects. The I.R.A., under pressure to disarm, issued its statement on Sunday after Prime Minister Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, called off a trip to Belfast when the group's first declaration fell far short of expectations. London and Dublin are calling on the I.R.A. to declare its 30-year war with the British over, plan its disbandment and give up its weapons as necessary steps to reviving the suspended Northern Ireland Assembly that balances power between Catholics and Protestants.

title: BORGWARNER SAYS QUARTERLY PROFIT WILL BEAT ESTIMATE
description: BorgWarner, one of the world's largest makers of engine turbochargers, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose to about $1.65 a share, helped by increased demand for turbochargers in Europe. First-half profit is expected to climb to $3.10 to $3.20 a share, BorgWarner said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had estimated that the company would earn $1.44 in the first quarter and $1.67 in the second. Europeans are buying more fuel-efficient diesel cars, whose relatively sluggish acceleration benefits from the power added by turbochargers. The company, which is based in Chicago, will release full first-quarter results on April 22.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 3 about a lawsuit by the Diocese of San Bernardino, Calif., accusing the Archdiocese of Boston of having failed to disclose a priest's history of sexual abuse before his transfer to California referred incorrectly to the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops, which declined to comment on the specifics of the suit. It is a membership organization convened to address broad concerns of the church; it is not a national governing body.

title: Syria Harbors Iraqis and Grants Transit to Hezbollah, U.S. Asserts
description: Syria is allowing some members of Hezbollah, a Shiite Muslim militant group based in Lebanon, to travel from Syrian-controlled southern Lebanon to Iraq, current and former United States intelligence officials said today.

In lieu of flowers a contribution to the New York Society Library would be greatly appreciated. A memorial service will be held later this month in NYC.

title: Clash in Mosul Complicates Already Troubled U.S. Arrival
description: MOSUL, Iraq, April 15  At least 10 Iraqis were reported killed and 16 injured today in a clash in northern Iraq that Marines called a gun battle and Iraqis described as the shooting of unarmed civilians. The deaths further complicated the already troubled arrival of American troops in Mosul, a city considered a center of Iraqi nationalism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMEAL, FRANK P.
description: SMEAL-Frank P., 84, died April 8, 2003 at his home, after a long illness. Mr. Smeal was born in Sykesville, PA. He lived in Jackson Heights, Queens, NY and New Shrewsbury before moving to Rumson, NJ in 1969. Mr. Smeal, a 1942 Phi Beta Kappa graduate in economics at Pennsylvania State University, went on to earn a Master's in Business Administration from Harvard University in 1947 and a law degree from New York University in 1952. A retired partner of Goldman Sachs, Inc., he spent his 38 year career on Wall Street as an expert in the municipal bond market. As Executive Vice President and Treasurer of Morgan Guaranty Trust Co., he was instrumental in counseling New York City through its 1975-76 fiscal crisis. He became a partner and member of the Senior Management Committee of Goldman Sachs in 1977 and retired in 1985. Frank was a past-president of the Municipal Bond Club of New York and former Chairman of the Government and Federal Agencies Securities Committee of Public Securities Association. He was treasurer of the United Chapters of Phi Beta Kappa and of the Phi Beta Kappa Foundation. Frank also served as Chairman of the Greater New York Councils of Boy Scouts of America, Chairman of the Penn State Development Councils, and Chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, NYC, NY. He was also a member of the Board of the Mount Nittany Society. Frank was named a Distinguished Alumnus of Penn State University in 1974 and an Alumni Fellow of the College of the Liberal Arts in 1986. Penn State's Smeal College of Business Administration was named in Honor of Frank and his wife, Mary Jean. They were also recognized by the National Center for Disability Services, Albertson, Long Island, NY where the Frank P. and Mary Jean Smeal Learning Center was established. Mr. Smeal was predeceased by his wife of 55 years, Mary Jean (nee Popp); his brother, Ted; a sister, Pauline Alexander, and his parents Samuel and Mary Smeal. He is survived by his daughter, Mary Margaret ''Maggi'' Smeal, MD; his son, Henry ''Hank'' F. Smeal; two grandchildren; sisters Dorothy Schwabenbauer and Olga Stormer; and three nieces, Janice King, Josephine Caylor, and Judy Olsen. Funeral service will be private and under the direction of the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank, NJ 07701 (1-888-747-0332). The family asks that, in lieu of flowers, memorial contributions be made to: Boy Scouts of America, New York Council Office, 350 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10018 (212-242-1100) or Inner-City Scholarship Fund, 1011 First Avenue, Suite 1400, New York, NY 10022-4134 (212-753-8583) or Smeal College of Business Administration, Penn State University, Development Office, 501 Business Administration, University Park, PA. 16802 (814-863-0345). Expressions of condolences may be sent to 12 Beekman Place, New York, New York 10022.

title: Front Row
description: In fashion, as in show business, belief in overnight success persists despite what everyone except inhabitants of distant solar systems knows are the odds. So when Henri Bendel advertises one of the periodic open calls it has held for several years, supply-side prospects from all points of the compass arrive in hordes. They were already lined up yesterday morning at 6 -- people from Santa Barbara, Calif., Philadelphia, Nashville and the wilds of Brooklyn carrying their photographic look books, toting garment bags, wheeling clothes racks and, pardon the clich, holding tight to their dreams.

title: Accused Helper of Al Qaeda Pleads Guilty
description: A Muslim charged with aiding Al Qaeda pleaded guilty today to a lesser charge and agreed to help in the investigation of a long-sought imam in London, Sheik Abu Hamza al-Masri.

title: A Hotel With Buzz, or Is It a Din?; Along With the Glamour, Noise Complaints in SoHo
description: It is one of the brightest new stars in Manhattan's hotel firmament, with its stylish decor and monogrammed toilet paper. It is one of SoHo's hottest traffickers in bohemian sang-froid, too, with its celebrity guests and regular bar crowd of aesthetes. Russell Crowe liked the $3,500-a-night penthouse duplex so much, he offered to buy it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARFSTEIN, SIDNEY J.

Remembrances can be sent to Sheppard Pratt Health System, Baltimore, MD. 21204, or Central Synagogue, NYC 10022, or the Hospice of Palm Beach County, Palm Beach, FL. 33407.

title: G.I.'s and Iraqis Patrol Together To Bring Order
description: Order took a slightly firmer hold on Baghdad today as American soldiers and a few Iraqi police officers patrolled the capital's devastated streets together for the first time, but looting, shooting and burning continued almost a week after Saddam Hussein's government fell.

title: Too Hot, Too Cold and Just Right
description: Emergency medical crews give medicine to as many as 800,000 Americans a year, but a new study suggests that many of the drugs are stored improperly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOODY, JAMES P.
description: DOODY-James P. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of James P. Doody; a Life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. John H. FitzSimons, Pres. Henry F. White Jr., Historian

title: For Many Iraqis, an American Patrol Is a Welcome Sight
description: For three weeks, Lt. Col. Rock Marcone's armored battalion led the way as the Army clawed a path to Baghdad. But when 3-69 Armor rumbled into the Iraqi capital today, it had an entirely different mission: providing security for thousands of residents alarmed by the breakdown of order.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Telecom Unit Sold
description: After five years of losses, the British telecommunications company mmO2 bowed to shareholder pressure and sold its Dutch subsidiary, O2 Netherlands, to Greenfield Capital Partners, an investment group, for 25 million euros ($26.9 million). MmO2, formerly the mobile unit of British Telecom, said it would take a charge of $2.2 billion on the sale. Analysts had estimated the business was worth 100 million to 300 million euros ($108 million to $323 million). However, Peter Erskine, the chief executive, called the sale price realistic given market conditions in the Netherlands, where two players, KPN and Vodafone of Britain, dominate. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

title: With Much At Stake, The Nets Crumble
description: Kenyon Martin slowly dribbled out the clock tonight with a look of disgust and left the ball bouncing heavily on the court, the air having long been deflated from the Nets' game.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BALDWIN, ALEXANDER RAE
description: BALDWIN-Alexander Rae. 20 years gone by. You are missed. Forever in our hearts. Beth, Alec, Daniel, Billy, Jane, Stephen and Carol

title: Grundig, the Radio Maker, Is Insolvent
description: Germany's protracted economic woes claimed one of its postwar corporate icons today as Grundig, the illustrious but faded maker of television sets and radios, filed for insolvency.

title: A Basketball and a Dream
description: Relishing the occasion of his American professional debut and a moment he recognized as classically Kodak, the rookie from the Republic of Georgia sauntered onto the court to face a player who certainly needed no introduction.

description: A Nation at War, a daily separate section, begins on Page B1. Complete metropolitan and sports reports share a section. By flipping over The Metro Section, bottom-side up, readers will find the sports pages, starting with S1.

title: Morgenthau Seeks a Broad Tax To Help With Public Safety Costs
description: Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, took the unusual step yesterday of calling for a new public safety tax on commuters and New York City residents to help pay for police officers, firefighters and prosecutors. His proposal comes as city officials are preparing broad cuts to the Police and Fire Departments to close a growing deficit, now estimated at $3.4 billion.

title: As the Iraq War Goes On, Afghan Violence Increases
description: It was a good place for an ambush, a natural parapet sticking up from a riverbed within easy firing range of the road, and a warren of gullies providing cover for the getaway. The men who fired on United States Special Forces, killing two instantly and critically wounding a third, chose their spot well, Afghan intelligence officers here said, as they walked over the site.

title: Squeezed Colleges See Credit Ratings Drop
description: Though its natty campus may not show it, Clarke College is in an admittedly tight spot. Its student body has shrunk, its endowment even more. At the moment, the college has more debts than money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEFRANCESCO, VINCENT
description: DeFRANCESCO-Vincent, 94. Of Forked River, NJ, died Monday, April 14 at home. He was employed at The New York Times before retiring in 1970. Surviving are his wife Anna (nee Ravallo) of 70 years, four daughters and sons-in-law, Rose and John Meola of Woodcliff Lake, New Jersey, Joan and Joe Colella of Forked River, NJ, Anna and Philip Iaderosa of Lords Valley, PA, Virginia & Joe Vargas of Monticello, New York, 12 grandchildren and 18 great-grandchildren, one surviving sister and brother, Mary Introcaso and Guy DeFrancesco. For further information contact Layton Funeral Home, Forked River, 609-971-6800.

title: QUARTERLY LOSS AT CUMMINS WILL BE WIDER THAN EXPECTED
description: Cummins, a maker of high-powered diesel engines, said yesterday that its first-quarter loss would be 85 cents to 95 cents a share, wider than expected, because of weak demand for power-generation equipment. The company will report full results for the quarter on Thursday. Cummins's forecast in January was for a loss of 50 cents to 60 cents, and the average estimate in a Thomson First Call survey of analysts was 57 cents. Most of the company's markets were weak and demand for power generators has continued to decline, said Jason Rawlings, a spokesman.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 2 Plead Guilty In Betting Ring
description: Ronald Trucchio, who prosecutors said was a captain in the Gambino crime family, pleaded guilty yesterday to taking part in an illegal sports-betting operation grossing $30 million a year. His son, Alphonse, also pleaded guilty. The senior Mr. Trucchio faces three years in prison for attempted racketeering, and his son faces four years. Known as Ronnie One-Arm, after a childhood accident, the father, 51, had little involvement in the operation and accepted a plea bargain to avoid a long ''devastating'' trial, his lawyer, Joseph Corozzo, said. Alphonse Trucchio, 25, may be the youngest man ever inducted into an American Mafia clan, said the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown. But the son's lawyer, Ronald Rubinstein, said the son was merely involved in a ''harmless bookmaking case'' when an unhappy bettor ''ratted them out.'' Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: A Top Partner Quits Law Firm After 38 Years
description: Stephen Fraidin, a top partner at the New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, defected yesterday to Kirkland & Ellis in a surprising move that had Wall Street lawyers buzzing.

title: Sacking the Past
description: ''Iraq'' is a relatively new name for an ancient land, a place whose history echoes more clearly in its former name, ''Mesopotamia.'' And beyond Mesopotamia lurk the shadows and relics of ancient Akkadians, Sumerians and Assyrians, as well as the biblical and historical associations that arise with the mention of cities like Babylon and Ur and Nineveh. The antiquities of Iraq tell the history of the rise of civilization. Until this past weekend, one of the most important collections of Iraqi antiquities could still be found in Baghdad.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: 70 Inmates Moved To Louisiana
description: The Corrections Department transferred 70 women to a private lockup in Louisiana to ease crowding in the Tutwiler Prison for women. The prison is under a federal court order to reduce the inmate population. Corrections Commissioner Donal Campbell said that the women were moved to the private South Louisiana prison in Basile and that they might be there up to 60 days. A lawyer who sued over prison conditions, Lisa Kung, was furious that the prisoners were transferred without notice. The executive director of the Alabama State Employees Association, E. J. McArthur Jr., said prison guards might go to court because the transfers could affect their ranks. Last year, a federal judge said the prison was overcrowded and understaffed. Alabama may transfer male prisoners out of state to reduce crowding of state inmates in county jails and may speed paroles. Dana Beyerle (NYT)

Rumsfeld presenting Michael Jordan with the American flag that flew over the Pentagon on the first anniversary of the Sept. 11. terrorist attacks. Two hours later, when Jordan left the Washington Wizards' 93-79 loss to the Knicks with 2 minutes 2 seconds to play, the crowd of 20,173 rose to its feet and stood for the rest of the game and the 15-minute postgame ceremony in which Jordan was honored with a video montage.

description: Navistar International, the truckmaker, said today that it had reached an agreement with Ford Motor regarding the cancellation of plans to supply V-6 diesel engines for the company's light trucks.

description: Citigroup reported strong results for the first quarter yesterday as a recent acquisition in California bolstered results in its consumer banking business and low interest rates encouraged consumers and corporations to borrow more. The bank was also able to set aside less for problem corporate loans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNINGHAM, JAMES F.

title: Mugabe's Recruits Flee Brutal Zimbabwean Past
description: It's neither the week they spent in jail nor the nights on the streets that most torment the dozen or so young Zimbabweans standing like scared deer in a park at the center of the city. Their nightmares, they said, come from the demons inside.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Doctors Strike
description: The country's 300 public health doctors went on strike to protest pay and work conditions, and forced health authorities to stop tracing infectious diseases. The National Disease Surveillance Center, which employs some of the doctors, has reported a case of the respiratory disease known as SARS in a town on the west coast and has had to curtail its operations. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Today It's Puerto Rico, Tomorrow It's the World

description: WAGER-Eli, Justice. He set a standard for public service too seldom equaled. Respected and loved by Carol and Jerry Berman

title: E.P.A. Orders Companies to Examine Effects of Chemicals
description: Scientists and regulators are raising concerns about the potential health and environmental effects of an important family of industrial chemicals.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The American Pavilion at the Cannes Film Festival in Cannes, France, named the sponsors for the 2003 festival, scheduled for May 14-25. They include: Bon Appétit magazine, published by the Condé Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications; the Eastman Kodak Company ; The Hollywood Reporte r, published by the VNU Business Publications USA unit of VNU; the Intel Corporation ; JVC ; The Los Angeles Times , published by the Tribune Company; and SAGIndie , a Screen Actors Guild program for independent filmmakers.

title: Taking Over City Hall, Local Cleric Won't Leave
description: A local cleric has ensconced himself in city hall after appointing himself mayor of this southern Iraqi city, and he refuses to leave.

title: A Gymnastic Pop Singer Caught Up in a Melodrama
description: There is essentially one reason -- and it's a very good one -- to see ''The Jackie Wilson Story,'' and that is the star, Chester Gregory II. To call a performer unique is generally to be clichd and hyperbolic, not to mention wrong, but Mr. Gregory puts on a show of such physical and vocal dexterity that it's almost impossible to imagine that anyone else could do it.

title: American Airlines Unions Vote Today on Concessions
description: The three major unions at American Airlines said yesterday that they would conclude voting on concessions by this morning and try to get results to the company before 11 a.m. in Texas.

title: Pataki Blames Legislators For Impasse Over Budget
description: Gov. George E. Pataki defiantly shifted the burden of solving New York's budget crisis onto the State Legislature today, saying its two top leaders had offered no concrete alternatives to the plan he submitted 75 days ago.

title: PENTAGON ASSERTS THE MAIN FIGHTING IS FINISHED IN IRAQ
description: The Pentagon declared today that major combat operations in Iraq were over after United States forces took control of Tikrit, the last bastion of the old government.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Insurer's Profit Rises
description: A leading reinsurance company, Hannover Re, said it earned 267 million euros ($287 million) last year, up from from 11 million euros last year but short of its target of 300 million euros. Hannover said write-downs on the value of its capital investments hurt its 2002 results. The year-earlier income was held down by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States. In its outlook for 2003, Hannover said rate increases would be well below the 8.3 percent increase last year. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Tax Day Puts Illegal Immigrants in a Special Bind
description: Janette and her husband, Juan, have a continuing argument about taxes. It is not about who is keeping track of the receipts or who should call the accountant. They are illegal immigrants, and what they cannot agree about is whether to file an income tax return.

title: U.S. Threatens to Impose Penalties Against Syrians
description: Six months ago, Syria voted with the United States to demand that Saddam Hussein disarm, helping to make the United Nations Security Council resolution on Iraq unanimous.

title: WorldCom Files Plans For Next Life
description: WorldCom Inc., which filed for bankruptcy-court protection in July, filed a reorganization plan yesterday that envisions it emerging from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection this year.

title: Three Released After Questioning in Stabbing
description: One day after a bouncer at a lounge on the Lower East Side died while trying to enforce the city's new antismoking law, circumstances surrounding the killing remained murky. And early this morning, two brothers with whom the bouncer scuffled were released by the district attorney's office.

title: Good Riddance to the School Boards
description: There comes a moment in ''Monty Python and the Holy Grail'' when King Arthur encounters a villainous knight blocking a bridge. With a sword stroke, the king lops off his enemy's arm. 'Tis but a scratch, the knight replies. Even after Arthur severs the remaining limbs, the knight refuses to succumb, vowing through bared teeth, ''I'll bite your legs off.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The situation of Iraqis is as if one eye is crying and one eye is laughing.''

title: Lawmaker And Lawyer: No Conflict, Says Silver
description: The conventional wisdom in Albany has always been that efforts to change the state's tort laws faced certain death in the Democratic-led Assembly, in no small part because the speaker, Sheldon Silver, is himself a trial lawyer.

title: Williams's Job Change Was the Correct Decision
description: THE other shoe finally fell yesterday. Roy Williams is out at Kansas and back to the University of North Carolina, where he played and coached.

title: Politics and Religion Join the Fray in Shiite Slum
description: The mullah with the automatic pistol in his hand pointed to the dead man in the hospital courtyard and said he was a Syrian suicide bomber who had come to attack Saddam City, a poor Shiite Muslim neighborhood, hoping to destabilize a newly liberated Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: A brief art review in Weekend on Friday about a show of portraits at Southfirst in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, misstated the address. It is 60 North Sixth Street, not 6.

title: Bush Says Hussein's Regime is 'No More'
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  President Bush declared today that "the regime of Saddam Hussein is no more," and that the United States would now shift its focus from combat to the search for weapons of mass destruction and the conversion of Iraq into a model of democracy in the Mideast.

description: As Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman made his way to the clubhouse after last night's game, he emphasized the positives.

description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention yesterday became the second group to fully map the genome of the virus most suspected of causing the mysterious respiratory disease known as SARS.

description: FRANK-Conrad Bennett. Beloved husband of Cynthia. Loving father of Terri and Craig. Adored grandfather of Samantha and Jaclyn. Dear brother of Arnold Frank. Loving father-in-law of Nina. Beloved uncle. Funeral services were held on Monday, April 14, 2003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEBENZAHL, NANCY BAAR
description: NEBENZAHL-Nancy Baar. It is with deep sorrow and regret that we mourn the passing of Nancy Baar Nebenzahl of Glen Head, NY, & Lake Worth, FL. Talented artist, sculptor and rug maker. Beloved mother of Marcie Aiuvalasit, James and Andrew Nebenzahl, mother-inlaw of Anthony Aiuvalasit, Sue Molinda and Maureen Nebenzahl, loving grandmother to Tony, Sharon, Jason, Alethea, Adam, Amelia and Christopher. Services Wednesday, 11 AM, at Congregation Emanuel of Westchester, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, Florida.

description: Two teams of lawyers representing shareholders in AOL Time Warner are filing extensive complaints accusing the company of defrauding investors, opening a legal battle that could determine the extent of the company's liability for AOL's disappointing acquisition of Time Warner in 2001.

description: Diana Brown met her court-appointed lawyer for the first time on the day she pleaded guilty to several serious crimes five years ago. They spent five minutes together and have not spoken since.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about signs that order is being re-established in Baghdad misidentified the television program on which Gen. Tommy Franks said the American military was dividing the city into zones to deal with pockets of fighters. It was ''Fox News Sunday,'' not CNN's ''Late Edition.''

title: Bush to Use Ratings in War To Sell Proposed Tax Cut
description: With hostilities in Iraq apparently winding down, the White House signaled today that it would put President Bush's wartime popularity to work immediately on behalf of his beleaguered tax cut plan, reflecting deep anxiety among Republicans about the political peril in the weak economy.

title: After All the Speculation, Williams to Coach Tar Heels
description: Roy Williams, who extended a winning basketball tradition at Kansas in his 15 years as coach, will now seek to revive the fortunes at North Carolina, his alma mater.

title: Philip Morris Can Post Less For an Appeal
description: A Illinois judge cut in half yesterday the amount that Philip Morris must post while it appeals a recent court judgment. The decision averts a potential bankruptcy filing by the company and ensures that it will make a promised payment to state governments.

title: Quest for Weight-Loss Drug Takes an Unusual Turn
description: A pill to make you thin: it has long been a dieter's dream.

title: Woman Charged in Shooting Death of Daughter, 7
description: The mother of a 7-year-old girl who was shot in the chest while she lay in bed 10 days ago was charged today with her murder, Branford police officials said.

title: Market Place; I.B.M.'s Results Seem to Reassure Wall Street
description: I.B.M. reported solid gains in both sales and profit for the first quarter, showing again that the company has made itself into a bulwark of comparative stability amid the deep slump in the technology business.

title: Whitney Scraps Expansion Plans
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art announced yesterday that it has scrapped its plans to build an ambitious expansion designed by the Rotterdam-based architect Rem Koolhaas, a signal that there may be further belt-tightening for the institution.

title: 6 Iraqi Officials Offer To Surrender to U.S.
description: Last week, Lt. Gen. Tahaseen Rafan was an Iraqi domestic intelligence official running a network of spies in Kurdish-controlled northern Iraq. Today he is frightened, alone and in hiding, one of thousands of members of Saddam Hussein's security apparatus who have abruptly gone from predator to prey.

title: When a Drama Workshop Goes Berserk, Genders Bend
description: Experiencing ''She Stoops to Comedy,'' the new play written by and starring David Greenspan, is like listening to opera singers practicing their scales after a few drinks. Their voices rove all over the place, not always prettily, but you have to admire the flexibility of their instruments. Anyway, they seem to be having such a good time, who's going to begrudge them their fun, even if it's not always possible to share in it?

title: Cecil H. Green, 102, Dies; Texas Instruments Founder
description: Cecil H. Green, a founder of Texas Instruments and a major educational and medical philanthropist, died on Friday in La Jolla, Calif. He was 102.

description: The Nasdaq Stock Market announced today that it had chosen a new chairman and a new chief executive to replace Hardwick Simmons, who has held both jobs since September 2001.

title: Monaco Investors Acquire Big Stake in Korea Refiner
description: A little-known overseas investment fund collided today with a government that is determined to keep it from gaining control of the SK Corporation, Korea's largest oil refiner and the flagship of the SK Group, the country's third-largest conglomerate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIELE, HARRY D.
description: BIELE-Harry D. Died peacefully in his sleep April 11, 2003. Born April 29, 1908. His life was dedicated to Israel and satellite causes. Executive Director of National Committee for Resettlement of Foreign Physicians from 1940-43; Executive for U.J.A., 1947 serving for many years, as Director in Trade and Industry Division. Led over 40 Study Missions to Israel. Retired 1973 from U.J.A. and became Executive Director of the American Friends of Bar Ilan University. In 1975 appointed fundraising consultant with American Friends of the Weitzman Institute. Survived by sister Rita Kane and brother Dan Biele. Funeral arrangements private.

title: Mounting Debt Forces Closing Of Noted New Jersey Theater
description: Citing mounting debt that they could not overcome, officials of the John Harms Center for the Arts announced today that their theater, which opened in 1926 as a silent movie and vaudeville house and became the cornerstone of this city's revived downtown business district, was closing its doors for good.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Keeping Organic Standard For Chickens
description: Congress repealed a provision in the omnibus spending bill that had loosened a standard for organic food, a move that would have benefited Fieldale Farms, a chicken company in Baldwin, Ga. The repeal was part of the $79 billion bill approved on Saturday to pay for the war in Iraq. Representative Nathan Deal, Republican of Georgia, had inserted the measure in a last-minute deal behind closed doors. That move caused an outcry from a coalition of citizens, corporate food producers, farmers and environmentalists. The organic standard went into effect in October after 12 years of debate, public comment, regulation and legislation. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: Kmart Faces Hurdle on Plan To Exit Bankruptcy Soon
description: Kmart, which began presenting its reorganization strategy before a federal judge in Chicago yesterday, said that the majority of its creditors had approved its plan to emerge from bankruptcy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERSON, WOLFE, BRIGIT TA
description: LIEBERSON - WOLFE - Brigit ta. The Board of Directors of the George Balanchine Foundation mourn the passing of our friend and fellow Board Member, Brigitta LiebersonWolfe, professionally known as Vera Zorina. Her contribution to dance and theatre on the ballet stage, on Broadway, and in Hollywood, enhanced by her kindness and personal modesty, will remain an inspiration. Barbara Horgan, Chairman Paul H. Epstein, President Lourdes Lopez, Exec. Dir. Nancy Reynolds, Dir. of Rsch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRAN, JAMES P.
description: CURRAN-James P. On April 14, 2003. Dear brother of Margaret Hummel, Peter M. and the late John J. Also survived by nieces and nephews. Over 20 years service to the Port Authority. Family will receive friends at Leo F. Kearns, 6140 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Our Lady of the Angelus Church, Wednesday, 9:30AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Ali Wakes Up
description: In the POW camps the Americans are practicing peace with yesterday's enemies.

title: Trying to Close Technology Divide As Satellite Operators Battle Cable
description: The recent acquisition of DirecTV by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation adds another piece to his global satellite empire and puts him at the center of a fierce technological battle -- one in which he and other satellite operators have lost the clear advantage they once had over cable competitors.

title: Bach, in Japanese Hands
description: The Bach Collegium Japan, a period-instrument orchestra and choir that was founded in 1990 and is based in Tokyo and Kobe, made its Carnegie Hall debut on April 8 with one of its specialties, Bach's St. Matthew Passion. The ensemble was conducted by its founder and music director, Masaaki Suzuki, who comes to the business of Bach conducting with an impeccable pedigree: he studied the harpsichord and organ with Ton Koopman and Piet Kee in Amsterdam and taught in Germany before he returned to Japan to start his group.
