title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: 6-Digit Bank Error and I.R.S.
description: The federal government dropped its claim in bankruptcy court that a woman who cashed a $100 savings bond owed the Internal Revenue Service more than $2 million in taxes on the bond's interest. When the woman, Tyashika Bailey, 24, of Montgomery, cashed the bond in 1999 at Compass Bank, a teller filled in the blank for the $48.68 in interest with Ms. Bailey's Social Security number. Ms. Bailey, an insurance clerk who earns $15,000 to $20,000 a year, said she learned of the claim last fall in a letter from the I.R.S. and filed for bankruptcy to clear that and another tax debt. The government has dropped its opposition to her plan to repay the government $60 a month. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Pipe Maker Is Fined Over Safety Violations
description: McWane Inc., an Alabama-based pipe manufacturer with one of the worst workplace safety records in America, has been fined $196,000 for new violations at its largest plant, the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration announced yesterday.

title: Powell Says 'There Is No War Plan' Against Syria
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  Secretary of State Colin Powell said today that "there is no war plan" against Syria, as the United States appeared intent on cooling anxiety in the region caused by recent tough-sounding comments from the Bush administration.

title: Madden Is Everywhere As Bruins Go Nowhere
description: Scott Stevens, the Devils' captain, was reading a newspaper article late in the season in which the leading contenders for the Selke Trophy were being discussed.

title: The Deadly Trails Of Typhoid Mary
description: History's most famous superspreader was Typhoid Mary, born Mary Mallon in Ireland in 1869 and a cook for wealthy New York families.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Strikes Ground Flights
description: More than 30,000 travelers were affected by an eight-hour strike by Italian airline workers and air-traffic controllers that forced the cancellation of hundreds of flights. About 85 of the canceled flights were being rescheduled after the strike ended at 6 p.m. local time, but thousands of stranded passengers were still left without flights. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUVANT, PHILIP
description: KRUVANT-Philip. Age 89. Of South Orange, N.J. On April 13, 2003. Beloved husband of Naomi (nee Goldberg). Cherished father of William, Steven, Kenneth and Roger. Dear grandfather to nine grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Services were held Monday, April 14, Bernheim Apter Kreitzman, Livingston, N.J. Contributions in his name may be made to the Hospice of Saint Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston, N.J.

title: James McNeill Whistler, Painter and Fashionista
description: The subject of fashion during wartime raises touchy questions about whether it's relevant to discuss what people are wearing when others are dying. The Oscars this year stressed the A-word (appropriateness) while offering little evidence that its piety was genuine. After all, Fran Lebowitz said, it's not as if ''anyone in Hollywood volunteered to roll bandages.''

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Murdoch Sells A Unit
description: Rupert Murdoch, who is paying $6.6 billion for control of DirecTV, is selling the New Zealand section of the News Corporation to an Australian rival. The rival, John Fairfax Holdings of Sydney, confirmed that it was acquiring the Murdoch unit. Fairfax owns Australia's oldest major daily paper, The Sydney Morning Herald, published since 1831. Market analysts said that Fairfax was expected to pay about 1 billion Australian dollars ($605 million) for the Murdoch-controlled Independent Newspapers Ltd., which has 4 major newspapers, 15 magazines and 60 local newspapers in New Zealand. John Shaw (NYT)

title: 'Requiem' On War By Pacifist Of the Past
description: Given the contractual and logistical arrangements involved, concerts these days are planned months (sometimes years) in advance, generally with little thought to the world outside the concert hall. So it was an extraordinary coincidence that the Juilliard School's presentation of the Britten ''War Requiem'' at Carnegie Hall should take place on Wednesday evening at the end of a day when television screens were filled with images of Iraqis celebrating the end of Saddam Hussein's rule in Baghdad.

title: Firm Wins $62 Million Deal To Restore Education in Iraq
description: Creative Associates International Inc., a firm based in Washington, has won a $62 million contract from the United States Agency for International Development to improve primary and secondary education in Iraq.

title: Book Study as Insubordination Under the Mullahs
description: READING LOLITA IN TEHRAN

title: One Killed and 3 Are Wounded at New Orleans School
description: A gunman carried an AK-47 assault rifle into a high school protected by four security guards and a police officer today and sprayed bullets into the school gymnasium, killing a 15-year-old boy and wounding three teenage girls, the authorities said.

title: Americans See Clear Victory in Iraq, Poll Finds
description: Americans overwhelmingly consider the war in Iraq a success, and a majority say the victory will stand even if Saddam Hussein remains at large or if the United States fails to unearth chemical or nuclear weapons, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: The Mayor's Mistake on Workfare
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg was widely praised last year when he said that the city was moving away from a welfare policy whose main goal was bouncing people from the rolls by any means necessary. Instead, the mayor promised an approach that would embrace training and education programs to move people from dependency into real, lasting jobs. After more than a year, his administration's actions have yet to match its words.

title: An Iraqi-Born Officer Of the U.S. Army Helps To Bridge Cultural Gaps
description: When Lt. Col. Frank J. Miskina speaks to intelligence and military officers about Iraqi prisoners of war, his words carry unusual resonance: the Baghdad-born officer served as an officer in the Iraqi Army in the 1970's.

title: French Threat to Militant Muslims After Council Vote
description: PARIS, April 15  France's interior minister threatened today to expel any Muslim religious leader considered extremist after a fundamentalist Muslim organization unexpectedly won a large number of seats in an election for the country's first national council of Muslims.

title: It's Not Just Bonds, It's Who's After Bonds
description: When Barry Bonds batted with the score tied, two outs and no one on base in the bottom of the ninth inning on Sunday night, the Los Angeles Dodgers did not ponder the situation for long before intentionally walking him. Manager Jim Tracy put the potential winning run on base for the San Francisco Giants, which would usually be considered a dubious decision. But with Bonds, it is considered a sensible move.

title: Hotels Doing Well, Despite Slump
description: The same forces that are mauling the airlines are taking a heavy toll on the hotel business.

title: A Couple Separated by War While United in Their Fears
description: Sarai Thompson had finally been able to get some rest after hours of tossing and turning. Then, she recalls, she rolled over and saw her husband tucked under the white covers beside her, and she began to cry. He was not really there or anywhere in their two-story white town house just outside Camp Lejeune. He was 6,500 miles away in the desert of Iraq.

title: Europe Asks Compromise On Auditors
description: The European Union warned today of retaliation if the United States requires European audit firms to register with its new accounting oversight board.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Ex-Official Convicted In Fuel Deception
description: The former vice president of a petroleum-testing company has been convicted of aiding the bogus testing of gasoline, allowing millions of gallons of substandard gasoline to be sold. A federal jury on Friday found the former vice president of Saybolt Inc., Thomas M. Hayes, guilty of conspiring to violate the Clean Air Act, making false statements to the federal Environmental Protection Agency, committing mail fraud and obstructing justice. Mr. Hayes faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Saybolt, which pleaded guilty in 1999 to conspiracy to falsify documents, has been fined $3.4 million. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Syria Fears the Unknown: What's Behind U.S. Threats
description: Last week, Syria's main scientific research institute staged its first air-raid drill in recent memory.

title: Planner of Achille Lauro Hijacking Is Reported Captured
description: WASHINGTON, April 15  The Palestinian guerrilla leader who masterminded the 1985 hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro, in which a New York City man was slain, was reported today to be in American custody in Iraq.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Stricter Penalties For Teen Killers
description: Nearly four years after a woman was strangled by her then-15-year-old neighbor in western New York, the State Legislature passed a bill yesterday that would increase the minimum sentence for a teenager convicted of second-degree murder to 7 1/2 to 15 years, from 5 to 9 years. The Republican-led Senate overwhelmingly approved the legislation yesterday, five days after the Democratic-controlled Assembly approved it, and it is expected to be signed by Gov. George E. Pataki. The bill was prompted by the killing of Penny Lea Brown, 39, of Salamanca, N.Y. Mrs. Brown's father, Jerry Lockwood, along with relatives, led a campaign to increase the penalties for juvenile offenders. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Staying or Going? Anthony to Decide
description: Carmelo Anthony had just rung the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and was savoring another memorable moment in the week since leading Syracuse to the men's college basketball national title. Then someone ruined it by asking him the same old question again.

title: Comcast Puts Off a Sale
description: The Comcast Corporation, the cable television operator, agreed to a one-month delay in selling its share of a joint venture to Paul Allen for $725 million.

title: Text: Brig. Gen. Vincent K. Brooks
description: Following is a transcript from a briefing by Brig. Gen. Vincent K. Brooks, deputy director of operations for Central Command as transcribed by Federal Document Clearing House Inc.

title: Handing Over the Keys to Iraq
description: At the Hilton Hotel here, one can watch the gentle waves wash in from the turquoise sea, or, on a recent occasion, observe an Iraqi missile sail 300 feet overhead. It's also the nerve center for the tight-lipped American officials, under retired Lt. Gen. Jay Garner, who constitute Iraq's shadow government-in-waiting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAVERTY, DOROTHY E.
description: HAVERTY-Dorothy E. On April 13, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Edwin A. Haverty. Reposing at the Memorial United Methodist Church, 250 Bryant Avenue, White Plains, New York, 914-949-2146 on Wednesday, 9:30 - 11:30AM. Services to follow. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, MAGGIE
description: ROSS-Maggie. Age 62 of Nashville, TN. Gracefully died March 28th, 2003. Maggie is survived by her husband of 46 years, George Ross; her children, Georganna Husband and Micheal Ross; her mother Margaret Patton; her grandchildren Coleman Ross, Gracyn Husband and Riley Husband; her siblings, Mike Patton, Pat Patton, Rita Hansford, Bobbie Mcloud and Debbie Staver; also all her nieces and nephews; and a host of adoring friends.

title: Prisoners' Families, Their Joy Unabated, at Last Have a Day to Exhale
description: Ronald D. Young Sr. has plenty of questions for his son and namesake.

title: Once Again, Scientists Say Human Genome Is Complete
description: The human genome is complete and the Human Genome Project is over, leaders of a public consortium of academic centers said today.

title: Spain Expels 6 Iraqi Diplomats After Arms Cache Is Revealed
description: Spain has ordered six Iraqi diplomats to leave Madrid after the top diplomat reportedly told the Spanish authorities about a cache of illicit guns in the Iraqi Embassy.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL GAINS. Crude oil rose on speculation that OPEC might cut production to offset a return of Iraqi oil supplies. In New York, crude oil for May delivery rose 44 cents, or 1.6 percent, to $28.58 a barrel.

title: A Nation at War
description: On the Battlefield

title: U.S. OVERSEER SET TO REMAKE IRAQ
description: The retired American general who will run post-war Iraq for the Bush administration flew to Iraq today on a mission to remake the country's politics, a process he predicted would be messy and contentious.

title: LOEWS TO BUY NATURAL GAS PIPELINE FOR $795 MILLION
description: The Loews Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a 5,800-mile natural gas pipeline from the Williams Companies for $795 million. Loews will pay Williams $795 million for the pipeline unit, the Texas Gas Transmission Corporation, and assume $250 million in debt, the companies said. The pipeline can deliver 2.8 billion cubic feet of gas a day, enough for 11.2 million homes, from Texas and Louisiana to the Midwest and Southeast, Williams said. Loews is based in New York. Williams, which is based in Tulsa, Okla., will record a loss of as much as $120 million on the sale. Williams has announced or completed $2.1 billion in divestitures this year.

title: Out From the Shadows, In the Name of Motown
description: The six men in red jackets onstage at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Friday night were hit makers who never became showmen. They were the Funk Brothers, the surviving members of the Motown Records studio band from 1965 to 1972, and they were accepting the spotlight three decades after the world first danced to their music.

title: Latest in Series Of Bold Breaks Frees 3 Inmates At French Jail
description: In the latest in a chain of spectacular jailbreaks at French prisons, accomplices descended on a prison in central France in a helicopter today, then used a buzz saw to cut through steel security netting and free three inmates.

title: After denials, Burger King has made Young & Rubicam its lead creative agency.
description: TWO and a half weeks after emphatically denying plans to add Young & Rubicam Advertising in New York to its agency roster, the Burger King Corporation yesterday announced a significant realignment of assignments centered on awarding Y.& R. Advertising the duties as lead creative agency on its national account.

description: With Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg ordering layoffs for 5,401 city workers, New York City's municipal unions are facing their biggest squeeze in three decades and are in unusual disarray about how to deal with it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARNES, BIRNBAUM, MAR CIA (NEE GABOR)
description: PARNES - BIRNBAUM - Mar cia (nee Gabor). Born in 1930 in Brooklyn, NY, longtime resident of Boca Raton, FL and Englewood, NJ, passed away on April 9, 2003 at her home in Florida. Loving wife of the late Burton Parnes. Cherished and beloved mother to her three sons, Howard, Fred and Mitchell, Howard's wife Kristen, Fred's companion Isabelle, and a dear sister to Ruth Heller. An avid and accomplished bridge player and instructor for 30 years and author of the instruction book ''The Bridge Notes of Marcia Parnes.'' She will be greatly missed and deeply mourned by all who knew her, including her many friends, relatives, nieces, nephews and Alan and Jonalyn Birnbaum, the son and daughter-in-law of the late Milton Birnbaum, her devoted and loved second husband. We all adored and loved you and will miss your smile always. In lieu of flowers please send donations to DRADA, 600 North Wolfe St., Meyer 3-181, Baltimore, MD 21287. Services will be held at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York, on Wednesday, April 16, at 11:15. Burial to follow at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MASSACHUSETTS: MURDER CASE INVOLVES STUDENT A Harvard graduate student was arraigned on charges of stabbing to death a hotel cook in a rundown section of Cambridge early Saturday morning. The student, Alexander Pring-Wilson, who was scheduled to receive a master's in Russian and Eastern European studies this semester, was described as walking home after drinking at a nightclub when he had had an argument with the cook, Michael Colono, 18. It is unclear who started the fight. Mr. Pring-Wilson's lawyer, Jeffrey Denner, said his client was defending himself against two men and suffered lumps and bruises on his head. Mr. Pring-Wilson's mother is a former prosecutor in Colorado Springs. His father is a criminal defense lawyer. Fox Butterfield (NYT)

description: The old man stood waist deep in the grave. Black flies swarmed around his ankles and scattered whenever he plunged his shovel into the dirt.

title: American Air Gets Concessions From 2 of Its 3 Main Unions
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, appeared to stave off filing for bankruptcy protection today after two of its three biggest unions agreed to substantial cuts in jobs, pay and benefits and the third said it had extended the period for its members to vote on the proposed cutbacks.

description: The Women's National Basketball Association announced yesterday that its 2003 draft, which had been scheduled for tomorrow, would not be held because the league had not reached agreement with the players union on a new contract.

description: The ChevronTexaco chief executive, David J. O'Reilly, took a 45 percent pay cut last year as shares of the company had their biggest decline in at least two decades and profit slid.

title: Travelers Are Scarce in Turkey, and So Is Business
description: Year after lucrative year, Bayram Coskun watched a seemingly endless convoy of buses rumble toward his roadside cafe here, disgorging tourists by the hundreds. He busily filled their cups with tea, and they readily lined his pockets with money.

title: 2 Sexual Abuse Lawsuits Filed Against L.I. Diocese
description: Using a scathing grand jury report as a road map, lawyers for nearly three dozen sexual-abuse victims filed a pair of lawsuits in Nassau County against the Diocese of Rockville Centre.

title: CNN's Silence About Torture Is Criticized
description: A recent acknowledgment by Eason Jordan, CNN's chief news executive, that he withheld some accounts of Saddam Hussein's brutality for years to protect the lives of Iraqi sources came in for some withering criticism yesterday.

title: Balletic Sonnets, Surprises Included
description: Someone needs to give the James Sewell Ballet from Minneapolis and Mr. Sewell's always imaginative, often exquisite ballets a full season in New York. In the meantime, thanks go to the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts for presenting Mr. Sewell's chamber troupe with three New York premieres at Brooklyn College's Whitman Hall on Sunday afternoon.

title: A Warning for Arthritic Knees
description: People with arthritis of the knee are often advised to exercise the muscle on the front upper part of the leg, the quadricep.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, KATHY LEE
description: MORRIS-Kathy Lee. On April 14, 2003, in Boston, MA. Devoted daughter of Helen and Henry. Loving sister of Larry. She will be cherished by all who ever knew her. Funeral services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY, Wednesday, April 16, 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to the American Cancer Society.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: AOL Sues Five Over Unsolicited E-Mail
description: America Online filed suit yesterday against five marketers it accuses of being responsible for sending more than one billion unsolicited e-mail advertisements to its members. As AOL's subscriber count has started to decline, the company, which is the biggest Internet provider in the United States, has stepped up its efforts to fight the more obnoxious aspects of the Internet, including pop-up advertisements and unsolicited e-mail, known as spam. The lawsuits seek monetary damages of at least $10 million and court orders to halt further spam. The lawsuits were filed in federal court in Alexandria, Va. One defendant is Michael Levesque, identified as the proprietor of BrightNight/WebXTasy, a purveyor of pornography, based in Issaquah, Wash. Another is George Moore, of Maryland Internet Marketing, which sells software. AOL also filed suit against three other e-mail marketers, which it did not name. Filing suit will allow the company to subpoena records and identify the marketers. Mr. Moore and Mr. Levesque have unlisted phone numbers. There were no replies yesterday to e-mail messages sent to addresses associated with the e-mail domains that were identified by AOL. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Williams's Job Change Was the Correct Decision
description: THE other shoe finally fell yesterday. Roy Williams is out at Kansas and back to the University of North Carolina, where he played and coached.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Stony Brook: National Megan's Law Help Line
description: A Long Island group, Parents for Megan's Law, said yesterday that it planned to establish a nationwide telephone line to help locate sex-offender registries in local communities. The group's director, Laura Ahearn, said an operator at the toll-free line would answer the phone and guide callers toward Internet registries and law enforcement offices with access to registries. Access differs among states. Ms. Ahearn said the number 1-888-ASK-PFML (1-888-275-7365) has been designated for the line and may be operating by year's end. The disclosure law is named for Megan Kanka, 7, of Hamilton, N.J., who was killed in 1994 by a neighbor who was a convicted sex offender. Stacy Albin (NYT)

description: Following are excerpts from a question-and-answer session yesterday with Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld and from a briefing by Brig. Gen. Vincent K. Brooks, deputy director of operations for Central Command, both as transcribed by Federal Document Clearing House Inc. Full transcripts are at nytimes.com/iraq.

title: Neglected Baroque Opera Languishes No Longer
description: Over the last 20 years the Paris-based American conductor William Christie has played a central role in resuscitating French Baroque music. But this does not mean that Rameau, Lully and Charpentier are exactly household names, even in France. Rameau's last opera, ''Les Borades,'' has only now entered the repertory of the Paris National Opera, 240 years after it was written. Like its composer, the work was long forgotten.

title: Nuclear Material, but No Smoking Gun, Found at Plant
description: KARBALA, Iraq, April 15  An American team hunting for unconventional Iraqi weapons at an ammunition plant near Karbala have discovered some radioactive material in a maintenance building and biological equipment that can be used for peaceful or military purposes buried in metal containers, but no "smoking gun" proving that Iraq made chemical, biological or nuclear materials at the plant.

title: For a Historic Ship, a New Port of Call
description: The United States, the fastest passenger ocean liner in the world in its heyday but now a fading hulk on the Philadelphia waterfront, has been bought by Norwegian Cruise Lines.

title: Lawyer Discusses the Timing Of HealthSouth Revelations
description: The former chief executive of HealthSouth, Richard M. Scrushy, first learned of an accounting fraud at his company March 17, a day before the company's chief financial officer secretly recorded him for the F.B.I., a lawyer for Mr. Scrushy said today.

title: Charity Begins at Schedule A
description: Most people think of today as tax day. But it is also an ideal moment to reflect on whether we've given enough to charity. Thanks to Schedule A, tax day is often the first time that we add up how much we've given and see how it stacks up against what we've earned over the year.

title: Inviting Humans to Sprout Wings and Soar
description: It's one thing to know birds, another to join the flock in the air. Some scientific consultants on the film ''Winged Migration,'' a documentary on the great travels of birds, had the chance to fly with the creatures they study on an ultralight aircraft that was the moviemakers' primary tool.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUM, LEONARD
description: DRUM-Leonard, 78. Passed away March 18, 2003, after a long battle with cancer. Was a featured actor on Broadway in Marat Sade, Walking Happy, and as Black Eagle in the revival of Whoopee! Appeared off-Bway, television on The Ozzie and Harriet Show, and in the Fosse film, All That Jazz, and toured as Mayor of River City to John Davidson's Music Man. Served in The U.S. Navy during W.W. II. There are no immediate survivors except for his many friends.

title: McDonough Chosen to Head Accounting Board
description: William J. McDonough, the longtime president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, was chosen to be chairman of the new Public Company Accounting Oversight Board by the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Leap Wireless Files For Bankruptcy
description: Leap Wireless, known for its low-price unlimited local wireless service, said yesterday that it and its subsidiaries filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Sunday after it was unable to pay back its debt. Leap, a spinoff of Qualcomm, said it was close to reaching an agreement with major creditors on a plan to restructure its debt. A final agreement is expected to be approved in the next few weeks. The company said all its operations would continue during the restructuring, and it does not anticipate any organizational changes or reduction in its work force as a result of the filing. The company said it expected to file a preliminary draft of a reorganization plan with the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of California in San Diego.

description: THE other shoe finally fell yesterday. Roy Williams is out at Kansas and back to the University of North Carolina, where he played and coached.

title: Stress: It's Impossible to Avoid, but Possible to Conquer
description: I pick up my morning newspaper and flip directly to the sports pages because almost every article on Page 1 is about the war. I turn on the radio to get the traffic and weather reports only to hear that American troops have been hit by fire from their own side or that they have killed Iraqi civilians trying to escape the war zone.

title: HILLENBRAND TO CUT UP TO 300 HEALTH CARE JOBS
description: Hillenbrand Industries, a leading maker of coffins, hospital beds and incubators, said yesterday that it would cut as many as 300 jobs as it overhauls its health care unit. The reductions will result in an expense of $9 million to $11 million in the period that ends June 30, the third quarter of Hillenbrand's fiscal year. The jobs that will be cut are salaried positions in Hillenbrand's Hill-Rom health care unit. The cuts affect about 5 percent of the unit's employees and will take place over the next year, the company said. The company, based in Batesville, Ind., will announce second-quarter results on May 8.

title: A Heroin Ring That Had Brains Was Done In by Noses, Police Say
description: The smell was the suspects' undoing, the police said.

title: New Jersey Opens Files Showing Failures of Child Welfare System
description: New Jersey officials made public the state's confidential files yesterday on the deaths and abuse of more than a dozen children in its care, offering for the first time its own, fully detailed look at how child welfare officials, and often others, failed some of New Jersey's most vulnerable children.

title: Inventories Rose in February; Some Relief Is Seen for March
description: Business inventories rose for a 10th consecutive month in February as snowstorms led to a drop in retail sales, the Commerce Department reported today. Total business sales fell the most in 15 months.

title: Noel Fox, 63; Sang With Oak Ridge Boys
description: Noel Fox, a former bass singer with the Oak Ridge Boys who became a power in the music business, died here on Thursday. He was 63.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERKINS, RICHARD S.
description: PERKINS-Richard S. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art deeply mourn the passing of Richard S. Perkins, a devoted Trustee and Benefactor who served for many years on the visiting committee to the Department of Islamic Art as well as on various Trustee Committees. During his tenure as a Trustee (1963-1987), and as a Trustee Emeritus in the years since, he was a generous donor of works of art and funds to the Museum. He served this institution with distinction and will be greatly missed. We offer our sincere condolences to his family. James R. Houghton Chairman Philippe de Montebello Director David E. McKinney President

title: In Hometown, Hussein's Glory Is Quickly Gone
description: The breeze off the Tigris blew through the empty halls of President Saddam Hussein's grandest palace today, its once fearsome opulence reduced, it seemed, to the most crushing sort of banality.

title: Irish Visitors (Some Even From Ireland)
description: Among the concertgoers at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon were noticeable numbers of people clad in green to profess their cultural solidarity with the National Symphony Orchestra of Ireland in its New York debut. Naturally, like most major orchestras today, this one has a culturally diverse roster of players. Glancing down the list, mixed among surnames like O'Connell and Fitzgerald you saw many names like Ting Zhong Deng, a violinist, and Eckart Schwartz-Schultz, the principal cellist. Since 2001 the orchestra's conductor has been Gerhard Markson, a dynamic German.

title: Mayor's Plans Ask for Closing Of 2 City Zoos
description: New Yorkers might not notice the reduced number of sanitation workers, and most would take little note of the diminished role of the Department of Employment, two results contained in a tough budget plan that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is to announce today.

title: Making the Tax System Fairer
description: When Charles Rossotti stepped down last fall as Internal Revenue Service commissioner, he said the I.R.S. was ''losing the war'' against tax cheats. A newly released report confirms his fears. It concludes that criminal enforcement against tax cheating is ''in shambles,'' and that the biggest offenders are getting off easiest. Americans racing to meet tonight's tax deadline, as well as those who have already beaten the rush, are entitled to know that the government is committed to improving its record.

title: Founder of East Coast Bloods Is Given 50 Years
description: A federal judge in Manhattan sentenced the leader of the Bloods street gang to 50 years in prison yesterday, saying she had considered the ''amount of violence and lawlessness'' he had encouraged, and ''the absence of much of anything on the positive side of the ledger.''

title: U.S.-Led Talks in Iraq End With Pledge to Meet Again in 10 Days
description: UR, Iraq, April 15 - Iraqi exile leaders, tribal sheiks, ethnic Kurds and Shiite clerics gathered in a tent near the birthplace of Abraham today and said they would work to create a fully democratic government in Iraq.

title: A Dark, Smelly Hole in the Ground, but All Theirs

title: City Has a $100 Million Plan To Develop Downtown Brooklyn

title: CENDANT HIRES FINANCIAL OFFICER FROM DREAMWORKS
description: The Cendant Corporation, the travel and real estate services company, said yesterday that it had hired Ronald Nelson from Dreamworks SKG as its chief financial officer, effective May 12. Mr. Nelson succeeds Kevin Sheehan, who will become chairman and chief executive of Cendant's vehicle division, which includes Avis rental cars. Mr. Nelson has been the chief operating officer at Dreamworks since its founding in 1994. The appointment of a new finance chief will free Mr. Sheehan to focus on Cendant's integration of the Budget rental car business, which it bought last year.

description: The federalist Liberal party took an insurmountable lead tonight in provincial elections to wrest control of Quebec from the separatist Parti Qubcois. The vote should shelve the possibility of another divisive referendum on independence for the foreseeable future.

description: On a bright and brisk spring noon at the heart of London, Matthew Collins, a road safety officer from the city authorities, stood ready to offer his advice to the capital's newest potential casualties: scooter riders.

title: Op-Art
Technology Briefing | Software: Unisys Posts 18% Rise In Net Income
description: The Unisys Corporation, a seller of business computer servers, software and related services, said yesterday that first-quarter profit rose 18 percent after revenue increased for the first time in more than three years. Net income rose to $38.5 million, or 12 cents a share, from $32.7 million, or 10 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Revenue increased 2.7 percent, to $1.4 billion, from $1.36 billion. Income from the company's pension plan fell to $6 million, from $38 million. Unisys, whose largest customer is the federal government, has been coping with slumping demand for computers by cutting costs and trying to increase sales of services like payment processing and billing for other companies. Outsourcing revenue rose 20 percent and made up 37 percent of total sales in the quarter. Shares of Unisys rose 72 cents, or 7.7 percent, to $10.07.

title: Lost No More: An Etruscan Rebirth
description: The Romans relished their founding myths. Aeneas, a fugitive from fallen Troy, anchored in the mouth of the Tiber River and there in the hills of Latium rekindled the flame of Trojan greatness. Romulus and Remus, twin sons of Mars and a sleeping beauty, were suckled by a she-wolf and grew up to establish the city destined for grandeur.

title: How One Person Can Fuel An Epidemic
description: A child in China so infectious that he is nicknamed ''the poison emperor.'' A Chinese doctor who infects 12 fellow guests in his Hong Kong hotel, who then fly to Singapore, Vietnam and Canada. An elderly Canadian woman who infects three generations of her family.

title: Columbus Youngster Is a Target
description: The signs that KYLE MARTINO of the Columbus Crew has arrived are stippled all over his body -- a bruise here, a bump there.

title: South Africa to Pay Reparations to Victims of Apartheid Crimes
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 15 — President Thabo Mbeki said today that his government would pay reparations totaling some $85 million to more than 19,000 victims of apartheid crimes, who testified about their suffering before the Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

title: End of 'Major' Combat, Fall of Tikrit, Anxiety Over Syria
description: The northern city of Tikrit fell without a battle and American military commanders declared that major fighting in Iraq had come to an end. American forces started to pull out of Iraq and those that remained began a transformation from combat to postwar reconstruction. The work of keeping the peace and forming a new government proceeded slowly, but the victory in Iraq pushed up President Bush's approval ratings at home.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Antiterror Plans
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on hospitals' response to -- and ability to coordinate services after -- a nuclear, biological or chemical attack. Council Chambers, City Hall, Manhattan, 1 p.m. Information: (212) 564-7757.

Among many charities, Mrs. Kennedy was a state and national officer of the Daughters of the British Empire. She is survived by a brother, the Rev. Canon Albert W. Tarbell, Albuquerque, NM, three sons, Anthony III of Rose Valley, PA, where Mrs. Kennedy lived for over 60 years, Richard T. P., NYC and Rose Valley, Jackson W. T., of Toms River, NJ, and Eaglesmere, PA, six grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. Services will be Wednesday, at 11 AM, at Christ Church, 311 South Orange St, Media, PA. Burial will be private at the US Naval Academy, Annapolis, MD.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: TELECOM UNIT SOLD After five years of losses, the British telecommunications company mmO2 bowed to shareholder pressure and sold its Dutch subsidiary, O2 Netherlands, to Greenfield Capital Partners, an investment group, for 25 million euros ($26.9 million). MmO2, formerly the mobile unit of British Telecom, said it would take a charge of $2.2 billion on the sale. Analysts had estimated the business was worth 100 million to 300 million euros ($108 million to $323 million). However, Peter Erskine, the chief executive, called the sale price realistic given market conditions in the Netherlands, where two players, KPN and Vodafone of Britain, dominate.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: A Challenge to White Supremacy, 100 Years Later; Scholars Revisit W. E. B. DuBois, Who Found a New Way to Think About Race in America
description: ''It is a peculiar sensation, this double-consciousness, this sense of always looking at one's self through the eyes of others, of measuring one's soul by the tape of a world that looks on in amused contempt and pity.''

title: Cases of Lethal New Illness Rise Sharply in Interior Region
description: Reported cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome rose sharply today in an interior province of northern China, heralding the possible spread of the disease through the country's vast, medically underserved hinterlands.

title: Mets Come Up Empty In Trip to Puerto Rico
description: Mets reliever David Weathers felt as if he were on vacation last Friday when he woke up and saw the Caribbean Sea. After today, he may want to chose a different destination for a real break.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bid For Bank Stake
description: Cerberus Partners, an investment fund, offered to buy 49 percent of Aozora Bank for 101.1 billion yen ($839 million), raising its stake in a lender it helped return to profit after a government bailout. Cerberus, which owns 12 percent of Aozora, said it would exercise its right to match a bid by the Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, Japan's No. 2 bank, for the stake, which is owned by the Softbank Corporation. Cerberus said it planned a long-term investment, without being more specific. The fund is based in New York.

title: A Notable Advance on SARS
description: In the month since severe acute respiratory syndrome set off a global health alert, scientists have identified the virus that probably causes the disease, deciphered its entire genome and begun developing diagnostic tests to identify its victims. When one thinks of the years it took to identify the cause of AIDS and develop a diagnostic test for it, the progress on SARS is a remarkable scientific achievement.

title: Child Welfare Files
description: Paper Trails: New Jerseys Division of Youth and Family Services, obeying a court order, released confidential files on cases of abuse and neglect, some fatal, involving 17 children in its foster care system.

title: Science Under Control
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Napa's Un-California Chardonnay
description: IN 1943, Fred McCrea, a San Francisco advertising executive, and his wife, Eleanor, invested in a small goat ranch on the lower slopes of Spring Mountain, in the Napa Valley, as a weekend hideaway. They had no interest in growing grapes, but in 1946, encouraged by friends, they began planting a few vines each year. They called the place Stony Hill, and when the first vines matured they sold their grapes, mostly chardonnay and pinot blanc, to other wineries.

title: Inquiry Faults Chemical Mixers and City For 'Witch's Brew' in 2002 Chelsea Blast
description: Federal investigators say a commercial tenant and the city share responsibility for an explosion that ripped apart a Chelsea loft building last spring, injuring dozens of people and rattling New Yorkers already jittery since the Sept. 11 terror attack. The tenant, a sign-making company, stored and mixed hazardous chemicals in the basement without adequate safety training for its workers and also without the proper permits, and the city monitored that chemical inventory poorly, investigators say.

title: A Budget Goes From Bad to Ugly
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg proposed not one, but two plans to close the $3.4 billion gap in New York's budget. One was horrible. The other was much worse. Both promise to raise the cacophony of calls to save firehouses, education programs, zoo monkeys and city jobs. With few other options available, the mayor clearly hopes that New Yorkers protest loud and long -- in the direction of Albany and city union leaders.

title: Prosecution Says Qaeda Member Was to Pilot 5th Sept. 11 Jet
description: The Justice Department has shifted the government's theory of the case against Zacarias Moussaoui, arguing that this confessed member of Al Qaeda planned to help hijack a fifth plane and crash it into the White House, people with access to classified information about the case said today.

title: Italy Seeks Extradition of Captured Cruise Ship Hijacker
description: ROME, April 16  Italy said today that it would seek the extradition of the Palestinian militant Abu Abbas after his capture by United States forces in Baghdad this week and 18 years after he led a terrorist group that killed an American on a hijacked Italian cruise ship.

title: With Taurus in Its Last Days, Ford Bets on 3 Cars to Take On Japan
description: The Ford Motor Company is starting to write the obituary of the Taurus, the last American sedan that credibly competed with Japan.

title: Operas With Integrity in Common
description: A lot of opera composers today seem to get straitjacketed in their ideas of what opera is supposed to do or how it is supposed to be put together. So it is edifying to see two experimental operas that say exactly what their composers wanted to say, rather than what they felt they should.

title: White House to Start Online Forum
description: The White House said today that it would begin an interactive feature on its Web site that will allow Internet users around the world to have a virtual discussion with Bush administration officials.

title: The Tough Club, Reborn as a Gastro-Pub
description: NEW YORKERS are spoiled. Whether the Dow rises or falls, whether the economy goes boom or bust, they refuse to relax one nonnegotiable demand, that the city supply them with one good restaurant after another.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBB, AUDREY W.
description: ROBB-Audrey W. The officers, employees, agents of Brown Harris Stevens are deeply saddened by the death of our friend and colleague Audrey W. Robb. Our sincerest condolences to her family.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Two Men Shot, One Fatally
description: A 24-year-old man was shot to death and a 19-year-old man was shot in the ankle last evening, the police said. The shootings occurred at the corner of Parkside and Ocean Avenues just before 6 p.m. near the southeast entrance to Prospect Park, they said. The 19-year-old was taken to Kings County Hospital in stable condition, and the 24-year-old was pronounced dead on arrival.Officer Louis Camacho said the victims had not yet been identified, no guns had been recovered, and the motive for the shooting was not yet known. There were no suspects, and the investigation is continuing, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: G.M.'s Quarterly Earnings Beat Forecasts
description: First-quarter earnings at General Motors beat Wall Street's expectations yesterday, but they were viewed skeptically because gains in the company's financing operation, particularly its mortgage business, offset weakness in its automotive operations.

description: In certain counties of New Jersey in 2001, nearly one in five children who were placed in what state officials considered their most promising foster homes nonetheless wound up abused or seriously neglected, according to the state's own statistics.

The officers and directors of Metropolitan Jewish Health System sadly mourn the untimely passing of Sidney Sharfstein, beloved father of our esteemed fellow board member, Howard Sharfstein. May his legacy act as a source of inspiration to all those whom he touched. We pray that his fond memories will sustain you, and the love and prayers of those who care will comfort you. We share in your loss. Our profound sympathy and sincere condolences to the family. Steven L. Topal, Chairperson of the Board Eli S. Feldman, President & CEO

title: Recent Plays
description: A Man Never Wrong, Just Wronged

title: South Africa to Pay $3,900 to Each Family of Apartheid Victims
description: President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa said today that his government would pay reparations totaling $85 million to more than 19,000 victims of apartheid crimes who testified about their suffering before the Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

title: Peeling the Mozzarella
description: Super mozzarella has arrived from Italy. A speciality of Puglia, it is called burrata, and it comes with bits of dried porcini or black truffle. The porcini add a touch of earthiness; the truffles punctuate the butteriness. Eating any one of them is like mainlining heavy cream. Only better.

title: Harmony For People Out of Tune With Life
description: If Joe Jackson had been born a few decades earlier, he would have been writing show tunes. He's constantly imagining characters and situations, letting narrators tell their stories on the way to an ardent chorus while slipping musical games behind the melodies. Luckily, Mr. Jackson grew up in the punk-rock era, and with the new-wave band he formed 25 years ago he cut away pop sentimentality and revved up the beat. He made three albums with that band from 1978 to 1980, and he has reunited with them to make the new ''Volume 4'' (Restless/Rykodisc) and to tour.

title: Warning Issued To J. P. Morgan
description: J. P. Morgan Chase & Company was told yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it might face legal action over its relationship with the Enron Corporation, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPIN, RAIZEL ''ARES.''
description: HALPIN-Raizel ''Ares.'' June 22, 1925 to April 11, 2003. Beloved mother, sister, art lover, chef, musician, teacher, benefactor, and friend to many. A Memorial will be held at Angel Orensanz Synagogue, 172 Norfolk St, NYC at 11:30 A.M. Sunday, April 20th.

title: Lieberman, Raising Less, Spends Proportionally More
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman burned through 40 percent of the money his presidential campaign raised in the first three months of the year, by far the highest percentage of any major Democratic candidate, according to federal campaign-finance reports filed today.

title: Cutting To the Chase At the Start
description: Katsuhito Ishii's 1999 ''Shark Skin Man and Peach Hip Girl,'' which opens today at the Two Boots Pioneer Theater in the East Village, works some minor variations on the enduring outlaw-couple-on-the-run story, putting it in a context of harsh social satire and nihilistic despair.

title: Experts' Pleas to Pentagon Didn't Save Museum
description: The plunder last week of Iraq's national museum, one of the Middle East's most important archaeological repositories, occurred despite repeated requests to the Pentagon by experts and scholars that the site be protected when American troops entered Baghdad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILWEIL, DAVID
description: HEILWEIL-David. Age 82, of Riverdale, NY, on April 14, 2003. Beloved husband of Enid, cherished father of Victoria, Andrea, and Jeffrey. Dear grandfather to Pamela, Christopher, Lauren, and Matthew. President of Heilweil Produce. A kind, generous man, he will be sorely missed by all who knew him.

title: Bruins Avoid Sweep As Daneyko Takes Seat
description: The streak is over. And so are the Devils' chances of a first-round sweep.

title: South Korea Abstains From Vote Assailing North on Rights
description: SEOUL, April 16  South Korea joined 13 other nations today in abstaining from voting on a resolution adopted by the United Nations Commission on Human Rights that condemns North Korea for "widespread and grave" abuses of human rights.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the financial health of the hotel industry misspelled the surname of the chief executive of the Cendant Corporation's hotel group. He is Steven Rudnitsky, not Rudintsky.

title: Terrorism Threat Level Drops From Orange to Yellow
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 — With the war in Iraq seemingly near an end, the Bush administration lowered the official terrorism threat level today.

title: Free to Protest, Iraqis Complain About the U.S.
description: Protests against the American forces here are rising by the day as Iraqis exercise their new right to complain -- something that often landed them in prison or worse during President Saddam Hussein's rule.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENEDICT, DAVID
description: BENEDICT - David, Cantor Emeritus. Temple Israel, Lawrence, NY, mourns his death and extends deepest sympathy to the bereaved family. Jay H. Rosenbaum, Rabbi Joel Gerstel, President Joel Y. Zion, Rabbi Emeritus

title: Testing Fad Is Farce For the Disabled
description: FIFTEEN years ago, when Linda Mischley was looking for a public school for her severely disabled son, she moved hundreds of miles from northern Michigan to this Detroit suburb, so her Bobby could attend the Wing Lake Developmental Center.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Help For Cable Unit
description: The Telstra Corporation and PCCW helped their Reach unit repay one-fifth of a $1.5 billion loan with an advance for using its undersea cable network, meeting demands from creditors who were concerned it might not meet debt obligations. Telstra and PCCW also said they would buy at least 90 percent of their international capacity from Reach, which is based in Hong Kong, until the remaining $1.2 billion loan is paid.

title: Cable's War Coverage Suggests a New 'Fox Effect' on Television Journalism
description: The two commentators were gleeful as they skewered the news media and antiwar protesters in Hollywood.

title: YankeeNets Holds Newark Meeting
description: A negotiator for YankeeNets said the company and a team from the City of Newark held a productive meeting yesterday on the proposed arena for the Nets and the Devils.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLAZEROFF, MARTHA
description: GLAZEROFF-Martha. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Myron Fenster, Int. Sr. Rabbi Steven Markowitz, President

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Williams College art historian Whitney S. Stoddard on Monday referred incorrectly to the Institute for Advanced Study, where his former student Kirk Varnedoe is now a professor of art history. It is in Princeton, N.J., but is not part of Princeton University.

title: Land of the Free? What a Country!
description: ''As Long as We Both Shall Laugh''

title: After 2 Years of Gains, Gold Struggles to Keep Its Luster
description: Sales of gold coins in the United States are off to a fast start this year, with 251,000 ounces sold by the United States Mint so far. At this pace, the 2003 total will surpass that for all of 2002 by the middle of next month.

title: Persuading Big Business To Help Look For a Vaccine
description: The government is trying to enlist drug makers and biotechnology companies in the search for drugs and vaccines to fight SARS, the respiratory illness that has sickened thousands of people and killed 154.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Chemical Trade Inquiry
description: The European Commission has raided the offices of several chemical companies as part of a cartel investigation involving the markets for hydrogen peroxide, solvents and paint ingredients. BASF of Germany and Solvay of Belgium confirmed yesterday that antitrust officials visited their offices in late March. Both companies said they were cooperating with the investigation. The European Commission said it suspected the companies of fixing prices and dividing the European Union market among themselves. It did not name the companies raided. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Guilty Plea In Pornography Case
description: A law professor has pleaded guilty to 100 counts of possessing child pornography. The professor, Edward Samuels, 54, taught copyright law at New York Law School and is on paid administrative leave. On Monday, when Mr. Samuels entered his plea in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, Justice Brenda Soloff said she would sentence Mr. Samuels to four years in prison. Last June, the law school's computer technicians discovered pornographic images of children on the professor's office computer. Later, in a search of Mr. Samuels's home computer, investigators found more than 100,000 pornographic images of children. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESINGER, ALVIN L., D.D.S.
description: SCHLESINGER - Alvin L., D.D.S., Age 97. Died on April 12, 2003. He was predeceased by his loving wife Harriet and is survived by his children, Michael and wife Lauren; Rosalind and husband Ronald; grandchildren, Robert and wife Deborah, Philip, Leonard, Charles and sister Muriel Gluck, residing in Beverly Hills, California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'ATRI, JUSTIN W.
description: D'ATRI-Justin W. On April 14, 2003 of Forest Hills, New York. Specialist in Securities Law for over forty years. Husband of the late Doris, missed and loved by family and friends. Reposing at Fox Funeral Home, Inc., Ascan Avenue corner Metropolitan Ave, Forest Hills, NY, Thursday, April 17, 4-8 PM. Funeral Blessing Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, on Friday, at 10 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to a charitable cause would be appreciated.

title: Launching Is Delayed For Repairs To 2 Robots
description: Problems aboard two spacecraft scheduled for exploration missions on Mars have prompted NASA to delay the launching of the first one about a week, space agency officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A Sports of The Times column in some copies on Sunday about Ricky Barnes, an amateur golfer competing in the Masters, referred incorrectly at one point to the university he attends. It is Arizona, not Arizona State.

title: Conversation Piece and Appetizer, Rolled Into One
description: Chefs have discovered arancini, which are breaded, deep-fried balls of risotto and cheese. They were given the name, which means little oranges in Italian, because traditionally they are made with saffron rice, which gives them an orange tint. They are the cocktail or appetizer tidbit of the moment.

title: A Man Never Wrong, Just Wronged
description: ''The Gospel of John''

title: Last Braise Of the Season
description: JUST when I was ready to fire up the grill, it seemed there was both time and weather for one more braised dish. It seemed appropriate to honor the season's ambivalence by cooking something I had been messing around with throughout the winter: brisket simmered with sweet white wine.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Official Loses Job In Scheme
description: Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich fired a commissioner for the Illinois Industrial Commission, saying she had schemed to keep friends of former Gov. George Ryan in high-paying state jobs. The commissioner, Diane Ford, is accused of masterminding a plan that allowed Ryan loyalists to resign for four days and then return to their jobs to start new four-year terms. Mr. Blagojevich is seeking to fire two other employees for their role in the plan, which affected about 40 employees, many of whom earned $80,000 a year. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Experiments on Monkeys Zero In on the Cause of a Mysterious Disease
description: Monkeys experimentally infected with a new coronavirus have developed an illness similar to the mysterious human respiratory disease SARS, and it is now almost certain that the coronavirus causes the disease, a World Health Organization official said here today.

title: Midas Begins Review of Its Creative Work
description: Midas Inc. has begun a review for the creative part of its account, which has been handled since October 2001 by Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York. Though billings were not disclosed, Midas spent $40.6 million to advertise in major media last year, according to CMR, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres.

title: Market Place; NASD Says Invemed Inflated Commissions on Trades
description: A small securities firm in New York that is run by Kenneth G. Langone, a director of the New York Stock Exchange and a founder of Home Depot, illegally shared in customer profits by overcharging them to trade in hot new stock offerings during 1999 and 2000, according to a lawsuit filed yesterday by securities regulators.

title: CADBURY GIVES SNAPPLE PRESIDENT ANOTHER PRESIDENCY
description: Cadbury Schweppes said yesterday that Jack Belsito, the president of the Snapple Beverage Group, had been named to the additional post of president of Mott's Inc., based in Stamford, Conn. In addition, the company said Brad Irwin, who was president of Mott's, was appointed the United States president of Cadbury Schweppes' Americas Confectionery division. Dave Gerics, who is the chief financial officer for Mott's, will also hold that position with Snapple, which is based in White Plains. Sherri Day (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Dessert Wine That's a Public Secret
description: THE imposing Renaissance Chteau de Monbazillac in southwestern France has a lovely sweet wine to offer, but few Americans, even wine buffs, have tasted it.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: A Flexible Conglomerate
description: The SK Corporation, one of South Korea's largest oil refiners, agreed to work with a new shareholder, Sovereign Asset Management, to make its operations clearer and said it was not being threatened with a hostile takeover from the European fund. SK, whose chairman is in jail because of an accounting scandal at an affiliate, may give outside directors more power and sell assets, said Yu Jeong Jun, the chief financial officer at SK. It will defend itself should Sovereign have an alternative motive, he said. The ability of the fund, which is based in Monaco, to improve management at SK is seen as a test of the government's commitment to reducing manipulation of local conglomerates by founding families.

title: In a New York City Budget, Less Isn't Always Less, Experienced Observers Say
description: It is normal for city workers facing thousands of pink slips to conjure nightmarish visions of the woe to befall the city.

title: Thailand's Drug War
description: To the Editor:

title: Enron's Art to Be Auctioned Off
description: Claes Oldenburg's sculpture of a pair of giant electric outlets fashioned from bright orange vinyl, which was to have adorned Enron's 40-story office tower in downtown Houston, is just one of 35 works of art from the company heading for the auction block in the coming months.

title: Bloomberg Offers Two Budgets, One Bleak and the Other Bleaker
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg released two budget proposals yesterday, a $44.5 billion best-case plan that he described as ''painful'' and a backup plan of $1 billion less that he said would be ''devastating.''

title: Frustrating Start to Season Is Catching Up to Piazza
description: There was a smile on Monday, however fleeting, when television cameras captured Mets catcher Mike Piazza in the visitors' dugout at Hiram Bithorn Stadium in San Juan, P.R., where the Mets were helping the Montreal Expos open their temporary home. At last, Piazza was enjoying himself, something that has seldom happened since the middle of last season.

title: The Bicoastal Difference That Really Isn't
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the defense by the speaker of the Assembly, Sheldon Silver, against accusations of conflict of interest when dealing with tort reform bills referred incorrectly to a law firm at which he once worked. The firm, Schneider, Kleinick, Weitz & Damashek, remains in business. (Brian Shoot, a partner whose name made up part of the firm's name, has since left.)

title: A Spring Feast for the Senses
description: WHEN properly prepared, a crown roast of lamb seems a gift sent straight from the Kennedy era, an entree of terrific richness and dainty proportion. When we were young, our dad made one every Easter. The roast, with its ring of vertical rib bones topped with paper frills, was an architectural feat second only to a volcano cake -- though, as we later discovered, a lot easier to pull off. In our college years, the crown roast of lamb's symbolism might have clouded our affection for the dish had Dad and Mom not already given it up for more fashionable showstoppers like osso buco and beef tenderloin.

title: Dutch Court Sentences Killer Of Politician to 18-Year Term
description: The man who confessed to killing Pim Fortuyn, the right-wing Dutch politician, was sentenced to 18 years in prison today for an assassination that reverberated throughout Europe and continues to disturb this country's politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, IDA
description: GINSBERG-Ida. The Faculty, Advisory Council and Alumni Association and staff of the Columbia University School of Social Work note with profound sorrow the death of Ida Robbins Ginsberg on April 13, at her home in New York City. The wife of our late Dean and Professor Emeritus, Mitchell I. Ginsberg, she was a devoted and beloved friend of the School and a generous contributor to the establishment of the Judith Ginsberg Memorial Scholarship, the Ida R. & Mitchell Ginsberg Social Policy Endowed Fund and the Ginsberg Professorship in Contemporary Urban Problems. She will be long remembered for her caring nature, warm and cheerful spirit and dedication to the objectives of social work. A memorial service will be held on April 27 at 2PM at the Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave & 76 St, in New York City. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Ginsberg Social Policy fund at the School. Sincere condolences are extended to her sister and other members of the family. Jeanette Takamura, Dean

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Thomas Flynn, 90, Administrator During 70's Fiscal Crisis
description: Thomas David Flynn, a retired New York accounting executive and the first chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was known as Big Mac during the city's dark fiscal days in the mid-1970's, died on Saturday while on a family vacation in Puerto Rico. He was 90 and lived in Princeton, N.J., having moved there recently after 50 years in Sands Point, N.Y.

title: Newark Mayor Fails to Oust City Schools Superintendent
description: Supporters of the state-appointed Newark schools superintendent, Marion Bolden, swept all three seats at stake here in elections for the local school advisory board tonight, beating back a drive by allies of Mayor Sharpe James and some local unions to replace her, unofficial returns showed.

title: WARNACO NAMES JOSEPH GROMEK ITS CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Warnaco Group Inc., the maker of Calvin Klein jeans and Speedo swimsuits, named Joseph Gromek as chief executive and president. Mr. Gromek, 56, was president and chief executive of Brooks Brothers Inc., Warnaco said. He succeeds Tony Alvarez, who has led Warnaco since November 2001, when Linda Wachner was ousted amid investor criticism of her management decisions and pay. Warnaco is focusing on sportswear, intimate apparel and swimwear after exiting Chapter 11 in February. Warnaco sought protection from creditors in June 2001.

title: Leonard Tose, 88, Is Dead; Owned Philadelphia Eagles
description: Leonard Tose, a son of an immigrant peddler who built a multimillion-dollar trucking business, bought the Philadelphia Eagles pro football team in 1969 and later sold the business and the team to pay off more than $25 million in gambling debts at Atlantic City casinos, died yesterday in Philadelphia. He was 88.

title: Peca and His Line Are Dry, And Isles Need Some Rain
description: Islanders center Michael Peca has not scored a goal since Feb. 23, or 14 hours before Coach Peter Laviolette unabashedly and somewhat uncharacteristically touted Peca as a candidate for nothing less than the Hart trophy.

title: ALTRIA BONDS RALLY AFTER COURT DECISION
description: The bonds of Altria, the parent of Philip Morris, rallied yesterday, and Standard & Poor's, the credit agency, said that it would no longer consider cutting Altria's credit rating to noninvestment grade ''at this time.'' The two developments resulted from the decision by an Illinois state judge on Monday to permit the company to secure an appeal by making cash payments over the next year totaling $800 million and by pledging an existing $6 billion company note plus interest payments. The price of Altria's 7.65 percent bond due in 2008 rose sharply as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 5.73 percent, from 7.61 percent on Monday. S.& P. said it would not now consider a credit downgrading because the reduction in the size of the appeal bond for Philip Morris ''has averted the possibility of its filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in the very near term.'' Jonathan Fuerbringer (NYT)

title: CHIEF EXECUTIVE SIGNS TO RENEW CONTRACT AT CBS
description: Viacom Inc. said yesterday that Leslie Moonves signed a new contract to remain chief executive of the CBS broadcast television network. Mr. Moonves, 53, already president and chief executive of the unit, was given the additional title of chairman, a Viacom spokesman, Carl Folta, said. He declined to comment on terms of the new agreement. Mr. Moonves, who joined CBS in 1995, has overseen a turnaround in audience ratings and profit at the network.

title: Jets Hope To Patch Some Holes With Draft
description: After an off-season in which the Jets absorbed more body blows than Chad Pennington does in most games, Jets General Manager Terry Bradway recently stretched the calendar a bit, trying to make what has been months of loss more palatable.

title: A Baby Nut for Adult Tastes
description: Among the loveliest signs of spring in markets in the Mediterranean and the Middle East are baskets of downy, pale green fresh almonds. Gathered before the shell and the nut inside have hardened, they are often served chilled to be nibbled before a meal  velvety green coating and all  dipped in salt or salted water.

title: North Koreans And U.S. Plan Talks in Beijing
description: President Bush has approved a plan for the United States to begin negotiations with North Korea in Beijing next week, the first talks between the countries since the government of Kim Jong Il threw out international inspectors and restarted its main nuclear weapons plant, United States and Asian officials said today.

description: To the Editor:

title: '85 Hijacker Is Captured In Baghdad
description: American forces in Baghdad today captured the leader of a Palestinian terrorist group responsible for the attack in 1985 on an Italian cruise ship, the Achille Lauro, in which an American was killed.

title: Yellow Ribbon? Fine, but Heed New Red Tape
description: The war in Iraq appears to be winding down, but it may take a bit longer to bring peace to a small South Jersey town that has been torn over the right to hang yellow ribbons in support of the troops.

title: Robert H. Helmick, 66, Former U.S.O.C. President
description: Robert H. Helmick, a former president of the United States Olympic Committee who resigned in 1991 because of perceived conflicts of interest, died yesterday at a hospital in Des Moines. He was 66.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday mischaracterized Ronald Reagan's history of military service. Although he was disqualified from combat duty because of poor eyesight, he was a captain in the motion picture unit of the Army Air Corps.

title: E.P.A. Plans Crackdown On Dirty Diesel Engines
description: The Bush administration proposed rules yesterday that would deeply cut the soot, sulfur and smog-forming pollution from diesel engines in construction, farm and other industrial equipment.
