title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Writer-Turned-Radical-Chic-Politician Sentenced
description: A regional court in Saratov sentenced Eduard Limonov, a onetime Soviet dissident poet who came to lead Russia's ultra-nationalist National Bolshevik Party, to four years in prison on charges of buying weapons in 2001 to establish an armed group and conduct a terrorist attack. The court dropped accusations of a plot to overthrow the Russian government. Mr. Limonov was exiled from the Soviet Union in 1974 and briefly became a literary star in New York before moving to Paris and, in 1994, back to Moscow. His trial has been a cause clbre among Russian writers and artists. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Shuttle Panel Looks at Tie Between Foam Piece and Heat Spike
description: Members of the board investigating the Columbia disaster said today that they now believed that the spot where a large piece of foam struck the shuttle during launching was very close to sensors that detected a temperature spike of hundreds of degrees in the minutes before the breakup.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Novartis Posts Profit
description: One of Europe's largest drug companies, Novartis, posted a better-than-expected profit of $1.06 billion in the first quarter despite taking a loss on its shares of Roche Holding. The company said group operating profit rose 24 percent, to $1.35 billion, while sales rose 13 percent, to $5.72 billion. Novartis, based in Basel, Switzerland, wrote down the value of its 6.2 percent stake in Roche, its crosstown rival, by $269 million as a result of Roche's loss of 4 billion Swiss francs last year. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: New Online Genre Supplies Lessons on the War in Iraq
description: It is 3 p.m., and in an online newsroom here, Leah Clapman, an editor, makes a conference call to discuss the day's news developments from Iraq with three former high school teachers.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Busier Than Ever

title: Flawed Khmer Rouge Trial Better Than None
description: It seems straightforward enough. Some of the worst mass killers of our times are living freely now in Cambodia, playing with their grandchildren and tending their flower gardens. They should be put on trial.

title: Governing Iraq, Not Fighting It
description: To the Editor:

title: Young Lawyer, Old Issue: Seeking Social Justice
description: SO let's get this straight. Vanita Gupta is all of 28, a 2001 graduate of New York University Law School and a lead lawyer in the Tulia, Tex., case in which more than a tenth of the town's black population was arrested in a drug sting based on the uncorroborated testimony of one out-of-control undercover officer.

title: Desolation and Despair, But Singing of It Proudly
description: Laments turned to rage and then to triumph when Annie Lennox sang at the Apollo Theater on Monday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLIVEN, JOHN SHEFFIELD SR.
description: BLIVEN-John Sheffield Sr. Age 81, of St. Simons Island, GA. and formerly of Lloyd Harbor, N.Y. and Providence, R.I., died April 12, 2003. Mr. Sheffield was a World War II Navy veteran and attended Brown University. He retired from Bankers Trust as a Senior Vice President with 45 years of service. Mr. Bliven was a member of Christ Church, Frederica, St. Simons Island, where he was a member of the choir. He also served on the Board of Directors for Mary House on St. Simons Island. Funeral services will be 3 P.M. Friday, April 18, 2003 at Christ Church, Frederica, St. Simons Island, GA, with Father Douglas Renegar and Father Curtis Mears officiating. Burial will be in the churchyard. Visitation 4-7 P.M. Thursday at Edo Miller and Sons Funeral Home, Brunswick, GA. Surviving are his wife, Mary H. Bliven; sons, John S. Bliven, Jr., St. Simons Island and Peter S. Bliven, Laurel Hollow, N.Y.; a daughter, Barbara D. Kersten, Worcester, N.Y.; grandchildren, Aaron Laskowski, Bay Port, N.Y., Martha Anne Bliven, St. Simons Island, Brooke A. Bliven, Allison V. Bliven and Emma E. Bliven, all of Laurel Hollow, N.Y. Memorials may be made to Christ Church, Frederica, 6329 Frederica Road, St. Simons Island, Georgia 31522.

title: Jason Bellini: Iraqi Boy Faces Long Recovery
description: KUWAIT CITY (CNN) -- A 12-year-old Iraqi boy, who lost both of his arms, his parents, brother and seven other family members in a coalition bombing raid near Baghdad, arrived early Wednesday at a hospital in Kuwait City.

title: Discrimination Is Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: History Up In Smoke
description: Last week, the C.I.A. was leaning toward believing that Saddam Hussein was alive and Osama bin Laden was dead. This week, the C.I.A. is leaning toward believing that Osama bin Laden is alive and Saddam Hussein is dead.

title: Disney Reaches a Deal For the Sale of the Angels
description: After several years of seeking a buyer for the Anaheim Angels, the Walt Disney Company has agreed in principle to sell the team for more than $180 million to an Arizona businessman, a person apprised of the negotiations said today.

title: Geography of an Easter Dessert: From Italy to TriBeCa
description: ENZO PEZONE, a chef and an owner of Pepolino, a small Tuscan restaurant in TriBeCa, recently won a contest sponsored by the Italian Culinary Institute in New York with his recipe for a ricotta tart. The tart was based on a dessert served at Cibreo, a restaurant in Florence, Italy, where Mr. Pezone worked for 15 years.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Grocer's Sales Decline
description: One of Britain's largest supermarket chains, Safeway, which is the target of a takeover battle involving five bidders, reported a decline of 0.1 percent in same-store sales in the quarter that ended on March 31. The company said full-year profit would be within the range of market expectations at about 335 million ($526 million). The prospective buyers, Morrison's Supermarkets, the Tesco Corporation, J Sainsbury and Wal-Mart Stores, face lengthy scrutiny by the European competition commission to determine if their bids will be permitted to go ahead. Safeway said it had not had any recent contact with Philip Green, a British retail entrepreneur, who has been cleared to bid immediately. A Safeway rival, Somerfield, said that it had been approached by a possible bidder. The retailer said it was uncertain whether an offer would follow. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

title: 3 Chip Makers Post Results That Meet Expectations
description: Intel, Motorola and Texas Instruments, three of the world's largest chip makers, all reported earnings yesterday that met or slightly exceeded Wall Street's expectations.

title: Quebec Result: Solidly for Canada
description: During his failed provincial election campaign, Premier Bernard Landry predicted that Quebec would become a sovereign state within 1,000 days after his victory.

title: INSIDE
description: Virus Said to Be Identified

title: Shocking Art in Edwardian Digs
description: In the former County Hall overlooking the Thames, a museum opens tomorrow that is devoted to the brash British contemporary art favored by its founder.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Job Agency Tops Forecast
description: The world's largest temporary employment company, Adecco, posted better-than-expected first-quarter results. Net income for the company, which is based in Switzerland, fell 6 percent, to 64 million euros ($68.8 million), but market analysts had expected an even larger decline. Sales also fell 6 percent, to 3.8 billion euros. Adecco said cost-cutting measures, which included layoffs, helped offset a global decline in demand for temporary workers. Adecco said its income and sales were higher in local currencies, but the strength of the euro against other currencies, particularly the dollar, reduced both figures. Sales in the United States rose 10 percent. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, New York, the third- largest securities firm, said it had agreed to purchase the Ayco Company, Albany, to offer new financial planning services to executives of Goldman's corporate clients. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Bloomberg Names 5 New Members to Rent Guidelines Board
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appointed five new members to the city's Rent Guidelines Board yesterday, giving the board the quorum necessary to hold its first meeting of the year and barely avoid canceling a second meeting in a row.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILLERLANE, MADELINE C.
description: KILLERLANE-Madeline C., 86. Formerly of Brooklyn. Passed away on April 15, 2003. at her home in White Plains, NY. Madeline was the much loved wife of the late James. She was the dear mother to Rose and James. The Beloved grandmother of Christina and James III. Madeline was retired from the Brooklyn Public Library. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, White Plains. Funeral blessing Friday 10 AM at Our Lady of Sorrows Church.

title: Marines Take On a New Role: Keeping Order in Hussein's Hometown
description: American marines expanded operations today throughout this city, once at the center of Saddam Hussein's power, as civilians returned from the outskirts, gawking at scenes that had once seemed impossibly unlikely.

title: Morgan Vice Chairwoman to Join Buyout Firm
description: Julie G. Richardson, a vice chairwoman of J. P. Morgan Chase and one of the top women in investment banking on Wall Street, is leaving to join the buyout firm of Providence Equity Partners.

title: Court Hears Fight Over Numbers Used For Cellphones
description: The wireless telephone industry appealed to a federal court in Washington yesterday to block a government effort to allow consumers to keep their cellphone numbers when they switch mobile phone carriers.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: DANBURY: 2 ACCUSED OF CHILD ABUSE A Danbury man and his former girlfriend have been arrested and charged with sexually abusing a teenage girl for three years and videotaping the encounters at the homes of both suspects in nearby Putnam County, N.Y. The girl, now 17, told the Danbury police on April 1 that she had been abused by the couple, Bernard Diaz, 53, and Donnaann Dambro, 43, from age 13 to 16. Two days later, the police searched Mr. Diaz's home and Ms. Dambro's home in Southeast, N.Y. The police said they found videotapes of the couple sexually abusing the girl. Both face child sexual abuse charges and may face federal charges, the police said. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Pay-Cut Deadline Extended at American
description: American Airlines said yesterday that it would extend until this afternoon a voting deadline on $340 million in concessions from its flight attendants' union. The move came after the union pushed American closer to a threatened bankruptcy filing, failing by a narrow margin yesterday to approve the cuts.

title: Carrying the Worst News, Dutifully
description: He drove north on Route 91 in a government-issue sedan, weighed down by the news he carried. He could not rest until he had delivered the news, and he had to do so as quickly as possible. It was that kind of news.

title: Three Parts Become One And Art Is the Winner
description: It may sound strange to speak of a three-member enterprise as having institutional memory, but in the world of chamber music the Beaux Arts Trio is an institution, and the pianist Menahem Pressler its memory. Mr. Pressler, 79, was a founder of the trio in 1955, and as different string players have come and gone in recent years, he has held firmly at the piano bench, lending some continuity among the musical chairs.

title: Roto-Rooter
description: I was chatting with an Egyptian friend in Cairo two weeks ago when she got a joke e-mailed to her cellphone, which she immediately shared with me. It said: ''President Bush: Take Syria -- get Lebanon for free.''

title: One Huge Step for Cleaner Air
description: One consistent thread in Christie Whitman's sometimes bumpy tenure as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency has been her steady advocacy for tougher controls on the enormous amount of harmful air pollution caused by diesel engines. In her third month on the job, despite court challenges and industry opposition, she reaffirmed rules imposed by her predecessor, Carol Browner, that sharply limited emissions of soot and smog-forming gases from diesel-powered trucks and buses. On Tuesday, Ms. Whitman announced equally tough standards for ''non-road'' diesel engines, used in construction, agricultural and industrial equipment.

title: The Rake, The Devil And Their Tragic Deal
description: The director Jonathan Miller has essentially become persona non grata at the Metropolitan Opera. The trouble started in 1998, when he publicly challenged some questionable artistic choices Cecilia Bartoli insisted on for Mr. Miller's production of Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro.'' It's all too bad because over the years this feisty British director provided the Met with some vividly imaginative productions, none better than his 1997 staging of Stravinsky's only full-length opera, ''The Rake's Progress.'' Happily, that production returned to the Met on Monday night, with the sure-footed stage director Laurie Feldman in charge of theatrical matters, and James Levine again conducting a score he reveres.

title: Much of City's Destiny Is Up to Albany, Not Mayor
description: Moments after laying out his description of a New York City with far fewer firehouses, thousands of laid-off workers and no pools for city children to frolic in during the summer, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg stared toward the cameras and talked wistfully about why the city's fiscal predicament left him ''a little sad, a little angry.''

title: Achille Lauro Figure Caught
description: American forces in Baghdad captured Abu Abbas, the leader of a Palestinian terrorist group responsible for the attack in 1985 on the cruise ship Achille Lauro. Page B1.

title: The Microbe Test
description: To determine whether a particular microbe causes a particular disease, scientists rely on a testing process devised in 1890 by the German bacteriologist Robert Koch.

description: TRANSFORMING LEADERSHIP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEFRANCESCO, VINCENT
description: DeFRANCESCO - Vincent. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Vincent DeFrancesco, associated with The Times from October 1963 until retiring in April 1973.

title: The Home-Front War on Taxes
description: With the blitzlike speed of his generals, President Bush has come out fighting for his disastrous plan for more upper-bracket tax cuts, which will only stoke the nation's record levels of deficit spending and deepening debt well beyond his incumbency. In a Rose Garden plea for his economic ''growth'' package yesterday, Mr. Bush artfully adapted his war-room posture to link applause lines for the Iraqi success thus far with fresh appeals to rally behind a new battle against the dividends tax.

title: S.E.C. Picks A Fed Banker To Lead Panel
description: William J. McDonough, the longtime president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, was chosen to be chairman of the new Public Company Accounting Oversight Board yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: For Korean-Americans, Concerns for a New War
description: Like many residents of the nation's largest Korean-American population here, Ik Kyun Choe, who immigrated to California in 1974, is worried that after the United States-led coalition finishes its military campaign in Iraq, North Korea will be its next target and the results could be disastrous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIX, NORMAN
description: DIX-Norman. Died quietly comforted by his wife and friends on April 14, 2003 after an accident on April 1. Survivors are his beloved wife, Elayne Neufeld Dix, three children and their spouses, Mitchell Dix and Bonnie Taub-Dix, Edna and Michael Miller, and Floyd Dix and Cindy Nord. Also survived by six grandchildren, Adam, Sam, Jesse, Sage, Thomas and Josh. Dear brother of Stuart Dix and partner Wilma, sister Evelyn Dix and nine brothers and sisters-in-law and their spouses, 28 nieces and nephews and seven great nieces and nephews. Quiet, dignified with a great sense of humor, Norman enjoyed many years with his adored Elayne, unconditionally loved his children and grandchildren, was a gentle and funny presence with family and friends. We remember a full life with many international outdoor adventure trips, zest for life in Copake, good times with family and friends. In lieu of flowers, send contributions to Doctors Without Borders, P.O. Box 1869, Merrifield, VA 22116-9644.

title: By Garden's Standards, Chaney Is a Success
description: THE question to ask, more than why, is why not? Why wouldn't Don Chaney get another chance to coach the Knicks and a contract extension to immunize him from lame-duck disease? Why wouldn't Chaney get the same opportunity to work at Madison Square Garden again next season that Scott Layden apparently will?

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Holy Thursday and the first day of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

description: A Nation at War, a daily separate section, begins on Page B1. Complete metropolitan and sports reports share a section. By flipping over The Metro Section, bottom-side up, readers will find the sports pages, starting with S1.

title: Inching Toward Democracy, Catching a Big One, Changing a Chant
description: A diverse group of Iraqis took tentative steps toward democracy as President Bush declared the end of Saddam Hussein's government. Washington kept up pressure on Syria, crowds turned on American troops and a terrorist leader from the 1980's was captured in Baghdad.

title: Knicks Sign Chaney To Contract Extension
description: Don Chaney did not guide the Knicks to the playoffs for a second straight season, but he got better results than nearly everyone expected when Antonio McDyess sustained a season-ending knee injury in October.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, BETTY
description: EDELMAN-Betty. Beloved wife of the late Sydney. Devoted mother of Pat (Alan) Schwartz and Arlene (Mark) Bernstein. Adored grandmother of Steven Schwartz, Robert (Mary) Schwartz, Brad (Tama) Bernstein, Emily (Barry) Baum and loving great-grandmother of Spencer and Justin Bernstein. Services private.

title: Food Is in Short Supply in Baghdad as Problems in Getting It to Market Persist
description: The only splash of color in the otherwise drab Batawiyan market comes from the tomatoes, oranges, apples and green beans in Adnan Hassan's tiny vegetable stand.

title: Prosecutors Say Spy Suspect Revealed Details of Inquiry
description: An F.B.I. informer in Los Angeles accused of being a Chinese double agent appears to have compromised a highly delicate nuclear espionage investigation by revealing to Beijing the identities of two F.B.I. agents working on the case, officials said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Burberry's Sales Rise
description: The British luxury goods retailer Burberry said sales rose 30 percent in the six months ended in March from the period a year earlier. Total revenue was up 22 percent. During 2002, Burberry introduced new products like rubber-backed trench coats and opened stores in New York, London, Barcelona, Hong Kong and Florida. This year, it plans to open four more stores in the United States and an outlet in Milan. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINDELS, ARTHUR EDWARD

description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Notebook; Presidential Yacht Sequoia
description: A finely crafted motor yacht that witnessed key historic moments in American history languishes at a marina near the Tidal Basin in Washington. There it is susceptible to vandalism, weather and larcenous souvenir seekers. It ought to be in a safer place where it can be revered rather than rented.

title: Nostalgic Sounds of Old Folkies Who Never Were
description: After seeing Mitch and Mickey, the legendary folk-music duo of the 1960's, reunite on the stage of Town Hall to perform their signature tune, ''A Kiss at the End of the Rainbow,'' I wanted nothing so much as to go out to the garage and dig out some of their old LP's, just for old times' sake. The only problem -- apart from my not having a garage -- is that these dewy-eyed singers, their songs so twee and noodle-headed as to make Richard and Mimi Faria sound like the Ramones, never existed.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 29 about South Korea's ties with the United States included a reversed poll finding published in the Korean press, on South Koreans' attitudes toward the presence of American troops. The polling firm, Fn Research and Consulting, later reported that in the survey of 2,154 adults, 68.4 percent wanted American troops to remain in the country and 31.6 percent wanted them withdrawn. The firm sent a correction to Korean newspapers, and the South Korean consulate general informed The Times.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: ALBANY: BILL WOULD BLOCK PART OF SCHOOL PLAN A group of state senators from New York City introduced a bill yesterday to block a key part of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's effort to overhaul the city schools. Senator Frank Padavan, left, a Queens Republican and the bill's principal sponsor, said it would block the reorganization of the 32 local elementary school districts into 10 "instructional zones." The Senate bill is sponsored by six Democrats and two Republicans. The bill would require the city to maintain 30 to 37 school districts, each with a superintendent, support staff and office. Currently, there are 32 school districts for elementary schools, one district in each borough for high schools, and a handful of districts for special programs. The mayor contends that the 32 elementary school districts are not being eliminated but are being incorporated into the larger zones.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 8 miscalculated the incidence of reported cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome in Hong Kong. Based on the number of cases at the time, it was 1 in 7,700, not 1 in 80,000.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: WRITER-TURNED-RADICAL-CHIC-POLITICIAN SENTENCED A regional court in Saratov sentenced Eduard Limonov, a onetime Soviet dissident poet who came to lead Russia's ultra-nationalist National Bolshevik Party, to four years in prison on charges of buying weapons in 2001 to establish an armed group and conduct a terrorist attack. The court dropped accusations of a plot to overthrow the Russian government. Mr. Limonov was exiled from the Soviet Union in 1974 and briefly became a literary star in New York before moving to Paris and, in 1994, back to Moscow. His trial has been a cause célèbre among Russian writers and artists.   Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a bar at the Plaza Hotel where smoking is allowed because of an exemption under New York City's new antismoking law misidentified it. It is the Oak Bar; the Oak Room is the neighboring restaurant.

title: Living, Thieving and Dying on Casablanca's Mean Streets
description: From Luis Buuel's ''Olvidados'' of 1950 to the current ''City of God,'' films about the hard lives of street kids have made up a substantial portion of the art-house market. But this genre has degenerated over the years, from the cruelty and absurdism of Buuel's vision to the voyeuristic kicks of the 1981 films ''Christiane F'' and ''Pixote.''

title: U.S. Weighs Trial of Terror Suspect in '85 Ship Killing
description: WASHINGTON, April 16  Bush administration officials today hailed the capture of the terror suspect Abu Abbas in Iraq as the long-sought "nexus" between Baghdad and terrorism, and they met to discuss whether he should be tried in the United States on charges related to the hijacking of the Achille Lauro cruise ship in 1985.

title: Quesadillas, Assimilated
description: Chris Santos, left, and Peter Kane, the former owners of Wyanoka in Chinatown, missed the inventive quesadillas they sometimes served there, so they opened the Mexican Sandwich Company, at 322 Fifth Avenue (Third Street) in Park Slope, Brooklyn. They serve 10 quesadilla combinations, on three layers of 6- or 12-inch tortillas -- plain, spinach, whole wheat or tomato-flavored -- with fillings like white bean and chorizo, barbecued duck confit or wild mushroom, $6.50 to $14. You can also design your own. Delivery is free ($10 minimum) from Fourth Avenue to Prospect Park, St. Marks Avenue to 15th Street.

description: VOX populi says Martha Burk failed because only 40 protesters showed up outside the Masters golf tournament last Saturday.

description: STERLING-Morry. On April 15, 2003. Beloved husband of Selma. Loving uncle of Sherwood and Harry. Services Wednesday 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Show Returning To Manhattan
description: After leaving New York City for a year after its 2001 performance at Madison Square Garden, the National Horse Show will return to Manhattan in the fall for a five-day run at Pier 94 and the adjacent show piers on the Hudson River at 54th Street. The dates, announced yesterday, are Wednesday, Oct. 29, through Sunday, Nov. 5.

title: Knicks End a Dismal Season On a Familiar, Losing Note
description: It could have been any other night, any other season. The Indiana Pacers were in town to face the Knicks at Madison Square Garden. Reggie Miller still elicited a chorus of boos every time he launched an off-balance jump shot, arms extended and legs splayed. There were celebrities lining the court and a capacity crowd filling the stands.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Manhattan; Cooling the Empire State Building on the Cheap
description: In August and September of last year, the Empire State Building saved a total of $48,000 in air-conditioning costs by switching between steam and electricity to supply chilled water throughout the building's air-conditioning system. If they had been able to use the technique earlier, the managers of the 102-story building say, they would probably have saved about $200,000 over the course of the summer.

description: To the Editor:

title: Wealthy Real Estate Family Settles Decade-Long Feud
description: The Milstein family ended a bitter, decade-long feud yesterday over a fortune estimated at $5 billion that had pitted cousins against uncles as they lobbed lawsuits at each other, forced the sale of prime Manhattan real estate and raised a ruckus at the bank they owned.

title: Way Off Broadway, the Auto Show
description: No city on Earth is more capable of expertly staging a show than New York, but until recent years the city's annual auto exhibition has been an also-ran to Detroit, Frankfurt, Paris and Tokyo. Some of the blame falls to timing, the New York stop on the international auto show circuit coming late in the model year (though in the thick of the spring selling surge). The overseas shows held in the autumn, and Detroit's event in early January, grab the headlines and the attention of the press corps, so that's where the manufacturers have generally invested their resources in implausible multimillion-dollar concept cars, over-the-top displays and dramatic presentations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIXON, SYLVIA
description: DIXON-Sylvia. On April 14, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Robert S. Dixon. Loving mother of Clara Kozol and Robert Shapiro. description: Following is an excerpt from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's budget address yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times. A full transcript is online at nytimes.com/nyregion.

description: The big earner in Gov. George E. Pataki's family last year was not the governor himself but his wife, Libby, who reported $206,500 in income from consulting fees and four speeches that she gave to a powerful California law firm expanding into New York, and two computer and security companies.

title: Nets Clinch Division As Bulls Beat 76ers
description: The Nets were triumphant tonight even though they were idle, winning another Atlantic Division title thanks to the Chicago Bulls.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Man Admits 27 Bank Robberies
description: A man who disguised himself by puffing out his cheeks like Dizzy Gillespie's has admitted committing 27 bank robberies in five states over four years, the United States attorney's office said yesterday. The authorities nicknamed the man, Cazzie L. Williams, 30, of East Orange, ''the Puffy-Cheeked Bandit.'' He pleaded guilty on Monday in Federal District Court here to a four-count indictment, admitting 18 New Jersey robberies as well as others in Virginia, Maryland, Ohio and Pennsylvania. Sentencing is scheduled for Aug. 13. Mr. Williams, a former postal worker, could get up to 80 years in prison. His robberies netted from $1,000 to $16,300. A fingerprint match led to his arrest last October. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Experts Say China Has Greatly Underestimated Virus Cases
description: BEIJING, April 16  Chinese authorities have significantly understated the prevalence of severe acute respiratory syndrome in Beijing, international medical investigators said today. Cases are possibly now in the range of 100 to 200 rather than the 37 that were officially reported on Monday, they said.

title: New Jersey Officials Urged To Help Close Nuclear Plant
description: Antinuclear and environmental advocates called on state officials today to press for retiring the Oyster Creek nuclear power plant in this fast-growing area of the Jersey Shore, which they said would be difficult to evacuate after an accident or attack.

title: Columbia Names Dean For Its Journalism School
description: Lee C. Bollinger, president of Columbia University, said yesterday that Nicholas Lemann, the Washington correspondent for The New Yorker, had agreed to become dean of the Graduate School of Journalism, an appointment that comes at a pivotal time for the school.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: CHEMICAL TRADE INQUIRY The European Commission has raided the offices of several chemical companies as part of a cartel investigation involving the markets for hydrogen peroxide, solvents and paint ingredients. BASF of Germany and Solvay of Belgium confirmed yesterday that antitrust officials visited their offices in late March. Both companies said they were cooperating with the investigation. The European Commission said it suspected the companies of fixing prices and dividing the European Union market among themselves. It did not name the companies raided. Paul Meller (NYT)

Contributions may be made to the New Canaan Library, or to the Saint Mark's Church Outreach Commission for International Projects.

title: Pairings: A White Wine With Enough Backbone to Handle a Lively Risotto
description: WHEN you get a chance to drink wines like the Stony Hill chardonnays, it is worth your while to think ahead a little and plan out a good meal. These chardonnays have excellent structure, with a core of acidity, ample mineral content and a youthful zip. They seem to glide over your palate, whereas so many chardonnays skid.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: COMPUTER HORIZONS SHARES SOAR The stock of the Computer Horizons Corporation leaped yesterday after the company said it would consider an unsolicited takeover offer valued at about $154 million from Aquent. The company, which provides information technology services, advised its shareholders to take no action until its review of the offer was completed. Computer Horizons shares rose $1.65, or 58 percent, to $4.49. Aquent, a private professional services firm in Boston, offered Monday to buy Computer Horizons for $5 a share, a 67 percent premium to the stock's $3 closing price on Friday. Based on Computer Horizons' roughly 30.8 million shares outstanding as of Dec. 31, Aquent's offer would put the total price over $154 million. Aquent said it would seek to elect two independent directors to Computer Horizons' board and would try to amend its bylaws to allow shareholders who own 10 percent or more of the shares to call a special meeting. Currently, only management or the holders of 50 percent or more of the company's outstanding stock can call such a meeting. (Dow Jones/AP)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Venice Landmark Damaged By Fire
description: A fire partly destroyed Mulino Stucky, a 19th-century neo-Gothic flour mill that is considered one of Venice's important landmarks. The fire burned the top floors of the 1895 building, collapsing a wall and spreading black smoke over the island. No injuries were reported, and the cause of the fire was not known. The building, on the western end of Giudecca island, across the lagoon from the main island of Venice, is in the process of being being restored and converted into a hotel and housing complex. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Chaney's Contract Is Extended as Coach of Knicks
description: Don Chaney did not guide the Knicks to the playoffs for a second straight season, but he got better results than nearly everyone expected when Antonio McDyess sustained a season-ending knee injury in October.

title: Judge Allows Suit in Death Of Gay Mate
description: A judge on Long Island has ruled that a gay man who joined his domestic partner in a civil union in Vermont can file a wrongful death lawsuit as a spouse.

title: Success in Iraq Helps Congressman's Quest
description: Two decades ago, a young California lawyer and Vietnam veteran named Duncan Hunter rode Ronald Reagan's coattails to Congress, sweeping aside a long-serving Democrat. As he left home, he recalls, his father gave him this advice: ''You've got to go to Washington and get that seat, because it's important to our country.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Convicted Of Rape
description: A man already serving a sentence at Rikers Island for stealing from a Macy's storeroom was found guilty yesterday of separate charges that he raped and robbed a Macy's employee in January 1998. The man, Joe Felder, 40, of Brooklyn, pounced on an employee who had gone into a stockroom at Macy's flagship store in Herald Square, prosecutors said in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The employee stabbed Mr. Felder with her identity badge, and he bled onto a bathrobe in the stockroom, prosecutors said. DNA recovered from the bathrobe linked Mr. Felder to the crime. He is serving two and a half to five years in prison and could be sentenced to an additional 25 years to life if he is declared a persistent felony offender at sentencing, which has not been scheduled. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Moving In With a Family That Struggles on the Edge
description: ''Love and Diane'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 12, 2002; the full text is online at nytimes.com/movies. The film opens today at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village.

title: For Dassault Aviation, Iraq Means Less Work
description: The military side of Dassault Aviation was having a tough time making new sales even before the war in Iraq. The company, France's only warplane builder, lost a $4.4 billion, 40-jet order in South Korea to Boeing last spring, and in December, Poland picked Lockheed Martin for a $3.5 billion, 48-plane contract, again passing over Dassault's Mirage and Rafale jets.

title: Pieces Awash In Originality, Sometimes On the Edge
description: Ivy Baldwin has a wild imagination. Though a relatively unseasoned choreographer, Ms. Baldwin is also unafraid of testing her audience's limits. Her new ''To Tears in a Bucket,'' performed by her company on Saturday night at Joyce SoHo, became almost unbearable to watch and hear. But it was original and promising.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Bill Would Block Part Of School Plan
description: A group of state senators from New York City introduced a bill yesterday to block a key part of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's effort to overhaul the city schools. Senator Frank Padavan, left, a Queens Republican and the bill's principal sponsor, said it would block the reorganization of the 32 local elementary school districts into 10 ''instructional zones.'' The Senate bill is sponsored by six Democrats and two Republicans. The bill would require the city to maintain 30 to 37 school districts, each with a superintendent, support staff and office. Currently, there are 32 school districts for elementary schools, one district in each borough for high schools, and a handful of districts for special programs. The mayor contends that the 32 elementary school districts are not being eliminated but are being incorporated into the larger zones. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: At the Velvet Rope, a Volatile Science; Bouncer's Death Highlights Perils and Tactics of Working the Door
description: Do not call him a bouncer. Bouncing is a last resort. For the self-respecting guy at the door, bouncing is crude.

title: South Dakota's Cosmic Battle Over a Dry Mine
description: Rarely have neutrinos -- subatomic waifs that usually stream unencumbered through trees, people and the rest of the universe -- fomented public protests, a lawsuit and a preliminary restraining order.

title: At Least 10 Iraqis Are Dead In Clashes in Northern Iraq
description: American marines killed at least 10 Iraqi men today and wounded up to 16 others in a chaotic clash with thousands of protesters in northern Iraq, Iraqi officials said.

title: Glavine and Benitez Halt Mets' Skid at Six
description: Almost by circumstance, Armando Benitez was able to deliver his mandate to Tom Glavine tonight. Benitez, the Mets' fragile closer, and Glavine, the imported ace from the Braves, wear uniform numbers 49 and 47 and have neighboring lockers on the road. So Benitez was in a perfect position minutes before the Mets took the field against Pittsburgh tonight.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts Briefing column yesterday about the 50th anniversary of William S. Burroughs's book ''Junky: Confessions of an Unredeemed Drug Addict'' misstated the year of the author's death. It was 1997, not 1977.

description: April 15, 2003

title: Nasdaq Decides to Split Job Once Chief Retires in May
description: The Nasdaq stock market, having struggled through three years of falling technology stock prices, yesterday named two men -- one of its directors and an outside executive -- to succeed Hardwick Simmons, who is retiring as chairman and chief executive.

title: Canada Raises Interest Rate on Inflation Concern
description: The Bank of Canada raised its benchmark interest rate for the fifth time in the last 13 months, citing prospects for a renewed burst of economic growth later this year and concerns about inflation.

title: A Neighborhood Sushi Spot Swims in an Ocean of Them
description: PERHAPS as compensation for its lack of easy access to the subways, the neighborhood around First Avenue in the 70's has been given a pretty fair blessing: an unusual number of excellent, moderately priced sushi bars.

title: A Baby Nut for Adult Tastes
description: Among the loveliest signs of spring in markets in the Mediterranean and the Middle East are baskets of downy, pale green fresh almonds. Gathered before the shell and the nut inside have hardened, they are often served chilled to be nibbled before a meal -- velvety green coating and all -- dipped in salt or salted water.

title: Curators Appeal for a Ban On Purchase of Iraqi Artifacts
description: The world's museum officials and archaeologists appealed to the American government yesterday to take stronger steps to prevent further pillaging in Baghdad and called for a moratorium on the purchase of Iraqi antiquities on the international market.

title: Bush Urges U.N. to Lift Economic Sanctions Against Iraq
description: ST. LOUIS, April 16  Having declared Saddam Hussein's rule to be ended, President Bush called on the United Nations today to lift economic sanctions on Iraq, moving to allow greater sales of Iraqi oil to help pay for its reconstruction.

title: Sports of The Times; By Garden's Standards, Chaney Is a Success
description: The Knicks' coach has done a better job than their general manager. THE question to ask, more than why, is why not? Why wouldn't Don Chaney get another chance to coach the Knicks and a contract extension to immunize him from lame-duck disease? Why wouldn't Chaney get the same opportunity to work at Madison Square Garden again next season that Scott Layden apparently will?

title: State Leaders Vow to Stop Health and Education Cuts
description: New York's two top legislative leaders vowed today to restore $1.9 billion in cuts -- mostly to health care and education -- that Gov. George E. Pataki had proposed. The announcement set the stage for the Legislature to pass its own budget in the next two weeks if the leaders cannot reach agreement on a final plan with the governor.

title: Microsoft Exceeds Expected Profit But Stays Cautious
description: The Microsoft Corporation, the world's largest software company, posted slightly higher-than-expected quarterly earnings yesterday even as it adopted a cautious outlook, warning that the personal computer industry remains sluggish, in part because consumer confidence is so fragile.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm happy that Saddam Hussein is gone. I don't care if the Americans are here or not. But nothing has changed for me. I am out of jail, but I have no job, nowhere to live.''

title: Iraqi Man Was Actually A U.S. Agent, Lawyer Says
description: An Iraqi man accused of working secretly as an agent for Iraqi intelligence in New York City was actually trying to help the United States learn about Iraq's intelligence activities, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: Slump in Plane Travel Grounds Wichita, World's 'Air Capital'
description: Their income from the aircraft industry has evaporated. Their split-level home of six years, in a neighborhood sliced from farmland, has a Coldwell Banker ''For Sale'' sign in front. Deborah Salter has sold her jewelry. Her husband, Jim, has sold his truck, guns, tools and lawn mower.

description: Civilian experts recruited by the United States to hunt for unconventional weapons in Iraq say bureaucratic confusion and infighting have delayed their effort to a point that the search itself may be compromised.

description: President Bush lowered his target for his tax cuts today to $550 billion, a significant retreat on his economic principles and an admission that his original package worth $726 billion was dead.

title: In European Union Milestone, 10 Lands Sign Pacts to Join
description: ATHENS, April 16  During a historic ceremony in the cradle of democracy, the leaders of 10 countries signed treaties here today to join the European Union, extending its reach to include a broad swath of Europe once allied with the former Soviet Union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARNOW, MIRIAM SARE
description: CHARNOW - Miriam Sare, age 79, of Reston, VA died on April 12, 2003 at her home. She was born in New York City, NY on September 9, 1923 to the late Harry L. and Hadassah Dondes Sare. She will be missed by Sally and Gary, Karen and Charlie and their children: Noam, Mika, Ian and Hannah and her sister Aviva. Shiva will be held Friday April 18th, 2-7 PM at 275 Windsor Place, Brooklyn, NY. A memorial service was held on Tuesday, April 15 in Reston, VA. Family suggests that Memorial Contributions may be made to an organization devoted to peace and justice or the Humane Society. For information Adams - Green Funeral Home, Herndon, VA.

description: DYMOND - Jonas. Dear, sweet man, treasured friend, you will be sorely missed and always remembered. Sam, Marion, Paul, Andrea, Jay and Alissa Maizes

Survived by wife of 66 years, Dallas Wing Laurier Shriver and son Stephen of Mechanicsburg, PA. www.neillfh.com

title: Easter Lunch Without a Scramble
description: WHEN Easter falls late, as it does this year, it is impossible not to feel aware of the earlier, pagan festivities that underpin the holiday: the sense of renewal, of spring in the air. There is no better time for an easy celebratory lunch, all generations welcome.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Tenants Vow To Fight Evacuation
description: Tenants of a 66-unit apartment building in Harlem were told by a building inspector yesterday that their apartments would be evacuated at 8 a.m. today, they said. The building, at 321 St. Nicholas Avenue, at West 126th Street, has 53 occupied apartments . Some tenants said last night that they did not intend to leave their homes. Amy Thogmartin, project manager of Neighborhood Restore, a nonprofit housing agency that owns the building, said the Department of Buildings was called in to inspect structural hazards in the building about two weeks ago. As of Monday, she said, ''They made the determination that they had to evacuate the whole building.'' Reached last night, spokeswomen for the Department of Buildings and the Department of Housing Preservation and Development said they could not comment on the structure's specific problems. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Looking at Postwar Bush, Glum Democrats Ponder How to Win in 2004
description: The swift fall of Baghdad has complicated what many Democrats had already viewed as the difficult task of unseating President Bush and winning back Congress next year, party leaders say.

title: Bouncer's Death Unresolved as 3 Are Freed
description: The three siblings arrested in connection with the death on Sunday of Dana Blake, a bouncer at a Lower East Side nightclub, were not carrying weapons and had nothing to do with the killing, their lawyer said yesterday.

description: To the Editor:

title: 4 New Jersey Officers Charged in Man's Death
description: Four police officers in Bloomfield, N.J., were charged yesterday with fatally injuring a man by subduing him as he suffered an epileptic seizure at work, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 8 miscalculated the incidence of reported cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome in Hong Kong. Based on the number of cases at the time, it was 1 in 7,700, not 1 in 80,000.

title: Renaissance Duck Confit, Ready for Any Artful Meal
description: It's not that duck confit, the rich, meaty duck leg slow-cooked in fat, needs help. But Charlie Trotter, the Chicago restaurateur, has packaged duck confit with subtle and effective flavorings. I warmed up his curry and fennel version, took the meat off the bone in chunks and used it in a basmati rice pilaf with a yogurt sauce. Another time I crisped the orange and ginger confit in the oven and served it with wilted spinach. The confit is $19.95 for a package containing two servings from www.charlietrotters.com.

title: U.S. Inspectors Find No Forbidden Weapons at Iraqi Arms Plant
description: An American team hunting for unconventional Iraqi weapons at an ammunition manufacturing and storage plant near Karbala have discovered some suspicious items, but appeared to have come away yet again without the ''smoking gun'' proving that Iraq made chemical, biological or nuclear materials here.

description: Papi, otherwise known as Tomas Fuentes (Eduardo Verastegui), is a dashing, impossibly handsome Los Angeles advertising executive who has used his frequent-flier card to establish romantic relationships with three different Latina lovelies in three different cities.

title: Tests to Resume on AirTrain; Crash Is Tied to Human Error
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that tests could resume as early as today on the $1.9 billion AirTrain line to Kennedy Airport. The announcement came after investigators found that human error, not structural problems, caused a fatal crash in a test on the line last year.

title: 3 Israelis and 2 Palestinians Are Killed in Separate Shootings
description: Two Palestinian gunmen, two Israeli civilians and an Israeli officer were killed in separate shootouts today in the West Bank city of Nablus and at a crossing point to the Gaza Strip.

title: Morgan Stanley and U.S. Agency Fail to Settle Sex Bias Lawsuit
description: Forcing the chiefs of Morgan Stanley and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to sit in a stifling federal courtroom in lower Manhattan for three hours yesterday was not enough to bring about a settlement in a long-running sex-discrimination lawsuit against the investment firm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDDINGTON, MICHAEL J. JR.
description: REDDINGTON - Michael J. Jr. of East Northport (formerly of Manhasset). Beloved father of Michael and Helen, Robert, James and Alli, Patricia, Steven. Cherished grandfather of four. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, 3-5 and 7-9PM. Religious service 10 AM Thursday, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Survived by the mother of his children, Joan Reddington Corrigan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Institute of Cancer Research.

title: CNN Moves Zahn to Prime Time, Pitting Her Against Fox Show
description: Paula Zahn, who has been the primary anchor on CNN's morning news coverage for the last two years, will move to a two-hour prime-time program starting Monday, the network announced yesterday.

title: Dilemma's Definition: The Left And Iraq
description: This has been a tough war for commentators on the American left. To hope for defeat meant cheering for Saddam Hussein. To hope for victory meant cheering for President Bush.

title: Exposure of Church Group to Disease Raises Chance of Its Spread in Toronto
description: The possibility that severe acute respiratory syndrome could be spreading to the Toronto population at large increased significantly with the news that 500 members of a church group had been exposed to the disease March 28 and may have passed it to others.

title: War and Weather Are Cited For Drop in Industrial Output
description: Industrial production fell in March for a second month, as manufacturers cut back during the war and utilities generated less power as the weather warmed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANZER, RANNY
description: RANZER-Ranny. Of Boca Raton, FL. Loving husband of Sylvia and the late Ethel Ranzer. Died on April 14. He is survived by his sons Mark and David, daughters-in-law Judy and Joanne, grandchildren Cori, Karen, Ian, Alan and Beth Ranzer. Ranny spent his career in the garment center where he was a partner in Parade Dress Co. and Ranelle Fashions.

title: Refund Too Good For I.R.S. To Believe
description: Last year around this time, the authorities said, things seemed to be going pretty well for Benjamin Harris, a career office temp from Crown Heights, Brooklyn. His 2001 tax return had been processed speedily, and his refund check had been direct-deposited into his account at an HSBC bank branch in Manhattan.

title: Pledge Made to Democracy By Exiles, Sheiks and Clerics
description: Iraqi exile leaders, tribal sheiks, ethnic Kurds and Shiite clerics gathered in a tent near the birthplace of Abraham today and said they would work to create a fully democratic government in Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, THOMAS D.
description: FLYNN-Thomas D. Died on April 12, 2003 at age 90 while on vacation in Puerto Rico. Beloved husband of Harriet Howland for 62 years; father and father-in-law to Susan and Stephen Gordon, Christine Flynn and Paul Segal, and John and Leslie Flynn; grandfather to Alexandra and John Gordon, Hannah, Sayre and Sarah Flynn and Emma Segal. A private interment will be held in Port Washington, New York, on Saturday, April 19th. A Memorial service will be held in Princeton, N.J. at The Princeton University Chapel on May 3rd at 11am.

title: Peaches Coaxed From the Sand
description: LAST summer as I was visiting a date farm in this scruffy Coachella Desert community three hours southeast of Los Angeles, my jaw dropped at an incongruous vision across the road: an orchard of young peach trees braving the 120-degree heat, looking as out of place as a grapefruit grove in New York.

title: French Threaten Expulsions After Muslim Militants Win
description: France's interior minister threatened today to expel any Muslim religious leader considered extremist after a fundamentalist Muslim organization unexpectedly won a large number of seats in an election for the country's first national council of Muslims.

title: Charles H. Bell, 95, Executive Who Led General Mills' Growth
description: Charles H. Bell, the son of the founder of General Mills, who helped transform a flour-milling company into an international diversified food manufacturer, died on Saturday in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 95.

title: Getting Serious Might Spoil the Quest for 'the Ultimate'
description: In ''Bulletproof Monk'' Chow Yun-Fat and Seann William Scott are a multicultural, multigenerational mentor-and-protg team uniting to prevent a precious Tibetan text called the Scroll of the Ultimate from falling into the wrong hands, which in this case are the hands of a very nasty Nazi (Karel Roden) who still dreams of world domination. I doubt there is much more I can say that will influence your opinion of this movie, which opens nationwide today. There are, generally speaking, two kinds of people in the modern film audience: those who care about defending the Scroll of the Ultimate and those who don't.

title: Once Sweet and Heavy, Now Dry and Desirable
description: IT was not so long ago that kosher wines ranked right up there with Jgermeister and Coors Light on the quality scale. They were as sweet as Cherry Coke and about as complex. And those kosher wines that did try to break the mold were rough around the edges at best.

title: Stores, Go-Karts and Skiing, Together in Spain
description: Madrid's version of Xanadu, which shares the name of the stately pleasure dome decreed by Kubla Khan and imagined by Coleridge, is a vast shopping mall under construction by America's Mills Corporation and Spanish partners that aims to seduce shoppers into spending money on fun as well as consumer goods.

description: AGE did not mellow Michael Jordan; it disillusioned him as he scoured every boyish face on the Washington Wizards' roster but failed to see himself in any of their eyes.

title: Nassau Chief Asks to Prepare For Layoffs
description: The Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, has told department heads to prepare to lay off 642 employees, including 278 from the Nassau Police Department, in an effort to close a $138 million budget gap for 2004.

title: Marines Again Kill Iraqis In Exchange of Fire in Mosul
description: The first few rounds of rifle fire barely seemed to faze the burly American marine standing behind the barbed wire. He glanced over his shoulder and continued his conversation with a visitor.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Pipeline Financing
description: Japan reiterated that it is prepared to invest $1 billion to help finance a Russian oil pipeline that would stretch from the Siberian city of Angarsk to Nakhodka, on Russia's eastern coast. The Russian news agency Itar-Tass quoted Yoshiro Kamata, president of the Japan National Oil Corporation, as saying the financing would pay for the construction of an oil terminal and an oil refinery. Japan has been lobbying the Russian government to build the pipeline from Siberia east to the Pacific Ocean. Another proposal would set the route south to China, at half the cost. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Journal's Closing Spells End Of an Era
description: Partisan Review, the quarterly journal of culture and politics that emerged from the ideological ferment of the 1930's to become the house organ for a generation of brilliant American intellectuals and writers, is ceasing publication after 66 years. The journal's final issue, a tribute to its co-founder and editor in chief, William Phillips, who died in September at 94, is being mailed to subscribers this week.

title: FAO ASKS TO CLOSE STORES IF FINANCING ISN'T FOUND
description: FAO, owner of the F. A. O. Schwarz and Zany Brainy toy store chains, has asked a bankruptcy judge for permission to close its remaining 158 stores, including its flagship outlet on Fifth Avenue, unless the company can find financing, court papers say. FAO said Monday that investors offering to buy $30 million in stock backed out after ''unexpected complications'' with a $77 million loan package. FAO's reorganization plan hinges on the transaction and requires it to complete financing by tomorrow. Judge Lloyd King was scheduled to hear the request today at Federal Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. FAO operated 253 stores when it filed for Chapter 11 protection in January and won court permission to close 95.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Drug Maker's Profit Falls
description: Akzo Nobel, the largest Dutch drug maker, said first-quarter profit fell 41 percent as the antidepressant Remeron lost sales to cheaper generics and the company had job-cutting costs. Net income fell to 139 million euros ($150 million) from 234 million euros for the period a year earlier, the company said. Akzo's chief financial officer, Fritz Froehlich, said profit might drop 20 percent this year, in part as generics erode sales of Remeron, which brought in about a fifth of 2002 pharmaceutical revenue. All of Akzo's biggest pharmaceutical lines posted lower first-quarter sales and two new drugs have been delayed.

title: An Art Center Left in Ashes
description: Amal al-Khedairy stood amid the ruins of her elegant waterfront home and cursed the people who had rained the bombs on her.

description: April 16, 2003

title: A Hard-Wired Baroque Lights Up Milan Show
description: THERE were cabbage roses in the land of molded plastics last week at the annual Milan furniture fair. Swank minimalism was still in evidence, of course, but it was the blowzy prints and shiny crystal chandeliers that caught the eye.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILK, ARTHUR E.
description: WILK-Arthur E., 79. Died April 13, 2003 in Sarasota, FL. Founder of Arthur E. Wilk Advertising, Chicago. Survivors include wife Carole, three children and three grandsons.

title: Before Lightning Can Strike, a Sky Watcher Pulls the Plug
description: SUMMER thunderstorms will be here soon, and with them the inevitable lightning that can fry a modem, PC or home entertainment system.

description: NEWARK, April 16  One day after supporters of the state-appointed schools superintendent won a resounding victory in elections for the school advisory board, the state's education commissioner announced today that the superintendent's only rival for the job had withdrawn his name from consideration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, THOMAS D.
description: FLYNN-Thomas D. The President and Trustees of Columbia University express deep sorrow at the passing of our Trustee Emeritus, Thomas D. Flynn, a graduate of the Columbia Business School, Class of 1939. He was a respected colleague whose leadership as a University Trustee was marked by enthusiasm and distinction. Columbia University extends its profound sympathy to his wife Mrs. Harriet Flynn and their family. Lee C. Bollinger, President of the University David J. Stern, Chair of the Trustees

title: White Sox Tighten Security After a New Field Incident
description: Following the second on-field incident of fan violence at their ballpark in seven months, the Chicago White Sox beefed up security tonight at U.S. Cellular Field. Major League Baseball, meanwhile, said it would review security at all stadiums, though it will be up to the individual stadiums to implement changes.

title: Sharon at Passover
description: One year ago, Jews at their Seder meal were stunned to learn that Arab terrorists had massacred 29 of their brethren assembling for remembrance of the Israelites' escape from slavery. Fast-forward to this year's Passover: Jews recounting the exodus from Pharaoh's Egypt are reminded that 22 million Iraqis have just been freed from a modern tyrant's bondage.

title: Merrill's Earnings Increase on Strength in Bond Business
description: Merrill Lynch yesterday became the latest Wall Street firm to announce strong results in the midst of a stock market drought. Driven by the robust environment for trading and underwriting bonds, Merrill recorded earnings of $685 million for the first quarter of this year, up 6 percent from the period last year.

title: Strikes in the East
Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Boy Killed In Fall From Window
description: A toddler died yesterday after falling from a 17th-floor window, the police said. The boy, who the police said was 2, fell from the window of a large apartment building at 175 First Street at 5:46 p.m., and was pronounced dead at 6:13 p.m. at University Hospital, said Lt. Derek Glenn. The death appeared to be accidental, he said, adding that the boy was being cared for by an aunt at his grandmother's apartment, and that the window he fell from had a window guard on it. The police did not release the child's name. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Extradited On Ecstasy Smuggling Charge
description: The head of what prosecutors called the biggest known Ecstasy-smuggling organization was arraigned yesterday in federal court on drug and conspiracy charges after his extradition from Spain to New York. The man, Oded Tuito, 41, an Israeli citizen, was indicted in Brooklyn in 1999 while he was living in France, but was able to fight extradition from there and then from Spain until several weeks ago, prosecutors said. Prosecutors said that Mr. Tuito's organization has brought millions of Ecstasy tablets from Paris, Brussels and Frankfurt to New York, Miami and Los Angeles, employing strippers, Hasidic students and mentally retarded people as couriers. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: U.S. Generals Meet in Palace, Sealing Victory
description: Gen. Tommy R. Franks, commander of America's war on Iraq, sealed his victory today by convening a meeting of his top allied land, air, naval and special-operations officers in what was once one of Saddam Hussein's proudest palaces, now a symbol of his vanished grip on the country.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Retailer Investigated
description: The public prosecutor in the Netherlands said he had begun an investigation into the Dutch retail giant Royal Ahold after the Feb. 24 disclosure of accounting irregularities. It is the first time Dutch justice authorities have confirmed they are investigating Ahold, though a spokesman for the public prosecutor's office would not disclose the extent nor the nature of the investigation. ''We have received some papers from Ahold and we are looking into them,'' the spokesman said.

title: Loss Serves as Warm-Up for the Main Event: Kidd vs. Payton
description: From the Oakland playgrounds, from West to East, Jason Kidd and Gary Payton have challenged each other with the fierce pride of student and teacher, refusing to relent on their likely roads to the Hall of Fame.

title: El Paso Group Plans to Wave Flag High in Honor of Troops
description: Saying they want to honor soldiers killed and taken prisoner in Iraq, restaurant owners here announced today that they would begin an effort to collect $400,000 to build the nation's tallest flagpole at nearby Fort Bliss.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Holy Thursday, Good Friday and the first two days of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Dead Bouncer's Kin and Friends Protest Inquiry's Lack of Progress
description: Friends, family and neighbors of a bouncer who died after a scuffle over the city's new smoking laws held a heated rally last night. Speakers accused the city of stalling the investigation and going easy on three siblings who were arrested and then released.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Schools Superintendent To Keep Job
description: A day after supporters of the state-appointed schools superintendent won elections for the school advisory board, the state's education commissioner announced yesterday that the superintendent's only rival for the job had withdrawn his name from consideration. Commissioner William L. Librera said he would recommend to the State Board of Education that Superintendent Marion Bolden remain at the helm of the district, which has been under state control since 1995, for three more years. David L. Snead, the superintendent of schools in Waterbury, Conn., and the advisory board's choice to head the district, has decided to remain in that post, Mr. Librera said. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: U.S. May Punish Cuba for Imprisoning Critics
description: The Bush administration is considering a series of steps to punish the Cuban government for its recent crackdown on dissidents, officials said today.

description: Representatives of Women's National Basketball Association players will sit down with management today in a bargaining session that may determine whether the league will play this season and whether it will stay in business.

description: The $44.5 billion best-case budget proposal that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled on Tuesday calls for thousands of layoffs and cuts in services. This is a look at how it would affect various areas.

title: Columbia Panel Urges More Photos of Shuttle Missions
description: HOUSTON, April 17  Before space shuttles return to flight, NASA needs to develop better ways to inspect its aging fleet and ensure that pictures of the shuttles are taken during every mission, the independent board investigating the loss of the shuttle Columbia said today.

title: U.S. Bombs Iranian Guerrilla Forces Based in Iraq
description: American forces have bombed the bases of the main armed Iranian opposition group in Iraq, a guerrilla organization that maintained thousands of fighters with tanks and artillery along Iraq's border with Iran for more than a decade.

description: We are in the midst of a reader's dream, a publicist's nightmare and a best-seller logjam.

title: Sweet Dreams In a Bed Of Folk Art
description: The Museum of International Folk Art in Santa Fe, N.M., is known for its Mexican and South American folk pieces from Alexander Girard. But other textiles in the collection include an 1827 Swedish homespun, probably for a wedding. The designer Leigh Chandler enlarged its crewelwork floral motif and backed the velvet with a Fortuny print; queen-size duvet cover, $350. The sham's dobby stripe border comes from a Bolivian poncho, $65 in jute-cotton. This summer at the Down Quilt Shop, 518 Columbus Avenue (85th Street); (212) 496-8980.

title: A Job for Unesco
description: How do we repair the damage done? The meeting to be convened today by Unesco, the United Nations' cultural arm, is a good start. But it is only a start. The United States should ask the secretary general to give Unesco temporary responsibility for the historic sites and museums of Iraq. The United Nations should also convene a meeting of donor nations to establish a fund to deal with the crisis.

title: After a Long Climb, Cyberchat on Everest
description: TSERING GYALTSEN was devastated when a partner advised him over a month ago to give up on his dream of building a cybercafe this year at Mount Everest's base camp in Nepal because the bureaucracy was even more daunting than the technology.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Accused Of Impersonating a Lawyer
description: A Manhattan man has been accused of posing as a lawyer and telling people he could get parking summonses dismissed, the Department of Investigation announced yesterday. The man, Jose Diaz, 49, would promise to represent people at their hearings for a fee, take their money, but not show up at the hearings, the department said. He was arrested yesterday at the Manhattan Business Center on John Street, where people pay their parking tickets, and will be charged with perjury and criminal possession of a forged instrument -- fraudulent identification -- the department said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: ADVANCED MICRO POSTS WIDER FIRST-QUARTER LOSS Advanced Micro Devices , the computer chip maker, reported a wider first-quarter loss yesterday even as microprocessor sales improved and the company significantly reduced expenses. For the three months that ended on March 30, the company lost $146 million, or 42 cents a share, compared with a loss of $9.2 million, or 3 cents a share, in the same period last year. Excluding one-time items, the company lost $144 million, or 42 cents a share. Sales were down nearly 21 percent, to $715 million, in the first quarter of 2003 in contrast to sales of $902 million in the first quarter of 2002. Still, the results beat analysts' expectations of a loss of 48 cents on sales of $683.2 million, according to a survey by Thomson First Call. The results were announced after markets closed yesterday. Shares gained 30 cents, to close at $7.90 in regular trading. In after-hours trading, shares lost 9 cents. (AP)

title: A Study of Corporate Pension Funds Shows Many Assumed Outsize Gains
description: The first comprehensive examination of the pension funds of the nation's biggest corporations shows that nearly half made assumptions about their investment returns for 2002 that would be deemed too aggressive by federal regulators, starting this year.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a decision by Peter Fitzgerald, Republican of Illinois, against seeking re-election to the Senate misstated a position he took on a gun control measure, alienating other Republicans. He voted for it, not against it.

title: As War Ebbs, History, Hope and Fury
description: This is a story of a book, the chronicle of the violence done to this city under Saddam Hussein.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about plans by Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg to auction art owned by Enron misstated a term of the arrangement with the company. The auction house says there is no guarantee on a minimum amount to be raised.

title: Census Estimates Show Drop in Manhattan
description: The first estimates of population trends in New York City in the wake of the terrorist attacks of 2001 and after the onset of the recession suggest that either fewer people are moving into Manhattan from other parts of the country or more people are moving out -- or perhaps a combination of both.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN G.
description: COHEN-Norman G. Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Norman Cohen, beloved father of Nancy Roberts. We extend our deepest condolences to Nancy and her family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: J.P. Morgan's Net Up 43%, Aided by Low Interest Rates
description: J. P. Morgan Chase reported stronger-than-expected earnings yesterday, as low interest rates led to record mortgage refinancings and robust bond trading profits.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: BRIDGESTONE TO SELL BONDS The Bridgestone Corporation , Asia's largest tire maker, plans to sell bonds, a company official said, its first debt offering since a recall of 6.5 million tires linked to fatal accidents in the United States. The company, based in Tokyo, will probably sell 50 billion yen ($415 million) to 100 billion yen of bonds maturing in 7 to 10 years, bankers said. In Bridgestone's last debt offering, in February 2000, it sold 20 billion yen of 7-year bonds and 30 billion yen of 10-year bonds. Bridgestone is taking advantage of record-low government bond yields to sell its first debt since the 2000 recall, which cut profit and sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHN, KEITH R.
description: JOHN-Keith R., 51, of Effort, PA. died April 15. Survived by partner, Everette Dawson; brothers, Henry and Thomas. Memorial gathering is on Saturday, April 19, at 3PM at Keith and Everette's home. Contributions to the Monroe Animal League, P.O. Box 23, Stroudsburg, PA. 18360.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Tuesday about Roy Williams's decision to leave Kansas and take the head basketball coaching job at North Carolina referred incompletely to his standing among coaches who have won 400 games. Ranked by the number of seasons it took him, he was the fastest to win 400; ranked by the number of games it took, he was the fourth-fastest.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: HINDU HARD-LINER HELD The Hindu fundamentalist leader Praveen Togadia, arrested on Sunday for distributing tridents  the three-pronged weapon associated with the Hindu god Shiva  was denied bail by a court in Rajasthan. The state is governed by India's main opposition Congress Party; Mr. Togadia is general secretary of the World Hindu Council, allied with the Bharatiya Janata Party. He is charged with making inflammatory speeches and violating a ban on distributing tridents, and faces a possible life sentence. Rajasthan classified the trident as a dangerous weapon last week, in response to a campaign by the Hindu Council in which thousands of the implements have been distributed. The Congress Party contends that tridents were used by rioters last year in Gujarat state. (Agence France-Presse)

title: U.S. Forces Capture Hussein's Half-Brother
description: DOHA, Qatar, April 17  Marines and Special Operations forces early today captured Barzan Ibrahim Hasan al-Tikriti, a half-brother of Saddam Hussein, in Baghdad, the United States Central Command announced.

title: North Korea Blinks
description: Brinkmanship has given way to diplomacy in North Korea, and not a moment too soon. Instead of opening a nuclear bomb production line while the United States was preoccupied by Iraq, North Korea unexpectedly agreed to meet next week in Beijing with American and Chinese diplomats to talk about ending the North's nuclear weapons programs. The negotiations will not be easy, but the mere fact that they have been arranged suggests it may still be possible to induce North Korea to abandon its reckless pursuit of nuclear bombs.

title: Mild Weather and Low Rates Bring Surge in Home Building
description: Housing construction grew 8.3 percent in March, almost twice as much as economists had forecast, spurred by low mortgage rates and warmer weather.

description: IN the latest salvo in the battle over liquor and beer advertising, a new commercial this week encourages people to feel free to have a drink before driving home.

title: City Council Weighs a Budget of Its Own
description: In a sign of its distaste for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's budget, the New York City Council is considering the rare step of passing its own budget, though details have not been determined.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Boy Sentenced In Beating Death
description: A boy who beat a schoolmate to death with a baseball bat during an argument over $20 has been sentenced in State Supreme Court to up to nine years in a juvenile facility, the authorities said yesterday. The attacker, Randy Rosario of Ridgewood, was 15 and in the eighth grade at Intermediate School 77 in Ridgewood when he attacked Bryan Rivera near the school on Jan. 14. Now 16, the boy pleaded guilty to intentional manslaughter on March 14. Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said the boy was prosecuted as an adult but sentenced under juvenile offender guidelines. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

She was employed with the law firm of Parker, Harrison and Dietz in Sarasota, Florida. She was a veteran of U.S. Marines WW II. Survived by one niece, Martha B. Tart, of West Keansburg, N.J. Memorial donations to Hospice of S/W Florida, 5955 Rand Boulevard, Sarasota, FL. 34238. For more info Toale Brothers Funeral Home, Sarasota, FL.

title: Samuel J. LeFrak, Master of Mass Housing, Dies at 85
description: Samuel J. LeFrak, an outspoken champion of middle-income housing who headed the family company that produced it in and around New York City more plentifully than any other builder in the years since World War II, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.

description: REINER - Elaine, actress, died on Monday, April 14th. Daughter of (late) Harry and Emma Oshrin, sister of (late) Albert Oshrin, wife of (late) Manny Reiner and of (late) Hal Eaton. Survived by her sister Evelyn (Pat) Glazer, brother-in-law Irving Glazer, six nieces and nephews, nine great-nieces and nephews, and longtime companion Herman Liebmann. Services 11:30 AM, Sunday April 20th at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Visitation from 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Actors Fund of America, 729 7th Ave., NYC 10019.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: CHESHIRE: BABY SITTER ACCUSED OF ABUSE A baby sitter has been charged for a second time with sexually assaulting a child in her care. The worker, Janice Alspaugh, 53, was charged on Tuesday with two counts of fourth-degree sexual assault and two counts of risk of injury to a minor whom the police said was a 5-year-old girl. In December, Ms. Alspaugh was charged with sexually assaulting a 3-year-old girl under her care. She has pleaded not guilty in that case. On the most recent charges, Ms. Alspaugh was released on a promise to appear in State Superior Court in Meriden on April 23. (AP)

Nor could Mr. Kareem have known that in bringing together fellow Iraqi expatriates online, he would be planting the seeds of a political movement.

description: Gen. Tommy R. Franks, the commander of allied forces in Iraq, met with his top officers inside one of President Saddam Hussein's palaces in Baghdad, marking a symbolic end to the war four weeks after it began. With the Mr. Hussein's government dismantled, President Bush asked the United Nations to lift economic sanctions on Iraq. At home, a decrease in the level of credible threats led the government to lower the terrorism alert by one level, to yellow.

description: Two police officers yesterday fatally shot a Queens man who was carrying what looked like a pistol but was actually a pellet gun, the police said.

description: PITT-Jane Ries. Died peacefully on April 16, 2003, at age 64. Predeceased by her husband Martin Pitt, she is survived by her loving children Jennifer and Eric.
