title: Chief Ousted At Skandia Amid Tumult
description: Unswayed by Lars-Eric Petersson's offer to work for just 1 Swedish krona (12 American cents) for the rest of the year, Skandia, the Swedish financial services company, dismissed him today as chief executive and brought Leif Victorin, a former deputy chief executive, out of retirement to head the company until a permanent replacement can be found.

title: Jordan Bows Out for a Third Time
description: Michael Jordan, 40 years of age and favoring crafty head fakes and jump shots rather than the acrobatic dunks and astounding hang time that made him famous, ended his storied playing career tonight. Jordan, widely regarded as the greatest basketball player ever, headed into retirement for the third and presumably last time after his Washington Wizards lost, 107-87, to the Philadelphia 76ers at the First Union Center.

title: Experts to Send Team to Iraq in Wake of Museum Looting
description: PARIS, April 17  An international group of archaeologists and museum directors decided today to send an emergency fact-finding mission to Iraq to measure the damage done to the Baghdad Museum and other cultural institutions in the looting that followed the end of open hostilities.

title: British Inquiry Links Ulster Murders to Security Forces
description: LONDON, April 17  Officers from British Army intelligence and the Royal Ulster Constabulary in Northern Ireland actively helped Protestant guerrillas murder Catholics in the late 1980's, a report by Britain's senior police official said today.

title: As Japan Struggles, Pachinko Evolves
description: Chang-Woo Han has never had it so good. As Japan, the world's second-largest economy, struggles to regain its footing, his business, running the country's largest chain of pachinko parlors, is growing by leaps and bounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVELLE, JOHN
description: LAVELLE-John, 82, formerly of Bayside and Easthampton, NY in Winter Park, Fl, April 9, 2003. Born in Ireland 1920. Beloved husband, father, brother, uncle, grandfather, great-grandfather. Interment in Winter Park. Requiescat in pace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOVE, BRETT J.
description: LOVE-Brett J., 41. On April 12 in Los Angeles after a courageous battle with cancer. A professor, writer and filmmaker, he is survived by his loving wife, Laura Chavez Silverman, his mother and stepfather Yveta Synek Graff and F. Malcolm Graff of New York, father Robert L. Love of Sante Fe, brother Steven and sister-in-law Jeanie, nephew Chase Graff Love, extended family, friends and students. A graduate of AllenStevenson, St. Paul's School, Stanford University and USC Film School, Brett taught writing in the Humanities Division at Pepperdine University, specializing in film and popular culture. Memorial Service Saturday 1 PM, Pepperdine University Chapel. Contributions in his name may be made to Pepperdine University, Malibu, CA.

title: On the Ground in Iraq, the Best Compass Is in the Sky
description: ON an afternoon early this month, in the desert near Najaf, Iraq, elements of an elite United States Army unit received word of a column of almost 60 vehicles, including about two dozen tanks, moving along a nearby road.

title: Caring Intensively for Her Wounded Neighborhood
description: A CRUEL circumstance, in the form of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack that scarred her neighborhood, scared away many of her neighbors and devastated her then-fledgling restaurant, Vine, has rendered Julie Menin a bit of a human phoenix. For her, the ashes of the tragedy are the foundation for an improved downtown. Ms. Menin, who lives and works at 25 Broad Street -- and is the only downtown resident on the 13-member jury that will adjudicate the ground zero memorial competition -- is a futurist, and hers is a one-track mind.

title: Filibustering Priscilla Owen
description: Senators opposing Priscilla Owen, a nominee to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, are considering a filibuster to head off her confirmation vote. Filibusters are an extreme measure in which a minority of senators block an issue from being voted on. But the system for picking judges, which should be a relatively nonpartisan effort to seat jurists who reflect broad American values, has broken down. Filibustering Judge Owen's confirmation would send the Bush administration two important messages: the president must stop packing the courts with ideologues, and he must show more respect for the Senate's role.

title: Sakharov's Widow Opposes Moscow's Plan to Build Monument
description: A long-delayed proposal to erect a monument here to Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident who became the icon of resistance to Soviet oppression in the 1970's, has run into formidable opposition from an unlikely source: Mr. Sakharov's widow, Yelena Bonner.

title: Showcase for Innovation at Fair's Edge
description: AMONG the 26 buildings that house the furniture fair, one cavernous hall is the site of the Salone Satellite. In its sixth year, the Satellite mixes new designers (hoping to have their work picked up by manufacturers) with some that are more established (exhibiting more experimental works-in-progress). Design schools also come to show off student projects. The atmosphere is more relaxed than in the rest of the fair, although the stakes are still high.

title: An Industry Under Constant Scrutiny
description: With little fanfare, European authorities have conducted one investigation after another into anticompetitive behavior in the chemical industry. A dozen inquiries have now come to light over the last four years, with one previously unreported investigation already near completion and another just beginning.

title: Glenn Savan, 49, the Author of 'White Palace'
description: Glenn Savan, whose popular first novel, ''White Palace'' (1987), was about a St. Louis waitress's mismatched romance with an ad man, died on Monday at his home in Shrewsbury, Mo. He was 49.

On Thursday, the second day of press conferences before the public opening of the 2003 New York International Auto Show, that strategy is evident in more than a few of the vehicles unveiled at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Among the design features that seem to be getting an encore is the hatchback body style, essentially a rear liftgate that melds the trunk lid and rear glass to create a wide load opening and easy access to the cargo area.

title: Bush Takes No-Budge Stand In Talks With North Korea
description: President Bush has instructed the team that will negotiate with North Korea that the United States will not settle for another freeze on the country's nuclear program. Instead, senior administration officials said today, Washington will insist that the North dismantle both of its major nuclear weapons projects as part of any larger bargain with the United States.

They're incorporating elements of sketch and stand-up comedy and hoping to parlay their acts into feature films and Broadway musicals rather than arena tours. Last week the comedian and songwriter Stephen Lynch was profiled in this column. Here are three other very different up-and-coming artists who blur the border between music and comedy.

Instead the festival has substituted a more familiar play, ''As You Like It,'' in a compact rendering at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, performed with enthusiasm by a sprightly, fresh-faced ensemble.

title: So Real, and Yet So Inedible
description: Few plants are indestructible; here is one not even readily biodegradable. The Sprouted Taro Root, 17 inches tall, is the latest in artificial foliage. Juvenile leaves unfurl above a cast-resin, flat-bottomed base. Because the base is moistureproof, it can be submerged in water, or set on a dish of smooth pebbles or, for a postmodern look, just placed right on the coffee table. $12.25 at Pany Silk Flowers, 146 West 28th Street (Seventh Avenue); (212) 645-9526.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Tuesday about Roy Williams's decision to leave Kansas and take the head basketball coaching job at North Carolina referred incompletely to his standing among coaches who have won 400 games. Ranked by the number of seasons it took him, he was the fastest to win 400; ranked by the number of games it took, he was the fourth-fastest.

title: A Water Plant in the Bronx
description: Reviving one of his predecessor's most controversial proposals, Mayor Michael Bloomberg is asking Albany's permission to build a $1.3 billion water filtration plant in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. A similar plan failed three years ago because Rudolph Giuliani's administration did not fully consult with local residents or ask for legislative approval, as required by law. Mr. Bloomberg has promised to play by the rules. He is also offering Bronx residents $200 million for improvements to Van Cortlandt Park and other open spaces in the borough. This strikes us as a win-win deal for all concerned, worthy of Albany's support.

title: Taming an Untamed Rocker
description: The phrase ''keeping it real'' and all that it suggests certainly applies to Baby Jane Dexter, a longtime cabaret performer whose booming pop contralto is one of the more formidable voices on the New York nightclub stage.

title: A City Budget, and the Cries of Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Questions About Investor On Board of HealthSouth
description: A banner slogan on the Web site of the company founded by C. Sage Givens reads, ''Connecting with the right people makes all the difference.''

title: Rolling Hills Journal; Adultery May Be a Sin, But It's a Crime No More
description: When Richard C. Colyear was looking for ways to encourage the local City Council to prune outdated and irrelevant legislation from the Rolling Hills municipal code, he knew he had found the perfect argument in Section IX on ''immoral conduct.''

title: The Knotty Problem of Syria
description: To the Editor:

title: Backstage Pass to the Royal Opera
description: The nimble Bridge of Aspiration, a new pedestrian overpass four floors above the street, gives students of the Royal Ballet Academy in London direct backstage access to the Royal Opera House. ''It was annoying for them to go through security when they wanted to cross the lane,'' said the designer Jim Eyre of Wilkinson Eyre Architects in London. The slightly inclined structure was inspired by Eadweard Muybridge's time-lapse photography, which displayed multiple views of a figure in motion. The bridge is composed of 23 identical aluminum and oak frames with glass panels. Because each frame has been rotated 4 degrees, the glass roof at one end becomes a glass sidewall at the other. Handrails modeled on ballet barres, and the wooden floor, further allude to dance. The bridge, which is visible from the sidewalk but not accessible to the public, is at 46 Floral Street, in Covent Garden. Wilkinson Eyre can be reached at 011-44-207-608-7900.

title: Schools, Museums, Clinics, Trash: Spending Cuts Go All Around
description: The $44.5 billion best-case budget proposal that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled on Tuesday calls for thousands of layoffs and cuts in services. This is a look at how it would affect various areas.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Suspects Deny Killing Girls
description: A school caretaker pleaded not guilty to murdering two 10-year-old girls whose killings last summer horrified Britain and provoked a debate about whether the death penalty should be reinstated. The bodies of the girls, Jessica Chapman and Holly Wells, were found in a ditch last August, two weeks after they were seen walking together in their hometown, Soham, in eastern England. The caretaker, Ian Hunter, 29, pleaded guilty to a charge of conspiring to pervert the course of justice. Mr. Hunter's girlfriend, Maxine Carr, 26, pleaded not guilty to charges of helping an offender and perverting the course of justice. Their trial is to start Oct. 6. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit Falls At Reuters
description: The news and information provider Reuters Group reported a 10 percent decline in first-quarter earnings to 670 million ($91 billion) and warned that full-year revenue could be as much as 12 percent lower than last year as cash-short banks cut back on the number of terminals carrying financial data from Reuters. The company, which has cut 3,000 jobs over the last two years, plans to cut 3,000 more by 2006. Reuters also said it increased market share by two percentage points, to 39 percent, last year, despite analysts' concern that it is losing out to rivals like Bloomberg News. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

title: Knicks Dream Of Life In Playoffs
description: They cleared out their lockers and scattered for the summer, an early departure for the second season in a row. But as they filed out, each of the Knicks maintained a hope that when they convene here again in October, the same group will return for another shot at the postseason.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 6 about the objection of residents near the Brooklyn Bridge to New York City's plans to move the Office of Emergency Management's headquarters to 165 Cadman Plaza East misstated the current and planned uses for the three-story building there. A letter from residents, dated March 17 and delayed in reaching the editors, points out that the building is vacant; it is not being used by the American Red Cross. Under the plans, the building would not become the headquarters; it would be demolished and replaced by a larger one.

title: The Auditors' Auditor
description: After the Enron and WorldCom accounting scandals battered investors' confidence in corporate America's integrity, Congress rightly concluded that the nation could no longer afford to have the accounting industry police itself. Last year, it created the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, a government entity charged with setting standards for auditors to follow, as well as with reviewing their work and disciplining those who betray the public trust.

title: Bush's Next Test
description: As he turns his attention from the war to the economy, President Bush is confronting a reality that many of his predecessors, including his father, faced: a president cannot do all that much to strengthen the economy so it is strong for his re-election.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deli Owner Held In Money Transfer
description: A delicatessen owner accused of illegally transferring more than $650,000 to the West Bank and Jordan was ordered held without bond yesterday by a federal judge. The defendant, Alaa Odeh, 30, who owns a delicatessen on Staten Island, was found by the judge to be a flight risk. An indictment charges that at least $100,000 sent by Mr. Odeh was laundered for an Illinois narcotics trafficker. A federal prosecutor told Judge John S. Martin Jr. of Federal District Court that Mr. Odeh had the means and motive to flee to the Middle East, where he has relatives. Mr. Odeh has pleaded not guilty. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Jacques Torres
description: Following his participation in the TimesTalks series on March 8, Jacques Torres, the pastry chef, answered NYTimes.com readers' questions on Easter and Passover desserts.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ex-Chief Financial Officer Of WorldCom Is Indicted

title: Robert C. Atkins, 72, Creator of Controversial Diet, Dies
description: Dr. Robert C. Atkins, a cardiologist who devised a hotly debated weight-loss plan favoring steak and eggs over spaghetti and spinach that more than 30 million Americans have tried, died yesterday in Manhattan. He was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, BERNARD Z.
description: STEIN-Bernard Z. On April 15, 2003 in his 90th year, of complications from prostate cancer. Loving husband of Marion, father of Ellen (Howard) and Rob (Mara), grandfather of Andrew (Stephanie), David, Laura, Reyna and Bart. He was loved by family and friends, and his warmth and his smile will be deeply missed by all. Funeral services private. Because he was active in many philanthropic activities, the family requests in lieu of flowers contributions to the charity of your choice.

title: The Knotty Problem of Syria
description: To the Editor:

title: Administration Reduces Level of Terrorism Alert to Yellow, Citing the Fall of Hussein
description: The Bush administration lowered the color-coded terrorism alert level today but said it was still worried that agents of Saddam Hussein might try to conduct terrorist attacks against American targets.

title: Some Work Is Shifted For Cigarette Brands
description: British American Tobacco in London has shuffled worldwide assignments among its roster agencies for cigarette brands like Lucky Strike and Pall Mall.

title: Fleet Suspends Stock Specialist
description: A specialist for the FleetBoston Financial Corporation on the New York Stock Exchange has been suspended for trading irregularities in shares of General Electric, according to a person briefed in the investigation.

title: A Nation at War
description: In Iraq

title: New Charges Against Ex-WorldCom Executive
description: Scott D. Sullivan, the former chief financial officer of WorldCom whose accounting maneuvers plunged the company into scandal, was indicted yesterday on additional federal charges that accuse him of defrauding a series of banks out of billions of dollars.

title: New Labor Realities
description: The airline unions had to swallow the bitter medicine sooner or later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEND, DAVID J.
description: KEND-David J. Of Boca Raton, FL and New York City, died on April 15. Loving husband of Joan; father of Robert and Peter; father-inlaw of Katherine and Diane and grandfather of Sydney, Alyssa and Samuel Kend. He is also survived by his sister Connie and brother-in-law Albert Eisenstat of Atherton, CA and his niece Melissa Blau and nephew Michael Eisenstat. A funeral service will be held at Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, 7240 N. Federal Hwy, Boca Raton, at 11AM, Friday, April 18. Interment is at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, 130-04 Horace Harding Blvd, NYC at 10:30AM, Sunday, April 20. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Boca Raton Hospital for the David J. Kend Fund.

title: The Death of a Connecticut Marine Is Confirmed
description: In the last letter his family received, Cpl. Kemaphoom Chanawongse joked that his camp in Kuwait reminded him of the one on the sitcom M*A*S*H -- except that he would rename his MAHTSF, for Marines Are Here to Stay Forever.

title: Throw a Coin and Hear a Splash: City Fills Its Fountains
description: As New Yorkers optimistically began packing away sweaters and retrieving air-conditioners from winter storage, city officials engaged in a springtime ritual of their own yesterday: turning on the fountains that have been dry since the fall of 2001.

title: Old Ship's New Life
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Considers Indicting Terrorist Arrested in Iraq On Achille Lauro Murder
description: The Bush administration today explored ways of bringing charges against Abu Abbas, the Palestinian terrorist captured in Iraq, withholding judgment about whether to turn him over to Italy and rejecting Palestinian demands for his release.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMER, BERNARD
description: PALMER - Bernard. NYC, born April 22, 1917, died April 15, 2003. Husband of Marcia, father and grandfather of Michael and Diane Palmer (Dana), Robert & Sandee Palmer (Cary and Lori, Mindy), Diane and Buddy Slateman (Jennie, Sadie). ''He is leaving but the fighter still remains.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUMEREAU, EUGENE J.
description: SUMEREAU-Eugene J. of Demarest, NJ on April 16, 2003. Beloved husband of Jane (nee Nicholson). Devoted father of Christopher, Andrew, Paul, Timothy, Peter and the late Eugene. Loving grandfather of nine. Friends may call at Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ on Saturday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. No visitation on Easter Sunday. Funeral Mass on Monday 10 AM St. Joseph RC Church Demarest, NJ. Interment Maryrest Cemetery Mahwah, NJ. For directions you may visit us at www. barrettfuneralhome.net

title: EMC Posts Profit but Says Its Customers Remain Wary
description: EMC, the largest independent vendor in the business data storage industry, joined other major technology companies yesterday in reporting solid results for the first quarter. It announced that it had returned to profitability after more than a year struggling to cut costs and update its products.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We are busy trying to educate people, but the worried mind doesn't always hear.''

title: A Fence to Deny A Deer Its Dinner
description: AFTER 18 years trying to keep deer out of their fragrant native azaleas, succulent gooseberries and young magnolias, Lynn and Joseph Carbonell have given up on bars of soap, homemade garlic-and-pepper juice, bags of human hair and urine (from coyotes or children). Their three dogs are useless, too.

title: Doormen and Building Owners Push Back Strike Deadline
description: The union representing 28,000 apartment building workers and the association of building owners announced yesterday that they were extending the current three-year contract by two days, moving a strike deadline to next Wednesday, April 23.

title: A Dock Churns Out Pictures and Charges Your Batteries
description: Kodak has long used docks, similar to the cradles pioneered by palmtop computers, to simplify the downloading of digital images from its cameras to PC's. Its latest dock, however, allows users to bypass the computer altogether.

title: Envisioning a Safer City Without Turning It Into Slab City
description: NEW YORK'S public realm is choking behind a collar of concrete.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Telecom Shares Sold
description: Taiwan sold 21 percent of the total shares on offer on the fifth and final day of an auction of a stake in Chunghwa Telecom, the island's former telephone monopoly, after it lowered its minimum acceptable bid by 2 percent. The government sold 103.9 million Chunghwa Telecom shares at an average 49.75 Taiwan dollars a share, raising 5.17 billion Taiwan dollars ($149 million), it said. It earlier set a floor price of 49 Taiwan dollars, which is 1 Taiwan dollar lower than the minimum 50 Taiwan dollars it accepted on the auction's first four days and a 3 percent discount to the stock's closing price.

title: Driving Along a Virtual Road to Recovery
description: STEPHANIE WALL is from California, so driving is practically part of her DNA. It was a given that one day she would slide behind the wheel and zoom off; that's what everybody did.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bridgestone To Sell Bonds
description: The Bridgestone Corporation, Asia's largest tire maker, plans to sell bonds, a company official said, its first debt offering since a recall of 6.5 million tires linked to fatal accidents in the United States. The company, based in Tokyo, will probably sell 50 billion yen ($415 million) to 100 billion yen of bonds maturing in 7 to 10 years, bankers said. In Bridgestone's last debt offering, in February 2000, it sold 20 billion yen of 7-year bonds and 30 billion yen of 10-year bonds. Bridgestone is taking advantage of record-low government bond yields to sell its first debt since the 2000 recall, which cut profit and sales.

title: The Knotty Problem of Syria
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Names Executives
description: In the latest in a series of changes to its senior management, HSBC Holdings named Stuart Gulliver, left, head of global markets, as co-head of its corporate and investment banking division. The bank also announced that it had recruited John Studzinski, formerly vice chairman of Morgan Stanley and one of London's most respected investment bankers, as the other co-head. Analysts said they viewed the appointments as an indication that HSBC intends to build its investment banking business significantly. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

title: Flat Islanders Wilt Early In Losing Again to Ottawa
description: Islanders goaltender Garth Snow barely had time to flinch his left shoulder in an effort to stop the first shot he saw at Nassau Coliseum tonight. It sailed past Snow and wound up in the goal. Twenty-eight seconds had been played.

title: Market Place; Ford's Earnings Double Forecast From Wall Street
description: The Ford Motor Company's efforts to trim its bloated cost structure and revitalize its operations showed signs of progress yesterday as the company reported first-quarter results that were double Wall Street's expectations.

title: Eluding the Web's Snare
description: VICKI LEWIS, a 57-year-old former television producer who lives in Bethesda, Md., inhabits a household filled with Internet users. Her children are on the Internet constantly, as is her husband.

title: Fresh Eyes in Search Of a Few Cool Rooms
description: THERE are seven stories in the Kips Bay Decorator Show House, and as a group of early visitors made their way down the last flight of stairs, they could not shake the sense that something was missing. ''I really wanted to see a master bedroom,'' said Deon Pryce, 19. ''You can get ideas from how they set it up.''

title: An Army for Art
description: The looting of Iraq's national museum in Baghdad could have been prevented. The American and British forces are clearly to blame for the destruction and displacement of its cultural treasures. In fact, late last year, experts and scholars started working with the State and Defense Departments to identify key Iraqi cultural and archaeological sites and to have them removed from lists of potential bombing targets. While the museum was not bombed, troops failed to protect the building and its priceless contents from the chaos that engulfed Baghdad last week.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: DELI OWNER HELD IN MONEY TRANSFER A delicatessen owner accused of illegally transferring more than $650,000 to the West Bank and Jordan was ordered held without bond yesterday by a federal judge. The defendant, Alaa Odeh, 30, who owns a delicatessen on Staten Island, was found by the judge to be a flight risk. An indictment charges that at least $100,000 sent by Mr. Odeh was laundered for an Illinois narcotics trafficker. A federal prosecutor told Judge John S. Martin Jr. of Federal District Court that Mr. Odeh had the means and motive to flee to the Middle East, where he has relatives. Mr. Odeh has pleaded not guilty. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Balenciaga Opens a Shop With That Lived-In Feeling
description: ''Some people think it's unfinished,'' Nicolas Ghesquiere, the head designer for Balenciaga, said of the company's new boutique in Chelsea. He created the store with Dominique Gonzalez-Foerster, a French artist, and both were inspired by the asymmetrical modern gardens of the American landscape architect Garrett Eckbo and the Brazilian landscape gardener Roberto Burle Marx, who worked with Oscar Niemeyer on Brasilia.

title: Cuba Attacks U.N. Proposal on Jailed Dissidents
description: Cuba yesterday denounced a proposed amendment to a United Nations human rights resolution calling for the immediate release of the more than 75 Cuban dissidents imprisoned in recent weeks.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BANK NAMES EXECUTIVES In the latest in a series of changes to its senior management, HSBC Holdings named Stuart Gulliver, left, head of global markets, as co-head of its corporate and investment banking division. The bank also announced that it had recruited John Studzinski, formerly vice chairman of Morgan Stanley and one of London's most respected investment bankers, as the other co-head. Analysts said they viewed the appointments as an indication that HSBC intends to build its investment banking business significantly.

title: STARBUCKS AGREES TO ACQUIRE SEATTLE COFFEE COMPANY
description: Starbucks said yesterday that it had entered into an agreement to acquire the Seattle Coffee Company from AFC Enterprises Inc. for $72 million in cash and stock. Under the deal, Starbucks would own the Seattle's Best and Torrefazione Italia Coffee brands, 129 Seattle's Best coffee shops and 21 Torrefazione coffee shops. The deal was expected to close within 90 days and to reduce the company's earnings by 1 cent in 2003, Starbucks said. Sherri Day (NYT)

title: Putting 'Hip and Cool' Back in Family Films, Lots of Them
description: For one of Hollywood's newer teams, Cary Granat and Michael Flaherty cannot be accused of thinking small.

title: Who'll Blink In Albany?
description: On the surface, Gov. George E. Pataki seems to have adopted the same strategy this year in his battle with the Legislature over the budget that has worked so well for him in years past: refuse to compromise and then hold out until the political pressure on legislators to act builds to an intolerable level.

title: Coca-Cola Reports a Profit, But Fails to Sway Investors
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that strong sales of Vanilla Coke and Diet Coke in the first quarter allowed it to reverse course and report earnings despite economic challenges in some places overseas. But a modest growth of 4 percent in worldwide volume disappointed investors, who had been expecting a larger gain.

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: MONTANA: CELEBRATED SALOON CLOSES The M&M Cigar Store in Butte, a saloon that Jack Kerouac described as his ideal bar, closed on Tuesday after filing for bankruptcy. Patrons wept at last call; drinks had been poured round the clock since the bar opened in 1890. "This isn't a young man's joint, and the old-timers are passing away," said Charles Bugni, 78, who leased the business. Kerouac described it in 1970: "What characters in there: old prospectors, gamblers, whores, miners, Indians, cowboys, tobacco-chewing businessmen!" The bar survived Prohibition by proclaiming itself a tobacco shop. (AP)

description: VICARIOUS lounging, and lots of it. That's what you get whether you pay a $25 visit to the show house at 18 East 74th Street -- an 1871 brownstone refaced as a 1921 Italian Renaissance limestone -- or hand over $12.5 million to buy the mansion itself.

description: After losing the battle to win back his institution's accreditation, the president of Morris Brown College has abruptly resigned, leaving its board of trustees vowing to keep the 122-year-old college open, despite being a bit uncertain as to how.

title: Giants' Draft Plan Is to Wait and See
description: Ernie Accorsi makes himself available to reporters before the college draft every year, and every year he reveals almost nothing about what his draft strategy will be. Accorsi, the Giants' general manager, was not merely being coy yesterday, however.

description: The rumors have been frantic and virtually impossible to contain.

title: When a Snow Day Is More Than Just Play
description: Many fourth graders at Hernandez Elementary School here do not remember what they did on their last snow day, which was two years ago. Others like Gabriel Prado, 10, remember just the painful parts, like being hit by a snowball thrown by his older brother.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FINKELSTEIN, BERNARD
description: FINKELSTEIN - Bernard. Pappy dearest, a very happy 95th Birthday. We think of you always. Your Family

title: Iraq Pipeline To Syria No Big Secret, Experts Say
description: Although the Bush administration is moving to shut down a pipeline that provided Iraqi oil to Syria illegally, the United States and American oil companies have long imported Syrian oil, more of which became available after the pipeline opened about three years ago, oil industry experts here said today.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Change In Academy Inquiry
description: Without much notice, Representative Joel Hefley, Republican of Colorado, altered a measure creating a commission to examine the Air Force Academy's handling of rape complaints. As a result, the panel will not focus on ''accountability and responsibility'' for the scandal but will study the academy's policies and environment. Former cadets who were raped and their advocates said the change would let leaders escape responsibility. Mr. Hefley said the problem had been caused by a culture that is hostile toward women cadets, not by any officials. The measure was part of the spending bill for the war in Iraq, which President Bush signed. Diana Jean Schemo (NYT)

title: INVESTMENT FIRM TO PURCHASE LILLIAN VERNON CORP.
description: The Lillian Vernon Corporation, a catalog and Internet seller of monogrammed knickknacks and items for the kitchen and garden, agreed to be acquired and taken private by a closely held investment firm for about $60.5 million. The company said its chairwoman, founder and largest shareholder, Lillian Vernon, 76, would give up her daily responsibilities and be a nonexecutive chairwoman. Ms. Vernon began the business at her kitchen table in 1951 with money she got as a wedding gift. Ripplewood Holdings, which manages a private equity fund, and a partner, ZelnickMedia, may expand the business to people who shop on television and increase online sales, Jim Friedlich, a partner at ZelnickMedia, said. Ripplewood, which is based in New York and manages about $4 billion, and ZelnickMedia will pay $7.25 in cash for each share of Lillian Vernon, the companies said. The price was 73 percent more than the retailer's closing price on Tuesday. Lillian Vernon is based in Rye, N.Y.

title: The Mets Hire a Mental Skills Coach
description: The Mets have hired Fran Pirozzolo, a licensed psychologist, as a mental skills coach, following a directive by Fred Wilpon, the team's owner, to expand the support staff for players on the major league roster.

title: Mets' Good Times Last a Day
description: The Mets have excelled at treating their record with a bit of skepticism, noting that they have been blown out only twice in 15 games and have been in all the other games they lost. They could make the same contention tonight, but it did not change another frustrating outcome.

title: Health Group Certain of Agent in Respiratory Ailment
description: Ending a monthlong hunt for the cause of severe acute respiratory syndrome, the World Health Organization said yesterday that animal experiments had proved conclusively that the agent was a new member of the coronavirus family.

title: Scenes From Iraq: Mixed Messages?
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | South: Coastal Areas Are Sinking
description: Parts of the Gulf Coast in Louisiana and Mississippi are subsiding naturally at such a rapid pace that certain places along evacuation routes may soon become impassable in hurricanes, a study by federal scientists and experts at Louisiana State University has found. In many spots, terrain that is barely above sea level could sink a foot in the next 10 years, the scientists said at a New Orleans conference on hurricanes. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and agencies in the region plan to start incorporating the new data on ground elevation into models that are used to assess the hazard posed by approaching storms. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Harassment Of Dissident Claimed
description: The opposition party of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi said she had been harassed on a political organizing trip to northwestern towns, with local officials warning people to stay away from her rallies and loudspeakers disrupting her public appearances with music and Buddhist speeches. It was the second time in a row that her party has reported harassment of the pro-democracy leader during a trip. The military government denied the report, saying she might have ''encountered noisy conditions and overzealous cameramen.'' Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Midas Begins Review Of Its Creative Work
description: Midas Inc. has begun a review for the creative part of its account, which has been handled since October 2001 by Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York. Though billings were not disclosed, Midas spent $40.6 million to advertise in major media last year, according to CMR, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres.

title: Disney Unloads Angels, Money-Losing Champs
description: The Walt Disney Company had tried to unload the Anaheim Angels for four years until reaching an agreement on Tuesday to sell them for $180 million to Arturo Moreno, a Phoenix businessman with a quiet public profile.

title: WPP Creates Division to Unite Agencies
description: The WPP Group in London is making changes affecting several large agencies.

title: Our Boys, My Brothers
description: To the Editor:

title: Virus Badly Underreported in Beijing, W.H.O. Team Finds
description: A team of international medical investigators said today that Chinese authorities had significantly understated the prevalence of severe acute respiratory syndrome in Beijing, with cases easily surpassing the total of 37 officially reported here on Monday.

title: Economic Scene; The Congressional Budget Office's updated forecasting methods don't help the White House's argument for tax cuts.
description: WHEN the Bush administration took office in early 2001, the federal government was expected to produce a cumulative surplus over 10 years of $5.6 trillion. This March, the Congressional Budget Office, the bipartisan economic research arm of Congress, forecast that with a weaker economy than expected and still another tax cut proposed by the president, the federal government would produce a deficit of $1.8 trillion over 10 years.

description: Manhattan

title: ALTRIA POSTS 7.6% DECLINE IN PROFIT FOR FIRST QUARTER
description: The Altria Group said yesterday that quarterly profit fell, hurt by poor sales of cigarettes at its Philip Morris unit. The company also suspended its share buybacks. Altria's first-quarter net profit fell 7.6 percent, to $2.19 billion, or $1.07 a share, from $2.37 billion, or $1.09 a share, in the period a year earlier. Analysts had expected Altria to earn about $1.06 a share, according to Thomson First Call. Revenue fell 5.7 percent, to $19.4 billion. Altria said its repurchase plan would remain suspended until it regained access to the capital markets. Altria's ability to finance debt has suffered since its credit ratings were cut after a $10.1 billion ruling against Philip Morris. Shares of Altria fell 75 cents, to $31.70.

title: KODAK HIRES A CHIEF FOR DIGITAL CAMERA SALES
description: The Eastman Kodak Company hired a former Olympus Optical Company executive, Yusuke Kojima, to head sales of digital cameras, which have become Kodak's fastest-growing business as revenue from film has declined. Mr. Kojima, 58, worked at Olympus for 35 years and headed its entry into digital cameras, Kodak said. Sales at Kodak, the world's largest photography company, have declined in the last three years as digital photography's popularity has grown and sales of film for conventional cameras have fallen. Kodak's digital camera unit will be profitable by 2004, the company has said.

Chester, both of Atlanta; daughter, Tracy Chester, of Westport, CT; two grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. description: NOTHING is harder on floors than summer, the season of sandy feet and beach towels deposited in damp piles. This year rescue is at hand in the form of modular carpet tiles. Normally seen only in banks and offices, they are now available for the home. The tiles, which come in do-it-yourself kits, can be used in any room as well as in basements and garages. The advantage, of course, is that in case of spills or fraying, individual tiles can be picked up and washed or replaced.

title: When Opportunity Knocks, Hitchcock Cannot Answer
description: Sterling Hitchcock has never regretted signing with the Yankees before last season. It is hard to wish away a two-year, $12 million contract. But Hitchcock would rather work for his money. Instead, he has collected it for doing almost nothing.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Teacher Is Hit-Run Victim
description: A teacher was in extremely critical condition last night after being struck in a hit-and-run incident outside his school in Brooklyn. The authorities said the teacher, Ilirjan Lika, 31, was walking from Middle School 409 in New Lots, where he teaches science, across Linden Boulevard to get lunch around 11:30 a.m. when he was struck by what a witness said was a Dodge Intrepid. Mr. Lika underwent surgery last night at Brookdale Hospital for internal injuries and a head wound. No arrest has been made, but school officials said a construction worker who saw the collision followed the hit-and-run driver in another car and was able to give the car's license number to the police. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Missing in Action
description: When looters descended upon the Iraq Museum in Baghdad last week, they despoiled one of the world's pre-eminent collection of artifacts from the Tigris and Euphrates Valleys. Founded in 1923, the museum displayed thousands of objects in a score of galleries, from prehistoric stone tools to medieval manuscripts. The most important finds from archaeological excavations in Iraq in the last 80 years were housed there, plus their records and photographs. Tools and painted pottery bore witness to the beginnings of human agriculture and settled life. Indeed, the whole range of human productive endeavor for 5,000 years was there: sculpture, metal work, glass, ceramic, ivory, textiles, furniture, jewelry, and parts of ancient buildings. Inscriptions and documents told the story of peoples, states, empires, and civilizations every school child can name: the Sumerians, Akkadians, Babylonians, Assyrians, Persians, Greeks, Parthians, Jews, Sassanians and Arabs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAINE, KATHARINE MORTI MER
description: BLAINE - Katharine Morti mer died April 14th. She was 80. The cause was cancer. Mrs. Blaine was a descendant of John Jay the first Chief Justice of the United States and Robert Livingston, the first Governor of New York colony. She lived in Tuxedo Park, Southampton and Manhattan where she graduated from the Chapin School. Her first marriage to Oliver C. Biddle of Philadelphia and her second to tennis champion Francis X. Shields Sr. ended in divorce. She was widowed by Richard Gillespie Blaine in 1972. She leaves her daughters, Christine Mortimer Biddle of New York, and Katharine Shields of San Francisco, sons William Xavier Orin Hunt Shields of Hollywood, Florida, Alston Shields of New York and Walker Blaine of Barnet, Vermont; her grandchildren, Spencer Biddle Millius, Morgan Christina Shields and Holten Joseph Shields; a sister, Eve Pell Ledyard, two brothers Richard Mortimer and John Jay Mortimer of New York. There will be a service conducted by her son, Walker Blaine, at the New York Shambhala Center on Thursday, April 24th at 6:30 P.M., at 118 West 22nd Street.

description: Two veteran executives of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority were quietly dismissed last year after investigators developed evidence that they took bribes to allow building contractors to submit fake bills to the agency, according to M.T.A. and other officials with knowledge of the case.

title: BUSH URGING U.N. TO LIFT SANCTIONS IMPOSED ON IRAQ
description: Having declared Saddam Hussein's rule to be ended, President Bush called on the United Nations today to lift economic sanctions on Iraq, moving to allow greater sales of Iraqi oil to help pay for its reconstruction.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: NEWARK: BOY KILLED IN FALL FROM WINDOW A toddler died yesterday after falling from a 17th-floor window, the police said. The boy, who the police said was 2, fell from the window of a large apartment building at 175 First Street at 5:46 p.m., and was pronounced dead at 6:13 p.m. at University Hospital, said Lt. Derek Glenn. The death appeared to be accidental, he said, adding that the boy was being cared for by an aunt at his grandmother's apartment, and that the window he fell from had a window guard on it. The police did not release the child's name. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Gadgets That Warm to the Real You
description: CONCERNS about security these days go beyond terrorist alerts, in their many colors. With computer larceny, system break-ins and identity theft growing every year, long-practiced security measures are not necessarily enough. Passwords can be stolen. Locks can be picked. Systems can be infiltrated.

title: Shrugging Off The Desktop, A Mini-Drive Runs Programs
description: Many U.S.B. external drives are now small enough to double as key chains, but the latest Iomega Mini U.S.B. drive offers more than just plentiful file storage -- 256 megabytes -- in a small package. With its built-in Iomega Active Disk software, certain programs can run straight from the portable external drive without having to be installed on a PC.

title: As the Class Struggle Hurtles Ahead
description: The Classical Theater of Harlem has followed a bold success -- its ragged, rousing version of Jean Genet's race-baiting circus, ''The Blacks,'' which moved to the East 13th Theater -- with the work of another clamorous iconoclast, the Polish writer and philosopher Stanislaw Witkiewicz. His play ''The Crazy Locomotive'' was first performed in the 1960's, although written decades earlier, in 1923, which makes its surrealist representation of a world dragged toward ruin and amorality by mechanization and money seem rather prescient. It runs through Sunday at the Harlem School of the Arts.

The building, a 21-story red-and-tan-brick tower that spans 360 feet on the southern side of 34th Street between Second and Third Avenues, rises above many surrounding structures.

title: Where Time Has Paused

Her office in the Chrysler building was eye-level with the gargoyles. But where did her love of climbing end?

title: IN RESTATEMENT, FLEMING TO LOWER PROFIT BY $85 MILLION
description: Fleming, the grocery distributor, said yesterday that restatements to correct accounting errors and the loss of a supply contract lowered pretax profit for 2001 and part of 2002 by as much as $85 million. The restatements for the seven quarters result from the loss of a supply contract with Kmart and make corrections to the timing of supplier payments, Fleming said. In addition, Fleming will record a larger loss in the fourth quarter of 2002 than previously reported, resulting in a loss for the year. Fleming, which filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this month, is restating the results after reviewing its accounting policies. Its bookkeeping is being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

She committed her life to her family and friends, and the medical treatment of children, and had a passion for the arts, music, and good food. Burial Service at Westchester HillsStephen Wise Cemetery, Route 9A, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY, Friday, April 18 at 11AM, followed by a Memorial Service at Temple Beth Shalom, 740 North Broadway, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY at 12 noon. title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Forked River: 2 Guards Reported Asleep At Nuclear Plant
description: Two security guards for the Oyster Creek nuclear power plant have been suspended after falling asleep at a security checkpoint, plant officials said yesterday. Around 4:50 a.m. Tuesday, a plant employee discovered the guards asleep, said Ernest J. Harkness, the plant's vice president. The guards, whose names were not released, are employed by a private company and are assigned to check identification of those entering the employee parking lot. They were 9 hours into a 12-hour shift and had been asleep no longer than 20 minutes, Mr. Harkness said. Stacy Albin (NYT)
