title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, ROBERT
description: SHAPIRO-Robert. On April 15th, 2003. Beloved husband of Gloria. Devoted father of Edward & Daniel and fatherin-law of Terry. Dear brother of Constance Rossoff, Laura Kirschner and the late Adelaide Shapiro. Cherished grandfather of Matt and Rachel. Services Sunday, 9:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Green River Cemetery, East Hampton, LI.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose as stocks gained and a manufacturing index fell less than expected this month. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0889, down from $1.0912 on Wednesday.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Glover's Opinion on War?

title: A New Look at Arab-Israeli Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Airline Pilots Set To Carry Firearms
description: After a graduation ceremony this weekend, a group of pilots from several of the nation's largest airlines will return home with a special gift from the federal government: a .40-caliber semiautomatic handgun that, beginning next week, they can carry into the cockpits of their planes.

title: American's Executive Packages Draw Fire
description: Union leaders at American Airlines yesterday denounced the company's disclosure on Tuesday night that it had set up a trust fund to protect top executives' pensions if the company went into bankruptcy and that it planned to pay bonuses to several executives for staying with the company until 2005.

title: In the Skies Over Iraq, Silent Observers Become Futuristic Weapons
description: On the third day of the Iraq war, a mysterious American aircraft loitered high over Baghdad for hours on end, evading a withering barrage of missile and artillery fire.

title: J. Paul Getty Jr., Philanthropist, Dies at 70
description: J. Paul Getty Jr., the remote American-born heir to an oil fortune who made Britain his home and beneficiary, died yesterday in London. He was 70.

title: Sports of The Times; The Rich (You Know) Get Richer
description: TODD ZEILE has heard the grumbling in dugouts around baseball: ''The Yankees get every call in Yankee Stadium.'' ''The ball always bounces the Yankees' way.''

title: When Freedom Leads to Anarchy
description: The Bush administration, ill prepared to curb the lawlessness that has swept Iraq, is reinforcing one of the world's most powerful antidemocratic forces: the fear of chaos. Even as looting subsides, vigilantism flourishes. Revenge killings are reported to have begun in Kirkuk, and Kurdish militiamen are said to be ousting Arabs from villages around the city.

title: Schmidt Adds His Support To Have Rose Reinstated
description: Mike Schmidt, dressed today in a dark-blue sport jacket, khakis and a white, short-sleeved polo shirt, is enjoying a relaxed, content lifestyle here, but he made it clear at a news conference that he has one more serious fight left: to help Pete Rose become eligible for the Hall of Fame.

title: Confusion Over North Korea Statement on Nuclear Program
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 18  Just days from the opening of discussions with the United States, North Korea said today in an English-language statement that it was reprocessing nuclear fuel rods, but there were growing indications late in the day that the North Koreans had mistranslated their own announcement from the original Korean.

title: 36 Hours | La Jolla, Calif.
description: LA JOLLA may be a village, as the municipal parking signs remind everyone, but there is more going on here than in many American cities. It has a superb theater, a fine art museum and scenic attractions ranging from improbable cliffside architecture to white-foamed surf that remains in constant motion while chubby seals take their afternoon naps. There are food festivals, outdoor concerts and a writers' conference on the calendar, not to mention the Annual Underwater Pumpkin Carving Contest, timed for the weekend before Halloween. A mere dot on the map at the end of the 19th century, La Jolla boomed after World War II as San Diego, 20 miles to the south, began to spread its suburban tentacles up the coast. (The San Diego branch of the University of California, in fact, is in La Jolla.) Much of what has kept La Jolla attractive can be traced to a single benefactor, Ellen Browning Scripps, who turned her house into the Museum of Contemporary Art and whose surname is linked to gardens, ocean-front parks and other features of the village, including the popular Institution of Oceanography. CONSTANCE L. HAYS

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile on April 9 about Justin Ferate, a tour guide who prepared the licensing test for sightseeing guides in New York City, misspelled the name adopted by a group of performers in tribute to a Broadway musical of 1900. They were the Florodora sextet, not Floradora.

title: Lawsuit Against Diocese of Brooklyn Is Dismissed
description: A judge in Queens has dismissed a major lawsuit against the Diocese of Brooklyn over allegations of long-ago sexual abuse by priests, rejecting an unusual argument intended to get around the statute of limitations.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Equipment Orders Rose In March
description: North American companies that sell equipment used to build semiconductors had a gain in new orders last month, a trade group said, as the industry coped with the worst two-year decline in its history. New orders rose 8.1 percent, to $823 million, in March on a three-month average basis, based on preliminary results, according to Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International, a spokesman for the association, Michael Droeger, said. The so-called book-to-bill ratio for the month was 0.99, meaning equipment makers received $99 in new orders for every $100 of goods sold.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELDMAN, GAIL LOGAN
description: FELDMAN-Gail Logan. A year passed. You are always loved, respected and remembered. William and Robert

title: Rival Game Maker Decides To Join the Bidding for Sega
description: A new bidder emerged today for the Sega Corporation, Japan's biggest maker of arcade games, prompting investors to drive Sega's share price up sharply.

title: Important Discoveries
AT THE MOVIES
description: A Portraitist Of Agony

title: Nets and Bucks Expect Guards to Dictate Series
description: They infuse their teammates with the lifeblood of bounce passes, clutch shots and confidence. Against each other, their hearts beat frantically faster, driven by a competition that began when they were prep standouts in Oakland, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMER, BERNARD
description: PALMER - Bernard. NYC, born April 22, 1917, died April 15, 2003. Husband of Marcia, father and grandfather of Michael and Diane Palmer (Dana), Robert & Sandee Palmer (Cary and Lori, Mindy), Diane and Buddy Flateman (Jennie, Sadie). ''He is leaving but the fighter still remains.''

title: Big Board Investigating Floor Trades
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it was investigating the practices of some of its traders, adding to pressure on the exchange's managers to demonstrate that they are protecting the interests of small investors.

title: U.S. Military Releases 927 Prisoners Captured in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  The United States military has released more than 900 Iraqi prisoners, leaving 6,850 still in custody, the Pentagon said today.

title: Hunting and Fishing Lodges: Going Where the Game Is
description: WHO: Tim Quinlan, 50, construction worker.

title: Neighbors of Iraq Express Concern Over U.S. Intentions
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, April 18  Leaders of the six countries that share a border with Iraq, including Syria, met here today for their first postwar summit, sharply criticizing the United States for its mounting pressure on Syria and saying they expected to conclude the meeting with a unified stance against even a short-term military occupation of Iraq.

title: FAO REACHES DEAL WITH INVESTORS; STORES TO STAY OPEN
description: FAO Inc., which operates the F. A. O. Schwarz and Zany Brainy toy store chains, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with investors who will buy $30 million in stock, clearing the way for it to conclude bankruptcy reorganization as soon as Monday. The reorganization, approved on April 4 by Judge Lloyd King of United States Bankruptcy Court, almost fell apart Monday when investors led by Kayne Anderson Capital Advisors threatened to back out of an offer to buy shares. The agreement averts a threatened closing of all 158 Zany Brainy, Right Start and F. A. O. Schwarz stores. The company, which filed for bankruptcy protection in January, has closed 95 stores and laid off workers to cut costs.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Harvard's Sexual Assault Policy
description: A committee investigating Harvard University's policy on sexual misconduct is recommending that the university adopt new preventative education programs and create an office to prevent and investigate sexual assaults. The proposals mandate a night of sexual assault education during freshman orientation and immediate access to counseling for victims. The committee was formed in response to anger over a policy approved last May that required students who file misconduct complaints to provide ''corroborating evidence,'' like witnesses. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Cuban Litmus Test
description: Even though Fidel Castro has been brutally cracking down on peaceful dissent in recent weeks, the timid United Nations Human Rights Commission let Cuba off easily yesterday. The 53-member body, led by none other than Libya, approved an anemic resolution asking Havana to accept the visit of a U.N. human rights observer. It defeated an amendment that would have condemned the recent roundup and sham trials of nearly 100 independent writers and advocates for democracy.

title: In Iraq's Remote Corners, a Few Americans Seemed '10 Feet Tall'
description: Even before American forces took control of Baghdad last week, a small team of American Special Forces troops had leapfrogged farther north and used a handful of M1-A1 Abrams tanks to seal off the highway leading to Tikrit, hoping to prevent flight there by Iraqi leaders, military officials said today.

title: A Chameleon Gets Brighter
description: Color-shifting paint, the car finish that changes color before your eyes, is widening its palette with the paint on the limited-edition 2004 SVT Mustang Cobra. The car goes from green to blue to purple to nearly black, depending on the light and the viewing angle of the beholder. It is on display from today through April 27 at the New York International Auto Show.

title: U.S. Seeks End to What It Calls Deceptive E-Mail Operation
description: The Federal Trade Commission asked a federal judge today to shut an Internet operation that it said used deceptive e-mail messages to draw people to pornographic Web sites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILZER, HERBERT RICHARD
description: PILZER-Herbert Richard. On April 15th, 2003. A truly remarkable person. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth Pilzer, loving brother of George Pilzer, devoted friend of Edith Landau Litt, loving and dynamic father of Lynn Pilzer Sobel and Neal Pilzer and father-in-law of Anita Pilzer and Eric Sobel. Adoring grandfather of Anna and Peter Sobel and Lauren and Julia Pilzer. Private funeral. The family will receive friends at the home of Anita and Neal Pilzer, 200 Washington Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, Friday from 5-9PM. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Phelps Hospice.

title: Owners of Hyatt Chain Must Reveal Breakup Plan, Judge Says
description: Members of the Pritzker family, which owns the Hyatt Corporation hotel chain, must turn over an agreement to break up their $15 billion empire to a judge, who will decide whether to give it to lawyers for a teenage heir.

title: INSIDE
description: British Tied to Ulster Killings

title: The Renaissance of White Plains; A Wallflower of a City Becomes the Belle of the Ball
description: During the 1990's, as cities everywhere seemed to prosper and expand, this unassuming city became the wallflower of Westchester. The office vacancy rate ballooned to 31 percent. The downtown turned ghostly at night. And not a single movie screen flickered across its nine square miles.

title: A Timely Moral Lesson in a Seldom-Heard Piece
description: It's unfortunate to have done your most famous work under someone else's name, but such is the case for the Austrian composer Friedrich Cerha, who is known in this country mainly for his completion of Alban Berg's operatic masterpiece, ''Lulu.'' Mr. Cerha, however, spent decades among the leadership of his country's avant-garde, and his own music should get more airtime here than it does. Mark Shapiro and the adventurous Cantori New York chamber chorus deserve credit, then, for presenting Mr. Cerha's cantata, ''An die Herrscher der Welt,'' published in 1950 but never performed in this country until Sunday afternoon at the Church of the Holy Trinity in Manhattan.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: New Plan For Fourth Graders And Test
description: Nearly 5,000 fourth graders in the Boston public schools will have the option of not retaking the writing part of the state's standardized test. Superintendent Thomas Payzant had ordered all fourth graders to retake the test, which asked students to write about their last snow day, after some parents objected that snow had not closed Boston schools in two years. He reconsidered after other parents argued that their children would not do as well on the second test, and those parents can now have their children exempted from the retest. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Opposition Rises to Crime Bill's Curb on Judicial Power in Sentencing
description: A bill that Congress recently passed setting up a national alert system for child abductions includes provisions that have created an uproar among federal judges and legal scholars because they limit judicial discretion in sentencing criminals.

title: 'Venus and Mars'
description: Directed by Harry Mastrogeorge

title: New Castle Journal; Where Cigarette Sales Have Increased Tenfold
description: From the foot of the Delaware Memorial Bridge, where the cars spill in from New Jersey, it is an easy 1.9-mile swoop (three minutes in good traffic) to the Delaware Tobacco Outlet. On Saturday, the manager, Shirley Legeza, arrived to find a busload of New Yorkers waiting for her to open.

title: 'Marion Bridge'
description: Directed by Wiebke von Carolsfeld

title: Not Just for Children, a Suspenseful Allegory of Greed, Fate and Racism
description: Louis Sachar's 1998 novel ''Holes,'' which among other prizes has won a Newbery Medal and a National Book Award, has also, and more important, attracted a fanatical following among children in the middle grades. Since these tend to be the most passionate and also the pickiest members of the reading public, their fierce regard for Mr. Sachar's book should not be taken lightly.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Charges Expected In Insurer Case
description: The Australian government will bring 56 criminal charges against 20 executives involved in the $2.5 billion collapse of HIH Insurance two years ago, the federal treasurer, Peter Costello, said. He accepted recommendations for prosecutions in an 18-month judicial investigation that found that incompetence, mismanagement and deception were responsible for the corporate collapse, the largest in Australia. Senior executives of the government's insurance watchdog agency, facing claims of inadequate supervision, are expected to be replaced. John Shaw (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Electronics Profit
description: The net profit for LG Electronics, a core company of the LG Group, the country's second-largest conglomerate, was 194 billion won ($159.9 million), 12 percent below net profit in the first quarter of last year. Revenue for the first three months hit a high of 5.2 trillion won, up 18 percent from 4.4 trillion won, but losses by affiliate firms and currency charges cut into the final results. The company sold 5.6 million phones from Jan. 1 through March 31, nearly double the 3.1 million phones it sold in the first quarter of 2002. LG Electronics, which sold its semiconductor division to Hyundai Electronics, now Hynix Semiconductor, in 1999, also makes consumer items like computer monitors and television sets. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Life Resumes With Eating, Waiting, Work
description: Throughout Baghdad yesterday, there were signs of people making small steps to return to normal life. Work proceeded on restoring electric power, and some gasoline stations had fuel. Stores were beginning to open, and there were food vendors on the streets in some parts of the city. It was by no means business as usual. Fires still burned, although Iraqi firefighters continued to put them out. Bank robbers were still at work, and when marines caught some of them in the act, they had to deal with angry crowds who wanted their money right away. F.B.I. agents were on their way to Iraq to help track down stolen museum artifacts. Nonetheless, here and there Iraqis and Americans, civilians and soldiers, enjoyed small pleasures and the luxury, after the terror of war, of being annoyed by long lines. And at least a few soldiers, who bought soft drinks or food, enjoyed the chance to be viewed not as liberators or invaders, but as customers.

title: Mark Dion -- 'Collaborations'
description: American Fine Arts

title: What Hope Now for Mideast Peace?
description: JERUSALEM (CNN) -- As the U.S.-led military campaign against Iraq nears an end, a common refrain on the streets from Tel Aviv to Ramallah is what will the Iraqi war mean for Middle East peace and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEFFNER, RUTH B.
description: HEFFNER-Ruth B. On April 16, 2003 at age 90. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin Heffner. Loving mother of Lenore Briskman, Rhoda Becker and John Heffner. Cherished grandmother of eight and great grandmother of seven. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Friday April 18th, 1:30PM. Interment to follow at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Waterford Layoffs
description: Waterford Wedgwood, the manufacturer behind the Waterford Crystal and Wedgwood brands of luxury goods, laid off 94 temporary workers at its factory in the city of Waterford after experiencing falling demand for its products. Pending discussions with its labor unions, the company is likely to cut costs further by closing its two Irish plants, which employ 1,600 people, for one week in June; a spokesman said such short-term closings were common during slow retail periods of the year. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: A Vibrant San Juan Gets Its Groove Back
description: THE night sky darkens slowly and the sea flattens, with only the gentlest waves breaking on the shore, the sea and the sky becoming one, the line between the two blurred, gone. The beach girls have retired to wash off the sand and put on the flimsiest skirts to show off newly bronzed legs. The jet skis that noisily crisscross the water all day are finally still, the beach chairs are folded and stacked away, the vendors are gone, and, from a rooftop nearby, the beach seems untouched, placid, silent.

title: Moving In With a Family That Struggles on the Edge
description: ove and Diane" was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 12, 2002. The film opens today at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village.

title: Rebuilding Contract, Threats to Syria From Congress, Help for a Museum
description: The attention of the United States has turned increasingly to the reconstruction of Iraq. The administration selected an American company to oversee the huge job of putting Iraq back together, but the contract angered allies. F.B.I. agents were sent to Iraq to help recover stolen antiquities, and Special Forces troops in Baghdad caught another of Saddam Hussein's half brothers.

title: Husband Held After 2 Bodies Are Identified
description: MODESTO, Calif., April 18 - Scott Peterson, the husband of a woman eight months pregnant who vanished on Christmas Eve, was arrested today in connection with her death and that of their baby, the Modesto police said.

title: A Sculptor Hears the Call Of the Wild
description: The French sculptor Antoine-Louis Barye (1795-1875) was born into poverty, had little formal schooling and almost never left Paris, so his choice of subject for his art is particularly surprising. For a half-century he created bronze sculptures of exotic wild animals, including lions, tigers, reptiles and birds of prey, in minute detail. He often depicted them in mortal combat, captured in the moment before the kill.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ARKANSAS: NEW EFFORT ON STATE BUDGET Gov. Mike Huckabee said he would call the General Assembly back into session within weeks to try to enact a $7 billion state budget. The legislative session ended on Wednesday night after Republicans and conservative Democrats in the House blocked consideration of a tax increase to finance appropriations. The impasse leaves state agencies without spending authority in the fiscal year beginning July 1. House Republican leaders said they preferred to tap reserve funds rather than raise new revenue. Democrats hold large majorities in both houses. (NYT)

title: U.N. and European Union Consider the Future of Iraq
description: As the new debate began here today over how to lift sanctions against Iraq, the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, was in Greece, imploring European Union leaders to forge a shared position on the terms and timing of Iraq's political and economic reconstruction.

title: Omer Fast
description: Postmasters

title: A Mighty Global Power and Its Heir Apparent
description: EMPIRE

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Good Friday and the second day of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERTHEIM, ALBERT
description: WERTHEIM-Albert, 62, of Bloomington, IN., died April 16, 2003. Cherished son, husband, father, grandfather, father-in-law, relative, mentor, colleague and friend, he will be profoundly missed.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Mercury Shares Plunge On Earnings Forecast
description: Shares of Mercury Computer Systems Inc., whose products are used to create radar and sonar images for the military, fell as much as 30 percent yesterday after the company said that its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings might be 16 cents to 20 cents a share. Shares fell $6.88, or almost 26 percent, to $19.78. The shares had declined 13 percent this year. Robert Stone, a media and electronics analyst with the SG Cowen Securities Corporation, had estimated earnings of 26 cents for the fourth quarter. Mr. Stone, who owns no shares in the company, cut his forecast yesterday to 17 cents, on revenue of $46 million, and downgraded it to market perform from outperform.

title: Art Experts Mobilize Team To Recover Stolen Treasure And Salvage Iraqi Museums
description: An international group of archaeologists and museum directors agreed today to send an emergency mission to Iraq to assess the damage suffered by the National Museum and other Iraqi cultural institutions in the looting that followed the fall of Saddam Hussein's government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IAMS, JOAN WALKER
description: IAMS-Joan Walker, 77, in Austin, Texas. Formerly of Great Neck, Manhattan, and Opio, France. A writer, mainly about television in the '50s and '60s, for Newsweek, Cue, National Observer, New York Magazine, and Sunday New York Times. Daughter of newspaperman Stanley Walker. Widow of Thomas H. Wenning, longtime Newsweek movie and theatre reviewer. Widow of Samuel H. (Jack) Iams, writer and journalist. Survivors include four stepchildren.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ACCENTURE, Hamilton, Bermuda, the world's largest computer consultant, won a $500 million, five-year contract to improve bill-collection systems at the consumer telephone unit of AT&T, Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERKLEIT, NICOLE
description: SILBERKLEIT-Nicole. Died suddenly on April 16. She was such an important part of the lives of her children Suzanne, Michele and Martine; her sons-in-law Jordan, Rob and Charles; her grandchildren Jake, Nick, Alexander, Caroline and Romy; and her cousins Cecile, Philippe and Renee, Alexander and Elizabeth. We miss her already. She was a survivor of Auschwitz. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Shoah Foundation, Dept 4W00, PO Box 3168, Los Angeles, CA 90078 Memorial service Friday, April 18th at 11:00 AM at The Carlyle Hotel, 35 E 76 St, NYC

title: Civil Rights Lawyers Seek Teeth For Rules on Police Surveillance
description: Civil rights lawyers yesterday asked a federal judge who recently eased court-ordered limits on police surveillance of political groups to revise the guidelines so that the city could be held in contempt if they are violated.

title: Ferry Operator Is the Target Of U.S. Inquiry
description: Federal authorities are investigating allegations that the region's leading private ferry company defrauded the federal government of hundreds of thousands of dollars in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attack, according to investigators involved in the case.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Chip Maker's Loss Declines
description: Chartered Semiconductor, the world's third-largest chip subcontractor, said its first-quarter loss narrowed to $75.7 million, compared with a loss of $128.4 million a year earlier. Revenue rose 23.1 percent, to $103.8 million. The company said customers remained cautious but that it expected demand for its high-end semiconductors to increase its capacity use this quarter. At the same time, Chartered faces increasing competition from Malaysia and China for older, less-sophisticated chips. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINER, ELAINE
description: REINER - Elaine, actress, died on Monday, April 14th. Daughter of (late) Harry and Emma Oshrin, sister of (late) Albert Oshrin, wife of (late) Manny Reiner and of (late) Hal Eaton. Survived by her sister Evelyn (Pat) Glazer, brother-in-law Irving Glazer, six nieces and nephews, nine great-nieces and nephews, and longtime companion Herman Liebmann. Services 11:30 AM, Sunday April 20th at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Visitation from 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Actors Fund of America, 729 7th Ave., NYC 10019.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It is one thing to know that I'll have to lead 30 soldiers who don't like me because I am a snot-nosed kid from West Point. But now I might have to go over there and basically be mayor of a town. That is a mission I never imagined.''

title: 'Seabiscuit' Captures A 1930's Love Affair
description: No one could read Laura Hillenbrand's best-selling book, ''Seabiscuit: An American Legend,'' and not recognize that the horse biography was one of the great love stories of the 1930's.

title: An Improvising Weaver Stops The Jays Cold
description: The sweat on Jeff Weaver's forehead vanished the moment he walked onto the field, wiped away by the tireless grip of winter. The outfield flags whipped above Weaver as he tried to get warm in the bullpen, leaning into fastballs that died the moment they left his hand. Weaver's second pitch of the game, another fastball, crossed the inside corner and was hammered into left field for a double by Toronto's Shannon Stewart.

title: RUSSELL IS BUYING MOST OF SPALDING SPORTING GOODS UNIT
description: The Russell Corporation, the maker of Russell Athletic and Jerzees sportswear, said yesterday that it would buy most of the sporting goods business of Spalding Holdings for $65 million. Spalding makes and sells Dudley brand softballs and Spalding basketballs, volleyballs, footballs and soccer balls. Russell said it would buy the inventory, brand names and contracts of Spalding Sports Worldwide. The transaction does not include Spalding's golf operations. Spalding said it would focus on the golf line, which includes the Top-Flite, Ben Hogan and Strata brands. Shares of Russell rose 16 cents, to $18.16. Spalding is controlled by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Economic Growth
description: The Russian economy expanded by 6.4 percent in the first quarter of this year compared with last year, the prime minister, Mikhail Kasyanov, said. The growth figure, which beat government forecasts, outstripped industrial production for the quarter, indicating strong growth in other sectors of the economy, like services. Russia's economy has been expanding since 1999, when the effects of a currency devaluation plucked the country's economy out of seven years of post-Soviet recession. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: U.N. Gives Cuba Mild Rebuke Over Crackdown on Dissidents
description: The United Nations Human Rights Commission passed a mild rebuke to Cuba today, but it said nothing about the recent crackdown on dissidents that has set off international outrage.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLASER, ANNIE
description: BLASER - Annie. 4/18/1989. Mother, grandmother, greatgrandmother, we all miss you and love you forever. The Blaser Family

title: Documents Show Urgent Iraqi Push to Recruit and Control Troops
description: Eid Ali Abbas Jaafar, an Iraqi serviceman, vowed to give his life in ''a martyr mission against the American-Israeli enemies'' or anyone else who attacked ''this dearly beloved country.''

title: Legends Strike a Pose, With or Without Music
description: The rock star Madonna and the photographer Nan Goldin, each a legend in her own right, share some artistic territory that, complete with pitfalls, is being highlighted by overlapping gallery exhibitions in SoHo and Chelsea. Both artists emerged from the East Village in the late 1970's and early 1980's. Working on opposite sides of the camera, each became known for images that were postmodern revelations of the flesh. Both gained prominence from setting these images to music.

title: W.N.B.A. Faces Deadline for Deal
description: The W.N.B.A. and its players union negotiated in New York yesterday and said they would continue to talk today, trying to reach a collective-bargaining agreement before the league's deadline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ROBERT MYLES
description: MILLER-Robert Myles. 77. Died April 17th after a long courageous battle with emphysema. Robert, born, lived and loved New York, died at home. He leaves his wife of fifty-one years, Selma (nee Gruenstein); son, Robert Myles Jr. and wife Jill Winitzer, daughter Amy Ruth and husband John Klossner; daughter Linda Ellen and husband Mark Minton; grandchildren Jeremy, Aliza, Lane, Chhany, Benjamin and Surya; dog Mimi and his Checker car. He founded Lee Myles Advertising Firm. Visiting at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison at 81 St, Saturday April 19, 7-9PM with service Sunday 11:30 AM Burial private.

title: Preventing a Miscarriage of Justice
description: The Supreme Court is meeting today to consider the fate of Delma Banks Jr., a Texas death row inmate whose execution it temporarily halted last month. Mr. Banks's conviction was marred by malfeasance by the prosecutors, terrible work by his own lawyers and racial discrimination in jury selection. And there is serious doubt about his guilt. The Supreme Court must not allow him to be put to death.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about plans for a science fiction shrine in Seattle misstated the title of the 1947 book credited by Paul G. Allen, the force behind the project, with having made him a fan when he was a child. The book, by Robert A. Heinlein, was ''Rocket Ship Galileo,'' not ''Spaceship Galileo.''

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway Posts Wider First-Quarter Loss
description: Gateway Inc., the personal computer maker, reported a wider first-quarter loss yesterday after it raised prices for personal computers and demand fell. The net loss widened to $197.7 million, or 62 cents a share, from $123.2 million, or 39 cents, in last year's first quarter, Gateway said. Sales declined to $844.5 million from $992.2 million. Gateway sold 506,000 PC's in the quarter, down 30 percent from the fourth quarter and 22 percent from the year-earlier period. Gateway is charging higher prices on the PC's to try to become profitable. Gateway said on March 17 that it would close 80 of its 272 stores and lay off 1,900 workers to save $200 million a year in expenses. Shares of Gateway rose 3 cents, to $2.42.

title: Exchange to Warn Investors on Companies
description: Throughout its history, the New York Stock Exchange has protected the companies whose shares it trades by declining to disclose to investors when a company's financial position no longer meets the exchange's listing standards.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Chip Tariffs Sought
description: Four semiconductor manufacturers in Taiwan plan to ask their government to impose tariffs on South Korean semiconductors, charging that Hynix Semiconductor, the embattled South Korean company, has received government subsidies. The United States Commerce Department has issued a preliminary ruling imposing a 57 percent tariff on Hynix semiconductor imports, and Infineon Technologies of Germany is asking its government to decide on a similar penalty. Taiwan manufacturers sell 20 percent of the world's semiconductors. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Detroit's Playoff Showing Ends as a Cameo
description: Midway through the winter, the first part of a documentary called ''The Season: Detroit Red Wings'' was broadcast on ESPN. It showed the Stanley Cup champion Red Wings in the locker room, in their homes and on the road.

description: For many New Yorkers, the budget blues have come on slowly, like a bad, unkickable cold that finally becomes a miserable sinus infection. A street on Staten Island looks a bit dirtier; an Upper West Side subway station seems to have a few more homeless people.

title: A Reticent China Undercuts Its Milder New Image
description: China's restrictions on information about a highly infectious respiratory illness has undermined five years of diplomacy intended to alter its image as a prickly regional power and to improve relations with neighboring countries, Asian politicians and analysts say.

title: RECOTON AGREES TO SELL A BUSINESS TO GEMINI INDUSTRIES
description: Recoton, an electronics maker that filed for bankruptcy protection this month, has agreed to sell its consumer electronics accessories business to Gemini Industries for $50 million, according to court papers. The sale requires the approval of a bankruptcy court. Recoton filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on April 8, listing assets of $223.6 million and liabilities of $234.6 million. Under the terms of its financing, Recoton must sell its remaining assets to pay off its debt. Gemini, which is owned by the privately held York Management Services of Edison, N.J., is a distributor of consumer electronics accessories and communications components. Gemini is based in Clifton, N.J., and Recoton is based in Lake Mary, Fla.

title: A Beady-Eyed Perspective on Migrating Birds
description: The breathtaking cinematography of migrating birds in Jacques Perrin's mystical documentary ''Winged Migration'' transports you to an exalted realm where nature operates under its own inviolable laws and humanity is portrayed as a crude, destructive interloper in the natural scheme of things.

title: Hopes Disintegrate Into a Life of Degradation
description: In many ways the 16-year-old title character of Lukas Moodysson's great, heartbreaking ''Lilya 4-Ever'' could be any throwaway teenager living anywhere in the world. But growing up in a grim unidentified town somewhere in the former Soviet Union (much of the movie was filmed in Estonia) makes Lilya's plight infinitely sadder than if she were an overprivileged brat mopily foraging in a land of plenty.

title: Grim News for Knicks: More Surgery for McDyess
description: The optimism the Knicks felt about their future was crushed yesterday when a CT scan on Antonio McDyess's broken left kneecap revealed that he would need bone-graft surgery, which could keep him sidelined for most of next season.

title: For Families, a Return to Baghdad to Pick Up the Pieces
description: They are finally coming home.

title: The Quest for Illicit Weapons
description: The continued failure of American forces to find any ''weapons of mass destruction'' in Iraq must be worrying some officials, particularly at intelligence agencies that assured the White House that Baghdad had such weapons. If Saddam Hussein authorized his field commanders to use chemical weapons, as Secretary of State Colin Powell suggested to the United Nations in February, presumably some of the weapons should have been overrun by Army and Marine forces as they closed in on Baghdad. Yet so far every report of suspicious items has proved to be a false alarm. The very fact that pressure is mounting on the Bush administration to prove the presence of unconventional weapons makes it imperative that the White House bring in experienced inspectors from the United Nations and the International Atomic Energy Agency to help locate illicit materials and enhance the credibility of any findings. Current White House plans to bypass the U.N. are heading in the wrong direction.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Debate Over Borrowing
description: Mary Harney, left, Ireland's deputy prime minister and minister for trade and employment, told a European politics conference that Ireland should be allowed to breach the European Union's growth and stability pact, which limits government borrowing to 3 percent of gross domestic product for countries in the European single currency. ''We need flexibility in the way that we interpret it,'' she said in a radio interview. Ireland needs to borrow to invest in its infrastructure because the country has the second-lowest ratio of debt to gross domestic product in the union, she said. Peter Sutherland, a respected economic commentator who formerly served as the union's commissioner from Ireland and as chairman and managing director of Goldman Sachs International, opposed Ms. Harney's position in his presentation, and supported a cautious approach to the pact. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Chief Auditor Is Appointed By New Panel
description: Douglas R. Carmichael, a prominent accounting professor, was named yesterday as the first chief auditor of a new accounting oversight board.

title: A New School War
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg succeeded where others had failed when he persuaded the State Legislature to transform the city's school system from a semiautonomous body into a city department controlled by the mayor. But Mr. Bloomberg and Albany are at loggerheads over the question of how much he and his schools chancellor should be allowed to change the sprawling 32-district system, which remains the last vestige of the old era.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Pope Has Stern Message
description: Pope John Paul II celebrated two Holy Thursday Masses at the Basilica of St. Peter in Vatican City. He also signed an encyclical letter, the 14th of his pontificate, intended to crack down on what he considers abuses of the eucharist. The 78-page encyclical, reserved for matters of great importance to the church, issued a stern reminder that divorced Catholics who remarry cannot receive communion and warned against taking communion in non-Roman Catholic churches, lamenting that communion is being celebrated ''as if it were simply a fraternal banquet.'' It also said that only priests could say Mass. The 82-year-old pontiff, who suffers from Parkinson's disease, used a new mobile throne. He told the thousands gathered at the evening Mass that their donations would go to the victims of the war in Iraq. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL CLIMBS. Crude oil rose after OPEC members including Iran, Algeria, Qatar and Indonesia said the group should reduce output. In New York, crude oil for May delivery rose $1.37, or 4.7 percent, to $30.55 a barrel.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Appetizers are usually a lot more fun than entrees. Perhaps that's why the French call a bite-size pre-appetizer an amuse bouche, something that entertains the palate. Gerry Hayden, formerly the chef at Aureole, has built an entire menu around appetizers at Amuse, the spacious restaurant formerly known as the Tonic.

title: Company Has Ties in Washington, and to Iraq
description: The company that will lead the reconstruction of Iraq had its beginnings in 1898, when Warren A. Bechtel and his pack of mules were hired to grade railroad beds in the Oklahoma Territory. A century later, his company, which is still controlled by his descendants, is one of the world's largest and most politically connected construction companies.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Food Prices Rise As Truckers Strike
description: More than two and a half million delivery vehicles were grounded for a fourth consecutive day as talks between government officials and striking truckers failed to produce any progress. In parts of the country, the strike has already pushed up prices for fruits and vegetables and has slowed industrial production. The truckers' demands include immunity from a new value-added tax scheduled to go into effect this year, relief from frequent diesel price increases, and the cancellation of a ban on 15-year-old trucks. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: REGULATION OF CHILD SUPPORT COLLECTION AGENCIES A group of City Council members unveiled two bills yesterday intended to regulate private child support collection companies that pocket much of the money they were hired to collect. The bills, which grew out of a two-week investigation into how the companies do business, would set a 15 percent cap on the amount the companies could charge customers and require them to disclose, in writing, the terms of contracts and all fees associated with their service. Since many of the companies are private and not regulated by federal law, customers — often poor single parents — have little protection from those who slip in extra charges and hidden contract terms, the council members said.  Nicole M. Christian (NYT)

title: U.S. GIVES BECHTEL A MAJOR CONTRACT IN REBUILDING IRAQ
description: The Bush administration awarded the Bechtel Group of San Francisco the first major contract today in a vast reconstruction plan for Iraq that assigns no position of authority to the United Nations or Europe.

It may cross your mind at the Japan Society, where a beautiful show of early Buddhist sculpture from Korea and Japan is dispensing lessons in several kinds of grace.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Dell Recaptures PC Sales Lead
description: In a still-tepid personal computer market, the Dell Computer Corporation reclaimed the top spot in the first quarter, but progress by Toshiba signaled that 2003 may prove to be the year of the notebook. Dell, of Austin, Tex., reclaimed the sales lead from the Hewlett-Packard Company of Palo Alto, Calif., according to figures released yesterday by the research companies IDC and Gartner Dataquest. Dell's ties to business customers proved more resilient than Hewlett's consumer base in the first three months of 2002, a quarter that generally favors the corporate market. IDC reported that Dell's worldwide sales grew 24.7 percent, to 5,989,000, and its market share rose to 17.3 percent from 14.2 percent. I.B.M. and Fujitsu Siemens were third and fourth, respectively, in IDC's rankings.

title: Briefly Noted
description: AFGHANISTAN: TALIBAN FIGURE HELD Afghanistan's government said it had arrested a leader of the former Taliban government's feared religious police. The state-run Kabul Radio said the man, Maulawi Qalamuddin, had been arrested by government security agents. It did not say when or where the arrest took place. Mr. Qalamuddin was deputy head of the Religious Affairs Ministry and ran that agency's Department for Prevention of Vice and Promotion of Virtue. In that role, he became notorious for strictly enforcing Taliban religious decrees, including ordering public beatings of women who failed to completely cover themselves while outdoors. (Reuters)

title: China Cautions Officials Not to Hide SARS Cases
description: BEIJING, April 18 — China's top leaders, seeking to quell an international uproar over the honesty of their medical reports as well as to halt a dangerous new virus, have issued their strongest warning yet about severe acute respiratory syndrome and have explicitly cautioned officials not to cover up the spread of the disease.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Electroglas To Cut 25% Of Work Force
description: Electroglas Inc., a maker of semiconductor equipment, said yesterday that it would cut 25 percent of its work force in the next two quarters. The company also said delays in customer bookings and shipments led to a loss in its first quarter. The net loss widened to $23.3 million, or $1.09 a share, from $14.8 million, or 71 cents, a year earlier. Sales for the quarter ended March 31 fell 19 percent, to $9.47 million from $11.7 million. Electroglas employed 469 workers as of December 2002, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Its loss widened because of $8.5 million in expenses for writing down the value of its San Jose, Calif., campus, the company said. Shares fell 21 cents, or 13 percent, to $1.36.

title: Boom Times For Repo Guys
description: IT'S 10 p.m. Do you know where your car is? Max Pineiro knows where somebody's is, and he is about to steal it. Driving his Ford F-150 truck around a rough-and-tumble neighborhood of Rahway, N.J., on a Monday night, he and his partner, Sergio Costa, don't take long to find what they want, a red Honda Accord. Unlocking the car will be easy -- they even have a key -- but if there's an alarm, they are worried about disabling it before being caught.

title: SHARES OF PACIFICARE HEALTH RISE 27% ON EARNINGS NEWS
description: Shares of PacifiCare Health Systems, a leading operator of Medicare health plans, jumped 27 percent yesterday after it said first-quarter profit rose more than expected and full-year earnings would be higher than previous estimates. First-quarter profit was at least $1.90 a share, more than twice analysts' average forecast, the company said. PacifiCare's Medicare business has become more profitable because of cost-cutting steps it took last year, including dropping patients and offering fewer benefits, a spokesman said. PacifiCare's stock rose $6.10, to $29.11 a share.

title: Oil, Food and a Whole Lot of Questions
description: President Bush's call to lift economic sanctions against Iraq could mean the end of the United Nations oil-for-food program, which has overseen the country's oil sales since 1996. Not only are France and Russia likely to object, but they may well support efforts by Secretary General Kofi Annan to modify the oil-for-food system, which is due to expire on May 12, and give it a large role in rebuilding the country. Whatever Mr. Annan's reasons for wanting to reincarnate the operation, before he makes his case there's something he needs to do: open the books.

title: Up-and-Coming Dancers Committed to the Classical
description: Two defining principles of the ABT Studio Company were clear from the first moments of Antony Tudor's ''Continuo,'' which opened the program Tuesday night at the Kaye Playhouse. The easy perfection of body line and the liquid arms of Daniel Keene and Caity Seither made obvious the viability of pure classical ballet and the rewards of training young dancers to honor and commit to that purity. American Ballet Theater's junior troupe, directed by John Meehan, celebrates those values in a time when they are too readily dismissed.

description: There has been no change in Augusta National Golf Club's position on barring women as members, despite recent comments made by its chairman, William Johnson, a club spokesman said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Dino Yannopoulos, a former stage director for the Metropolitan Opera, misstated the record attained by the performance of ''Lohengrin'' under his direction on Nov. 15, 1952, and misidentified the featured tenor. Including tours, this was the Met's 492nd performance of the opera; it was promoted as the 300th performance on the Met stage. The tenor was Hans Hopf, not Jussi Bjoerling.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Cameras In The Courtrooms
description: The State Supreme Court temporarily opened most courtrooms to print and broadcast cameras beginning in July, bringing Mississippi in line with a majority of states. Cameras will be barred from divorce and child custody proceedings as well as the testimony of informers, protected witnesses and victims of sexual crimes. The Supreme Court will have to act by Jan. 1, 2005, to make the rule permanent.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Software Profit
description: Europe's largest software maker, SAP, said rigorous cost-cutting enabled it to triple net profit in the first quarter, beating stock-market expectations despite falling sales. Net profit amounted to 186 million euros ($203 million) in the period from January to March, compared with 65 million euros a year earlier. By contrast, sales fell 8 percent, to 1.52 billion euros, and software license revenues declined 12 percent, to 352 million euros. Much of the sales drop was attributable to exchange-rate fluctuations, SAP said. SAP, which is based in Walldorf, Germany, expects earnings per share to rise as much as 17 percent this year despite persistent global economic weakness and uncertainty. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Only Red, Please. Yellow and Blue Are Not Wanted.
description: No other color has quite the vitality, the symbolism, the strong gutsy presence of red. It is the color of sin, spilled blood, war and Christmas. It signals succor (the Red Cross), derring-do (the Scarlet Pimpernel), hospitality (the red carpet), warning (traffic lights and such) and political subversion (Communism). Even an animal, like a bull, can become aroused at the sight of red.

title: NATIONAL STEEL ACCEPTS BID FROM U.S. STEEL
description: National Steel said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its assets to the U.S. Steel Corporation for $850 million, rejecting a higher offer from AK Steel Holding. That offer did not include an agreement with unionized workers. The acceptance of the bid from U.S. Steel, which has already reached a labor agreement with the steelworkers, averts a possible strike. U.S. Steel increased its cash bid to $850 million from $775 million. It had already increased its offer last week by $25 million to include the National Steel Pellet Company. AK Steel bid $925 million. Both bidders also agreed to assume about $200 million in liabilities. The auction results will be presented for approval Monday to Judge John H. Squires of United States Bankruptcy Court in Chicago.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: SOFTWARE PROFIT Europe's largest software maker, SAP, said rigorous cost-cutting enabled it to triple net profit in the first quarter, beating stock-market expectations despite falling sales. Net profit amounted to 186 million euros ($203 million) in the period from January to March, compared with 65 million euros a year earlier. By contrast, sales fell 8 percent, to 1.52 billion euros, and software license revenues declined 12 percent, to 352 million euros. Much of the sales drop was attributable to exchange-rate fluctuations, SAP said. SAP, which is based in Walldorf, Germany, expects earnings per share to rise as much as 17 percent this year despite persistent global economic weakness and uncertainty. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Time to Ask, Who Needs Albany?
description: SIXTEEN months into his mayoralty and 37 years after he first came to New York to make his fortune, Michael R. Bloomberg has discovered that the city's fate rests largely with a distant, often-uncaring Albany. That made him angry, Mr. Bloomberg said this week as he announced a worst-case budget for the next fiscal year that is already producing shock and ugh.

title: Fearing SARS, Ontario Urges Wider Quarantines
description: In an extraordinary measure, Ontario health officials yesterday asked anyone who has even one symptom of SARS to stay home for a few days out of fear that anyone developing the respiratory disease might spread it during the Easter holiday weekend.

title: In Hoopla Over a P.O.W., A Mirror of U.S. Society
description: There have been many television magazine shows devoted to Pfc. Jessica Lynch, and several movie treatments are in the works, including an unauthorized NBC made-for-television movie.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, MARTIN
description: SHAPIRO-Martin. April 18th 1998. We love you, remember your intelligence and humor. Love, Miriam, Ellen & Stev

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCHMAN, ARNOLD
description: DEUTSCHMAN-Arnold. Age 83, suddenly on April 16, 2003. First Vice President of Investments at Smith Barney. Beloved husband of Blossom. Devoted father of Cliff and Rob and father-in-law of Chris and Ellen. Cherished grandfather of Cate, Nicki, Beth, Danielle and David. Services Sunday 1 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Howe Shakes Runs Out of His New Lineup
description: One could tell much by watching Mike Piazza's expressions the past week, witnessing how pained he was by the struggles he and the Mets were having. His face changed into his trademark scowl tonight when he became the first player to homer off the green wall beyond center field at PNC Park, and the Mets witnessed many unlikely but welcome sights in their 7-2 victory over the Pirates.

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: A Nation at War, a daily separate section, begins on Page B1. Complete metropolitan and sports reports share a section. By flipping over The Metro Section, bottom-side up, readers will find the sports pages, starting with S1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODZEIT, SYLVIA GLICK
description: GOODZEIT-Sylvia Glick. Beloved wife of the late David S. Goodzeit, mother of Margaret Goodzeit and the late Andrea Goodzeit, ''grandmommy'' of Jamie, Elizabeth and Steven Flynn, and sister of Lillian Weiss. Graveside services at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ, Friday, April 18 at 1 P.M.

title: Deal With Diesel Fumes
description: To the Editor:

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Dropping a Fee (But Not Really)

title: Trapped Under Floor In a Gothic Ordeal
description: It was a Poe story set on Chambers Street. An ordinary business meeting between two men veered into vitriol. At knifepoint, the authorities said, one of the men was bound and gagged by the other, and then imprisoned in the claustrophobic space beneath the floorboards of an apartment. Only after 28 hours trapped in this netherspace, with no food or water, was he able to pry his way out. This is the gothic episode that the police say unfolded in the heart of TriBeCa.

title: Valerie Jaudon
description: Von Lintel Gallery

title: Love in Bloom: A Weekend Affair That Lasts Forever
description: BY the time Grandiflora, a popular gardening center in Red Hook, N.Y., opened its doors at 9 a.m. last Sunday, a line of customers had already begun to form. After a week in which a freakishly late snowstorm had hit the New York area, the latest cruel joke of an interminable winter, the sun was out, the temperatures were in the 60's, and it appeared that a long-delayed spring had finally arrived.

title: Arab TV Broadcast Is Said to Show Hussein on April 9
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  An Arab television network broadcast a videotape today of a man it said was Saddam Hussein rallying the faithful on the streets of Baghdad last week. But American intelligence analysts were skeptical that the tape was what it purported to be.

title: A New Look at Arab-Israeli Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Win-Now Redskins Try A Free-Agent Face Lift
description: Steve Spurrier left his hotel room a few weeks ago, wandering across a dew-covered courtyard toward a gathering of his peers at the N.F.L. owners meetings in Phoenix. Upon his fashionably late arrival, Spurrier, the coach of the Washington Redskins, noticed Dallas Cowboys Coach Bill Parcells seated at a table with cameras, notepads and questioners for as far as the eye could see.

title: Huge Gravesite Is Found in Northern Iraq
description: The mounds stretch in rows for more than a quarter mile across the hard, cracked earth at the edge of an industrial park here. Many are covered in weeds; all but two look undisturbed.

title: HIBERNIA, LOUISIANA BANK, PLANS TO ELIMINATE 290 JOBS
description: Hibernia, Louisiana's biggest bank, plans to eliminate 5 percent of its work force to cut costs after first-quarter earnings fell 5.1 percent and lending money became less profitable. About half of the 290 jobs that will be cut are vacant, Hibernia said. Expenses related to eliminating the jobs will reduce earnings in the second quarter by $3.9 million, or 3 cents a share. Net income in the first quarter fell to $56.2 million, or 36 cents a share, from $59.2 million, or 37 cents a share, a year earlier, as homeowners paid down more of their mortgages, the company said. Revenue fell 3.9 percent, to $246 million from $256.1 million. The bank has $17.7 billion in assets and about 260 branches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, THOMAS D.
description: FLYNN-Thomas D. The President and Trustees of Columbia University express deep sorrow at the passing of our Trustee Emeritus, Thomas D. Flynn, a graduate of the Columbia Business School, Class of 1939. He was a respected colleague whose leadership as a University Trustee was marked by enthusiasm and distinction. Columbia University extends its profound sympathy to his wife Mrs. Harriet Flynn and their family. Lee C. Bollinger, President of the University David J. Stern, Chair of the Trustees

title: Lawmakers Take Aim At Syrians
description: Lawmakers in both parties say they will renew a push for economic and diplomatic penalties against Syria when Congress returns at the end of the month, reviving proposals resisted by the White House last year.

title: A Wealth of Worthy but Neglected Theater Songs
description: The cabaret singer Karen Akers has a two-decade history of shining a light on worthy songs that might otherwise have disappeared. And in her wonderful new show, ''Theater Songs,'' which plays through May 24 at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel (5 West 44th Street), the singer ventures further into obscure territory than she has ever gone before.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MASSACHUSETTS: HARVARD'S SEXUAL ASSAULT POLICY A committee investigating Harvard University's policy on sexual misconduct is recommending that the university adopt new preventative education programs and create an office to prevent and investigate sexual assaults. The proposals mandate a night of sexual assault education during freshman orientation and immediate access to counseling for victims. The committee was formed in response to anger over a policy approved last May that required students who file misconduct complaints to provide "corroborating evidence," like witnesses.

title: Report Says British Officers Helped Kill Ulster Catholics
description: Officers from British Army intelligence and the Royal Ulster Constabulary in Northern Ireland actively helped Protestant guerrillas kill Roman Catholics in the late 1980's, a report by Britain's senior police official said today.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Let the Power Games End
description: After a scandalous binge of executive back-stabbing, mismanagement and conflicts of interest, the United States Olympic Committee is proposing to put itself out its misery with a wholesale revamping of the organization's bloated power structure.

title: Net Up at Fortune Brands
description: Fortune Brands Inc., the maker of Jim Beam bourbon, said today that first-quarter earnings rose 18 percent after it completed the acquisition of the cabinet maker Omega Group. Net income rose to $99.5 million, or 66 cents a share, from $84 million, or 55 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 9.6 percent, to $1.39 billion from $1.27 billion, the company said. The shares rose $2.43, or 5.5 percent, to $46.60 a share.

title: TAURASI NAMED NATION'S TOP PLAYER
description: Diana Taurasi, the 6-foot junior guard who led Connecticut to its second straight N.C.A.A. title, has been named winner of the Honda Award as the nation's outstanding women's college basketball player.

title: Small Opera On a Big Stage
description: Few subjects are more operatic than sex and violence. Yet few operas are less melodramatic, on the surface, than Benjamin Britten's ''Rape of Lucretia.'' For one thing, it's small: a chamber opera with an orchestra of only 13 instruments. It's stylized with a formal, distanced tone. The composer even draws a veil of music, poetry and Christian moralizing over the title event.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NORMAN G.
description: COHEN-Norman G. The Board and Staff of The Children's Museum of Manhattan mourns the passing of the beloved father of our estteemed board member Nancy Cohen Roberts. We extend our deepest condolences. Judy Hannan, Chairman Laurie Tisch Sussman Honorary Chairman Andrew Ackerman Executive Director

title: 3 Congressmen Urge Arafat to Compromise
description: Three United States congressmen met with Yasir Arafat today, piercing the Bush administration's boycott of the Palestinian leader as he continued to dicker with his prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, over the composition of a new government.

title: Russia Approves Private Pipe To Carry Oil Bound for U.S.
description: Dropping its previous opposition, the Russian government gave a green light today to plans for a privately owned oil pipeline to Murmansk that would carry oil bound for the United States.

title: Philadelphia Drops a Manager Of Five Elementary Schools
description: For 4,500 pupils at five Philadelphia elementary schools, the privatization experiment that began last fall has ended. Philadelphia school officials announced on Wednesday that they were canceling their contract with Chancellor Beacon Academies, the company that was managing those schools, because it had not made significant educational improvements here.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Retailer's Sales Decline
description: The retailer Pinault-Printemps-Redoute said its revenue for the first quarter fell 6.1 percent, to 6.3 billion euros ($6.88 billion) from 6.71 billion euros one year earlier. The Paris company said its core retail stores performed well, but were hurt by poor performance in Rexel, an electrical products distributor. Pinault owns 73 percent of Rexel and is expected to sell the business. The chief executive, Serge Weinberg, has already sold the company's finance and office supply units as part of a strategy to focus on consumer goods and provide funds for a $4 billion bid for the Gucci Group. Pinault already owns 61 percent of Gucci. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Time to Crack Down On Field Invaders
description: IT would seem more than inconvenient to build a fence and dig a moat around the ball field to keep unruly fans at bay. It has happened with soccer pitches in some Latin American countries, but would it work in, say, Yankee Stadium or Dodger Stadium -- or, more to the immediate point, U.S. Cellular Field, the home of the Chicago White Sox? Or should officials be permitted to arm themselves with some type of defensive weapon, like Mace?

title: FAMILY FARE
description: The Devil And the Don

title: Kurt Schwitters -- Collages, Paintings, Drawings, Objects, Ephemera
description: Ubu Gallery

title: China Cautions Officials Not to Hide SARS Cases
description: BEIJING, April 18  China's top leaders, seeking to quell an international uproar over the honesty of their medical reports as well as to halt a dangerous new virus, have issued their strongest warning yet about severe acute respiratory syndrome and have explicitly cautioned officials not to cover up the spread of the disease.

title: Some Shareholders Are Far From Preferred
description: THINGS are looking up for the Perini Corporation, a major construction company. ''The last three years we had very good income,'' said Robert Band, the company's president. This month Perini was one of the first companies to get a government contract for work in Iraq, which could be worth $100 million. The company's common stock is up 38 percent this month.

title: Splish, Splash: Love Those Fords
description: JOHN CLIFFORD was ready to cross Mill Creek, in Haverford, Pa., and the absence of a bridge did not deter him. He drove his Buick LeSabre down the bank and plowed across, producing a robust spray and emerging 20 feet later.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: IVORY COAST: UNITY AS DEATH TOLL MOUNTS The country's new unity government held its first cabinet meeting with newly sworn-in rebel ministers, even as the rebels accused the government of new attacks in the western region. The new government includes members of the governing party, the political opposition and rebels. The coalition is part of French-brokered January peace accords aimed at ending six months of civil war in Ivory Coast, the world's top cocoa-producing nation. "We are going to live together and build peace," a government spokesman said. But a rebel spokesman said government-sponsored helicopter attacks had killed 28 people in the last 10 days and injured almost 100 others, many of them civilians. France, which has 3,000 troops monitoring the cease-fire, confirmed the attacks. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOLLENDER, SELMA
description: HOLLENDER-Selma. Your smile is forever in our hearts. Alex, Jane, Beth, Wendy, Herb, Pearl

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOENWETTER, SUMNER EDWARD
description: SCHOENWETTER-Sumner Edward, on April 15th, of lymphoma. Husband of Susan Lehman, brother of Cynthia Sobel, brother-in-law of Gerald Sobel, uncle to Adam and Melissa Sobel. Artist, musician and eternal scholar. As Sumner Crane, his composition ''Jon Gavanti'' and Mars group's recordings stand as monuments of No-Wave music. Service Monday, April 21, 4-6 PM at Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street.

title: Criticism Mounts in Ontario Over High Rate of SARS Cases
description: TORONTO, April 18  As Ontario health officials braced today for a wider outbreak of SARS around Toronto in the coming days, criticism is beginning to mount that political and health care leaders have made some critical miscalculations in their attempts to avert a broader epidemic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORNAMBE, ROSE MARIE (NEE GRESIO)
description: TORNAMBE - Rose Marie (nee Gresio) suddenly on April 14, 2003. Beloved wife to the late Dr. Paul Tornambe. Loving mother of Paul, Eugene, Ronald and Robert. Cherished grandmother of seven. Funeral on Monday, 8:30 A.M., from the Arlington Funeral Home, Inc., 83-15 Parsons Boulevard, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432 (at Grand Central Parkkway). Mass of Christian Burial at 9:30 A.M., at the St. Nicholas of Tolentine R.C. Church. Interment in Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Heart Association in her memory. Visitation Saturday only 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Madden Comes Up Big as Devils Move To Second Round
description: John Madden said he had read the newspaper clippings before the Devils' first-round series against the Boston Bruins. ''The ones that said I'm only 5-foot-10 and 190 pounds,'' Madden said. The ones, in other words, that implied that Madden's lack of size could be exploited by Boston's 6-4, 220-pound Joe Thornton, who had finished third in the National Hockey League in scoring with 101 points this season.

title: Corrections
description: APublic Lives profile on April 9 about Justin Ferate, a tour guide who prepared the licensing test for sightseeing guides in New York City, misspelled the name adopted by a group of performers in tribute to a Broadway musical of 1900. They were the Florodora sextet, not Floradora.

title: Iraq to Run On Dollars Till It Gets New Currency
description: As the focus in Iraq shifts from waging war to paying wages, the Bush administration plans to run Iraq on dollars until it fosters a replacement for today's nearly worthless ''Saddam dinars.''

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SINGAPORE: CHIP MAKER'S LOSS DECLINES Chartered Semiconductor, the world's third-largest chip subcontractor, said its first-quarter loss narrowed to $75.7 million, compared with a loss of $128.4 million a year earlier. Revenue rose 23.1 percent, to $103.8 million. The company said customers remained cautious but that it expected demand for its high-end semiconductors to increase its capacity use this quarter. At the same time, Chartered faces increasing competition from Malaysia and China for older, less-sophisticated chips. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Baghdad Peace: Made in Kosovo
description: BAGHDAD, April 18  One of the signal accomplishments of the American military has been its ability to rapidly shift its focus from fighting Saddam Hussein's Republican Guard to securing Iraq's capital. American forces that were blasting Iraqi tanks and paramilitary fighters less than two weeks ago are now patrolling Baghdad's neighborhoods, seeking out new Iraqi civic leaders and trying to ensure that the capital is sufficiently stable for the reconstruction that lies ahead.

title: For Third Time in a Year, Brazilian Airline Loses Chief
description: The management of Varig, Brazil's flagship airline, has been thrown into turmoil by the departure of its third chief executive in less than a year, further endangering the government's efforts to spare the struggling airline from bankruptcy through a merger with its main rival, TAM Linhas Areas.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Struggling Rapper in a Hood Filled With Porsches
description: Before it chokes on its own formula, the hip-hop comedy ''Malibu's Most Wanted'' tosses around enough zany notions about race, pop culture attitudes and stereotypes to prove that it has at least half a brain in its head. That's considerably more gray matter than can be found in most teenage-slanted comedies nowadays. The lightning-tongued movie, embellished with joking rap parodies, stars Jamie Kennedy as Brad Gluckman, known as B-Rad, the privileged white Los Angeles rapper he created for the WB television comedy series ''JKX: The Jamie Kennedy Experiment.'' At his most feverish, B-Rad, who lurches around gracelessly under a baseball cap worn sideways, suggests a callow, inept Eminem imitator.

title: Rumsfeld Looking for Help In Finding Outlawed Arms
description: Even with coalition forces now controlling most of Iraq, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that the United States would still need the help of Iraqis to find banned weapons in their country.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: MERCURY SHARES PLUNGE ON EARNINGS FORECAST Shares of Mercury Computer Systems Inc., whose products are used to create radar and sonar images for the military, fell as much as 30 percent yesterday after the company said that its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings might be 16 cents to 20 cents a share. Shares fell $6.88, or almost 26 percent, to $19.78. The shares had declined 13 percent this year. Robert Stone, a media and electronics analyst with the SG Cowen Securities Corporation, had estimated earnings of 26 cents for the fourth quarter. Mr. Stone, who owns no shares in the company, cut his forecast yesterday to 17 cents, on revenue of $46 million, and downgraded it to market perform from outperform.   (Bloomberg News)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Whitney Museum's decision to abandon an expansion designed by the Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas misstated his involvement with Prada stores. Although he designed the one in SoHo and another being built in Los Angeles, he did not create Prada's signature lime green dcor; it was the work of the Italian architect Roberto Baciocchi.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: BRIDGEPORT: MAN PLEADS GUILTY IN GIRL'S DEATH A 25-year-old Greenwich man pleaded guilty yesterday to federal charges in the death of a 13-year-old girl he met on the Internet. The man, Saul Dos Reis, admitted he had gone to Danbury to have sex with the girl, Christina Long. Prosecutors said they would seek a prison term of 25 years, the maximum allowed for two counts involving interstate travel to engage in unlawful sex with a minor. He is to be sentenced on July 7. In March, Mr. Dos Reis was convicted on state charges of manslaughter and sexual assault in the death. (AP)

title: L.I. Principal Is Charged With Possession of Crack
description: The principal of a Long Island high school was arrested Wednesday night after police officers found half a gram of crack cocaine inside his car, the authorities said today.

title: Chief Resigns at Primedia; Main Owner Focuses on Sale
description: Thomas S. Rogers, the chief executive of Primedia, which publishes New York and Seventeen magazines, resigned yesterday over plans by the company's controlling investor to dismantle the business he was hired to build.

title: Democrats' Lost Voice
description: To the Editor:

title: At a French Trial, a Tale Unfolds of Graft on High
description: A chapter of France's recent history is on trial in the Palace of Justice these days, unfolding like a Zola epic, with wealth, privilege, careerism and corruption.

title: In Effort to Restore Spending to the State Budget, the Vexing Question is How
description: The Democratic leader of the State Assembly and the Republican leader of the State Senate put out a grandiose statement on the eve of their 12-day vacation: they vowed to restore $1.9 billion in state spending but refused to say how to pay for it.

title: Religion and Science
description: To the Editor:

title: A Brisk Tour, Concluding With a Boa
description: The mezzo-soprano Susan Graham, for her first recital at Carnegie Hall, took the audience on a tour of several worlds Monday -- those of 19th-century Gypsies by way of Brahms, Viennese proto-Serialists by way of Berg, and several sides of Paris through cycles by Debussy and Poulenc and operetta arias by Messager and Simons. She moved easily among these styles, always with a sense of when, and in what measure, to address the music with sobriety, playfulness, subtlety or charm. Malcolm Martineau endorsed her interpretive decisions with deft support at the piano.

title: Rejecting The World
description: The Bush administration did the right thing on diesel emissions this week, curbing an important source of air pollution. Yet George Bush has, in general, reneged on the environmental promises of his 2000 campaign. Most notably, he broke his campaign pledge to regulate carbon dioxide emissions, offering instead a purely voluntary -- and therefore, one might have thought, meaningless -- plan to limit global warming.

title: Job-Search Web Site To Seek New Agency
description: Monster, the job-search Web site operated by TMP Worldwide, said unexpectedly yesterday that it had parted ways with Arnold Worldwide in Boston, which had handled its United States account since September 2000.

title: U.S. Captures A Half Brother Of Iraqi Chief
description: With still no sign of Saddam Hussein himself, American Special Forces here today captured one of his half brothers, a former intelligence chief who is on a list of 55 Iraqis wanted by the United States authorities.

title: Forced to Catch Up, Islanders Run Out of Time
description: The series followed form, after all. The Ottawa Senators found ways to score goals and the Islanders, wiped out by a season-long chase, huffed and puffed while hoping for an upset.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Business Briefing column yesterday about the first-quarter performance of Reuters Group referred incorrectly to the results and misstated the dollar equivalent. The company reported 670 million in revenue, not in profit -- the equivalent of $1.05 billion, not $91 billion.

title: Across and Down, Competitively
description: WALKING into the 26th American Crossword Puzzle Tournament one recent Saturday morning in Stamford, Conn., I was greeted by a fashion show.
