description: Theater

title: South Korea Aide Sees Long Road Ahead in Talks With North
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 18  South Korea's newly appointed ambassador to the United States predicted today that talks with North Korea on the nuclear crisis would devolve into a "long, arduous process" with no certainty of success or even advance understanding of what the North wants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIGNER, HERBERT
description: SIGNER-Herbert. Age 86, on Wednesday, April 16, 2003, of Rockville, Maryland, and formerly of New York City. Beloved husband of the late Esther Signer, devoted father of Robert Signer and Deborah Signer. Also survived by six grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Monday, April 21, at 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York, New York. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, New York.

title: Hero in a White Lab Coat at Ground Zero forAsthma
description: IN a comic book world, James DeFranco would be the fair-haired muscleman prying loose the evil boa constrictor from the throat of the South Bronx.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Flow of Money to Stock Funds Is Most in a Year
description: With war winding down, investors have poured more money into stock mutual funds than they have in a year, according to the latest weekly data.

title: Colgate, Aided by Profit Margin And Sales, Posts 12% Net Gain
description: Colgate-Palmolive said yesterday that its net income increased by about 12 percent in the first quarter, lifted by both sales growth and a record gross profit margin.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Coca-Cola is taking lines from a classic in its campaign to stimulate a thirst for Diet Coke.
description: TWO decades ago, the Pepsi-Cola Company peddled Diet Pepsi with a campaign that carried the theme ''Now you see it, now you don't.'' These days, those words could be used to describe the status of advertising for a competitive brand, Diet Coke, which has appeared, disappeared and reappeared with bewildering irregularity as the account changed agencies three times in five years.

title: Islamic World Less Welcoming to American Scholars
description: Elizabeth C. Stone, a professor of anthropology, had planned to spend the summer excavating a 2,600-year-old city surrounding an ancient citadel in eastern Turkey. But like scores of other American professors, she was forced to cancel her trip as American tanks rumbled toward Baghdad.

title: Book Examines Nevada Test That Left Fallout in Troy, N.Y.
description: Fifty years ago this month, a nuclear bomb test went awry in the desert near Las Vegas, and the result was fallout and a substantial radiation dose in an unexpected place -- Troy, N.Y. A new book on the subject relying heavily on declassified documents shows that the Atomic Energy Commission moved quickly to limit public exposure to radioactive fallout near the blast, while the exposure may actually have been larger in Troy, a city next to Albany.

title: Jets Take a Cautious Approach as Draft Nears
description: With two picks in the first round of next weekend's college draft, the Jets are in position to do something dramatic to make everyone forget an off-season that has been marked by unexpected personnel departures.

title: A Physician's Odyssey in a Frozen World
description: Dr. Jerri Nielsen went to the South Pole looking for solitude.

title: Beeskow Journal; Germany's Bleak Display: 6,780 Neo-Nazi Scrawls
description: The vivid mural on the wall in front of the Albert Schweitzer High School here in the former East Germany is a model of multicultural enlightenment, with its pictures of a black child and a white child holding hands in friendship.

title: Some Skeptics Say Arms Hunt Is Fruitless
description: While many analysts say it is just a matter of time before American searchers uncover unconventional arms in Iraq, a few experts consider that unlikely. Before the war, they argued that Iraq probably had no weapons of mass destruction; that is why, they say now, the search has ended so far in failure.

title: Young in the Heartland, Seeking Video Salvation
description: If you're interested in playwriting talent and want to see it muscling toward maturity, you'll find no more fascinating example than ''Stone Cold Dead Serious,'' a play by Adam Rapp receiving a stirringly acted production at the Chashama Theater.

title: BRIEFLY:SEOUL : Abstention from rights vote draws fire
description: In a move that has drawn fierce criticism from human rights campaigners, South Korea has joined 13 other countries in abstaining from voting on a UN resolution to condemn North Korea for "widespread and grave" abuses.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: New Effort On State Budget
description: Gov. Mike Huckabee said he would call the General Assembly back into session within weeks to try to enact a $7 billion state budget. The legislative session ended on Wednesday night after Republicans and conservative Democrats in the House blocked consideration of a tax increase to finance appropriations. The impasse leaves state agencies without spending authority in the fiscal year beginning July 1. House Republican leaders said they preferred to tap reserve funds rather than raise new revenue. Democrats hold large majorities in both houses.

title: Gay Partners, Too, Are Separated by War, and by Their Need for Secrecy
description: Forget the lavish hugs dockside, the bands and cameras and teary-eyed spouses. This couple's reunion will be different.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Regulation Of Child Support Collection Agencies
description: A group of City Council members unveiled two bills yesterday intended to regulate private child support collection companies that pocket much of the money they were hired to collect. The bills, which grew out of a two-week investigation into how the companies do business, would set a 15 percent cap on the amount the companies could charge customers and require them to disclose, in writing, the terms of contracts and all fees associated with their service. Since many of the companies are private and not regulated by federal law, customers -- often poor single parents -- have little protection from those who slip in extra charges and hidden contract terms, the council members said. Nicole M. Christian (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Growth Estimate Cut
description: The Italian government cut its 2003 growth forecast in half, but some economists say the figure is still too optimistic. The Italian economy will grow 1.1 percent this year, the finance ministry said in its quarterly bulletin. The forecast is in line with what the International Monetary Fund is expecting for the Italian economy and comes after a government prediction made in September for growth this year of 2.3 percent. ''The cut is an indication that the government is coming to terms with reality, but 1.1 percent is still on the optimistic side,'' said Fabio Scacciavillani, an independent economist. Eric Sylvers (NYT)

title: At Journey's End, a Marine Is Mourned
description: The distance between the front stoop of Riayan Tejeda's childhood and the door to the military recruiting office in Washington Heights is 206 steps, give or take a stride. The 206 steps also mark the distance between boyhood and manhood; hard-knock neighborhood and war-torn country; life and death.

title: And the Winner is Bechtel
description: Awarding the first major contract for reconstruction in Iraq to a politically connected American company under restricted bidding procedures sends a deplorable message to a skeptical world. Critics of the invasion often say it was launched for the control of oil and other venal motives, not for the benefit of the Iraqi people or to rid the world of a growing menace. The Bush administration should work hard to dispel that mistaken notion and should bend over backward to avoid reinforcing it. Yet the award of a contract worth up to $680 million to the Bechtel Group of San Francisco in a competition limited to a handful of American companies can only add to the impression that the United States seeks to profit from the war it waged.

title: Police Appeal for Public's Help To Find Serial Robber in Bronx
description: Detectives asked for the public's help yesterday in finding an armed robber who is stalking elderly apartment dwellers in the Bronx. The robber catches his victims off guard by offering to help carry their groceries, the police said.

title: Young and Hungry Captives

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Central Banker Extends Term
description: The European Central Bank president, Wim Duisenberg, left, has formally accepted a European Union request that he postpone retirement for as long as it takes to find a successor. Mr. Duisenberg said he was willing to stay beyond his planned July 9 retirement date to ensure a smooth transition, according to a letter he sent Thursday to Prime Minister Costas Simitis of Greece, who currently holds the European Union's rotating presidency. European governments asked Mr. Duisenberg to postpone his retirement to give his designated successor, the Bank of France governor, Jean-Claude Trichet, time to clear his name in a false-accounting trial, or for governments to find someone else.

description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have asked a federal judge to bar the public from the courtroom next week when an undercover police officer testifies in a drug trial, saying that revealing his identity could endanger him.

title: The Military in Transition: From Combat to Containment
description: Defeating the Iraqi military and putting an end to the Baath Party power structure is really only half the battle. With the end of large-scale hostilities comes the need for street-level security -- block by block, town by town. Although allied troops must remain prepared for combat, the main enemy is no longer an opposing platoon or even a die-hard enemy soldier, but rather civil disorder. Below is a look at some of the tools and tactics the military uses to create and maintain stability.

title: The True Good Samaritans
description: The Christian evangelist Franklin Graham recently announced that his relief agency, Samaritan's Purse, is ''poised and ready'' to bring humanitarian aid to the Iraqi people. That has prompted critics to raise serious questions about the involvement in Iraq of Mr. Graham, an emerging icon of American civil religion. But since no one doubts the Iraqis could use the aid, Mr. Graham should go -- and prove to the Arab world that he's there to help, not crusade.

title: Rediscovering Lost Works
description: Leon Botstein has staked out his own territory: little-known, large-scale symphonic literature of the 19th and 20th century. The latest rediscovered putative masterpiece was the first symphony of Gavriil Popov, which the conductor and the American Symphony Orchestra unveiled at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night in a program titled "The Circle of Shostakovich." Mr. Botstein showed his refreshingly idiosyncratic programming tendencies by playing the symphony as the first piece of the evening: a massive, sometimes unwieldy curtain-raiser, a good 45 minutes long.</P.

title: Town Loner Charged in Chilling Case of Sexual Captivity
description: Every community has its resident crank: a junk-hoarding, pigeon-feeding loner whose behavior might be irksome but is seldom menacing. Here in this upscale suburb of Syracuse, John T. Jamelske, 67, could often be seen sifting through cans at the local recycling center or driving along Route 92 in one of his rusty old clunkers, his white hair flying in the wind. ''He was a strange bird, but we have a lot of strange birds around here,'' said James DiStefano, the town supervisor.

title: A new museum on the Hudson fosters a local cultural renaissance
description: NEW YORK  More than a century after the American landscape painters Thomas Cole, Frederick Church and Albert Bierstadt immortalized the rural beauty of the Hudson River Valley in their art, this scenic region of New York State is enjoying a cultural renaissance. And Beacon, a former hat factory town 60 miles north of Manhattan with a population of 13,000, stands at its epicenter.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Utility Sheds Unit
description: The FirstEnergy Corporation, a utility holding company, gave its stake in the Argentine power company Emdersa to a former subsidiary after failing to sell the business. First Energy tendered the shares to GPU Argentina Holdings Inc., which is now independently controlled. First Energy said the move would reduce its second-quarter profit by $63 million, or 21 cents a share. The noncash costs represent the value FirstEnergy had placed on Emdersa and a related foreign-exchange loss, the company said. GPU Argentina was spun off by FirstEnergy and is now controlled by a director, John T. Banigan, who will decide what to do with Emdersa, a FirstEnergy spokeswoman, Kristen Baird, said. FirstEnergy acquired Emdersa as part of its $10.8 billion purchase of GPU Inc. in 2001. The company tried to find a buyer for the Argentine power distributor last year and failed because of the country's financial crisis, FirstEnergy said.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Washington: Space Telescope Delay
description: Because of problems with a rocket, NASA postponed the launching of an infrared telescope that is to be the last of its so-called Great Observatories, joining the Hubble Space Telescope and the Chandra X-Ray Telescope. The flight of the Space Infrared Telescope Facility, or Sirtf, will occur no earlier than mid-August, the agency announced. One of nine solid-fuel booster motors attached to the Boeing Delta II rocket must be replaced because of defects. To avoid interfering with the launching of two Mars ground rover spacecraft, scheduled for June 7 and June 25, the agency has moved the Sirtf mission to late summer. Warren E. Leary (NYT)

He leaves his wife of fifty-one years, Selma (nee Gruenstein); son, Robert Myles Jr. and wife Jill Winitzer, daughter Amy Ruth and husband John Klossner; daughter Linda Ellen and husband Mark Minton; grandchildren Jeremy, Aliza, Lane, Chhany, Benjamin and Surya. He founded Lee Myles Advertising Firm. Visiting at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison at 81 St, Saturday April 19, 7-9PM with service Sunday 11:30 AM Burial private. Contributions in his memory may be made to Association for Help of Retarded Children, 200 Park Avenue South, New York, NY 10003.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Appeal Denied

He has consistently said the charge was fabricated. Mr. Anwar has one appeal, to Federal Court, Malaysia's highest court. He has just finished serving a concurrent sentence for corruption. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Symbolic Day But No Deal
description: The British and Irish governments waited without success to obtain a disarmament statement from the Irish Republican Army needed to break the stalemated Northern Ireland peace process and restore the suspended power-sharing government in Belfast created by the so-called Good Friday agreement five years ago. David Trimble, leader of the province's largest Protestant party, the Ulster Unionists, complained that a settlement was being held up by ''a couple of hundred hoods.'' London and Dublin are proposing a set of concessions on matters of interest to the Irish republican movement like the demilitarization of the North and the promise of no prosecution for I.R.A. members wanting to return from abroad, but they say the I.R.A. must first declare an end to its 30-year-war against the British and dismantle its arsenal of weapons. The proposal will likely be shelved next week if no I.R.A. pledge emerges. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: NO INFLATION TARGET Under pressure to take more measures to jump-start Japan's economy, Toshihiko Fukui, the central bank governor, instead squashed speculation he might endorse the adoption of an inflation target. Mr. Fukui said inflation targets are "one important tool" for a central bank to consider, but adopting one in Japan now would prove fruitless. Like his predecessor, Masaru Hayami, Mr. Fukui said the banks are too busy writing off their nonperforming loans to use any fresh liquidity to create new loans.   Ken Belson (NYT)

description: Qwest Communications International, the largest local telephone company in Minnesota, has failed to win support from state regulators in its bid to sell long-distance service there.

title: Tape Shows Hussein But Resolves Nothing
description: As the Bush administration continued efforts to find whether President Saddam Hussein of Iraq was alive or dead, an Abu Dhabi television station broadcast a videotape showing Mr. Hussein greeting well-wishers in a Baghdad neighborhood. The station said it was told the tape was made on April 9, the day Mr. Hussein's statue in a central Baghdad square was pulled down. American intelligence officials expressed doubt about the date of the tape.

description: Gov. George E. Pataki issued a direct challenge to legislative leaders today, vetoing a bill that would have given school districts an extra two weeks to present their budgets to voters.

description: Standard & Poor's has lowered the credit and debt ratings of the AAR Corporation, which leases and maintains aircraft parts for airlines, to noninvestment grade because airlines are cutting schedules and grounding planes, reducing demand for the company's services.

description: The killing was strange from the start, and has gotten only stranger. A bouncer stabbed to death, some said, because of the city's new ban on smoking in bars. A missing weapon. Three siblings arrested, then released, then revealed to be the children of a Chinatown gangster.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Feb. 25 about the choice of a product called FieldTurf as the synthetic surface for Giants Stadium misstated the number of teams in the National Football League that will play next season on AstroPlay, a competing product. None will, not seven. A representative of FieldTurf pointed out the error a week after the article appeared. This correction was delayed for research on the use of various synthetic surfaces, and on surfaces used for practice.

title: Man Eyed in Drug-Rap Inquiry Pleads Guilty to Gun Charges
description: A man who federal investigators have said is the link between drug trafficking in New York and the rap music industry pleaded guilty to federal gun possession charges yesterday in federal court in Baltimore.

title: Wanted: More Nurses
description: To the Editor:

title: California Man Arrested in Death of Wife
description: Scott Peterson, the husband of a woman eight months pregnant who vanished on Christmas Eve, was arrested today and will be charged with murder in connection with her death and that of their baby, prosecutors said.

title: Quiet Investor Taking Stake In Korean Oil
description: Who is Sovereign Asset Management, and what does it want with SK Corporation, South Korea's biggest oil refiner?

title: Samsung Profits Fall 41%, but Investors See Recovery Ahead
description: Samsung Electronics posted a 41 percent drop in first-quarter profit today but said it had overcome ''economic instability'' at home and abroad.

title: Killing of Boy Adds to Scandal in Florida
description: In the latest case of a youngster's falling through the cracks of the Florida child welfare system, a 5-year-old boy was beaten to death on Tuesday. His father, in whom the state had placed his care without a thorough check that would have disclosed a violent criminal past, has been arrested and charged with murdering him.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 20 about the Marxist historian Herbert Aptheker misstated the number of volumes in his ''Documentary History of the Negro People in the United States'' and the title of his doctoral dissertation. It is seven, not three; his dissertation is ''American Negro Slave Revolts,'' not ''Black Slave Revolts.'' The article also referred incompletely to Mr. Aptheker's editing of the writing of W. E. B. DuBois. Besides correspondence, Mr. Aptheker edited 40 volumes of DuBois's published writings, including an annotated bibliography.

title: Get Recycling Out of the Dumps
description: Last year, Mayor Michael Bloomberg told New York City residents to put away their bins for plastics and glass and suspended that part of municipal recycling. The move was supposed to save money and buy time to improve the programs. But it turns out that the savings were mostly illusory, and the Bloomberg administration's commitment to sorting out its trash problems seems shaky.

title: Veterans and Priorities
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Are Unfazed By Twins and Ballpark
description: Three losses in the first week of October ruined last season for the Yankees. They have lost only three times since then, and there is no telling when they might lose again.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's kind of hard to feel sorry for yourself when so many people were hurt worse or died.''

title: De-fense! De-fense! De-fense!
description: I don't think President Bush is going to war with Syria anytime soon, but I can understand why he might be tempted. Not just because it's another terrorist-coddling, weapons-hoarding, dissident-torturing, neighbor-molesting, America-hating despotism. Not because Mr. Bush peaked too soon in Iraq and needs another victory to carry him into 2004, or because he hopes to distract us from the con artistry of his economic policy.

title: Israel Offers Concessions, but Palestinians Are Wary
description: With the Bush administration preparing to push a new Middle East peace initiative, Israel said today that it was willing to pull back troops, release some Palestinian prisoners and ease travel restrictions if an emerging Palestinian government made a serious effort to halt violence.

title: 'Just Shoot Me'
description: Aweek into the air war in Iraq, as the upper decks of the carrier Abraham Lincoln bustled in preparation for a heavy night of strike fighter missions, a petty officer, Naveed Muhammad, quietly took off his shoes and laid out a green prayer rug on the floor of the ship's chapel.

title: Kentucky Signs Smith to Extension
description: Tubby Smith, who led Kentucky to a 32-4 record this season, signed an eight-year contract extension yesterday. The deal will be worth as much as $2.5 million a year and will make him the highest-paid coach in college basketball, the university said.

description: SONN-Carl Robinson. August 1, 1929 to April 19, 199

description: Joseph Jones, an assistant coach at Villanova for the past six seasons, was named the men's basketball coach at Columbia.

title: Surrealist Treasures Sold Despite French Protests
description: Andr Breton's vast collection of Surrealist art, photographs, books and manuscripts, which was sold in a 10-day auction that ended here late Thursday, fetched the equivalent of $50.1 million, around 50 percent more than the firm running the auction, CalmelsCohen, had estimated.

title: In Military Wards, Questions and Fears From the Wounded
description: Lance Cpl. James Klingel of the Marines finds himself lost in thought these days when he is not struggling with the physical pain, his mind wandering from images of his girlfriend back in Ohio to the sight of an exploding fireball to the sounds of twisting metal.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Cellphone Subsidy
description: NTT DoCoMo Inc. will help defray costs to develop newer handsets for two years, signaling optimism that lower-priced phones with longer battery life will spur demand for its high-speed wireless service. DoCoMo, Japan's biggest mobile phone operator, will subsidize half the development costs at handset makers such as the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company and the NEC Corporation through April 2005, said Shiro Tsuda, a senior executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFRAK, SAMUEL J. ''TIGER,''
description: LeFRAK-Samuel J. ''Tiger,'' friend, dear sweet man, your larger-than-life life ended, know again my respect and gratitude. You stood by me in 1978, sheltered our apartments in your management, and by seeking me for your staff, strengthened my resolve. You said we ''built for midgets''-we are all midgets compared with you. To Ethel, your children and their children, the Maidmans send their condolences. Richard and Gail Maidman

title: After All These Eons, She's Still a Tunic-Ripper
description: The understatement of several millennia: Helen of Troy was a dude magnet.

title: Corrections

He was a contributor; the author is William Rivers Pitt.

title: Watch the War? I'm in It
description: Satellite phones are like the voice of God in Baghdad, a city where the phone lines have been down for weeks. If an unlucky soul should happen to pull one out on the street, he would be instantly swamped by an awestruck crowd, begging with near religious fervor to make a call.

title: Texas Reactor Is Leaking Cooling Water From Its Base
description: A nuclear reactor in Texas is leaking cooling water from the bottom of its giant reactor vessel, a development that experts view with concern because they have never seen it before, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: No Inflation Target
description: Under pressure to take more measures to jump-start Japan's economy, Toshihiko Fukui, the central bank governor, instead squashed speculation he might endorse the adoption of an inflation target. Mr. Fukui said inflation targets are ''one important tool'' for a central bank to consider, but adopting one in Japan now would prove fruitless. Like his predecessor, Masaru Hayami, Mr. Fukui said the banks are too busy writing off their nonperforming loans to use any fresh liquidity to create new loans. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Brazil to Let Squatters Own Homes
description: For more than a century, the residents of Brazil's hillside and waterfront squatter settlements have been clamoring to have their occupancy rights recognized by law. Now, in one of its boldest steps on behalf of some of Brazil's poorest people, the new government is promising them formal title to their homes.

title: Anxiety in the Air
description: My fingerprints are on file with the F.B.I., safety officers pat me down each day on the way to work, I'm separated from co-workers and customers by a bulletproof door and government decree, and my seatmate might be packing heat: my profession has certainly changed. As an airline pilot, I know these and other new security measures are necessary. But for me, ''security'' recently took on new meaning. Now I'm concerned about job security.

title: Legal Aid Programs Challenge Restrictions That Hinder Class-Action Suits
description: A lawsuit being heard in federal court in Brooklyn seeks to overturn federal rules that block legal aid programs that accept taxpayer money from filing class-action suits, lobbying or representing immigrants without green cards.

title: No Criminal Charges Seen For Driver of Runaway Bus
description: The driver of a runaway bus that plowed through three blocks of a residential street in Queens on Thursday will not face criminal charges in connection with the incident, the authorities said yesterday.

title: F.D.A. Approval Of Nasal Vaccine For Flu Expected
description: Every year, tens of millions of Americans roll up their sleeves for sometimes painful flu shots. The Food and Drug Administration is expected soon to approve a painless alternative -- a flu vaccine squirted into the nose rather than injected.

description: Far from this Nigerian capital, in a provincial town called Sagbama on the edge of the oil state Bayelsa, the election commission office lies ransacked, with ballot boxes broken and the governor's lodge in embers.

title: National Briefing: West
description: NEVADA: GOLD PRODUCER ACCUSED The world's largest gold producer, the Newmont Mining Corporation , interfered with a state investigation into accusations that it repeatedly discharged dangerous pollution at its open pit Lone Tree mine near Winnemucca, state investigators have found. Newmont officials refused to answer questions from the Division of Environmental Protection until the attorney general's office intervened, state officials wrote. Most of the accusations, by two former employees, could not be substantiated, but that may have been a result of Newmont's stonewalling, an investigative report obtained by The Associated Press said. Newmont denied interfering with the inquiry.   (AP)

description: A study has found that one of every four children in central Harlem has asthma, which is double the rate researchers expected to find and, experts say, is one of the highest rates ever documented for an American neighborhood.

description: As Ontario health officials braced for a wider outbreak of the mysterious respiratory illness around Toronto in the coming days, criticism is beginning to mount that political and health care officials have made some critical miscalculations in their attempts to avert a broader epidemic.

title: Lifting Sanctions on Iraq
description: Everyone understands that the main reason for international economic sanctions on Iraq vanished with the ouster of Saddam Hussein. The world no longer needs to worry about keeping Iraqi oil revenue out of the hands of an ambitious dictator intent on buying weapons. Instead, it should be seeking ways to increase that revenue as quickly as possible to rebuild a shattered country and improve the living standards of its people.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Police Superintendent To Retire
description: Chicago's police superintendent for the last five years, Terry Hillard, announced his retirement, saying that the death of nine officers during his tenure had taken a toll on him. A 35-year veteran of the the department, Mr. Hillard recently mourned the death of one of his closest friends and colleagues, First Deputy Superintendent John Thomas, who died of a heart attack. Mr. Hillard will step down on Aug. 15, just after he turns 60. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: The Latest Theory Is That Theory Doesn't Matter
description: These are uncertain times for literary scholars. The era of big theory is over. The grand paradigms that swept through humanities departments in the 20th century -- psychoanalysis, structuralism, Marxism, deconstruction, post-colonialism -- have lost favor or been abandoned. Money is tight. And the leftist politics with which literary theorists have traditionally been associated have taken a beating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEND, DAVID J.
description: KEND-David J. Of Boca Raton, FL and New York City, died on April 15. Loving husband of Joan; father of Robert and Peter; father-inlaw of Katherine and Diane and grandfather of Sydney, Alyssa and Samuel Kend. He is also survived by his sister Connie and brother-in-law Albert Eisenstat of Atherton, CA and his niece Melissa Blau and nephew Michael Eisenstat. A funeral service will be held at Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, 7240 N. Federal Hwy, Boca Raton, at 11AM, Friday, April 18. Interment is at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, 130-04 Horace Harding Blvd, NYC at 10:30AM, Sunday, April 20. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Boca Raton Hospital for the David J. Kend Fund.

The Rev. R. John Nelson, a Roman Catholic priest, performed a nondenominational ceremony at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York.

description: THERE'S more pep in Patchogue than there ha's been in years. New stores, facades, lighting, walkways, planters and downtown concerts that draw up to 8,000 people are rejuvenating the business district. Restaurants are also pumping new life into the old town.

title: The View/From Jewett City; No Man Is an Island (but He Can Certainly Own One)
description: WHEN Dan Durand was a child, he swam, fished and skated on a lake surrounding a small wooded island in his hometown of Jewett City. Then he grew up and bought the half-acre site, naming it ''Danhattan Island'' and building a house so he could play on Ashland Lake anytime he wanted.

title: My Two Wars
description: A few hundred feet over Nasariya, through smoke rising from a city ablaze, a small shoulder-launched surface-to-air missile went hurtling past the aging CH-46 Sea Knight helicopter in which I was riding to deliver emergency medical care to Marines injured in a firefight. About then it occurred to me: I am too old for war.

title: A Pair of Angels Lose Their Wings
description: NEXT weekend, CBS's ''Touched by an Angel'' will shuffle off this network coil after nine years. It seems amazing that this intensely earnest drama is not only still on the air, but just a few seasons removed from top-five status. A show where angels, week after week, tackled everything from Internet porn to AIDS? To the uninitiated, the whole thing sounded more like a ''Saturday Night Live'' sketch than a prime-time drama.

title: Scenes That Linger: An Iraq Chronicle by the Witnesses to a War
description: The words and pictures tumbled forth 24 hours a day, at once crystal clear and confusing, indelible and unexplained. The images linger: the rolling tank's-eye views, the blinding sandstorms, the firefights, the rescues, the falling statues and the rising flags, the losses and the looting.

description: In the aftermath of a political gathering of Iraqis organized by the United States in Ur, the biblical birthplace of Abraham, the question of who should write a new Iraqi constitution and how it should be adopted is being discussed.

title: When Orchestras Can't Wait for Composers
description: KURT MASUR, during a three-week return to the New York Philharmonic beginning on Thursday, will present two premieres. It was supposed to be three, but Krzysztof Penderecki didn't complete his oratorio ''Phaedra'' in time. The other two works, Lukas Foss's ''Passacaglia, Bachanalia, Passacaglia'' (May 1) and Siegfried Matthus's Concerto for Two (May 7), were originally supposed to be part of Mr. Masur's 75th-birthday and farewell celebration at the Lincoln Center Festival last summer, but they didn't fit into the program for various reasons.

title: Q. & A.

Because my downstairs neighbors have a dog, I began to explore adopting one for myself. When I phoned the landlord, however, he withheld his consent. He thanked me for having the courtesy to ask, but claimed that the neighbors below had never bothered to request permission and that, had they done so, he would not have approved. Can the landlord selectively enforce this clause of the lease? . . . David M. Buss, Manhattan.

title: Following The Bling-Bling: A Rap Auteur
description: IN a converted theater here last week, a cast of 300 locals was trying its best to impersonate a New York hip- hop party. There were big beats, very short shorts and a requisite dollop of gunplay. On the fringes of the action, John Ridley shared a theory about drama and melodrama. Mr. Ridley, 37, wore a gray hooded sweatshirt and a baseball cap that said Las Vegas, and when he turned serious the hood seemed to creep up over his head. He was carrying a hot-pink Britney Spears backpack. Drama, he said, is when you leave some holes in the action. Melodrama, on the other hand, was strictly organ notes and Aaron Spelling.

title: Efficiency And Equity (In the Same Breath)

Nor is there much doubt that the wealthiest would see the greatest gains. Yet meaningful discussion of the potential widening of inequality -- the polarization of rich and poor -- has been sadly lacking.

title: Bellows And Barks To Soothe The Soul

When Ms. Kalman, the author of 12 children's books, was a student at New York University, she abandoned writing -- and a prose style she calls purple -- and turned to drawing. ''I gravitated to people who had light in their work, who weren't nihilists,'' she said. She loves Duchamp's deadpan irony, Chagall's surrealism, with people floating in air, and Ludwig Bemelmans's Madeline books. ''And, of course, Dr. Seuss,'' she said.

In Central Park, Lewis Carroll's March Hare, near 74th Street and Fifth Avenue, is the dandy. On Fifth Avenue, at Bergdorf Goodman, the London milliner Philip Treacy showed his Easter bonnets, and a woman, far left, wore one at Palm Sunday services. title: Powers of Perception
description: Helen Keller has been dead for 35 years, so perhaps it's safe to express an uncharitable thought: her autobiography is not the heartwarming document that children are taught it is. Read it as an adult, and you may find it strangely disturbing. Roger Shattuck, who wrote the introduction and afterword to a new, unexpurgated edition of Keller's ''Story of My Life'' (the book also includes Annie Sullivan's account of her famous pupil's education, Keller's earliest letters, and essays by the book's original editor, the critic John Macy), says it belongs ''next to the epic of Odysseus finding his way home and to the history of Columbus finding his way to a 'New World.' '' This implausible claim is true. The tale of a sightless, soundless, wordless and nearly bestial child's transformation, through instruction in the manual alphabet, into one of the most polished personages of her day has shaped our modern sense of human possibility as definitively as did the ''Odyssey'' and Columbus's discoveries.

title: ABUSES IN FOSTER CARE
description: State files released last week under court order show that nearly one in five children who were placed in what officials regarded as the better foster homes in counties around Newark in 2001 were subsequently abused or seriously neglected. The files, covering 3,800 children, dealt with foster parents considered likely to adopt the children, and the rates of abuse were 30 times what national child experts say is tolerable for child welfare systems. Officials said the statistics proved that the foster care system needed rethinking and fundamental change. The McGreevey administration is expected to propose legislation to create an independent agency to oversee child welfare and investigate abuse. George James

I'm envious, too, but with a great sense of admiration.

title: The Day The Traffic Disappeared
description: When Queen Elizabeth opened the new City Hall in London last year, some observers compared the building, designed by the architect Norman Foster, to a giant eye. And that is exactly what it looks like -- a glassy postmodern eyeball on the south bank of the Thames, staring across the river at its staid Georgian and Victorian neighbors as if to say, ''Welcome to the 21st century.'' Atop the building is a semicircular penthouse called London's Living Room, walled with windows that offer a commanding view of the city below. The idea behind this room is to offer a place for Londoners to gather, if only through the medium of a television camera, for the kinds of serious, big-family sit-downs that go along with governing a sometimes dysfunctional city of more than seven million -- a city so decentralized, in fact, that until three years ago it never had an elected mayor.

title: This Grass Is Always Greener
description: Perhaps synthetic life, like the natural world, has a cycle all its own. For if it seems unlikely that artificial turf -- that banal, discredited, visually displeasing fossil of the space age -- should now be positioned as a philanthropic boon to the world's poor, consider that its unlikely origins were in the world of philanthropy as well. In the 1950's, the Ford Foundation, alarmed by the deteriorating physical fitness of the nation's urban youth, financed an effort by scientists from a subsidiary of Monsanto Industries to develop an all-weather low-maintenance grasslike surface for city kids to play on. By the mid-60's they had come up with a prototype called Chemgrass. The first large-scale installation of a Chemgrass playing field, at the Moses Brown School in Providence, R.I., was a success in every respect, not least because it held up for more than 25 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHSBERG, ABRAHAM
description: FUCHSBERG-Abraham. Senior Partner of Fuchsberg & Fuchsberg, a New York City plaintiff's personal injury firm, passed away on April 15, 2003, at the age of 87. He was one of five siblings (including the late Honorable Jacob D. Fuchsberg, a former Court of Appeals Judge), all of whom had worked together at the firm at one time or another. Abraham served the firm as its Senior Partner for over 25 years. After graduating Magna Cum Laude at the College of the City of New York, Mr. Fuchsberg (pronounced Fyooks-berg) served his country in the U.S. Army and was made an instructor at the Philippine Institute of Armed Forces. After his service Abraham obtained his law degree from St. John's University (1950), when he then joined his brother Jacob in establishing the firm of Fuchsberg & Fuchsberg. The firm became nationally recognized for its representation of the injured, and was the first firm in the United States to ever obtain a million dollar verdict for a personal injury victim. Mr. Fuchsberg devoted his life to the preservation of victims' rights. He served as President of the American Trial Lawyers Civil Justice Foundation, President of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association and President of the Big Apple Pothole Corporation. He was an active member of the Board of Governors for the American Trial Lawyers Association for 35 years, and was selected as a Charter Member of Atla's Presidents Club in 1999. Mr. Fuchsberg was a Patron Founder of the Trial Lawyers for Public Justice. Abraham Fuchsberg was Editor-InChief of the Trial Lawyers Quarterly until 2002, having served in an editorial capacity since 1964. He is the author of ''Modern New York Discovery,'' ''New York Evidence'' and ''Poetic Justice,'' a book of his poetry and insights. He also wrote numerous articles for the New York Law Journal. Mr. Fuchsberg was Associate Editor of the National Trial Lawyer, New York, and a Contributing Editor for Medical Malpractice Law and Strategy. As a public speaker he has addressed tens of thousands of listeners. Through the Abraham Fuchsberg Family Foundation, Mr. Fuchsberg provided over a quarter century's support for consumers, the injured, the needy, and many Jewish philanthropies, including the United Jewish Appeal. Abraham Fuchsberg was widely considered a brilliant legal strategist, a tough negotiator and a tireless supporter of the underpriviliged. In his own verse: ''We do not toil for fatted calves, but for the have-nots, not the haves. We speak for the lost, the lame, the dying, All who come to us for justice crying. To raise up all who may be falling-That indeed is our proud calling.'' He is survived by his loving wife Shirley Fuchsberg, daughters Irene Minkoff and Rita Fuchsberg, his grandson Jonathan Minkoff, and his granddaughter Sarah Minkoff. A memorial service is being planned, the details of which will be announced on the website: www.thenewyorkfirm.com In lieu of flowers, friends are asked to make a tax deductable donation to the Abraham Fuchsberg Family Foundation, 100 Church St, Suite 1800, NY, NY 10007.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLETTE, GINA
description: GILLETTE-Gina, whose age was variously noted as 21, 29, 52 and early 80's, died of natural causes on March 16th, surrounded by her family as the sun set and the full moon rose in Granite Bay, California. Born in New York City to Josephine and D.D. Vincent, Gina was an artist by training, with a gifted eye for color and pattern. Gina did volunteer work for many years and assisted her husband in his business affairs. As a young woman, Gina spent a number of years in Italy, where she was wined and dined by the sons and daughters of the ruling class. With a keen sense of adventure, and first hand experience of ''la dolce vita'', Gina escaped with her father through Casablanca back to America when World War II broke out. At the end of the war Gina met and married Noeth B. Gillette; a young naval aviator from the great western state of Montana. Gina's interests included the fine arts, needle point, reading, traveling, gardening, sports shopping, Etruscan culture, and her many cats. Gina loved her ritual evening swim followed by a hot bath and a glass of one of her favorite California white wines. This ritual was always followed by an Italian dinner prepared by her beloved husband Noeth; a man of great intelligence, generosity and humor, who preceded her in death by 10 years. Gina leaves behind many good friends; two daughters, Maria and Lisa; a son-in-law, John Manzo; a granddaughter, Alisa; and two cousins, Grace Mungiole and Lucille Archer; who were both like sisters to her. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Gina V. Gillette Memorial Library Fund, Palos Verdes Library District, Attn: Barbara Roberts, 701 Silver Spur Road, Rolling Hills Estates, California, 90274.

title: No Headline

He is totally street: baggy jeans, wrist bands, fresh black Timberlands, a diamond stud in his left ear and a baseball cap (worn to the back, at an angle) with his name spray-painted across the bill in graffiti bubble letters. title: 'Good Kills'
description: As the war in Iraq is debated and turned into history, the emphasis will be on the role of technology -- precision bombing, cruise missiles, decapitation strikes. That was what was new. But there was another side to the war, and it was the one that most of the fighting men and women in Iraq experienced, even if it wasn't what Americans watching at home saw: raw military might, humans killing humans. The Third Battalion, Fourth Marines was one of the rawest expressions of that might. Based in Twentynine Palms, Calif., it specializes in desert warfare, and its forces number about 1,500 troops, equipped during the war in Iraq with about 30 Abrams tanks and 60 armored assault vehicles, backed up with whatever artillery and aircraft were required for its missions, like 155-millimeter howitzers and Cobra gunships and fighter jets. The battalion made the ground shake, quite literally, as it rumbled north from Kuwait through Iraq, beginning its march by seizing the Basra airport, continuing on past Nasiriya, into the desert and through a sandstorm that turned the sky red and became, at its worst moments, a hurricane of sand that rocked armored vehicles like plastic toys nudged by a child's finger. On the way to Baghdad, the battalion also fought fierce but limited battles in Afaq and Diwaniya, about 120 miles south of Baghdad, and in Al Kut, about 100 miles from the Iraqi capital.

title: The Philosopher of Islamic Terror
description: Paul Berman's article (March 23) on Sayyid Qutb failed to show any line of filiation from Qutb, executed in 1966, to Al Qaeda, established in the 1980's. Nowhere in Qutb's writings  several of which I have translated  can one find a parallel to Al Qaeda's advocacy of mass slaughter. Conversely, Osama bin Laden's statements show not a trace of Qutb's distinctive philosophy. Berman's article exemplifies the tendency to conflate into a malevolent blur all Muslims regarded as troublesome. As for the comparison of Pan-Arabists and Pan-Islamists with Fascists and Nazis, it is elsewhere in the contemporary Middle East that one might look for a closer analogue.

title: A Singing Detective Plays It Again

Its images may be writ small, but they translate into an almost overwhelming expansiveness -- not just because Mr. Amiel and his cinematographer, Ken Westbury, use every inch of the television screen to make the most of shapes, colors, light and movement, but because Mr. Potter's writing is so mountainously detailed.

He said the ties and scarves, at $40 apiece, provide the same type of protection as an N95 respirator, a commonly used face mask.

title: APPOINTMENT DEBATED

Instead, Mr. McGreevey named John E. Wallace, a judge from Gloucester County, to replace Justice James H. Coleman Jr., the first black on the court. Administration officials have said that Mr. McGreevey's support for Ms. Farber, who was born in Cuba, waned after he learned that a bench warrant had been issued for her arrest when she did not appear in court for a traffic ticket. Ms. Farber says she never received notice of the hearing, and she accused the governor's spokesmen of making ''defamatory statements'' about her. The nomination will require the Senate's approval. This traveling show, organized by the Museum of Latin American Art, in Long Beach, Calif., features 44 non-digital prints by 39 artists from 14 countries and Puerto Rico. Though the exhibition breaks no new technological or aesthetic ground, it brings together a diverse group of fine artists, whose nationalities often position them at the periphery of the contemporary art scene.

title: 'Power Failure'
description: SHERRON Watkins went to the Enron Corporations November management conference for the year 2000 determined she wouldn't be taken for a loser. The year before, at her first such meeting after being promoted to vice president, she had blown it. Booked into the Hill Country Hyatt and Resort for three days of corporate team building, she had opted, in the recreational hours, for the company-sponsored salsa-making class. At affairs such as these, where Enron took over the entire hotel and offered an array of afternoon networking and socializing activities, it was important to pick one that advanced your career. A smart, ambitious employee would never sign up for the afternoon of fly-fishing, for instance, because you couldn't lose the smell of fish in time for the evening cocktail party, and because you could wind up wasting your afternoon with guys who worked in the once crucial but now irrelevant pipeline division. That left, as career-building activities, skeet shooting, the Road Rally, tennis, golf, facials, pedicures, outlet shopping, and antiquing in a nearby Hill Country town.

title: Gowns Or Butter?
description: 'Is this absurd?'' asks Deeda Blair, leaning back in her leather chair at Hiramatsu, the exclusive restaurant on the le-St. Louis in Paris. It's January, and we're lunching on poached rabbit with cauliflower-stuffed macaroni on a bed of pured truffles, halfway through Paris's semiannual haute couture shows, the winds of war blowing all around what may turn out to be the longest continuous brink in the history of warfare. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOKER, JOHN, JR.
description: BOKER-John, Jr., 90, worldrenowned philatelist, key figure in WWII military intelligence history, and manufacturer of specialty cutlery, including the widely collected ''Boker'' pocketknife, died April 12 at his home in Scarsdale, NY. Recognized by the Collector's Club as the foremost philatelist of the latter half of the 20th Century, specializing in the fields of German States and U.S. Locals and U.S. Pre-cancels, John Boker has earned many of the field's highest awards, including the Smithsonian Institution's Lifetime Achievement Award (2002), the Robson Lowe Memorial Medal (2000), the Philatelic Foundation's ''Meritorious Service'' Medal, the Luff Award, the Berlin Philatelic Club's Lindenberg Medal (1981), the Collector's Club Medal (1970), the Lichtenstein Award (1967). and the Tilleard Medal (1967). He was a member ''Honoris Causa'' of the International Jury at CAPEX (1978). Chairman of the Expert Committee of the Philatelic Foundation, Chairman of the special Anphilex Invitational Exhibition of Classic Stamps (1971), Signer of the Roll of Distinguished Philatelists (1964), member of the International Juries since 1956, President of the Pre-cancel Stamp Society, President of the New York Pre-cancel Club, and twenty-five year member and former President and Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Collector's Club of New York. Boker traces his involvement in precancels back to age 10 when he came into possession of a box of stamps that were primarily New York and New Jersey Precancels. Being, at the time, unable to afford collecting both states, he opted to concentrate on NY and so began what was ultimately to become the finest aggregation of precancels ever put together in one album of any description. John Boker, a U.S. infantry Major and recipient of the Bronze Star, played a significant role working with the American and British Intelligence Service during, and particularly at the close of, World War II. He is best known for his work in interrogation and early ''Cold-War'' activities. Elected in 1990 to the ''Hall of Fame of Military Intelligence Service,'' Boker concluded his involvement with U.S. Intelligence as a post-War consultant for the newly established CIA. His contributions to World War II military intelligence history is documented in a number of books on the subject, notably ''The Service: The Memoirs of General Reinhard Gehlen,'' and Mary Ellen Reese's ''General Reinhard Gehlen: The CIA Connection,'' a dramatic account of the close connections between the chief of German Intelligence and U.S. spy units after World War II. Well-known by antique dealers and knife collectors, Boker, or ''Treebrand,'' superior quality pocketknives are foremost among the various types of cutlery and hand tools manufactured by H. Boker & Co. (Est. 1837) until the merger of the company with New Britain Machine in 1965. Boker's extensive business career also included his role as Director of Burnham Corporation from 1972 to 1988, Director and Vice President of the Nelson Fund Securities Company from 1958 to 1975, and Director of New Britain Machine from 1965 until its merger into Litton Industries in 1968. John Boker was born in 1913 in New York City, and graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Yale University in 1933. He is predeceased by his wife of 52 years, Polly Lupie Boker, and is survived by his two daughters, Pamela Boker and Joan Shisler, and six grandchildren.

title: A Story That Still Chills

The account of the brutal shooting of two policemen continues to draw shivers and speculation, even after four decades. In ''Night of the Devil: The Untold Story of Thomas Trantino and the Angel Lounge Killings'' (Camino Books), David Stout, a Washington reporter for The New York Times, sifts through the accounts once again, bringing focus to a barroom haze. What remains clear is that two men and four women loitered together around end-of-the-night drinks. Minutes later, the revelers were gone and two police officers, who had been checking for underage drinkers, lay in blood, stripped to their underwear. In the hunt for the shooters, one of the men, Frank Falco, was shot dead when the police confronted him in a Manhattan hotel room. The second man, Thomas Trantino, surrendered and was ultimately convicted after one of the most celebrated criminal trials in state history. Mr. Stout unravels the conflicting stories and patiently peels away the improbable. The author has his own motives and his own demons from the strangling murder of an aunt, and his approach to violent crime is unsentimental. And Thomas Trantino? Only in his 20's at the time, he was saved from execution. And he became the longest-serving prisoner on record before being released to a Camden halfway house in 2001. Jeremy Pearce

title: Questions of Assent, Questions of Belief
description: It is a bit hard to understand why Stanley Moss is not more famous. Maybe it's because he is so happily rather than haplessly predictable. A HISTORY OF COLOR: New and Collected Poems (Seven Stories, paper, $17.95) covers four decades of his work, starting with ''The Wrong Angel'' (1966), and reveals an astonishingly intact intellect and sensibility. In a sense Moss has been writing the same poem for more than 40 years -- elliptical meditations that take the self as a starting point of intellectual autobiography. There are debts to modernism here, but they show up as subtle homages, as a line pastiched from Eliot (''I should be grateful for another louse,'' he writes in ''The Louse'') or a loving echo of Marianne Moore (''What are years? Not a herd of cattle,'' we read in ''The Falcon''). Moss is constantly talking to the past. Yet the most repeated word in these 250 pages is God, and the fact that Moss's God is the God of the dis- or the unbeliever suggests that the best religious poetry still comes out of longing rather than conviction: ''I do not believe the spirits of the dead / are closer to God than the living,'' he writes in ''Creed.'' Even when religion is not the overt subject, as in a poem like ''2002, Alas,'' clearly written in response to Sept. 11, he is framing questions of assent, consent and belief. As neither a sentimentalist nor an ironist but a Shelleyan humanist, Stanley Moss is very much an acquired taste and deserves much more critical attention. J. T. Barbarese

title: Pursued by Bears
description: Generations of children have taken the Berenstain Bears of Jan and Stan Berenstain into their hearts. Many a 4-year-old has found comfort in the archetypal characters: the bumbling father, the intelligent, all-knowing mother, the universal brother and sister. In Bear Country, youngsters safely approach common issues: the world of family (''The Berenstain Bears' New Baby'') and friendship (their ''No Girls Allowed''), fears (their ''Afraid of the Dark'') and anxieties (their ''Go to School''). The Berenstains' success is measured by over 260 million copies of hundreds of titles sold. DOWN A SUNNY DIRT ROAD: An Autobiography (Random House, $20; ages 8 and up) is a dual memoir by the artists, both born in Philadelphia in 1923. It is told in alternating chapters, using a heavily illustrated procedure much like that of another narrative cartoonist in ''Bill Peet: An Autobiography.'' The Berenstains met at art school in 1941, but soon Stan was a medical artist in the Army, and Jan was taking classes while working as an aircraft riveter. The authors effectively mix narrative cartoons, photographs and their early schoolwork in this part of their story. Their marriage and commercial success as magazine illustrators are moderately interesting, but the real core of their autobiography describes the birth of their first children's book. They were fans of Dr. Seuss, and felt a similar presentation would work with their cartooning style, sense of humor and family adventures. The Berenstains traveled from Philadelphia to New York to meet with their editor for the Random House ''Beginner Books'' series, Theodor Geisel (also known as Dr. Seuss). Geisel used brutally blunt terms to describe the editorial changes he wanted. The Berenstains were crushed, but struggled to understand. The collaboration that transformed ''Freddy Bear's Spanking'' into ''The Big Honey Hunt,'' published in 1962 and still in print, is a primer in how picture books can be made to work. Gradually the Berenstains developed a kind of protocol for their stories: ''easy words, short sentences, word/picture clues, rollicking rhythm, resolute rhyme . . . shameless slapstick and outrageous jokes.'' Alas, the text of their memoir was not edited so rigorously. The sentences are often convoluted, and the book conveys little insight into how the Berenstains work today or what techniques they use now that the Bears have grown to a business that includes their sons Leo and Michael, producing paperback picture books, chapter books, videos, television cartoons and, of course, a Web site. Lisa Von Drasek

title: 'The Wife'

Just like our marriage, I could have said, but why ruin everything right now? Here we were in first-class splendor, tentatively separated from anxiety; there was no turbulence and the sky was bright, and somewhere among us, possibly, sat an air marshal in dull traveler's disguise, perhaps picking at a little dish of oily nuts or captivated by the zombie prose of the in-flight magazine. Drinks had already been served before takeoff, and we were both frankly bombed, our mouths half open, our heads tipped back. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRUMIN, M. JACK, M.D.
description: FRUMIN-M. Jack, M.D., 83, a dedicated anesthesiologist, teacher, scientist died at home in Menlo Park, CA, on April 8, 2003 of Parkinson's disease. Loving husband of Helen for 60 years, Menlo Park; loving father of Eric, Brooklyn; Melissa, Newton, MA; and the late Steven Frumin; loving father-in-law of Emily and Greg; cherished grandfather of Michael, Gregory, Jacob and Anna; loving brother of Abraham, Philadelphia. BS and MD, Temple University; Professor at Columbia-Presbyterian, Albert Einstein Medical School, Clinical Professor, Stanford University Medical School. Dedicated to patients, students and colleagues, he performed research in respiratory function and pharmacology, lectured and published widely, and guided and tutored hundreds of physicians in training. A founder of Physicians for Social Responsibility, he and Helen are longtime supporters of the movements for civil rights, peace, civil liberties and social justice. Memorial service at Temple Beth El, Sudbury, MA, April 27, 1 PM. Friends are welcome to Frumin home, Brooklyn, Tuesday, May 6, 2003, 7-9 PM. Memorial contributions may be sent to Physicians for Social Responsibility, 1875 Connecticut Ave, NW, Suite 1012, Washington, DC 20009.

title: Helen Overcomes Bad Men and Bad Press

Homer and Virgil paint her as a wanton, fickle princess whose desertion of her royal husband, Menelaus, led to the Trojan War. In classic drama, Helen fares equally badly: Shakespeare cast her as a vain and rather silly woman in ''Troilus and Cressida.'' Euripides tries to rehabilitate her, but to do so he has to divide her in two: a phantom Helen who elopes to Troy and her real self, who hides out in Egypt, craving redemption. Helen has received more favorable treatment in her pop culture appearances (she got some sympathy from Xena, Warrior Princess, who happened to be a childhood pal). But in general she's been assigned to the darker side of history. In the ''Oresteia,'' Aeschylus makes her name into a curse: she's ''hell to cities, hell to ships and hell to men.''

title: 'Ziff: A Life?'
description: Itook my last newspaper of the morning into the study, in order to read the car ads of the Union Leader , New Hampshire's yellow rag that might have supported Hitler on a No Tax pledge. As I sat down in the leather lounger, I noticed an early morning fax had arrived. More bad news? I mused. Yet another overnight rejection by a European publisher of the new novel? If I read it now, my morning of writing would be ruined. No way. I turned off the receptive fax machine and sat back with the safe ads for four-wheel-drive trucks. I wanted a Toyota 1986-87, with an extra cab, for about $3,500. The only one I found had "the usual bed/body rust," so I stood up, stretched, and went to pee before starting to work. The awful daily grind; was Sisyphus an obscure novelist?

He has two more icons under way for a Franciscan monastery in Chicopee, Mass., while an upstate New York church New York recently sent him 16 religious statues to restore.

title: A Mixed Message For the Schools
description: ALMOST half the state's superintendents and educators are trying to figure where they went wrong. When they finish sorting that out, they will have to resubmit their school budgets to municipal boards and councils and decide where they can cut -- from personnel or programs.

title: Private Sector; Almost at the Top at Marriott
description: AS John W. Marriott III wound his way through the cavernous kitchen of the Wardman Park Marriott hotel here, he reached out to shake hands with every employee and to exchange some banter.

title: Swedish Rider Jumps Into First
description: When Marcus Merschformann of Germany rode Camirez B. without a fault to win the second leg of the $254,000 Budweiser World Cup final for horse show jumpers in Las Vegas on Friday night, he ensured himself a spot in the final field of 28 horses and riders competing for the championship today. But the victory was too little for him to overtake the riding star of the show thus far, Malin Baryard of Sweden.

title: Out of Argentina's Chaos, a Familiar Face Returns

But at 72, after more than a decade in office and three years as a virtual pariah, Mr. Menem, Argentina's former president, is once again running for office and has become the focal point of the presidential election that is barely a week away.

title: April 13-19: INTERNATIONAL; THE POST-HUSSEIN ERA
description: President Bush all but declared victory in Iraq, saying, ''The regime of Saddam Hussein is no more.'' But Mr. Bush made clear that he is not finished with other nations, like Iran and Syria, that he considers threats to the security of the United States. He also turned attention to North Korea, which agreed to talks with the United States and China over its nuclear program and then announced that it had begun reprocessing spent fuel rods, a step toward acquiring fuel that could be used to build more nuclear weapons.

title: The Silencing Of Gideon's Trumpet
description: Forty-one years ago, a poor, isolated prisoner in Florida, the least influential of Americans, wrote a letter to the Supreme Court -- a letter in pencil, on lined prison paper -- claiming that he had been wrongly denied the right to a lawyer when he was convicted. The Supreme Court agreed to hear his case and found that the Constitution required counsel to be provided in all serious criminal cases for defendants too poor to hire their own. Clarence Earl Gideon would have a new trial, this time with a lawyer.

title: Images From a Land of Whispers and Fear
description: In Iraq I was introduced to a culture of fear and repression. In the beginning the whispers, muted conversations and constant paranoia of our government appointed ''minders'' were nothing more than an annoyance. But I soon succumbed to a mode of self-censorship, playing by the rules to stay in the game. For an Iraqi, breaking the rules could mean prison, torture or even execution. If I were to break the rules -- pointing a camera at a police station, government building or presidential palace -- I might be kicked out of the country. For this reason the most symbolic moment of the war for me was on March 21 during the third night of American air attacks, standing on the roof on my hotel. Cruise missiles soared closely overhead, then smashed into the palaces that had been feared by the Iraqi people for nearly 30 years. As I watched these buildings burst into flames, I could only imagine the amazement it provided for the Iraqi people. This was not only the breaking of buildings, but a crumbling of a regime.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH -- 'Gypsy' Girls; Let Them Entertain You

She died because she chose to be a human shield. Her efforts were to impede the efforts of the Israeli Army to stop terrorism. Neither she nor her death served the cause of peace.

Shortly before her death, Rachel was photographed surrounded by Palestinian children while she burned a replica of the United States flag. This fact doesn't diminish the tragedy of her death, but it should have been noted in your article.

While most Iraqis want liberation, they may not yet be prepared for, or even understand, Western-style democracy. For the last 34 years under Saddam Hussein, Iraqis have been subjected to a highly nationalist -- even militaristic -- education.

description: The pretty people and the trendy shops can stay, but South Beach residents have had enough of the loud music that thumps nightly from car stereos, boomboxes and nightclubs here, and they want the city to turn down the volume.

The court needs to rule quickly on the legal challenges to the law, but time is running short and the issue is taking a disturbingly long time in making its way through the lower courts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOREAU, ANTOINE CLAUDE, M.D.
description: MOREAU-Antoine Claude, M.D. It is with profound sorrow and a deep sense of regret that we, the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center family and the Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology mourn the loss of our esteemed and respected staff member, Dr. Antoine Claude Moreau. He was an outstanding clinician and gifted surgeon who devoted his time to patient care as well as to medical student and resident training. Dr. Moreau was a Diplomate of the American Board of Obstetrics & Gynecology; a Fellow of the American College of Obstetricians & Gynecologists; Vice President of the Bronx OB/GYN Society; and Chief of Gynecology and Director of Student Teaching at Bronx-Lebanon. His everpresent broad smile, effusive warmth and the exuberance he manifested will certainly be missed. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife Eunide and children, Claudine and Martine. Milton Gumbs, M.D. VP/Medical Dir. Magdy Mikhail, M.D. Professor and Chairman Department of OB/GYN

title: Candid Coffee
description: I HAVE nothing against Italian food; some of my best meals have been Italian. But in central New Jersey, I'm always looking for different places. New American has made considerable inroads; Thai has brought us spicy beef salad, chicken-coconut soup and sticky rice with mango. But not a lot of Middle Eastern food is available that is not takeout. That is why I was delighted to find Seven Hills of Istanbul, where the tables are clothed, the chef turns out beautifully roasted halal-prescribed meats and the Turkish coffee is so seductive that when you get home after dinner, you will have plenty of time to plan your next visit because you can't sleep anyway.

title: A Hotbed of Confusion, in English

About one in seven residents of Long Island can't read English well enough to decipher complex messages like ''Double quarter-pounder'' (why isn't it a half-pounder?) and ''Filet-O-Fish.'' (what exactly is an O-Fish?). These phrases are not in anybody's dictionary, let alone an explanation of them. This could mean 400,000 potential sales lost each day. So they say it in pictures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUGLAS, EDWARD O.
description: DOUGLAS-Edward O., 76, formerly of New York City and Ghent, New York, died of heart failure on April 1 in Peterborough, New Hampshire. His ashes have been laid to rest at Deerfield Academy, his alma mater. Effy, his beloved cat and companion, predeceased him by three weeks. Of old New England stock, he sailed around the world on the square-masted brigantine Yankee in the late 1940's. While at sea, he began to nurture his lifelong love for travel and his interest in the cultures of the South Pacific and Southeast Asia. During his professional life, he worked in public relations and marketing. Building upon his mother's outstanding collection of English and early American antiques, and drawing upon his own sophisticated taste and style, he created elegant and comfortable homes throughout his life. His friends fondly remember his Dorothy Parkeresque wit, his wonderful story telling, and his urbanity.

title: Sun, Sand and, by the Way, Art

Windsor, as his development was to be called, would have a rolling golf course (with no tee times), a beach club (where everyone was fit), tennis courts (with players all wearing white) and polo fields (thwack!) -- all an easy commute from London. ''Three flights a day,'' he said.

The people we have met in towns like Moustiers, Carcassonne, Port-Grimaud, Lzignan, Avignon and others are friendly and kind. description: OUR first decade of married life was an exercise in stunning conformity. We married in our 20's because that's when everybody else was marrying. title: April 13-19: INTERNATIONAL; BRITISH SKELETONS IN IRELAND
description: For years human rights organizations and leaders of the republican movement in Northern Ireland charged that members of Britain's security forces assisted Protestant guerrillas in killing Catholics in the 1980's. Now a report from Sir John Stevens, the head of Scotland Yard, says they're right. It details a 14-year investigation into the 1989 murder of Patrick Finucane, a civil rights lawyer, and 25 other victims. The inquiry, still unfinished, was ''willfully obstructed and misled'' by police and military intelligence officials, Sir John said. Warren Hoge

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Secaucus; From a Swamp, an Ever-Changing Town

A former mayor, Anthony Just, boasts that he can see the Empire State building from the windows of his home on Front Street. The town's earliest recorded mention was in a land purchase treaty signed between the Dutch governor of New Amsterdam, Peter Stuyvesant, and Lenape Indian leaders in 1658. Then, it was referred to as an island called Siskakes, meaning ''black snakes,'' referring to the creatures that inhabited the area, which was then mainly swampland.

Calling hours at Higgins Home for Funerals, Watchung, NJ, on Monday, April 21st, 7-9 PM and Tuesday, April 22nd, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. title: The Living Room Revival House
description: TURNER CLASSIC MOVIES is a movie lover's paradise, an unending film festival. The revival house is dead in all but a handful of fortunate cities, and most neighborhood video stores stock a limited number of pictures made before the youngest clerks were born. Many titles have gone out of print on tape and have yet to be released on disc. But any aficionado whose cable company supplies TCM can see scores of movies every month, the vast majority of them more than 30 years old, including silents and foreign films. They're shown commercial-free, in the best available prints, and they're presented elegantly. Each one is annotated by the network's uncannily informed host, Robert Osborne; his introductions and afterwords, peppered with facts -- on-the-set anecdotes, placement within the career of a performer or filmmaker -- find distinction in even the least inspired studio release.

title: The World; Chaos in Congo Suits Many Parties Just Fine
description: AS in the Sherlock Holmes story about the dog that didn't bark in the night, sometimes silence says more than words. About one of the great tragedies of today's world, the silence is telling indeed. In Congo, according to an International Rescue Committee report released earlier this month, at least 3.3 million people have lost their lives in four and a half years of civil war. They have perished in combat, in massacres of civilians (the most recent occurred on April 3) and, most of all, in the disease and famine that strike when millions of desperately poor people are forced to flee their homes.

title: Crossroads Of Culture
description: In Baghdad in the ninth century, a much happier age than now, there was an area known as the Suq al-warraqin, the Stationer's Market. Lining its streets were more than 100 shops selling paper. Baghdad was an important center of paper making and, for the Byzantines at least, its products were the best. They referred to paper as ''bagdatixon'' and the standard size, roughly 29 inches by 43 inches, was known as a Baghdadi sheet. There were many different types, usually named after the city's rulers and governors of its provinces: Talhi paper, Nuhi paper, Tahiri paper. Paper was the new technology, and the Arabs were the masters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, HUGH
description: COLE-Hugh. Of Basking Ridge, N.J. and Vero Beach, FL, died on Thursday in Vero Beach. He was 81. The cause was emphysema and lung fibrosis. A born and bred New Yorker, Mr. Cole attended prep school in New York City where he achieved Diamond Belt status in boxing. He then entered Columbia University, but left to serve in the 7th Fleet in WW II. He was a true patriot and loved his country dearly. He leaves behind his wife of 57 years, Sally Igoe Cole and four children, Sara Alvaro, Elizabeth Finegan, Maryjo Paz y Mino, Hugh Jr., and twelve grandchildren. Daughter Mary Ashley died in 1998. Mr. Cole was a magical father who could make a trip to a delicatessen into an unforgettable adventure. He spoiled his children (not really) by making every Saturday a Present Day. His story-telling is legendary. Mr. Cole was President of Igoe Brothers, Inc., a wire and steel manufacturer, where he was in the forefront in dealing in the Eastern European open market in the trading of steel rods. He traveled extensively in his work. He served on the Manpower Commission of the State of New Jersey under Governor Hughes, and was a Director of Carteret Savings and Loan, among others. Mr. Cole was a man of diverse tastes from caviar to Tootsie Rolls. He felt equally at home at the Stork Club and the Point Pleasant Boardwalk, dining at the Four Seasons or eating at the diner. We will really miss him. Donations may be made to the VNA Hospice House of Indian River County in Vero Beach, FL. 32960.

title: Baritone at Home in a Foreign Land
description: With clever programming the baritone Thomas Meglioranza began both halves of his Tuesday night recital with the same four lines of text from Joseph von Eichendorff's ''In der Fremde'' (''In a Foreign Land''). First there was the somberly beautiful opening of Schumann's Opus 39 ''Liederkreis.'' The second was as a musical memory of the first, composed by Hanns Eisler as part of his ''Hollywood Songbook.'' For Schumann the text suggested the inner exile of a soul in winter; for Eisler, who sets the words above a jabbing piano line, exile in Los Angeles in the 1940's was very real and aching.

title: No Battle of the Sexes in These 3-D Mazes

title: Everglades in Peril
description: The most ambitious environmental rescue operation ever tried in this country -- a $7.8 billion plan to restore the Everglades -- is suddenly at risk. The reason is that one of the major players in the enterprise, Florida's politically connected sugar cane industry, wants to postpone into the distant future the deadline for cleaning up the polluted water flowing into the Everglades. And the Florida Legislature is poised to let the industry do it. This could mean serious trouble for an already fragile ecosystem. It would also violate the spirit of the federal-state partnership underlying the project and threaten the revenue stream on which it depends.

title: A Short Leash Creates a Tense Groove
description: If the Sea and Cake doesn't sound like a typical jam band, it's because the group has one accessory that most jam bands lack and many could use: a short leash. The musicians often take off in unexpected directions but they don't go very far. After a few steps, the tether pulls taut, and the whole band runs in place -- settling into a tense, stationary groove -- before changing direction and moving back the other way. After a few twists and turns, the songs end.
