title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Lexmark's Profits Rise On Sales Of Ink Cartridges
description: Lexmark International Inc., the second-biggest maker of computer printers in the United States after the Hewlett-Packard Company, said yesterday that first-quarter net income increased 32 percent as rising sales of ink cartridges offset a drop in machine sales. Net income rose to $94.6 million, or 73 cents a share, from $71.5 million, or 53 cents a share. Sales increased 5.7 percent to $1.11 billion from $1.05 billion, Lexmark said. Supplies like ink cartridges rose 18 percent, while sales of hardware like printers fell 7.7 percent. Hardware sales fell because of a transition to a new product line, the loss of Compaq Computer as a reseller and not being able to satisfy demand for all-in-one printers, the chief financial officer, Gary Morin, said. ''It was a relief to see them meet the high end of their guidance,'' said Tim Jossart, co-manager of the Touchstone Value Plus Fund, which manages $40 million in assets and holds 26,430 Lexmark shares. In January, the company had given a first-quarter forecast of 62 cents to 72 cents a share and analysts had expected 72 cents, according to a survey of nine analysts by Thomson First Call. Shares of Lexmark rose 31 cents, to $69.50 yesterday. They have gained 16 percent this year.

title: Washington's Man in Baghdad
description: Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld and Gen. Tommy Franks have won plaudits for their prosecution of the war, but history's verdict on their performance in Iraq will depend in no small measure on the job Lt. Gen. Jay Garner does. General Garner, a retired Army commander, will be Iraq's top civilian administrator during the months ahead. He needs to get a battered country running again and promote a revival of political life after decades of suffocating repression. With returned exiles already maneuvering for top positions and armed Shiite patrols eager to set up enclaves of Islamic law, General Garner has his work cut out for him.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Petrochemical Control Shifts
description: Thailand's bankruptcy court handed control of Thai Petrochemical Industry back to its founder, Prachai Leophairatana, ousting the company's creditor-appointed administrators, Effective Planners, for failing to meet the company's debt reorganization targets. Thai Petrochemical became Thailand's biggest defaulter in 1997, when it stopped payment on $4.2 billion in debt. Mr. Prachai fought creditors for three years to hang on to the company, often resorting to xenophobia and union fears of layoffs, until the court declared him bankrupt. Analysts said the new decision could hurt confidence among foreign investors, but Thai Petrochemical's shares rose on the news as investors calculated that the company stood more to gain with Mr. Prachai in charge than fighting from the outside. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bid From Builder Rejected
description: Caltagirone, a builder in Italy, and its partners abandoned their 2.55 billion euro ($2.77 billion) bid for the real estate company Metrovacesa, after shareholders refused to sell a majority stake. Shareholders owning 23 percent of Metrovacesa, a leading Spanish real estate company, offered to sell their shares to Caltagirone, Spain's stock market regulator said. The bid had been conditional on the Italian companies winning at least 50 percent of Metrovacesa's shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AHMAD, HAZRAT MIRZA TAHIR AHMAD
description: AHMAD-Hazrat Mirza Tahir Ahmad, 74. World Renowned Muslim Religious Leader. Hazrat Mirza Tahir Ahmad, head of the worldwide Ahmadiyya Muslim Community, born on December 18, 1928 in Qadian, India, passed away on April 19, 2003 in London, England. Mirza Tahir Ahmad was the fourth successor and grandson of Mirza Ghulam Ahmad, reformer of the age, and founder of this community established in 1889 in Qadian, India. Today this community comprises of over 170 million in membership, spread out in more than 170 countries. Here in the United States, it has been in existence since 1921. Among the most notable of Hazrat Tahir Ahmad's numerable achievements is the institution of Muslim Television Ahmadiyya, a first of a kind ever, 24 hour satellite station for Muslim programming. Also he oversaw the translation of the Holy Quran in excess of 50 languages. He himself was a prolific writer on various religious subjects. Remarkably, the entire membership of the Ahmadiyya Muslim Community had undeterred access to him personally.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: INTERNET SECURITY SAYS PROFITS MAY EXCEED PREDICTIONS Shares of Internet Security Systems Inc. , whose software protects computer networks from intruders, rose 11 percent on the Nasdaq yesterday after the company said second-quarter profits and sales might exceed analysts' forecasts. Profits, excluding some costs, will be 13 cents to 15 cents a share on sales of $60 million to $64 million, the company said late Thursday. Analysts on average expected earnings of 13 cents a share and sales of $62 million, according to Thomson First Call. First-quarter profits rose 59 percent as costs fell and sales gained 1.8 percent. Internet Security shares, which dropped 43 percent last year and 46 percent in the first quarter, rose $1.30, or 11 percent, to $13.11. Profits, excluding acquisition costs and other items, this year will be 57 cents to 65 cents a share, the company said. On that basis, which does not comply with generally accepted accounting principles, profits are expected to be 56 cents, according to Thomson First Call. Sales this year will be $248 million to $260 million, the company said. That compares with analysts' average forecast of $254.4 million. (Bloomberg News)

title: The Loneliest Victors
description: In the modern history of the West, armed conflicts between states have been concluded by the convening of the adversaries to sign documents of armistice, surrender and peace. Although these ceremonies formally marked the submission of the vanquished, they usually proceeded in gentlemanly ways. Witness defeated France's representative, Talleyrand, at the Vienna Peace Conference in 1815, mingling with the victorious allies as equal among equals.

title: Reported SARS Cases in Beijing Take Sharp 2-Day Jump
description: BEIJING, April 22  Reported cases in Beijing of the dangerous new respiratory disease were sharply raised again over the last two days, climbing by 249 to 588, as the government continued its belated campaign to provide honest figures and earn public trust.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: U.S. YIELDS ON SEARCH RULING The government has decided against appealing a ruling by a federal district judge that could imperil scores of related prosecutions around the country. The ruling was issued last month in a child-pornography case involving a Bronx man. The charge of possessing child pornography will be dismissed against the defendant, Harvey Perez, his lawyer said. Prosecutors had no comment yesterday. The judge, Denny Chin, ruled that F.B.I. agents "acted with reckless disregard for the truth" in preparing an affidavit used to get a search warrant for Mr. Perez's computer. Mr. Perez was accused of joining an Internet group and possessing pornography e-mailed from other members. But Judge Chin noted that not all members of the group chose to be on the e-mail list. The government has also decided not to appeal a similar ruling in St. Louis and has dropped charges against that defendant, his lawyer said.   Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Rev. Eric Butterworth, 86; Preached Positive Attitude
description: The Rev. Eric Butterworth, whose pulpit was in Lincoln Center and whose message of personal renewal through changes in attitude made him a popular leader in the New Age spiritual movement, died on Thursday at Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut. He was 86.

title: For a Longer Life, Try Living In New York City, Report Says
description: The next time you start to mutter under your breath about how life in the big city is taking years off your life, think about this: New Yorkers are living a lot longer than they did a decade ago and are living longer than Americans as a whole.

title: Possible Ban on Abortion Technique Leaves Doctors Uneasy
description: As a ban on a procedure that opponents call partial-birth abortion makes its way through Congress, many of the doctors who provide abortions say they remain confused about what will be banned and fear it will apply to other procedures used in the second trimester of pregnancy.

title: Furious, American's Unions Talk of New Votes
description: Still fuming over the failure of American Airlines to inform them of its compensation plans for senior management, all three of the company's major unions said yesterday that they would vote again or were considering voting again on $1.62 billion in annual concessions that their members had approved last week.

title: Building Residents Prepare To Step In if Workers Strike
description: With apartment building workers preparing for a possible strike after midnight tonight, residents in about 3,000 unionized buildings in New York City are planning ways to step in for their doormen, janitors, elevator operators, superintendents and handymen.

title: Profit Rises 18% For Stent Maker
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation, a maker of heart stents, said that its profit rose 18 percent in the first quarter after the company introduced new devices over the past year.

(The error was repeated on Sunday in a picture caption and in a cumulative list of war deaths.) The corporal was a member of the Second Battalion, 124th Infantry, not the 124th Infantry Division.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Argentine Is Elected To New Court
description: Luis Moreno Ocampo, an Argentine lawyer, was elected the first chief prosecutor of the new permanent war crimes court in The Hague. His election was by nations that had ratified the international treaty creating the court. Mr. Ocampo, who has taught at Harvard University's law school, led investigations against his country's military junta. Despite a decision by the United States to shun the global court, it is expected to begin hearing cases of war crimes and genocide by next year. Joya Rajadhyaksha (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHSBERG, ABRAHAM
description: FUCHSBERG - Abraham. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the passing of Abraham Fuchsberg, a cherished friend of UJA-Federation who earned enormous respect for his efforts on behalf of Israel and the Jewish people. His contributions to the Jewish community will be felt for generations to come. We mourn the loss of a dear friend, and extend our deepest sympathies to Mr. Fuchsberg's wife, Shirley; to their daughters, Irene Minkoff and Rita Fuchsberg; and to the entire Fuchsberg family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Ceremony Honors Veterans Not on Memorial
description: Nearly 400 Americans who died as a result of the Vietnam War but who are not eligible to have their names inscribed on the Vietnam Veterans Memorial were honored today in a ceremony that drew more than a thousand people to the memorial's site on the Mall.

title: In the Graveyard of Grunge, New Life
description: A decade ago Seattle was the rumbling epicenter of a coffee-fueled grunge nation. Its bands topped the Billboard charts and were on the cover of Time magazine. Hip designers snatched laid-back Northwest staples like the flannel shirt and put them on international runways.

title: Off-Field Feuding Doesn't Stop the Yankees on the Field
description: The Yankees are rollicking back to the happiest place on earth. They left the Metrodome today giddy over a four-game sweep of the Minnesota Twins, taking the best start in team history to Anaheim, Calif., where they crumbled last October at a ballpark on the same street as Disneyland.

Mr. Flanagan, a novelist, proposed a literary prize for fiction. The governor agreed, and the biennial Tasmania Pacific Region Prize, for an author from Australia, New Zealand or Melanesia, was born.

description: The 79-year-old president of Azerbaijan, Heydar A. Aliyev, collapsed twice during a nationally televised speech there today, prompting fresh questions about the health of a leader considered integral to the stability of his oil-producing country.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Yale Officials Added To Lawsuit
description: A former Yale University lecturer has added five university officials as defendants to a lawsuit against several Police Department officials who named him as a suspect in the 1998 killing of Suzanne Jovin, a Yale exchange student from Germany. In his amended suit, the former lecturer, James Van de Velde, 43, says Yale officials violated his civil rights. The lawsuit, originally filed in 2001 against the New Haven police chief, Melvin H. Wearing, and other police officials, has added as defendants Yale's president, Richard C. Levin; its vice president and secretary, Linda K. Lorimer; the dean of Yale College, Richard Broadhead; a university spokesman, Thomas Conroy; and the chief of the campus police, James Perrotti. The lawsuit says the Yale officials publicized information that the New Haven police considered Mr. Van de Velde a suspect. The Police Department has yet to make an arrest in the case, and a Yale spokeswoman said yesterday that university officials acted properly. Paul von Zielbauer (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Lucky Dog
description: As dog days go, April 15 started out pretty badly for Dosha, a 35-pound mutt in Clearlake. First it was hit by a truck. No bones were broken, but Officer Bob McDonald of the Clearlake Police didn't know that. He saw a dog in pain, and unable to locate the owner, shot it in the head, apparently to put it out of its misery. The next stop was the dog pound, where Dosha was left for dead in a freezer. Two hours later, Dosha's luck turned. An animal control officer checked the freezer and found one live dog with hypothermia and a wounded muzzle. Dosha is now doing well under a veterinarian's care.

title: ING GROUP TO BUY U.S. FUND MANAGEMENT COMPANY
description: ING Group, one of Europe's largest financial services companies, agreed to buy Delta Capital Management to add $275 million in assets to its fund unit in the United States. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Acquiring New York-based Delta Capital will expand ING's business of managing funds for institutional and wealthy clients, the company said. ING, which is based in the Netherlands, hired William F. Coughlin, a managing partner at Delta Capital, along with the partners Jonathan Kay, Anthony Cavlov and Michael Hemberger as portfolio managers.

description: Dan McNew thought he had shot the home movie of a lifetime. He had aimed his digital video camera at the shuttle Columbia as it returned to earth on Feb. 1; living near Dallas, in the path of the returning shuttle, he had caught the sight on video several times before.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint's First-Quarter Net Income Rose
description: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that first-quarter net income rose to $1.67 billion from $140 million in the year-earlier period on a gain from the sale of its directories business. The directory sale added $1.31 billion to earnings. Total sales fell 4.5 percent, to $6.34 billion from $6.64 billion. Sprint is relying on expense reductions to generate profit amid declining sales at its main phone business and slowing wireless revenue. The new chief executive, Gary Forsee, has less room to slash costs than his predecessor, William Esrey, who eliminated about 15,000 jobs in the last two years, analysts said. The company lowered its forecast for 2003 per-share profits at the local and long-distance phone unit by 10 cents a share, to $1.30 to $1.35. It also expects a sales decline of as much as 7 percent. That compares with a previous sales estimate of a low single-digit-rate decline. Sprint PCS's 2003 loss-forecast range was widened by 5 cents a share to 45 cents to 50 cents a share. On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Sprint's main phone unit rose 22 cents, to $11.27 a share. The company released results after the close of regular trading. In after-hours trading, the shares slipped 62 cents, or 5.5 percent, to $10.65.

description: The outbreak of SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome, took a severe turn for the worse in China and Hong Kong in recent weeks and also expanded its grip in Canada. There seems no doubt now that this new viral disease, a life-threatening pneumonia, has spread too far to be readily eradicated. SARS is almost certainly here to stay, and the only question is whether it will become a global pandemic or a sporadic nuisance.

description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's inspector general defended his record yesterday, testifying at a State Assembly hearing that his office was pursuing more cases than ever before and that the M.T.A. was cooperating fully.

description: WASHINGTON, April 22  Alan Greenspan got the backing of President Bush today for another term as chairman of the Federal Reserve.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 4 about the appointment of a dean of Harvard Law School referred imprecisely to a report in The Harvard Crimson about a third-year student who surveyed fellow students. The Crimson said the survey found that law students at Stanford and Yale were happier than those at Harvard. The student, Michael J. Passante, says he only speculated that students at Yale and Stanford might be happier, and that his survey drew no conclusion, since it involved only those at Harvard.

description: Urban Heights

title: Briefly Noted
description: ARRESTS IN JOURNALISTS' DEATHS The Afghan authorities said they had arrested five men on suspicion of murdering four foreign journalists in southeastern Afghanistan in November 2001. Amrullah Salahi, a senior official of the national intelligence agency, said the men had confessed to the killings. State-run Radio Kabul said the suspects were supporters of the former Taliban government and of Osama bin Laden's network, Al Qaeda. Mr. Salahi said one had been arrested several months ago, leading to the arrest of the others. "Because of security issues involved, we could not reveal the arrest of the first person," he said.

title: New Drug Tests in Baseball Stir Debate Among Players
description: The use of muscle-building drugs and amphetamines remains commonplace in Major League Baseball, current and former major leaguers say, even as players are being tested for steroids for the first time this season.

title: Lawyers Dispute Data on Guns in Crime Cases
description: Lawyers representing the gun industry challenged an analysis yesterday showing the source of guns tied to crimes in New York. The N.A.A.C.P., which is suing gun manufacturers and distributors, argues that the analysis helps show that the industry has long known that its distribution policies permit guns to reach criminals.

title: Texas Death Penalty Case to Get Supreme Court Review
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to hear a death-row inmate's appeal in a case that has become a focus of concern over the administration of the death penalty in Texas, a state that has conducted more than a third of the executions in the country in the past 25 years.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Careless Visitors Are Blamed For Fires
description: Wildfires raged in bogs and forests across Ireland over the long Easter weekend, consuming hundreds of acres of gorse, brush and tree plantations. Officials blamed careless visitors to the countryside for accidentally starting the blazes. The state forestry company, Coillte, carried water by helicopter from the Liffey River in Dublin to fires in the mountains south of the city, and firefighters in the midlands had difficulty quenching so-called bog fires, whose flames burn downward into dry peat and resurface later. The fires did not destroy any homes or cause any injuries, but a month of unseasonably dry weather has left firefighters without sufficient water supplies. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Collins Pops Onto Radar For Nets
description: For the better part of a week, controversy has swirled around Jason Collins, the Nets' second-year center. But you would not know it by looking at his placid demeanor or by listening to him speak.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, PANSY MODELL
description: BLOOM-Pansy Modell. The incredible loving wife of Bernard, devoted mother to Peggy and David Gershon, Robin and David Gelles, Heidi and Kenneth Glass. Adored grandmother of Jessica and her husband Michael, Rachel, Alisha, Stefanie, Matthew, Jared and Brandon. Sister of author, B. Modell and Selma Rosen. An Eyshet Hayil, whose sole purpose in life was to do for her husband & family. She will be forever remembered for her wisdom, strength & wonderful ability to love. As part of her total commitment to the traditions of her Jewish faith, she was a dedicated member of Temple Beth Sholom, where her husband Bernie was a past president, and she was always by his side. May her memory be for a blessing.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: JDA Software Reports Loss
description: The JDA Software Group said yesterday that it suffered a first-quarter loss because a 60 percent plunge in software sales caused overall revenue to drop 30 percent. JDA executives told analysts on a conference call that they expected software revenue in the current quarter to rebound from the first quarter, since worries about war in Iraq and the disruption from a restructuring of its sales team will be largely behind the company. They did not give specific second-quarter earnings or revenue goals. For the first quarter, JDA posted a net loss of $2.2 million, or 8 cents a share, compared with a year-earlier net profit of $4.5 million, or 16 cents a share. Revenue fell to $41.3 million from $59.2 million as sales of the company's important software licenses tumbled to $7.7 million from $19.5 million in the year-earlier period. Analysts, who lowered their estimates after the company issued a profit warning on April 2, had expected JDA to report revenue of $41 million, according to Thomson First Call. JDA shares rose 28 cents, to $10.29 a share on the Nasdaq.

title: Relatives of Suspect in Officer's Killing Appear in Court
description: A Passaic man who the authorities say accompanied his cousin on a drug deal that ended in a car chase and the murder of a police officer made his first appearance in court today, along with three relatives who are accused of helping the two men make their escape.

title: A Top Suspect In '91 Massacre Of Croatians Surrenders
description: A former Yugoslav Army commander, charged with directing the 1991 massacre of nearly 300 Croatian civilians during the siege of the Danube port of Vukovar, turned himself in to the Serbian authorities today.

title: Syria Is Forced to Adapt To a New Power Next Door
description: Riad al-Turk, Syria's most outspoken dissident, ticks off the roughly one-third of his life spent as a political prisoner: 13 months under the current president, Bashar al-Assad, a whopping 18 years in solitary confinement under Mr. Assad's late father and sundry years or months stretching almost back to independence in 1946.

title: Alas, Lucretia, Ravished On an Edwardian Sofa
description: The challenges of mounting a new production at the New York City Opera are much eased when the production can first be rehearsed and presented under ideal summer festival conditions at its affiliate company, the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y. The problem is that Glimmerglass has an ideally intimate 900-seat auditorium, while the 2,700-seat New York State Theater is anything but ideal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHSBERG, SHIRLEY
description: FUCHSBERG-Shirley. The Solomon Schechter School of Westchester mourns the death of our esteemed Trustee, grandparent and greatgrandparent, Shirley Fuchsberg. Shirley, along with her late beloved husband, Jack, were founding members of our school community. They nurtured our school in its infancy and Shirley became a matriarch of our Board as it matured. Her passion to provide Jewish education to children from throughout Westchester, her insistence on quality in Jewish education, secular studies and the arts, her honesty, intelligence, zeal and generosity will be a legacy for generations of our students. Her wise counsel will be missed. We offer our condolences to the entire family, children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. M. Mac Schwebel, Chairman Board of Trustees James M. title: World Briefing: Asia
description: BANGLADESH: FERRIES SINK More than 50 bodies were recovered after two ferries, one overloaded and the other carrying a wedding party, sank in Bangladesh rivers during a storm, witnesses said. Rescuers said one ferry, sailing from Dhaka to southern districts, was carrying 400 passengers, double its official capacity. It could be seen floating upside down. People climbed onto it, trying to cut holes in the hull to rescue passengers trapped inside. The other ferry, with about 100 passengers, was caught in the same storm and sank at Kishoreganj, 90 miles northeast of Dhaka. (Reuters)

title: DENDRITE MAKES OFFER FOR SYNAVANT, TOPPING RIVAL BID
description: Dendrite International Inc., which sells marketing and sales software to drug makers, offered to acquire Synavant Inc. for about $38 million in cash, or $2.50 a share. Synavant, which provides customer-relationship management services for pharmaceutical companies, agreed this month to be bought by Cegedim of France for about $35 million, or $2.30 a share. Dendrite, based in Morristown, N.J., filed a lawsuit in the Delaware Chancery Court seeking to have Synavant waive its poison pill, intended to protect the company during a hostile takeover bid, Dendrite said. Synavant is based in Atlanta.

Luella and Frank resided in San Antonio until 1975, when they moved to the New York area and Connecticut. In recent years they returned to San Antonio and their Hill Country ranch. Bennack Jr. of San Antonio and New York City; daughters, Shelley Bennack McCullough and her husband Robert, Dr. Laura Bennack and her husband Ron Peterson, Diane Bennack Sacchetti and her husband John, all of San Antonio, Cynthia Hinson and her husband Eric, Monroe, NC, Julie Bennack, New York City; grandchildren, Brian and Lacey Wulfe, Justin and Jennifer Peterson, Danielle, Nathan, Adam and Mae Hinson, Benjamin Sacchetti, and Connally and Beverly McCullough; sister, Annabelle Leyendecker and her husband Victor; brother, Gary Smith and his wife Joanie, all of San Antonio; sister, Linda Smith, Dallas, TX; numerous nieces and nephews. The family will receive friends Monday evening from 7 PM until 9 PM, at Porter Loring. Mass Tuesday, 12 noon, St. Peter Prince of the Apostles Catholic Church, Rev. Msgr. Liam Brosnan, Celebrant. Interment in Fort Sam Houston National Cemetery. Those who desire may send memorial contributions to the United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, 80 Maiden Lane, New York City, New York, 10038, or the San Antonio Youth Literacy, 700 N. St. Mary's St., Suite 210, San Antonio, TX 78205. The family invites you to leave a message or memory at www.porterloring.com by selecting Visitation and Services. Select Sign Guestbook at the bottom of the individual Memorial. For information, Porter Loring Mortuary, 210-227-8221.

title: White House May Reduce Plan for Dividend Tax Cut
description: Acknowledging that Democratic opposition and a revolt among moderate Republicans had forced them to lower their ambitions, Bush administration officials said today that they were considering scaling back President Bush's proposal to eliminate the tax that individual investors pay on stock dividends.

title: France Calls for Suspending U.N. Sanctions on Iraq
description: UNITED NATIONS (Reuters) - France's U.N. ambassador proposed Tuesday immediately suspending sanctions on Iraq and phasing out the U.N. oil-for-food program.

title: Fraud and Fear Mar Election in Nigeria, Monitors Say
description: Even as they commended the patience and fortitude of Nigerian voters, two groups of election observers from the United States expressed concern today about fraud and intimidation in some parts of the country on Election Day, and called on the government to improve confidence in the democratic process.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Jail For Soldiers In Killing
description: A military court convicted seven members of Indonesia's elite special forces for the torture and murder of Theys Eluay, the leader of a nonviolent campaign for independence for Irian Jaya, Indonesia's mineral-rich, easternmost province. Mr. Eluay was tortured, then strangled, in November 2001, after attending a party with the soldiers. It was only after intense pressure from the United States and Australia that Indonesia undertook a serious investigation, and ultimately a trial. The convictions are a rare instance of soldiers being prosecuted for human rights abuses. The maximum sentence today was 3.5 years, which brought immediate criticism from human rights advocates here. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: Editorial Observer; Try Telling the Politicians in Maine That Tax Cuts Are a Great Blessing
description: During a break in the Statehouse labors of stanching Maine's revenue hemorrhage, Representative Peter Mills, a rock-ribbed Republican and fiscal conservative, laughed out loud at the very notion of President Bush's dispatching emissaries to lobby the nation for still another big tax cut for wealthy Americans.

title: A Lifetime in Restoration, From Pianos to Prisoners
description: THE former lumberyard loading dock that serves as the vestibule of his eclectic theater company, the Culture Project at 45 Bleecker Street, is haunted by portraits of the dead, and the near-dead: all are residents, or former residents, of death row. Harit Allan Buchman, a producer whose own near-death experience was self-inflicted in a Triumph Spitfire sports car when he mistakenly presumed himself immortal at 19, is on personal terms with the portraits. Death row, he said, has its own cult outside; who knew?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PITT, JANE, M.D.
description: PITT-Jane, M.D. The faculty, staff, and students of Columbia University Health Sciences mourn the loss of a dear friend and esteemed colleague, Dr. Jane Pitt. A graduate of Radcliffe College and Harvard Medical School, Dr. Pitt had been a member of the Columbia University Health Sciences community since 1971, most recently serving as professor of clinical pediatrics at Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons and as an attending physician at Children's Hospital of New York at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. In her roles as medical educator, scholar, clinician, and advocate, Dr. Pitt remained deeply and steadfastly committed to improving the health and lives of children, dedicating her life to combating and treating a wide variety of pediatric infectious diseases including pediatric AIDS. In one of her most visible positions at Columbia Health Sciences, Dr. Pitt led the Women's and Children's Care Center at Children's Hospital, providing compassionate care for countless women and children with HIV. We extend our most heartfelt sympathies to her family, including her beloved children Jennifer and Eric. Her tireless and heroic spirit will be missed. Gerald D. Fischbach, M.D. Executive Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences and Dean of the Faculty of Medicine Columbia University

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, HERBERT
description: GOLDSTEIN-Herbert, died on April 17, 2003 at age 89. Beloved husband of Dalia for 25 years, brother of Fifi Daum of N.C. and her family. His family, friends and colleagues will profoundly miss his kindness, love and caring.

title: National Briefing | Health And Science: Morning-After Pill
description: The Women's Capital Corporation, the maker of a morning-after contraceptive pill called Plan B, applied to the Food and Drug Administration for permission to sell the drug over-the-counter. The drug is a high concentration of a hormone used in birth control pills, which can prevent pregnancy if taken within 72 hours of unprotected sex. Doctors do not know exactly why it works, but believe the hormones either delay ovulation or block the fertilization of an egg. Plan B, the more widely used of two morning-after pills available in this country, is now sold by prescription only, except in three states that allow certain pharmacists to dispense it. Kate Zernike (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Officer Can Testify In Secret
description: A federal judge agreed yesterday to a government request that he bar the public from the courtroom when an undercover police officer testifies in a drug trial in Federal District Court, lawyers said. The officer will be identified only by a badge number, and a transcript will be released after the testimony, which is expected to begin today. Prosecutors had argued that many of the officer's investigations were still open, that he was still returning to the same neighborhood, and that revealing his identity could endanger him and his ability to continue his undercover work. The judge, Thomas P. Griesa, ruled on the matter after a closed hearing. The lawyer for the defendant, Theo Frazier, had opposed closing the courtroom. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: McGahee Hopes to Allay Concerns Before Draft
description: Willis McGahee allowed himself three days to be depressed, one for each ligament he tore in his left knee in the Fiesta Bowl more than three months ago.

title: J.P. MORGAN TO STOP LEASING CARS IN TWO STATES
description: J. P. Morgan Chase & Company said yesterday that it would stop leasing cars in New York and Connecticut because of state laws that allow accident victims to sue leasing companies. The bank told auto dealers it would not purchase lease contracts in the two states after July 1, according to a spokeswoman, Charlotte Gilbert-Biro. J. P. Morgan lost a $28 million suit in Rhode Island last October and has already exited the business in that state. ''It no longer makes sense,'' said Jeffrey Levine, general counsel for the Chase Manhattan Automotive Finance Corporation. ''The downside risk of liability outweighs our ability to economically justify the leasing business in those states.'' The bank follows General Motors and Ford in pulling out of New York auto leasing as the cost of defending against lawsuits has risen.

title: RealNetworks To Acquire Listen.com, A Music Site
description: RealNetworks, a maker of software that plays Internet audio and video files, said yesterday that it would buy Listen.com, a closely held concern, for $36 million in cash and stock to obtain an Internet music subscription service.

description: Because of the seventh and eighth days of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow and Thursday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Inquiry Focuses on Skeletons of Space Shuttles
description: When the space shuttle Columbia first flew, 22 years ago this month, much attention was paid to its skin, which was made of a new type of heat-resistant tile. Few people focused on its skeleton, made of a much more familiar material -- lightweight, inexpensive aluminum.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Postal Shares For Sale
description: Singapore Telecommunications will begin the initial public offering for its postal subsidiary today, the company said. SingTel hopes to sell 60 percent of SingPost, the privatized Singapore postal system, for as much as 684 million Singapore dollars ($386 million) by the time the offering closes on May 6. The company will be placing its shares internationally, but said they would not be for sale in the United States, Canada or Japan. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Cheaper Air Fares
description: The Irish low-fare airline Ryanair Holdings will cut ticket prices by about 5 percent annually over the next five years, the airline's chief executive told Handelsblatt, a German daily. ''While many airlines will hike prices due to cost problems, we will cut our average price of 49 euros by another 5 percent annually,'' the chief executive of Ryanair, Michael O'Leary, said, according to an advance copy of an interview to be published today.

title: Five German Banks to Pool Loans in Joint Venture
description: FRANKFURT, April 22  Five of Germany's largest banks, mired in their worst downturn since World War II, plan to announce on Wednesday that they will pool up to $50 billion worth of loans in a new joint venture, which would help to lighten their over-burdened balance sheets.

title: For Spring, Color Is the New Black
description: Well before a bum economy, terrorism and war had entered the picture, retailers were intoning a mantra suggesting that Americans already owned all the basic wardrobe elements anyone could ever require. After submitting the image struggles of chains like the Gap to endless dissection, their underlying problems turn out to be rooted in something surprisingly simple: khaki fatigue.

title: Yale Graduate Students Will Be Polled on Union
description: The organization seeking to unionize more than 2,100 graduate teaching assistants and researchers at Yale announced yesterday that it would hold a secret-ballot election on April 30 to determine whether the university's graduate students want a union.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 22  President Hamid Karzai said today that he had won assurances from Pakistan that it would try to stem the violent cross-border attacks that Taliban and other rebels have been launching against Afghanistan in recent months.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: AT&T Unit Shifts On Bankruptcy
description: The AT&T Latin America Corporation, an unprofitable data-transmission unit of AT&T, said it converted its bankruptcy case into a voluntary one. The company, which was forced into bankruptcy last week by a creditor, MatlinPatterson Global Advisors, said it filed a request to convert its bankruptcy to Chapter 11 in Miami. The company said it planned to continue seeking a new owner or investor. AT&T cut off financing to the unit in October, creating a $40 million gap.

title: The Citizen-Scientist's Obligation to Stand Up for Standards
description: On April 2, I appeared at a symposium for students and teachers sponsored by the Illinois Math and Science Academy, a remarkably successful high school founded by Dr. Leon M. Lederman, a Nobel laureate in physics, to foster young people's interest in science.

title: U.S. Administrator in Iraq Pledges a 'Mosaic' Government
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  The top American civilian administrator for Iraq met today in northern Iraq with the two main Kurdish leaders and called for a new Iraqi government to be a "mosaic," fairly representing all Iraqis.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: No Major Job Growth Seen This Year
description: New York State lost 293,000 jobs in 2001 and 2002, more than two-thirds of them, 206,000, in New York City, state officials said yesterday. This year, the rate of job loss has slowed and there are ''promising economic signs'' in some areas. ''But we do not expect to see any major job growth this year,'' State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said. Jeanne B. Pinder (NYT)

title: Baghdad Workers Wait for Work, and American Managers
description: BAGHDAD, April 22  For four days now, the managers of public health services in Iraq have been going to the 12-story Ministry of Health, cleaning up after looters and waiting expectantly for the Americans they heard were coming.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Chip Investments
description: The Sony Corporation and its video game subsidiary, Sony Computer Entertainment Inc., will team with the Toshiba Corporation to build semiconductors for devices that work on high-speed networks. The companies will invest about 200 billion yen ($1.7 billion) during the next three years and start production in Japan of the large-scale integrated circuits by the second half of 2004. The chips will be code-named Cell and be integrated into the successor to the popular PlayStation 2 game consoles. The companies have worked with I.B.M. on developing the technology for the chips since 2001. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Knife-Holding Boy Is Shot
description: A police officer shot a 16-year-old boy in Elizabeth, N.J., last night after the boy came toward him with a knife, the police said. Just before 7 p.m., officers were called to an apartment on Elizabeth Avenue, where the boy was reportedly holding his younger brother at knifepoint.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: IRELAND: CARELESS VISITORS ARE BLAMED FOR FIRES Wildfires raged in bogs and forests across Ireland over the long Easter weekend, consuming hundreds of acres of gorse, brush and tree plantations. Officials blamed careless visitors to the countryside for accidentally starting the blazes. The state forestry company, Coillte, carried water by helicopter from the Liffey River in Dublin to fires in the mountains south of the city, and firefighters in the midlands had difficulty quenching so-called bog fires, whose flames burn downward into dry peat and resurface later. The fires did not destroy any homes or cause any injuries, but a month of unseasonably dry weather has left firefighters without sufficient water supplies. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: As Their Leaders Wrangle, Palestinians Look Askance
description: As his leaders clashed over what men would hold which seats in a new Palestinian government, Jamal Abu Rumi, college graduate and father of seven, sat at a curbside falafel restaurant here today with less than a dollar in his pocket, places to go and no hope of getting there.

description: Abbas Baloch gazed ruefully at a wide, shallow bay of the Arabian Sea. ''This used to be our land,'' he said. ''And now it's covered by the sea.''

title: More Machinations from Yasir Arafat
description: Yasir Arafat always stalls until the 11th hour before a fateful decision, often going on to make the wrong one. He is playing that game again today, withholding his approval from the government proposed by the new Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas. Mr. Arafat is holding shut the doors to any chance of reviving the search for peace in order to cling to what is left of his power. The greatest service Mr. Arafat could render his people, and his legacy, is to get out of the way.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Call Center Switched From India
description: Under fire for subcontracting a state service to India, the state Department of Human Services announced yesterday that it would now transfer callers seeking help with food stamps and other benefits to a center in New Jersey instead of one in Bombay. The department and eFunds, a private company handling the customer service, had moved the call center from Green Bay, Wis., to India in February 2002 to cut costs. But New Jersey legislators complained, so the company is planning to open a center in Camden in May, he said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: S.E.C. Looks At AOL Deal With Vivendi

title: World Briefing | Americas: Uruguay: Compensation For Dictatorship
description: President Jorge Batlle has announced that the government will pay damages to the families of people who died while in the custody of the military dictatorship that governed the country from 1973 to 1985, as well as to victims of guerrilla groups during that time. The decision is a result of an investigation Mr. Batlle ordered when he took office in 2000 and is intended to blunt efforts by left-wing groups to bring to trial those responsible for the disappearance of scores of people during the dictatorship. ''Uruguay cannot think of only some and not of others,'' Mr. Batlle said. ''It is time to turn the page and rebuild peace through the efforts of all.'' Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHSBERG, SHIRLEY G.
description: FUCHSBERG - Shirley G. Touro College Jacob D. Fuchsberg Law Center mourns the loss of our cherished friend, wise counselor, and generous benefactor. As a member of the Law School's Board of Visitors, Shirley was a source of strength and wisdom, providing leadership and guidance-always tempered with reality, humor and style. She was a true philanthropist-giving generously of her time and talent, along with her financial support. Her love of life and generosity of spirit will be sorely missed. She was intensely devoted to her family, but yet found the time to share her smile and her warmth with countless friends and charitable endeavors. To Roz and Dick, Susan and Ralph, Janet and Peter, and Alan and Robin along with her many grandchildren and greatgrandchildren, we extend our deepest sympathies and join you in celebrating her life. Howard A. Glickstein, Dean

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Ciber To Acquire Alphanet For $28.8 Million
description: Ciber Inc., a computer-consulting company, has agreed to buy AlphaNet Solutions Inc. for about $28.8 million, providing additional customers in New York and New Jersey. Ciber will pay $4.05 a share in cash or Ciber common stock for each AlphaNet share, Ciber said. The per-share value is 76 percent more than AlphaNet's closing price Thursday of $2.30. AlphaNet, which provides information-technology consulting, systems- integration and Internet-related services, has annual revenue of about $22 million, Ciber said. AlphaNet is a smaller regional competitor, a Ciber spokesman, Doug Eisenbrandt, said. The purchase will allow Ciber to add new and larger multinational customers in New York and New Jersey, Mr. Eisenbrandt added. The acquisition, which is expected to be completed by early in the third quarter, may add about $12 million to revenue and about 1 cent a share to earnings for the year, Ciber said. The company, based in Greenwood Village, Colo., helps software and hardware sold by different vendors work together. Shares of AlphaNet rose $1.66, or 72 percent, to $3.96 a share, yesterday on the Nasdaq. Ciber shares rose 6 cents, to $5.05.

title: Ask Jeeves Names A TBWA Sibling
description: Ask Jeeves Inc. in Emeryville, Calif., has expanded its relationship with the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group by naming the San Francisco office of TBWA/Chiat/Day to handle creative and strategic planning duties on its account.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Internet Security Says Profits May Exceed Predictions
description: Shares of Internet Security Systems Inc., whose software protects computer networks from intruders, rose 11 percent on the Nasdaq yesterday after the company said second-quarter profits and sales might exceed analysts' forecasts. Profits, excluding some costs, will be 13 cents to 15 cents a share on sales of $60 million to $64 million, the company said late Thursday. Analysts on average expected earnings of 13 cents a share and sales of $62 million, according to Thomson First Call. First-quarter profits rose 59 percent as costs fell and sales gained 1.8 percent. Internet Security shares, which dropped 43 percent last year and 46 percent in the first quarter, rose $1.30, or 11 percent, to $13.11. Profits, excluding acquisition costs and other items, this year will be 57 cents to 65 cents a share, the company said. On that basis, which does not comply with generally accepted accounting principles, profits are expected to be 56 cents, according to Thomson First Call. Sales this year will be $248 million to $260 million, the company said. That compares with analysts' average forecast of $254.4 million.

Then, starting in the 1980's, many departed, including General Foods and Texaco, in the mergers-and-acquisitions binge of the 80's and the downsizing that went with it. Soon 99-cent stores and tattoo parlors were sprouting in the formerly bustling downtown.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: An SK Unit Seeks Help
description: Even as the South Korean government has moved to head off a feared takeover bid for the SK Corporation, the country's largest oil refiner, by Sovereign Asset Management, executives of a troubled sister company are turning to Sovereign for help. SK Global, a trading company with $5.6 billion in debt and a swirling accounting scandal, is trying to arrange a bailout by its siblings in the SK Group, the country's third-largest conglomerate. Jung Man Won, the executive in charge of the effort, said he would ask Sovereign, a Monaco-based investment fund that has bought almost 15 percent of the SK Corporation's shares, to help finance the package because SK Corporation owns 38 percent of SK Global. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 3 Accused Of Faking Tiffany Jewelry
description: Federal authorities have arrested three people and accused them of selling counterfeit Tiffany & Co. jewelry. Nadine Vargas and her husband, Yaniv Shamir, had advertised the pieces on the Internet, according to a federal complaint. In December, federal agents found about 600 pieces of fake Tiffany jewelry at the couple's Staten Island home, the complaint said. The third suspect, Chee-Soon Tai, operated a store on Canal Street in Manhattan that sold fake Tiffany pieces, according to federal authorities. All three were arrested last week and charged with criminal copyright infringement. If convicted, they face up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Mr. Shamir and Ms. Vargas bought the jewelry ''legitimately at estate sales,'' their lawyer said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

description: The National Steel Corporation won bankruptcy court approval yesterday to sell its assets to the U.S. Steel Corporation for $850 million. U.S. Steel was chosen as the winning bidder after a two-day auction last week. It beat a higher offer by the AK Steel Holding Corporation that did not include an agreement with the steelworkers' union. U.S. Steel has negotiated a collective bargaining agreement with the union, and it will assume about $200 million in liabilities. Judge John H. Squires of United States Bankruptcy Court in Chicago approved the sale. The acquisition of National Steel's assets will allow U.S. Steel, based in Pittsburgh, to secure its position as the biggest steel maker in the nation.

title: CHIRON SAYS CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER WILL RESIGN
description: The Chiron Corporation, a leading biotechnology company, said yesterday that its chief financial officer, James Sulat, would resign. David Smith, 43, the vice president for finance, will take the post for an interim, it said. Mr. Sulat, 55, will leave next month ''to pursue other opportunities,'' a company spokesman, John Gallagher, said. Chiron, which sells vaccines, blood tests and drugs, hired a GlaxoSmithKline executive, Howard Pien, last month to take over as chief executive, succeeding Sean P. Lance, who remains chairman. Mr. Sulat, who has been at Chiron since 1998, declined to comment. Chiron is based in Emeryville, Calif.

title: CONOCOPHILLIPS TO BUY PART OF REFINERY FROM PREMCOR

ConocoPhillips, based in Houston, will buy processing units and other assets at the 70,000-barrel-a-day refinery in Hartford, Ill., Premcor said. The plant is near a ConocoPhillips's refinery, a 286,000-barrel-a-day operation in Wood River, Ill. The sale price was less than the value Premcor had placed on the assets. That shortfall and costs associated with the transaction will reduce Premcor's first-quarter earnings by $16.6 million before taxes, the company said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: U.S. Yields On Search Ruling
description: The government has decided against appealing a ruling by a federal district judge that could imperil scores of related prosecutions around the country. The ruling was issued last month in a child-pornography case involving a Bronx man. The charge of possessing child pornography will be dismissed against the defendant, Harvey Perez, his lawyer said. Prosecutors had no comment yesterday. The judge, Denny Chin, ruled that F.B.I. agents ''acted with reckless disregard for the truth'' in preparing an affidavit used to get a search warrant for Mr. Perez's computer. Mr. Perez was accused of joining an Internet group and possessing pornography e-mailed from other members. But Judge Chin noted that not all members of the group chose to be on the e-mail list. The government has also decided not to appeal a similar ruling in St. Louis and has dropped charges against that defendant, his lawyer said. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

The winning time at the Pearl River High School Relays in Rockland County was among the leading times in the country this outdoor season.

title: On the Art-Loan Front, Diplomacy Still Works
description: POLITICS and art, like money and friends, should be kept well apart. When they mix, things can go wrong badly: witness Hitler's attack on modern art as degenerate and Stalin's promotion of grim Socialist Realism. Experience shows that art is best left to artists and art lovers, with museums and galleries acting as intermediaries. Likewise, it is meaningless to attribute nationalities to art. Every major museum in the West boasts artists from dozens of countries.

The owner, David Muller, has a small herd of water buffaloes, whose milk has more calcium than cows' milk, he said. The yogurt, which comes plain or sweetened with Vermont maple syrup, is about $2 for a six-ounce container.

Simon Wiesenthal, the Holocaust survivor who devoted his life to tracking down fugitives responsible for the mass slaughter of Jews in World War II, told an Austrian magazine, Format, last week that he was closing his files. ''I found the mass murderers I was looking for, and I have outlived them all,'' he told the magazine. ''If there's a few I didn't look for, they are now too old and too fragile to stand trial.''

Survived by his wife of 57 years, Judeth Henken; his sons David, Joshua and Ethan; his daughter Tamar; his daughters-in-law Roni, Dorrie, Cynthia and Judy; and seven grandchildren: Danny, Adam, Michal, Eyal, Rebecca, Benjamin and Ariel. title: Flyers Slam Door On the Maple Leafs
description: Keith Primeau's previous playoff goal was a memorable one, but you have to have a moderately long memory to remember it. It came in the fifth overtime in the Philadelphia Flyers' victory in Pittsburgh on May 4, 2000.

title: Stern Backs Newark Arena
description: David Stern, the N.B.A. commissioner, expressed hope again tonight that the Nets would be able to reach a deal to build an arena in Newark, and he insisted that despite setbacks, the Nets would find a new home in New Jersey.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Trade Pact Threatened
description: The European Union again condemned Cuba's recent crackdown on dissidents and said the events had devastated relations in advance of a possible trade and aid pact. ''Clearly, politically, recent events have had a devastating effect,'' a spokesman for the union was quoted as saying by Agence France-Presse. European foreign ministers are to meet in June to consider the pact, which has been jeopardized by the imprisonment of about 75 dissidents and the execution this month of three men who hijacked a ferry. The spokesman said the deal was not dead. ''Let's not prejudge the situation,'' he said. ''It may improve from now until June.'' David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: McDyess Has Knee Surgery
description: Antonio McDyess, the Knicks' franchise-player-in-waiting, had bone graft surgery yesterday to expedite the healing of his broken left kneecap. The doctors, Michael Stuart and Robert Trousdale, who performed the operation at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., said the two-hour operation was successful, but no timetable other than ''sometime next season'' was given for McDyess's return to the court.

description: AOL Time Warner reported its first quarterly profit today since America Online acquired Time Warner more than two years ago.

description: This nation of one billion plus has tried just about every population disincentive known to man, including paying people to stop having children. So how to explain that one community here is paying its members to have more?

title: New Direction for Panel Investigating Columbia Loss
description: The chairman of the board investigating the breakup of the shuttle Columbia said today that the panel was moving into a new phase and planned to develop a working hypothesis for the accident and refine it to fit the available evidence.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank's Profit Falls
description: South Korea's largest financial institution, Kookmin Bank, reported income of 73.9 billion won ($61 million) in the first quarter of this year, down 89 percent from the 672.2 billion won ($558 million) that it earned in the first three months of 2002. The decline was attributed in large part to delinquencies in payments to its credit card units, including an affiliate, Kookmin Credit Card, and another that is an integral part of the bank. Yet another factor was the bank's exposure to SK Global, the trading arm of the SK Group, Korea's third-largest conglomerate. SK Global's debts total 8.2 trillion won, including 448.7 billion won owed to Kookmin. The price of Kookmin shares on the Korea Stock Exchange has dropped 21 percent this year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Health Care Accounting Urged
description: The state comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, yesterday urged Gov. George E. Pataki and the State Legislature to account for billions of dollars in annual health care spending within the state's budget, rather than outside it. An $8.7 billion extension of that program, known as the Health Care Reform Act, has been proposed for July. At this time, Mr. Hevesi said, about half the spending and revenue for the program is off budget, with the effect of shielding that spending from public view, artificially understating the state budget and reducing oversight of the spending. Al Baker (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., the largest provider of private-label credit cards, said it had won a seven-year extension of a card services contract with Lowe's Cos., Wilkesboro, N.C., the home-improvement chain. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Indonesian Cleric Denies Terror Accusations
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 23  A radical Islamic cleric who was long considerable untouchable here, sat impassively today as he listened to prosecutors accuse him of participating in terrorist acts against Indonesian Christians, and plotting to blow up the American embassy in Singapore.

title: A Collection Based On Good Connections
description: YOU never know what you'll find at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum in New York. Last July, for instance, a British art expert was combing through a box of drawings and unearthed a Michelangelo. In a collection of 250,000 objects that spans 23 centuries -- a quirky mix that runs the gamut from birdcages to buttons, blenders to books -- surprises turn up everywhere.

description: WASHINGTON, April 23  French officials responded brusquely today to an assertion by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell that France would be made to suffer for its opposition to the war in Iraq.

description: ON a warm Sunday afternoon, several dozen parishioners from the Church of the Living Christ in Fremont, Mich., assembled in front of a museum here. The day's tickets were already sold out, but this group had made its reservation long in advance.

title: Softer Washington Market Still Draws Interest
description: Nearing completion in this city's East End, a rapidly developing area popular with large law firms, is a new high-end office building that has been grafted onto a Hecht's department store. The six-story white-and-tan building, known as One Metro Center, has a sky lobby and sits directly over the Metro Center subway hub.

description: FOR anyone who has ever wondered why scientists and the public are so often at loggerheads over issues of food safety, Marion Nestle's provocative new book, ''Safe Food: Bacteria, Biotechnology and Bioterrorism'' (University of California Press, 2003), provides something of an answer.

description: PLEXIGLASS boxes protect the lions flanking its south entrance, and a plywood ramp covers its stairs, the better to roll crates of precious artworks into moving vans. Most of the collection is already in storage; next week , the Pierpont Morgan Library, one of New York's best-loved museums, will close for a $100 million renovation.

title: Accounts
description: * Gateway, Poway, Calif., to StarLink Worldwide, Chicago, to handle media planning and buying on its account, which had been handled by Initiative Media North America, New York, part of the Initiative Media Worldwide division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings were estimated at $150 million. StarLink is part of the Starcom MediaVest Group division of the Publicis Groupe. Last month, Gateway named Leo Burnett USA and Frankel, which are Publicis siblings in Chicago, to handle creative duties.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Home Improvement Sting
description: Sixty housing contractors face criminal charges for failing to register properly with the Department of Consumer Protection, the department's commissioner, James Fleming, announced yesterday. The unregistered contractors were caught in a sting that lasted four months. They had been invited to a house in Bristol and asked to bid on various jobs, including painting and roofing. State law mandates that all home improvement contractors register with the agency and pay a $160 annual fee. If convicted, each faces up to a year in jail and a $2,000 fine. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Testifying Anonymously in Drug Case, Undercover Officer Describes the Fear of His Work
description: An undercover police officer testified Monday that if there is a theme to his work, it is fear: fear of being discovered, fear of retaliation, fear of being attacked inside an apartment without being able to call for backup.

description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 22 - The Devils will open their second-round playoff series against the Tampa Bay Lightning on Thursday night at Continental Arena, the N.H.L. said today.

description: LONDON, April 23  Prime Minister Tony Blair issued a public challenge to the Irish Republican Army today, saying its refusal to make a clean break with its violent past was the sole remaining obstacle to a lasting peace in Northern Ireland.

description: In early February, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg issued a report on the status of various campaign promises he had made. Among those listed as ''done'' was a pledge to create segregated classrooms for disruptive students.

title: Open Pass for Three
description: The former champions Hale Irwin, Tom Kite and Tom Watson will play in this year's United States Open under special exemptions from the United States Golf Association. Irwin, 57, a three-time champion, has played in 32 consecutive Opens, the longest active streak. The Open will be played June 12-15 at Olympia Fields (Ill.) Country Club.

title: Maoist Rebels in Nepal Delay Talks With the Government
description: Talks between the government of Nepal and Maoist rebels have been postponed. A spokesman for the Maoists said on Monday that the two sides had differed over the initial agenda for the talks.

title: Ex-Credit Suisse Banker Charged With Obstructing Justice
description: Frank P. Quattrone, a former investment banker with Credit Suisse First Boston and other leading Wall Street investment firms, was arrested today on charges that he obstructed investigations by a federal grand jury and the Securities and Exchange Commission and that he engaged in witness tampering.

title: McGreevey Restricts Building Near Reservoirs and Waterways
description: Warning that unchecked real estate development has threatened New Jersey's drinking water supply, Gov. James E. McGreevey announced today that the state would impose new regulations that would sharply restrict building near 15 reservoirs, rivers and streams.

Service of Remembrance will take place at the Hartford Chapel of New York Presbyterian Hospital on Wednesday, 4 PM. Family members and friends may call Jay J. Sangerman at 212-922-0711.

title: Nigerian President Declared Winner Amid Cries of Fraud
description: Even as opposition parties denounced election results as ''frivolous,'' the Nigerian president, Olusegun Obasanjo, was declared the winner of a second term late this evening, inheriting fresh, potentially perilous challenges in an already divided country.

title: Tackling a Tall Order: The Bamiyan Buddha
description: TWO years after the giant statues known as the Buddhas of Bamiyan were destroyed by the Taliban, work to salvage the remnants and to prepare the site for a museum has been delayed because of security concerns throughout the region.

title: Opposition Candidate in Nigeria Urges New Vote
description: ABUJA, Nigeria, April 23  Calling last Saturday's presidential elections "the most fraudulent" in Nigeria's 40-year history, the chief opposition candidate this afternoon called for fresh elections, rejected redress through legal channels, and appealed to world powers to refuse to recognize a government that he said had rigged its return to rule.

title: An Old Box Factory Is a Haven for New Art
description: Michael Govan remembers the day he got his first glimpse of the abandoned 1929 factory built of steel, concrete and glass that overlooks the Hudson River and has since been transformed into Dia:Beacon, a $50 million art museum opening on May 18.

title: A Matter of Trust
description: One would think that America's commercial airlines had enough trouble these days without engaging in bad-faith bargaining with the unions, whose help they desperately need to stay aloft. This is, after all, an industry suffering from relentless competition from low-cost carriers, bloated overhead, an outdated business model and a travel-shy public. Amazingly, though, American Airlines has brought still more trouble upon itself by failing to disclose generous compensation packages for its senior executives even as it was asking the company's rank and file for wage and other concessions of $1.62 billion a year.

title: Corrections
description: A movie review in Weekend on April 11 about an aspiring filmmaker misstated the medium in which it was made, and a correction in this space yesterday misstated its title. It was made on film, not on digital video. Its title is ''XX/XY,'' not ''XX/YY.''

title: Profits More Than Double at Pfizer, but Lilly Posts a Decline
description: Pfizer said yesterday that first-quarter earnings more than doubled on the sale of businesses, while costs to cut jobs pulled down profit at Eli Lilly. Both reported increased sales of treatments for conditions from high cholesterol to schizophrenia.

title: Lawyers Taking Aim at Ford On Veracity of Expert
description: Questions about the credibility of an expert witness in lawsuits involving rollover accidents are putting the Ford Motor Company on the defensive, as lawyers for accident victims press claims that Ford covered up evidence that its Bronco II sport utility vehicle was dangerous.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Electrolux Lowers Outlook
description: The appliance maker Electrolux lowered its profit forecast for this year when presenting first-quarter results. In the first three months, net profit fell 58 percent, to 1.25 billion kronor ($149 million), as sales fell 4.5 percent, to 32.1 billion kronor, because of weaker demand in China, India, North America and Europe. The strength of the Swedish currency against the United States dollar also hurt results. Pretax profit was down 51 percent, to 1.79 billion kronor, but was in line with the market's expectations. For the full year, Electrolux said it expected its operating profit to be ''somewhat lower'' than last year's 7.5 billion kronor. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: A Big Room for Bigger Appetites
description: JEFFERY CHODOROW, the owner of Tuscan, is as much a social director as he is a restaurateur. Over the years, he has made his reputation by creating carefully designed dining environments that draw a young, attractive, fashion-conscious crowd. Even when his restaurants don't have a bouncer and a velvet rope, they feel as if they should. The food, which tends to be a series of stylistic gestures, ranges in quality from so-so to dreadful. Mr. Chodorow's target audience does not care, as long as the cosmopolitans are the right shade of pink.

title: Gap Opens Review For 3 Retail Chains
description: Gap Inc. has begun a review for an agency to handle United States television-buying assignments for its Banana Republic, Gap and Old Navy retail chains, which had been handled internally or on a project basis. Though billings were not disclosed, Gap spent $496 million advertising those brands last year.

title: Stars Come Out Firing in the Playoffs
description: Less than an hour after playing his final game last Wednesday, Michael Jordan stepped into the back of a media room, an unlit cigar hanging out of his mouth, and heard Allen Iverson, the diminutive Philadelphia 76ers star, say that Jordan was the reason he began playing basketball.

title: Justices Question California's Holocaust Victim Insurance Law
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  The Supreme Court appeared likely today to overturn California's Holocaust Victim Insurance Relief Act, which requires insurance companies doing business in the state to disclose information about every policy that they or their affiliates sold in Europe from 1920 through 1945.

title: Lots of Rubbernecking In These Traffic Jams
description: IN planning for the ''Matisse Picasso'' show, which has been drawing up to 4,000 visitors a day at the Museum of Modern Art in Queens, designers used a large three-dimensional architectural model of the exhibition to analyze where the masterpieces, the benches and the people would go. To make the long lines that were expected tolerable, the museum developed a plan that included street greeters, timed tickets, ticket scanners and extra coat-check stations. To keep visitors moving after they got inside the galleries, there have been plenty of security guards, a limited number of text panels to make sure people don't take too much time reading them and a one-way-in one-way-out traffic flow.

title: N.F.L. Draft: Image Is No.1 Pick
description: On the night of May 30 last year, the lights of a police car flashed across Ken Hamlin's windshield as he was about to pull into his apartment complex in Fayetteville, Ark., not far from the University of Arkansas campus.

description: The Bush team's vision for a postwar Iraq was founded on the dreams of exiles and defectors, who promised that Iraqis would shower American troops with flowers. Now, with the crowds shouting, ''No to America; no to Saddam,'' and most Iraqis already referring to the American ''occupation,'' the Bush administration seems puzzled.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: PROMOTING SECULARISM France needs a new law to keep religion and racism out of state schools, Education Minister Luc Ferry told Europe 1 radio. "We have to reaffirm very strongly the principles of republican secularism," Mr. Ferry said, against the rise of racism and anti-Semitism. "That requires a new law." The ideal, he added, would be to have "no sign of religion in school." The wearing of veils or head scarves by Muslim girls and other open displays of religiosity, including crucifixes, are banned in French schools, although some teachers turn a blind eye. At a Muslim conference on Saturday, Interior Minister Nicolas Sarkozy was booed when he said Muslim women must remove head scarves for identity card photographs.

title: A City Where Locals Are Welcome
description: AT the Museum of Contemporary Art here, the chief curator, Paul Schimmel, is committed to showing new work -- very new work. In organizing a recent survey of paintings by Laura Owens, a 33-year-old artist on the faculty at the University of California at Los Angeles, Mr. Schimmel selected not just her signature images -- beehives modeled with gobs of paint -- but also timelier paintings, like a wall-size landscape dotted with antiwar protesters. ''It was finished on the Tuesday before the opening on Saturday,'' Mr. Schimmel said.

title: Popovers, and a Century of Advice
description: ELLEN LEVINE moved her company into a new building a few weeks back, and when she tried to close the fancy double doors to her office, they kept jamming. She gave up and laughed. ''I'm the housewife from hell this week,'' she said easily, sitting cross-legged on the couch.

description: In Los Angeles, they not only show the work of local artists but even compete to find the next new star.

title: IRAN SAID TO SEND AGENTS INTO IRAQ
description: Iranian-trained agents have crossed into southern Iraq since the fall of Saddam Hussein and are working in the cities of Najaf, Karbala and Basra to promote friendly Shiite clerics and advance Iranian interests, according to defense and other United States government officials.

title: Norbert A. Schlei, 73, Legal Adviser in Kennedy-Johnson Era
description: Norbert Anthony Schlei, a legal adviser in the Kennedy and Johnson White House who played major roles in the Cuban missile crisis and civil rights legislation, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 73 and lived and practiced law in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: A Return To Court
description: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela was back in court on charges of fraud and theft. A prosecutor told the court that Ms. Madikizela-Mandela, a leading figure in the country's struggle against apartheid and the ex-wife of the former South African president, Nelson Mandela, did not make a credible defense. ''Her evidence was so bad,'' the prosecutor, Jan Ferreira, said, it was as if ''she hadn't testified at all.'' Ms. Madikizela-Mandela, 64, is charged with fraud and theft in a scheme to obtain bank loans for nonexistent employees of the African National Congress Women's League, which she heads. She has called the state's evidence ''a pack of lies'' and testified that she had been duped into taking part in the scheme. If convicted, she could face 15 years in prison. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: A Place to Hang Out and Learn a Thing or Two
description: THE most revolutionary thing about the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art's new education center is neither its slickly minimal design nor the array of technologies it uses, but its location: 7,000 square feet on the museum's second floor, right next to the permanent collection.
