title: Edgar F. Codd, 79, Dies; Key Theorist of Databases
description: Edgar F. Codd, a mathematician and computer scientist who laid the theoretical foundation for relational databases, the standard method by which information is organized in and retrieved from computers, died on Friday at his home in Williams Island, Fla. He was 79.

title: Milwaukee Finds Way To Turn the Tables
description: Bucks Coach George Karl was walking, satisfied, through the corridors of Continental Arena after Milwaukee's 88-85 victory in Game 2 of their first-round playoff series against the Nets tonight. As he headed to the Bucks' locker room, Gary Payton was headed in the opposite direction, and after a brief shaking of hands, Karl implored Payton, his stone-faced star, to be happy.

title: Shows All Over Town On Jazz Festival Lineup
description: The JVC Jazz Festival this year will include performances by Ornette Coleman, Chick Corea, Dave Brubeck and India.Arie among others. The lineup was announced yesterday by the event's longtime producer, George Wein, and his company, Festival Productions.

title: Vice Chancellor Named at CUNY
description: With cuts in state spending looming, it is not the most auspicious time to take the reins as the chief financial officer at the City University of New York. But at its last board meeting, CUNY's trustees named ERNESTO MALAVE as vice chancellor for budget and finance, a post he has held on an interim basis since last May. Mr. Malave, 45, attended CUNY's Borough of Manhattan Community College, where he was president of the student government and student representative to CUNY's board of trustees. He started working in CUNY's admissions office in 1983 while finishing his bachelor's degree at the College of New Rochelle. In recent months, he has addressed college groups and others to explain how CUNY was seeking to pare its costs so it could limit tuition increases next year. When the appointment was announced, SHAMSUL HAQUE, the student trustee on CUNY's board, praised Mr. Malave for his accessibility. Karen W. Arenson

title: Sorry, Fido. No Scraps for You.
description: This new gadget is a Prep Taxi, a stainless steel scraper by Chef's Planet that's designed to scoop up dicings, shreddings or peelings to transfer to a bowl, pot or trash can. As in a dustpan, the sides prevent whatever it picks up from falling onto the counter or floor. It can also double as a dough scraper. Broadway Panhandler in SoHo sells it for $19.95.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on April 11 showing the yields on 30-year and 15-year Freddie Mac securities misstated the figures for April 10. The 30-year yield was 5.35 percent, not 5.85; the 15-year yield was 4.67 percent, not 5.17.

title: Science Mechanic: Wrestling With Robots
description: RICH RABENA, FRANKLIN INSTITUTE SCIENCE MUSEUM

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: CUBA: TRADE PACT THREATENED The European Union again condemned Cuba's recent crackdown on dissidents and said the events had devastated relations in advance of a possible trade and aid pact. "Clearly, politically, recent events have had a devastating effect," a spokesman for the union was quoted as saying by Agence France-Presse. European foreign ministers are to meet in June to consider the pact, which has been jeopardized by the imprisonment of about 75 dissidents and the execution this month of three men who hijacked a ferry. The spokesman said the deal was not dead. "Let's not prejudge the situation," he said. "It may improve from now until June."    David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNACK, LUELLA
description: BENNACK - Luella. The Board and staff of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America extend their deepest sympathy to Frank A. Bennack, our longtime friend and generous supporter, and the entire Bennack family on their loss. Our thoughts and prayers are with you during this difficult time. John F. McGillicuddy, President Daniel R. Gasparo, Scout Executive

title: Release Set for Man Accused of Spying for North Korea
description: A local businessman was scheduled to be released on bail on Wednesday after he was arrested two months ago and accused of being an agent for North Korea and secretly providing information to it.

title: Benitez Remains Calm Despite Puzzling Slump
description: The results have been devastating. Four times in 17 days Armando Benitez has entered games to preserve a lead and lost it. The problem in his mechanics was spotted easily, even before Benitez saw videotape of his delivery Sunday: his left front shoulder pulls ahead of his body, wrecking the command of a fastball that scratches 100 miles an hour. It is a problem he has had before.

title: Recording Industry Goes After Students Over Music Sharing
description: Jason, a senior at the University of Maryland, ran one of the most popular Web sites on campus out of his shoebox dorm room here. The site let his 8,500 fellow dorm residents search for music files, among other things, stored on one another's computers and copy them in seconds.

title: A Bush Campaign, A 9/11 Anniversary
description: To the Editor:

title: Palestinian Deadlock Seen at Crisis Stage
description: A day before his legal deadline for appointing a new government, the Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, withdrew to his office today, saying nothing publicly and rebuffing almost all the diplomats and Palestinian mediators seeking to break his stalemate with Yasir Arafat.

title: Judge Rules U.S. Must Provide Statements From Qaeda Leaders
description: The trial judge in the case against Zacarias Moussaoui has ordered the Justice Department to provide defense lawyers with any statement made by captured leaders of Al Qaeda that would tend to exonerate Mr. Moussaoui, according to court papers made public today.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about White House efforts to get Israel to take the initiative in Middle East peace talks misstated the date of a meeting in Washington between senior administration officials and Israelis. It was on April 14, not the 15th. The article also included an official incorrectly among those who attended. Ephraim Halevy, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's national security adviser, did not.

title: SALE OF BETHLEHEM STEEL'S ASSETS IS APPROVED BY COURT
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation won a judge's permission yesterday to sell its assets for about $1.6 billion to the International Steel Group, controlled by Wilbur Ross. Judge Burton R. Lifland of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan approved the sale one day after a Bethlehem rival, the U.S. Steel Corporation, won approval to buy the assets of the bankrupt National Steel Corporation. With the combinations, U.S. Steel will remain North America's biggest steel maker and International Steel will rank second. Mr. Ross entered the steel business last year by creating International Steel from the assets of bankrupt companies, including Bethlehem, the LTV Corporation and Acme Metals Inc.

title: AS BAGHDAD WAITS FOR AID, PASSIONS RISE IN THE SOUTH
description: Islamic religious passions long suppressed under Saddam Hussein escalated today in Karbala, a city holy to the country's majority Shiites, while here in the capital Iraqis awaited material help from the United States but were wary of American political influence.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Off the Menu column last Wednesday about the hiring of Dan Silverman as chef at Lever House, a restaurant opening on Park Avenue in June, misstated his role in another restaurant. He was executive chef at the Union Square Cafe, not chef de cuisine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORE, WILLIAM F. SR.
description: DORE-William F. Sr. 82. Suddenly on April 20, 2003 of Manchester, MA. Formerly of Garden City, NY. Devoted husband of the late Helen Hope Simonson. Beloved father of William F. Jr., John, Nancy Nephew, Susan Scandore and Wendy Killeen. Also survived by twelve grandchildren. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, Thursday 10 AM.

title: Liberty-Bell Plan Shows Freedom and Slavery
description: VISITORS to the Liberty Bell on Independence Mall in Philadelphia have traditionally been treated to a quick lecture about freedom, followed by a photo opportunity with the bell. Soon they may learn about another, less-celebrated part of American history: slavery.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Joins Clean Fuel Program
description: New York City has joined the federal government's Clean Cities campaign, an effort by the Department of Energy to promote the use of vehicles powered by alternative power sources, like natural gas, ethanol and electricity. The city has the largest municipal fleet of vehicles in the country using alternative fuels, city officials said yesterday. The city also maintains partnerships with the private sector to increase the use of such vehicles, which are designed to reduce air pollution and the nation's dependence on fossil fuels. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the Clean Cities designation would help the city continue such programs. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Free Brooklyn-Manhattan Ferry to End Soon
description: Ferry service between Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan, one of the small changes wrought by the upheaval of Sept. 11, is slated to end next Wednesday, much to the consternation of some commuters and elected officials.

title: Cultivating a Partnership
description: In Portuguese, ''business from China'' means a deal sent from heaven, a once-in-a-lifetime chance to get rich. So it should be no surprise that Brazilian business is suddenly looking east.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Sinn Fein Is Resolute
description: Gerry Adams, president of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, stood firm on the impasse blocking progress in the Northern Ireland peace accord, saying a statement on disarmament from the I.R.A. that the British and Irish governments have found vague and noncommittal was in fact clear and convincing. ''There is no lack of clarity in this statement,'' Mr. Adams told supporters in Belfast. The two governments are holding back a series of proposals addressing Sinn Fein concerns because the ''act of completion'' that the I.R.A. was supposed to produce in return falls short of a renunciation of armed struggle. London and Dublin are seeking the I.R.A. pledge in their effort to renew the power-sharing Protestant-Roman Catholic government that was suspended in October. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Can't Live By Wine Alone
description: M Boutique, tucked just inside the door of the new Morrells Restaurant, which opens tomorrow at 900 Broadway (20th Street), carries some items that you would expect from its wine-store owners, like sterling silver wine coasters ($99 each) and olive oils made by wineries (Nikos Antonakeas, an owner, and Dagmar Venus, the retail manager, stock the shelves, above). Other items are surprising, like a Danish coffeemaker called CafeSolo, left. Ground coffee and boiling water are stirred in the carafe, allowed to sit for four minutes, then poured through a filter. It's a bit like cowboy chuck-wagon coffee (coffee and water boiled together), but the result has a rich extraction and less sediment than with a French press pot. The coffeemakers, which come with wet-suit-style jackets, are $69 for a four-cup pot, $64 for a two-cup.

title: Merger Creates Russian Oil Giant With Big Dreams
description: In a deal regarded as a coming of age for Russian capitalism, two oil companies here announced today that they would merge to create the world's fifth-largest publicly traded oil company.

title: INSIDE
description: Candidate From the Left

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: CORNING LOSS NOT AS WEAK AS EXPECTED Corning Inc., the world's largest maker of fiber optic cable, posted a quarterly loss yesterday that was not as weak as expected because of its growing nontelecommunications business. The company posted a first-quarter loss tied to continued weak spending in the telecommunications market and its previously announced settlement of asbestos claims. It forecast second-quarter results in line with expectations. Corning's shares rose 10 cents, to $6.21. "Putting aside the strength of our fiber and cable business in Asia last quarter, we are not seeing a lift in our telecommunications businesses, but this does not surprise us," the company's chief financial officer, James Flaws, said. Corning has been battered by the slump in the telecommunications sector, which accounts for half its sales. The company had previously said that cost controls, growth in its technologies segment and stable sales volume in optical fiber and cable would increase results. Corning reported a net loss for the first quarter of $205 million, or 17 cents a share, compared with a loss of $90 million, or 10 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. Excluding one-time items, the company posted break-even results. Analysts had been expecting Corning to post a first-quarter loss, excluding one-time items, of 3 cents a share, according to a survey conducted by Thomson First Call.    ( Reuters )

title: Another Senseless Tax-Cut Attempt
description: With this year's federal deficit exploding toward the $500 billion level and the national-debt ceiling needing a trillion-dollar increase, it seems unfathomable that Congress and the White House remain locked in a suicide pact of another tax cut. Yet here comes that persistent White House sales team with a fresh label on their tax-cut patent medicine. Facing only a small Senate line of Republican resistance, President Bush has sent out aides with some smooth talk about a phased-in, rather than full gulp, version of his beloved dividend tax cut. His plan would cost the Treasury $396 billion in lost revenues in a 10-year boon accruing mostly to upper-bracket taxpayers.

title: Newhouse School Is Growing
description: The Samuel I. Newhouse Foundation has given $15 million to Syracuse University's Newhouse School of Public Communications, the school has announced. The money will be used to build a third building, Newhouse III, in the Newhouse School complex. DONALD E. NEWHOUSE, president of Advance Publications Inc., said the Newhouse School must expand if it is to fulfill its mission. ''The ever-changing, ever-increasing forms of public communications that new technologies engender have greatly multiplied the areas of expertise needed by professionals,'' he said. Construction is expected to begin in the fall of 2004. Karen W. Arenson

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: CHUBB CUTS OUTLOOK Chubb, the British securi- ty systems company that is reported to be the target of a takeover bid by United Technologies , warned that results for the first half of 2003 would be well below expectations. Chubb said that it expected sales for the first four months in Asia, its largest market, to be down 6 percent from last year, citing lower prices that have resulted from aggressive competition. Sales in Onity, the company's money-losing hotel door locks business in the United States, are expected to be down 16 percent. Analysts said that Chubb's worse-than-expected report would make it difficult for the company to attract a premium from bidders. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Big Board Says Inquiry Is of Breach Of Lesser Sort
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that contrary to news reports, it was not investigating whether its traders had improperly bought stocks in advance of big orders from investors, a practice known as front-running.

title: A Promise of Education And Its Lasting Legacy
description: IN 1988, Ewing M. Kauffman, a civic-minded man who owned the Kansas City Royals and made his fortune in pharmaceuticals, promised a free college education to every ninth grader at his alma mater, Westport High, a poor, heavily minority city school. There were conditions. They had to graduate from Westport in four years, be drug-tested and not become pregnant.

title: Minnesota's Small Lineup Puts the Bite on the Lakers
description: After Monday's practice at the Target Center, Kevin Garnett addressed Minnesota's impending Game 2 lineup change with understandable caution. Kobe Bryant and Shaquille O'Neal dominated a big Timberwolves lineup in the Lakers' Game 1 rout. What chance would a smaller lineup -- with Wally Szczerbiak at small forward and Anthony Peeler at guard -- have against those two?

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday about the selection of Carmichael Lynch as the advertising agency for the A. G. Edwards & Sons brokerage firm misidentified the other finalist. It was McKinney & Silver in Raleigh, N.C., not the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/Chiat/Day.

title: The Team That Is Playing Home-Away-From-Home Games This Season Is Home at Last
description: The resilient little team with the small payroll, the serious talent and the uncertain future finally played a sleep-in-your-own-bed home game tonight. The Montreal Expos returned to a surprisingly boisterous Olympic Stadium after 19 games on the road, including 10 where they were home only because they batted last at their rental park in San Juan, P.R.

title: Given Five Extra Years to Live, New Yorkers Look for a Catch
description: Let's play a game.

title: U.S. Envoys Arrive in China For Talks With North Korea
description: American envoys arrived here today for talks with North Korea on its nuclear weapons program, breaking a six-month diplomatic impasse and at least temporarily easing fears of a military confrontation between the Korean War enemies.

title: 11th-Hour Deal Averts Strike By Doormen And Janitors
description: The union representing 28,000 apartment building service workers announced early this morning that it had reached a tentative three-year contract with the association of building owners, averting a strike threatened against 3,000 buildings in New York City. After two days of exhausting talks, negotiators for the two sides announced a settlement that calls for wage increases averaging 2.8 percent a year over three years, as well as for increased employer contributions for health care and pensions.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Possible New Flag
description: The State Senate approved a bill creating what would be the state's third flag in as many years, but its future remains uncertain. The bill corrected errors in a House version that would have made the flag a foot too long, forcing the bill back to the House on Friday, the last day of the legislative session. Black representatives are vowing a filibuster, or at least a fight. They oppose a provision in the bill that allows for a referendum next year on another possible flag that would include the racially divisive Confederate battle cross. David M. Halbfinger (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, JAMES F.
description: MURPHY-James F. Of East Williston, NY and Delray Beach, FL. on April 20, 2003. Beloved husband of Monica. Devoted father of James M. and Robert E. Loving grandfather of Paul, Kathryn Rose, Austen and Suzanne. Cherished great grandfather of Lauryn Rose. Dear brother of Lauraine Smith and Sheila Fox. Funeral mass Friday April 25, 2003 10 AM at Saint Aidan's R.C. Church, Williston Park. Interment to follow at Holy Rood Cemetery. For information Weigand Bros Funeral Home.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Candy Maker For Sale
description: The Archibald Candy Corporation, which makes Fannie May and Fanny Farmer candies, said it was seeking a buyer for its Laura Secord unit, one of Canada's best-known retailers of chocolates and ice cream. A sale would let Archibald, based in Chicago, focus on its other brands and expand in the United States, the company said. Archibald hired Paragon Capital Partners to provide advice and seek a buyer or investor. The closely held Archibald bought Laura Secord from Nestl in 1999. The Canadian chain has 174 shops and sells at more than 2,000 outlets run by other retailers. It had sales of 78.5 million Canadian dollars ($54 million) in 2002.

title: Within a Cookie Crust, a Wine-Dark Pear
description: ''BAKING a tart with a custard filling that's made with red wine is something I've been wanting to do for more than five years,'' said Hlne Darroze. ''For me, the wine had to be Madiran.''

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Amgen Posts 45% Rise In Profit
description: Amgen Inc., the world's biggest biotechnology company, said yesterday that its profit in the first quarter climbed 45 percent. The company said sales of its Enbrel arthritis drug and anemia medicines contributing to the gain. Amgen said it expected 2003 product sales of as much as $7.6 billion, $400 million higher than previous estimates. Profit for the full year will be as high as $1.90 a share, excluding costs for last year's acquisition of Immunex, the company said. Previously, Amgen had said earnings on that basis would be as much $1.80 a share. Sales of Enbrel, which Amgen gained through the Immunex purchase last year, helped increase profit, Amgen said. Net income increased to $493.3 million, or 37 cents a share, from $340.9 million, or 32 cents, in the same period in 2002. The company's shares rose 86 cents, to $60.94.

title: Mermaid Forced to Cover Up Settles With City for $10,000
description: In what one lawyer called a small victory for artistic freedom -- or at least for the bawdy traditions of the Mermaid Parade in Coney Island -- the city has agreed to settle a false arrest lawsuit filed by a woman who was detained at the 2001 parade because she exposed her breasts.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Advanced Micro's New Chip To Be Used By I.B.M.
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said yesterday that its new Opteron chip would be used in some server computers made by I.B.M. Advanced Micro said at a conference in New York that it had started selling the Opteron, which digests data in chunks of either 32 bits or 64 bits. Opteron can run the roughly 100,000 programs already written for Intel-based chips as well as 64-bit applications for tougher tasks. While Intel's Xeon and Itanium chips do one or the other, Advanced Micro's chip can do both, making it more flexible, analysts and investors have said. Advanced Micro last week reported a wider first-quarter loss on a 21 percent revenue drop over the period a year ago. Its share of the microprocessor market dropped to 15 percent in 2002 from 22 percent in early 2001 as Intel outspent the company sixfold, building more efficient factories. The company declined to forecast sales or volume for Opteron. Shares of Advanced Micro rose 12 cents, to $8.44. They have gained 30 percent this year. I.B.M. shares rose $2.27, to $85.63.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Loss For Chip Maker
description: Infineon Technologies, Europe's second-biggest maker of semiconductors, had an eighth consecutive quarterly loss as cost cuts failed to keep pace with a slump in memory-chip prices. Infineon's net loss for the three months through March widened to 328 million euros ($357 million), or 45 cents a share, from a loss of 108 million euros, or 16 cents a share, a year earlier, the chief executive, Ulrich Schumacher, above, said on a conference call with analysts. Mr. Schumacher said his goal to return Infineon to profit in the fourth quarter after 2.3 billion euros of losses in the last eight depends on the direction of memory prices, as all other divisions near break even.

title: Investors Asking Where The Money Went
description: Desiree Phillips said she believed investing with A & A Global Resources would give her the money to get her son and his new family off to a good start. Delores Cobb saw Global Resources as the means to finally buy a little place of her own, and leave her public housing apartment to her daughter and grandchildren.

title: Field Trip: Manhattan Statues in a Garden in the Bronx
description: WHEN I first saw Aristide Maillol's reclining nude, ''The River,'' hanging her head over a tropical lily pool in the courtyard of the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory, I thought she looked much better there than at her home in the sculpture garden at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: New World Culture With a Party Flair
description: The only flaw in Los Hombres Calientes, the New Orleans band that played at Sweet Rhythm last weekend, is compactness. The best examples of the music they draw from -- samba, salsa, mambo, Haitian and Afro-Brazilian rhythm, jazz and New Orleans parade rhythm -- are always more expansive, more overflowing and deeper than what they do.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Promoting Secularism
description: France needs a new law to keep religion and racism out of state schools, Education Minister Luc Ferry told Europe 1 radio. ''We have to reaffirm very strongly the principles of republican secularism,'' Mr. Ferry said, against the rise of racism and anti-Semitism. ''That requires a new law.'' The ideal, he added, would be to have ''no sign of religion in school.'' The wearing of veils or head scarves by Muslim girls and other open displays of religiosity, including crucifixes, are banned in French schools, although some teachers turn a blind eye. At a Muslim conference on Saturday, Interior Minister Nicolas Sarkozy was booed when he said Muslim women must remove head scarves for identity card photographs. Elaine Sciolino (NYT)

title: Viacom Reports a Profit; Radio Unit Is Still Troubled
description: Viacom posted solid first-quarter results yesterday on a strong performance from its cable networks, television and video businesses. But poor performance at its radio business continued to worry investors and management.

title: Dude, Where's My Spice Grinder?
description: DAVE LIEBERMAN, a senior at Yale, was standing in his home kitchen before two cameras, his nose powdered, eggs and a whisk nearby on the makeshift set.

title: READER'S DIGEST TO END SWEEPSTAKES AFTER 41 YEARS
description: Reader's Digest Association Inc. said yesterday that it would stop holding sweepstakes after 41 years to focus on more efficient ways to attract subscribers to its magazine, the world's largest in terms of paid circulation. The company expects that the switch will reduce the paid circulation that Reader's Digest Magazine promises to advertisers to 10 million by 2004, from 11 million now. The company first used sweepstakes, which invite prospective subscribers to enter contests, in 1962. Reader's Digest said it would continue to use methods like telemarketing and the Internet to try to increase circulation.

title: Pasta and Pizza, to Bring the Family Together
description: MAYBE it's evidence of a personality flaw, an innate cynicism or just an exaggerated set of boundaries, but I've never understood the appeal of the ''family style'' restaurant. Perhaps you're familiar with the system? Each item on the menu comes in an outsize portion that feeds at least two people and more likely three. You pass around the platter like a trough, serving yourself as if you were at the family dinner table.

title: Senate G.O.P. and Pataki Square Off
description: The leader of the Republican majority in the Senate declared today that his chamber would approve additional money for local school districts early next week, even if it meant a bruising political battle with Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: 'Bull Durham' Stars on HBO
description: The actors Susan Sarandon and Tim Robbins had their invitations revoked by the president of the Baseball Hall of Fame for a planned 15th anniversary commemoration of ''Bull Durham,'' but they will discuss the film May 2 on HBO's ''On the Record with Bob Costas.''

title: 'Overreacting' to Terror? The Threat Persists
description: To the Editor:

title: Moving Beyond the Pinto: Cool Beans for Spring
description: FEAR not the dried bean.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Linden: Motor Speedway Proposed
description: A development group that includes the actor Paul Newman, left, the race-car driver Mario Andretti and the political consultant James Carville have proposed a 100,000-seat, $410 million speedway, entertainment complex and hotel for Linden, just off the New Jersey Turnpike amid the area's sea of petroleum storage tanks. The group had suggested its project, a Nascar track called Liberty Speedway, for the Meadowlands, but the racetrack lost out to a plan for a family entertainment, hotel and office complex. The Linden City Council is considering the proposal for Tremblay Point. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: OFF THE MENU
description: The Food of Nice

title: Can a Brooklyn Baboon Make a Life in the Bronx?
description: IF only Richard L. Lattis could impress on city budget maestros what might become of the hamadryas baboons if the Prospect Park Zoo loses its financing, as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's doomsday budget proposes. (It could close the zoo.) Don't those bozos -- not Mr. Lattis's words, but just imagine the baboons' musings -- at City Hall know that it is not easy to find a species a new home?

title: W.H.O. Adds Toronto to List of Cities to Avoid Because of SARS
description: TORONTO, April 23  The World Health Organization today added Toronto to its list of places that travelers should avoid because of an outbreak of a contagious respiratory disease, shattering this city's image as a safe place to live and visit.

title: New Ammunition for Backers of Do-or-Die Exams
description: The rocky terrain of educational research has gotten even rockier.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Monday about developments in Iraq misidentified the Shiite Muslim observance for which hundreds of thousands of pilgrims were traveling to ceremonies in Karbala. The holiday is Arbaeen, marking the end of the 40-day mourning period that followed the killing of Hussein, grandson of the Prophet Muhammad, in 680. (Ashura, 40 days earlier, is the anniversary of the killing itself.)

title: Why Did The Pickle Need a Tums?
description: As the fresh produce season begins, cooks might think about pickling, an ancient method of preserving food and one of the most universal. In ''Pickled'' (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, $22.50), Lucy Norris tells readers how to pickle foods safely and gives recipes, which are divided into chapters according to type of food (cucumbers, cabbage, fruits, fish like herring and so on). The recipes come from pickle makers around the country. There's even one that calls for Tums, not as an antidote to eating too many pickles, but to add calcium in the pickling mixture and help keep pickles crunchy.

title: CALENDAR
description: An Evening at Noche

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENFELD, CHARLOTTE (NEE WEISSMAN)
description: RUBENFELD - Charlotte (nee Weissman), age 81 of Monsey, New York. She was born in New York and was united in marriage to the late Jack Rubenfeld. She is survived by daughters Marjorie Wetmore and Jayne Rubenfeld-Waldron; son, Stephen; six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren; brother, Lester; dear friend, Edward Hall. Shiva at her home in Monsey, New York, Thursday evening to Wednesday morning. Donations Doctors Without Borders, Hadassah Medical Center.

title: France Urging U.N. to Suspend Iraq Penalties
description: The French ambassador to the United Nations called today for the immediate suspension of most United Nations sanctions against Iraq, allowing unrestricted nonmilitary trade to resume.

title: Trip to Queens Yields Boroughed Treasure
description: ASK anyone in Queens where to find it, and more than likely you'll draw a blank stare.

description: Bush Supports Greenspan For Fifth Term as Fed Chief

title: Recipe: Kuromame
description: Time: About 3 hours

title: In Hotbed of Shiite Emotion, Clerics Jockey for Leadership
description: With pilgrims clogging every road, a police car led a convoy of four or five sport utility vehicles toward a mosque here. The convoy was carrying the brother of Muhammad Bakr al-Hakim, who leads one of the main exiled opposition parties trying to consolidate its power in Iraq.

title: 2 Military Contractors Post Gains in Quarter
description: Lockheed Martin and Raytheon reported increases in first-quarter sales yesterday, led by demand for fighter jets, missiles and radar products.

title: Biennial: The Show Critics Love To Hate
description: EVERY two years, one imagines art critics rubbing their hands together and licking their chops as they prepare to participate in what has become a venerable tradition: bashing the Whitney Museum of American Art's Biennial. No matter that the artists have included Georgia O'Keeffe, Edward Hopper and Jackson Pollock.

title: Teddy Edwards, 78, Deft Star Of Los Angeles Jazz Scene
description: Teddy Edwards, a deft and soulful saxophonist who was a mainstay of the Southern California jazz scene and played what is said to be the first recorded bebop solo on tenor saxophone, died on Sunday in Los Angeles, where he lived. He was 78.

title: POST PROPERTIES RECEIVED TAKEOVER BID LAST MONTH
description: Post Properties Inc., a developer, received a $26-a-share takeover offer last month, but the board declined to pursue talks with the potential acquirer, the company's former chairman said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Post, a real estate investment trust based in Atlanta, received an offer from a ''reputable real estate investment firm'' on March 14, the former chairman, John A. Williams, said. He did not identify the firm. Mr. Williams was ousted as chairman in February but remains on the board. One reason the company did not pursue the bid was that it was only a slight premium to the stock price, a spokeswoman said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, SHERWOOD P.
description: MILLER-Sherwood P. M.D. On April 21, 2003. Beloved husband of Blossom. Devoted father of Ann, Jonathan and David. Cherished grandfather of nine. Funeral services Friday, 10 a.m. at ''Gutterman's Inc.,'', 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Peronism's Demise? Don't Bet Your Shirt on It
description: Every time this country is plunged into a period of great trauma and misfortune, it instinctively looks to Juan Pern and his heirs for solace and salvation. To this day, something about Peronism stirs the souls of Argentines and fascinates even other Latin Americans.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Almost Indian
description: SAAG PANEER -- cubes of freshly made cheese in a sauce of spicy, slow-simmered spinach -- is a standard in Indian restaurants and has long been a favorite of mine. In fact, back when I tackled such challenging projects, I made my own paneer, which is nearly impossible to find here.

title: A Traveler Lured Beyond The Brand-Name Galleries
description: ON a recent trip to Atlanta, I set aside time for a visit to the city's best known art institution, the High Museum of Art, only to decide that the special exhibitions did not intrigue me. Having gone to the museum nearly every visit in the past, I queried a friend for names of the city's smaller art collections.

title: 'Mr. Personality,' featuring Monica Lewinsky, draws the young audience of advertisers' dreams.
description: JUST when viewers who hate reality television shows were praying that the list of flops since January might kill the genre and make it safe to remove their hands from their eyes, Monica Lewinsky and 20 young guys in masks turned up on the Fox network Monday night, and, in the jargon of the business, popped a number.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 22, 2003

title: Animated Performers Onstage And Screen
description: Susan L. Dodge's choreography made her program called ''At the Corner of . . .'' a theatrical meeting place filled with works of many kinds presented by her Dodge Dance Company on Friday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio.

title: Los Angeles Admits Fault In Sewer Spills Cited in Suit
description: The City of Los Angeles, which had been sued by local groups and state and federal officials over repeated sewage spills, accepted liability today for more than 3,670 spills over the past decade.

title: Temples of Culture Are Needy, Too. Tai Chi, Anyone?
description: IN Texas, they held late-night hours and classes in yoga and tai chi meditation. In Oregon, a bunch of grandmothers marched. In Minnesota, they tried air fresheners with reproductions of paintings on the back, and a museum staff member dressed up like a mummy -- all for the sake of art.

title: Banishing Hans Blix
description: Having won a military victory in Iraq without the support of the United Nations, the Bush administration now seems determined to search for Baghdad's unconventional weapons without help from Hans Blix and his team of international inspectors. That is too bad. The hunt for these weapons would be aided by the presence of independent experts, and the credibility of any discoveries would be much enhanced if they were confirmed by the U.N.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: In Richmond, a Museum Aims for the Big Leagues
description: IT'S a Monday morning, and Michael Brand, the director of the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, has just returned to his office from a week in New York. He has been to the ''Matisse Picasso'' exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, the ''Manet/Velzquez'' show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Chen Zhen installation art show at P. S. 1 Contemporary Art Center. He is impressed by what he has seen. But he is also convinced that he can do the same things at his own institution, 340 miles south.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, MADELINE (MADDY)
description: EDELMAN-Madeline (Maddy). Beloved wife of Herb, loving mother of Mindy and Marc, loving mother-in-law of Rob, adoring Grandma of Ryan, devoted daughter of Bob and Elaine Silverman, and cherished sister of Les, lost her courageous fight, and succumbed on April 21, 2003.

title: Sugar interests hit at UN study on illness links
description: The Sugar Association in the United States is lobbying Congress to challenge more than $400 million for the World Health Organization because of a nutrition report, to be published Wednesday, that says the high consumption of sugar contributes to obesity, chronic diseases and tooth decay.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about developments in Iraq misidentified the Shiite Muslim observance for which hundreds of thousands of pilgrims were traveling to ceremonies in Karbala. The holiday is Arbaeen, marking the end of the 40-day mourning period that followed the killing of Hussein, grandson of the Prophet Muhammad, in 680. (Ashura, 40 days earlier, is the anniversary of the killing itself.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAVEL, IRWIN A.
description: SHAVEL-Irwin A. On April 20, age 88, a courageous and charitable man, died at home with his best friend and beloved wife, Bobbie, of 59 years by his side after an illness of mesotheliomia. Devoted father to Martha, Laurie and Nancy. Loving fatherin-law to John Jessop and Richard Gabel. Adored grandfather of Sara, Alexis and Julia. Dear brother to Howard, Lawrence and Henry. Funeral service, 11:30 AM, April 24, at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY.

title: Afghanistan Presses Pakistan To Stop Cross-Border Attacks
description: President Hamid Karzai said today that he had won assurances from Pakistan that it would try to stem the violent attacks across the border that Taliban and other rebels have been carrying out against Afghanistan in recent months.

title: Even the Getty, Hillside Temple Of Antiquities, Shows a Hip Side
description: ON an afternoon in March, the Los Angeles artist Alexis Smith checked to see whether stray marks had appeared on the walls in the restaurant at the J. Paul Getty Museum. Or, more precisely, she looked for marks on her contribution to the walls: a wry, site-specific artwork organized around the theme of taste that was commissioned for the 1997 opening of the Getty Center, the Modernist complex on a Brentwood hilltop designed by the architect Richard Meier.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: L3 PROFIT RISES L3 Communications Holdings said yesterday that quarterly earnings jumped on increased military business, including intelligence, secure communications and reconnaissance. L3, which also makes bomb-detecting equipment, said it expected more orders both within the United States and abroad for airport security products. The company said that recent acquisitions had helped improve its earnings and that it saw more opportunities to acquire privately held or public companies. Shares of L3 rose $2.63, or 6.5 percent, to $42.80. The shares fell more than 10 percent in the first quarter. L3 reported earnings of $49.7 million, or 50 cents a share, for the first quarter, compared with earnings in the year-earlier quarter of $4.9 million, or 6 cents a share, which included accounting changes totaling $24.4 million, or 30 cents a share. Analysts had expected earnings per share of 42 cents to 54 cents, with a mean estimate of 47 cents, according to Thomson First Call.    (Reuters)

title: Cruiserweight Looking for Recognition
description: Vassiliy Jirov of Kazakhstan won a gold medal at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics and has held a world title since 1999. But many boxing fans would not recognize him even if he introduced himself.

title: Can't Live by Wine Alone
description: MBoutique, tucked just inside the door of the new Morrells Restaurant, which opens tomorrow at 900 Broadway (20th Street), carries some items that you would expect from its wine-store owners, like sterling silver wine coasters ($99 each) and olive oils made by wineries (Nikos Antonakeas, an owner, and Dagmar Venus, the retail manager, stock the shelves, right). Other items are surprising, like a Danish coffeemaker called CafeSolo. Ground coffee and boiling water are stirred in the carafe, allowed to sit for four minutes, then poured through a filter. It's a bit like cowboy chuck-wagon coffee (coffee and water boiled together), but the result has a rich extraction and less sediment than with a French press pot. The coffeemakers, which come with wet-suit-style jackets, are $69 for a four-cup pot, $64 for a two-cup.

title: UNIFORM MAKER AGREES TO $131 MILLION BUYOUT
description: Varsity Brands Inc., a maker of cheerleading, soccer and dance uniforms, said yesterday that it had agreed to be bought by its senior management and the closely held merchant banking firm Leonard Green & Partners for $130.9 million in cash and debt. Varsity shareholders will get $6.57 a share. Yesterday the stock rose 36 percent, closing at $6.40 a share, up $1.40 from Monday's close. The chief executive, Jeffrey Webb, and Varsity's senior management will exchange a portion of their shares for stock in the new company. Mr. Webb will remain chief executive of Varsity, which is based in Memphis.

title: FAO PLANS REVERSE STOCK SPLIT ON EXIT FROM BANKRUPTCY
description: FAO, which operates the F. A. O. Schwarz and Zany Brainy toy-store chains, said it was preparing a reverse stock split as part of its exit from bankruptcy protection. Shareholders will receive one new share for each batch of 15 shares they already hold, FAO said. FAO is scheduled to complete its bankruptcy reorganization today after receiving $30 million in financing from Kayne Anderson Capital Advisors.

title: G.I.'s and U.S. Civilians Seek a Relationship
description: Black Hawk helicopters and Chinooks carrying teams of officers from V Corps arrived at this bleak, fly-ridden airport this afternoon to set up an Army headquarters facing a delicate task: working out a viable arrangement with the new civilian team seeking to rebuild Iraq.

title: Turning War Into Peace in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Man Arrested On Indecency Charge
description: A Long Island man was arrested yesterday after meeting an undercover investigator who had posed online as an under-age girl. The accused, Christopher Gazzo, 33, of Port Jefferson, was charged with two counts of distributing indecent material to a minor. If convicted, he faces up to four years in prison. Mr. Gazzo, who sent instant messages and e-mail to a person he thought was a 14-year-old girl, had at least two sexually explicit exchanges of messages, the Nassau County district attorney's office said. His request for a meeting allowed yesterday's arrest, the 15th in the two-year operation. A call to Mr. Gazzo's home was not returned. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Congressional Memo; Persistent Conflict for Gays and G.O.P.
description: In the long and conflicted history between gays and Republicans, Senator Rick Santorum -- caught in a storm over his remarks equating homosexuality with polygamy and incest -- is writing a new chapter.

title: Chinatown Bank Endures Run As Fear Trumps Reassurances
description: It looked like a colorized newsreel from the Depression: panicky depositors lining up outside a bank, convinced it was about to fail, demanding dollars they had entrusted to savings accounts and keepsakes they had put in safe deposit boxes. They seemed to expect the tellers to say the cash drawers were empty, the vault bare.

title: Giants May Need to Improvise in the Draft
description: The Giants need defensive linemen, yet the key to their first-round selection may turn out to be a quarterback who never wears their uniform.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Impaled In Jump
description: A woman jumped from a third-story window yesterday, impaling herself on an iron fence, the police said. Neighbors said it was her second attempt at suicide. Her mother died this year, the neighbors said, and her father and sister are dead. About 1:15 p.m., the woman, whom neighbors identified as Cynthia Lawrence, 55, leaped from a window of her apartment at 1929 Quentin Road in Gravesend. The spikes of the three-foot fence pierced her chest and leg, a Fire Department spokesman said. Firefighters from Ladder Company 109 cut away a section of the fence and took the woman to Kings County Hospital, where she was pronounced dead, the police said. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHSBERG, SHIRLEY
description: FUCHSBERG-Shirley. The Anti - Defamation League mourns the passing of Shirley Fuchsberg, a member of ADL Women's Division. We extend our condolences to her children and the entire family. Glen A. Tobias, National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

title: Russia and Ukraine Dispute Chernobyl Safety
description: Days before the 17th anniversary of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, Russia and Ukraine disagreed today over whether a concrete enclosure built to contain radiation from the exploded reactor building was leaking and in danger of collapse.

title: Bribery Case Is Reinstated
description: The Salt Lake Olympics have been over for more than a year, but the Salt Lake City bribery scandal refuses to die.

title: Marathon Buys Oil Operation in Russia
description: The Marathon Oil Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire the closely held Khanty Mansiysk Oil Corporation for $275 million.

title: Love Joins the Laptop In Sentimental Journeys
description: Sing a sappy love song accompanied by an indie-rock band, and people will think you really mean it. Sing the same song accompanied by a laptop computer, and people might think it's all a put-on. At a sold-out concert at Northsix in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Friday night the Postal Service split the difference, using live guitars and drums and keyboards to embellish computer-driven love songs that were by turns picturesque and sublime.

title: Iraqi Shiites Show Their Fervor in City They Hold Holy
description: Long forbidden, long hidden, the whips of mortification were flagellating today as Iraq's Shiite Muslim majority celebrated its newfound political freedom -- and potential political power.

title: Earnings at Coach More Than Double
description: By Bloomberg News

title: In a Hotbed of Shiite Passion, Clerics Jockey for Leadership
description: KARBALA, Iraq, April 22  With pilgrims clogging every road, a police car led a convoy of four or five sport utility vehicles toward a mosque here. The convoy was carrying the brother of Muhammad Bakr al-Hakim, who leads one of the main exiled opposition parties trying to consolidate its power in Iraq.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Is Everybody Happy?

title: Hevesi Says M.T.A. Moved Millions to Simulate a Deficit
description: A state audit has concluded that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority secretly shifted hundreds of millions of dollars in surplus money to create the appearance of a huge deficit in 2003, misleading transit riders about the need for a fare increase this year, according to officials involved in preparing the audit.

title: For Italy's Art Cops, the Chase Is On
description: JUST about every day, Col. Ugo Zottin, a lean, punctilious man, clicks an icon on his computer and steals a glance at Caravaggio's ''Nativity.''

title: With Artichokes, Do as the Romans Do
description: Artichokes, those springtime stalwarts, are given a classic Roman treatment at Giorgione restaurant, 307 Spring Street (Hudson Street). The chef, Jody Williams, left, trims and fries them to make carciofi alla giudia, Jewish-style artichokes. First she trims the artichokes down to the yellow leaves and scoops out the hairy choke, but not the heart. Then she pares the tough skin from the stem. She cooks the artichokes slowly in a deep pot, with enough olive oil to cover them, at 225 degrees until they are tender. She drains them and allows them to cool, and just before serving, fries them, stem up, in an inch of olive oil, pressing them lightly so the leaves crisp and open up like a flower. A brief draining and salting, and they're ready to serve.

title: Asian Longhorned Beetle Threatens Trees in Queens
description: The Asian longhorned beetle has plagued thousands of New York City trees over the last few years, emerging most recently in Queens. But officials said yesterday that if the latest wave of infestation is not checked, forests across the Northeast could be in danger.

title: Chinese Capital Closes Schools for at Least Two Weeks
description: With a terse announcement in this morning's newspapers, the city of Beijing closed all its primary and secondary schools until May 7 at least, and said the 1.7 million affected students should study at home, using a newly improvised online educational service.

title: Iran Is Said to Send Agents Into Southern Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  Iranian-trained agents have crossed into southern Iraq since the fall of Saddam Hussein and are working in the cities of Najaf, Karbala and Basra to promote friendly Shiite clerics and advance Iranian interests, according to defense and other United States government officials.

title: Mayor Criticizes Some Banks For Failing to Deter Robbers
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly met yesterday with banking industry officials to lecture them on ways to stem a sharp increase in bank robberies in recent months. The meeting came just hours after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg harshly criticized some banks for failing to provide better security.

title: U.S. Warns Iran Against Interfering in Iraqi Politics
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  The United States warned Iran today not to interfere with the development of a government in Iraq. The warning was in response to growing signs that Tehran is trying to influence Iraqis to oppose United States forces and to push for an Islamic government similar to Iran's.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Pacific Crossing May Sell Assets To Pivotal
description: Pacific Crossing Ltd., the bankrupt former unit of Global Crossing Ltd., may sell its assets and subsidiaries to Pivotal Telecom, a closely held unit formed by Pivotal Private Equity, for $63 million. Pacific Crossing operates a fiber optic telecommunications network between Japan and the United States. The network was completed in 2000, costing more than $1.35 billion, Pivotal Private Equity said yesterday. Pivotal Private Equity expects the sale to be completed by the end of the year.

description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEILL, RAYMOND H.
description: WEILL-Raymond H. The Philatelic Foundation mourns the death of its longtime Benefactor, Trustee and recipient, in 1988 together with his late brother Roger, of The Mortimer L. Neinken Medal for meritorious service to our organization. Louis Grunin, Chairman

title: Seeking A Cure For Art Anxiety
description: NOT long ago, I ran into a neighbor with whom I enjoy an elevator friendship that has been effortlessly maintained for years. Hannah is the image of urban sophistication, a slim, stylish woman who works at a museum. The elevator was on its way down when she turned to me and said in an urgent tone, ''I need to talk to you.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRAN, JAMES MICHAEL ''BUDDY''
description: CURRAN-James Michael ''Buddy''. On April 22, 2003. Cherished son of the late Michael Curran and Bridie Mitchell Curran, beloved father of James Michael Curran, Jr. and Kathleen Lindsay, dear father-in-law of Gail Curran and Bruce Lindsay, loving grandfather of Sean and Ryan Curran and Terri & Kimberly Lindsay. Interment Thursday, 1 PM, at Calverton National Cemetery. A memorial service in his memory will be held at a later date. For further information please contact Krtil Funeral Home, 212-744-3084.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Getronics Sells Unit
description: The struggling Dutch information-technology concern Getronics said it would sell its Human Resources Solutions unit for about 315 million euros ($343 million) to a Dutch investment company. The sale price exceeded many analysts' expectations and should result in a book profit for Getronics of about 270 million euros. Getronics, a provider of corporate computer network services, needs cash to pay off hundreds of millions of euros in debt, much of it related to its 1999 acquisition of Wang Global of the United States. Proceeds from the sale of Human Resources Solutions, which processes about two million pay slips a month, will go to pay down Getronics' convertible debt. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Focus Shifts From Weapons To the People Behind Them
description: Information supplied by an Iraqi scientist that Iraq destroyed chemical weapons and biological-warfare equipment before the war has shifted the focus from finding such weapons to locating key people who worked on the programs, experts and military officers said.

title: A Dark Horse Fights the Odds Again
description: When Dennis J. Kucinich was the enfant terrible of Cleveland politics back in the 1970's and at 31 became the youngest person ever elected mayor of a major American city, it was not far-fetched to think that he would someday be a presidential contender. Beyond his proven ability as an electoral winner, he had plenty of time remaining to reach for higher office.

title: Mount Maker: Ready for an Earthquake
description: McKENZIE LOWRY, J. PAUL GETTY MUSEUM

title: What Roles Will World Bank and I.M.F. Play in Iraq?
description: NEW YORK (CNN/Money) - Though the roles of the United States and the United Nations in rebuilding Iraq are still unclear, two other groups, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, are almost certain to take part -- and some critics worry that might be bad news for the future of Iraq's economy.

title: For $2, a Bottle Of Wine and Change
description: MOVE over Mondavi. Step aside Gevrey-Chambertin. And Grgich Hills, get lost. Make way for Two-Buck Chuck, at $1.99 a bottle the hottest thing in the wine market since, well, since nothing. There's never been anything like it.

title: MOODY'S LOWERS CREDIT RATINGS OF ALTRIA AGAIN
description: The long-term credit ratings of the Altria Group were cut by Moody's Investors Service yesterday to the second-lowest investment grade because the company's financial flexibility is being crimped by cigarette litigation. Moody's lowered the ratings on Altria, the parent of Philip Morris, to Baa2 from Baa1. It was the second such reduction in a month. The ratings of Kraft Foods, the company's food unit, were maintained at A3. About $20 billion of debt is affected, Moody's said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOKER, JOHN R., JR.
description: BOKER-John R., Jr. The Collectors Club (NY) mourns the death of our longtime and illustrious member, past President, major benefactor and recipient of many awards. He was the towering figure in world-wide philately over the past half century. To his daughters, Pamela Boker and Joan Shisler, and grandchildren, we extend condolences. Collectors Club of New York

title: Regime Change, Part 2
description: While the war in Iraq has rightly grabbed all the attention in the Middle East, another effort at regime change has also been going on in the neighborhood, and it's been quite a drama. It's the silent coup that Palestinian moderates, led by Mahmoud Abbas, have been trying to undertake against Yasir Arafat.

title: Gun Maker Found Liable in Shooting Accident
description: An Oakland jury has found a California gun maker, its designer and its main distributor partly liable in an accidental shooting that left a 7-year-old boy a quadriplegic.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Chubb Cuts Outlook
description: Chubb, the British security systems company that is reported to be the target of a takeover bid by United Technologies, warned that results for the first half of 2003 would be well below expectations. Chubb said that it expected sales for the first four months in Asia, its largest market, to be down 6 percent from last year, citing lower prices that have resulted from aggressive competition. Sales in Onity, the company's money-losing hotel door locks business in the United States, are expected to be down 16 percent. Analysts said that Chubb's worse-than-expected report would make it difficult for the company to attract a premium from bidders. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

title: Luella Bennack; Philanthropist, 67
description: Luella M. Bennack, a supporter of many Texas and national charities and the wife of Frank A. Bennack Jr., vice chairman of the board of the Hearst Corporation and previously its chief executive, died on April 17 at her home in San Antonio. She was 67.

title: Devils Are Hoping For Lift From Brylin
description: The Devils will open their second-round playoff series against the Tampa Bay Lightning tomorrow night at Continental Arena, the N.H.L. said yesterday. The Devils also learned that forward Sergei Brylin had been cleared to play for the first time since he broke his right wrist on Feb. 5.

title: DUKE ENERGY PLANS TO SELL MORE ASSETS TO CUT DEBT
description: The Duke Energy Corporation plans to increase asset sales by $400 million this year to reduce debt and fend off a possible downgrading of the company's credit rating, its treasurer said yesterday. Duke plans to sell $1.5 billion in assets this year outside of its North Carolina utility, including $1.1 billion in sales that have already been announced or closed, the treasurer, David Hauser, said on a conference call with analysts and investors. Moody's Investors Service said last month that it might cut Duke's investment-grade rating because some of the company's businesses were tying up too much cash.

title: Sniper Alley Is Quiet, But History Is Restless
description: THE shallow prehistoric canoe is too long to capture in a single gaze. Resting on iron braces, its black, rocklike oak stretches 43 feet, the coarsely carved ridges smoothed by thousands of years in the muck of a riverbed in northern Bosnia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDENSTEIN, MORRIS (MOE)
description: SEIDENSTEIN - Morris (Moe), 94, died on April 21. Predeceased by his wife Shirley of over 30 years. He was loved by all generations. Survived by daughter Barbara and Joel Levine, son Bruce Seidenstein and stepson Joel and Judie Redler, brother Bernie & many grandchildren and great grandchildren.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Lawsuit In Nightclub Fire
description: In the first federal lawsuit over the nightclub fire that killed 99 people, the state and its fire marshal, Irving J. Owens, are accused of failing to adequately inspect the property and improperly training local safety officials. The suit was filed on behalf of two survivors and the widow of a man killed in the Feb. 20 fire at the Station nightclub. Other defendants include the club's owners, Jeffrey and Michael Derderian; Great White, the band whose pyrotechnics ignited the blaze; American Foam Company, which sold the foam used for soundproofing, and the town of West Warwick. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about unwanted junk e-mail, or spam, referred incorrectly to such messages received by America Online. They account for more than 70 percent of the messages that AOL receives, not of those that it delivers to users. (AOL discards the messages it identifies as spam.)

title: Airline's Chief Faces Difficulties In Wake of Silence On Executive Pay
description: Donald J. Carty's failure to tell embittered unions at American Airlines in a timely manner about compensation packages for senior executives will result in continuing hostility toward him, possibly jeopardizing his ability to revamp the ailing company even if it avoids bankruptcy, workers and industry experts say.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm used to fighting for lost causes.''

title: Albany Attacks Bloomberg's School Plan
description: State lawmakers yesterday attacked Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to reorganize the city's local school districts as illegal and accused him of using his control of the expanded Board of Education to turn it into a useless panel that rubber-stamps his initiatives and has little input on policy decisions.

title: Bloomberg Tells Top C.E.O.'s He's Optimistic on State Aid
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg met yesterday with a group of the city's most important business leaders, at their request, to brief them on the state of the budget.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORMAN, CAROL
description: DORMAN-Carol, of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Rockville Centre. On April 22, 2003 in NYC. Loving wife of Avram, devoted mother of Kenneth and Sandie, David and Gail, Ida, and Ellen and Ronald, proud grandmother of Rachel, Stephanie, Jessica, Matthew, Ricki, Jaclyn, Stacey and Jared. Funeral will be held 10:45am Friday, April 25, 2003 at Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton. Interment at Eternal Light Cemetery, Boynton Beach. She will be deeply and lovingly missed.

title: American Overseer in Iraq Returns to a Kurdish Zone
description: Jay Garner, the retired lieutenant general appointed by the Bush administration to oversee Iraq's reconstruction, made an emotional return to northern Iraq today, 12 years after commanding a relief mission here that saved the lives of thousands of Kurds who had broken with Saddam Hussein's government.

title: Shopping Center Tries to Recapture Its Old Shine
description: It's not easy pumping life into a struggling property just down the road from a newer, larger and flashier cousin. Still, that is the aim of the revitalization going on at Spring Valley Marketplace, a 321,000-square-foot shopping center that has spent the last five years in the shadow of the Palisades Center in West Nyack, just three miles away.

description: Stocks rose yesterday, driving the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to a three-month high, as improved sales at insurance companies and drug makers fueled optimism that corporate earnings would exceed estimates.

title: Nissan Is Set to Report Another Solid Year
description: Nissan Motor will announce record profit for the third consecutive year on Wednesday, as cutbacks and a new lineup of cars offset stiffer competition in the United States. Despite a slowing global market, Nissan, Japan's third-largest automaker, said it expected more gains this year.

title: 5 Big Banks In Germany In Loan Pool
description: Five of Germany's largest banks, mired in their worst downturn since World War II, plan to announce on Wednesday that they will pool up to $50 billion worth of investment-grade loans in a new joint venture.

description:
By MARIANNE ROHRLICH
The Kips Bay Decorator Show House is not a home but a laboratory meant to encourage experimentation.

description: Greenspan Says Yes

description: KAUFMAN - Meyer. We mourn the loss of a very kind man, and extend our deep sympathy to the whole family. The Low Family

title: A Printer Dons Many Hats
description: Dell Computer, which already has lines of palmtop computers and portable projectors, has entered the printer market by introducing four models: a multifunction color inkjet for home use, a laser printer for home offices and two heavy-duty units for larger offices.

title: Virus Proves Baffling, Turning Up in Only 40% of a Lab's Test Cases
description: Canada's main virology laboratory has found the virus for severe acute respiratory syndrome in only 40 percent of probable and suspect cases, a surprisingly low rate that puzzles the laboratory's scientific director and other health officials.

title: Graphic Artists Cross a Line: We're Not Just Hired Pens
description: ON a hot, airless afternoon earlier this month, Geoff McFetridge, a graphic designer, showed up for a quick session at a skateboarding park a few miles north of the house he shares with his girlfriend in the Los Feliz neighborhood here. A slightly built 32-year-old with a mustache and a dusting of freckles, Mr. McFetridge climbed out of a Land Rover carrying a battered skateboard and wearing a dark blue ''Hang Loose Hawaii'' T-shirt. Rounding out his 1980's throwback attire were a chunky black Casio watch and a pair of red Vans sneakers faded almost to pink.

title: Pataki Takes Firmest Stand Against Higher Tax on Rich
description: Gov. George E. Pataki, facing a huge budget shortfall, questions about his leadership and a new poll that showed his approval rating dropping fast, stood firm today in his opposition to increasing income taxes on New York's wealthiest residents.

title: Sports of The Times; New Address For Nets: The Garden?
description: A NEW arena in Newark, that's still the ticket, proclaimed David Stern. ''We're standing in the oldest unremodeled arena in the N.B.A.,'' the always informative commissioner said Tuesday night at Continental Arena, which opened in ancient times, 1981, bearing the name of Brendan Byrne.

title: China Offers Its Help in U.S.-North Korea Nuclear Talks
description: As American envoys today completed a first day of talks to persuade North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons program, China appeared to be playing an unusually assertive role in pressing both sides to keep open lines of communication even if an initial round of discussion produces no breakthrough.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Arts & Ideas on Saturday with the Connections column, about Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, was published in error. It showed Wilhelm Furtwngler conducting the Prelude to ''Die Meistersinger'' by Wagner, not the Ninth.

title: AOL's First-Quarter Results Surpass Chief's Forecast
description: AOL Time Warner reported a larger-than-expected quarterly profit yesterday. It was the first earnings release since America Online acquired Time Warner more than two years ago that was not marred by unpleasant surprises.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Posed As Sultan To Steal
description: A Queens man stole more than $65,000 from two women who believed he was a neurosurgeon and a member of the Kuwaiti royal family worth more than $10 million, prosecutors said. The man told the women that although he was the son of the Kuwaiti prime minister, he could not get his funds because of turbulence in the Middle East. The man, Benjamin Maybanks, 39, of Astoria, had legally changed his name to Sultan ibn Chandler Sabah al Sabah Dantata. Mr. Maybanks accepted gifts from the women to furnish his ''temporary'' Manhattan residence, the Manhattan district attorney's office said. He was being held in $5,000 bail yesterday after being charged with felony grand larceny and scheming to defraud. He could face up to 15 years in prison if found guilty. Mr. Maybanks was already on probation after pleading guilty in 2000 to stealing more than $50,000 from a jeweler who thought Mr. Maybanks was a sultan. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qualcomm Says Income More Than Doubled
description: Qualcomm Inc., whose mobile-telephone technology is used by 135 million people, said yesterday that second-quarter net income more than doubled amid higher demand for handsets containing the company's software and chips. Qualcomm increased its fiscal 2003 profit forecast and said in a statement that it planned to sell its Vesper phone unit in Brazil. The company, which makes cell-phone chips and software and receives a royalty on every handset that uses its patented code-division multiple access, or C.D.M.A., technology, has benefited from rising demand in the United States and Asia for phones that include color screens, cameras and games. Second-quarter net income was $103 million, or 13 cents a share, compared with $43.9 million, or 5 cents a share, a year earlier, Qualcomm said. Results include $160 million in asset impairment expenses for Vesper, the company said. Revenue increased 50 percent to $1.04 billion from $696.1 million. The company said profit in the year ending Sept. 30, excluding wireless investments, was expected to be $1.38 to $1.41 a share. Qualcomm had previously forecast profit of $1.34 to $1.39. Excluding the company's QSI investment segment, which contains the Vesper assets, second-quarter profit would have been $314 million, or 38 cents a share, Qualcomm said. That compares with analyst forecasts of 36 cents on that basis. Shares of Qualcomm, which is based in San Diego, rose to $34.15 in after-hours late trading after falling 23 cents, to $32.98 in regular trading. They were down from a high of $200 in January 2000.

title: Resting Ankles, Knees, Hips and Wallets

The seat depth can be adjusted, as can the angles of ankle, knee and hip; the back adjusts automatically. Mirra will be in stores in June. Locations, www.hermanmiller.com. Mr. Barr, a driving force in the impeachment of President Bill Clinton, lost his seat in the 2002 Republican primary after redistricting by a Democratic-controlled Legislature left him to fight another Republican incumbent, John Linder. In February, Mr. Barr said he would seek to replace Representative Johnny Isakson, who is running for the United States Senate. Mr. Barr said that over the Easter weekend he decided he wanted time for his family, practicing law and writing a book. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 2-Wheel Getaway Thwarted, Police Say
description: A man with a knife stole nearly $13,000 from a Queens bank yesterday before he was captured as he tried to escape on a bicycle, the police said. The man, identified as Karis Nembhard, 21, entered a Chase Bank branch at 165-40 Baisley Boulevard in Locust Manor at 11:45 a.m., dressed in black and wearing gloves and a ski hat, the police said. After grabbing a woman in her 70's, he held a knife to her throat and told tellers to fill a nylon bag with cash, the police said. When he ran out, security guards at the Rochdale Village housing complex helped capture him, the police said, and he was charged with robbery, criminal possession of a weapon, menacing and reckless endangerment. But both projects have fizzled and now the love affair between Mr. Koolhaas and the city appears to be on the rocks.

title: Oozing Jacobsen's Cool Modernism, Just As It Did in the 1960's
description: ''Room 606'' may sound like the title of an unknown Hitchcock thriller, but it is a book about a single room designed by Arne Jacobsen, one of the foremost masters of Danish modern design. In ''Room 606: The SAS House and the World of Arne Jacobsen'' (Phaidon, $69.95), the architect Michael Sheridan chronicles the life of a room at what is now the SAS Royal Hotel in Copenhagen. Built in the 1960's, a breakthrough decade for free-spirited design, it was envisioned as a groovy pit stop for travelers. Some of Jacobsen's most eloquently economical designs -- the Egg and Butterfly chairs -- were created for the hotel, and Room 606 still oozes a cool modernism, from the spaceship-shape hanging lamps to the wenge built-in bed stand (albeit with pass twin beds). The room, available for $598 a night, is maintained in pristine condition. In just one room (and 270 pages) the book explores Jacobsen's career as an architect of glass houses, zoomy restaurants and complex textiles. JULIE V. IOVINE

description: The Indian petrochemical company Reliance Industries said that its quarterly profit rose 32 percent, helped by higher global prices for fuels and chemicals. Reliance said net profit in the quarter, which ended in March, was 11.01 billion rupees ($232 million). Excluding a one-time gain in the year-earlier period, income at Reliance was up 41 percent. Shares fell more than 2 percent yesterday. Reliance has interests in oil and gas, plastics and telecommunications. Saritha Rai (NYT)

description: He made the decision on his 21st birthday, checking his .210 batting average after four years in the minor leagues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILBUT, BERTHA
description: HEILBUT - Bertha. Best friend of her sons Anthony and Wilfred (Gail) and of her grandchildren Nicholas and Bretta. Loving wife of the late Otto Heilbut and devoted sister of the late Hans Lewinsky, Esq. During the 1930's, in her native Berlin, she and Otto assisted his cousin, the great Wilfrid Israel (the original of Landauer in Christopher Isherwood's ''Goodbye to Berlin'') in the rescue of many of their fellow Jews. After her emigration to New York, she earned a BS (in two years) and an MSW. As a psychiatric social worker, she specialized in single-parent and interracial adoption. Always ahead of her time, she outraced herself to her 92nd birthday. No services.

Beloved wife and best friend of Charles for 54 years. Adoring mother of Karen and Susan (Greg). Devoted grandmother of Jessica and Madelynn. Loving sister of David (Carolyn) and sisterin-laws Rosalie and Judith. She will be greatly missed by her family, relatives and myriad of friends from New York and Florida. Donations may be made to the cancer research program of your choice.

description: The F.B.I. has opened an internal ethics investigation to determine whether its agents abused their authority by secretly seizing from a news organization documents on international terrorism, officials said today.

description: Don't call ''The Dirty Girls Social Club,'' Alisa Valdes-Rodriguez's new novel, hot or spicy. Those clichs are always applied to Hispanics, she says.

title: The Rural Life; Spring Green
description: A couple of weeks ago, I was in Central California, in the agricultural midland of the San Joaquin Valley, where geometry rules. Almonds, grapes, English walnuts and apples stood in careful ranks beneath the warm sun, the apples blooming and the bees working the blossoms over in every grove. Then I came home. The passengers on the plane let out a collective groan when we dropped under the clouds above Albany and saw a layer of ice over everything below us. The ice was just a fleeting reminiscence of winter, and melted the next day. The real remainder of winter was the look of the land itself. The earth had been flattened by the cold compress of all that snow. The grass was leveled. Where leaves had blown up against the stone walls last October, there was now an indiscriminate brown mat of partial decomposition. Any natural order in the landscape had been eradicated.

title: Europe Sues Greece Over Airline Subsidy
description: The European Commission said today that it was suing the Greek government for refusing to retrieve 194 million euros ($213 million) in state aid granted to Olympic Airways, assistance that the commission has said is illegal.

description: To the Editor:

title: For a Flamboyant Laborite, Iraq Looks to Be His Epitaph
description: LONDON, April 24 — For anyone worried that the House of Commons has become too well-behaved to produce defiant oratory and eccentric behavior, George Galloway is a throwback to a provocative and histrionic past.

title: A Ponte Vecchio for a Wisconsin Town
description: A two-lane bridge over the Fox River in De Pere, Wis., just south of Green Bay, may have a pedestrian mall (sketch, top right) in its future. The Claude Allouez bridge (top left) is scheduled to be replaced by a wider span, but instead of tearing the old structure down, a local architect, Chad Cornette, proposes turning it into a ''living bridge'' (design above) modeled on European shopping bridges like the Ponte Vecchio in Florence, Italy. The living bridge would be lined with stores, cafes and a museum dedicated to the Fox River. Mr. Cornette, 31, said he based the idea on a bridgelike shelter he designed while a student at the Frank Lloyd Wright School of Architecture. ''A Wal-Mart is being built about three miles away, and we're looking at how we're going to save our downtown,'' he said. ''This could be a draw.'' The De Pere City Council is expected to vote on the project this year. FRED A. BERNSTEIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERITT, KENNETH
description: MERITT-Kenneth, December 10, 1928-April 21, 2003. His family of friends will miss the wit, charm and humor of a special pal, gone too soon. Bless you, Kenny.

title: AT HOME WITH: David Armstrong; Softening the Line Between Past and Present
description: DAVID ARMSTRONG collects tiny cartes de visites portraits, late-19th-century photographs printed on stiff, palm-sized cards that were presented as keepsakes to loved ones. Mr. Armstrong has hundreds of them -- soldiers raffish in their Civil War uniforms, young men in top hats, girls in maid's uniforms -- in loose piles throughout his turn-of-the-century row house in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn. ''I think they're really interesting not only because the people in them are dead, but because they're long dead,'' he said. ''It punches in the idea of time.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: E.P.A. Office To Use Wind Energy
description: All the electricity at the Environmental Protection Agency's regional headquarters in Lower Manhattan will be supplied by wind power beginning next month, E.P.A. officials said yesterday. The contract will make the E.P.A. the largest federal buyer of wind energy in New York State. The E.P.A. occupies about half of a 30-story office tower at 290 Broadway, and buys 6.2 million kilowatt-hours of electricity a year, or enough for 1,800 average apartments. The renewable energy will cost about 10 percent more than fossil fuel, an official said. Kirk Johnson (NYT)
