title: What Congress Owes New York
description: Operation Atlas, New York City's plan to protect itself from terrorist attacks, is likely to cost $700 million a year, much of it in overtime pay for police officers and firefighters. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has asked the federal government for money that would offset the costs of the program. While Congress has offered some $200 million in security spending, it has no intention of footing the entire bill. A close reading of the Constitution, however, suggests that it should.

description: The debate over providing health care for the 41 million Americans without insurance moved into the realm of dollars and cents yesterday as sponsors of several plans for universal insurance coverage produced cost estimates for the first time.

According to court papers, in 2000 an appeals court invalidated such a state provision. Soon after that, the Brooklyn Democratic organization enacted a rule effectively reinstating the provision, Judge Nina Gershon of United States District Court wrote in her decision, dated March 25. title: Secrets Behind the Subways
description: New York's bus and subway riders were understandably steamed yesterday after hearing that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had been hiding its money in order to argue for a fare increase this year. One rider told a television crew he wanted somebody's head on a spike. The urge is understandable, if extreme. As the latest reports from State Comptroller Alan Hevesi and City Comptroller William Thompson Jr. make clear, this public authority has forgotten one basic thing: it's public. Its books and actions should be transparent, with no sneaky stuff that shifts revenues out of sight or makes the bigger picture impossible to understand.

title: From Palm, Simplest of Frills
description: FROM their conception, Palm organizers have been designed according to what its employees only half-jokingly call the Zen of Palm: a belief in simplicity, minimizing the steps required for each task and avoiding superfluous features. But as this unprofitable period in high-tech history drags on, it must be hard to maintain that philosophy in the face of peer pressure from palmtop makers like Sony and Microsoft. At those companies, ''Add more features'' appears at the top of the corporate priority list. ''Simplify'' appears much farther down, just beneath ''Redesign the registration card.''

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: TURKEY: HEAD SCARF DISPUTE President Ahmet Necdet Sezer and his military chiefs boycotted a reception observing the founding of Parliament because the wife of the Parliament's speaker was expected to attend wearing an Islamic-style head scarf. But she also skipped the event, in an effort to defuse the controversy, although about a half-dozen wives of deputies turned up in the scarves. Although most Turkish women wear the scarves, the practice is banned in public buildings, and secularists see them as an Islamist challenge to the government.    (Reuters)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Ex-Prime Minister Cleared
description: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police ended an eight-year investigation and exonerated Brian Mulroney, prime minister from 1984 to 1993, of allegations that he accepted kickbacks in 1988 from Airbus Industries to purchase 34 jets for Air Canada, which was then publicly owned. Progressive Conservative Party allies of the former leader said the investigation was politically inspired. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: City Without Fear
description: An anxious city hangs between fear and indifference. Vague color-coded alert signals flicker in and out of consciousness. Homes are stocked with supplies that seem futile against powerful, unseen weaponry. The dilemma of urbanity weighs on city residents: the traits that make cities desirable also render them prime targets.

title: Leiter Gives Enough To Carry The Mets
description: Al Leiter had watched David Cone, the pitcher he helped cajole out of retirement, leave his start Tuesday night in the second inning with a hip ailment, uncertain when Cone would return. Leiter grimaced seven innings later as Jeromy Burnitz took a fastball off his left hand while batting, breaking a bone and interrupting one of the few promising starts for the Mets.

Although she has recommended the book in the past, it will not be on a new version of her book list later this year, which will include only new fiction.

title: Grandmother Never Put Together This Kind of Bed-Warmer
description: A show of 16 art textiles by the Manhattan Quilters Guild is called Times Squared. The 36-inch-square pieces include Robin Schwalb's ode to the silent-screen star Harold Lloyd, ''Time Runs Out,'' top, $4,000, and Jeri Riggs's ''Fall From Grace,'' $3,100, a comment on autumn after 9/11. ''Times Square is such an iconic image of Manhattan that we made it our theme,'' said Ms. Riggs, the curator. Times Squared is open weekdays from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m., and by appointment on Saturdays through May 16, at the Lobby Gallery, 1155 Avenue of the Americas (44th Street); www.quiltart.com/timesquared or (212) 789-1155. N.C. MAISAK

description: MOST children anticipate the last day of school like a convict counting down to a parole date. This June, when that magical buzzer sends kids screaming into the humid summertime, my children will join in the glee, but I expect to be filled with emptiness.

title: ENTREMED SHARES SOAR AFTER REPORT ON CANCER DRUG
description: Shares of EntreMed Inc. soared for a second day yesterday after the company said an experimental cancer drug showed promise in early tests. Stock in the company, based in Rockville, Md., rose $1.19, or 43 percent, to $3.94 a share. The drug, Panzem, showed signs that it might be effective against cancer cells in laboratory tests, the company said on Tuesday.

title: DYNEGY AND SOUTHERN AGREE TO NULLIFY THREE CONTRACTS
description: Dynegy Inc., a power producer that is quitting energy trading after losses brought the company close to filing for bankruptcy court protection, agreed to pay $155 million to the Southern Company to nullify three wholesale electricity contracts. The agreement will cancel $1.7 billion in payments Dynegy would have had to make to Southern over the next 30 years, Dynegy said. Dynegy will get back $96 million in collateral. The contracts were for a combined 1,100 megawatts of power, or enough for about 880,000 homes. Dynegy, which is based in Houston, has sought to end ''tolling contracts'' like those with Southern, under which Dynegy pays power plant owners a fee for the right to sell their electricity. For Southern, an Atlanta-based utility owner with four million customers and about 37,000 megawatts of generating capacity, the agreement will result in a one-time gain of $88 million after taxes, the company said in a filing today with the S.E.C.

title: Injured Jeter Waits to Return but Doesn't Always Watch
description: These are weird days for Derek Jeter, the passionate baseball player who cannot play for the Yankees because of a dislocated left shoulder. When Jeter works out in Tampa, Fla., he feels as if it is the off-season instead of April. Sometimes, Jeter is so immersed in rehabilitation that he does not know if the Yankees have won until he watches highlight programs.

title: Burn, Mix, Copy, Back Up: A Suite That Does It All
description: The era of the shiny silver disc is flourishing now that compact discs and DVD's have become standard mediums for listening to music, watching movies and storing more data than that drawer of old diskettes. For those who have the power to burn but are not yet sure what they want to do with that CD or DVD recorder, a software suite from Pinnacle Systems can handle just about any audio, video or system backup project that might come to mind.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Asthma Funds Sought
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer called yesterday for a $200 million increase in federal funds to fight asthma in New York City. The current asthma program, administered by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, has 23 asthma counselors to work with children and parents. Senator Schumer proposes hiring 2,000 more. A recent study, conducted by the Harlem Hospital Center and Harlem Children's Zone, a nonprofit group, found that one out of four children in central Harlem had the disease. His loft in the garment district is like a supermarket filled with thousands of bolts of fabric. Be prepared to walk crowded aisles, hunting and gathering as you go. Linen sold in the D & D building for $75 to $90 a yard is $8 to $35 here. Ultrasuede is $10 to $25 a yard. Fake Persian lamb to cover a chair cushion or throw pillow is $35 to $55 a yard. Printed cottons for summer slipcovers start at $5 a yard. Super Textiles, 134 West 37th Street, is open Monday through Friday; (212) 643-8700. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAFT, RHODA M.
description: KRAFT-Rhoda M., on April 22, 2003, of Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Hackensack, New Jersey. Beloved wife of the late Marvin. Devoted mother of Richard E. Kraft and Melissa A. Kraft. Dear sister of Dr. Arthur Wein. Loving grandmother of Marlon & Simone. Service Friday 12:30 P.M. at Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, NJ. For information, 800-522-0588.

title: The News from Home, Sealed With a Click
description: WHEN her son Nyje was deployed in the Persian Gulf aboard a Navy amphibious assault ship, Rose Carmichael of rural Maxton, N.C., had only one surefire way to send a message to him: by calling her brother in Paterson, N.J.

title: Many Dead Tigers Are Found At Big Cat 'Retirement Home'
description: On his Web site, John Weinhart bills himself as running a retirement home for big cats once used by the entertainment industry. But what officials found at his home in rural Riverside County this week was more like a mortuary.

title: A Stalwart in the Crease Propels the Lightning
description: Nikolai Khabibulin had finished perhaps the defining moment of his hockey career Sunday night in Washington.

description: Pruning With a View

title: Mortgage Applications Off
description: Applications for mortgages fell last week to the lowest level of the year as the pace of refinancing cooled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFRAK, SAMUEL
description: LeFRAK-Samuel. The members of the Board of Directors of the Children's Blood Foundation express their condolences to Denise LeFrak Calicchio and John Calicchio upon the death of Mr. Samuel LeFrak. To honor the incredible spirit and many contributions of Samuel LeFrak, the Children's Blood Foundation will establish a fellowship fund in his name under the Division of Pediatric Hematology and Oncology at New York-Presbyterian Hospital.

title: TRAVELERS URGED TO AVOID TORONTO BECAUSE OF SARS
description: The World Health Organization added Toronto today to its list of places that travelers should avoid because of an outbreak of a contagious respiratory disease, shattering this city's image as a safe place to live and visit.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: ASTHMA FUNDS SOUGHT Senator Charles E. Schumer called yesterday for a $200 million increase in federal funds to fight asthma in New York City. The current asthma program, administered by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, has 23 asthma counselors to work with children and parents. Senator Schumer proposes hiring 2,000 more. A recent study, conducted by the Harlem Hospital Center and Harlem Children's Zone, a nonprofit group, found that one out of four children in central Harlem had the disease. Nationally, asthma is the leading chronic disease among children. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Consumer Spending Rises
description: Despite rising unemployment and concerns about pension reform, consumer spending in France rose slightly in March, according to the national statistics institute, Insee. Consumer spending increased 0.3 percent last month after falling 0.7 percent in February, while consumer prices rose 0.5 percent month-on-month in March. The report follows another Insee survey that stated that consumer confidence last month fell to a seven-year low. In February, unemployment in France rose to 9.2 percent. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGEL, CHARLES
description: VOGEL - Charles. Beloved husband of the late Esther Vogel. Father, grandfather, brother and friend. Died suddenly in the company of friends, April 22, 2003. He is survived by three sons and spouses. Jeffrey and Brenda, Carl and Valarie, Peter and Maureen. Grandchildren Michael, Lucas, Sarah, Zachary, Jordan, Alexis and Michael. His vision of social and economic justice will continue to inspire us. Donations in his memory can be made to radio station WBAI-FM.

title: An Electronic Inventory Of Precious Possessions
description: Q. I want to make an inventory of my clothing, compact discs, DVD movies, videotapes and books. What kind of software should I get? I have a Dell laptop with Windows 2000 and Office XP.

title: For M.T.A., Bottom Line Is a Matter of Credibility
description: In hindsight, when all the accounting wisdom has been accounted for, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's multibillion-dollar financial plan for the next two years may be judged to be not only sound, but wise. The decision to raise the fare, after seven years of holding steady, may be seen as prudent, even overdue.

title: Stanford Fullback Doesn't Mind the Dirty Work
description: Casey Moore does not believe he was born a fullback. He did not run headlong into the couch at age 2 or deliver a forearm to the mailman at 6.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, FRANCES JANET
description: WEBER-Frances Janet. Of Fairlawn, NJ on April 22. Beloved wife of Julius. Loving mother of Laura Menter and husband Jerry and the late Robin Weber. Cherished and proud grandmother of Lisa, Raina and Debra Menter. Services at 11:30 AM Friday at Louis Suburban Chapel, Fairlawn, New Jersey.

title: Sports of The Times; Life's Turns Can Dash an Elite Athlete's Hopes in an Instant
description: TRAVELING north on Interstate 605, an inviting sign off to the left welcomes visitors to the City of Hope. The slogan refers to a medical research community founded here in 1913, but the name is fitting imagery for Dennis Weathersby, one of Duarte's favorite sons.

title: Another Unworthy Judicial Nominee
description: Carolyn Kuhl, a nominee to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, seems to have undergone a classic confirmation conversion. As a lawyer and as a California state court judge, she advocated objectionable positions on civil rights, abortion and privacy. But at her confirmation hearings, she backpedaled furiously. Her testimony may have been tactically shrewd, but it failed to allay serious concerns about how she would perform as a judge. The Senate should not confirm her.

title: Pictures of Working Life, Taken by Working Hands
description: THERE are people who feel invisible. Many of them cook our food, clean our apartment buildings and toil in lonely jobs. Theirs is a world that many do not see or know. And it is a world that Esther Cohen, with the donation of 100 cameras, set out two years ago to record.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''At the beginning, I was afraid, but it became normal. Of course you scream, but it is normal to scream.''

title: Virus Baffles Health Officials
description: Canada's main virology laboratory found the virus for severe acute respiratory syndrome in only 40 percent of probable and suspect cases, puzzling health officials. Page A13.

title: Detainees From the Afghan War Remain in a Legal Limbo in Cuba
description: Fifteen months after the first hooded and shackled detainees arrived at a primitive tent facility known as Camp X-Ray, some 664 prisoners seized after the Afghan war remain here in a legal, political and geographical limbo.

title: Touring Homes on the East Coast
description: FROM houses with a distinguished architectural pedigree to row-house apartments with antiques and collectibles, the season of house and garden tours has arrived. Here is a sampling of events on the East Coast. Unless otherwise noted, all tours are self-guided.

title: American Air's Parent Reports Huge Loss
description: AMR, the parent of American Airlines, reported a first-quarter loss of $1.04 billion yesterday, reflecting a dismal three months in which it struggled to fill seats and avoid bankruptcy court even as air travel plummeted because of a depressed economy, the invasion of Iraq and the global spread of a new respiratory illness.

title: Chairman and Chief Executive of American Airlines Steps Down
description: After a week of sharp criticism from unions about executive benefits, Donald J. Carty resigned today as chairman and chief executive of American Airlines, which continued to struggle to avoid a bankruptcy filing.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Pinnacle Shares Drop On News Of Forecast
description: Shares of Pinnacle Systems Inc., which makes video-editing software used by media companies, fell as much as 21 percent yesterday after the company said fourth-quarter profit would miss its forecast. The stock dropped $2.14, or 18 percent, to $9.76. The shares have declined 29 percent this year. The war in Iraq caused broadcast clients to cut spending on new products and projects they had already started, the chief financial officer, Arthur Chadwick, said on a conference call with investors late yesterday. Profit, excluding some costs, will be 9 cents to 11 cents a share this quarter, Pinnacle said. The company in January predicted 11 cents to 13 cents. Pinnacle had a net loss of $8.37 million, or 14 cents a share, on revenue of $65 million in last year's fourth quarter. Excluding some costs, profit would have been 7 cents. The company said its net loss narrowed to $626,000, or 1 cent a share, in the period that ended March 31, from $7.95 million, or 14 cents, a year earlier.

title: Gephardt Issues Proposal on Health Insurance
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, a Democratic candidate for president, called yesterday for repealing President Bush's tax cut and using the money to finance a multibillion dollar program to provide health insurance for nearly every American.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUGUSTINE, ROSE
description: AUGUSTINE-Rose. Manhattan School of Music is deeply saddened by the passing of our longtime friend and patron, Rose Augustine. She had a profound and positive impact on the School, leaving an enduring legacy. Her philanthropy and tireless support of the arts was an inspiration not only to generations of guitarists, but to all who knew her. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to her family and friends. David A. Rahm, Chairman, Board of Trustees Marta Istomin, President

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Lyndhurst: $6 Million Set For Preserve
description: The New Jersey Meadowlands Commission agreed yesterday to match $3 million in federal funds for the purchase of 1,000 acres of private land for a wildlife preserve. The land is part of 8,400 acres of wetlands, landfill and tributaries that the commission is seeking to preserve. The federal money required local matching funds. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Both Sides Seen as Winners in Settlement That Averted a Strike by Apartment Workers
description: Negotiators for building owners and apartment building workers said yesterday that both sides had emerged victorious by reaching a settlement at the brink of a strike, but union officials sounded happier than management about the agreement.

title: In a Bank Run, Money Outtalks a Bullhorn
description: Nervous depositors hoping to withdraw their money were lined up eight-across outside the Abacus Federal Savings Bank branches in Chinatown for the second day in a row yesterday. Joining them were the police, the news media and and the bank's chief executive, who used a bullhorn to beg the throng to leave its money where it was.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Funds For Phones
description: NTT DoCoMo will provide additional loans to Hutchison 3G UK Holdings Ltd. to help the company introduce DoCoMo's 3G network in Europe. DoCoMo already owns a 20 percent stake in H3G UK, but a sagging market has forced it to write down most of that investment. At H3G UK's request, DoCoMo will provide a loan of 200 million. DoCoMo is trying to build a network of wireless providers that will adopt its third-generation technology so that phone users can use their phones in different parts of the world. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KETYER, SIDNEY, M.D.
description: KETYER-Sidney, M.D. Director of Radiology for Trinitas Hospital in Elizabeth, N.J. Husband of the late Elizabeth (nee Goldberg). Father of Stephen and Edward Ketyer, M.D. Brother of Gloria Aronson. Grandfather of three grandchildren. Service from Menorah Chapels, 2950 Vauxhall Rd, Union, N.J., Thursday, April 24 at 11:30AM. Contributions may be sent to Trinitas Hospital, 225 Williamson St, Elizabeth, New Jersey 07207.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Change Of Mind On House Race
description: Bob Barr, the former congressman, has withdrawn from the race for the Sixth Congressional District seat. Mr. Barr, a driving force in the impeachment of President Bill Clinton, lost his seat in the 2002 Republican primary after redistricting by a Democratic-controlled Legislature left him to fight another Republican incumbent, John Linder. In February, Mr. Barr said he would seek to replace Representative Johnny Isakson, who is running for the United States Senate. Mr. Barr said that over the Easter weekend he decided he wanted time for his family, practicing law and writing a book. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Tuesday about the Bush administration's enforcement of clean air rules misstated the origin of an investigation that led to a recent settlement involving Alcoa. It was set off by a citizens' suit filed in Texas in September 2001; it was not begun by the Clinton adminstration.

title: Metro Matters; Transit Chief Has the Style Of His Boss
description: MAYBE there is an unofficial school of applied politics secreted somewhere on the outskirts of Albany, a place where people who serve Gov. George E. Pataki have to take a required seminar in offensive politics.

title: Blindsided by Bandwidth Fees, Online Barkers Think Twice
description: GIVING things away, even digitally, can cost a lot. I hadn't realized just how much until I turned on my computer one day last month and discovered that I might owe $15,000 to an Internet company.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Special Olympics Are On
description: The Special Olympics planned for Dublin in June will go ahead despite concerns that such an international gathering could facilitate the spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, organizers said. Fewer than 200 of the 7,000 people competing will come from countries that have been most affected by the disease, said Mary Davies, the games' chief executive. The games, the first held outside the United States, open on June 21. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGNER, ELEONORA (NEE KOBRYNER)
description: LANGNER-Eleonora (nee Kobryner), died April 22, 2003. Beloved wife of Carl, cherished mother of Margaret, devoted mother-of-law of Adam. Adored grandmother of David. Graveside service Friday, April 25, 2003, 11AM, Gates of Zion Cemetery, Monsey, NY. She will be deeply and lovingly missed. Hellman Memorial Chapel, 15 State St., Spring Valley, NY 10977, (845) 356-8600.

title: Reviews by Amtrak And Coffee Growers
description: Two advertisers are beginning reviews on their accounts.

title: Sixers In Control As Hornets Go Quietly
description: The New Orleans Hornets were supposed to get tough physical, if possible -- even brutish. Three days removed from being embarrassed by Allen Iverson's 55-point performance, the Hornets were thought to be fired up and ready to scrap, eager to lay hard fouls and body checks on Iverson and his Philadelphia 76ers teammates.

title: POLLUTION ISSUE RAISED AT AMERICAN ELECTRIC'S MEETING
description: A resolution urging the country's biggest electric producer, the American Electric Power Company, to do more to disclose and reduce its emissions of global-warming gases and air pollutants won 26.9 percent of shareholder votes at the company's annual shareholders meeting yesterday. While that is far from a majority, it is one of the biggest showings so far for a global-warming-related resolution. The resolution, filed by the Connecticut pension fund and Christian Brothers Investment Services Inc., asked the company to disclose how its profitability could be hurt by the company's status as a major emitter. American Electric, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, makes about 70 percent of its electricity in the United States by burning coal.

title: A Hot Commodity With a 30,000-Year Lineage
description: Australia's Aborigines may have created one of the world's oldest art forms and have certainly created one of the newest. Travelers in the remote outback of central and northwestern Australia can see cave paintings and rock carvings that date back at least 30,000 years. Then they can drive back to the big coastal cities and buy paintings by direct descendants of those ancient artists, who use modern paints and canvases but still refer to symbols and images that may predate the oldest cave paintings in Europe.

title: Connecticut Postal Employees Claim Deception on Anthrax
description: When the United States Postal Service and state and federal health officials found evidence of anthrax spores on a machine in a postal distribution center here in 2001, they shut the machine down and decontaminated it. What they did not do was announce that the concentration of spores was the highest in the nation.

title: Riviera Championships: Openings Then and Now
description: American national championships are open to all comers, but European championships are not. As a result top European experts regularly cross the Atlantic and win titles, but the converse is not true.

title: Justices Show Their Doubts On State Law On Holocaust
description: The Supreme Court appeared poised today to overturn California's Holocaust Victim Insurance Relief Act, which requires insurance companies doing business in the state to disclose information about every policy that they or their affiliates sold in Europe from 1920 through 1945.

title: Programmer Says U.S. Cut Funding After Comments
description: A respected Canadian computer programmer says the United States government severed research financing for a computer security project he was working on after he made remarks in the Canadian press critical of the American military.

title: Free-Wheeling Marionettes In an Allegory of Free Will
description: Clever and imaginative, the Israeli choreographer Inbal Pinto works on an intimate scale. Yet those who seek a wider fable about our time may find it in ''Oyster,'' with which the Inbal Pinto Dance Theater opened a week's run at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night.

title: ALCOA TO CUT 275 JOBS AND REDUCE PRODUCTION CAPACITY
description: Alcoa Inc. said yesterday that it would eliminate 275 jobs in Texas and Washington State and trim production capacity at smelters in New York State because of rising costs. The company said it would cut 150 jobs in Rockdale, Tex. About 125 people in Ferndale, Wash., will lose their jobs by June, a spokesman, Kevin Lowery, said. Production capacity at smelters in Massena, N.Y., will be reduced by 24 percent. Alcoa is moving production from costly plants, mostly in the United States, to lower-cost smelters. Alcoa has about 127,000 employees.

title: NEW OPPONENT FOR U.S. WOMEN
description: Visa problems for the Nigerian national team forced the United States women's team to find a new opponent, Canada, for a friendly match Saturday at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in Washington.

title: Like a Swerving Commuter, a Selfish Router Slows Traffic
description: TIM ROUGHGARDEN is a computer scientist who studies the packets of data that rocket along the Internet at the speed of light. But while developing his theories, he often contemplates something far less dynamic: commuters stuck in traffic.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Arrest In Legislator's Killing
description: Prosecutors investigating the killing of Sergei N. Yushenkov, a prominent liberal member of Parliament and a critic of the government, said they had detained a 20-year-old Moscow man as a suspect. Revenge is a possible motive. Investigators said they believed that the suspect might have linked a previous arrest and the imprisonment of his father to a letter in which the father had attacked Mr. Yushenkov. The deputy interior minister said after testifying in the case in a closed session of Parliament that there was ''ample and sufficient'' cause to detain the suspect, identified as Artyom Stefanov. Mr. Yushenkov, who was co-chairman of the Western-style Liberal Russia Party, was shot to death outside his Moscow home last Thursday. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Designers' Visions On a Test Drive
description: For the decorator Larry Laslo and 18 other designers, the Kips Bay Decorator Show House is not a home but a laboratory meant to encourage experimentation. ''Designers can use show houses to try out ideas before they present them to clients,'' Mr. Laslo said last week in the pink dining room he designed at the show house (18 East 74th Street; 212-988-6991; through May 18). Elaine Griffin, another designer at the show house, said: ''A show house is where you see a designer's purest vision -- unencumbered by a client's likes or dislikes.'' Here are some ideas from the designers.

title: A Five-Alarm Crisis
description: New York City's public safety and emergency forces have risen magnificently to the challenge of terrorism. Yet the city's firefighters -- our first responders -- are not as well equipped as they should be in the event of an attack. The Fire Department needs better training, better technology and better cooperation from other government agencies.

title: IMAX SHARES RISE ON ITS PLANS ON 'MATRIX' SEQUEL FILMS
description: The Imax Corporation announced plans to convert two sequels to the science-fiction movie ''The Matrix'' to its wide-screen format, setting off a gain of 11 percent in its stock. Imax said it would change the sequels, ''The Matrix Reloaded'' and ''The Matrix Revolutions,'' to its 70-millimeter format. The original movie, released by Warner Brothers in 1999, generated more than $170 million in ticket sales in the United States and Canada. Imax is trying to increase demand for its projection equipment by converting hit films for its screens, which are as high as eight stories and as wide as 100 feet. Stock in Imax, based in Mississauga, Ontario, rose 64 cents, to $6.70 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RINGER, ROBERT H.
description: RINGER - Robert H., 50. Friends, family and co-workers mourn the passing of Robert Ringer, graduate of Fordham Law School and Manhattanville College. Memorial service, Sunday, April 27, 1 PM, The Unitarian Universalist Congregation, 48 Shelter Rock Rd, Manhasset.

title: Mavericks Take Command Despite Wells's 44 Points
description: Early in the first quarter of Game 2 tonight, a Blazers forearm sent the Mavericks' Dirk Nowitzki stumbling as he ran downcourt in transition. The stealth shove to the back, delivered craftily by Bonzi Wells, typified Portland's strategy for defending Nowitzki after his 46-point outburst in Game 1 of this first-round playoff series.

title: Some Growing Pains For City's Help Line
description: New Yorkers will tolerate a bit of bad advice on where to get the best sea bass. They understand that movie listings must always be double-checked. But they will not stand for bad information about alternate side of the street parking.

title: National Briefing | New England: New Hampshire: Mistrial In Priest Abuse Case
description: A mistrial was declared in the case of a Roman Catholic priest accused of raping an altar boy in 1985 because the jury was deadlocked after 13 hours. The priest, the Rev. George Robichaud, has admitted to inappropriate contact with the victim, now a state trooper, but denies raping him. The man said he was 15 at the time of the incident, but defense lawyers pointed to pretrial testimony in which the trooper said he was 14 to 16. Sixteen-year-olds are not considered minors under New Hampshire law. Lawyers said the case would probably be retried. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Convicted In Secret-Witness Trial
description: A man accused of conspiring to distribute crack was found guilty by a federal jury in Manhattan yesterday, in a trial in which a key witness's identity was kept secret. A Federal District Court judge agreed to close the courtroom after prosecutors said that publicly identifying the witness, an undercover police officer, would hamper his work and put him in danger. The officer had been investigating narcotics trafficking in a housing project on East 28th Street in Manhattan. The defendant, Theo Frazier, could face up to life in prison. Mr. Frazier's lawyer, Philip R. Schatz, who opposed closing the courtroom, said the closing would be an issue in any appeal. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: S.E.C. Is Advised to Take Action Against Couple
description: Officials in the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission have recommended that it file an insider trading suit against a former Wall Street analyst, Holly B. Becker, and her husband, Michael J. Zimmerman, a professional stock trader who has worked at several large hedge funds, according to a person involved in the investigation.

title: Chairman Of Insurer Says He Plans To Step Down
description: Robert A. Georgine, chairman and chief executive of Ullico, the embattled union-owned insurer, told the company's board yesterday that he would step aside as chairman in the face of a threatened proxy fight by his critics, company officials said.

title: Strike in Zimbabwe Shuts Businesses, Imperiling the Economy
description: In another blow to Zimbabwe's economy, most major stores and factories were closed today in support of a three-day strike called by the country's principal labor movement to protest the government's decision to triple the price of gasoline.

title: Prosecutors Seek to Limit Questioning in Terror Trial
description: The Justice Department is seeking broad new powers to prosecute terrorist defendants by urging an appeals court to deny Zacarias Moussaoui the right to question a captured member of Al Qaeda who features prominently in his indictment, according to a newly declassified court brief made public today.

title: Why Work in the Bedroom When You Can Cross the Lawn for Privacy?
description: Just because the commute is better does not necessarily mean it is preferable to work at home in a spare bedroom. Todd Barker lives with his family in a shingled saltbox in Jericho, Vt., but works for the Meridian Institute, a nonprofit company in Colorado. Which meant he often spent spare time at home answering e-mail notes sent from other time zones. ''Todd wanted to be able to leave the office,'' said his wife, Monique Gilbert.

title: Pull The Plug
description: Delma Banks Jr. had eaten his last meal and, in a controlled panic, was starting to count off the final 10 minutes of his life when word came last March 12 that his execution was being postponed because the Supreme Court might want to review his case.

title: A Republican Group Demands That Senator Apologize to Gays
description: A Republican group whose officials include former President Gerald R. Ford and Mary Cheney, the daughter of the vice president, demanded today that Senator Rick Santorum apologize to gays for his remarks equating homosexuality with bigamy and incest.

description: A judge with deep roots in Brooklyn Democratic politics is to be arraigned today on charges that he took gifts from lawyers -- including airline tickets, boxes of expensive cigars and cash -- in return for favoritism toward their clients in divorce cases, a criminal justice official said yesterday.

title: Alan Greenspan Re-ups
description: Not so long ago the idea of replacing Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board would have seemed like a heretical threat to the nation's prosperity. First appointed in 1987, near the end of the Reagan administration, the owlish and Delphic Mr. Greenspan has served four successive presidents with distinction. He is also widely regarded as one of the two main architects -- the other being Robert Rubin, President Bill Clinton's Treasury secretary -- of one of the great economic booms in American history.

title: Body By Fisher, Sound By Bose
description: ''ONE of the best audio systems on earth,'' said Tom Nousaine, who tests loudspeakers for manufacturers and magazines from his home in Pinckney, Mich. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUPPER, PATRICIA MCKEON CHACE
description: SUPPER-Patricia McKeon Chace. Palm Beach philanthropist, died Wednesday April 23, 2003. Born in Palo Alto, California, graduate of The University of Oregon and lived throughout the world and the United States. She called Palm Beach and Greenwich, Connecticut home for the last 30 years. Patricia was an accomplished artist and equestrian. Distinctions and Honors include, United States Croquet Hall of Fame. Patricia was the first recipient of the ''Women of Distinction'' honor in 1991 given by Palm Beach Atlantic University. She and her late husband Fred Supper also established the Frederick and Patricia Supper Center of Achieving Excellence in Business and the Supper Honors Program at Palm Beach Atlantic University. She received the 1991 Hermes Philanthropist of the Year award. She and her husband established the Patricia and Frederick Supper Galleries at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Connecticut, The Frederick and Patricia Supper Central Sculpture Garden at the Norton Gallery in Palm Beach, Florida, the Supper Club at the National Croquet Center in West Palm Beach, Florida, and the Supper Library at the Long Ridge School in Stamford, Connecticut. She was a member of the Board of Directors of Hospice of Palm Beach County and The Croquet Foundation of America. She was also a member of The Society of the Four Arts, The National Institute of Social Sciences and the Preservation Foundation of Palm Beach, and was a Patron of The New York Botanical Garden. Patricia was also a Co-Founder of the Greenwich Croquet Club. She was a recipient of the Red Cross Award, and was President of The Frederick & Patricia Supper Foundation, Inc., a charitable foundation to promote arts and education. She is survived by two daughters, Kathleen Chace Larzelere of Lake Placid, New York and Cynthia Chace Gray of Stamford, Connecticut and four grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Frederick & Patricia Supper Foundation, Inc., C/O Brown Brothers Harriman, 240 Royal Palm Way, Palm Beach, Florida 33480. Services will be held Friday, today April 25 at 10:30 A.M. at Bethesda By the Sea, Palm Beach, Florida.

title: World Briefing: Africa

He appealed for an additional 79,122 tons of food supplies for this year, urging donors to deliver their pledges quickly. He said so far less than half of the total food aid pledged had been delivered. (Reuters)

description: SERBIA: NEW CHARGES FOR MILOSEVIC Serbian officials said the police had charged the former Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, left, and eight others in the death of Ivan Stambolic, a former Serbian president, who disappeared in 2000. The body of Mr. Stambolic, Mr. Milosevic's mentor before they became rivals, was discovered during the crackdown after last month's assassination of Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic. News media reports in Belgrade quoted the police as saying that Mr. Milosevic, now on trial at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, gave orders for the "permanent removal" of Mr. Stambolic, while the actual killing was done by an elite police unit. The police reportedly want to question both Mr. Milosevic and his wife, Mira Markovic, who is believed to have fled to Russia. Marlise Simons (NYT)

With a downtown that shuts down by night, Atlantans drive home to their signature neighborhoods, pockets in and around the city that define their inhabitants. Perhaps the best known of these is Buckhead, a semi-urban sprawl of strip malls, mansions (both old and new), world-class shopping and dining and a night-life scene with something for every kind of frat boy. But skip that scene to explore the older, ever-regenerating neighborhoods of this city to discover Atlanta's lesser-known charms.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Posts Smaller First-Quarter Loss
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation, North America's largest maker of telephone equipment, posted a smaller first-quarter loss from continuing operations yesterday as two years of cost-cutting began to pay off. A gain from asset sales led to Nortel's first net income in 13 quarters. The loss from continuing operations shrank to $136 million, or 3 cents a share, from $841 million, or 26 cents, a year earlier, Nortel said in a statement. Revenue fell a less-than-forecast 18 percent, to $2.4 billion, the smallest decline in two years. The chief executive, Frank Dunn, has laid off more than half of Nortel's work force to counter slumping demand for switches and routers, leading to a 35 percent drop in selling, general and administrative expenses in the recent quarter. Mr. Dunn has said he does not expect demand to pick up this year, which has some investors concerned. Shares of Nortel rose 2 cents, to $2.58.

description: Robert Blackburn, an artist who founded the influential Printmaking Workshop in New York, died on Monday at the Village Nursing Home in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: Scenes of Ritual Flagellation Resonate at Mosque
description: The cuts on Akber Ali Mirza's back are healed, but his joy is fresh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, BERTRAM
description: ROSS-Bertram, on April 20, 2003. Beloved partner of John Wallowitch. Dear brother of David Prensky and uncle of William Prensky & Catherine Prensky Mason. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Saturday, April 26th, 3 PM. Contributions may be made to The Mary Anthony Dance Theatre Foundation, Inc. For The Bertram Ross Scholarship Fund, 736 Broadway, 7th Floor, NY, NY 10003.

title: Sticker Shock
description: President Bush's re-election strategists are planning a double-edged blitz next year fueled by the patriotism of Sept. 11 commemorations and financed by the free-spending donors who broke all contribution records when he ran in 2000. As outlined in The Times by Adam Nagourney and Richard Stevenson, the riskier part may be the effort to wrap his nomination and acceptance speech at the New York convention in the aura of the 9/11 anniversary. But the other priority, sufficient Republican campaign money, is a sure thing.

title: James Joyce's Daughter, Scars and All
description: Walk into a performance of a work about James Joyce's daughter, whose erratic behavior led her to be institutionalized for almost half a century, and you expect something a bit impenetrable. You get it at ''Cara Lucia,'' a dense but intriguing theater piece by the Mabou Mines troupe having its world premiere at the Here Arts Center in the South Village.

title: Mideast Next for Bush: After Iraq, a Strong Hand
description: Having removed a historic threat to Israel's existence, deployed about a quarter million troops a few hundred miles from Jerusalem and coaxed forth an emerging Palestinian leadership, President Bush appears in a strong position to pursue peace in the Middle East, perhaps the strongest of any American president since the 1967 Arab-Israeli war.

title: Fifth Chief Financial Officer at HealthSouth to Admit Fraud
description: A fifth former chief financial officer at HealthSouth agreed today to plead guilty to a fraud charge, federal prosecutors said.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: After Long, Hard Climb, a Lesson on Life
description: John Higgins, a 16-year-old defensive tackle at Fordham Prep, asked the Penn State star Jimmy Kennedy yesterday, ''How did you balance school and football?''

title: Ex-Fianc Shoots Actress, And Then Commits Suicide
description: A Yale graduate with a promising acting career was shot in the face early yesterday morning by her former fianc, who then killed himself, the police said. The shootings took place outside the woman's apartment in Chinatown in front of her visiting mother.

title: Security Council Votes to Extend Oil-for-Food Plan in Iraq
description: The Security Council voted unanimously today to extend the United Nations oil-for-food program in Iraq for an extra three weeks, until June 3. But diplomats made it clear that this action does not preclude the adoption of new proposals to further alter or eliminate the program before that date.

title: MacTavish Asking About the Rangers
description: With it becoming more apparent that Glen Sather will not return as the Rangers' coach next season, Craig MacTavish, who has coached the Edmonton Oilers the last three seasons, may be emerging as a candidate to succeed him.

title: Governor Pataki's Lower Manhattan
description: What with his polls tanking and New Yorkers increasingly miffed about his handling of the state's financial crisis, Gov. George Pataki desperately needs a win. He got one yesterday when he spoke to business leaders in Lower Manhattan.

description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Nutley: Racial Bias Suit Settled
description: A private swim club, accused of discriminating against blacks and other minorities, has settled a lawsuit with the state by agreeing to pay a fine of $25,000 and allowing the state to monitor the club's admission practices for two years. Patrick Nardone, owner of the La Terrace Swim Club in Nutley, admitted no wrongdoing in the agreement, reached Wednesday with the State Division on Civil Rights. The state sued after two club members, Philip and Annmarie Giordano, said that after they asked permission to hold a party at the club in June 2002, Mr. Nardone asked for a guest list and barred those whose names sounded black or Hispanic. The Giordanos filed a separate bias suit, which is pending.

title: Corrections
description: A quotation on Tuesday beneath a picture with a Public Lives profile of Harit Allan Buchman, producer of ''The Exonerated,'' misstated a word he used in asserting that every other civilized country had abandoned the death penalty. As the article reported, Mr. Buchman said, ''We don't own the moral high ground here'' -- not ''have the moral high ground.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I was hesitant at first, to be frank with you, because I was worried that the first pictures coming out of Iraq would be a wounded grandchild of Saddam Hussein.''

title: Bucks Use Brute Force to Keep Game 3 Close
description: MILWAUKEE, April 24 - The play was heading in the other direction, the Bucks racing up the floor for the final play of the first quarter. Rodney Rogers, a reserve forward for the Nets, was following the play when he was shaken by a forearm shiver from Anthony Mason, Milwaukee's burly forward.

title: The Heart Of Darkness, In Cambodia And Beyond
description: In the heart of darkness where Matt Dillon journeys in ''City of Ghosts,'' blood runs hot, blood runs often, and blood runs thick.

title: STANDARD REGISTER TO CLOSE PLANTS AND CUT 500 JOBS
description: Standard Register, which prints business forms and labels, said yesterday that it would eliminate about 500 jobs and shut some factories and warehouses. The job cuts, which include reduction through attrition, amount to 8.3 percent of the company's work force of 6,000. Standard Register is consolidating plants as increased use of print-on-demand services reduces the need for inventories of forms, a spokesman said. Operations at plants in Oklahoma City; Dallas; and Spring Grove, Ill., will be merged into a new plant in Dallas, while warehouses in Memphis and Peoria, Ill., will close. Pretax costs for the job cuts and consolidation will be $27 million to $30 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Supermarket Bid Rejected
description: The British supermarket group Somerfield rejected a 509 million ($810 million) takeover offer by a group led by the entrepreneurs John Lovering, left, and Bob Mackenzie, saying that the proposed price of 103 pence a share undervalued the business. A number of conditions were attached to the bid, including Somerfield's handing over its books for due diligence work. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

description: `Fraktur Treasures From the Schwenkfelder Library and Heritage Center'

description: To the Editor:

description: By day, Ira Rubin takes care of his ailing mother and works as a production manager at a matzo factory in Jersey City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, VERONICA
description: DAVIS - Veronica, died peacefully at home in Irvington, New York on April 23, 2003 after a long illness. She was the much loved sister of Father Bernard J. Campbell, CSP; Mrs. Margaretta Bruegger of Snowmass, CO. and Mrs. Ellen Appelle of Irvington, New York. She was the beloved aunt of Nicole, Amanda, Michael, and Matthew Appelle and John Francis and Retta Bruegger. Ronnie was a graduate of Cornell University, Catholic University and Georgetown University and a dedicated and caring professional who touched many thousands of lives over a thirty year career as a nurse practitioner and midwife. She practiced her profession at the Navaho Reservation near Gallup, New Mexico, Washington, D.C., Portland, Maine and New York City. Her last place of employment was North Central Bronx Hospital where she was most esteemed for her consummate skill and kindness. Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated on Saturday, April 26, 10:00AM, Transfiguration Church, N. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorials to Phelps Hospice, Sleepy Hollow, NY appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFEE, WILTON
description: JAFFEE - Wilton (Wink), Boulder, CO., died Tuesday, April 22 at the age of 77 of prostate cancer. Wink, formerly of NYC, and graduate of Michigan University, moved to Colorado 35 years ago, settling in Aspen. Mr. Jaffee moved his family to Boulder, Colorado ten years ago to benefit from the learning opportunities the town provided. Mr. Jaffe was a prominent and esteemed commodities trader. He was the youngest person to hold a seat on the NYSE. He was a historian and a philanthropist supporting educational endeavors. He is survived by his wife Melissa, their children Catherine and Arthur, by previous marriages: Robert of Chicago, Edward of CT., Alexander of AZ, sister Barbara of Denver, adopted daughter Adriana of Turin, Italy; his son William predeceased him. A private service will be held Sunday, April 27 at noon, Boulder, Colorado.

title: Orders for Durable Goods Rise, But So Do New Jobless Claims
description: Orders for durable goods unexpectedly jumped last month, and first-time claims for unemployment benefits rose last week to their highest level in a year, two government reports released today showed.

title: Drawing a Line at Pets With Long Scaly Tails
description: Putting on a brave face, John Boyko came here Wednesday and stood before a brightly lighted holding pen to visit the foundling that he had spent the better part of a decade raising. ''Hey, Walley,'' he cooed, as the cage door was opened. ''Hey, girl.''

title: Justice for Iraq
description: Tariq Aziz, the former deputy prime minister of Iraq, is one of the best known of Saddam Hussein's inner circle, making his capture yesterday especially significant. In the deck of cards of Iraq's most wanted, distributed by the Pentagon, Mr. Aziz is the eight of spades. The aces are Mr. Hussein, his secretary and his two sons. The cards do not list the acts for which the men are wanted, but the crimes they committed include genocide, torture and the use of chemical weapons. Justice for these crimes is a vital goal of the postwar occupation of Iraq. But the administration's announced plans for justice -- an Iraqi tribunal, supported by the United States -- cannot accomplish the task.

title: A Beauty as Fleeting as Life
description: The ailanthus is the tree that grows in Brooklyn, but it's the cherry tree that lights up the borough these spring days. The Brooklyn Botanic Garden is a showplace for more than 200 ornamental flowering cherry trees in 45 varieties -- now in different stages of bloom -- with luminescent petals ranging from the palest baby-girl pink to the shade of bubble gum to lavender splash.

title: In Letter, Powell Defends Shelling of Journalists' Hotel
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell has written a letter to the Spanish foreign minister defending the shelling of the main hotel for journalists in Baghdad that killed two cameramen, including one from Spain, on April 8.

title: Ernst Partners Accept Limits On Audits
description: Two partners of Ernst & Young who failed to detect the accounting fraud at CUC International have agreed to be barred from auditing public companies, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday.

title: Pettitte Ends Flawless Run by Yankee Starters
description: Rube Benton, Slim Sallee and the other starting pitchers for the 1916 New York Giants still have their place in history. The rampaging 2003 Yankees will not break their record for consecutive games won by starting pitchers. Not now, anyway.

title: 'A Decade Under the Influence'
description: Directed by Richard LaGravenese and Ted Demme

title: Economy Grew Slightly in the First Quarter, Report Says
description: The United States economy expanded at a tepid annual rate of 1.6 percent in the first quarter, the Commerce Department reported today, a barely perceptible improvement from its 1.4 percent rate of advance in the last three months of 2002.

title: A hair-care chain counts on humor to put it out front.
description: A BAD haircut is no laughing matter, but a good one -- well, that might be reason for a chuckle or two, and might build some brand loyalty in the process.

title: Municipal Union's Lawyers Resign After Ethical Storm
description: The law firm representing District Council 37's benefits fund tendered its resignation yesterday, after the union's executive director, Lillian Roberts, faced an ethics storm because she helped steer a contract to the firm, where her nephew is a partner.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: I.R.S. to Ask Working Poor For Proof on Tax Credits

title: JetBlue Posts 34% Increase in First-Quarter Profit
description: JetBlue Airways, the three-year-old discount airline, said yesterday that first-quarter profit climbed 34 percent as it added flights and carried 70 percent more passengers.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Neighbors Reconcile
description: Thailand put a formal end to its three-month diplomatic freeze with Cambodia, returning its ambassador, Chatchawed Chartsuwan, to Phnom Penh for the first time since withdrawing him after anti-Thai rioting Jan. 29. The Thai Embassy and several Thai businesses were burned and vandalized. The ambassador will live in the former house of the Japanese ambassador until his own residence is renovated after extensive damage. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Mandela's Former Wife Found Guilty in Theft and Fraud Case
description: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, the former wife of Nelson Mandela and once exalted as the ''Mother of the Nation,'' fell to scandal today when she was convicted of dozens of charges of theft and fraud.

title: Back From Iraq, High-Tech Fighter Pilots Recount Exploits
description: More than an hour after President Bush ordered the secret strike against Saddam Hussein's bunker on the first night of the Iraq war, Lt. Col. David Toomey was streaking toward Baghdad in his F-117A stealth fighter when, he said, he realized he had a big problem.

title: Marcelo Pombo
description: Marvelli Gallery

title: Revlon Lost $48.7 Million in First Quarter
description: Revlon Inc., the cosmetics maker controlled by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, said yesterday that its first-quarter loss widened to $48.7 million as it cut prices and increased advertising. Sales rose at the fastest pace in more than four years.

title: G.O.P. Completes Draft of Its Bill on Industrial Security
description: Nineteen months after the Sept. 11 attacks, Congressional Republicans have prepared a long-awaited proposal that requires thousands of chemical sites to assess their vulnerability and their response plans to a terrorist attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, MAX
description: FISHMAN-Max. We mourn the loss of our longtime friend and associate. Condolences to the families. Ruth Golbin and Family

title: Sizing Up the Draft
description: A look at teams' needs and possible selections heading into the first round of the N.F.L. draft. By Damon Hack

title: A New Generation at De Beers
description: De Beers, the world's diamond giant, has spent much of the last century or so cajoling, strong-arming or schmoozing the governments of the lands where it does business, generally getting its way. Now, in its home base, South Africa, the privately owned, white-run De Beers faces its newest challenge from a government bent on cementing black political empowerment with black economic power.

title: Threat Gone, Iraqis Unearth Hussein's Nameless Victims
description: First the gravedigger found some teeth. ''Please, just barely scrape the sand,'' Adel Rahaif Hani, whose brother, Satter, was arrested as a political prisoner in 1995, begged the digger. ''I'm worried he's just below this layer.''

title: A Pianist Calls Attention To Vivid Contrasts in Style
description: Part of the genius of Beethoven's late piano music is the way it at once contains the memory of music's past and the seeds of its future. For the opening of her Weill Recital Hall debut program on Wednesday night, the Canadian pianist Katherine Chi chose to emphasize the latter aspect of the composer's giant ''Hammerklavier'' Sonata (Op. 106), making it sound forward-looking and radical. Disjunction was favored over connection, turbulence over smoothness, strangeness over familiarity.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit At Carmaker
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation said profit more than tripled to 38 billion yen ($317 million) in the year that ended March 31, thanks to strong sales in North America and cost-cutting measures. Mitsubishi, which is 37 percent owned by DaimlerChrysler, said sales rose 10 percent and operating profit doubled, to 83 billion yen ($693 million). Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about SARS in China misstated the timing of the dismissal of two senior officials and the government's acknowledgment that the number of confirmed cases of the disease was much higher than previously reported. It was was last Sunday, not Saturday.

title: Roads Not Taken
description: Congressman Richard Gephardt's new proposal -- to scrap the 2001 tax cut and use the reclaimed revenue to provide health benefits to the uninsured -- has been widely dismissed as unrealistic. And in political terms that's probably true. After all, these days it's considered ''moderate'' to support an irresponsible tax cut that is merely large, as opposed to gigantic.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bank Run Abates
description: The F.B.I. continued its search yesterday for the fugitive branch manager of a Chinatown bank where panicked depositors withdrew more than $2 million in a three-day bank run. Depositors of the bank, Abacus Federal Savings, continued to show up yesterday to demand their money, but lines were shorter. Bank officials and federal regulators said the bank had enough cash to meet demand. The branch manager, Carol Lim, was dismissed April 13 after working at the bank for 15 years. She has not been charged with a crime but is wanted for questioning in connection with what bank officials say is the embezzlement of $1 million.

title: Sports of The Times; U.S. Must Work to Avoid Lenient Image Toward Drugs
description: WHEN Ben Johnson was busted during the 1988 Summer Games, Carl Lewis claimed his secondhand gold medal as a triumph for clean living and pristine drug tests. Knowing what he knew, Lewis might have exercised a bit more humility.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about Alisa Valdes-Rodriguez, a novelist who once worked as a reporter at The Boston Globe -- which she called ''a racist institution'' in a 1998 Globe interview -- misstated a word in a recent comment from Nick King, an editor at the paper. He said that a lot of issues she raised while working there were ''really insubstantial'' -- not ''really substantial.''

title: Mets Take Full Advantage Of Astacio's Healthy Return
description: An empty black plastic bag, moving at the speed of a cat on the prowl, crossed Pedro Astacio's path as he was about to throw his first pitch of the season. Astacio hit the first batter he faced last night, Craig Biggio, and it looked as if it would be yet another unlucky night for the Mets.

title: Zooming In On Real Life
description: Watching Jean-Xavier de Lestrade's documentary ''Murder on a Sunday Morning,'' you wonder how he got access to shoot as freely as he did. An account of a murder trial in Jacksonville, Fla., the film persistently stays in the faces of the 15-year-old defendant, Brenton Butler (who was acquitted), and his family; the dogged defense team; the prosecutor; and detectives assigned to the case.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: NEW HAVEN: DEAN NAMED AT YALE SEMINARY Yale University officials yesterday named the Rev. Joseph Harp Britton dean of the Berkeley Divinity School, an Episcopal seminary affiliated with Yale Divinity School, effective July 1. He succeeds R. William Franklin, who resigned last year after Yale auditors questioned his use of school money.

title: When All or Nothing Is What It Seems
description: In ''Identity,'' which opens today nationwide, a group of strangers find themselves stranded at a ramshackle motel on -- how to put it? -- a dark and stormy night. Like the setting, the characters themselves have the damp, bedraggled air of clich. There is a spoiled, has-been actress (Rebecca DeMornay), whose limo driver, a former policeman (John Cusack), has apparently driven in from a French movie, with his dark overcoat and his dog-eared copy of ''Being and Nothingness.'' These two are joined by a creepy desk clerk (John Hawkes), a call girl with a suitcase full of money (Amanda Peet), a nice-looking family (John C. McGinley is the dad), a desperate-seeming young couple (Clea DuVall and William Lee Scott), and a corrections officer (Ray Liotta) transporting a snaggle-toothed criminal (Jake Busey).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, WALTER H.
description: BLUM-Walter H., on April 23, 2003, beloved husband of Jane, caring father of Joanne and Ellen (Barry), proud grandfather of Jessica Leto and Jill, Cara and Kate Eisenpress. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, BARBARA (NEE PEYSTER)
description: ROTH-Barbara (nee Peyster). Formerly of East Hills, New York. Passed away after a prolonged battle with lung cancer at age 75 in Boca Raton, Florida. Beloved wife and best friend of Charles for 54 years. Adoring mother of Karen and Susan (Greg). Devoted grandmother of Jessica and Madelynn. Loving sister of David (Carolyn) and sisterin-laws Rosalie and Judith. She will be greatly missed by her family, relatives and myriad of friends from New York and Florida. Donations may be made to the cancer research program of your choice.

title: 4,000 Quarantined in Beijing as Suspected SARS Cases Climb
description: BEIJING, April 25  At least 4,000 Beijing residents with exposure to a contagious respiratory disease are being kept in isolation, often in their own homes, health authorities said today, and a second major hospital was put under total quarantine, with virtually no one allowed to enter or leave.

title: Las Vegas 2003: Forget the Chips, Try the M&M's
description: THE last time I vacationed in Las Vegas, I traveled in an R.V. lousy with shower-challenged dudes and empty fast-food containers. That was for my bachelor party, back in the days when pulling all-nighters at $2 blackjack tables and dropping large chip tips on the trays of busty cocktail waitresses seemed like the height of bacchanalian cool. It was really more like a bad frat party with free drinks, but for me, Las Vegas still pulsed with the same nocturnally thrilling energy that had made it Sinatra's and Dino's town three decades earlier.

title: No Biz Like This Biz
description: THIS weekend at the Little Shubert Theater on West 42nd Street, 330 otherwise seemingly intelligent people will sit down to learn the ins and outs of a world where 80 percent of business propositions fail, where millions of dollars are regularly tossed out the window, where one's very job title is often spit out like a curse.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Big Easy Money
description: The closing of ExxonMobil's New Orleans office could send 300 engineers to the company's Houston headquarters. But Mayor C. Ray Nagin said New Orleans and neighboring parishes would offer $25,000 to those who take jobs at other area oil-and-gas companies. ''If we can keep 100 of these engineers in metro New Orleans, we will be sending a message to the corporate world that there is something about doing business in the region that isn't reflected in the bottom line.'' David M. Halbfinger (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A theater review yesterday about ''Dream a Little Dream,'' a musical starring Denny Doherty, a former member of the Mamas and the Papas, misspelled the surname of another member of the group. She was Cass Elliot, not Elliott.

title: Iran Strongly Disputes American Accusations of Interfering in Iraq's Affairs
description: Iran's foreign minister brushed off American accusations of interference in Iraq today at a joint news conference with the French foreign minister, Dominique de Villepin.

title: Beachfront Condos: Guaranteeing a Place in the Sun
description: WHO -- Jay Coffey, 60, retired oil executive, shown with his wife, Judy

title: Students in a Fog
description: Federal law now demands that schools close the achievement gap between middle-class children and those from low-income or minority families. But all the money, teacher education and standardized tests in the world aren't going to help if students are at home sick or falling asleep in class.

title: Making the Dean's List At the Con Art School
description: Early in ''Confidence,'' Dustin Hoffman, playing a grizzled, jumpy gangster known as the King, gives some rambling lowlife advice to Jake Vig, a smooth young con artist played by Edward Burns. Don't rely too much on style, the King warns, because ''style can get you killed.'' Since the King is the designated heavy, responsible for the death of one of Jake's running partners, his wisdom can be safely disregarded, and in any case we are primed to root for the suave, smirky Jake as he skips across a carefully plotted grid of doublecrosses and narrative zig-zags. But the King's lecture, delivered in his strip-club headquarters as exotic dancers audition in the background, sums up everything wrong with this slick, empty exercise in fast-talking tough-guy attitude.

description: BASEBALL

title: Jets May Move Up To Select Tackle
description: The Jets told Georgia defensive tackle Johnathan Sullivan in the last two days that they were considering moving up in this weekend's draft to secure him, Sullivan's agent, Len Rowe, said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: PROFIT AT CARMAKER The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation said profit more than tripled to 38 billion yen ($317 million) in the year that ended March 31, thanks to strong sales in North America and cost-cutting measures. Mitsubishi , which is 37 percent owned by DaimlerChrysler , said sales rose 10 percent and operating profit doubled, to 83 billion yen ($693 million). Ken Belson (NYT)

title: G.O.P. Hypocrisy
description: Gay groups are trying to turn Senator Rick Santorum into the next Trent Lott. It's not going to work. Mr. Lott lost his post as Senate majority leader because he said something he wasn't supposed to. Mr. Santorum, who holds the No. 3 position in the Senate leadership, was only repeating what many Republicans have already said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bill To Protect Witnesses
description: Councilwoman Christine Quinn said yesterday that she would introduce legislation next week intended to protect witnesses who testify before the City Council. Under the bill, harassing or intimidating Council witnesses would become a Class A misdemeanor, punishable by a fine and possibly a prison sentence. Firing or demoting Council witnesses would also become illegal. ''Very frequently, workers will choose not to testify because they're afraid, very soundly, of repercussions on the job,'' Ms. Quinn said.

title: OPEC Production Cut Is Less Than Expected
description: OPEC surprised the oil market today by announcing a smaller-than-expected reduction in output.

title: Specialists Deploying To Disable Any Arms
description: Teams of military experts are preparing to leave for Iraq next week to disable and destroy any chemical, biological or other unconventional weapons that are found, defense officials said.

title: INSIDE
description: American's Chief Resigns

title: Rivera Nears Return, but Torre Won't Rush
description: The Yankees' continuing bullpen problems are not causing them to rush Mariano Rivera. In fact, the Yankees are being especially conservative with Rivera, who may not return until next weekend.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Tuesday about James McManus, a poet and novelist who has written a book about poker, referred incorrectly to the final deal, which gave him a victory in a game of no-limit Texas hold'em. The cards common to all players did not include two 5's; that would have given his opponent a winning hand.

title: Abram Bergson, 89, Theorist Who Studied Soviet Economy
description: Abram Bergson, an economist who brought sophisticated analytical tools and a theorist's rigor to the study of the Soviet economy, died on Wednesday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 89.

title: Running Flat, But Running
description: The thump-thump of a tire going flat always brings a sinking feeling, and it is worst on a busy highway with no place to pull over. So-called run-flat tires, which can travel up to 125 miles without air, solve the problem, but they have been offered mostly on luxury and sports cars. Now Toyota is edging them further into the mass market by putting Bridgestone or Dunlop run-flats on the all-wheel-drive version of the 2004 Sienna minivan.

title: 2-Bedroom Condominium; South Padre Island, Tex.; $499,000
description: WHERE South Padre Island, Tex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALLANTINE, JOHN W.
description: BALLANTINE-John W., on April 20. Beloved husband of Rosina Ballantine, loving father of Lucia Ballantine, John Ballantine and Marc DeRossi. Cherished grandfather of Elizabeth, Anna and Emilia. Family will receive friends Friday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral services Saturday, 11AM, at Heavenly Rest, Fifth Ave at 90th St.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Printer's Profit Falls
description: The Canadian printing company Quebecor World Inc. said first-quarter profit shrank 47 percent as prices dropped and the company's unprofitable French operation performed poorly again. Net income for the three months to March 31 was $24.5 million, or 12 cents a share, Quebecor World said. The result was down from $46 million, or 28 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 5 percent, to $1.53 billion from $1.46 billion. Quebecor is based in Montreal.

title: Best Draft Action Often Off-Camera
description: ESPN's coverage of the National Football League draft is a phenomenon: for 16 hours over two days, seated talking heads will be interrupted every so often by a walking talking head named Paul Tagliabue, who will be performing his commissionerly duty of announcing each team's pick.

title: In Texas, a Family Responds to the Call of the Hunt
description: LAST weekend was an important holiday for the Schwartz family. I am talking, of course, about Easter.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Hotelier's Profit Falls
description: In its first trading update since being spun off from Six Continents, InterContinental Hotels, whose 3,300 hotels include the Holiday Inn and Crowne Plaza chains, said first-quarter profit fell substantially because of the war in Iraq, the outbreak of the disease known as SARS and global economic woes. InterContinental also said it would reduce its back office staff of 2,600 people by 800 to save $100 million a year. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Kukoc Again Making Subtle Contributions
description: MILWAUKEE, April 24 - The rings were almost a forgotten part of Toni Kukoc's past as he toiled in Atlanta for part of two seasons. Playing for a National Basketball Association also-ran, Kukoc was reduced to a bit player on a bad team.

title: G.E. WILL ACQUIRE CROMPTON'S SILICONE UNIT
description: General Electric said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the silicone unit of the Crompton Corporation for as much as $1.05 billion. Crompton will get $645 million in cash and a G.E. specialty-chemicals business that makes compounds to curb oxidation and strengthen plastic. The companies valued the business at $160 million. Crompton will also receive payments of $105 million to $250 million over three years. The unit that G.E. is buying, OSi Specialties, makes silicone for adhesives and sealants used in products from lipstick to electronics. Crompton, based in Middlebury, Conn., said it would use proceeds from the sale to pay down long-term debt and contribute to its pension plans.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS TO PAY $55 MILLION IN TAXOL SETTLEMENT

The settlement requires Bristol to pay $12.5 million to compensate patients who bought Taxol or its generic equivalent from 1999 to February 2003, the California attorney general, Bill Lockyer, said. An additional $37 million will go toward reimbursing government entities and the remainder will pay administrative and legal costs. Bristol-Myers has already reached a $670 million agreement to end claims that it used its patents to thwart generic competition for Taxol and the company's anti-anxiety drug BuSpar.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: COURT SAYS VERIZON MUST IDENTIFY DOWNLOADERS A federal court said yesterday that Verizon Communications must reveal the names of customers suspected of downloading copyrighted songs from the Internet without permission even as it appeals the decision to a higher court. Judge John Bates of the United States District Court in Washington said Verizon must reveal the names of the two reported copyright infringers within two weeks unless the appeals court says otherwise. Judge Bates originally ordered Verizon to reveal the customers' names in January, but Verizon had argued that their identities should be protected as it pursues an appeal. The ruling is another legal victory for the recording industry as it tries to stamp out the unauthorized Internet song-swapping it says is partly responsible for a decline in CD sales. The Recording Industry Association of America took Verizon to court last summer in an effort to get the company to help crack down on online song-swapping. The association argued that Verizon is obligated under the 1998 Digital Millennium Copyright Act to help its members protect their copyrights. Verizon says it is willing to help, but argued that the law applies only to Web pages stored on its computers, not traffic on the peer-to-peer networks that merely travel across its wires. After Judge Bates rejected that argument in January, Verizon said that the law also violated free-speech and due-process rights protected by the Constitution. ( Reuters )

Environmentalists support the cap, saying it would set a favorable precedent for the rest of the country. But many power plant owners and others oppose it, saying that it would increase their operating costs, leading to higher electricity rates, and put New York at a disadvantage when attracting new businesses. title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: QUEENS: MAN WITH SWORD IN STANDOFF A 24-year-old Ridgewood man waving a long sword kept the authorities at bay for more than seven hours last night on the roof of a building near his home, the police said. Around 3 p.m., mental health counselors came to the man's home on 60th Street in Ridgewood to take him to a psychiatric facility. When he saw them coming, he climbed out the back window to the roof of his three-story house, said Capt. Jonathan Levine. The man then jumped a floor down to a nearby roof, and refused to come down until around 10:20 p.m., when he exchanged the sword for a cigarette and the chance to use a restroom, the police said. He was then taken to Elmhurst Hospital Center. No one was injured in the standoff, and the police did not file charges against the man, Captain Levine said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia: New Charges For Milosevic
description: Serbian officials said the police had charged the former Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, left, and eight others in the death of Ivan Stambolic, a former Serbian president, who disappeared in 2000. The body of Mr. Stambolic, Mr. Milosevic's mentor before they became rivals, was discovered during the crackdown after last month's assassination of Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic. News media reports in Belgrade quoted the police as saying that Mr. Milosevic, now on trial at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, gave orders for the ''permanent removal'' of Mr. Stambolic, while the actual killing was done by an elite police unit. While staying at a Queens parish, he befriended a parish employee who gave him permission to take her son on a Father's Day beach trip. After the boy accused the priest of abuse, Father Kiarie was arrested on June 25 and charged with endangering the welfare of a child and other sex abuse counts.
