title: HAWAIIAN AIRLINES DEFENDS MANAGEMENT IN COURT FILING
description: Hawaiian Airlines is fighting an attempt by the Boeing Company's financing unit to oust the airline's management and have a trustee take over its bankruptcy reorganization. The Boeing unit, the Boeing Capital Corporation, has asked the United States Bankruptcy Court in Honolulu to name a bankruptcy trustee, arguing that the airline's top executives have engaged in ''self-dealing'' and may not act in creditors' interests. Hawaiian Airlines, which sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in March, leases $546.3 million worth of equipment from Boeing and will owe $18.4 million by a May 20 deadline to decide whether to abandon the leases, court papers show. Hawaiian Airlines, in a response filed yesterday, said Boeing's request lacked merit. The Honolulu-based airline is a unit of the publicly traded Hawaiian Holdings Inc.

title: Deep Cuts Have Not Closed Deficit in Many States, Report Says
description: Despite widespread spending cuts that have helped many states narrow their budget gaps, more than half the states are still struggling to balance their budgets for the current fiscal year and the next, according to a new report by the National Conference of State Legislatures.

title: New Jersey Set To Investigate Inmates' Claims Of Brutality
description: Acting Attorney General Peter C. Harvey said today that he would open a criminal investigation into charges that guards beat and brutalized inmates at Bayside State Prison in 1997.

title: Provocative Economist at Chicago Awarded Prize
description: Steven D. Levitt, a professor at the University of Chicago, was awarded the John Bates Clark medal by the American Economic Association yesterday. The prize, which is given every two years, recognizes him as the leading economist under age 40 in the United States.

title: Contract Is Signed And Draft Conducted
description: The Women's National Basketball Association and its players union signed a new collective bargaining agreement yesterday, ending a period of tense labor relations that nearly led to the season's cancellation. Within hours of the announcement of the deal, the league conducted its delayed player draft.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WALSEY, BETTY
description: WALSEY-Betty. Still loved. Still missed. Still setting the standard. We will never forget her gentility, understanding, and love. Milton, Elliot, Steve

title: Talks Progress for Arena In Newark, Despite Troubles
description: This time last year, as the Nets were heading into the N.B.A. playoffs, the proposed Newark arena long envisioned as the future home of the Nets and the New Jersey Devils faced some stiff competition of its own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPANO, ROSE
description: SPANO-Rose. The residents and staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale note with sorrow the passing of Rose Spano, beloved mother of our dear friend, Andrew Spano, Westchester County Executive. Rose was a lovely woman, who always had a smile for everyone who knew her. We will miss her warmth and friendship. We extend our condolences to Andy, Brenda and the entire family, and pray that they will be comforted by fond memories. The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale Daniel Reingold, Exec. VP

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: MONTANA: TIME WARP ON THE AUCTION BLOCK More than 50 years after the Fifth Avenue Grocery in Roundup closed, locking in a time warp thousands of items, most of them in mint condition, the store's contents are to be auctioned next week in Billings. They range from the mundane  soap, honey and cigarettes  to the rare and valuable  an American Flyer miniature train set with a wind-up locomotive and a Coca-Cola display still in its wrapper. The store shut down in 1952 after the owner died and her children decided against carrying on the business. The children, who recently died, never sold the property or emptied it. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: Areport in the World Briefing column on Tuesday about attacks in Afghanistan included an erroneous report from a United States military spokesman about the nationality of one soldier and the cause and nature of his wound. He was an Afghan, not an American Special Forces soldier; he was wounded by brick fragments after a bullet hit a wall, not by a bullet in the thigh.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: A Dream Flight
description: Realizing what he said was a longtime dream, Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra rode as a passenger in an F-16 fighter jet on Thursday. The air force said the aircraft was on its way to an air show. Mr. Thaksin flew despite a warning from a doctor who said it might aggravate the prime minister's occasional ear infections. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Winnie Mandela Is Sentenced to Four Years for Theft and Fraud
description: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, the former wife of Nelson Mandela, was sentenced today to four years in prison on dozens of counts of theft and fraud.

title: Presumed Innocence? Not on Cable TV News
description: One does not have to listen too carefully to surmise where Geraldo Rivera, the Fox News Channel correspondent and anchor, stands on Scott Peterson's alleged role in the killing of his wife, Laci.

title: Embraces That Morph Into Grappling
description: ''In/Flux'' flowed on. No mood or dramatic situation remained constant in this production, choreographed and performed by Joyce S. Lim and Nami Yamamoto on Thursday night as part of the Danspace Project's City/Dans series at St. Mark's Church in the East Village.

title: Iraqi Civilians Killed in Blast at Ammunition Storage Site
description: BAGHDAD, April 26  At least six Iraqis were killed here this morning after an attack on a huge ammunition dump on the outskirts of the city set off powerful explosions in a residential area, the United States military said.

title: Out of the Slums of Rio, an Author Finds Fame
description: IT seems somehow apt that when Paulo Lins looks out the living room window of his comfortable apartment in an artists' neighborhood here, he sees a mountainside on which is perched one of this city's most notorious squatter slums. For while he may have become a celebrated author, he knows all too well what it is like to live over there on the other side.

title: One Body Found in City Island Drownings
description: Abody that surfaced near City Island on Friday night was identified today as one of four teenagers who set out on a rowboat in January and were assumed to have drowned after one of them placed a desperate 911 call to say that the boat was sinking.

title: As Toronto Grapples With SARS
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUPIANO, ANTHONY
description: LUPIANO - Anthony. The Early Childhood Learning Center of Temple Israel expresses deepest sorrow at the death of Anthony Lupiano. Our hearts reach out with compassion and love to Fara, Erica, Matthew and Michael. Nancy-Ellen Micco, Director ECLC Lori Sitomer, P.A. President

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about the use of microchip implants to identify pets referred incorrectly to two companies marketing the technology. The companies, Trovan Ltd. and its American distributor, InfoPET Identification Systems, remain in business.

title: Entertainment Industry Loses in Net Case
description: In a huge setback to the big record and movie companies, a federal judge in Los Angeles ruled in favor of two online services that allow people to share music, movies and other digital files freely over the Internet.

title: As Toronto Grapples With SARS
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice Dept. Seeks Sept. 11 Transcripts
description: The Justice Department has asked to review the transcripts of secret Congressional hearings on the Sept. 11 terror attacks before they are handed over to a new federal commission that is also investigating the attacks, panel officials said today.

title: Early Verdi With All Stops Out
description: There's no intellectual defense for early Verdi. Either you get it or you don't, and if you have to ask why, you probably aren't going to.

title: Dean Says, 'I Object,' to CUNY Law Students
description: Since its founding in 1983, the law school of the City University of New York has taken pride in its zeal to produce lawyers with a social conscience and a left-wing sense of the public interest.

title: Heston Era at N.R.A. Nears End; Iowa Republican Is New Leader
description: Charlton Heston ends his tenure as president of the National Rifle Association this weekend, as 60,000 members of the group gather here for their annual convention. He will be succeeded by Kayne Robinson, a retired police detective and former chairman of the Iowa Republican Party.

title: Iraq's Revived Communists Appeal to the Masses, a Bit Uncertainly
description: Among the myriad political parties blooming across this revived capital, perhaps the most unlikely one is the bearer of the hammer and sickle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELLEN, SUSAN (MAIER)
description: MELLEN - Susan (Maier), age 57. Beloved wife and soul mate of Seymour Mellen. Adored and cherished mother of Richard Phillips. Devoted daughter of Antoinette Maier and the late Ernest (Tex) Maier. Fought bravely and taken too soon. Funeral private.

title: Iraqi Factions, Guests of Spain, Hold Meeting On the Future
description: Iraqi opposition parties, including those boycotting American-led efforts to install an interim government, discussed building their country's democratic future at a weekend meeting that began here today.

title: Suit Seeks Compensation for Loss of a Jewish Retail Empire
description: Hers was a melancholy childhood marked by family secrets, hard work and meals eaten in silence. Growing up on a chicken farm in South Jersey, Barbara Principe could not comprehend the sadness that shadowed her mother and father, German immigrants who fled Hitler's escalating terror in 1939.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9

title: Army Secretary Quits
description: Army Secretary Thomas E. White, who was questioned about his ties to the Enron Corporation and clashed with Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, abruptly resigned.

title: Defense Secretary Flying to Persian Gulf
description: SHANNON, Ireland, April 26  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld flew to the Persian Gulf today, beginning a trip that officials said would take him to Afghanistan, Iraq and other countries to review America's military and postwar reconstruction commitments in a region dramatically altered by the fall of Saddam Hussein's government.

title: As Companies Reduce Costs, Pay Is Falling Top to Bottom
description: For the first time since the 1980's, the average pay of workers at all income levels is falling.

title: Groups Want U.S.O.C. Presence
description: The independent commission examining how to restructure the United States Olympic Committee learned one lesson yesterday: everybody wants the organization to reform and streamline, but nobody wants to be left out.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I was like a crippled old man when I was discharged. I couldn't walk fast, I couldn't talk because I would cough, I couldn't hold my baby.''

title: Hunting War Criminals
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen declined against the dollar as the United States said North Korea acknowledged it had nuclear weapons. In New York, the dollar settled at 120.35 yen, up from 119.95 on Thursday.

title: INSIDE
description: No Bankruptcy at American

title: Jets Trade Up With an Eye on a Defensive Tackle
description: The Jets got a head start yesterday on what is expected to be a trade-filled National Football League draft, sending their two first-round picks to Chicago to acquire the Bears' No. 4 spot in today's first round. The deal puts the Jets in position to grab one of the premier players in the draft, and they are believed to be considering Kentucky defensive tackle Dewayne Robertson, the top-rated player at that position.

title: A Deal That Worked
description: The clash between American and North Korean negotiators this week reminded me of another push to get rid of nuclear weapons: not the 1994 talks with North Korea, which did not succeed in the end, but those with Ukraine, which did. After months at the table with Russia and the United States, the Ukrainians let their 1,900 warheads go to Russia for destruction.

title: Canada Increases Pressure on World Health Organization to Lift Travel Advisory
description: Canada ratcheted up the pressure today to persuade the World Health Organization to reverse its advisory to travelers to avoid Toronto because of the outbreak of the highly contagious respiratory disease known as SARS.

title: Pataki Back to Budget Talks But Resolution Is No Clearer
description: New York's Republican governor, George E. Pataki, did the political equivalent of unfolding his arms today, re-entering negotiations with the state's two top legislative leaders. After a brief bargaining session, he claimed to have won an agreement from them to restore less money to programs scheduled to be cut.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Denial By Goldman
description: Goldman Sachs denied that it had served as an adviser to the South Korean distiller Jinro, which has accused Goldman of misusing confidential information. The two companies are in a dispute over Jinro's failure to meet a deadline to repay $1.4 billion in debt. Goldman has asked a Seoul court to put Jinro into receivership, while Jinro has asked the court to seize $270 million worth of Jinro bonds held by Goldman. Jinro has accused Goldman of misusing information it obtained as an adviser during the 1997-1998 financial crisis in Asia and of preventing the company from finding new investors. A Jinro spokesman said that Jinro and Goldman had a confidentiality agreement and that led Jinro to give Goldman inside information. Goldman denied it had worked as an adviser and said that Jinro's law suit was an attempt by a discredited management to retain control of the company. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Pataki Aide (Mayor's Friend) Will Oversee Banks
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today nominated one of his top officials, Diana Taylor, who is also Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's companion, to be the next superintendent of the New York State Banking Department.

title: Police Say Prisoner Hired Man to Plant Bombs in Officer's Car
description: A Queens man on parole was arrested on Thursday on charges that a jailhouse acquaintance paid him to plant five crude bombs and two guns in a police officer's sport utility vehicle last month, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PIKER, MYRON
description: PIKER-Myron. To commemorate the beginning of remembering time.

title: End of Game 3 Leaves Karl Rankled
description: ST. FRANCIS, Wis., April 25  Across from the Bradley Center, a digital crawl ran in the window of a watering hole with the words, "We wuz robbed."

title: The Governor's Bad Medicine
description: By calling for drastic cuts in assistance to hospitals, nursing homes and home care, Gov. George Pataki is in effect taking back what he gave last year. Back then, in a display of election-year largess, he used state funds to give health care workers pay raises totaling $1.8 billion and in return won union endorsements. Everyone dealt in was happy, for the moment.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BAE SYSTEMS, a London-based military company, said it won a $34.7 million contract from Boeing Co., the aircraft company based in Seattle, to develop flight control and spoiler operation computers for future U.S. Air Force C-17 air transports.

title: Does a Dollar a Day Keep Poverty Away?
description: In Vietnam a dollar buys half a pound of rice, half a pound of potatoes and a third of a pound of ground beef. In Mexico a dollar buys a pound of rice, a pound of beans and half a loaf of bread.

title: State Court Begins Review Of Procedures
description: Court administrators have begun a top-to-bottom review of procedures in the matrimonial division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, where clerks and court officers will soon be reassigned on a rotating basis. The changes, outlined yesterday by Brooklyn's chief administrative judge, Ann T. Pfau, come in response to what prosecutors described as a bribery scheme involving a judge and several court employees who worked with him.

title: Ways to Report On a Dictatorship
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNOWLES, ROBERT WIN THROP, JR. (BOBBY)
description: KNOWLES - Robert Win throp, Jr. (Bobby). Age 88. Died April 14, 2003. A perennial amateur golf champion in the mid 20th Century. He competed in the 1951 and 1952 Masters Tournament. In 1949, he captured the New England Amateur, followed by the French Amateur in 1950. He was also a three time champion of the Palmetto Southern Cross Tournament. A memorial will be held Monday at the Palmetto Golf Club in Aiken, S.C. Surviving are his widow Barbara Rutherfurd Knowles, daughters Lucy M. Knowles and Alice R. Knowles, sisters Mrs. William Dickinson, Mrs. John Glancy, and two grandchildren.

title: A Pianist Whose Play Speaks Pure Viennese
description: Can a common geography reconnect what the centuries have pulled apart? This would seem to be the central question posed by Mitsuko Uchida's yearlong Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall devoted to the music of Vienna. On Thursday night in Weill Recital Hall, the pianist gathered solo and chamber works by Mozart, Schubert and Berg, presumably in search of a common Viennese accent.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the possibility that counterfeiting has occurred in Iraq misidentified the United States government agency responsible for the investigation. It is the new Department of Homeland Security. (The Treasury Department oversees the Secret Service, which was sent to investigate.)

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: KENYA: SEEKING MORE AIDS DRUGS The government announced plans to sharply increase the availability of crucial anti-AIDS drugs by 2005. Kenya has about 2.2 million H.I.V. and AIDS patients, but only 7,000 receive life-prolonging anti-retroviral drugs. The government has asked the Health Ministry to raise that number to 40,000 by mid-2005, said Kenneth Chebet, director of the national program for control of AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases. The treatment will cost more than $14.6 million per year.

title: North Korea May Be Angering Its Only Ally
description: China sought today to put a positive face on the abrupt end to talks it had arranged between the United States and North Korea, but diplomats and analysts argued that North Korea had alienated China, its only significant ally, by declaring that it had already become a nuclear power.

title: Estate planning: Preparing for the worst-case scenario
description: PARIS  When Michael Carter, an American, died this winter in Paris at the age of 45, he left a wife, three small children, a wide circle of friends  and one of the worst nightmares an expatriate family can face.

title: How a Joke Saved a Slam, Assuming It Occurred at All
description: Some bridge stories have a believe-it-or-not quality: they stretch the reader's credulity to the limit. The diagramed deal, which appeared this year in a bridge column (not this one), belongs in that category, and you can decide whether it is fact or fiction. There is a negative clue.

title: Assessing the Weapons Search
description: One continuing divide between those who supported the Bush administration's invasion of Iraq and those who opposed it seems to be weapons of mass destruction. Many opponents, while stunned by the swiftness with which the Iraqi government and military crumbled, harp on the failure by American troops to produce any definitive proof so far that Iraq had chemical or biological, let alone nuclear, weapons. Those who supported the war are for the most part muting whatever concern they may feel. President Bush, in an interview with Tom Brokaw on NBC News this week, expressed confidence that the weapons would be found but warned that it might take some time.

title: AK Steel Posts Wider Loss
description: The AK Steel Holding Corporation, a leading supplier of automotive steel, said yesterday that its first-quarter loss widened as costs rose and demand fell.

title: Credit Suisse Says Job-Cut Savings and Bond Unit Lifted Net
description: The Credit Suisse Group, the Swiss bank, reported its first quarterly profit in a year today as revenue at its bond business rose and costs declined after 9,350 job cuts.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Muslim men who were fulfilling a government requirement to register at immigration offices misstated the day that an Egyptian parking attendant registered in Arlington, Va. It was Tuesday, not Thursday.

title: KING PHARMACEUTICALS EXPECTS TO HIT LOW END OF TARGET
description: King Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter profits, excluding some items, would be as low as 33 cents a share, the bottom of the company's forecast range. King, which is based in Bristol, Tenn., expects to record charges of $85 million to $90 million, or 35 cents to 37 cents a share, for the three-month period, a spokesman, James Green, said. Including the expense, King expects its per-share net income to range from a 4-cent loss to earnings of 2 cents, Mr. Green said. He would not give a dollar figure. The company also plans to cut second-quarter and full-year earnings estimates because of a canceled purchase of medicines from the Elan Corporation, which would have given it Elan's Skelaxin muscle relaxant and Sonata sleep aid. King fell 42 cents, or 3.8 percent, to $10.77 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Religion Journal; Taking Jesus as Spouse, and Living a Life in Prayer
description: As Kathleen Danes prepares to become a June bride, in her bedroom closet hangs her gown, in a shade of sky blue. It is not that Ms. Danes is ineligible for virginal white. Quite the contrary; at her church ceremony, she will formally become a consecrated virgin wedded to Jesus Christ. She chose that hue, she said, because it was the color worn by the Virgin Mary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBY, DAVID R.
description: JACOBY-David R., Attorney. We have love and fond memories of 63 years together. Husband, father, grandfather, uncle, great and great-greatuncle. Services Sunday, April 27, 2003, 10:30am at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 9860 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL FALLS. Oil prices fell in volatile trading amid confusion over the decision by OPEC to cut daily production while also increasing quotas. In New York, crude oil for June delivery fell 38 cents, to $26.26 a barrel.

title: CLERIC IN IRAN SAYS SHIITES MUST ACT
description: A religious edict issued in Iran and distributed to Shiite mullahs in Iraq calls on them ''to seize the first possible opportunity to fill the power vacuum in the administration of Iraqi cities.''

title: Boston Archdiocese Lowers Goal for Fund-Raising Campaign
description: The Archdiocese of Boston today announced its first fund-raising campaign under Bishop Richard G. Lennon, seeking to raise $9 million in a diocese where donations have plummeted and budgets have been slashed since the sexual abuse scandal exploded here 15 months ago.

title: Travelers Have Enough Worries; Airline Woes Hardly Faze Them
description: When Rick Kupcunas heard rumors a few weeks ago that American Airlines might file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, the Dallas-based technology consultant cashed in 150,000 of his frequent-flier miles to get four tickets for a family vacation to the West Coast.

title: Editorial Observer; At 16 Cylinders, Here Comes the Ultimate American Dream Machine
description: At the New York auto show, Ford has an interesting little vehicle on display. It is sort of an ultimate green machine -- fueled by hydrogen, lubricated by cornflower oil, rolling on tires made of corn, built with panels of soy. I can imagine waking up one morning to find my ride being devoured by groundhogs. Ford calls it the Model U, invoking a pioneering, back-to-basics machine. Fascinating but very lonely.

title: Army Secretary Steps Down; Had Clashed With Rumsfeld
description: Thomas E. White, whose tenure as Army secretary was marred by questions over his ties to the scandal-plagued Enron Corporation and his advocacy for an artillery system canceled by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, resigned abruptly tonight.

title: Reviving The Doors: A Franchise In Flux
description: As travesties go, it could have been worse. At times during the concert by the reconstituted Doors at Roseland on Thursday night, the band briefly reawakened its indelible late-1960's sound, with Robby Krieger's jabbing blues guitar lines, Ray Manzarek's spookhouse-calliope organ and Ian Astbury's careful mimicry of Jim Morrison's voice. Then the illusion faded, and the new Doors became a passable Doors tribute band holding an invaluable trademark.

title: Paraguay's Election Features Novel Issue: Reform
description: On a continent that has been swept by grass-roots movements against more than a decade of market reforms, the leading opposition candidate in presidential elections scheduled here for Sunday is swimming in the other direction.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Thursday about the Nets' preparations for Game 3 of their playoff series misattributed a comment from a player. It was Kerry Kittles, not Jason Kidd, who said he needed to be more aggressive, adding: ''We have to make those shots. With the defenses collapsing on our forwards, we as perimeter players have to be able to make plays.''

title: Burns Sees Cup Drive As Being Half Empty
description: Devils Coach Pat Burns will not work the room as a stand-up comedian any time soon, but he was more sour and blunt than usual today.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Chemical Spills Into River
description: Just after midnight a tanker carrying xylene collided with a towboat pushing grain barges on the Mississippi River near Garyville, spilling about 42,000 gallons of the chemical, the Coast Guard said. There were no injuries, said Odfjell ASA, a Norwegian company whose subsidiary owns the tanker. Xylene is used as a solvent and paint thinner. The Coast Guard is investigating. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEEBER, EVELYN
description: BEEBER-Evelyn. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Devoted mother of Allen and Judy Beeber. Loving grandmother of Shari Lang, Jason, Justin, and Jordan Beeber, and great-grandmother of Samantha and Jessica Lang. Service Sunday 12:45, ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Corrections
description: A credit was omitted in Circuits on Thursday for a picture of Seth Pack, a former computer virus writer who now works in security. It was by Tim W. Kimzey for The New York Times.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Chicago Economist Wins Prize for Studies on Crime

title: Westbrook Is Focus Of a Disney Movie
description: Peter Westbrook, the Asian and African-American fencer who won a bronze medal in the 1984 Summer Olympics and created a foundation in Harlem to teach the sport to inner-city youngsters, is the focus of a movie from the Walt Disney Company.

title: Economy Grew At Rate of 1.6% In First Quarter
description: Dragged down by the uncertainty of war and high energy prices, the economy expanded 1.6 percent at an annual rate in the first quarter, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

title: Family Waits, Now Alone, for a Missing Soldier
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAVA, FRANK
description: FAVA-Frank. Gone Fishin' Beloved son, brother and friend, passed away on the evening of April 24, 2003. Cause of death was cardiac arrest. He is survived by his mother, Beverly Morse, his sister, Darice Lang, his stepfather John H. Morse Jr., his brother-in-law Joseph Lang, his god-daughter Abbi K. Davis and a wealth of friends dear to his heart, to numerous to mention. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St., Sunday, April 27th 6PM. Contributions to Frank's memory may be made to New York City Relief for the Homeless at 1181 East Broad Street, Elizabeth, NJ 07201.

title: Can SARS Be Stopped? Experts Differ, but Fear a Third-World Epidemic
description: Can the spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome be stopped and the disease eradicated from the world? Or will SARS join a long list of other infectious diseases that stay with us, entrenched, at some level, in most countries?

title: Unions Are a Victim Of Their Own Success At the Nation's Airlines
description: Strange as it may seem, the unions representing tens of thousands of workers at American, United, Northwest and other airlines have been taking such a pounding partly because they have been so successful.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Turbine Maker To Cut Jobs
description: The French engineering company Alstom said it planned to eliminate 3,000 jobs in its power-turbo systems unit, which makes heavy- duty gas turbines, large steam turbines and generators. The cuts represent 27 percent of the unit, which currently employs 11,000 people across Europe. Alstom said that the division was facing a sharp downturn in the gas turbine market, a decrease in orders for steam power plants and a significant market overcapacity. In March, Alstom's market value fell by half in less than a month and it is now struggling with a debt of about 5 billion euros ($5.5 billion). Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: AMERCO SAYS INSURANCE UNIT WILL END SOME BUSINESS
description: Amerco, the parent of U-Haul International, said its Republic Western Insurance Company unit would discontinue business not related to U-Haul as part of a plan to reduce costs. The move is expected to lead to staff cuts at Republic Western and may cause near-term losses, Amerco said. The company said it was still determining the number of jobs that would be affected and the timing. A spokeswoman, Jennifer Flachman, said the insurer had about 350 employees. The insurance unit has had losses of more than $100 million in recent years on coverage not related to the U-Haul vehicle-rental business, Amerco said.

title: Spinning Connections In a Worldwide Groove
description: The New York band Yerba Buena started its life about two years ago, drawing its members from pop and jazz and Cuban music, playing sets that formally ricocheted all over the place. One piece would be an acoustic ballad, one would be a thundering Afrobeat song, one a shameless and pleasurable number cribbed from 70's soul. The idea was to start from the funk-positive position of a savvy New York party band and work backward through various iterations of worldwide Afro-Latin culture through salsa and boogaloo, Yoruban religious music and finally West Africa itself.

title: The Future Is Past
description: As with all that goes up, that magnificent bird, the Concorde, is about to come down. I was lucky enough to have crossed the Atlantic on either the French or British version a couple of dozen times, and on each trip I couldn't escape the feeling that I was appearing in a film. A very high-budget film. As an extra. I needed only look at my fellow passengers -- Wall Streeters, rock icons, and stars of stage, screen and rehab, each with a ton of Vuitton -- to realize that I was soon to travel faster than the speed of sound, sitting across the aisle from some very high rollers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, EDWIN SAUL
description: MARKS-Edwin Saul. On April 24, 2003 at home surrounded by Nancy, his childhood sweetheart and loving wife of 53 years and his daughters, Carolyn Marks Blackwood, Linda Marks Katz and Constance Marks Miller; his sons-in-law, Greg Quinn, Richard Katz and James Miller. Loving grandfather of his 3 grandchildren, Gabriel, Laura and Sophia. He is survived by his sister Marjorie Boas Levins, his brother-in-law Jack Levins and his childhood friend and brother - in - law Jerome Abeles and Betsy McGrathAbeles. His generosity, sense of humor and kindness in word and deed will always be remembered by those who knew him. Services will be held Monday, April 28 at 11 AM at Temple Beth El, 5 Old Mill Road in Great Neck. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the BoasMarks Biomedical Science Research Center at North Shore-Long Island Jewish Hospital or to the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory.

title: Harvard Sweeps Adams Cup Regatta
description: In Annapolis, Md., Harvard's men's varsity heavyweights took their undefeated record to "our favorite regatta," as Mike Skey, the Crimson captain, called this triangular matchup with Navy and Pennsylvania, and captured the Adams Cup on the Severn River for the fourth straight year. Harvard dominated all five races, winning "like the Harvard crews of a decade ago," said Stan Bergman, Penn's coach, whose crews finished last in every race. Navy's coach, Rick Clothier, was equally impressed, saying to Bergman, "They just took us all out."

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Painstakingly, Picking a Jury For 3rd Trial In Race Killing
description: Lawyers in the latest Crown Heights trial were gathered around the judge's bench in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday. The prosecutor, Lauren Resnick, objected to the removal of prospective juror No. 66. She said that the defense appeared to have vetoed her as part of a pattern of getting rid of Jewish jurors.

title: In Hong Kong, even your friends keep their distance : Close encounters with a virus
description: HONG KONG  Nothing kills your social life in Hong Kong these days quite like telling people you report on SARS.

title: Store Manager Is Indicted In Sex Abuse of Employees
description: A Hollywood Video store manager was indicted yesterday on charges that he repeatedly sexually abused five of his employees and raped one of them.

title: With Mutter and Previn, Music Is a Family Matter
description: Authors of fiction are admonished to write what they know. Andr Previn seems to have done that in his new Violin Concerto.

title: A Cloudy Spring at Penn State
description: Joe Paterno can tell you how he shared an office a quarter of the size of the showroom-quality spread he inhabits here in the barely four-year-old Lasch Football Building on the Penn State campus. ''We got the job done,'' he said, lifting his heavy-rimmed glasses to rub his eyes. ''This is all for the next guy.''

title: Argentina's Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Rumsfeld Says Prisoners Are Providing Useful Data
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that some captured senior Iraqi officials were providing ''useful'' information to American interrogators. He also said the United States had released more than 1,000 other prisoners, mostly Iraqi soldiers who surrendered during the war and had no intelligence value.

title: WESTPOINT TO CLOSE REST OF TOWEL-MAKING COMPLEX
description: WestPoint Stevens Inc., which makes Ralph Lauren Home bedding and bath products, will shut the remainder of a towel-manufacturing complex in Roanoke Rapids, N.C. The closing of the two plants and a distribution center, scheduled for June 28, will affect about 320 employees, who will be given priority should jobs be available at other plants, a spokeswoman, Toni Cauble, said. The company, which is based in West Point, Ga., had shut part of the complex in 2001.

title: McDynamo Romps At Keeneland
description: McDynamo passed the front-running favorite Al Skywalker around the far turn and went on to win the $150,000 Grade I Royal Steeplechase for the Sport of Kings by seven and a half lengths yesterday on Keeneland's closing day in Lexington, Ky. The victory was the third straight for McDynamo, a 6-year-old gelding who was ridden by Craig Thornton and is owned by Michael Moran of Unionville, Pa.

title: A Briton Who Hailed Hussein Is Said to Have Been in His Pay
description: For anyone worried that the House of Commons has become too well behaved to produce defiant oratory and eccentric behavior, George Galloway is a throwback to a provocative and histrionic past.

title: GLOBALSTAR GETS PERMISSION TO SELL ASSETS TO ICO
description: Globalstar, a satellite telephone company, won a bankruptcy judge's permission to sell its assets to ICO Global Communications Holdings. ICO, a London-based satellite communications company financed by the cellular phone entrepreneur Craig O. McCaw, will pay $55 million for the assets and 54 percent of the reorganized stock. Another bidder, Thermo Capital Partners, had offered as much as $55 million for 67 percent of the stock. Judge Peter Walsh of United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., approved the sale.

title: Expected U.S. Plan on Iraq Likely to Face U.N. Dispute
description: A United States plan that is likely to call for the endorsement of allied authority to run Iraq and for an end to the United Nations' sole control over its oil will prompt dogged opposition from several Security Council members when it is introduced here next week, diplomats here predicted today.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Online Diary column of Circuits on Thursday about a Web site recounting trials in 18th-century London misstated the surname of a creator of the site. He is Tim Hitchcock, not Hutchinson.

description: To the Editor:

title: Machinations Start to Unfold Even Before the Picking Begins
description: The first surprise, two days before the N.F.L. draft, was the sight of Southern California quarterback Carson Palmer smiling on a podium in Cincinnati as the Bengals snatched him as their No. 1 pick.

title: Young Actress Shot by Former Fianc Dies
description: A 22-year-old aspiring actress whose former fianc harassed her for two months before shooting her in the face and killing himself outside her Lower East Side apartment building early Thursday morning, died at Bellevue Hospital Center yesterday, the authorities said.

title: NASA Official Urges a Focus on Potential Problems
description: One of the greatest challenges for NASA managers when space shuttles start flying again will be finding better ways to anticipate problems that can compromise safety, the leader of the space agency said today.

title: Former Secretary of State May Be Big Board Nominee
description: Hoping to bolster its credibility after a series of missteps, the New York Stock Exchange is planning to nominate Madeleine K. Albright, the former secretary of state, to its board, people briefed on the proposal said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: JOBLESS RATE RISES Japan's unemployment rate rose to 5.4 percent in March, from 5.2 percent in February, and the number of new jobs slipped, a sign of the economy's fragile state. The cuts come as industrial production, a leading driver of the economy, slows and banks push more of their lenders to overhaul their businesses. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Labor
description: BOSTON TEAMSTER INDICTMENT George Cashman, one of the most powerful Teamster officials in New England, admitted accepting $20,000 through extortion as part of a plea deal with federal prosecutors on the eve of a trial for embezzlement in Boston. Mr. Cashman, president of Teamsters Local 25, which represents movie truck drivers, was charged with extorting $100,000 from a health care company and with falsifying time sheets, enabling 19 truck drivers to collect more than $72,000 in health benefits. Mr. Cashman faces a possible prison sentence of 30 to 37 months and will lose his job as a result of the plea. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Bayer's Annual Earnings Jump as Costs Are Cut
description: Bayer, the German drug maker, said today that it expected operating profit to jump more than 10 percent this year after cutting costs.

title: Mayor Wants a Parade for Returning Troops
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he has offered to give a ticker-tape parade up lower Broadway for the American troops returning from the war in Iraq, and is waiting for a response from Washington.

title: U.S. to Announce Role for Iraqis in Their Nation's Oil Industry
description: After insisting for months that it intends to let Iraqis run their own oil industry, the Bush administration is expected to announce next week a plan that puts day-to-day control in the hands of senior Iraqis within the Oil Ministry, say people who have spoken with the administration and some former Iraqi oil officials.

title: Lawyers Silent on Possible Asbestos Trust
description: Plaintiffs' lawyers are not usually a meek lot. But they seem to have lost their voice in the debate over a national trust to end all asbestos lawsuits, which might cost them tens of billions of dollars in attorneys' fees over the next 30 years.

title: In a City Claimed by Kurds and Arabs, U.S. Troops Try to Keep Peace
description: Adel Abdul Saad ran up to the leader of an American military patrol on Thursday afternoon and begged for help. The Kurds would come back that night, the 30-year-old Arab frantically warned. If the Americans did not protect them, the Arabs would defend themselves.

title: Bush May Declare Victory Thursday
description: President Bush may formally declare a military victory over Iraq as early as Thursday, when he plans to visit an aircraft carrier returning from the Persian Gulf, White House officials said today.

title: Hong Kong Doctor's Ordeal As Patient With New Disease
description: When Dr. Yu Cheuk-man, an associate professor of cardiology, tested the clinical skills of a group of medical students in a hospital ward here on March 6, he paid little attention to the 26-year-old pneumonia patient in a nearby bed.

title: Reader's Digest Reports a Loss
description: Reader's Digest Association Inc. had a third-quarter loss because of job-cut costs and said profit this quarter will fall more than forecast.

title: BEIJING BROADENS SARS QUARANTINE; MORE CASES FOUND
description: At least 4,000 Beijing residents who have been exposed to SARS are being kept in isolation, health authorities said today, and a second major hospital was put under total quarantine as China struggled to contain the disease here in the capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAUGHAN, THOMAS F.
description: VAUGHAN-Thomas F. Age 72, died Thursday, April 24, 2003. Beloved husband of Donna, devoted father of Cathy, Thomas, Margaret and father-in-law to Edward. Loving grandfather of Brian, Christian, McKenzie and Elizabeth. Dear brother of Catherine Gallagher, Mildred Bugge and Jack and Robert (Vincent). Retired from the Stereotype Department of The New York Times 2000. He was in show business as a singer/entertainer and was a partner in a few restaurants, an active member in the church choir, a past member of the 107th New York National Guard. Visitation Applebee - McPhillips Funeral Home, 130 Highland Avenue, Middletown, NY Sunday 2-4 & 7-9. Mass 10 AM Monday Mt. Carmel Church, Middletown. Burial to follow at St. Paul's Cemetery, Bullville, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, PAIGE
description: BROOKS-Paige, of Coral Springs, Florida, formerly of Armonk, NY, and Teaneck, NJ, on April 22. Devoted mother of Andrew and Emily Bauer. Loving sister of Joan Hillman and Amy Blau. She will be remembered as a wonderful teacher, magical artist and loving friend. May she rest in peace. Private service Sunday.

title: As Profit Falls, Samsung Turns More Aggressive
description: The Samsung Electronics Company announced today that it would spend $500 million to upgrade its sole overseas chip plant, in Austin, Tex. Within hours of that announcement, Samsung's stock dropped 2.4 percent -- North Korean officials said that they had the capability to make nuclear bombs.

title: Pettitte's Shaky Outing Is a First for the Yanks
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., April 25  It was the kind of night that happens to all pitchers, even the best ones. Mechanics are off, pitches stay up, hitters get ahead in the count. Until Thursday, the Yankees had somehow avoided this for 21 games.

title: Illegal Aliens Can Be Held Indefinitely, Ashcroft Says
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft has ruled that illegal immigrants who have no known links to terrorist groups can be detained indefinitely to address national security concerns.

title: Travelers Seem Calm As Airlines Squirm
description: There were few tears or traumatized passengers at O'Hare International Airport this afternoon.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Thursday about the Environmental Protection Agency's decision to buy wind-generated electricity for its regional headquarters in Lower Manhattan misstated the use to which the power will be put. The wind power goes into a general grid, not to individual customers; the agency's electricity will continue to come from a variety of sources.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: BUS HIJACKING The police seized a 17-year-old Lebanese native who hijacked a bus and held several people hostage for seven hours, demanding the release of four arrested members of Al Qaeda, including one said to be a mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks. Nobody was injured in the incident. The police said they did not believe that the youth had any connection to terrorist groups. The hijacking began in the northern city of Bremen when the teenager, a naturalized German citizen, seized a bus and its 14 passengers. He demanded the release of Ramzi bin al-Shibh, who was arrested in Pakistan last year. Mr. bin al-Shibh is believed by investigators to have been one of two crucial Qaeda figures behind the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELANEY, MARK ALEXANDER
description: DELANEY-Mark Alexander. It is with heartfelt sorrow that the family of Mark Alexander Delaney share with family and friends the sad news of his unexpected death on Tuesday, April 22, 2003. He died suddenly at home at the age of 47. Born in West Hartford, CT, he lived in Lake Hiawatha, NJ, Cherry Point, NC, and West Palm Beach, FL. Mr. Delaney was a self-employed carpenter who excelled in advanced mathematics. He was a member of the Delbarton Alumni Association, The Fordham University Alumni Association. He was a member of the swim team at Delbarton and played hockey for Fordham University. He was an avid surfer and sports enthusiast. He is survived by two daughters, Meghan Lynn Delaney and Chelsea Ann Delaney, five siblings, Elise Ann Collins of Boonton Township, Michael John Delaney of Boonton Township, Sean Gerard Delaney of Dorchester, MA, Frank A. Delaney IV of Rumson, NJ and Erin Kathleen Delaney of Boonton Township, his parents Frank A. Delaney III and Elise (Murphy) of Boonton Township, three great-aunts, Kathryn Corley Sharp of Mass, Mary Flaherty Stuermer of Montville, NJ and Elizabeth Addis Corley of Denville, NJ, nine aunts and uncles, many nieces and nephews and 33 cousins. Friends may call at Lewis & Carey Funeral Home, 312 West Main St, Boonton, NJ on Sunday April 27th 2-6PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Mary's Abbey at Delbarton on Mendham Road in Morristownship on Monday, April 28th at 10AM. A private cremation will follow Mass. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory to Sunrise House, 37 Sunset Inn Rd, Newton, NJ 07860 or the Delbarton School Fund, St. Mary's Abbey office, Mendham Road, Morristown, NJ 07960 would be greatly appreciated.

title: Mussina Takes Control Against the Rangers
description: The best player in baseball had no chance. Not tonight, not with the way Mike Mussina was pitching.

title: Long Beach Poly Pulls Off 2 Upsets
description: The girl sprinters of Long Beach Poly of California twice stunned the Jamaican high school runners that usually dominate the Penn relays with impressive victories yesterday at Franklin Field in Philadelphia.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Honda Profit Rises
description: The Honda Motor Company said profit rose 9.4 percent in its fiscal fourth quarter ended March 31 as a result of cost-cutting and the success of its minivans and sport utility vehicles. Honda, Japan's second-largest carmaker, earned 117 billion yen ($975 million) in the quarter as sales grew 7.4 percent. For the full fiscal year, Honda's profits grew 17.6 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Iraqi Civilians Killed in Blast at Ammunition Storage Site
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 26  At least six Iraqi civilians were killed on the outskirts of Baghdad today when explosions ripped through an ammunition dump guarded by American troops in their neighborhood. Military officials said a group of attackers had fired a flare into the cache, setting off the blasts.

title: PENTAGON SENDING A TEAM OF EXILES TO HELP RUN IRAQ
description: The Pentagon has begun sending a team of Iraqi exiles to Baghdad to be part of a temporary American-led government there, senior administration officials said today.

title: On a Friday in Baghdad, Shiites Gather for Prayer for First Time in Four Years
description: Thousands of Shiite Muslims, some sobbing with emotion, prostrated themselves in prayer before the largest mosque in the capital's main Shiite neighborhood here today as part of the Shiites' first mass prayer meeting in the city in four years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENACHEM, PEARL HERBERT
description: MENACHEM-Pearl Herbert, 89, of Sunny Isles, Florida, passed away April 24, 2003. Her beloved husband, Louis Menachem and son, Neil Menachem preceded her in death. Pearl is survived by her brother, Marvin Herbert, daughter - in - law, Barbara Menachem, grandchildren, Andrew, Fred, Seth Menachem and Mara MenachemKarlinsky, great-grandchildren, Jackson Menachem and Neil Karlinsky and dear friend and caretaker Wilna DesHommes. Graveside services will be held 11:00 AM Sunday, April 27, 2003 at Knollwood Park Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Runoff Is Likely After Argentines Vote Tomorrow
description: With Argentines preparing to cast ballots for a new president on Sunday, candidates and voters alike are assuming that a runoff will be required, and that former President Carlos Sal Menem will be one of two survivors. As a result, the fierce battle for the second slot has suddenly intensified and become the focus of the campaign.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column on Tuesday about attacks in Afghanistan included an erroneous report from a United States military spokesman about the nationality of one soldier and the cause and nature of his wound. He was an Afghan, not an American Special Forces soldier; he was wounded by brick fragments after a bullet hit a wall, not by a bullet in the thigh.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Chip Makers Have Gains
description: The Toshiba Corporation and Fujitsu Ltd., two of Japan's largest chip makers, said profits grew in the last quarter of Japan's fiscal year, which ended March 31. Toshiba earned 51.9 billion yen ($433 million), while Fujitsu's profits were 50.3 billion yen. The profits resulted partly from thousands of layoffs and factory closings. Toshiba, which concentrates more on chips for consumer-related products, said it expected an upturn this year; Fujitsu, which relies more heavily on the telecommunications industry, was less optimistic. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Wall St. Firms Near Settlement
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission cleared up the final issues today and prepared to announce a settlement on Monday of the long-running investigation of conflicts of interest involving stock analysts at the largest Wall Street firms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLORI, RALPH G.
description: FLORI-Ralph G. On April 24, 2003. Beloved husband of Ann. Loving father of Heidi. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd., Flushing. title: The Monk in the Lab
description: These are times when destructive emotions like anger, fear and hatred are giving rise to devastating problems throughout the world. While the daily news offers grim reminders of the destructive power of such emotions, the question we must ask is this: What can we do, person by person, to overcome them?

title: Neophyte Michigan Squad Wins Medley at Penn Relays
description: Fourteen teams started the men's distance medley in the Penn Relays today, and after two miles or so of the two-and-a-half-mile race they figured to be somewhat separated. Instead, with little more than 600 meters remaining, 11 teams were running in a tight single file, every one with a chance.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Landlord's Profit Falls
description: The Brookfield Properties Corporation, the largest office landlord in Lower Manhattan, said first-quarter earnings fell 37 percent as revenue declined after the company spun off its homebuilding business. The Toronto-based company, which owns most of the World Financial Center, said net income fell to $50 million, or 29 cents a diluted share, from $80 million, or 47 cents a diluted share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue dropped 14 percent, to $295 million. Funds from operations, an earnings measure used by real estate companies that adds back depreciation, rose to $86 million, or 51 cents a diluted share, from $78 million, or 45 cents a diluted.

title: A Path to Arab Democracy
description: It is hard to imagine a more precarious or more promising -- time in the Middle East. Will Iraq become a secular democracy or a new theocracy? Will the change in the Palestinian leadership usher in needed reform and a chance for statehood and peace with Israel, or will the revolving door of violence and enmity continue to spin? The region hangs in the balance. The direction in which it tips will depend on the choices made now by the Arab world, Israel and the United States. All have responsibilities they must assume.

title: Giants Will Be Drafting With 49er Disaster in Mind
description: Almost everyone wearing a uniform, from Trey Junkin to Jason Sehorn to Jeremy Shockey to Matt Allen, had a chance to stop the hemorrhaging when the Giants blew their 24-point lead to the San Francisco 49ers in a Jan. 5 playoff game. One more reception, one more batted pass, one more decent snap, and the 49ers' miracle comeback would have ended.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Growth Slows
description: Preliminary fig ures released by the Office for National Statistics showed that gross domestic product grew by just 0.2 percent in the first quarter of 2003, its weakest pace in a year. In his budget earlier this month, the chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, above, predicted the British economy would grow 2 percent to 2.5 percent this year. The economy was held back by a poor performance from the service sector, particularly at hotels and restaurants. But manufacturing output was estimated to have grown after declines during the previous two years. Economists said the weak growth figures could increase the likelihood of a cut in interest rates at the May meeting of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

title: Manhattan Loop Nears for Bikes; A Dream of Pedal Pushers, Ring Is Patchy but Ridable
description: In its modest way, it has been a quest as irrepressible as sailing a ship around the globe. New York's Magellans on bicycles have long yearned to complete a loop of Manhattan Island. The chief obstacle has always been that Manhattan's shores, unlike those, say, of Paris, were designed for commerce and commuting, and only in a few patches for pleasure.

title: From Minimalism to a Cartoon in Sound
description: The string quartet Ethel played the final installment in its three-concert series at Miller Theater on Thursday evening and brought Miller's season of adventurous programming to a close as well. The series was built around the complete string quartets of John Zorn and Julia Wolfe. That isn't an enormous amount of music -- Ms. Wolfe's three quartets, recently released on CD, take only 35 minutes to play; Mr. Zorn is somewhat more expansive -- so the quartet filled out its programs with works by other composers as well.

title: 'Cos' Slips Smartly Into a World of Torn Jeans
description: Updating the setting of an operatic staple can easily seem a strained attempt by a stumped director to inject a familiar work with contemporary resonance. The British director Jonathan Miller's production of Mozart's ''Cos Fan Tutte,'' which opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Harvey Theater on Thursday night, takes this story of two young military officers in late 18th-century Naples who, on a bet, test the fidelity of their fiances, and zaps it to a chic modern-day loft.

description: SINCLAIR-Mabel (Walling). Age 105 of North Andover, MA, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Widow of James McKenzie Sinclair. Loving mother of Ruth S. (Mrs. Decius B.) title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAZAN, HENRY (HAROUTIUN)
description: KAZAN-Henry (Haroutiun) Sarkis Khanzadian was born in Zara, Armenia on September 9, 1906. He emigrated to the United States in January 1914, with his mother and two sisters (his third sister was born in New York City). He graduated from Eastside Evening High School, New York University and St. John's Law School, all of which he attended at night while working fulltime. He passed the NY State Bar Exam on his first try. He was a proud World War II veteran. He was a tireless salesman and sales manager for Nutone/Scoville; on his retirement in the 1970's he was managing sales for the entire Northeast region. After his retirement, he was active in his condo association at 840 Ocean Drive, Juno Beach, FL, serving on the board and as president. He served similarly in the resident's association of Shinnecock Shores in East Quoque, Long Island, where he was a board member, past president, and building and roads chairman. He and his late wife, M. Victoria Karagozian Kazan, endowed a visiting professorship, a publication and lecture fund, and various other projects of the Armenian Studies Program at California State University at Fresno. He is survived by his sister, Elizabeth Kazanjian, nieces Iris Noorian Kassabian and Iris Desilets, nephew Robert Bear, great nieces Anahid Kassabian and Crystal and Cheryl Bear, great nephew Dikran Kassabian, great-great niece Maral Kassabian Svendsen, greatgreat nephews Stephen, Richard and Michael Kassabian and numerous other friends and family including Harold Aram Veeser, Noble Mitchell and Joe Devon. His courage, vibrancy, generosity and wisdom will be sorely missed by us all. Anoush koun, Harry. A memorial service will be held in NY at a date to be determined. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Armenian Studies Program at California State University Fresno or North Shore Animal Shelter.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: TURBINE MAKER TO CUT JOBS The French engineering company Alstom said it planned to eliminate 3,000 jobs in its power-turbo systems unit, which makes heavy- duty gas turbines, large steam turbines and generators. The cuts represent 27 percent of the unit, which currently employs 11,000 people across Europe. Alstom said that the division was facing a sharp downturn in the gas turbine market, a decrease in orders for steam power plants and a significant market overcapacity. In March, Alstom's market value fell by half in less than a month and it is now struggling with a debt of about 5 billion euros ($5.5 billion).

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Advertiser's Sales Fall
description: The WPP Group, the advertising and marketing giant that owns J. Walter Thompson and Young & Rubicam, said revenue fell to 908.5 million ($1.45 billion) in the first quarter, down from 945.8 million ($1.51 billion) a year earlier. The advertising industry has been going through its worst slump in a decade as the global economic slowdown has caused companies to cut their marketing and promotional budgets. WPP won 410 million ($653 million) of new-business billings in the quarter, gaining major new clients like Coca-Cola, Cisco Systems and Vodafone. However, the group's biggest client, Ford Motor, which accounts for 7 percent of WPP's revenues, said recently that it wanted to reduce its marketing expenses by 20 percent as part of a five-year, $9 billion cost-cutting program. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

title: Ways to Report On a Dictatorship
description: To the Editor:

title: 11th-Hour Union Vote Keeps American Afloat
description: American Airlines backed away from the brink of a bankruptcy filing yesterday after the flight attendants' union agreed to substantial wage and benefit cuts. The agreement came a day after American's former chairman and chief executive, Donald J. Carty, resigned because of stinging criticism over executive benefits.

title: Writing in Schools Is Found Both Dismal and Neglected
description: Most fourth graders spend less than three hours a week writing, which is about 15 percent of the time they spend watching television. Seventy-five percent of high school seniors never get a writing assignment from their history or social studies teachers.

title: Iraqis Struggling to Reclaim A Land Literally Awash in Oil
description: A black, inky spill stretched as far as the eye could see along a desert road here among southern Iraq's oil riches. Ahmed Maki al-Selman, chief operator at a nearby pumping station, stood surveying the damage.

title: Bush Shows Looser Side in an Interview
description: Even when President Bush was in the middle of a meeting during the most critical moments of the war in Iraq, White House staff members would fetch him whenever the black-is-white Iraqi information minister, Muhammed Said al-Sahhaf, appeared on television. Mr. Bush, it turns out, was a big fan.

title: Rapper Is Hurt and 2nd Man Is Slain in Gunfire After Traffic Accident
description: A rising hip-hop artist, Ezekiel Jiles, who performs under the name Freaky Zeeky, was shot early yesterday and a member of his entourage was killed after a traffic accident in Manhattan escalated into gunfire.

title: Homeless to Represent U.S. in Soccer in Austria
description: The soccer team, a set of scruffy, middle-age men with hardened faces, filed into Baruch College's aging sixth-floor gymnasium in Midtown Manhattan.

title: These Drafts Come and Go, and So Do Agents' Fortunes
description: In the movie, the No. 1 pick dumps the title character, the good-guy agent Jerry Maguire, for a sleazy colleague the night before the National Football League draft.

title: If Rogers Isn't Back, at Least He's on His Way
description: Rodney Rogers heard it all season from his friends and teammates. It was the mantra he repeated to himself to fend off doubts and frustration.

title: April 20-26; The Coalition Moves Into a Fixer-Upper
description: WHEN you invade a country, you own it, at least temporarily. Which means you own all its problems, from governance to getting the plumbing working.

title: The Red Cross Faces Its Own Crisis
description: FOR relatives of American soldiers in Iraq, the Westchester chapter of the Red Cross is the telephone operator who locates their sons and daughters and relays their messages home. For the hospitals in the county, it is the main provider of blood. For the victims left homeless by two large fires in Yonkers last month, it was the principal source of food, shelter and cash for necessities. For teenagers taking lifeguard classes across the county, it is the authority that certifies skills, enabling them to work. For Westchester residents anxious about terrorist attacks, it is the school for classes on what to do in an emergency.

title: Pimp Slays Bully
description: STAGOLEE SHOT BILLY

title: Editors' Note; Editors' Note
description: A Sports of The Times column on Feb. 12 discussed college coaches who have spoken out against the death penalty, in particular Dean Smith, former basketball coach at the University of North Carolina.

title: The Rorschach Test
description: Last month, a quartet of academics published ''What's Wrong With the Rorschach?'' -- attacking a test administered to more than a million people worldwide each year. According to recent surveys by the American Psychological Association, 82 percent of its members ''occasionally'' and 43 percent ''frequently'' use the test, in which subjects speculate about five colored and five black-and-white inkblots. Test-givers in turn interpret the answers to diagnose mental illness, predict violent behavior and reveal suppressed trauma. Their conclusions are applied to everything from child-custody disputes to parole reviews. According to James M. Wood, an associate professor of psychology at the University of Texas at El Paso and one author of the book, tarot cards would work almost as well.

title: Streetscapes/The Architecture of Delano & Aldrich; How an Upper-Class Firm Tweaked Classical Norms
description: DELANO & ALDRICH were among New York's most sophisticated architects, with clients like the Knickerbocker, Colony and Union Clubs to prove it. A new monograph on the firm, ''The Architecture of Delano & Aldrich,'' by Peter Pennoyer and Anne Walker (Norton, 2003) gives the outsider a look inside the town houses, clubs and other buildings that staked out a reputation the architects enjoy to this day -- and also the insouciant touches that distinguish it from the typical upper-class architectural firm.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Bohemia Company Bought For $303 Million

title: Decorating a Shelter With a Sense of Humanity
description: To see Patricio Hurtado traipsing around flea markets in Connecticut or furniture warehouses in the Bronx, you might think he is just an eccentric collector with an eye for bargains. But Mr. Hurtado's mission is different: he is out to decorate among that most historically undecorated of places, the city homeless shelter.

title: Four Mexico City Restaurants That Stay Close to Their Roots
description: LIKE those of too many other cities, a number of Mexico City restaurants have turned to international cuisine; in white-tablecloth establishments, it is easier to find bad pasta than good tamales. There is no dearth of fabulous taqueras, but when it comes to good sit-down restaurants where the food has a sense of place, Mexico City is still struggling. There are some timid Italian and almost laughably old-fashioned French offerings, and new restaurant ''scenes,'' where food is an afterthought.

title: Some Pain-Free Ways to Balance the Budget
description: YOU have seen this phenomenon if you have ever been in a room with a baby whose diaper badly needed changing, or in a car whose tire went flat, or in a kitchen with a clogged garbage disposal. Everyone in the room or car knows there is a problem. Everyone even has ideas on what should be done about it. But nobody wants to do the job.

title: Investing; Before Selling, Watch Out for Those Fund Exit Fees
description: AS more investors reached their pain thresholds last year and cashed out their fund holdings, the amounts paid in exit fees to many top funds exceeded the amounts paid in entrance fees on other types of the funds' shares.

title: The Flight Of the Fluttering Swallows
description: In September, a North Korean boy named Heo joined a group of seven other refugees in China -- most of whom had left their homeland by crossing the Tumen River -- and boarded a southbound train from Jilin Province to Beijing. The North Koreans carried no luggage. With each passing stop and hour, they remained in their seats, increasingly fidgety and nervous. Once at the station in Beijing, they summoned a taxi and piled in. What lay before them was either freedom or long prison terms, which, they knew, would most likely include torture and extreme privation.

title: Commute to Nowhere
description: In 2001, I was ''early retired'' from General Motors. It was not my choice, and the financial penalty was high. I left expecting to find another job easily. I used all the search techniques in your article. Here are some things I discovered while not finding a job:

title: Agassi Becomes Oldest to Be No. 1
description: Andre Agassi became the oldest men's player to be ranked No. 1 in the world as he advanced to the final of the United States Men's Clay Court Championships last night with a 6-4, 6-1 victory over Jurgen Melzer of Austria in Houston.

title: A Muddled Electoral Field for Weary Argentines to Cross
description: Argentines, battered by the worst economic crisis in their country's history, complaining of a lack of capable leadership and badly divided along class and regional lines, will trudge to the polls on Sunday to elect a new president, their sixth in little more than a year.

title: Saddam Hussein Stole His Goddess of Spring
description: IS there some secret connection between new-age goddesses and dictators?

title: Deals and Discounts
description: NEW YORK FOR LESS As part of the InterContinental hotel chain's World Half Off program, it is offering 50 percent weekend discounts (Friday through Sunday nights) at its two Manhattan hotels. At the 686-room InterContinental The Barclay, 48th Street off Park Avenue, doubles on weekends start at $199 a night, with breakfast for two, through Sept. 21. Call (212) 755-5900. The InterContinental Central Park South has weekend rates of $259 through June 26, $225 from June 27 to Sept. 3, and $259 Sept. 4 to 21. Call (212) 757-1900. Both hotels are online at www.new-york.intercontinental.com. Reservations must be made at least a week ahead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPSOUTO, EVA
description: CAPSOUTO - Eva. Born Rousso in 1919, Izmir, Turkey. Died April 17th, first day of Passover. Matriarch of Capsouto Freres Restaurant in Tribeca. Wife of Marco. Survived by her sons, Jacques, Sami and Albert, daughter-inlaw, three grandchildren, sister, nephews, nieces, and their offspring. She will be dearly missed and her spirit will be remembered by many. Donations in her name can be made to: NYU Downtown Hospital, C/O Ms. Zichy, 170 William St., NY, NY 10038. Info: www.evacapfouto.org

title: Arizona Playing Catch-Up Because of Two Key Injuries
description: People searching for smoke and candor around the Arizona Diamondbacks should park themselves by Mark Grace's locker, toss out one question and listen. Between tugs on a cigarette Tuesday at Olympic Stadium in Montreal, Grace gave an honest analysis of a disappointing team. His words were so captivating that they almost made the smoke go unnoticed. Almost.

title: D-Day Memorial Is Clouded By Scandal, Debt and Doubts
description: On a clear day, the polished granite arch of the National D-Day Memorial here perfectly frames the view of this small city in the distance.

title: Sweet and Sour Pep Talk for Colombians
description: PART civics lesson. Part group therapy. Part game show. That was what 150 Colombians got at the Natives Theater in Jackson Heights, Queens, last Monday. Being Colombian in New York is not easy: family is far away, and American co-workers joke about drug trafficking, guerrillas and kidnappings. Sometimes, all that gloom sinks in.

title: Focusing One Hospital's Resources on One Disease
description: From a distance, the bright covered tent in the parking lot of Tan Tock Seng Hospital looks oddly joyful, like it could be housing a wedding. But a closer look shows powerful fans, X-ray machines tucked in a corner, and faces that exude worry -- at least what you can see of them, since everyone is masked.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: BY THE LAKE, by John McGahern. (Vintage International, $14.) In his sixth novel in a 40-year career, the Irish writer follows a year in the life of an unnamed village in County Leitrim, a place where hay is cut, lambs are born, fattened and sold at market and where the biggest event of the entire year is the arrival of a telephone pole. The narrative, which revolves around a couple in their 60's who return to the community, is ''initially demanding but ultimately rewarding,'' John Sutherland said here last year. McGahern ''ranks with the greatest Irish writers: Joyce, Yeats, Synge, Beckett, Heaney.''

title: Private Sector; Out-of-Town Help for New York City
description: While the WPP Group owns Madison Avenue icons like J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather, its chief executive, Sir Martin Sorrell, is not well known in New York. He is not even a resident, preferring his home in London and his villa in France.

title: Turning the Tide On Executive Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Shares of Corporate Nice Guys Can Finish First
description: STUPEFYING, is it not, how selfish behavior in the executive suite continues even as managers claim to care deeply about corporate governance issues? The ham-handed attempt by Donald J. Carty, the just-defenestrated chief of the AMR Corporation, to hide special executive pay perks while he cut workers' pay is only the latest indication that some powerful people still think the do-as-I-say, not-as-I-do approach is acceptable.

title: Bomb
description: Charles McGrath depicts the TV coverage of the war as confusing, repetitive, boring (The Way We Live Now, April 13). On the contrary, I felt that it was the ultimate reality show. Watching the embedded reporters, I could almost feel the sand in my face as the bullets flew. I jumped every time a shot rang out. As to the confusion, even some troops were confused and took a wrong turn into an ambush. Others were lost to friendly fire. I had to hold back the tears.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: A New Casino Is Coming. For Atlantic City, Is This Winner Take All?
description: The opening of the first new casino here in 13 years would be a big event even if the owner of the $1.1 billion Borgata Hotel, Casino and Spa wasn't heralding its debut this July by trashing the opposition.

title: Fill 'Er Up
description: FIFTEEN FOX PLACE doesn't serve liquor (except for a welcome nip of limoncello at the end of a long, long meal), but there is a delicious touch of the speakeasy about it -- a sense that only those who know the password can gain admission.

title: Letters
description: 'The Crisis of Islam'

title: History and Views at a Table by the River
description: IT'S easy to imagine the Olde Stone Mill in its original commission: taking up the waters of the Bronx River to power manufacturing. For the last 30 years, the building has stood derelict, but after a major renovation, including a wooden addition to the main structure, the mill is now ready to receive guests in its attractive dining rooms.

title: Introduction
description: Our article on out-of-work executives and their search for new jobs hit home, prompting a deluge of mail. Many readers identified with the white-collar unemployed, calling their plight gut-wrenching.

title: Sports of The Times; Remembering The Ultimate N.F.L. Draftnik
description: WHEN the phone rang in the office of Ernie Accorsi, the Giants' general manager, shortly before last year's National Football League draft was about to begin, the caller didn't need to identify himself.

title: Jobless and Hopeless, Many Quit the Labor Force
description: Worn down by job searches that have stretched on for months, demoralized by disappointing offers or outright rejections, some unemployed people have simply stopped the search.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Token Resistance

title: PLEA IN POLICE GROUP FRAUD
description: Frank Ginesi, 80, a former president of the New Jersey State Policemen's Benevolent Association, became the third former official of the group to admit to a scheme that federal investigators said defrauded the association of $1 million. He faces up to 10 years in prison. An indictment said that he and others siphoned money from dues paid by the association's 35,000 members, from premium payments into a voluntary insurance fund and from convention fees charged to members. Investigators said Mr. Ginesi and the others funneled the money into personal accounts and used much of it to buy real estate, jewelry and cars. Ronald Smothers

title: Court Expansion Takes Step Forward
description: The long-awaited expansion of State Supreme Court in Riverhead, stalled last year by a financing dispute between the Suffolk County executive, Robert Gaffney, and the County Legislature, is now back on track toward an autumn groundbreaking. The legislature is expected to approve the project, which would add eight courtrooms to the Griffing Avenue complex, as early as May 13.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANNON, ELIZABETH
description: GANNON - Elizabeth. Of Lloyd Harbor, NY, and Jensen Beach, FL, suddenly on April 24, 2003. Beloved wife of Jerome, devoted mother of Gregory, Michael, Diane Bertolina and Leigh Avella. Adored grandmother of Derek, Sean, Taylor, Jordan, Dillon, Bryan, Meghan, Anthony, Curtis, Brooke, Elizabeth, Nicolas and Christopher. Dear sister of Edward and Fred Ressel. Visitation Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave, Huntington Station. Mass Thursday, 9:45 AM, at St. Patrick's Church, Huntington. In lieu of flowers, donations in Elizabeth's memory to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation, Suite 1209, 654 Madison Ave, New York, NY 10021, are appreciated.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Whose Sidewalk Is It, Anyway?
description: ONE evening last summer, while walking our puppy Lilah down the street in Larchmont, a huge S.U.V. careered out of the darkness. I jumped out of the way, dragging Lilah after me -- a narrow escape. Come to your senses, I said to myself, get up on the sidewalk! So I did. But it was terribly overgrown, with overhanging bushes and low tree limbs. Within a block I found myself back in the street.

title: Executive Life; His Quest: A Safe (and Efficient) Airport
description: TAKING on the responsibility for security at one of the nation's largest airports does not necessarily mean talking daily with Tom Ridge, deciding when to call in the National Guard to patrol the concourses or even having an office with a view of airplanes landing.

title: Can a Smile Bridge The Divide?
description: SUSAN FALES-HILL'S life is as deceptively glamorous as Ms. Fales-Hill herself is beautiful. Married to a banker, she lives on Park Avenue, gives generously of her time to several worthy causes and has a portrait of a proper Boston ancestor on her wall to prove that she could, if asked, be a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution.
