description: Americans are increasingly worried about identity theft, a survey conducted this month for Star Systems, a unit of Concord EFS Inc. , has found.

title: Sports of The Times; With Baker as Manager, Difference in Cubs Is Like Night and Day
description: THE Cubs have gotten off to a rollicking and not wholly unexpected start this season in their annual, seemingly quixotic quest to end their 94-year drought as world champions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, HARRY S.
description: ADLER-Harry S., 92. Public accountant. Beloved husband of Mary. Cherished father of Marlene T. (Harvey) Birch and Michael L. (Joan) Adler. Devoted grandfather of three and great-grandfather of four and dear uncle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, DELORES (NEE ZIMMERMAN)
description: MANDEL-Delores (nee Zimmerman), age 73, formerly of Freeport, NY, died April 25th in Tamarac, FL surrounded by her family. She will be greatly missed by Daniel, her devoted husband of 52 years. Much loved mother of Matt, Amy (Karen) and Jodi (Chris), and adored Nana of Mollie and Anna. Loving sister of Sylvia Eisner and sister-in-law of Harold Eisner.

description: Weeks

title: Every Government's Mandate
description: More than 3,000 years ago, from his compound on the banks of the Nile, Ramses II issued an order that modern-day governors and mayors will find depressingly familiar. ''Ye shall no more give the people straw to make brick, as heretofore,'' the pharaoh commanded. ''Let them go and gather straw for themselves.'' But they still had to produce the same number of bricks.

The Rev. Charles Sweeting performed the ceremony at the Wesleyan Methodist Church on Harbour Island in the Bahamas.

description: LOOKS are not, technically speaking, everything.

title: Private Sector; Product Placement of the Year Award?
description: The threat of terrorism, the weak economy and the specter of SARS may have stimulated the teleconferencing business as much as they have hurt the airlines. But not many teleconferencing companies get a boost like the one that Wire One Technologies is hoping for this weekend, when ESPN uses its service on its two-day broadcast of the National Football League draft.

title: The Master of Fake Masterpieces
description: THE painting, ''Aprs le Bain,'' is clearly a Renoir; a rosy-cheeked, plump woman kneels by a pond, her eyes gracefully downcast as she dries herself with a cloth. In the lower right corner is Renoir's signature. The price tag: $2,800.

title: Italian Place Requires a Hefty Appetite
description: DINO'S is calm and civilized on weekdays, raucous and rough edged on weekends. Although its atmosphere offers two different experiences, there are some constants. Among them are consistently tasty Italian food, gargantuan portions, pennywise prices and obliging, though inexperienced, waitresses.

title: Commercial Property/Westchester; A Grand View, and Metro-North Too
description: THE view from the Hudson River waterside here is expansive, with the Palisades visible across the broad stretch of water and the scene bracketed by the Tappan Zee and George Washington bridges.

description: They kept pressing through the narrow checkpoints today, long lines of Greek and Turkish Cypriots, on foot, by car, on motorbikes, winding past the watchtowers and the barbed wire that had kept them apart for nearly 30 years.

title: Dressed Up Amid Disorder, Unarmed Officers Stand Idle
description: Warrant Officer Muhammad Shaqeer Abdul Razzaq, his black police beret in one hand and an ornately carved walking stick in the other, did not flinch at the crack of a dozen gunshots half a block away from the Althamiya Police Station, where he has worked for 30 years.

description: SHELBY FOOTE

title: Preaching Self-Reliance From Atop the Podium
description: HE doesn't eat crabs (or any seafood, for that matter). And he couldn't tell you the score of the last Orioles game or the title of a John Waters movie. Yet the Russian conductor Yuri Temirkanov is fitting almost as snugly into the Baltimore scene as the formstone on row houses.

title: Leaving Elementary School at 48
description: MOST children anticipate the last day of school like a convict counting down to a parole date. This June, when that magical buzzer sends kids screaming into the humid summertime, my children will join in the glee, but I expect to be filled with emptiness.

title: AIRLINE HEAD RESIGNS
description: Donald J. Carty resigned after five years as chairman and chief executive of American Airlines, which continues to struggle to avoid a bankruptcy filing. Mr. Carty, 58, had been criticized for his handling of negotiations with the airline's unions over wage and benefit concessions.

title: A Unique Masters
description: To the Sports Editor:

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Dishes From the Deep
description: New York has no shortage of seafood restaurants, and they reflect the city's diversity.

title: Somers Star Set to Try Pentathlon
description: THE Loucks Games at White Plains High is the largest track meet held at a United States high school. The 36th edition, on May 9 and 10, is bigger than ever.

title: Lions Weigh Options And Then Plunge In
description: Draft day for the Detroit Lions was centered in a room filled with seven huge boards here at the team's new-age complex. One board ranked all the potential draftees' abilities, another listed the team's view of the top 300 players, another the players who intrigued the Lions despite their medical or character issues, another each team's draft choices, another the Lions' current depth chart and needs, and one each for the American Football Conference and the National Football Conference listing rosters as reference for possible trades.

title: Georgia Lawmakers Drop Rebel Cross From the Flag
description: Ending, for now, a battle over symbols of history and hate that threatened to bring racial animosity back to the forefront of Georgia politics, the General Assembly late Friday adopted a new state flag that does not include the Confederate battle emblem.

title: Film; How Hilary Duff Made Off With Your Daughter
description: IN the recent Hollywood issue of Vanity Fair, 15-year-old Hilary Duff was aptly named ''The Tween Queen'' for her virtual domination and definition of cool for kids in the ''in-between'' years -- those roughly 9-to-13-year-olds with major purchasing power who are too grown up for cartoons but not quite ready for ''Gilmore Girls.'' As the star of the Disney Channel series ''Lizzie McGuire'' (also on ABC on Saturday mornings), Ms. Duff has found herself at the helm of a burgeoning franchise that includes record contracts, a clothing line, home accessories, dolls and a successful line of books. She's about to star in ''The Lizzie McGuire Movie'' (opening Friday), and she's just enjoyed a bit of Hollywood fame in the hit kiddie-spy flick ''Agent Cody Banks.''

title: All Scrubbed Up and Nowhere to Go
description: I am a pediatrician in a large teaching hospital in Toronto, and I miss my patients. In a city that has reported about 200 cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, and 19 SARS-related deaths over the last month, you'd think I'd be busier than ever. But in an effort to minimize exposure to the disease, many doctors have been kept from doing their jobs, reducing hospitals to caring only for the most severely ill.

title: Susanna Woodbury, James Newsom
description: Susanna Munroe Woodbury, a daughter of Candace and David Woodbury of New Boston, N.H., was married there last evening to James Harlan Newsom, a son of Dr. John Newsom and Dr. Carolyn Newsom of Yardley, Pa. The Rev. Robert Woodland, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the New Boston Community Church.

description: To the Editor:

title: New Rules May Drive Push to Privatize . . .
description: Have tougher corporate governance rules made public ownership less attractive for companies?

title: Purposeful Exploration
description: I USED to sell advertising and syndicated programming to different stations in pretty remote places, like Pittsburg, Kan. I'd call on a TV station and hear kids in the lobby whisper, ''It's Connie Chung!'' So I waved at them. Why ruin their fantasy?

title: How One Artist Filled In the 'Holes' Known as New Jersey
description: ROBERT SMITHSON is best known and revered as an artist of the American West. His roots, however, both artistically and personally, are deep in New Jersey.

title: The New Face of France's Far Right
description: Marine Le Pen looks, sounds and thinks so much like her father that when she was a child, her mother called her ''the Clone,'' a nickname that sticks to this day.

title: A Suite And the City: Eloise's New York
description: I NEVER saw New York in the 50's. Not in person. But I know it was a grand place, with smiling doormen, clean subways and lovable taxi drivers, a city of postwar confidence and prewar manners. Women wore gloves and hats to the office. New Yorkers never worked late, leaving by 5 o'clock to go out and drink pretty cocktails and smoke cigarettes (yet never get drunk or develop emphysema). And there were elegant hotels with presidential suites, revolving doors and room service.

title: Anand's Positional Precision Leads to a Blindfold Victory
description: When can two second places total to an overall first prize? Answer: in the 12th annual Melody Amber Blindfold/Rapid Tournament at the Vista Palace Hotel in Roquebrune Cap-Martin, Monaco, March 15th to 27th.

title: Defense Chief Begins a Visit To Review Mideast Stability
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld today began a trip that officials said was intended to take him to Afghanistan, Iraq and other Persian Gulf countries to review America's military and postwar reconstruction commitments.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is what we see today -- job searches that can take 6 to 12 months. By six months, people really start to doubt themselves, and they start to doubt they're ever going to find anything.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANCHEZ, EMIL M.
description: SANCHEZ-Emil M. Attorney. It is with deep sadness that the family of Emil M. Sanchez shares with friends the news of his death on April 26, 2003. Beloved father and distinguished member of the legal community. He will be greatly missed. Services will be held at Leo F. Kearns, Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park, NY, Monday, 2-4 and 8-10 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUGUSTINE, ROSE L.
description: AUGUSTINE-Rose L. Drisha Institute for Jewish Education mourns the passing of our founding donor, Rose L. Augustine. Her generosity and vision has made it possible for thousands of women to enrich their lives and the lives of others. May her memory be a blessing. Rabbi David S. Silber, Founder and Dean Daniela Weiss Executive Director

title: In North Hempstead, a Vote About Voting
description: CONTENDING that his community of Roslyn Heights ''seems to be forgotten or dumped on,'' Chris Cavaliere told members of a commission that studied government reform in North Hempstead Town that the system of electing council members needs to be changed.

title: Suffolk Patient's Death Leads to a Probe
description: EAST HAMPTON and Suffolk County leaders, already fuming over the County Health Department's staff shortages and curtailed services, are demanding an investigation to see if an East Hampton man's death from a heart attack could have been averted if a county clinic had not turned him away just three days before he was stricken.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELLEN, SUSAN (MAIER)
description: MELLEN - Susan (Maier), age 57. Beloved wife and soul mate of Seymour Mellen. Adored and cherished mother of Richard Phillips. Devoted daughter of Antoinette Maier and the late Ernest (Tex) Maier. Fought bravely and taken too soon. Funeral private.

title: DeAnne Dixson, Joseph Geoghan III
description: Krysten DeAnne Dixson, the daughter of Jodie Anne Dixson of Scottsdale, Ariz., and Thomas B. Dixson of Blowing Rock, N.C., was married yesterday to Joseph E. Geoghan III, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Geoghan of Hampton Bays, N.Y. The Rev. Avelino Balatucan performed the ceremony at Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church on Harbour Island, the Bahamas.

title: Mandee Heller, Jason Adler
description: Mandee Jo Heller, a daughter of Beverly and David Heller of Miami Beach, was married there last evening to Dr. Jason Lawrence Adler, a son of Barbara Adler and Dr. Lawrence Adler of Pittsburgh. Cantor David Muchnick officiated at Temple Emanu-El of Greater Miami.

title: 'The People's Firehouse' Faces Another Fierce Battle of Wills
description: When the city announced plans this month to close eight firehouses, many New Yorkers were angered. But for neighbors of one firehouse in Williamsburg, the news was a wrenching flashback to a battle they thought they had won years ago.

title: Beijing Hurries to Build Hospital Complex For Increasing Number of SARS Patients
description: As the number of reported SARS infections rose sharply today here in China's capital, a small army of construction workers rushed to erect a sprawling hospital complex in the northern suburbs that will soon house at least a thousand people who have the highly infectious respiratory illness.

title: And Now: 'Operation Iraqi Looting'
description: LET it never be said that our government doesn't give a damn about culture. It was on April 10, the same day the sacking of the National Museum in Baghdad began, that a subtitled George W. Bush went on TV to tell the Iraqi people that they are ''the heirs of a great civilization that contributes to all humanity.'' And so what if America stood idly by while much of the heritage of that civilization -- its artifacts, its artistic treasures, its literary riches and written records -- was being destroyed as he spoke? It's not as if we weren't bringing in some culture of our own to fill that unfortunate vacuum. It was on April 10 as well, by happy coincidence, that the United States announced the imminent arrival of nightly newscasts from Dan Rather, Jim Lehrer and Brit Hume on newly liberated Iraqi TV. Better still, the White House let it be known, again on that same day, that it was seeking $62 million from Congress for a 24-hour Middle East Television Network that would pipe in dubbed versions of prime-time network programming.

title: An Unlikely Hit, Steeped in Gloom, Has Legs
description: It wasn't a total shock. There had already been inexplicable booms in Gregorian chant and mystical Minimalism. Still, the success of ''Mormimur,'' a 2001 recording from ECM and a runaway seller by classical standards (almost 100,000 copies to date), came as a surprise. Now, on Saturday evening, the album's performers -- Christoph Poppen, a violinist, and the Hilliard Ensemble -- bring the concept to life at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola on Park Avenue.

title: Prague Dining
description: To the Editor: In response to Richard Epro's request for restaurants offering native cuisine in "Dining in Prague" (Letters on Travel, March 30):

title: Commute to Nowhere
description: Near the conclusion of the article, I learned that Tom Pyle and Lou Casagrande were contemplating teaching as a kind of career default. Perhaps with a degree, Jeff Einstein, too, would consider this. ''I suppose I can always teach'' is a familiar refrain. Teaching is a demanding profession. I wish them well.

title: Private Sector; Once Eponymous, Now Anonymous
description: Martha Stewart has been relatively reclusive since the Securities and Exchange Commission said it was investigating the possibility that she used insider information when she sold shares in ImClone Systems, the company run by her erstwhile friend Sam Waksal. title: Goodbye 'Fountainhead,' Hello Kibbutz
description: AT the end of February, when Studio Daniel Libeskind was named winner of the design study on the future of the World Trade Center site, it was only the latest sign of the degree to which celebrity has come to dominate high-profile architectural practice. Mr. Libeskind prepared his scheme with the help of a 27-member architectural staff, not to mention engineers, photographers, landscape designers and a ''slurry wall consultant.'' To judge from the way he and the press have treated his design, though, he might as well have created it by himself, working in the sort of cloistered isolation we associate with painters and novelists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLEY, KEVIN PATRICK

Devoted father of Mary, Kevin, Peter, Kathleen and Timothy. Cherished grandfather of ten. Graduate of Notre Dame University and retired vice-president of Wrangler Kids. title: A Trust That Shields More of An Estate
description: IN one word, my third-grade teacher was able to sum up the man I would become. In a parent-teacher conference, she told my parents that I was lazy. (From what I've been told, my parents didn't protest; they already knew.)

title: The I.R.S. Goes After the Poor
description: The Internal Revenue Service is planning to impose oppressive new documentation requirements on taxpayers applying for the earned-income tax credit, which for more than a quarter-century has been an important source of income for the working poor. Notwithstanding the agency's claim that the requirements are necessary to prevent fraud, the new policy is deeply flawed. It is unfair, particularly in view of the fact that the I.R.S. is devoting diminishing resources to tax cheating by corporations and the wealthy. And it is so burdensome it will drive many poor taxpayers to give up a tax break they are legally entitled to take.

title: Where Dinosaurs Roamed: It Wasn't the Food That Killed Them
description: IF the dinosaurs that roamed Connecticut 200 million years ago were to make a comeback, they could do worse than to move to Rocky Hill. Here, at Dinosaur State Park -- renowned for its ancient tracks of the extinct species -- an ''arboretum of evolution'' has taken shape in front of the signature geodesic dome. The more than 400 species contained in this 10-acre arboretum are as close as possible to those that flourished in New England during the Jurassic, Triassic and Cretaceous periods.

title: In How Many Languages Can Lucia Go Mad?
description: THE old argument about opera in the original versus opera in the language of the audience has long been settled in favor of the original, notwithstanding a few holdouts like the struggling English National Opera. The main reasons are the desire of singers to stick with the original language as they jet around the globe and the advent of titles, beloved by all but a few grumps.

title: Snapple King's N.Y.C. Town House
description: Jack Belsito, 42, the president of Snapple Beverage Group, could avoid a commute by living in White Plains, where the company's headquarters are located. But he'd rather live in Manhattan. ''I think it's a great place to raise children,'' says Belsito, who has a son and twin daughters. ''White Plains is a sort of small town, relatively vibrant, a nice place to work. But it's not a place for us to live.'' In 2000, the Belsitos moved from an apartment to this four-story, 5,000-square-foot town house on the Upper West Side because they wanted more space and a backyard. ''The only places we looked at had balconies or some yard,'' he says. ''We use ours a lot. I grilled steaks out there on Sunday.'' Belsito works long days -- he recently also took the helm at Mott's, a company that, like Snapple, is a division of Cadbury Schweppes -- and rarely eats dinner with the family during the week. ''So we try to eat together on the weekends,'' he says. ''We make a big effort on Sundays.''

title: The World; The Enemy of My Enemy, but Not My Friend
description: THE point seemed as plain as flat feet in those first, stumbling days of the invasion, when Iraqi paramilitaries with nothing more than rifles and AK-47's turned back a missile-armed brigade of Apache helicopters, and guerrillas staged raids on the lumbering supply convoys of the American forces.

title: That's Amore
description: On a summer night last year, I was threading my way with a friend along the two-block stretch of Mulberry Street between Grand and Canal, past those sidewalk restaurant tables to which unwary tourists are still lured by disingenuous guidebooks promoting the charms of Little Italy, as if the children of the old immigrants had not abandoned these narrow streets years ago. Today, little is left of the once vivid neighborhood except the traditional Italian food stores along Grand Street and the restaurants, souvenir shops, espresso bars and a few stranded old-timers on Mulberry.

description: THERE was something in the way she danced.

title: 'Last Man Out'
description: In the town of Springhill, Nova Scotia, in 1958, coal-mining men dropped through the crust of the earth to a few of the deepest roads on the planet. All day and all night they chiseled toward the earth's core, carving an architecture like the downward-coiling tunnels of a child's plastic ant farm. In helmets, coveralls, and pit boots, they shuffled along pebbly paths a vertical mile underground, to the sound of infernal dripping. At that distance above ground, planes crossed the clouds.

title: An Accessory Over Ice

And the presence of the Silver King on the menu at WD-50, Wylie Dufresne's new restaurant on Clinton Street on the Lower East Side, is perfectly appropriate. The drink, a version of a gin fizz, is an unofficial host to the low-riding hip hospitality of Mr. Dufresne's haute cuisine establishment.

The ruling by Mayor Edward Tyler . . . has drawn condemnation worldwide from supporters of America's troops in Iraq, who believe -- like the mayor's opponents here -- that Mr. Tyler is behaving a bit like, well, a certain Iraqi dictator.'' -- News report, April 3.

title: NEW DRIVERS' LICENSES
description: New Jersey drivers' licenses, known as the easiest outside Alaska to counterfeit, will be replaced starting in late July with a digital model that state officials say will be among the most tamper-proof anywhere. Governor McGreevey announced plans for the new design last week, promising that the phase-in could be handled at offices of the Division of Motor Vehicles. The licenses are to have an array of security features, like holograms, a bar code and digital signatures. The state has no timetable yet for replacing the licenses, and officials have not decided how many licenses will be replaced before they expire. The new system will raise the license fee to $24, from $18. Laura Mansnerus

Apartment prices will be from about $600,000 to $4.5 million.

title: ROWAN TO EXPAND
description: Rowan University said last week that it would build a satellite campus in Camden with the hopes of doubling its enrollment, to 1,000 students. The university, which now shares space with Camden County College, will use $5 million in state funds and $5 million of its own money for the 50,000-square-foot building on Cooper Street. The project is part of a $175 million state plan to revitalize the city and is expected to be completed by 2005. Michael J. Grabell

title: Jay-Z Sweet-Talks a Punjabi Beat
description: PANJABI MC FEATURING JAY-Z: 'BEWARE OF THE BOYS (JAY-Z REMIX)' (Sequence) A few months ago, this song was a surprise hit single in Europe. It was called ''Mundian to Bach Ke,'' and it mixed bhangra with a sample from the ''Knight Rider'' theme and a loping hip-hop beat, while a guy from Coventry delivered a sermon (sung in Punjabi, naturally) on female modesty. This new remix adds a couple of deft verses by Jay-Z, who never met a beat he couldn't sweet-talk. He's in a cosmopolitan mood, segueing from hotel-room boasting to anti-war rabble-rousing: ''Checking in daily, under aliases/ We rebellious/ We back home/Screaming, 'Leave Iraq alone.' ''

The doctors' offices here are filled not with the sterile stuff of most medical suites, but with fragments of a wide world: an intricate mandala of blue Buddhas, masks from Senegal, a Bedouin traveler carved in stone and sand. A sign reads: ''Adversity introduces a man to himself.''

title: Making a Clean Sweep Through the Garden
description: IT was 80 degrees two weeks ago when I set out to prune the trees, shrubs and vines I should have pruned in February and early March. (Blizzards, downpours and near-zero temperatures did not inspire brisk mornings pruning the pear tree.) But now that old tree, as well as two young Asian pears, are in full bloom. So it's too late to prune them, other than removing deadwood and suckers. There is still plenty to prune, of course, like the winter jasmine that has just finished blooming. And in a few weeks, other spring bloomers, like forsythia, lilacs and mock oranges, will be ready for an overhaul. All of them are overgrown and in need of hard pruning from the very base of the plants.

description: MILNER - Dorothy Soule. Died at her home at Essex Meadows, Essex, CT on April 24, 2003 after a courageous bout with cancer. She was 87 years old. Mrs. Milner was born and raised in Syracuse, New York, the daughter of Oscar Frank and Dorothy Soule. She graduated from Westover School, Middlebury, CT and attended Syracuse University of Fine Arts. In 1937 she married the late Benjamin C. Milner III, who prior to his death in 1972 was a partner in the New York law firm of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett. Mrs. Milner was a founding member of the Junior League of the North Shore, Long Island, and was active in a variety of organizations including the Lighthouse for the Blind and the Mattinecock (L.I.) Garden Club. She also served as the Chairman of the Board of Governors at Westover School. At the time of her death she was a member of the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, CT. Mrs. Milner is survived by her three children, Dorothy Pease of New Canaan, CT; Lillian Smyser of Chagrin Falls, OH; B. title: 'Family History'
description: Ilie in bed these days and watch home movies-a useless exercise, to be sure, but I can't stop myself. Ned's an amateur filmmaker, and ever since we got our first video camera when Kate was born, he has documented our family's life, not just birthday parties and anniversaries but smaller, more telling moments. When I appear in these tapes, I'm usually laughing and covering my face, saying No, no, I look terrible. Ned is almost always behind the camera. Kate, Kate, Katie, his deep voice cajoles, come here, baby doll. And then, after Kate as a baby, a toddler, a blurry little blond girl, she begins to become sharper and clearer, her features morphing themselves into a face of such extraordinary beauty that sometimes I felt shocked to realize she was my daughter.

title: Brel and Belgium
description: To the Editor: I was somewhat amused by Corinne LaBalme's characterization of Jacques Brel as a ''favorite son'' of Brussels in ''What's Doing in Brussels'' (April 13). I imagine Brel would have been amused as well.

title: COMING UP
description: On Monday, President Bush will travel to Dearborn, Mich., to speak with a group of Arab Americans about his vision for a liberated Iraq. On Thursday, Mr. Bush will travel to San Diego to speak with sailors aboard the aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln, which is returning from combat missions in the Persian Gulf. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell will testify Tuesday before a Senate committee about the future of NATO and its role in Iraq. He also plans to travel to the Middle East on Thursday.

title: Limn's Troupe Now Bears Her Signature
description: AMERICAN modern dance was born and grew up to the sound of rolling thunder. Or so it seems, looking back on a mere three decades or so of revolutionary dance made in the heyday of that new art by women and men with larger-than-life personalities. Today, however, many of them have receded into the shadows. Choreography by Ruth St. Denis, Ted Shawn and Doris Humphrey is seldom performed. The ownership of Martha Graham's dances was bitterly contested in a recent battle. But the Limn Dance Company soldiers on, surviving the death of Jos Limn in 1972 and persisting in the face of changing fashions and economies.

title: A Crunchy Menu For a Youthful Crowd
description: THE invitation was explicit: ''Barefoot formal -- evening gowns, jewelry and no shoes!'' And so, on a recent rainy Friday night, 12 girls from St. Ann's, a private school in Brooklyn, pulled on their raincoats and headed over to the home of their friend Lena Dunham on College Place in Brooklyn Heights, where they left shoes and socks in puddles in the foyer.

title: From China's Provinces, a Crafty Germ Breaks Out
description: An hour south of Guangzhou, the Dongyuan animal market presents endless opportunities for an emerging germ. In hundreds of cramped stalls that stink of blood and guts, wholesale food vendors tend to veritable zoos that will grace Guangdong Province's tables: snakes, chickens, cats, turtles, badgers, frogs. And, in summer, sometimes rats, too.

title: April 20-26; The Battle Lines Start in Washington
description: IN the annals of famous ''Don't Invite 'Em's'' -- people feuding so hotly that you would never want them together at your small dinner party -- American secretaries of state and defense have always been especially prickly pairs.

description: SAMURAI WILLIAM

title: When a TV Network Could Be Cynical About War
description: All wars are popular for the first 30 days,'' wrote the historian Arthur Schlesinger Jr. By the time ''M*A*S*H'' hit the airwaves in 1972, the year the last American ground troops left Vietnam, that deadline had long expired. An antiwar sitcom that blossomed during wartime, ''M*A*S*H'' ran for 11 years, and it was explicitly intended as a commentary on Vietnam. But the show's setting was the Korean War of the 1950's, a chronological remove that gave the show's creators a perverse freedom, as well as a stamp of universality. To watch it now is to gaze back at an era of angry skepticism, personified by the prankster antihero Hawkeye Pierce (Alan Alda). In the bleak universe of ''M*A*S*H,'' spokespeople are liars, generals are bullies and anyone who mouths patriotic slogans is a dupe or a hypocrite. ''By the time we waded in, by the time we came on the air, people really wanted to get the hell out of Vietnam,'' recalled Larry Gelbart, one of the producers. ''And even a corporation like CBS was ready to do a show like that.''

title: When Repairs Force a Tenant Out
description: Q. I have lived in a rent-controlled apartment in Greenwich Village for more than 50 years. Over the years my building has been slowly settling. The result is that the floors of my living room, bathroom and kitchen have a tilt of more than three inches from level. I was told that to fix the problem, the entire floor would have to be torn up, the beams would have to be realigned and adjusted and a new floor would have to be laid -- and that it would take at least six to eight weeks to complete the work. I was informed that I must pack up completely and move out while the work is being done. They said they would cover the cost of moving my furniture to storage but would not cover the cost of my alternative accommodations. Can I demand that they cover the difference in cost between what I have to pay for a replacement apartment and my monthly rent? Can I insist that they cover the cost of moving me back into the apartment? . . . Elizabeth Yule, Manhattan.

title: No Grass Grows Under These Feet
description: NOT many teenagers have been brought down by the Securities and Exchange Commission. But Jonathan Lebed, 18, fresh from high school graduation last year, is not letting that distinction hold him back. He has money to make and political office to win.

title: Private Sector; A Madison Ave. Bond to Women
description: MARY LOU QUINLAN worked her way up the corporate ladder for 20 years, becoming one of the few women to be named president and chief executive of a major Madison Avenue advertising agency. But for Ms. Quinlan, a usually upbeat 49-year-old, the achievement turned out to be a hollow victory.

title: Talking Up A Drug For This (And That)
description: THE drug Actimmune would not appear to have great sales potential. It is approved to treat only two rare diseases that together afflict just 800 Americans.

description: To the Editor:

title: The World: Out on the Edge; American Power Moves Beyond the Mere Super
description: STEALTH drones, G.P.S.-guided smart munitions that hit precisely where aimed; antitank bombs that guide themselves; space-relayed data links that allow individual squad leaders to know exactly where American and opposition forces are during battle -- the United States military rolled out all this advanced technology, and more, in its lightning conquest of Iraq. No other military is even close to the United States. The American military is now the strongest the world has ever known, both in absolute terms and relative to other nations; stronger than the Wehrmacht in 1940, stronger than the legions at the height of Roman power. For years to come, no other nation is likely even to try to rival American might.

title: Harmony in Hartford: Play On
description: LIKE many American orchestras, the Hartford Symphony Orchestra is expected to post a deficit at the end of this season, because this year its endowment has lost much of its value and financing from state arts organizations has dropped off.

title: Wily Wild Turkeys Lurk in Abundance for the Hunt
description: On Thursday, New York State's spring turkey season, a monthlong quest for what many hunters regard as the wiliest game bird in North America, will get under way.

title: Want a Wegmans? Many Shoppers Do
description: FREE-RANGE chickens, organic mesclun and the allure of other healthful food may be remaking some segments of the grocery industry. But Wegmans, a family-owned supermarket chain that began in Rochester in 1915, is taking the message beyond the crunch of fresh granola and getting rave reviews from Fortune magazine.

title: Editorial Observer; To Worship Freely, Americans Need a Little Elbow Room
description: The Bible Belt has historically viewed New York as a godless place. This caricature is blown away when you actually live in this polyglot immigrant city where the world's religions are widely subscribed to and crammed together cheek by jowl as nowhere else. New York has Christian houses of worship next to Muslim houses of worship next to Buddhist temples next to synagogues. The Protestant denominations come in Spanish, Caribbean, African, Asian and even hip-hop inflections. We have everything from postage-stamp storefront churches to 15,000-person mega-churches with lavish productions that draw overflowing crowds.

title: 'Good Faith'
description: THIS WOULD BE '82. I was out at the Viceroy with Bobby Baldwin. Bobby Baldwin was my one employee, which made us not quite friends, but we went out to the Viceroy almost every night. My marriage was finished and his hadn't started, so we spent a lot of time together that most everyone else we knew was spending with their families. I didn't mind. My business card had the Viceroy's number in the corner, under "may also be reached at." Buyers called me there. It was a good sign if they wanted to see a house again in what you might call the middle of the night. That meant they couldn't wait till morning. And if they wanted to see it again in the middle of the night-well, I did my best to show it to them. That was the difference between Bobby and me. He always said, "Their motivation needs to be tested, that's what I think. Let 'em wait a little bit."

description: THE Colonial style former farmhouse that houses the office of Ashford's top elected officials has crooked floors, drafty windows with rotting sashes and a wheelchair ramp that rises to a doorway too narrow for a wheelchair to squeeze through.

description: After more than a half-century at the helm of her eponymous mail-order company, Lillian Vernon, 75, who founded the company at her Mount Vernon kitchen table in 1951, will relinquish its ownership and management in July.

description: LONDON, April 27  The Irish Republican Army will disarm fully as part of the Northern Ireland peace settlement if the other parties to the accord fulfill their obligations, Gerry Adams, president of the guerrilla group's political ally, Sinn Fein, said today.

description: HENRY FORD changed the world. His Model T put the automobile within reach of the working class. The assembly line and the $5-a-day wage, two other Ford innovations, made the T affordable.

title: Everyone Knows This Is Somewhere
description: THERE is nothing inherently remarkable about how I ended up in New York. Like most people who live here, I just got out of a cab one afternoon and there I was. That's pretty much the whole story. And it all seemed completely normal to me -- until I started talking to people and telling them where I was from. Only then did I realize that I am an absolute alien here, akin to the likes of Yao Ming, Tony Blair and/or Chewbacca.

title: Lore Among The Ruins
description: WHEN Western civilization becomes trying, you can always leave it for another. One way is to go back in time to Maya civilization. At the height of their empire, from the 3rd to the 10th century, the Maya ruled in an unbroken chain of cities and villages from southern Mexico through Guatemala and Belize and down to western Honduras and El Salvador. It would take a lifetime, maybe many, to see the architectural ruins and remains of those cities, so staggeringly beautiful and strange.

title: To Explain Mom's Job Takes More Than a Day
description: THIS past week brought the official change from Take Our Daughters to Work Day to Take Our Children to Work Day. I have lobbied for such a change in this space, so I was proud to take Evan, my 12-year-old, and Alison, my writer-to-be niece, to the office with me on Thursday. The day taught them a lot about how this newspaper works. It taught them very little, I'm afraid, about what I actually do here.

''I'm agog at the forsythia,'' she exclaimed, marveling at the enormous arrangements. At 70, she seems to be what she is, a proud new grandma enjoying a day on the town. Though she clutched her lower back periodically -- arthritis? -- she ordered some wine and chatted happily about her writing. Here's a sample:

title: An Englishman's Dream of a City
description: SINCE I came to live in New York in September, I've been trying to remember what my future was like. When I was 9 or 10 in my quiet English suburb, I had a little slide show of mental images that represented what was to come. As with any boy of that age, there were glimpses of a racetrack, a winner's rostrum, heroic orations or, later, bright lights and record-album covers; but all these faded in time.

title: Her Stage Mother, Herself
description: BERNADETTE LAZZARA didn't want to go on the road. She was finishing the eighth grade at P.S. 58 in Queens and preferred to stay home with her Ozone Park friends. To them, at least, she was a normal kid. She told them as little as possible about her other life, the life across the river in Manhattan: the dancing lessons, the singing lessons, the go-sees and auditions.

title: Harvard Sweeps Adams Cup Regatta
description: The Harvard men's varsity heavyweight crew stayed unbeaten by capturing the Adams Cup yesterday for the fourth straight year. The annual event, a triangular meet with Navy and Pennsylvania, is held on the Severn River in Annapolis, Md.

title: CHANGE AT NASA
description: Ron Dittlemore, NASA's shuttle program manager, who became the face of the agency immediately after the Columbia crash, said on Thursday that he would leave when the investigation was done. But that may be a while. After obtaining a three-hour briefing from more than 30 NASA experts, officials said that they could not conclude -- so far, at least -- that debris that hit the orbiter on liftoff was the cause of the fatal damage. Matthew L. Wald

But broader economic shock waves from the disease have barely begun to resonate in the United States, which is China's second-largest trading partner, behind Japan, and one of China's biggest sources of foreign investment.

The nightclub fire in Rhode Island, the attacks on the World Trade Center and the crash of an EgyptAir jet off of Rhode Island meant long days and nights for both men.

description: Although he points out the shortcomings of ''victor's justice,'' Anderson argues in its favor. Nuremberg worked, however, because the aggressors lost. What happens when the aggressors win?

description: A large piece of sheet metal fell off the top of the Bertelsmann Building in Times Square yesterday afternoon, injuring two pedestrians and snarling traffic in the theater district.

title: N.F.L. Draft Starts on Offense, Then Shifts to Defense
description: So much of the N.F.L. draft smacks of a high school prom, minus the boutonnieres. Almost every executive is smiling or patting a co-worker on the back.

title: Trembling At Noises, Living in Fear Another Wall Will Collapse
description: Jacquelin Castillo mops her kitchen twice a day to keep the cockroaches at bay, and watches the mice dance at night outside her first-floor kitchen window. Because there is no gas, she cooks rice and meat for her husband and three children on an electric burner. The post office doesn't deliver the mail anymore. And there's one other little matter: the building she lives in is missing a wall.

title: Kelly Riordan, Paul Horwitz
description: Kelly Jeannine Riordan, a lawyer in Washington, and Paul Stephen Horwitz, a lecturer on constitutional law, are to be married today at River Farm, the headquarters of the American Horticultural Society in Alexandria, Va. Rabbi Harold S. White is to officiate, and the Rev. Michael J. Kelley, a Roman Catholic priest, will take part in the ceremony.

title: Swimming in the Middle of London
description: WHEN I travel I like to swim. Swimming gives me energy for sightseeing -- from the slow plod of touring museums to the many miles I log in cities trying to keep up with a husband who can walk for eight hours without stopping for lunch. A good swim helps restore my equilibrium, lost from packing and unpacking, rushing to catch airplanes, standing in lines, and eating poorly. It makes me a more pleasant traveling companion.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about local school elections held statewide misstated the percentage of districts that rejected their budgets for the 2003 fiscal year. It was 208 of the 550 school districts, or 37 percent, not 63 percent.

title: A Taut, Last-Minute Stretch to Save an Airline
description: A dozen or so men walked out of the Hyatt Regency by the Dallas airport last Wednesday night holding in their hands the fate of the world's largest airline.

title: Riches for the Eye and Tastebuds
description: MORELIA'S reputation precedes it: a Spanish Baroque city in the Mexican state of Michoacn, built low to the ground, of rosy quarry stone. I wanted to stroll its decorous courtyards, gape at extravagantly sculptured facades and, at least architecturally, breathe some 18th-century air. At the same time (not all my plans were so high-minded), I was going to indulge my sweet tooth. The city is a candy-making center, with a market devoted to sweets, the Mercado de Dulces, housed in a Baroque Jesuit college.

title: Exile Leader Says Hussein Is Still Alive
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  Ahmad Chalabi, the returned Iraqi exile leader, said today that Saddam Hussein and his sons were alive, being tracked, and likely to be found soon. But he also said that weeks ago Mr. Hussein ordered explosives-rigged vests like those used by suicide bombers, which presumably could be detonated if capture loomed.

title: Dog Owners Are Fighting The Yoke of Oppression
description: It's right there in the Constitution, somewhere between the inalienable right to jaywalk and the freedom to double-park. Walking your dog without a leash is even regarded by some Upper West Siders to be among life's happier pursuits.

title: Wiring the Dream Nest
description: Empty nesters used to trade down when they bought a house or apartment. No longer, says the National Association of Home Builders, which will report on Tuesday on home-buying habits of Americans aged 50 and over at its Seniors Housing Symposium in Indian Wells, Calif.

title: U.S. Says Turks Tried to Smuggle Arms Into Northern Iraq City
description: Men who identified themselves as Turkish Special Forces soldiers tried to smuggle grenades, night-vision goggles and dozens of rifles into this oil-producing city in northern Iraq this week, American military officials said today. The officials say they believe that the weapons, which were hidden in an aid convoy, were bound for ethnic Turkmens living here.

title: Abdullah: Road Map Crucial to Mideast Stability
description: LONDON, England (CNN) --A democratic Iraq will be essential in helping stabilize the Middle East, Jordan's King Abdullah II told CNN Sunday, but the key component must be resolving the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians.

title: At Their Fingertips, Tabletop Gardens
description: TO most people, the beauty of spring is primarily visual: pink cherry blossoms, golden forsythia, that special new green of the first leaves. But to the residents of the Guild Home for the Aged Blind here, people whose sight is totally or almost gone, these small pleasures requiring only the senses of smell and touch are very important indeed.

title: U.S. PLANS TO ADD TO TEAMS IN HUNT FOR IRAQI WEAPONS
description: The Bush administration, concerned about the failure to find unconventional weapons in Iraq, is moving to triple the size of the team searching for scientists and for incriminating lethal materials. Some officials are even saying that they are losing hope of finding actual weapons.

title: Pretty in Prairie
description: Girls who admired their mothers' prairie skirts last year can now flounce through spring in their own. Triple-tiered like their adult counterparts, the new children's skirts combine patterns and colors to youthful effect. Bright pastel skirts by the Gap (above, $34.50 each) come in combinations of florals, stripes and checks, while Old Navy makes a similar version in pale, contrasting shades ($18.50). Funky Kids offers a less ruffly alternative with tiny navy and red flowers ($15.95 at Rugged Bear stores). title: Ray Hicks, Who Told Yarns Older Than America, Dies at 80
description: Ray Hicks, who lived on a remote mountain and became famous among folklorists by telling stories older than America about ghosts, witches and a trickster named Jack, died last Sunday at a nursing home in Boone, N.C. He was 80.

title: Nothing Out of the Ordinary, But More Than Meets the Eye
description: THERE is a view, popular in England, that Bill Brandt's talents as a photographer have long been underestimated. This idea is quietly quashed by a touring retrospective of his photographs at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven, which confirms that Brandt, perhaps Britain's most famous 20th-century photographer, was no more or less a talent than we've always thought: marvelous chronicler of London streets and air raid shelters during World War II, patchy portraitist and lousy nude photographer.

title: SPEEDWAY PROPOSED
description: A development group that includes the actor Paul Newman, the race-car driver Mario Andretti and the political consultant James Carville has proposed a 100,000-seat, $410 million speedway, entertainment complex and hotel for Linden, just off the New Jersey Turnpike. The group had suggested its project, a Nascar track called Liberty Speedway, for the Meadowlands, but it lost out to a plan for a family entertainment, hotel and office complex. Ronald Smothers

title: Baghdad Blasts At Arms Dump Kill at Least 6
description: At least six Iraqi civilians were killed on the outskirts of Baghdad today when explosions ripped through an ammunition dump guarded by American troops in their neighborhood. Military officials said a group of attackers had fired a flare into the cache, setting off the blasts.

title: A Taste of College, Then Maybe a Full Course
description: OVER spring break, hundreds of high school juniors in Westchester traveled across the country for an annual rite of passage: the college tour. Student guides who have mastered the art of talking while walking backward extolled the virtues of their schools to teenagers and their parents. There are SAT review courses and tutors to come, coaching for admissions interviews and editing of college essays. For some families, the grooming process for college has been under way since middle school, with ever younger children encouraged to build their extracurricular activities and place into advanced academic tracks.

title: Both Sides May Be Wrong About The Budget
description: LISTENING to senators and representatives argue about the budget this month, one might have thought that the future of the United States economy was hanging in the balance.

title: Sports of The Times; Jazz's Blue-Collar Men Grow Old Together
description: THEY'RE the lucky ones. John Stockton and Karl Malone have grown old together when other legends have grown isolated in locker rooms where teammates with Playskool shaving kits thumb through PlayStation catalogs.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH/Trisha Meili; Something to Celebrate
description: IT was fitting that it was spring, because Trisha Meili was celebrating a renewed public life. She came to New York on Monday to promote her book, ''I Am the Central Park Jogger,'' at a reception that turned into an impromptu news conference.

title: Astoria Journal; With Rituals and Feasts, Queens Comes Alive During Orthodox Easter
description: Most Christians packed away their baskets, bonnets and bunnies a week ago. But today Eastern Orthodox Christians celebrate Easter, a date determined by the Julian calendar and the first full moon after the spring equinox. Astoria, Queens, with its large population of Greek-Americans, has become the site of one of the world's largest celebrations of this Orthodox holiday known as Pascha, the culmination of 40 days of fasting and a solemn week that includes an elaborate reenactment of the last days of Christ's life.

description: AS the nation's new Public Company Accounting Oversight Board organizes this month, the publication of ''Unaccountable: How the Accounting Profession Forfeited a Public Trust'' (Wiley, $27.95) by Mike Brewster, may seem well timed.

title: Karrie Woodcock, Robert Schweikert Jr.
description: Karrie Ellen Woodcock, the daughter of Carol Woodcock and Dr. James Woodcock of Centerport, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Schweikert Jr., the son of Joyce Schweikert and Mr. Schweikert of Nutley, N.J. "Nearly all trolley lines had abandoned their trips ... and livery men refused to send carriages out," it was reported later in the proceedings of the congress. People live on Diamond Island and Mule Island, and a boat goes between them in the morning to pick up children and take them to the bus stop on the mainland near the town launch. Monk Island has a lighthouse on its point. The light comes in my window, because our house sits on the granite cliff of Pigeon Cove. We face east toward the outstretched ocean and a chain of islands called the Seven Sisters. Joan went on a field trip for school when she was in fifth grade to one of the Sisters. Her class was supposed to collect plants in plastic bags and draw pictures of flowers and leaves on the lined pages of their notebooks. Soon after they arrived, Joan was hit in the face by a bird. A huge white seabird flew up from its nest as she was walking in the marsh. "It was being protective," their Nature Reserve guide told her.

title: Cupid, Circe and Jesus
description: ''Nothing quite like these photographs had been attempted before,'' Julian Cox, assistant curator of photographs at the J. Paul Getty Museum, writes in JULIA MARGARET CAMERON: The Complete Photographs (Getty, $150). Perhaps the most celebrated photographer in Victorian England, Cameron (1815-79) ''proposed her own radical brand of photographic truth, one that dissolved the boundaries between fact and fiction and image and life.'' She created the bulk of her major work in a seaside village on the Isle of Wight, near Emily and Alfred Tennyson. When painters, writers, musicians, scientists and politicians came to pay homage to the poet laureate, they were invariably met by Cameron imploring them for a portrait session. This complete collection of Cameron's reveals the profound bipolarities of her production: extravagantly mannered yet psychologically intimate, wildly ambitious yet intensely devotional, unabashedly painterly yet enraptured with the written word. Her gallery of portraiture ranges from Charles Darwin to Anthony Trollope, the literary references of her narrative tableaus run from Milton to Byron, her spectral ''Annunciations'' and ''Salutations'' transform domestic servants into exalted Madonnas. Her images of children are delightful and disturbing. As models for Cupid or Circe or the baby Jesus, they emanate ethereal anxiety. The wet-collodion process Cameron employed was time-consuming, technically demanding and dangerous (the cyanide vapors and silver nitrates could cause blindness or worse). But such details did not matter to her. ''From the first moment I handled my lens with a tender ardor,'' she wrote; ''and it has become to me as a living thing, with voice and memory and creative vigor.'' Frederick Kaufman

title: How the West Can Be One
description: Dear American Friends: We must put the West together again. Our 60-year-old community of Europe and the United States, which we have called in shorthand ''the West,'' has been grotesquely split over Iraq. In recent months, a new Eurasian axis of France, Germany and Russia has squared up against a Euratlantic alliance of the United States, Britain and Spain. Now, after the victory in Iraq, the future of the West will be decided in the Middle East. If we care about the West, we need to work out together what to do about the Middle East.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEIER, MICHAEL P.
description: BEIER-Michael P. Of Manhattan (formerly of Massapequa), on April 25, 2003, of ALS (Lou Gehrig's Disease), at the age of 39. He was a loving husband and father to his wife Theresa and his children Carly, 6, and Dustin, 4. Beloved son of Robert and Kathleen. Dear brother of Bob, Susan, Joseph and Kathleen. After his diagnosis, Michael became involved with the MDA and was named a national vice president of that organization. He worked tirelessly to raise public awareness about ALS and to raise funds for research to find a cure. Michael was a Director of Equity Trading for Credit Suisse First Boston in Manhattan and enjoyed a Wall Street career for 18 years. He leaves many family members and friends to remember his wonderful spirit for life and his generous nature that never waned even in the face of a terrible disease. He will be sorely missed by us all. The family will receive friends Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Services will be held Tuesday, 10:30 AM, at Unitarian Church of All Souls, 1157 Lexington Avenue at 80th Street. Michael asked that in lieu of flowers donations may be sent to MDA Wings Over Wall Street, 1140 Avenue of the Americas, Suite 1801, New York, New York 10036. wingsoverwallstreet.org

title: It's Starting to Feel Right As Piazza Gets Swing Back
description: Mets catcher Mike Piazza showed up for batting practice Friday and immediately shed his batting gloves. It was a damp, chilly day, and a bad swing produced a hit off the end of the bat -- as well as a jolt to the hands that felt like a live wire.

title: Michigan Democrats Won't Vote Early
description: Michigan Democrats today dropped their threat to pre-empt the New Hampshire primary next year. Meeting in Lansing, party leaders bowed to pressure from national Democrats not to schedule their primary a week before the New Hampshire vote and instead set their caucus for Feb. 7, nearly two weeks after the New Hampshire contest.

title: Eric Andersen Distills The Present From the Past

Mr. Andersen faced stiff competition from other musicians who were also performing in the city that night, so his friend just laid it on the line. ''How many of those artists,'' he asked, ''have written songs as good as Eric Andersen's?''

description: IT takes a special eye to spot the potential of the Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research in north Yonkers. Some of the boards used to cover the windows litter the lawn. title: Fair Housing
description: While apartment shopping, my girlfriend was offered a place that another couple were also vying for. When she went to sign the lease, the landlord implied that the sexual orientation of the two other people was a factor in his decision. My girlfriend is loath to benefit from bigotry, but it is possible that the apartment was awarded on her merits -- credit rating, references, etc. Is she ethically obliged to turn it down? S.A., Great Barrington, Mass.

title: Travel Advisory; Norton Museum Now Florida's Largest
description: The Norton Museum of Art in West Palm Beach has opened a new 45,000-square-foot wing, making it the largest art museum in Florida. The $20 million addition, with 14 new galleries, increases its exhibition space by 75 percent. The museum, which opened in 1941 with 500 works from the industrialist Ralph Hubbard Norton and his wife, Elizabeth, and now has more than 5,200 artworks, is known for its impressive collection of European and American modern masters such as Matisse, Monet and Picasso, O'Keeffe and Pollock. It also has a distinguished collection of Chinese art and 1,600 photographs, with seminal works representing photography's major developments.

Active on the school board and in community organizations, they led a busy life as their son and daughter grew up. Now, while other empty nesters are moving away, the Schonbergs continue to live in the rustic hamlet, which is part of the town of New Castle in northern Westchester.

title: GREENSPAN STAYS
description: President Bush tacitly acknowledged last week that his administration's success depends in large part on a man outside his control: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Months earlier than expected, Mr. Bush announced that he wants to nominate Mr. Greenspan for a fifth term as Fed chairman. Mr. Greenspan, 77 years old, is not loved among ardent believers in Mr. Bush's tax-cutting proposals. But the Fed chairman's stature with investors, and his willingness to reduce interest rates to almost unimaginable levels, has made him too important to replace just yet.

title: Out of Harlem Comes A Vibrant Chronicle
description: FOR a celebration of the 25th anniversary of the Studio Museum of Harlem, Thelma Golden, the museum's deputy director for exhibitions and programs, chose 85 pieces from among more than 1,500 objects in the permanent collection, which includes historical and contemporary work by African-Americans and artists of the African diaspora. The focus of the three-part exhibition now at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton is on those who have had a direct relationship to the Harlem community or the museum itself, including several former artists in residence.

title: Ahead of His Moment
description: Anyone with an interest in photography remembers looking for the first time at Robert Frank's ''The Americans,'' the photo-essay he crafted after traveling the country on a Guggenheim grant in the mid-1950's. His vision was news. But before becoming that Robert Frank, he was already an auspicious artist revolutionizing straight photography. After emigrating as a young man from Switzerland, the son of a middle-class family, he went to work as a fashion photographer for Harper's Bazaar. Though he was good at it, it boxed him in. So in the early 1950's, this 27-year-old, driven by reckless curiosity and intuition, took off for London and Wales to work entirely without restraints. Frank has published only a scant selection of pictures from that journey. Many stunning, never-before-seen images of that time are now finally available to us in the exhibition ''Robert Frank: London/Wales,'' which opens May 10 at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington. (A book of the same name is being published simultaneously by Scalo.)

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: At the age of 61, Samuel R. Delany has negotiated the passage from boy wonder to grand old man of science fiction with enviable grace. Delany, who published eight well-received novels before his 25th birthday and has won four Nebula Awards and two Hugos, is now a professor of English and creative writing at Temple University. Over the last two decades he has become science fiction's leading academic critic, bringing to bear on the finest products of the genre the apparatus of postmodern analysis.

title: WEAPONS ORDERED DESTROYED

The order covers 12,000 weapons used by state troopers, some corrections officers in state prisons and some workers at psychiatric hospitals. Melting the guns in a foundry maintained by the Department of Law and Public Safety will prevent them from being diverted to criminals, the governor said. Karen DeMasters

The skull was of a political prisoner from Saddam Hussein's regime, and the grieving Iraqis were relatives who had exhumed it from a graveyard filled with other victims of Saddam's torture. Just under the picture was an article about President Bush vowing that weapons of mass destruction will be found in Iraq, as he promised.

title: When Love Hurts (a Movie)
description: ALTHOUGH his movie ''Jersey Girl'' doesn't come out until November, the writer and director Kevin Smith is already feeling anxious about its chances for success. Research audiences have responded positively to the story line about a music promoter whose life changes after he falls in love and has a child, and they call the love scenes ''hot.'' Only a few people have said things like, ''Oh god, enough of these two already.'' But Mr. Smith knows that he is at the mercy of a phenomenon that is beyond his control and could wreak havoc with his film. ''Jersey Girl'' stars the tabloid entity that he calls Bennifer: the betrothed, Bentley-riding, bussing, perpetually intertwined celebrity couple Jennifer Lopez and Ben Affleck.

title: STATE TO RESTRICT BUILDING

New regulations that do not require legislative approval will essentially ban most residential and commercial development within 300 feet of reservoirs. Mr. McGreevey said the new rules would not cause undue hardship to the construction industry. But many builders were quick to criticize the plan, predicting that it would exacerbate the housing shortage that already makes New Jersey housing costs among the highest in the nation. title: Being Any Number of Versions of the Self He Has Invented
description: John Malkovich may have to leave his life. Or at least the part of his life -- no small part -- that is his home in the south of France. Except when he's making a movie on location, Malkovich and his family live here, near Provence, year round. But lately he has been involved in a dispute with the French government -- one he'd rather not go into detail about -- and now Malkovich may have to look for another home. ''I'll probably have to leave,'' Malkovich, who is 49, says softly, sitting in the enormous kitchen that took him two years to get just right. Hours ago, Malkovich returned on the train from Paris, where he was discussing a play he recently directed, and he is wearing a black suit of his own design and a pale blue shirt. He has a look of elegant scruffiness -- he is big-boned, and his curly gray-blond hair and beard seem to circle his face. Nicole Peyran, the mother of his son and daughter, is with the kids at the family apartment in Aix-en-Provence, an hour away, where the children attend a bilingual school. Solo for the afternoon, Malkovich is preparing lunch, carving thin slices off a huge piece of prosciutto that has its hairy hoof still attached. The leg of the pig is secured by a metal rod attached to a small vise. ''Oh,'' Malkovich explains, ''I had this built. There's a butcher in town that will do that for you.'' Malkovich pauses. ''But you have to ask.''

After his diagnosis, Michael became involved with the MDA and was named a national vice president of that organization. title: A Clean Air Rule That Works

The provision, known as ''new source review,'' requires older power plants to install modern pollution-control equipment whenever they significantly expand production. It recorded its most dramatic victory last week when Dominion Resources of Virginia, one of the country's biggest polluters, agreed to spend $1.2 billion to clean up eight coal-burning power plants.

title: For MetroStars Magee, Saturday Was Quite a Day
description: BOB BRADLEYs first victory as the MetroStars coach, 1-0 over Columbus, was also his 83rd in Major League Soccer, a league record. The rookie MIKE MAGEE set a team record when he became the youngest player (18 years 236 days) to score a goal, his first as a professional. Magee, an early replacement for striker JAIME MORENO, who left the match with a hamstring injury, was later replaced by JACOB LeBLANC. Magee needed to fly home to Chicago to attend his girlfriends senior prom. I got my first goal and it takes a lot of pressure off the next game, Magee said. There is a lot of pressure with both the prom and M.L.S. Ah, the problems of youth. Magee had started the MetroStars first two games of the season, looking a bit tentative and getting pushed around by the defense. There are times when he will start and there are days when he will be a reserve, Bradley said. For young guys growing there are always ups and downs. The same cannot be said for the clubs other top rookie, midfielder RICARDO CLARK. Clark looked comfortable and confident in all three games. Against Columbus (the last eight matches between the teams have been decided by a goal), he made a 50-yard dash in the second half that ended with a blistering shot on goal from nearly 30 yards out. After a disastrous 2002 season in which the teams central defense struggled, EDDIE POPE and STEVE JOLLEY have been solid in front of goalkeeper TIM HOWARD. CLINT MATHIS has been assertive in midfield after coming back from a hernia operation, but he has yet to regain the form that made him one of the most dangerous players in the league. On Saturday in the first half, he buried a free kick into the defensive wall. In the second half, he set himself up for a left-footed shot from the top of the area, which he pushed over the goal. In the past, it would have been a goal.

title: Roddick Plays at Rockefeller Center
description: Less than 24 hours after losing a three-set match to Andre Agassi at the United States Mens Clay Court Championships in Houston, Andy Roddick was back on the court yesterday. This time, he was at the Rockefeller Center ice rink in Manhattan, hitting a few lobs, smiling for the cameras and playing the role of ambassador for the United States Tennis Associations kickoff of USA Tennis Month. Roddick, who arrived in New York shortly after midnight, was on a makeshift court built on the rink to play doubles with Alexandra Stevenson against Jim Courier and Zina Garrison. Despite the loss to Agassi, who is now the worlds top-ranked mens player, Roddick said he felt good heading into the European clay-court season, which culminates with the French Open next month. Ive had a couple of knick-and-knack injuries, and so its been kind of spotty: one good week, one bad week, Roddick said. I still have to come into my own, but I had a good week in Houston and pushed Andre to the ropes. Roddick, who lost in the first round at the French Open last year, said he planned to prepare this year by playing outdoors on clay in Hamburg, Germany; St. Polten, Austria; and Rome. James Blake, another rising American talent who was on hand yesterday, also plans to play in Rome and Hamburg as warm-ups to the French Open. To see if Americans can prove once again, we can play on clay, Blake said. I hope Andy and me can show that. Yesterday, Blake, 23, and Roddick, 20, wanted to show a future generation the fun side of the game. People just walking by may see us, Roddick said as passersby looked on. They may never have picked up a racket, but thats the point of this. To show people how cool tennis is.

The sheer scale of the enterprise -- more than doubling the size of the United States and paying for much of Napoleon's effort to conquer Europe -- makes either viewpoint almost irresistible. But each misses what is most remarkable about the transaction: the speed with which it was accomplished and the ease with which the huge territory became American.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Water Mill: Police Search For Killer
description: The Suffolk County police were searching yesterday for a man they said shot two men, one fatally, at an acquaintance's house on Saturday afternoon. The police said that the motive for the shootings was unclear and that they did not have the full name of the gunman. Around 4 p.m., two men, identified by the police as James R. Garcia, 25, and John Manuel Rojas, 19, visited the Water Mill home of Alan Kuchtuk, who was asleep. Two other men, guests at Mr. Kuchtuk's house, talked to Mr. Garcia and Mr. Rojas and an argument apparently broke out. One of the guests shot Mr. Garcia twice in the chest, killing him, and shot Mr. Rojas in the head, Detective Sgt. Edward A. Light of the Suffolk homicide squad said. Mr. Rojas was listed in good condition yesterday. The gunman and two other witnesses fled, Detective Sergeant Light said. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MODELL, MICHAEL S.
description: MODELL-Michael S. On April 28, 2001, our precious, beloved son Michael lost his battle against Crohn's disease and cancer. On this, the second anniversary of his death, the entire Modell family laments his tragic and untimely passing with profound sorrow. He was our talisman of hope, our wellspring of joy, our touchstone of wisdom and strength. His legacy of courage, compassion, laughter and love will live in our hearts forever. His extraordinary integrity and countless acts of loving kindness will guide us as we honor his memory each day of our lives. Like a glorious shooting star, Michael blazed across the heavens showering us with his luminous beauty. His passing has left us in anguish, bereft of the angel we cherished and loved. This day, as we light a candle for a loving husband, a devoted father, a supportive brother, a doting uncle, and an adoring son, we echo his dying words and say, Michael of blessed memory, we will love you always. The Modell Family: Shelby and Bill; Abby, Alex, Andrew, Ashley; Leslie and Shawn; Mitchell, Robin, Melissa, Brittany, Ashley N., Matthew & Maxwell

title: Public Health Fears Cause New York Officials to Detain Foreign Tourist
description: A foreign tourist arrived in New York City early this month with a guidebook in hand and Knicks tickets in his pocket. But he did not use them because he also arrived with a suspected case of SARS and spent virtually his entire vacation involuntarily detained in a hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRCHBLUM, LILA
description: KIRCHBLUM-Lila. On April 27, 2003. Beloved wife of Harold. Cherished mother of Mark and Michael. Loving mother-in-law of Nancy and Caren. Adored grandmother of David, Eric, Matthew and Evan. Devoted sister to Pearl and Howard, Lenny and Claire. She will be deeply missed by all.

title: Thousands Riot in Rural Chinese Town Over SARS
description: CHAGUGANG, China, April 28  Thousands of residents of this rural town, believing that a local school would be turned into a ward for urban SARS patients, ransacked the interior of the four-story building on Sunday night.

title: For Equality on the Front Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Novels With the Power To Change Young Lives
description: At a tough branch library in Philadelphia -- there were more guards than librarians -- a teenage boy I thought had slept through my speech stood up and asked, ''Do you use drugs when you write?''

title: Texans Draft Yanks' Henson in 6th Round
description: If Drew Henson had wanted to play football last year, the Houston Texans might have taken him with the first overall pick of the N.F.L. draft. Today, with Henson still scuffling in the Yankees' minor league system, the Texans took Henson with the 19th pick of the sixth round.

title: For Muslims, a Mixture Of White House Signals
description: When President Bush travels to Dearborn, Mich., on Monday to speak to Iraqi exiles and other Arab-Americans, he will trail behind him considerable uncertainty about his administration's intentions toward Islam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERMAN, SYMON
description: FERMAN-Symon. The entire Roisen and Kwiat family mourns the passing of Alice Roisen's beloved brother, Symon Ferman, who passed away April 25th after a prolonged illness. He will be missed by all of us; Alice, Jacques and Shelley Roisen, Rita and Sheldon Kwiat and their children, Steven, Michele and Steve Siegel. Our condolences to the entire Ferman family.

title: Using Termite Flatulence Against Them
description: TERRY CLARK, whose family runs a pest-control empire in Stockton, Calif., believes he has a better way to find termites: monitoring the methane they expel.

title: Graham Stuart Thomas, 94, British Gardener and Writer
description: Sir Graham Stuart Thomas, whose passionate knowledge and love of plants placed him among the world's greatest gardeners, died on April 16, in a hospital near his home in Woking, England. He was 94.

title: Mets Double Their Futility In Losses To Arizona
description: Sure, the Mets looked awful in losing a doubleheader to the Arizona Diamondbacks yesterday at Shea Stadium. But it was futility with flair. Over both games, they struck out 27 times, a major league record for two nine-inning games in the same day as they lost by scores of 6-1 and 7-3 before a big crowd on a beautiful afternoon.

title: Hoping for Big Dividends, Giants Tap Small Programs
description: There are no more secrets in the N.F.L. draft, some executives claim, but the players picked by the Giants in the second and third rounds are at least highly classified, with backgrounds more typical of double agents than of football players.

title: Franks Foresees a Weapons Hunt at 'Several Thousand Sites'
description: Gen. Tommy R. Franks, the commander of allied forces in the Persian Gulf, said today that the hunt for unconventional weapons in Iraq would require scouring ''several thousand sites,'' a process that experts said could take months.

title: Pierce Dominates 2nd Half, Putting Pacers on Brink of Elimination
description: Three days ago, Paul Pierce and the Boston Celtics were lauded for their balanced offense. That is what it takes to win in the playoffs, it was said. That is Celtics basketball, it was written.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORCHHEIMER, PAUL L.
description: FORCHHEIMER - Paul L. Died peacefully at age 86, on Saturday, April 26, 2003. Husband of the late Gerda, brother and brother-in-law of Igo and Marion, father and father-in-law of Mark, Shelley, Linda, Robert, Elliot, Joan, Claire and George. Grandfather of Adam, Scott, Daniel, Jeremy, Kenneth, Ilana and Jacob. Uncle, cousin, and friend to many. Born in Karlsruhe, Germany, he emigrated to Israel and then to the United States. Since 1948 he devotedly served as founder of Paul L. Forchheimer and Company, investment brokers. May his memory be a source of strength and blessing.

title: Tacoma Police Chief Shoots Wife Before Killing Himself, Authorities Say
description: The wife of the Tacoma police chief was in critical condition today, a day after her husband shot her in the head in a mall parking lot and then fatally shot himself, the authorities said.

title: Sports of The Times; Simmses' Long, Hard Wait
description: THE wait is what hurt. Chris Simms had been led to believe that he would be selected 15th to 25th in the first round of the N.F.L. draft.

title: Mayhem Dosed With Psychological Awareness
description: NO SECOND CHANCE

title: Compressed Data; Amazon Site's Child Reviewers Spur Privacy Charge
description: A privacy complaint filed last week with the Federal Trade Commission argues that contrary to law, some reviewers for the online retailer Amazon.com are children.

title: U.S. Will Move Air Operations To Qatar Base
description: The United States is shifting its major air operations center for the Middle East from Saudi Arabia to Qatar, the first step in what is likely to be a significant reduction of American forces in Saudi Arabia and a realignment of American military presence in the region, senior military officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, ARTHUR
description: GOODMAN-Arthur. Poppy, you filled our lives with humor and love, you are always smiling and forever in our hearts. Peter, Marian, Cris and Nick Goodman Jaye, Mark, Josh and Jordan Roter

title: One Tough Deal on Path to the Hall of Fame
description: Players from New York have played a dominant role in the history of the game. The proof is that exactly half of the members of the American Contract Bridge League's Hall of Fame, 36 of 72, played their bridge largely or wholly in the metropolitan area.

title: Corrections
description: An architecture review on Wednesday about the Richard B. Fisher Center for the Performing Arts, designed by Frank Gehry for Bard College, misstated the site of another Gehry building, the Weisman Art Museum at the University of Minnesota, which also has a metal facade and a boxlike structure. It is in Minneapolis, not St. Paul.

title: Top German Officials Back Schrder's Economic Overhaul
description: FRANKFURT, April 28  Chancellor Gerhard Schroder gained ground today for his politically divisive plan to overhaul Germany's paralyzed economy, as new statistics showed how desperately the country needs a jolt.

title: INSIDE
description: 2 Stock Analysts to Settle

title: War Plan Drew U.S. Commandos From Shadows
description: For America's Special Operations forces, the war in Iraq almost started with a disaster.

title: 'Little Bitty,' More's the Pity
description: The Republicans controlling Congress return this week to anguish over how much more of a tax cut the nation's wealthiest citizens have coming. The leaders and President Bush would be wise to focus instead on the needs of the growing army of unemployed Americans. A total of 2.6 million private sector jobs have been lost across the past two years -- a record for any modern presidency. Mr. Bush should be jawboning on behalf of benefits for the jobless as heartily as he now tours the land for still more relief for the affluent.
