description: An architecture review on Wednesday about the Richard B. Fisher Center for the Performing Arts, designed by Frank Gehry for Bard College, misstated the site of another Gehry building, the Weisman Art Museum at the University of Minnesota, which also has a metal facade and a boxlike structure. It is in Minneapolis, not St. Paul.

title: Giants' Draft
description: Scouting report on the Giants' draft picks.

title: High-Speed Precision On Draft's 2nd Day
description: Even the most focused fan can see his attention span waning on the second day of the N.F.L. draft, when the big names give way to lesser-known players like Kansas State receiver Taco Wallace, who is believed to be the first Taco ever drafted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, PETER
description: STONE-Peter. Husband of Mary. Brother of David. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in his name to the Robin Hood Foundation or the Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation.

title: For Equality on the Front Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Randolph, 76, Broadway Set Designer
description: Robert Randolph, a designer of sets and lighting for Broadway productions for three decades, died on March 2 at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 76.

title: Webdenda
description: BBDO Worldwide , New York, promoted one employee and hired two others for new strategic planning posts. Sheron Davis , planning and research director, was named director for marketing services. Tracy Lovatt was named director for communications planning; she had most recently been president at Momentum Worldwide, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. And Timothy Malefyt was named director for cultural discoveries; he had been vice president and senior planner at the Troy, Mich., office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, which is being closed by its parent, the Publicis Groupe. BBDO is part of the Omnicom Group. The Council on National Newspaper Advertising , New York, is being formed to encourage national marketers to buy additional ad space in newspapers. David Altschiller , who heads Altschiller Associates, New York, was named chairman. Peter Ferraro was named publisher at The Fader magazine, New York, succeeding Jon Cohen and Rob Stone, who were named founding publishers. Mr. Ferraro had been vice president for advertising at the New York office of Transworld Media, part of the Time Inc. unit of AOL Time Warner. The Fader is published by Cornerstone Promotion. The Hartford Financial Services Group , Hartford, agreed to become the first sponsor of the United States Paralympics , Colorado Springs. Terms were not disclosed. The Paralympics is part of the United States Olympic Committee, which had been the sole source of its financing. The Heico Companies , Chicago, named Korey Kay & Partners , New York, as agency of record on the account of the Air and Health UV Home Air Sanitizer, a new product. Billings were estimated at $4 million to $6 million. Anna Herceg , advertising sales manager at Seed magazine , New York, was named to the new post of advertising director. Also, the magazine hired two Detroit sales representatives. One, Debbie Hausler , had been senior vice president and director for non-automotive media at the Warren, Mich., office of Campbell-Ewald, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. The other, John McHugh , had been director for advertising at the Troy, Mich., office of Gruner & Jahr USA Publishing, part of Bertelsmann. Seed is published by the Seed Group. Dennis Hernandez was named director for Hispanic marketing to head Mobile Hispanic, Atlanta, a new tours and events marketing agency being opened by Mobile Media Enterprises. He had been director for sponsorship at Corporacion Interamericana de Entretenimiento, Miami, an entertainment and events marketing company. Tricia Melton was named vice president for marketing at Lifetime Entertainment Services , New York, succeeding Joan Blanski, who left, the company said. Ms. Melton had been vice president for marketing at Oxygen Media, New York. Lifetime Entertainment is a joint venture of the Hearst Corporation and the Walt Disney Company. More magazine , New York, promoted two employees and hired two others. Lee Bowles , sales assistant, was named account manager. Wendy Kittredge , health director, was named to the new post of sales development director. Julie Graham was named to the new post of special events director; Ms. Graham had been events marketing manager at DoubleClick, New York. Danielle Yuen was named promotions director, succeeding John Balen, who left, the company said. Ms. Yuen had been marketing manager at the Primedia Teen Internet Group, New York, part of Primedia. More is owned by the Meredith Corporation. NKH&W , Kansas City, Mo., hired three employees and promoted another. Mark Mastro was named account executive; he had been account executive at Zillner Marketing Communications, Lenexa, Kan. Mary Mitchell was named account coordinator; she had been art buyer and creative coordinator at Valentine-Radford, Kansas City. And Gail Wordekemper , senior account executive, was named management supervisor. Noesis Healthcare Interactions , Parsippany, N.J., promoted two employees. Uma Ginde , vice president and group copy supervisor, was named associate creative director. And Brenda Rebilas , group art supervisor, was named vice president and associate creative director. Noesis is part of CommonHealth, a unit of the WPP Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, GARY
description: RUBIN-Gary. The Officers, Board of Directors, and Staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the sudden and untimely loss of our esteemed colleague, Gary Rubin, Managing Director of UJA-Federation's Commission on the Jewish People. A professional with exceptional gifts, he was tireless in his commitment to the welfare of the Jewish people. We mourn the loss of an immensely capable man and quintessential ''mensch,'' and extend our deepest condolences to Gary's devoted wife Sheila, his children Ari, Michal, Jonah, and Bracha, his two brothers David and William, and to his entire family. Larry Zichlin President Morris W. Offit Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay Executive VP and CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, EDWIN SAUL
description: MARKS-Edwin Saul. On April 24, 2003 at home surrounded by Nancy, his childhood sweetheart and loving wife of 53 years and his daughters, Carolyn Marks Blackwood, Linda Marks Katz and Constance Marks Miller; his sons-in-law, Greg Quinn, Richard Katz and James Miller. Loving grandfather of his 3 grandchildren, Gabriel, Laura and Sophia. He is survived by his sister Marjorie Boas Levins, his brother-in-law Jack Levins and his childhood friend and brother - in - law Jerome Abeles and Betsy McGrathAbeles. His generosity, sense of humor and kindness in word and deed will always be remembered by those who knew him. Services will be held Monday, April 28 at 11 AM at Temple Beth El, 5 Old Mill Road in Great Neck. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the BoasMarks Biomedical Science Research Center at North Shore-Long Island Jewish Hospital or to the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory.

title: Iraqis Anxiously Await Decisions About the Operation and Control of the Oil Industry
description: The brain center of Iraqi oil exports, a sprawling state organization that controlled the shipments from the Persian Gulf to the Turkish port of Ceyhan on the Mediterranean Sea, is dark and quiet.

title: Bond Sale Schedule For Coming Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes the regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills today and a four-week bill on tomorrow.

title: The chief of Cordiant, the big agency company, keeps a steady hand in trying to halt its decline.
description: DAVID HEARN is no secret agent, but he has embarked on a mission that if not impossible is highly improbable: rescuing the beleaguered Cordiant Communications Group, whose plight is perhaps the most dire of any agency company in the struggling advertising industry.

title: 2 Analysts Likely to Pay $20 Million In Fraud Case
description: Henry Blodget, the former Internet analyst at Merrill Lynch, and Jack B. Grubman, the former telecommunications analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, are expected to pay almost $20 million in fines and penalties and agree to be barred permanently from the securities industry today, according to a person briefed on the investigation. The sanctions are to be disclosed when regulators announce the final agreement in the $1.4 billion investment banking research settlement.

title: Intense Search Off City I. for Bodies of 3 Boys
description: Divers with the Police Department searched the waters off City Island again yesterday, looking for the remains of three of the four boys who vanished after shoving off into Long Island Sound in a tiny dinghy three months ago. The body of one of the boys, Max Guarino, 17, was found Friday, prompting an intense search for the bodies of the other three.

title: Indonesia Willing to Reopen Aceh Talks, but Sets Tough Terms
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 28  After an emergency cabinet meeting today, the Indonesian government said that it was willing to resume peace talks with Aceh Province separatists that broke down late last week.

title: The Tulia Story Isn't Over
description: A grand jury in Texas has indicted the ex-cop who conducted a slimy undercover operation that devastated much of the black community in the small Panhandle town of Tulia.

title: Recalling 45's, Music Labels Push Market for DVD Singles
description: Sign a contract with Epic Records, home to artists like Celine Dion, Good Charlotte and Kelly Osbourne, and you can expect to have your every move followed by a video manager toting a high-definition camera. Signing records for fans, fooling around backstage before shows, talking with the director of your latest clip for MTV -- all is captured as potential bonus footage for DVD singles.

title: Marsh Arabs Cling to Memories of a Culture Nearly Crushed by Hussein
description: ''It was paradise,'' said Hassan Naslob, 51. ''When I was a child, life was good.''

title: Apple Is Said To Be Entering E-Music Fray With Pay Service
description: Apple Computer plans on Monday to introduce a digital music service, according to industry analysts. It is a move that thrusts the company into the middle of a contentious and technologically challenging area of digital commerce.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Police Officer Stabbed
description: An off-duty rookie police officer was stabbed three times in the back yesterday during an argument outside a bar in the South Bronx, the police said. The officer, Michael Rodriguez, 25, told officials he had been defending his cousin, whose cellular phone had hit someone else's car when she dropped it. An argument with four men, who were in the car, followed, and Officer Rodriguez and a 30-year-old friend were stabbed at 5:45 a.m., the police said. The friend's name was not released. Both men were in stable condition at Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center yesterday, the police said. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Court Delays Bid to Cut Size Of Fire Crews
description: Taking aim at budget cuts its members say will jeopardize public safety, the union representing New York City firefighters has won a court order temporarily prohibiting the city from reducing the size of crews on certain engines to four from five.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNER, DONALD C.
description: POSNER-Donald C. On April 27, 2003. Beloved husband of Carol. Loving father of Alix, Lee and Michael. Dear brother of Alan and Richard. Cherished grandfather of Carly, Eli, Daniel and Andrew. Services Tuesday, 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Climbing the Walls to Climb Bridges Again
description: Dave Frieder remembers the days when he could pack his $3,000 camera and $4,000 gyroscopic stabilizer and go climb a bridge  the days before Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIELDS, FRANCIS A.
description: SHIELDS-Francis A. Age 61, a resident of Palm Beach, FL, died after a protracted illness on Friday, April, 25, 2003. Born in New York, he was the son of the late Francis Xavier Shields and the late Princess Marina Torlonia of Rome, Italy. Beloved husband of Didi, devoted father of Brooke, Marina, Cristiana, and Olympia, stepfather to Diana Auchincloss Cunningham and Thomas Gore Auchincloss, loving and adored grandfather of Buck, Hughie, Mackenzie, Emma, Tate and Minnie, brother of Marina Torlonia, half-brother of Katherine and William Shields and devoted friend of many too numerous to list. He was a graduate of the Buckley School, St. Paul's School and the University of Pennsylvania. He lived life to the fullest, fought valiantly with dignity and courage and was taken too early. He is loved by many and will be missed and never forgotten. A private family service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407. For further information, Quattlebaum Funeral Home, West Palm Beach, FL; 561-832-5171.

title: 80 Are Arrested After Raid at Cockfight
description: About 80 people were arrested early yesterday after the police raided a rundown Bronx building where a cockfight was taking place and seized nearly 20 roosters trained to attack in bloody fights, the authorities said.

title: Behind AMR, a Chairman Who Flies in All Directions
description: AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, reached deep into the corporate playbook by naming Edward A. Brennan chairman after the resignation of Donald J. Carty as chairman and chief executive.

title: AMERICANS ARREST WOULD-BE LEADER OF IRAQ'S CAPITAL
description: American forces today arrested Baghdad's self-appointed mayor, Muhammad Mohsen Zobeidi, bundling him and seven of his top aides into an Army Humvee after he defied warnings to stop acting as the city's chief administrator.

title: Bank One Said to Seek Buyer for a Unit
description: The Bank One Corporation is seeking to sell its corporate trust business for more than $1 billion as it focuses on the higher-growth credit card and retail operations, according to executives close to the company said yesterday.

title: On Capitol Hill, Ideology Is Distorting an African AIDS Success
description: In 1991, 15 percent of Ugandans had the AIDS virus. A decade later, the rate was 5 percent, a drop unmatched anywhere in the world. How this was done is now the focus of a tragically ideological argument about the shape of Washington's programs to fight AIDS overseas.

description: In a city besotted with art, London shows how the old is germane to the new.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: State Health Care Cuts Criticized
description: Two of the city's top health officials warned of severe consequences yesterday if the state cuts health care as deeply as proposed. Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the city health commissioner, told a City Council hearing that the cuts for his agency would total $50 million in the coming fiscal year and would, among other things, reduce the staff at the city's poison control center, possibly leading to longer waits on the emergency telephone line. He also said some schoolchildren could miss the opening of school because of cutbacks in a program that offers required vaccinations. Dr. Benjamin K. Chu, president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, said proposed cuts in Medicaid would reduce the agency's revenue by $200 million, forcing layoffs and service cutbacks. The proposed cuts are intended to help close a budget gap of some $11.5 billion, in the state's $90.8 billion budget. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLINTOFT, GERALD J.
description: FLINTOFT-Gerald J. On April 22, 2003 at age 68. Beloved husband of Ann Flintoft. Devoted father of Gerald, Thomas and Mark. Loving grandfather to his four grandchildren. Adored brother of Mary Collings and Richard Flintoft. Admired attorney at Pennie & Edmonds LLP where he dedicated himself for 30 years, 27 as partner, until his retirement in 1999. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, April 29 at 11:00 AM at Our Lady of Mary, Rt. 7, Sheffield, MA. In lieu of flowers the family has requested donations be sent to The Hillsdale Library, The Millerton Library or The American Cancer Society.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Elections In Doubt
description: Politicians began their first day of campaigning for May 29 elections to the Northern Ireland Assembly while representatives of the British and Irish governments met in Belfast to discuss whether to postpone the vote until the rival Catholic and Protestant parties could agree on a plan to get the body up and running again. The assembly was suspended in October over allegations of continuing Irish Republican Army paramilitary activity, and Protestant leaders say they will not resume participation in the power-sharing legislature unless the I.R.A. renounces violence. London and Dublin welcomed a new nonviolence pledge from Gerry Adams, president of Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political wing, but said they still needed clearer assurance that paramilitary activity was ended. Warren Hoge (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: A Subject Barely Mentioned at Merrill Meeting
description: A year after David H. Komansky, the chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company, apologized to shareholders for the firm's tainted investment advice, he barely discussed the topic at the firm's annual meeting here today.

title: Health Group Relies on a Time-Tested Rule to Determine Last New Case
description: In declaring Vietnam the first country to stop its outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, the World Health Organization relied on a time-tested rule of thumb used by epidemiologists.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Chip Makers' Results Improve
description: Two of Japan's largest chipmakers had upturns in the latest fiscal year but are cautious about this year. Hitachi Ltd. returned to profitability in the year ended March 31, earning 27.9 billion yen ($232.2 million) after losing a record 484 billion yen last year. Hitachi, however, expects profit to fall 82 percent this year and sales to decline 2 percent. The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, the smallest of Japan's five big chip makers, lost 11.8 billion yen last year, one-seventh the size of the previous year's loss. Mitsubishi expects to earn 5 billion yen in the current year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Despite Protests, Senate Approves Bush Nominee for Court
description: WASHINGTON, April 29  Jeffrey S. Sutton was approved by the Senate today for a seat on a federal appeals court, despite a protest from disabled people who complained that he had tried to take away some of their rights.

title: Iraqis Set to Meet to Pick Transitional Government
description: A political gathering of about 300 Iraqis, sponsored by the United States and Britain, decided tonight to call a national conference in a month's time to select a postwar transitional government for Iraq.

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT IS BUYING ALLIED WASTE PROPERTIES
description: Waste Management Inc. agreed to buy collection businesses in five states and landfill operations in Oklahoma from a rival, Allied Waste Industries, for $73 million. The assets include hauling, transfer and material-recovery operations in New Jersey, and hauling operations in South Carolina, Georgia, Colorado and Oklahoma. The Allied Waste assets being acquired represent $125 million in annual revenue, Waste Management said. Waste Management is based in Houston. Allied Waste is based in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Teenagers Questioned In Death
description: The police are questioning three teenage boys, whom they did not identify, in connection with the shooting death of a 12-year-old Chicago boy who was killed just after participating in a neighborhood cleanup. The boy, Rene Guillen, whose family recently moved into the neighborhood, was killed on Saturday, possibly by gang members who were looking for someone else, the police said. Rene, a seventh grader, was hit when a group of teenagers fired into a crowd of children. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: Energy Profit Rises
description: Statoil, Norway's largest oil and gas producer, reported that net income rose 20 percent increase on the first quarter, to 3.59 billion Norwegian kroner ($508 million). High oil prices and increased output were offset partly by a weak dollar exchange rate and lower gas prices. For the period, Norsk Hydro, which ranks second in Norway to Statoil, earned 2.48 billion kroner ($351 million), an increase of 16 percent. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The weekly ''Most Wanted'' chart in Business Day yesterday mislabeled the shares of Dow Jones & Company that were among the top-performing media stocks for the week ended Friday. The percentage change and closing price -- up 56.8 percent, to $58 -- were for the company's Class B shares, not for its common stock.

title: Holocaust List Is Unsealed By Insurers
description: After years of delay, German insurance companies are making public the names of 363,232 victims of the Holocaust who were covered by life insurance policies but whose records were previously sealed, an international insurance commission said today.

title: Making Baby's Heart Beat Faster
description: Babies who share a bed with their mothers tend to have higher sleeping heart rates than other babies, scientists have found, but the cause -- and any possible implications -- are unclear.

title: Excerpts From Settlement With Citigroup on Salomon's Recommendations
description: Following are excerpts from the settlement between federal regulators and Citigroup. The company, along with other financial services companies, had been charged with conflict of interest in stock recommendations made by its analysts, including Jack B. Grubman of its Salomon Smith Barney (S.S.B.) unit. The full text is online atnytimes.com/business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWHOUSE, CAROLINE
description: NEWHOUSE - Caroline. On April 26, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Theodore. Devoted grandmother of Amy Bermant Adler and Julie Bermant Lobel. Cherished greatgrandmother of Jill and Emily Adler, and Joshua, Isaac, Jonathan and Sarah Lobel. Services Wednesday, April 30th, 10AM at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave and 65th St. In lieu of flowers contributions to Career Transitions for Dancers, 165 W. 46th St., Suite 701, NYC 10036.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Getronics To Cut Jobs
description: The debt-ridden Dutch information technology company Getronics said yesterday that it would close 20 offices and eliminate 1,000 to 1,200 jobs as part of a reorganization that could cost up to 60 million euros ($66 million). Getronics, already suffering from a continuing technology slump, is struggling to survive under the weight of half a billion euros in debt, much of it acquired in association with its 1999 purchase of Wang Global of Billerica, Mass. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Thumbs Up After Batting, But No Return Set for Jeter
description: Derek Jeter turned to a Yankees public relations assistant and gave an enthusiastic thumbs up today after taking his first batting practice off a tee since he dislocated his left shoulder nearly a month ago.

title: In Trenton, an Emotional Plea To Restore Money for Culture
description: In an emotional defense of the historical and cultural programs that Gov. James E. McGreevey has proposed cutting, the New Jersey secretary of state, Regena Thomas, told legislators today that ''this was not a good decision.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOROVOY, HYMAN
description: GOROVOY - Hyman, of Brooklyn, NY on Sunday April 27, 2003. As a very young child Hy immigrated from Poland with his family to America and has lived in Brooklyn ever since. An Army Veteran and Philanthropist along with his brothers, he built many apartment complexes throughout Northern, NJ and until his recent retirement continued to own and operate several of them. Beloved husband of Annette for 63 years. Devoted father of Murray. Loving grandfather of Ivy Gantert and Eric Gorovoy, and great-grandfather of Benjamin and Samuel Gantert. Services today 11:30am at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLESHMAN, NORMAN
description: BLESHMAN - Norman. Be loved husband of Rita. Devoted father of Joe (Lucia Vassallo), and Martha Bleshman. Cherished grandfather of Rachel and James. Dear brother of Betty Pollett. Services Tuesday, 2:15 PM, at ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Poor Patients Are Not Getting Hospital Information, Study Finds
description: A study of 16 nonprofit hospitals on Long Island found that they do an inadequate job of informing low-income, uninsured patients that they may be eligible for free or reduced-fee care.

description: In the latest state-versus-state battle over water rights to reach the Supreme Court, the justices agreed today to decide whether Virginia needs Maryland's permission to draw water from the Potomac River, which forms part of the boundary between the two.

title: Defying Odds on Road to Derby
description: It is a tale that begins in Utah, gallops through Panama, gathers momentum in cyberspace and has now landed here in the bluegrass of Kentucky. It involves an 82-year-old legendary record producer who cultivated the sound of Chuck Berry and helped launch the dawn of rock 'n' roll; two jockeys, one of them with the most victories in thoroughbred racing history and the other a 20-year-old making his Kentucky Derby debut; and a certain white-haired trainer who in recent years has nearly put a stranglehold on America's most famous race.

We extend our deepest sympathies to Edith and her husband, Henry, and to the entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that North Korea had put forward a plan in its meeting with American and Chinese envoys last week under which it would ''deal with'' its nuclear programs but would ''expect something considerable in return.''

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY INCREASES STAKE IN PETROCHINA
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment vehicle of Warren E. Buffett, raised its stake in the PetroChina Company, China's biggest oil producer, for the third time this month, prompting some investors to buy the stock. Berkshire Hathaway bought 85.37 million shares on April 11 and 31.41 million more four days later, PetroChina said in an April 25 filing to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. Berkshire now owns 9.1 percent of PetroChina's publicly traded stock, or 0.9 percent of the company. China's government has a 90 percent stake.

description: To the Editor:

description: Brandishing a big microphone and even bigger questions, Dr. Neil DeGrasse Tyson bounded nimbly about a stage in the American Museum of Natural History the other night, playing a sort of Jerry Springer of science.

title: Henderson Heads to Newark For Path Back to Majors
description: At 44, with 24 memorable major league seasons behind him, Rickey Henderson says he has plenty of baseball left. And that, he said yesterday, is why he signed last week with the Newark Bears of the independent Atlantic League and hopes to make his debut Thursday night against Bridgeport in the season opener at Newark's Riverfront Stadium.

title: To Commute to Capital, Early Bird Gets 'Slugs'
description: A chilly dawn is breaking over the Horner Road commuter parking lot in Woodbridge, 25 miles south of Washington, D.C. A woman in a white Mercedes pulls up to the front of the line of people dressed for office work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, EDWIN S.
description: MARKS-Edwin S. The directors, officers, associates and staff of Carl Marks & Co, and its affiliated companies mourn the passing of our beloved and admired friend, colleague and chairman. Edwin Marks was a man of keen intelligence, unshakable integrity and great compassion for his fellow human beings. His philanthropy was legendary, as was his profound love of family and country. We extend our deepest sympathy to his adored Nancy, his daughters Carolyn, Linda, and Connie, his sister Marjorie Boas Levins and all the other members of the Marks and Boas families.

title: Control Freak, Finagler And Hollywood Legend
description: When Lord Weidenfeld suggested to Sam Spiegel that he write his memoirs, Spiegel rejected the idea as ''maledictory.'' That word, Natasha Fraser-Cavassoni said, was ''a Spiegelism meaning a bad omen.'' Writing her biography ''Sam Spiegel,'' Ms. Fraser-Cavassoni was determined to deal with all sides of this prismatic character, the con man who was ''a great finagler'' and the glamorous figure she knew when she was a teenager.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Corvis Infringed Ciena Patent, Jury Says
description: The Corvis Corporation, which makes equipment for fiber optic telecommunications systems, infringed a patent owned by its rival, the Ciena Corporation, a federal court jury decided yesterday. The verdict came after a different jury in the same court said last month that Corvis products used technology protected by another Ciena patent, but did not infringe two other patents. Damages will be determined at a separate trial before Judge Joseph Farnan Jr. after appeals, according to court papers. Both companies were founded by the inventor David R. Huber, Ciena in 1992 and Corvis in 1997, lawyers said during the three-day trial. Ciena reported $361.1 million in fiscal 2002 sales and a $1.59 billion loss, while Corvis reported $20.2 million in 2002 sales and a $507.7 million loss, as the industry struggles through a worldwide slowdown. While Mr. Huber is listed as one of four inventors on the 1996 Ciena patent, he did not have a license when he left to form Corvis, and ''it's wrong to take somebody else's technology,'' Ciena's lawyer, Ruffin Cordell, told jurors in Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del. Company officials did not immediately return phone calls seeking comment. Shares of Ciena rose 24 cents, or about 5.8 percent, to $4.46. Shares of Corvis dropped 8 cents, to 73 cents.

title: 10 WALL ST. FIRMS REACH SETTLEMENT IN ANALYST INQUIRY
description: Prosecutors announced a settlement today with the nation's biggest investment firms that bars the head of the largest bank from talking to his analysts, details a far greater range of conflicts of interest than previously disclosed, and leaves the industry exposed both to further regulation and costly litigation.

title: A Family Gone AWOL And a Baby Gone Awry
description: Our only child was born seven years ago with a rare birth defect requiring multiple surgeries and three months in neonatal intensive care.

title: Iggy and the Stooges And Nods to Yesterday
description: The audience and bands at this year's Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival here seemed to be coalescing around a musical theme: the 60's.

title: A Bit of Self-Mockery, a Lot of Stamina
description: ''Die Meistersinger'' returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday, and while the Otto Schenk staging, with sets by Gnther Schneider-Siemssen, retains its archival fidelity to 16th-century Nrnberg, it suggests a few hints of shabbiness as well. Maybe the impression of wear is in our heads, the product of a Met production seen a few times too many. In any case, durability is a Wagnerian virtue, and in middle age this ''Meistersinger'' has by general agreement all its moving parts still in workable shape.

title: Critic's Notebook; London Is Agog Over Art, Especially Saatchi's
description: This city is art besotted. Mobs congregate for Titian before the National Gallery opens in the morning. The show is stupendous, somehow more impressive for being crowded into the gallery's basement, where temporary shows go, an uncongenial space that I imagined would diminish the exhibition's effect. Instead, hung without ostentation, the pictures looked grander by contrast with their setting.

title: Rose Augustine, 93; Championed the Guitar
description: Rose Augustine, a former chemistry teacher who with her husband revolutionized the world of the classical guitar by developing the nylon guitar string and who commissioned new works and underwrote concert series and competitions, died on April 21 in Manhattan. She was 93 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Patients on Anticlotting Drug Face a Tricky Balancing Act
description: David Bloom was a talented and intrepid journalist. He died just shy of his 40th birthday while covering the war in Iraq for NBC. He died seemingly suddenly, but not from hostile or friendly fire.

title: Police Lessons In Free Speech And Missteps
description: TACITLY, the Bloomberg administration acknowledges that it blundered in February when it refused to let antiwar protesters march in Midtown, as their kindred spirits were able to do, trouble-free, in cities around the globe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, MARY ROSENFELD
description: SANDERS-Mary Rosenfeld, 54 of New York died Sunday. Artist & organizer, sweet Mary was Administrative Coordinator, Department of Photographs at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She had worked in MOMA's Film Department and in the 1980s as Director of Logistics, CBS News Special Events. For many years Mary lived in Moscow with her beloved husband, Jonathan, where she taught art, sculpted and painted. Daughter of the late Buddy and Evelyn of Hewlett, New York and Tamarac, Florida. Mary leaves behind her adored sister Jackie Schuyler and husband Andy of Springfield, NJ, sister-inlaw Ellen Sanders of West Hartford, CT and especially close cousin Meryl Freedman and husband Bruce of West Simsbury, CT. Mary doted on her nieces and nephews Adam and Charlie Schuyler, Joy Radish and Ross Nirenstein and her Freedman cousins: Scott, Stacey, and Eric. She cherished cousins Marc, Eileen and Nicholas Hecker as well as Sybil Sanders, her dear mother-inlaw. Burial will be Tuesday 29 April at 1 pm at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, 7800 Myrtle Avenue Glendale (Queens) NY. Donations may be made to Women at Risk, Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, 601 W. 168th St., NY, NY 10032

title: U.S.-Europe Discord Rocks the Shared Economic Boat
description: Louis Vuitton of France sells its handbags there and Antinori of Italy its wines. The German software maker SAP sells more of its products there than it does at home.

title: GB&T AGREES TO BUY FIRST NATIONAL BANK OF THE SOUTH
description: GB&T Bancshares Inc., the parent of Gainesville Bank and Trust, agreed to buy First National Bank of the South for $25.9 million in stock, gaining an entry into the market south of metropolitan Atlanta. GB&T will exchange 2.895 shares of its stock for each share in First National Bank's privately held parent, Baldwin Bancshares, GB&T's chief executive, Richard Hunt, said. GB&T's other banks include United Bank and Trust and Community Trust Bank. The company is based in Gainesville, Ga.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: McCarthy Quietly Changes Registration
description: Carolyn McCarthy, a Democratic congresswoman for the last six years, has recently changed her party registration to Democratic from Republican, her spokesman acknowledged. The spokesman declined to elaborate. Ms. McCarthy first ran for Congress against a Republican incumbent after her husband, Dennis, was fatally shot while riding the Long Island Rail Road. The McCarthys had been registered Republicans. ''Everybody sees you as a Democrat,'' a colleague once said about Representative McCarthy, ''but I'll bet you haven't switched because it's the only thing you have left from your former life.'' Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Leaders, With Upper Hand, Give Pataki Time on Budget
description: The state's two top legislative leaders delayed adoption of a state budget today to give Gov. George E. Pataki more time to sign onto their spending plan, even as they sent a strong message to the Republican governor that they had the votes and willingness to act without him.

title: Did the Case for War Hold Up?
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress, Back at Work, Tries to Mend Breach Over Tax Cut
description: Congress returned today, and Congressional Republicans quickly set out to devise a strategy to enact President Bush's proposed tax cut and repair a rift between House and Senate leaders over the size of the reduction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITLEY, EDWARD D., CSP
description: WHITLEY-Edward D., CSP. On April 26, 2003 at age 78. Born in Newburyport, Massachusetts on September 8, 1924. He attended Currier Grade School in Newburyport, MA, and Newburyport & Governor Dummer Academy High Schools before going to the Paulist Fathers Juniorate in 1948. Taking summer courses at Harvard College in Cambridge, MA he earned his Masters degree in history and theology at the Paulist Fathers Major Seminary in Washington DC. Fr. Ed was ordained May 1, 1951 at the Paulist Fathers first foundation, St. Paul the Apostle Church, in Mid-town Manhattan. His considerable preaching talents took him to Lubbock, TX, Rome, Italy, Layton, UT, Toronto, Canada, and Detroit. A ten year stint preaching missions for the Air Force took him to every continent on earth and every state in the nation. Since the early 70's until recently he served as General Treasurer of the Paulist Fathers, and helping out on a regular basis at St. John the Evangelist Church in Beverly, MA. Once the official chaplain of the Baltimore Colts, he was noted for his good humor and captivating smile. Fr. Whitley is survived by his sister Margaret Roney of Newburyport MA, and his nephew James Roney of Richmond, VA. Viewing will be at Saint John the Evangelist in Beverly on Tuesday, April 29th. His body will be received at the Church at 7:00 p.m. with a Wake Service at 8:00 p.m. Fr. George Butera, the pastor, will preside. Mass of the Resurrection on Wednesday, April 30th at 10:00 a.m. Fr. Robert A. O'Donnell, CSP, one of Ed's classmates will preach and Fr. John Duffy, CSP, president of the Paulist Fathers will preside. Burial will follow at Saint Joseph's Cemetery in West Roxbury. In lieu of flowers please make a donation to The Paulist Fathers Retirement Fund

title: Edwin S. Marks, 76, Banker and Philanthropist
description: Edwin Saul Marks, an investment banker and supporter of Lincoln Center as well as medical and other cultural institutions, died on Thursday at his home in Great Neck, N.Y. He was 76.

title: Legal Immigrants Can Be Held Without Bail, Court Says
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 - The Supreme Court ruled today, in a case with significant impact on the rights of noncitizens, that the federal government can detain legal immigrants without bail during their deportation proceedings.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Law On Tax-Refund Loans
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed into law yesterday a bill that requires tax preparers to disclose the fees associated with so-called refund anticipation loans, also known as rapid refund loans. According to Mr. Bloomberg, few customers are aware how much the interest charges, loan costs and related fees will reduce the tax refunds they expect from the government. ''The disclosure requirements of this bill will ensure that consumers are informed about the costs associated with refund anticipation loans,'' he said. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Roddick Plays At Rockefeller Center
description: Less than 24 hours after losing a three-set match to Andre Agassi at the United States Men's Clay Court Championships in Houston, Andy Roddick was back on the court yesterday. This time, he was at the Rockefeller Center ice rink in Manhattan, hitting a few lobs, smiling for the cameras and playing the role of ambassador for the United States Tennis Association's kickoff of USA Tennis Month.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Growth Forecast Cut
description: The Asian Development Bank lowered its forecast for Philippine economic growth to 4 percent from 4.5 percent, warning that the government's budget deficit was preventing it from providing a fiscal stimulus. The revision follows last week's move by the rating agency Standard & Poor's to lower the credit ratings of the Philippines after the government exceeded its budget deficit target for the first quarter. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Forget Oscar and Felix: Messiness Is No Laughing Matter
description: What really distinguishes man from beast? Well, it's nothing as lofty as the philosophers would have us believe. Forget about theory of mind, morality or even the culinary arts. It's much simpler: the capacity to make a mess.

description: IF a front-page assault in The Onion, the weekly satirical newspaper, is any indicator that a new trend has reached cultural critical mass, the marketers of tooth-whitening products must have been dancing in the cubicle aisles last week.

description: A police detective testified today that Lee Malvo, the younger defendant in the Washington area sniper shootings, was read his rights before confessing to some of the attacks but that she continued to interrogate him without a lawyer after he requested one.

description: TORONTO, April 29  Citing a sudden ebb in the SARS epidemic here, the World Health Organization today lifted a week-old advisory urging that travelers delay all unnecessary travel to Toronto because of the outbreak of the mysterious respiratory disease.

title: U.S. Troops Fire on Iraqi Protesters, Leaving 15 Dead
description: FALLUJAH, Iraq, April 29  American soldiers shot dead what hospital officials said were 15 people at an anti-American rally here late on Monday. Accounts of the incident, which occurred on Saddam Hussein's birthday, varied widely today: Iraqis said the soldiers opened fire, unprovoked, while the soldiers said they were fired on first and then responded with a careful counter-attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, GARY
description: RUBIN-Gary. The American Jewish Committee mourns with deep sorrow the passing of Gary Rubin, our dear colleague and friend. Gary's boundless passion for Jewish life and his lifelong commitment to helping others, no matter their faith or ethnicity, is a continuing inspiration to all in the Jewish community. Gary's tireless efforts to realize the aspirations of a democratic, pluralistic America that was founded and continues to be strengthened by the diversity of our nation's population was largely the focus of his tenure at the American Jewish Committee, where he worked for 13 years, principally as Director of National Affairs. He devoted himself similarly to Jewish peoplehood and to the State of Israel. The sages were speaking of Gary when they wrote, in Ethics of the Fathers, ''the world rests on three pillars, Torah, communal service and deeds of kindness.'' We extend our heartfelt condolences to Gary's wife, Sheila, and to their children, Ari, Michal, Jonah and Bracha. David A. Harris, Exec. Dir. Shulamit Bahat Associate Executive Director American Jewish Committee

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATTISTI, ANTHONY M.
description: BATTISTI-Anthony M., suddenly on April 27, 2003, of New Hyde Park, NY. Cherished husband of Michele. Beloved father of Anthony, Toni and Stephanie. Adored grandfather of Ian, Marc, Alec and Evan. Reposing at Park Funeral Chapel, 2175 Jericho Turnpike, Garden City Park, NY, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10AM, St. Mary's R.C. Church. Entombment Pinelawn Memorial Park.

title: Former Domestic Security Aides Make a Quick Switch to Lobbying
description: When Tom Ridge arrived here after the Sept. 11 attacks and opened the White House Office of Homeland Security, the former Pennsylvania governor quickly surrounded himself with a group of trusted deputies, many of them drawn from the staff he assembled as governor.

description: Using sunscreen daily reduces the risk of skin lesions that are associated with skin cancer, Australian researchers have found.

title: CHIQUITA SELLS PANAMANIAN FRUIT UNIT FOR $19.8 MILLION
description: Chiquita Brands International Inc., the world's biggest banana producer, agreed to sell its money-losing Panamanian fruit business to a worker-owned cooperative for $19.8 million. The company will lend the group, Cooperativa de Servicios Mltiples de Puerto Armuelles, $5 million toward the purchase of the business, the Puerto Armuelles Fruit Company. A local bank will finance the rest, a Chiquita spokesman, Michael Mitchell, said. Chiquita, which is based in Cincinnati, has said it wants to cut $150 million in costs by next year.

description: Adam B. Kaufman, 29, describes his skin as a ''personal hell'' that leaves him in unrelenting pain.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Electronics Loss
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the maker of the Panasonic brand, said that it lost 19.5 billion yen ($162.3 million) in the year that ended March 31, a fraction of the record 431 billion yen it lost a year ago. Sales for the year rose 5 percent, helped by demand for flat-panel televisions and digital videodisc players. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Invoking Price Cuts, Procter & Gamble Lifts Profit
description: Procter & Gamble reported yesterday that its quarterly profit rose 22 percent amid higher sales of Crest toothpaste and Pampers diapers. Earnings this quarter may exceed analyst forecasts, the company said.

description: DEARBORN, Mich., April 28  President Bush said today that he would make good on his promise to bring stability to Iraq, and that Iraqis of all faiths and ethnic backgrounds could be assured of a voice in their new government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAYER, HERMAN R. (HANK)
description: NAYER-Herman R. (Hank) died in his sleep on April 23, 2003 in Oakland, California. He was 93 years old and had been living at St. Paul's Towers in Oakland, CA for the past 16 years. A graduate of Yale, class of '30, and of the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia, class of '34, Dr. Nayer was an internist who specialized in pulmonary medicine. He practiced at his office on 86th Street and at the NY Veterans Administration, Montefiore and Beth Israel Hospitals over a career that spanned 53 years and which included being a founding member and Medical Director of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York (HIP), a president of the New York Lung Association and a Medical Officer with the New York City Fire Department. During WW II, Dr. Nayer served in the Army as a Captain and Chief of Medical Services as part of the European African Middle Eastern Campaign in Persia. A Renaissance man of extraordinary intelligence, he was a member of Phi Beta Kappa and Alpha Omega Al Phi (medical honor society). An avid reader and scholar, he was a lover of Shakespeare, Freud and mathemathics and his curiosity ranged from politics to poetry. Herman Nayer was beloved by his patients for his kindness, expertise and sense of humor and will be sorely missed by his daughters, Anne of Davis, CA and Louise, of San Francisco, son-in-law Jim and granddaughters Sarah, Laura and Lily. (His wife Dorothy died in 2001).

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Rape Suspect Sought
description: The police are looking for a man they believe raped and robbed two women and attempted to rob a third at gunpoint this month and raped another woman in 1998. All of the attacks occurred in Hollis. On April 7 at 5:45 a.m., a 57-year-old woman was waiting for a bus at 193rd Street and Jamaica Avenue, when the suspect, who had a gun, took her to an isolated location, where he raped and robbed her, the police said. On April 23 at 5:50 a.m., the armed suspect tried to drag a 61-year-old woman into a driveway near the corner of Liberty Avenue and 187th Street. She yelled for help, and he fled. Two days later, a 60-year-old woman was waiting for a bus at the corner of Liberty and Camden Avenues when the armed suspect took her to an isolated location and robbed and raped her. DNA obtained after the attacks matched DNA obtained after an unsolved rape in 1998, in which a 46-year-old woman was sexually assaulted near 102nd Avenue and 186th Street, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: 2-Man Crew, With Modified Duties, Reaches Space Station
description: The pared-down relief crew arrived at the International Space Station today, just two men who will work to keep the massive project running in place until American space shuttles fly again and construction can resume.

description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder gained ground today for his politically divisive plan to overhaul Germany's paralyzed economy, as new statistics showed how desperately the country needs a jolt.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Worldcom Posts 2-Month Loss Of $289 Million
description: WorldCom Inc. had a combined net loss of $289 million in February and March as sales fell. WorldCom had net income of $43 million in March after a net loss of $332 million in February, the company said yesterday. Sales in March were $2.1 billion, up from $2.03 billion in February. Revenue from long-distance phone and data services has fallen as slack demand prompted WorldCom and rivals like AT&T and Sprint to cut prices. WorldCom, the No. 2 long-distance phone company in the country, filed for bankruptcy protection in July after admitting to accounting irregularities that totaled $11 billion.

description: The question was about tax loopholes and whether the 10 securities firms that agreed to pay $1.4 billion to resolve charges of wrongdoing by their research analysts would be able to squirm out of their plight by writing off their fines. title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Subway Security
description: The City Council's public safety and transportation committees have scheduled a joint public hearing on security in the subways. Council Chambers, City Hall, 1 p.m. Information: (718) 888-8747.

title: Matters of Emphasis
description: ''We were not lying,'' a Bush administration official told ABC News. ''But it was just a matter of emphasis.'' The official was referring to the way the administration hyped the threat that Saddam Hussein posed to the United States. According to the ABC report, the real reason for the war was that the administration ''wanted to make a statement.'' And why Iraq? ''Officials acknowledge that Saddam had all the requirements to make him, from their standpoint, the perfect target.''

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Dataram To Dismiss About 28% Of Work Force
description: The Dataram Corporation, a maker of memory products for servers built by companies like Dell Computer and Hewlett-Packard, will lay off about 28 percent of its work force and close a plant in Denmark to save money. Dataram will shift manufacturing from its Aarhus, Denmark, plant to one in Bucks County, Pa., the company said yesterday. The changes will save about $7 million a year. Pretax costs will total about $5 million in the fourth quarter, which ends tomorrow. Dataram will also write off about $11 million in purchased good will. Dataram said it would eliminate jobs and close the Denmark production center as companies cut spending on information technology because of the weak economy.

title: AMERICAN FORCES AND TERROR GROUP REACH CEASE-FIRE
description: American forces in Iraq have signed a cease-fire with an Iranian opposition group the United States has designated a terrorist organization, and expect it to surrender soon with some of its arms, American military officials said today.

title: Briefly Noted
description: IRAQI OFFICIAL ARRESTED The former Iraqi oil minister, Amir Rashid Muhammad al-Ubaydi, has surrendered to American forces, the United States Central Command said. He has been in custody since Monday, American officials in Qatar said. Mr. Ubaydi was listed as Number 47 on the list of the 55 most-wanted officials from Saddam Hussein's government.

title: Stakeholder Speaks Out To Koreans
description: The Monaco-based investment fund that holds the biggest single stake in the SK Corporation, South Korea's largest oil refiner, offered strongly worded advice today about how the company should spend its money.

title: Whiff of Spam Leaves Web Sites Offline
description: Scores of Web sites were taken off the Internet over the weekend because of new pressures on a commercial Internet service provider to stop unwanted marketing e-mail, or spam, and the companies that use it.

title: California Lawmakers Move to Fight U.S. Pollution Rules
description: A group of state legislators moved today to undercut revised regulations by the Bush administration that give utilities and other industrial plants more flexibility in complying with air pollution standards.

title: Standards and the Party Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Finally, Good News About SARS
description: Just when the reports about SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome, seemed to be getting bleaker, the World Health Organization issued some encouraging news yesterday. The agency said Vietnam, one of the first countries to be hit hard by SARS, had succeeded in stopping the local spread of the disease. Agency officials also said the epidemic appeared to have peaked in Hong Kong, Singapore and Canada, with fewer new cases being reported every day. Hong Kong is still far from containing the epidemic, but Canadian authorities say they have seen no transmissions outside health care settings for well over a week now. All this suggests that aggressive public health measures may indeed be able to contain this new and potentially fatal pneumonia.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Sexual Orientation Protection
description: State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi announced yesterday that he had signed executive orders that explicitly protect transgendered employees working in his office from discrimination and harassment. The transgendered includes transsexuals and transvestites. Last year, Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation to protect employees from discrimination based on their sexual orientation. The comptroller's orders, which were signed earlier this month, cover the 2,300 employees in Mr. Hevesi's office and outside contractors. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Women Brush Off the Hardships of Rebel Life
description: Three weeks ago, Mahnaz Bazazi was an ally of Saddam Hussein, a member of a terrorist group and an enemy of the United States. That is why an allied bomb hit the military base where she works. Three women were killed in the attack and Ms. Bazazi lost both her legs.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: ASYLUM SEEKERS LEAVE Britain forcibly sent 30 failed asylum seekers home to Afghanistan, the first Afghans it has deported since dropping the practice in 1995 because of instability there. The number of asylum seekers in Britain is a major issue in local elections on Thursday, and the government has pledged to halve the number of new arrivals by September. Thousands of Afghans have claimed asylum in Britain over the past decade, with 7,380 in 2002 alone. A voluntary procedure was set up offering $4,000 for anyone willingly returning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, IRVING
description: SHERMAN-Irving, on April 28th. Dearest husband of Etty. Devoted father of Sandy Nathanson and Jill Goldstein. Loving brother of Ann Sugarman and Robert. Adored grandfather of Howard, Ilene, Elizabeth, and Scott Goldstein, and Morgan and Emily Nathanson. Respected father-in-law of Allen and Aaron. Services, Wednesday, 1 PM at ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapels, 2576 Flatbush Ave. (near Ave. V), Brooklyn. Interment at the Baron Hirsch Cemetery. Irving will be missed by all of his friends and associates. Donations can be made to the Calvary Hospice.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: TEENAGERS QUESTIONED IN DEATH The police are questioning three teenage boys, whom they did not identify, in connection with the shooting death of a 12-year-old Chicago boy who was killed just after participating in a neighborhood cleanup. The boy, Rene Guillen, whose family recently moved into the neighborhood, was killed on Saturday, possibly by gang members who were looking for someone else, the police said. Rene, a seventh grader, was hit when a group of teenagers fired into a crowd of children.

title: Former Mayor of Paterson Is Given 37 Months for Bribery
description: Former Mayor Martin G. Barnes of Paterson was sentenced to 37 months in prison today on charges of taking $200,000 to $350,000 in bribes and gratuities from city contractors. During the sentencing, a federal judge expressed concern that Mr. Barnes failed to take responsibility for his actions even after pleading guilty.

title: OBITUARY : Richard Lankford, diplomat
description: Richard Lankford, 55, director of the press and information office of the U.S. Embassy in Paris since October 2000, died on April 18, the embassy announced.

title: Citigroup's Chairman Is Barred From Direct Talks With Analysts
description: Moving decisively to prevent bias in future research reports, the regulatory settlement announced yesterday bars Sanford I. Weill, chairman of Citigroup, and other senior officers from talking to Citigroup's research analysts on investment banking matters without a company lawyer present.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Passaic: Newborn Found Abandoned
description: The police are searching for the mother of a newborn baby left in a garbage can near an abandoned house early Sunday. The baby girl, who weighs 7 pounds 4 ounces, was barely breathing when discovered by passers-by but was listed in very good condition last night at Passaic General Hospital, said Detective Roy Bordamonte of the Passaic police. Passers-by had heard a muffled cry from the garbage and telephoned the police, he said. Detective Bordamonte said the baby was born about 1 a.m. A trail of blood led to the garbage can from the abandoned house. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: GETRONICS TO CUT JOBS The debt-ridden Dutch information technology company Getronics said yesterday that it would close 20 offices and eliminate 1,000 to 1,200 jobs as part of a reorganization that could cost up to 60 million euros ($66 million). Getronics, already suffering from a continuing technology slump, is struggling to survive under the weight of half a billion euros in debt, much of it acquired in association with its 1999 purchase of Wang Global of Billerica, Mass.   Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Radio Performance Closely Watched at Viacom
description: When John Sykes was named chief executive of Viacom's Infinity Broadcasting radio unit in March 2002, he hoped to add some of cable television's razzle-dazzle to the medium. Mr. Sykes, the former chief of the company's VH1 cable network, did not just want ''records all day long with disc jockeys.'' He was eager to incorporate more star power into troubled stations' programming, with visits from celebrities and plenty of news and gossip about them.

title: Q & A
description: Earlobe Crease

title: Iraqi Scientist Says U.S. Unlikely to Find Biological Weapons
description: Iraq's biological weapons program was shut down by economic sanctions in the 1990s and U.S. search teams are unlikely to find evidence of those efforts now, a leading program scientist said Monday.

title: Did the Case for War Hold Up?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Urges Passage of Bill to Provide $15 Billion for AIDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 — President Bush urged Congress today to swiftly pass legislation that would triple United States spending to contain the global AIDS scourge, putting aside conservatives' complaints that the legislation should favor sexual abstinence over condom use as the preferred disease preventative.

title: Spending by Consumers Rose As Incomes Gained in March
description: Americans spent more in March for the second consecutive month, the government reported today, returning to stores after February snowstorms and taking advantage of promotions to buy new vehicles.

title: Hypocrisy on Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. Is Said to Be Concentrating on Terror
description: Criminal investigators at the Environmental Protection Agency are referring fewer cases and working more on counterterrorism efforts and guarding Christie Whitman, the agency's administrator, according to interviews with senior agents and a report released today by an advocacy group.

title: W.H.O. Says Outbreak Is Fading in Vietnam and 3 Other Places
description: The World Health Organization today lifted its advisory against travel to Vietnam and said that SARS infections appeared to be dwindling in Singapore, Canada and here, but warned that the disease was still spreading in China.

title: Sports of The Times; Coaches Can Leave, Not Players
description: A FEW weeks ago I passed Ben Howland in the corridor of the Metrodome in Minneapolis. His Pittsburgh team had suffered a heartbreaking upset loss to Marquette in the third round of the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament. While Howland seemed deeply discouraged, he did not seemed crushed. There had been speculation for weeks that Howland would leave Pittsburgh after four seasons to move back home to California and become the head basketball coach at U.C.L.A.

title: Did the Case for War Hold Up?
description: To the Editor:

title: In 9/11 Design, Rules Are Set To Be Broken
description: Officials overseeing the competition to design a memorial to the victims of the terrorist attack of Sept. 11, 2001, and the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center promised yesterday that all entries would be considered, even those that stray from the official guidelines for the placement and content of the memorial.

title: Bush, Visiting Michigan, Promises All Iraqis a Voice in a New Government
description: President Bush said today that he would make good on his promise to bring stability to Iraq, and that Iraqis of all faiths and ethnic backgrounds could be assured of a voice in their new government.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The analogy is that if this were an operating room, they disinfected everything but the scalpel. The scalpel is left dirty.''

title: Columbia Opens Unit On Disasters
description: Columbia University has lured one of the stars of New York City's health care industry, Dr. Irwin Redlener, away from Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx to head a new policy center on disaster preparedness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUMLER, EGON
description: DUMLER-Egon. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed Member, Friar Egon Dumler, on April 26, 2003. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Private services were held. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, ELLEN DALE
description: LERNER-Ellen Dale. On April 27, 2003, age 53. Touched by an angel. Loved by everyone who knew her. Mourned by her devoted husband, Kirk Miller, her stepdaughter, Laura Miller, who called her mother, her sister, Amy L. Jans, her ''sistie'', and her parents, Bette and Byron Lerner, who adored her. Memorial service Wednesday, April 30 at 2 p.m. at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue and 91st Street. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the American Diabetes Association.

title: No Headline
Review/Fashion; Unraveling From Without, The Goddess in Everywoman
description: Even now, after works by Seurat have made their way to the walls of hotels in Las Vegas and dozens of graduate students have spent hours examining the cultural merits of Sidney Sheldon, there is still something jarring about looking into a vitrine at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and seeing a placard with the name ''Kylie Minogue.''

title: Sorenstam Tunes Up, Tunes Out
description: As the most compelling challenge of her career draws closer, Annika Sorenstam is fine-tuning her game, and tuning out her critics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOVAN, FLORENCE
description: DONOVAN - Florence. On April 26; died peacefully after a long, rich life. Survived by daughters Sally Madden and Winkie Plummer and three grandsons, Matthew, Andrew, and Peter Madden. She will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBECK, ELAINE A.
description: STEINBECK-Elaine A. On April 27, 2003 at age 88. Beloved wife of the late Nobel Laureate and Pulitzer Prize Winning Author, John Steinbeck. Mother of Waverly Scott Kaffaga and stepmother of Thomas Steinbeck and the late John Steinbeck IV. Grandmother of David Farber, Anderson Farber, Jebel Kaffaga and Bahar Kaffaga. Also survived by her sisters Jean Boone and Frances Atkinson. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Thursday, May 1st, 3PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Center for Steinbeck Studies at San Jose State University, San Jose, Ca, Bay Street Theater, Sag Harbor, N.Y. or Zachary Scott Theater Center, Austin, TX.

title: In Twist, Defendant Admits to Stabbing In Crown Hts. in '91
description: Through almost 12 years and two previous trials, lawyers for Lemrick Nelson Jr. denied that he was involved in the killing of an Orthodox Jew named Yankel Rosenbaum during the racial unrest in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, in 1991.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Church Reception Fells 13
description: One person died and twelve others fell seriously ill after attending a church reception in New Sweden on Sunday. The thirteen, all parishioners at the Gustaf Adolph Lutheran Church, were all thought to have drunk coffee and eaten dayold sandwiches and cake there. Some of the stricken have said the coffee tasted odd. State police and health officials are focusing on the food, which was left over from a bake sale, but will not rule out any other factors. An autopsy will be performed on the victim, 78-year-old Walter Morrill of New Sweden, on Tuesday. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Education Dept. Hires 108 Local Supervisors
description: The city's Education Department has hired 108 people -- most of them currently superintendents or school principals -- to serve as local instructional supervisors, a new administrative position that is crucial to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's systemwide reorganization of the public schools.

title: Cordiant at New Risk as Client Quits and Key Deadline Nears
description: The survival of the Cordiant Communications Group, the ailing advertising company, was thrown into doubt today when the company said its biggest agency had lost a major client, the liquor maker Allied Domecq, and that it might not be able to report its 2002 earnings by a May 1 deadline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIBERSON, HAROLD
description: EIBERSON-Harold, 89, on April 28, 2003. Services Wednesday, April 30, 12 noon, Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

title: GOODRICH LOWERS FORECAST AND CUTS 1,700 JOBS
description: The Goodrich Corporation said yesterday that it planned to lay off 1,700 workers in the next two years and slashed its 2003 profit forecast amid falling demand from plane makers. Profit from continuing operations this year is expected to be 27 cents to 42 cents a share, Goodrich said. Its previous forecast was for $1.45 to $1.60 a share. Costs this year for write-downs, job cuts and plant closings will be more than five times what was expected, Goodrich said. The company gets about a third of sales from the Boeing Company and Airbus, which have cut production as the air travel slump continues. Goodrich gave the lower forecast after reporting that first-quarter profit more than doubled because of proceeds from the sale of a business. Excluding that gain, the company posted a loss. First-quarter net income rose to $29.4 million, or 25 cents a share, from $14.3 million, or 15 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 23 percent, to $1.1 billion from $896 million.

title: City and State to Give Free Asthma Care to Homeless Children
description: After three years of litigation, New York City and the state have agreed to provide free medical care to thousands of homeless children with asthma.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BREWER TO SELL ASSETS Scottish and Newcastle, one of Europe's biggest brewers, unveiled plans to sell its entire pubs business to pay for the expanding its brewing operations. The sale of about 1,450 pubs, hotels and restaurants is expected to raise about 2 billion ($3.2 billion). The company, based in Edinburgh, also said it wanted to acquire HP Bulmer, an English cider maker, and had bid 165 million ($263 million) for it. It also wants to buy the whole of the Central de Cervejas brewing group of Portugal, in which it currently owns a 49 percent stake, and the associated business of Sociedade da Agua de Luso. Scottish and Newcastle already owns 3 of Europe's top 10 beers in Kronenbourg, Fosters and Baltika. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

title: Wasteful Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel Gadgets That Promise Safety and Security Are Selling Briskly
description: Years before anyone heard of severe acute respiratory syndrome, Ronald D. Salk, a travel executive based in Long Beach, Calif., frequently caught a cold or suffered from congestion after returning home from long-distance flights.

title: Europe Reveals Plan for Closer, More Independent Military Ties
description: BRUSSELS, April 29  Their goals may have been laudable but their timing could not have been worse.

description: Here's a news item you may have missed:

title: Vitamins: More May Be Too Many
description: A growing number of medical experts are concerned that Americans are overdoing their vitamin consumption. As many as 70 percent of the population is taking supplements, mostly vitamins, convinced that the pills will make them healthier.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: SURGE IN SHIPBUILDING ORDERS Hyundai Heavy Industries said it tripled the value of shipbuilding contracts in the first quarter compared with the first quarter of last year. The company, the world's largest manufacturer of merchant ships, said contracts signed from Jan. 1 to March 31 were worth $2.4 billion, while those signed a year earlier were worth $762 million. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: GIRL RAPED AT SCHOOL A 14-year-old girl was raped by two 14-year-old boys at their school yesterday, the police said. The attack occurred at Intermediate School 302, at 350 Linwood Street, in Highland Park, inside a first floor bathroom, the police said. No weapon was used, said Officer Louis Camacho. The victim was taken to Brookdale Hospital. No one had been arrested as of late last night. A call to a Department of Education spokesman was not immediately returned. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: After an Actress's Shooting Death, an Ad Echoes Her Life
description: On the Saturday before Lyric Benson was murdered, she paused on the street with her mother and a friend to look at herself in a giant American Express advertisement, and they giggled.

title: Corrections
description: A correction on April 19 about the obituary of Michael Wayne, a son of John Wayne, was published in error. The name on the father's birth certificate was indeed Marion Robert Morrison, as the obituary said on April 4; the middle name was informally changed to Michael later when a younger brother was named Robert.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Brewer To Sell Assets

The sale of about 1,450 pubs, hotels and restaurants is expected to raise about 2 billion ($3.2 billion). The company, based in Edinburgh, also said it wanted to acquire HP Bulmer, an English cider maker, and had bid 165 million ($263 million) for it. It also wants to buy the whole of the Central de Cervejas brewing group of Portugal, in which it currently owns a 49 percent stake, and the associated business of Sociedade da gua de Luso. title: Corrections
description: An article on April 4 about the appointment of a dean at Harvard Law School referred imprecisely to the views of a third-year student who surveyed fellow Harvard students, and a correction in this space last Tuesday summarized The Harvard Crimson's coverage of his survey incorrectly. The student, Michael J. Passante, says he speculated that law students at Yale and Stanford might be happier than those at Harvard. He did not conclude that they are happier, nor did his survey address the question. The Crimson article merely quoted Mr. Passante; it did not attribute his view to the survey.

title: Newspaper in Seattle Sues Rival That Is Also Partner
description: The Seattle Post-Intelligencer and its parent company, the Hearst Corporation, filed suit here today against the Seattle Times Company, hoping to block any attempt by The Times to dissolve a 20-year-old joint operating arrangement between the papers.

title: Quite a Day for MetroStar
description: BOB BRADLEY's first victory as the MetroStars' coach, 1-0 over Columbus, was also his 83rd in Major League Soccer, a league record. The rookie MIKE MAGEE set a team record when he became the youngest player (18 years 236 days) to score a goal, his first as a professional.

title: SARS IS THE SPARK FOR A RIOT IN CHINA
description: Thousands of people rioted in this rural town on Sunday night and ransacked a local school, residents said, after word spread that the four-story building would be turned into a ward for patients suffering from severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about a Russian Soyuz rocket carrying two astronauts to the International Space Station referred incorrectly in some copies to the launching time. It was Saturday, local time, not Friday.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Air India Bombing Trial
description: The murder trial of two Sikh immigrants accused of involvement in the bombing of an Air India flight nearly 18 years ago that took the lives of 329 people began in a new high-security courtroom. Ripudaman Singh Malik, left, a Vancouver millionaire, and Ajaib Singh Bagri, a 53-year-old sawmill worker from Kamloops, British Columbia, pleaded not guilty. The case has been marred by erasures of wiretap evidence. Several witnesses have died, two under suspicious circumstances. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Chief Executives Named at 2 Agencies
description: Senior managers at two agencies are being promoted to chief executive.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Bertram Ross, a longtime leading member of the Martha Graham Dance Company, misstated the length of his relationship with his surviving companion, John Wallowitch. It was 36 years, not 34.

title: I.O.C. Hopes for Bidding Frenzy
description: On June 5 and 6, one media conglomerate will follow another into a room at the International Olympic Committee's headquarters in Lausanne, Switzerland, to explain their strategies for broadcasting the 2010 and 2012 Olympics.

title: How to Mix Politics With Religion
description: Twenty-four years after Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini outmaneuvered Iran's religious establishment, his spiritual disciples in Iraq are attempting a similar clerical coup d'etat. In Iraq before Saddam Hussein, as in Iran before the Islamic revolution of 1979, Shiite clerics often had political influence. But they generally respected the age-old Shiite doctrine that clerics should keep their distance from politics.

title: Dragons, a Brief History Long in Miles
description: The first dragon myths appear with the Sumerian legends of the god-mother Tiamat who transforms herself into a legged, horned serpent, and of the snake Zu who steals the law tablets.

title: Sinead O'Connor to Retire, but for How Long?
description: When Sinead O'Connor announced her retirement from the music business last week, the press here dutifully took note, with small newspaper articles tucked in the back pages. But the public seemingly failed to notice the departure of a singer who was once Ireland's biggest, and at times most notorious, international star.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDER, MICHAEL A.
description: BENDER-Michael A. 73, of Shoreham, LI, and Boca Grande, FL, suddenly on April 25, 2003. Adored husband of Belinda. Loved father and stepfather of Michele Myers, Leslie Farless, Sabina Milbank and William Martin. Brother of Peter Bender and Mary Ellen Bender and grandfather of Sabina Milbank, Emmaline Milbank, Joseph Hunter Milbank, Timothy Lassiter and Robin Myers. Memorial services Wednesday, April 30, 11 AM, St. Anselm's Episcopal Church, Woodville Road, Shoreham, NY, through Alexander-Tuthill Funeral Home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHANZER, ETHEL
description: SCHANZER - Ethel. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of Ethel Schanzer, wife of our fellow member Ben Schanzer, and extend sincere condolences to him and his family. Alex C. Solowey, President

title: More Than Money Is at Stake in Votes By Airline Unions
description: Workers in other industries could only dream about the rules of everyday conduct established by agreements between the major airlines and their unions over the last few decades. Pilots worked 80 hours or less during an entire month. Mechanics were paid for waving planes away from gates. Flight attendants got to stay in luxury hotels on the road.

title: Hotel on Trial Over Attack That Killed 2 Businessmen
description: A lawyer for families of two victims of a fatal shooting in a Cairo hotel 10 years ago asked a federal jury in Manhattan yesterday to find the hotel liable in the attack, which the lawyer blamed on lax security.

title: From Many Imaginations, One Fearsome Creature
description: A huge scaly serpent, usually with the wings of a bat or bird. Four or two or no legs. Breathes fire or poisonous fumes. May talk, but won't take guff from mere mortals. Sometimes has a vulnerable underbelly (good luck, Siegfried!) and sometimes is solid armor plate. May guard a treasure. May diet on virgins, or anything that crosses its path, halitosis-barbecued.

description: Offer by North Korea

title: Struggling With Crises From SARS to Iraq War
description: WITH acres of fawning marble statues and fake-frescoed vaulted ceilings, the 3,000-room Venetian Hotel resembles a version of the Vatican designed by Franco Zeffirelli.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETITMAIRE, FELIX J.
description: PETITMAIRE-Felix J., age 89, of Moon Township, PA, formerly of Stuart, FL and most of life in Rockville Centre, NY. Husband of the late Elizabeth (Watts) Petitmaire. Beloved father of Carol, Marcelle, Andre and Lorraine Petitmaire; grandfather of seven. Preceded in death by twin brother Maurice Petitmaire. Former manager for Henry Hudson Hotel, (NYC), Roosevelt Hotel (NYC), Belmont Hotel (Chicago) and the New York City Yacht Club, 1962-1980. Memorial Service private. Memorials may be made to the American Cancer Society.
