title: Howard Dean's Remark on Military Draws Fire From Kerry
description: Howard Dean, the former Vermont governor running for president, has told an audience in New Hampshire that the United States ''won't always have the strongest military,'' an assertion that drew a strong rebuke today from one of his rivals for the Democratic nomination.

title: Finding Fraud on Wall Street
description: After five months of negotiating the fine print, 10 Wall Street firms accused of issuing tainted stock research agreed yesterday to the terms of a landmark $1.4 billion settlement. Three of the firms -- Citigroup's Salomon Smith Barney, Merrill Lynch and Credit Suisse First Boston -- were charged with actually issuing ''fraudulent'' stock recommendations. This unambiguous language, not the fines' dollar amounts, may be the most significant outcome of the inquiry undertaken by the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, and other regulators.

title: Powell, Denouncing Crackdown, Calls Cuba 'Aberration' in West
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell criticized Cuba today as an ''aberration in the Western Hemisphere'' and said the administration is studying ways to respond to the Havana government's recent crackdown on its critics.

title: MasterCard Settles Case With Retailers Ahead of Trial
description: MasterCard International reached an unexpected settlement yesterday with Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and thousands of other retailers just as a multibillion-dollar lawsuit over its debit card policies was about to go to trial.

title: After 15 Years, Two Men Are Tried in Officer's Death
description: Almost 15 years after a robbery that ended with the death of a police officer, the police say, two men were brought before a Manhattan jury yesterday to face felony murder charges.

title: Disabled But Able
description: ''A Matter of Dignity: Changing the Lives of the Disabled,'' by Andrew Potok. Bantam Books, $24.95.

description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NCR CORP., Dayton, Ohio, the world's largest maker of automated teller machines, agreed to supply, install and manage 1,500 automated teller machines over the next 18 months for State Bank of India, the country's largest commercial bank. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Veteran's Guidance And Goal Lift Tampa
description: Dave Andreychuk said he had fond memories of his three-plus seasons with the Devils and was crushed when he had to leave in 1999. Tonight he helped defeat them.

title: Cholesterol Drug and Alzheimer's
description: Statins, used by millions of people with high cholesterol levels, may also have potential as a medication for Alzheimer's disease, a new study reports.

title: Learning Team Spirit Behind Bars
description: Fran Morgan, an identity thief and jailhouse volleyball coach, paced the sideline in her state-issued maroon and gray as her team warmed up for its weekly tournament. The competition took place inside the York Correctional Institution in Niantic, Connecticut's only women's prison.

title: SPIEGEL PLANS TO CLOSE 60 STORES AND TRIM 900 JOBS
description: Spiegel Inc., the owner of the 98-year-old Spiegel catalog, plans to close 60 of its Eddie Bauer stores and eliminate 900 positions. Spiegel filed for bankruptcy court protection last month. The stores will remain open until it receives bankruptcy court approval to close them, the company said. Spiegel operates 529 Eddie Bauer clothing, home and outlet stores in the United States and Canada. The company, which is based in Downers Grove, Ill., sought protection from creditors on March 17 after losing more than $727 million in the last two years. The Eddie Bauer stores scheduled for closing are in 24 states and the District of Columbia; eight are in California.

title: Caroline H. Newhouse, 94, Philanthropist

title: NEWS SUMMARY

title: BROOKFIELD PROPERTIES OFFERS TO BUY REST OF AFFILIATE
description: The Brookfield Properties Corporation, Lower Manhattan's largest office landlord, offered to buy the shares of a Canadian real estate affiliate, BPO Properties Ltd., that it does not already own for 86.7 million Canadian dollars ($59.9 million). A Brookfield unit would pay $13 a share in cash plus 0.5 common share of Brookfield for each BPO share. The offer values BPO at $27.83 a share.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Girl Raped At School
description: A 14-year-old girl was raped by two 14-year-old boys at their school yesterday, the police said. The attack occurred at Intermediate School 302, at 350 Linwood Street, in Highland Park, inside a first floor bathroom, the police said. No weapon was used, said Officer Louis Camacho. The victim was taken to Brookdale Hospital. No one had been arrested as of late last night. A call to a Department of Education spokesman was not immediately returned. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: A First Draft: Assessing The Winners and Losers
description: The Arizona Cardinals threw a draft party Saturday morning, a daring move for a franchise that has one playoff victory since moving from St. Louis after the 1987 season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, PETER
description: STONE-Peter. We mourn the loss of Peter Stone, brilliant writer, great wit, good friend and co-founder of Guild Hall's Academy of the Arts, and recipient of its Lifetime Achievement Award in Literary Arts. Melville Straus, Chairman of the Board Edward Bleier, Chairman, Academy of the Arts Ruth Appelhof, Director The Board and staff of Guild Hall

title: Beyond High C, High Technology; A Tenor Turns to Restoring Opera Recordings
description: For the love of opera, Stefan Zucker trained to reach the upper limits of the tenor's range.

title: Officials Clear Two Groups On Financing Of Campaigns
description: In its first enforcement action under the new campaign finance law prohibiting the national political parties from using ''soft money'' in federal campaigns, election regulators have rejected accusations that two recently established political groups illegally evaded those rules.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- Buenos Aires; Where Glamour and Chaos Merge
description: Buenos Aires has long been considered a city that does not know where it is. It consciously rebuilt itself at the turn of the last century in the image of Paris. Walking along the Avenida de Mayo, lined with Belle poque buildings, you would think you were in France. Adding to the confusion are young fashion plates who seem to have spacewarped from Milan.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Turbine Unit Acquired
description: The French engineering company Alstom sold its industrial turbines unit to Siemens, the German engineering company, for 950 million euros ($1 billion). The move is part of Alstom's plan to sell 3 billion euros in assets to help pare its debt, which currently stands at about 5 billion euros ($5.5 billion). Alstom's industrial turbines unit had 1.25 billion euros in sales annually and currently employs about 6,500 people. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: From Running Columbia to Relieving Iraqis' Misery
description: THERE are fewer than half a dozen private American relief agencies authorized to help in the rebuilding of Iraq. The United Nations has been shut out. The Europeans have been shut out. Nation-building will be handled primarily by the Pentagon and the huge private construction firms that have been granted multimillion-dollar contracts.

title: Brain Surgery, Without Knife or Blood, Gains Favor
description: Without so much as a nick to her scalp, Cheryl Hogarth had major brain surgery on a tumor that had grown to nearly the size of a Ping-Pong ball deep within her brain.

title: Crack Down on Spam
description: No one with an e-mail account needs to be told that unwanted commercial messages, better known as spam, are a bad problem that is getting worse. America Online reports that 70 percent of the e-mail its users receive is now junk, and that the quantity has doubled just since the beginning of this year. Much of the increase is being fueled by Internet marketing companies, which charge as little as $500 to send out a million e-mail messages. Internet service providers have taken steps to clamp down on spam, but the tools at their disposal are limited. Congress needs to help.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONDON, PEARL
description: LONDON-Pearl. The Poetry Society of America wishes to pay tribute to Pearl London. Elegant and energetic proponent of the art of poetry, gifted and inspiring teacher, generous and devoted member of the Board of Governors of the Poetry Society of America. We mourn her and will miss her. Funeral services will be held today at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave. at 65 St., 12 noon.

description: BASEBALL

title: Suspect Charged With Plotting To Fight U.S. in Afghanistan
description: An American citizen detained for more than a month as a material witness in a terrorism case in Oregon was charged today with plotting to fight against American soldiers in Afghanistan.

title: LANDLORD TERMINATES WYNDHAM LEASE ON 15 HOTELS
description: Hospitality Properties Trust terminated the lease on 15 hotels held by Wyndham International Inc. after Wyndham failed to pay rent on the properties. Hospitality Properties said the 15 hotels, all of them in the Summerfield by Wyndham chain, will be managed by the Candlewood Hotel Company. Hospitality Properties, a real estate investment trust, is negotiating with Wyndham on continuing its lease on 12 other Wyndham hotels on which Wyndham did not pay rent. Wyndham, which is based in Dallas, is controlled by the investors Thomas Lee and Leon Black. Wyndham missed $3.6 million in rent payments due April 1 on the 27 hotels, Hospitality Properties said this month.

title: F.D.A. Chief's Fast Start Earns Praise and Doubt
description: Mark B. McClellan, the new commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, knows he has critics lying in wait. He also has special interest groups, from corporations to consumer advocates, ready to plead. His decisions, as he is well aware, can save lives or ruin them, and can make or break a company's fortunes. But he focuses, he says, on what is the right thing to do in handling an agency with a budget of $1.6 billion, whose responsibilities reach over 20 percent of the consumer economy. And he is moving forward rapidly.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Asylum Seekers Leave
description: Britain forcibly sent 30 failed asylum seekers home to Afghanistan, the first Afghans it has deported since dropping the practice in 1995 because of instability there. The number of asylum seekers in Britain is a major issue in local elections on Thursday, and the government has pledged to halve the number of new arrivals by September. Thousands of Afghans have claimed asylum in Britain over the past decade, with 7,380 in 2002 alone. A voluntary procedure was set up offering $4,000 for anyone willingly returning. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: MEADWESTVACO NAMES A PRESIDENT AND A FINANCE CHIEF
description: The MeadWestvaco Corporation, a leading maker of coated paper for magazines, promoted James Buzzard to president and named a chief financial officer as the company seeks to restore profit. Mr. Buzzard, 48, had been executive vice president overseeing the integration of the Mead Corporation and the Westvaco Corporation, which merged in January 2002. Cynthia Niekamp, 43, succeeds Karen Osar as chief financial officer, a spokesman, Robert Crockett, said. title: A New Center for Performing Arts
description: By now one of Frank Gehry's architectural idioms -- sinuous, cresting waves of titanium or steel -- has become familiar enough to need no introduction. And yet it remains unfamiliar enough to force an observer to reabsorb it time after time. The newly unveiled Richard B. Fisher Center for the Performing Arts at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., has analogies in Bilbao, in the Frederick R. Weisman Art Museum at the University of Minnesota, and, of course, in the new Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles, which opens in October. But the Fisher Center is the least urban of Mr. Gehry's billowing constructions. It is encompassed by other things that appear to billow naturally, like trees and the Catskill Mountains, which can be glimpsed in their always atmospheric light across the Hudson. This gives the idiom an entirely new meaning.

title: East Asia Markets Rise Sharply as SARS Fears Recede
description: HONG KONG, April 29  Stock markets rose sharply across most of east Asia today as investors gained hope that an outbreak of a deadly respiratory disease could be brought under control.

title: Two Earnings Reports Set Off Biggest Rally in a Month
description: Stocks rose yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to its biggest rally in a month, on optimism that earnings are recovering after McDonald's and Procter & Gamble reported quarterly profits that beat analyst estimates. The dollar strengthened and Treasuries fell.

title: Sports of The Times; Japan's Big Moment in the Bronx
description: SHIGEO NAGASHIMA knows a big game when he sees it. A great player and the former manager of the Tokyo Giants (imagine Joe DiMaggio managing the Yankees), he is coming to Yankee Stadium tonight to see the first North American meeting between Ichiro Suzuki and Hideki Matsui.

title: Elaine Steinbeck, 88, Author's Widow, Dies
description: Elaine Anderson Steinbeck, who was one of the first women to become a Broadway stage manager and who in later years kept bright the artistic torch of her late husband John Steinbeck, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 88 and lived in Manhattan and Sag Harbor, N.Y.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Bank's Profit Rises
description: The banking concern ABN Amro Holding posted a 74 percent increase in first-quarter net profit, to 690 million euros ($762 million), largely as a result of cost-cutting measures and a surge in lending at its mortgage units in the United States. ABN's first-quarter results were also helped by the partial sale of its insurance operations, which brought in 111 million euros ($122.5 million). ABN's net profit rose 14.6 percent from the year-earlier period. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Republicans Ready to Cut a Deal on Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, April 29  Top Republican leaders of Congress said today they were ready to put a budget feud to rest and strike a tax cut deal, with Senate Majority Leader Bill Frist saying his objective now was to get the largest possible tax cut.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Server Shipments Rose 10% In First Quarter
description: Worldwide server-computer shipments rose 10 percent in the first quarter as leaders like the Hewlett-Packard Company and Dell Computer increased sales, a study said. Total shipments of servers, computers that handle tasks like retrieving Internet files and distributing e-mail, rose to 1.23 million from 1.11 million a year earlier, the Dataquest research unit of Gartner Inc. said. United States server shipments rose 13 percent, to 499,609 units from 441,540, Dataquest said. Hewlett, the world's largest server maker, shipped 3.6 percent more servers, and Dell, the world's No. 2 server company and the biggest United States seller, had 28 percent growth. I.B.M., No. 3 in the world, sold 20 percent more servers, while Sun Microsystems, which is No. 4, fell by 13 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEIER, MICHAEL P.
description: BEIER-Michael P. The Department of Neurology and the Eleanor and Lou Gehrig MDA/ALS Research Center at Columbia University Health Sciences mourn the passing of Michael Beier. He was a rare individual who faced his illness and increasing disability with resolve and determination, and served as an example to us all. He worked tirelessly to support ALS research, and chaired the ''MDA Wings Over Wall Street'' Gala to increase research leading to a cure. In honor of his remarkable efforts, we were proud to create ''The Michael Beier/ MDA Wings Over Wall Street Research Fund'' at Columbia University in December 2002. As national vice president of MDA, Mike was involved in many organizations for ALS, and he was an energetic campaigner to raise public awareness and funding for ALS research. We extend our deepest sympathy to Michael's family. Timothy A. Pedley, M.D. Chairman of the Department of Neurology Serge Przedborski, M.D. and Hiroshi Mitsumoto, M.D. Co-Directors of the Eleanor and Lou Gehrig MDA/ALS Research Center Columbia University Health Sciences

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: PROFIT AT OIL COMPANY BP , the British oil company, reported quarterly profit of 2.3 billion ($3.7 billion) for the first three months of the year, more than double the period a year earlier. Profit was helped by soaring oil prices resulting from a sequence of world events including the run-up to the war in Iraq, a national strike in Venezuela and civil unrest in Nigeria. A fall in oil prices from $31 a barrel to yesterday's five-month low of $23 a barrel is expected to lead to a slump in profits at BP during the current quarter. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

title: To the Top of the World, and Down Again
description: In a few weeks Britons will mark the day 50 years ago when a team of climbers representing their small island with its modest altitudes and imperial history reached the summit of the world's highest mountain half a world away, on the borders of Tibet and Nepal.

description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday received an award for his efforts in bringing high-technology jobs to 17 counties in the state. A consortium of business, academic and community leaders gives the annual award, called the MIKE (Mentoring, Inspiration, Knowledge and Entrepreneurship). New jobs in private business have been created in the counties, areas referred to collectively as the Tech Valley Corridor. I.B.M., for example, plans to create 1,000 new jobs at its chip plant in East Fishkill. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: GENERAL MILLS TO PAY DIAGEO HIGHER PRICE FOR PILLSBURY
description: General Mills Inc. will raise the price paid to Diageo for the Pillsbury foods business by about $270 million because its shares did not reach an agreed-upon price. As part of the October 2001 stock-and-cash transaction, General Mills said it would pay the difference between its price for the first 20 days of April and $49 for each share Diageo owns. The stock price averaged $45.56 and closed yesterday at $45.30 in New York Stock Exchange composite trading. The higher amount raises the final purchase price to about $10.4 billion.

description: The crewmen who have manned the International Space Station for five months said today that they would miss it but were eager to head home now that their replacements had arrived.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Drug Maker's License Suspended
description: Regulators have suspended the license of Pan Pharmaceuticals Limited of Sydney, Australia's largest contract maker of nonprescription health products. More than 200 Pan products, marketed under its main brand and other labels, were recalled yesterday by the company on the orders of the Therapeutic Goods Administration. The federal watchdog agency said that a continuing investigation revealed deficiencies in quality control and test reports by Pan. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUMLER, EGON
description: DUMLER-Egon. I started writing this when I heard that the hospice people were taking good care of you, easing your way, just as you eased all our ways, through wills, lawsuits, questions, and you eased our way through them, with a kind word, a gentle joke, and always the time to say words of encouragement. I will miss you dear Egon, I will miss your smile, your laugh and your good advice. But most of all, I will miss your delightful humanity. You were never just an attorney, you were a friend, a good friend. Someone once wrote, a friend isn't just someone who does favors, a friend is a person who reminds you who you are, and what you are. You always reminded me. Goodbye old friend, Lester

title: Corrections

It was 1947, when her career ended after her name surfaced before the House Committee on Un-American Activities, her family said -- not in 1952, when she refused to answer questions before the committee about membership in the Communist Party.

title: A Robust Red Goes Straight to the Point
description: IF it didn't have such a French-sounding name, petite sirah might have become the all-American grape we mistakenly think zinfandel to be. During the long hegemony of the jug wines, it was usually petite sirah that lent them whatever vinous character they could muster. Many a California wine sold as Burgundy or Chianti owed its modest appeal to a grape whose name never appeared on the label, the sturdy, blue-collar petite sirah.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Computer Horizons' Founder Resigns
description: The founder of Computer Horizons, John Cassese, who is under indictment on insider trading charges, resigned yesterday as chief executive and will get severance pay totaling $3.5 million. He had taken a leave as chief executive and resigned as chairman March 13 after his two-count federal indictment. The chief financial officer, William Murphy, will succeed Mr. Cassese as chief executive. A board member, Thomas Berry, was appointed chairman last month. Computer Horizons, a provider of computer services to companies, is fighting an unsolicited takeover offer from Aquent, a Boston-based information-technology consulting company. Computer Horizons has urged shareholders to reject Aquent's proposal to nominate two directors. Aquent, saying Computer Horizons is too small to compete on its own, offered $5 a share, or $146 million, on April 14. Aquent owns about 1.1 million, or 4 percent, of Computer Horizons shares. Computer Horizons has ignored the takeover offer, Aquent has said. Computer Horizons sued Aquent in Federal District Court in New Jersey yesterday, asking Aquent to ''correct its misleading proxy materials and invalidate any proxies received prior to such correction,'' according to a Computer Horizons statement. Aquent created a ''false impression'' that Computer Horizons was either for sale or the subject of a ''bona fide acquisition proposal,'' the statement said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Freer Trade Proposed
description: The European Union offered to open some of its service industries to outside competition to enhance global trade liberalization in areas like telecommunications, retailing, banking and computer services, but a top official said the move depended on other trading partners doing the same. ''We will withdraw parts of it if the union does not obtain quid pro quo from others in this process,'' the trade commissioner, Pascal Lamy, said. The offer, submitted to the World Trade Organization in Geneva, excludes sectors like entertainment, health and education services. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Corus Plans Job Cuts
description: Corus, the struggling British-Dutch steel maker, said it would cut 1,150 jobs in its continuing battle to stem losses at its British units. The company said it was also considering 2,200 more job cuts in the next two years. Since being formed by the merger of British Steel with Hoogovens in 1999, Corus has lost 2 billion ($3.18 billion) and its work force will have shrunk from 35,000 to 21,500 if all the planned job losses are completed. Corus has been badly hit by the worldwide slump in demand for steel as well as cheap imports from Latin America and the Far East. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Protesting Cuba's Place On Rights Panel
description: The United States walked out of a meeting to protest Cuba's election to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights for another three-year term. Sichan Siv, the American representative to the United Nations Economic and Social Council, which oversees the rights group, said after the vote: ''This is an outrage for us. We view Cuba as the worst violator of human rights in this hemisphere.'' Regional groups decide who fills seats. Latin America chose six countries, including Cuba, for six open seats, and all six were elected by acclamation. Cuba began its recent crackdown on dissidents as the Human Rights Commission was holding its annual meeting in Geneva. Daniel B. Schneider (NYT)

Beloved grandmother of five. Lover of life, vivacious and spirited, she will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Interment to follow at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, 331 E. 70th St., NY NY 10021-8698.

title: Mideast Hope Meets Its Enemy
description: The tragedy of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict has always been that the moment a glimmer of hope for coexistence appears, the forces of rejection and violence come calling. Yesterday, just as a new Palestinian leadership seemed to be clearing the way for a new era, a powerful bomb went off at a seaside cafe in Tel Aviv. The work of a suicide bomber, it claimed the lives of at least two victims. It must not be allowed to claim the new chance for peace as well.

title: SONY MUSIC CREATES DIVISION TO LIFT SALES
description: After years of failing to capitalize on the rising popularity of rap, hip-hop and rhythm and blues, Sony Music USA announced yesterday that it had created a division to work on developing artists in those genres in the hopes of increasing record sales in a declining market. Don Ienner, president of Sony Music USA, named David McPherson, 35, executive vice president for urban music. Mr. McPherson will oversee artist development, urban promotions and marketing. He will be based in New York and report to Mr. Ienner. The new division will have 54 employees. Lynette Holloway (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Simmering Tensions
description: The situation in Aceh, Indonesia's northernmost province, is on the verge of erupting into renewed bloodshed, diplomats and observers there say. The government said it was willing to resume talks with separatists from Aceh but laid down conditions that appeared to set the stage for a military assault. The Free Aceh Movement, better known as GAM, must forswear a desire for independence and lay down their arms, Security Minister Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono said. The guerrillas say they will not disarm until the Indonesian military returns to its barracks. There are 50,000 troops poised to move into Aceh. ''It looks very bleak,'' said a European diplomat, whose assessment was shared by American, Australian and Asian diplomats there. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: Rumsfeld Seeks to Reassure Iraqis on Visit to Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 30  Six weeks after the first airstrike aimed at toppling Saddam Hussein, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld drove through the conquered Iraqi capital today, reviewing the results of a war whose pace, scope and goals he oversaw with exacting measure.

title: Serbian Police Charge 45 in Slaying of Premier
description: In a sweeping conclusion to their investigation of the March 12 assassination of the Serbian prime minister, Zoran Djindjic, the Serbian police said yesterday that they had charged 45 people, including the nationalist politician Vojislav Seselj and a top adviser to the former president, Vojislav Kostunica. Dozens of organized crime figures, suspected war criminals and former top government officials were also charged.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: NEW LONDON: CONVICTED SCOUT LEADER ACCUSED A former Boy Scout leader from Ledyard who was convicted in 2000 of molesting boys is facing charges of violating his probation. The man, Joseph Dabrow, 46, was in Superior Court on Monday. Mr. Dabrow is serving his probation in New York State so he can live with his mother. A New York probation officer notified the state Office of Adult Probation that Mr. Dabrow might have violated the conditions of his probation by having contact with a 16-year-old boy and keeping pornographic videos in his bedroom. (AP)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Ferry Service Is Saved
description: Ferry service between the Brooklyn Army Terminal in Sunset Park and Pier 11 in Lower Manhattan will continue, officials said yesterday, although after today it will no longer be free. The city had said it would not be able to provide the service, started after the Sept. 11 attack, once the Federal Emergency Management Agency ended its $290,000 monthly subsidy. But a Brooklyn company, New York Water Taxi, responded to the city's invitation to take over the route. Starting tomorrow, commuters can ride the ferry every 20 minutes during the morning and evening rush for $4 each way. Fares will rise on June 1 to $5 for a single trip, $45 for a 10-trip book and $175 monthly. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bill Would Ban Ephedra Sale In City
description: Betsy Gotbaum, the New York City public advocate, announced yesterday that she and several City Council members would introduce a bill today to ban the sale of ephedra within the city. Ephedra is an herbal dietary supplement that supporters say is valuable for weight loss and body building but that the Food and Drug Administration says has been linked to heart attacks and strokes. The bill would allow doctors to prescribe ephedra, but only as a treatment for conditions other than obesity or fatigue. The unauthorized sale of ephedra would be punishable by a $1,000 fine. Nichole M. Christian (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Elizabeth: Expansion Of Cargo Traffic Is Planned
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey and officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey ceremonially drove the first spike yesterday for an $80 million expansion of rail service at the Elizabeth Marine Terminal. Over the next four years, the expansion will quadruple the number of cargo containers shipped to and from Midwestern and Western locations, Mr. McGreevey said. Currently, about 228,000 containers a year, or 13 percent of port traffic bound to or from inland points, go directly from ships to rail cars or vice versa. With an expected increase in cargo volume, the new tracks will increase that proportion to 25 percent of port traffic, Mr. McGreevey said. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: OMNICOM'S EARNINGS STEADY DESPITE SALES INCREASE
description: The Omnicom Group, the world's biggest owner of advertising agencies, said yesterday that first-quarter earnings were little changed. While costs rose and investment losses widened, sales increased 12 percent as the company gained new accounts. Net income was $128.58 million, or 69 cents a share, compared with $128.5 million, or 68 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue climbed to $1.94 billion from $1.73 billion, the company, based in New York, said. Omnicom, owner of BBDO Worldwide, is one of the few advertising companies to report higher sales. It attracted new accounts, including America Online and Office Depot, and added customers through acquisitions. Foreign exchange rates bolstered Omnicom's sales total by $107 million, its chief financial officer, Randy Weisenburger, said in a conference call with analysts and investors. The company generates about 43 percent of its revenue from outside the United States.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Interest Rate Lowered

The bank cuts its cash reserve ratio of banks by 0.25 percentage point to 4.50 percent. At its biannual credit and monetary policy announcement, the reserve bank said the cuts were effective June 14. The bank said interest rates declined in the last few years and that left little scope for larger reductions. The bank has forecast 6 percent growth in India's gross domestic product in the current fiscal year, which ends next March. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: 20 Ways to an Old Kentucky Buzz
description: Mint, syrup, bourbon. Horse-racing fans instantly recognize those ingredients for a mint julep, the signature cocktail of the Kentucky Derby, which will be on Saturday. In ''The Kentucky Mint Julep,'' a slim volume published by the University Press of Kentucky ($12), Joe Nickell writes that the term julep is derived from Persian and Arabic words for a syrup or rose water. Americans added mint, and Kentuckians their distinctive bourbon. The book has more than 20 recipes, nearly all of which require just mint, sugar, water, ice and bourbon in various combinations. The author's favorite uses hot water, the better to steep the mint, he says. It's definitely a book to read before you buy silver julep cups ($25 for four in silver plate from Fortunoff, or $320 for an official one in sterling from www.kyjulep.com).

title: Toward a Memorial Design
description: In just a few months -- by October, if things go according to schedule -- we'll know what the ground zero memorial will look like and how it will fit within the confines of Daniel Libeskind's architectural vision for the World Trade Center site. On Monday, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation kicked off the competition that will lead to a final design. Corporation officials and members of the memorial design jury made it clear that the contest is wide open. Even as they announced the competition guidelines, they seemed to downplay their importance. The implication is that what matters most, at the moment, is resonance, memory and the almost uncanny power that great memorials have. The details of making good plans fit the site can be adjusted later, before the jury reaches its final decision.

title: A Judicial Witch Hunt
description: James Rosenbaum is the chief judge of the United States District Court in Minnesota. Appointed by President Ronald Reagan and confirmed by a Republican-controlled Senate in 1985, Judge Rosenbaum is hardly an obvious target for conservatives seeking to reshape the federal bench. Yet he is now facing a Kafkaesque witch hunt, with Congress making dangerously improper demands for his files and notes because he has objected to federal sentencing policies that restrict a judge's discretion. The attack on Judge Rosenbaum is not only a sign of the right's continuing attempt to hijack the federal judiciary but also trespasses on the constitutional separation of powers. It must stop.

description: Even as the United States remains deeply engaged in Iraq, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and the armed services are considering sweeping changes to decades-old Pentagon practices and ingrained military culture to prepare faster for any future war.

title: For Catalog's Namesake, One Last Big Sale
description: LILLIAN VERNON seems in no mood to discuss garden gnomes. The conversation never mellows to the point of gnomes, listed as $29.98 and weather resistant in her recent Favorites catalog. (It got close, though.) Late Friday afternoon, Ms. Vernon, the 76-year-old founder of the catalog company, looks weary, distracted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIS, FREEMAN
description: ELLIS-Freeman. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Freeman Ellis, associated with The Times from March 26, 1945 until retiring August 1, 1992.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: MOLESTER MAKES STATEMENT IN PATZ CASE A convicted child molester who is suspected by the family in the abduction of 6-year-old Etan Patz 24 years ago has given a sworn statement saying he had nothing to do with the child's disappearance. Brian O'Dwyer, a lawyer for the missing child's parents, said yesterday that he deposed the prisoner, Jose R. Ramos, in a Dallas, Pa., prison for two hours on Monday. Mr. Ramos, a friend of a baby sitter who worked for the Patz family, is serving a 20-year sentence for abusing an 8-year-old boy. A judge ordered Mr. Ramos to answer questions for a lawsuit filed by Etan's parents, Stanley and Julia Patz, or risk being declared responsible for Etan's death. Despite Mr. Ramos's denial, Mr. O'Dwyer said, "We came away convinced more than ever we have the right person." (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDIN, FREDERICK H.
description: GOLDIN-Frederick H. The Board of Governors and members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Frederick H. Goldin. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved family. Richard J. Bornstein, Pres. Leon Fassler, Secretary

title: A Slap on the Wrist on Wall St.?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Blameless at St. Bonaventure: Coach's Protest Is a Bit Much
description: THERE were too many names, dates, allegations and one theatrical lawyer, which was, most assuredly, one too many. More than defending himself from the fallout of the recent St. Bonaventure basketball scandal yesterday, Jan van Breda Kolff managed to stage a filibuster worthy of C-Span at a swanky Manhattan address, Mickey Mantle's, on Central Park South.

title: The Changing Methods of a Standard Award for Schools
description: Since 1982, the federal Department of Education has given Blue Ribbon Awards to schools that it deems to be outstanding, as well as to those that have shown marked improvement.

title: A Generous Bouquet for a Rich Cut of Beef
description: WITH a name like petite sirah, you might expect something light with gentle splashes of acidity. But that is exactly what you will not get. Petite sirahs tend to present themselves with a thud that is rich with fruit, generous with earth and short on subtlety.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDAN, ROBERT E.
description: JORDAN-Robert E. Age 46. On Tuesday, April 29, 2003. Beloved son of Gladys Jordan. Husband of Karen. Father of Jessica. Brother of Alan. Funeral at Hebrew Institue of Riverdale, 11 AM today.

title: A New SARS Riddle: How to Know It's Beaten
description: The World Health Organization has said that SARS is over in Vietnam and waning in Hong Kong, and yesterday it said it would rescind the warning against travel to Toronto. Responding to the first favorable news about the spread of the disease -- severe acute respiratory syndrome -- since the agency issued a global health warning on March 12, the markets in Hong Kong are rebounding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWHOUSE, CAROLINE
description: NEWHOUSE-Caroline. Artists, Board, and staff of The Parsons Dance Company extend deepest sympathy to the family and friends of Caroline Newhouse, a continuous inspiration and motivating force for all of us. Dearest Caroline was always there for us with her wit, support and energy, and we will deeply miss her shining presence and her example of how to live life beautifully and generously.

title: Yankees' Contreras Is Sharp in His First Minor League Game
description: Jos Contreras was a more relaxed, confident and successful pitcher in his first start for Class AAA Columbus.

title: Rivera Is Back, And Jeter Is Antsy
description: Mariano Rivera and Derek Jeter joined their teammates in the clubhouse at Yankee Stadium last night for the first time this season, with one of them feeling relieved and the other feeling hopeful.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYCHTARIK, GERTRUD
description: RYCHTARIK-Gertrud. With sadness we report the passing of our dearly beloved mother, mother-in-law, and grandmother on April 28 in her 91st year. But we celebrate a life filled with goodness and compassion, with love and understanding, with vitality and joy of life, and with deep and long-lasting friendships. A life made richer through her wide-ranging interests in and knowledge of all things cultural, as well as her sense of business and of social graces. She was active in several philanthropic endeavors, and music organizations and also libraries benefited from her generosity. Her husband, Richard Rychtarik, artist, stage designer and architect, passed away in 1982. She is survived by her daughter Ann, her son-in-law John Trayna, and her grandson Andrew of Wayne, New Jersey, and a sister Lotte Reyersbach and a nephew and niece, Drs. Peter and Jane Reyers of Tucson, Arizona. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society, 1800-227-2345

title: 9/11 Panel, Blocked
description: To the Editor:

title: Improving the Neighborhood at Ohio State
description: After antiwar demonstrations some three decades ago at Ohio State University, many merchants along High Street, the commercial road just east of the sprawling campus, boarded up their windows. The university turned its back on the unsightly street and began expanding in the opposite direction, across the Olentangy River to the west.

title: SUNY Albany in Capital Campaign
description: The State University of New York at Albany has kicked off a $500 million capital campaign. The SUNY branch has raised $272 million in the campaign's preparatory phase.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: BERLUSCONI ALLY IS CONVICTED A court in Milan convicted Cesare Previti, a close friend of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, of bribing judges to favor Mr. Berlusconi's business empire. Mr. Berlusconi, a media tycoon, is a co-defendant with Mr. Previti in another corruption trial in Milan. Mr. Previti, 68, was defense minister in Mr. Berlusconi's 1994 government and his onetime personal lawyer. He was sentenced to 11 years in prison.

title: A Spring Repast For Pagans and Puritans Alike
description: WHEN I was in college I used to get up at dawn every May 1 to see the beginning of what we thought of as the first day of summer.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: BANK RESULTS DECLINE Woori Bankand the Shinhan Financial Group joined the major financial institutions reporting declines in net income in the first quarter of this year. Woori said its net income during that period was 205.1 billion won ($168 million), down 41 percent from the 345.2 billion won that it reported in the first quarter of last year. And Shinhan Financial, dominated by Shinhan Bank, said its net income in the first quarter was 56.4 billion won ($46 million), compared with 190.4 billion won in the first three months of 2002. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: State Pay Freeze Urged To Save Costs
description: A business group said yesterday that the state could help close its budget deficit by an across-the-board pay freeze for 1.2 million public employees. The group, the Business Council of New York State, called on Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders to freeze wages for state, municipal and school district employees. They estimated the freeze would save $2 billion to $3 billion for the state, New York City and other localities, and for school districts across the state. Daniel B. Walsh, the council's president, said that labor unions would undoubtedly oppose a pay freeze, but that it could prevent thousands of layoffs. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: U.S. Tells Iraq Oil Ministers Not to Act Without Its O.K.
description: An American official met today with Iraq's two most senior deputy oil ministers for the first time and warned them not to make any changes in their hierarchy without the approval of the allied forces in control of the country.

title: North Korea Warns of War if U.S. Uses Sanctions
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 30  In its most extensive commentary yet on discussions with the United States over its nuclear weapons program, North Korea reiterated today its willingness to negotiate, but warned that economic sanctions would lead to war.

title: Empire Maker Is Injured; Kafwain Is Scratched
description: For days, horseplayers have been looking for the tiniest bit of vulnerability in the Kentucky Derby favorite, Empire Maker, the impeccably bred and seemingly invincible Florida Derby winner. They found it today when his trainer, Bobby Frankel, acknowledged that the colt had bruised a heel in his right front foot in his last victory, in the Wood Memorial, and that he had sought veterinary attention for the ailment early this morning.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: 8 Basque Separatists Are Arrested
description: The police arrested eight Basque political activists accused of aiding the goals of the armed separatist group E.T.A. and the outlawed Batasuna Party, widely viewed as E.T.A.'s political wing. The Spanish interior minister, ngel Acebes, said the eight were leaders of an association called Udalbiltza. Judge Baltasar Garzn, pressing his long campaign against separatist violence, ordered the arrest of Basques connected to Udalbiltza, a cross-border grouping of French and Spanish Basque municipalities set up as the potential nucleus of an independent Basque state. But judicial sources quoted by the Spanish media said Udalbiltza was set up by E.T.A. to run candidates if the Batasuna Party was ever banned, as it was last year. Mr. Acebes accused Udalbiltza of organizing candidacies for regional elections set for May 25 to circumvent the ban. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: The Contagion Reaches Near the Top of the Chinese Communist Hierarchy
description: While the SARS virus may have emerged from teeming animal markets or sprawling suburbs in distant Guangzhou, it quickly mutated into a threat to China's Communist Party elite in Beijing.

title: Beijing Acts to Calm Public, Saying Fight on SARS Is Joined
description: BEIJING, April 30  In a live, televised news conference today the new acting Mayor of Beijing called the SARS epidemic severe and uncontrolled as he sought to convince a panicky public that the battle against the dangerous, fatal new disease is effectively joined at last.

title: When Insults Fly, Politics Gets Interesting
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Force Said to Kill 15 Iraqis During an Anti-American Rally
description: United States soldiers shot and killed 15 people at an anti-American rally late Monday, hospital officials said today. Iraqis said the soldiers opened fire, unprovoked, while the Americans -- who were positioned in a school -- said they were fired on first and then carefully counterattacked.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Oil Workers Are Held Hostage
description: Striking Nigerian oil workers have been holding 270 fellow workers, including 17 Americans, as hostages on oil rigs off the coast of the country, officials said. The striking workers are unarmed, said a spokesman at Transocean Inc., a Houston-based offshore drilling company that runs the rigs. The occupation of the oil rigs began two weeks ago over labor issues. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, STACEY
description: SCHREIBER - Stacey. Our heartfelt condolences to the Schreiber-Kaplan families on the tragic, untimely passing of Stacey. Anita, Arthur and Family

title: Voices From a War-Ravaged Country
description: The modest 61-minute video documentary ''Afghan Stories'' is a subjective response to world events by its maker, Taran Davies, an investment banker who resigned a week after Sept. 11 and left for Afghanistan a few weeks later. He took his video camera and a friend, Walied Osman, a Queens-born American of Afghan descent who would act as interpreter and adviser (and who also has a producer's credit).

title: Baltic Salmon That's Insulted by a Schmear
description: Most of the late-winter catch of salmon from the Baltic Sea off Denmark goes into smokers. Russ & Daughters, 179 East Houston Street (Allen Street), has some of this distinctive salmon, mildly smoky with a meaty texture and a relatively pale color. The salmon, sliced to order, is $36 a pound, and will be available for the next few weeks. A similar salmon is sold at Petrossian, 911 Seventh Avenue (58th Street) and at www.petrossian.com, for $75 for 1.1 pounds. It's best with just a splash of lemon; it requires no cream cheese.

title: Citing Funds, Ballet Tech Cancels Next Season
description: Eliot Feld's Ballet Tech company will suspend operations for the 2003-4 season, canceling three engagements at the Joyce Theater, Mr. Feld announced yesterday, saying he had made the decision to avoid a projected deficit of $665,000. The company-affiliated school, which offers free dance training and academic instruction to New York City public schoolchildren, will continue, he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, SEYMOUR
description: ROSENBERG-Seymour, 85, of Sullivan County, NY and Las Vegas, on April 28th, 2003. Loving husband of the late Marion Rosenberg. Beloved father of Susan, Lawrence, Jill and Jonathan. Adoring grandfather of Holly, Ryan, Nicole, Nathaniel and Alison. Service Wednesday, April 30th, at Parkside Memorial Chapels, Forest Hills, at noon.

title: Moles From the Old Hometown
description: If you have three or four hours to spare before your Cinco de Mayo party, you could make your own moles, sauces originally from Oaxaca and Puebla in Mexico. But there is a shortcut: Chocolate Mayordomo's dense dark red and black moles made from chilies, nuts, cinnamon, chocolate, onions and raisins.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Survivor Describes Hotel Attack
description: A man who survived a 1993 attack at an Egyptian hotel gave a vivid account yesterday of the shooting, in which two New Jersey businessmen were among several people who were killed. The survivor, Merrill Kramer, a Washington lawyer critically injured in the attack, said he had just finished dinner with the two men when he heard a shout and ''something that sounded like a balloon pop.'' One of his companions, Coby Hoffman, of Edison, appeared to be falling backward. His other companion, Robert L. Guidi, of Rahway, held up his hand as if to stop the man who was shooting at them. As Mr. Kramer began to run, he was shot in his midsection and leg. Mr. Kramer testified in a federal trial in Manhattan in which he and the families of the two dead men are seeking to hold the hotel, the Semiramis Inter-Continental Hotel in Cairo, liable in the attack. They cite lax security, which the hotel denies. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Big Flavor On a Bun
description: GENERALLY speaking, lamb is more flavorful than beef, with the possible exception of a perfectly aged prime strip steak or rib cut. Which means that a lamb burger is more flavorful than a hamburger.

title: President to Tell Nation That Major Combat in Iraq Has Ended
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  President Bush will speak to the American people Thursday evening from the deck of an aircraft carrier far out to sea, telling them that major combat in Iraq is over and it is time to look ahead, the White House said today.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: STRONG OUTLOOK AT TAIWAN CHIP MAKER The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Com- pany, the world's largest contract chip maker, said yesterday that its first-quarter net profit fell 34 percent from a year ago, but it forecast a strong second quarter. "I am quite optimistic," the chairman, Morris Chang, told an analysts' conference. "I say this because the strength of the orders is so diverse. All segments — computer, consumer and communications — are quite strong." The company said net profit for the January-March quarter reached 4.36 billion Taiwan dollars ($124.8 million), declining a third from the period last year, but surging 71 percent from the previous three months. The company's shares rose 91 cents, or 12 percent, to $8.60, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the British horticulturalist Graham Stuart Thomas on Monday misstated the title he held in the Order of the British Empire. He was an officer, not a knight.

title: The Forgotten Half of Budgeting
description: As Congress returns to business this week, with leaders bent on pushing President Bush's tax cut up from its $350 billion floor toward the $550 billion ceiling, there is little talk about the vital programs that face future cutbacks in the budget plan. At least $168 billion across the decade is scheduled to be wrenched out of domestic spending as more than $2 trillion in deficits and borrowing is rung up under Mr. Bush's ''growth'' program.

title: Report Finds Deep Poverty Is on the Rise
description: The number of black Americans under 18 years old who live in extreme poverty has risen sharply since 2000 and is now at its highest level since the government began collecting such figures in 1980, according to a study by the Children's Defense Fund, a child welfare advocacy group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALDER, KENNETH, M.D.
description: CALDER-Kenneth, M.D. We honor the memory of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Kenneth Calder, a highly respected and loved member of The New York Psychoanalytic Society. He was a Training and Supervising Analyst, and past president of The New York Psychoanalytic Institute, and was a strong influence in the advancement of psychoanalysis. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. Paul Rosenbaum, M.D., President/NYPI Leon Kupferstein, M.D., President/NYPS Edward Nersessian, M.D., Chair, Edu Committee/Inst

title: Suspect in 14 Bank Robberies Is Arrested After Phone Tip
description: Acting on an anonymous tip, the police arrested a homeless man yesterday in connection with 14 bank robberies in the city since late February, the authorities said.

title: Compact Living
description: The Architectural League of New York will display the work of the six winners of its Young Architects Forum.

title: The Art of Vanity
description: Dressing tables that do so much more.

title: Daily Struggle for Breath
description: An ambitious project in Harlem aims to mount a full-scale assault on asthma by directly intervening in the lives of asthmatic children.
